Or, when you're waiting for more people to arrive (it's easy to join in a game late, although you probably won't win...you entering will not affect or effect the strategy of those already playing).Played it for the first time today, and it's a game I'll definitely be buying.Bonus for parents with kids at or below teen ages:  Although there is a high degree of luck in this game (due to, well, the sole action of rolling dice), it is, at its heart, a math game.  It's all statistics--will the benefit of doing another roll outweigh the possible risk of "crapping out" for that turn?  Since that calculation will largely depend on which of the various dice you have in your hand before each roll, it's a perfect opportunity to use statistics and probability theory in real-life and fun situations.

As a bigot, it's hard for me to find books that advocate for and advance my position.  Especially books designed for little kids.  Thank God for this book.  Now, I can stimulate the creativity of my little children, while still installing in them important lessons.  Lessons like guns are good, health care is bad (at least if it comes from a Democrat president), and America is always right.  If there are any facts that don't support my positions, I would prefer to ignore them.  And if I can't ignore them, then I'd like to be able to shout them down.  And I want to teach my children the same lessons.  Without books like this one, we are in danger of raising a new generation of open-minded and tolerant adults . . . and it will be impossible to maintain our way of thinking if this happens.I'm looking forward to the next book in this series:  "I am not a witch (but if I were, it would totally be okay to cast a spell and turn President Obama into a newt)."

I had played this game, and had really enjoyed it.  When I opened it up, I saw that there were no rules included.  Luckily, having already played, I didn't need the rules.  But for first-timers, this would obviously be a problem.

Product was exactly as described.  Nothing special; nothing bad.  If this product was available in any local store, I'd buy it there.  But since it's not, and since I had to buy this via the internet, I have no complaints.

This book is divided into sections (breakfast; soups, desserts; main courses, etc), which makes it easy to find recipes, or to just explore.  The only downside to this book--but it's a major one!--is that the recipes themselves yield dishes that are not particularly tasty.  For instance, when I have made recipes from this book and also from the Real Food Daily cookbook, the RFD dishes are MUCH more tasty.  I've had this book for about a month, and I've made about 10 dishes.  So, there may be gems in here that I have just not yet made.  But so far?  Meh.

The Unfortunate Decisions of Dahlia Moss is a delightful book!  I am not sure how I found it, as it isn't the type of book I would typically read, but I am really glad I read it.The protagonist of the story is, of course, Dahlia Moss, an unemployed millennial who been feeling dejected since her boyfriend dumped her for a dental hygienist.  The plot unfolds when Dahlia is hired to find a virtual weapon that was stolen from a player in an online game.  Dahlia then interacts with a series of characters in both the virtual and physical worlds, all of whom are wonderfully eccentric.  The story line twists and turns, and the reader is privy to Dahlia's impressions and thoughts.The Unfortunate Decisions of Dahlia Moss is fun, funny, well-written, and just a delight to read.  Highly recommended.

I wear sunscreen every day, and it seems like I've tried just about every product made.  I've finally settled on using a daytime product for my face, neck and hands and a heavier, sweat resistant product when I work out or will be in strong sunlight.The La Roche-Posay Anthelios 60 product has a lot of positive factors:1.  The consistency is light, almost watery, and it is not dry or thick.2.  It's easy to rub in, and your skin will absorb the sunscreen.3.  The scent is quite lightTo use, the sunscreen, first I applied a serum and moisturizer, and let those sink in. Then, I applied a layer of the La Roche-Posay Anthelios sunscreen to my face and neck, waited a few minutes for that to absorb, and then applied another full layer.  I then did a few other grooming items like brushing my teeth, etc. while the sunscreen finished sinking in.  I don't wear foundation or power, and found that the La Roche-Posay Anthelios could be a tiny bit shiny, but in a nice, glowing way.  The product did not leave any of the dreaded white shadow on my skin.I found that my eyes were really sensitive to the La Roche-Posay Anthelios Sunscreen, so I needed to wash my hands well before applying under eye concealer, and then be very careful to not smudge any into my eyes.  Even the tiniest amount stung, but if I was careful, it was fine.  The other concern was that sometimes I could literally taste the chemicals in the sunscreen -- I guess from breathing it in?  That was a temporary affect, and went away within an hour.All in all, this is a very nice but not perfect sunscreen.  (The perfect sunscreen hasn't been invented yet!) The product absorbs well, is moisturizing, and doesn't leave a white cast, which are three of the biggest negatives in sunscreens.

I'm not a kid, but I do like the various Dummies books for kids as a fast introduction new technologies. Python for Kids is suitable for kids 9 or 10 and up, although they may occasionally need some help.My experience with Python for Kids is that the experience will be smoother on a Windows machine. My MacBook, which has the latest operating system, needed additional software to update the code editor. This turned out to be more trouble than it's worth, so I switched to my Windows 7 device, and everything was fine.The book is structured to be completed over four weeks. However, there are 10 projects, and I found it better to pace myself by project. A few projects are time consuming, so you should read and plan ahead a little.Python for Kids is a great choice for an introduction to Python or to programming. Completing the projects is fun, and the biggest challenge is making sure your code is accurate. I'd recommend this book to anyone who wants to check out Python to decide if they should learn more.

We used these baking cups to make pumpkin spice cup cakes (I am a big fan of anything pumpkin spice!). There are three things we liked about the Reynolds Baking Cups:1. The cups have an attractive, festive design.2.  They didn't stick to the cup cake pan.3.  The baking cup didn't stick to the cupcakes.These baking cups are sturdy and pretty enough to use them for things besides baking. They hold a serving of mixed nuts, and are cute with candy. I am so using the cups to hold paper clips and hair ties.Overall, a nice improvement over flimsy baking cups, and since we don't bake cupcakes nearly often enough, it's kind of cool to use them for other things.

How Software Works is not what I expected, which was a book about user interfaces, databases, applications, the internet, etc. A more accurate title for the book would be "How Some Software Works" or "How Software Does Some Really Cool Things."  The subtitle of the book tells you what the book is really about, which is encryption, computer generated imagery, game graphics, data compression, search, and concurrency.  All of these topics are quite interesting, and the book does a very good job explaining them.  However, I do think you need some understanding of computer science or mathematics to enjoy the book, versus working hard to understand it.I have rated this as four stars, but 3.5 would be better.  As an IT professional, I found the book interesting and found some of the illustrations to be similar to puzzles.  However, if you want to learn how software does work, this is not the book to read.

This Oster Fountain was very easy to set up.  First, we washed it with some mild dish soap and let it air dry to get rid of any lingering plastic odor. Then the pieces just snapped together. The fountain does make a quiet noise, I think it is a little bit like a light rain sound. It's pleasant and not annoying.I have two cats and I hope the fountain will encourage them to drink more. So far, they like to watch the water and they have taken a few drinks. Their favorite activity is to wash their paws in the fountain, which is a lot of fun to watch!

These Fruit of the Loom breathable boy shorts are incredibly light weight, and don't make any lines on your clothes. The breathable part comes from tiny perforations in rather fabric, which does make them a bit fragile. I wore the boy shorts with jeans, shorts, and while working out and had no issues, they did not move or creep. You really aren't aware that you are even wearing them.It's important to get the right size, I believe I should have gone down a size and they would fit better, but even so, I don't have any complaints. I wash these in hot water and then dry, and they have held up well. I don't usually like the boy short style, but these are an exception.

After about two weeks of using this Burt's Bees Renewal Intensive Firming Serum, I've found a number of positive things:1.  The serum has a pleasant but faint scent which rapidly dissipates2.  Although not a moisturizer, the serum helps to keep my skin moist.3.  There is some improvement in the clarity and tone of my skin.4.  The product is easy to use, it's a small bottle with an eye dropper.5.  There was no skin irritation, even on my neck which is sensitive.6.  I like that the product isn't over packaged with fancy pumps and dispensers.I can't really tell if the serum is "firming" my skin, that seems to be asking a lot from a serum! However, it has been beneficial for my skin tone, and I really like the light, soft, not sticky texture.

The Past is a contemplative, slow paced story centered around four siblings vacationing at the family's summer home.  The house is old and falling to pieces, and as no one has the money or inclination to repair the house, the house will likely be sold.  This upcoming change to tradition adds a slight sense of poignancy to the story, but no one really talks about it much.Each sibling brings their hopes and problems with them -- loneliness, a new wife, a preoccupied husband, children,and quasi step children.  The story dances and sways between the different characters, and is filled with beautiful words that form a barrier between the story and the reader.  In the midst of the book, there is a sudden jump back in time to when their mother ran away from her husband and returned home to her parents.  This part of the plot gently trails off.The Past is exceptionally well written, and the writer's love of words is clear.  It is a slow, meandering, ambiguous type of book, and will appeal to readers who enjoy the craft of writing as much as they enjoy the plot.

This is the first Dead Sea Essentials product I've used, although I've seen the brand in upscale drugstores. My hands are mildly dry, and I use lotion 5 or 6 times a day, some times more as I tend to wash my hands often. This Witch Hazel Hannd Cream has a soft, creamy-custardy texture. It's not too liquidy but not dry or tacky, so there is good manageability getting the cream where you want it. There is a light floral fragrance when you first apply the cream, but this fades quickly and then it's almost fragrance free. The cream is a little slick and sticky at first, but it absorbs into your skin in less than a minute. Your hands feel soft, but not slippery. I tend to have dry cuticles, and I don't use much nail polish, and the Dead Sea Essentials Hand Cream did a good job moisturizing my hands and nails. Overall, I quite like this cream, it works well and has a really nice feel.

Scrum for Dummies is a great introduction to the scrum methodology. The book won't make you an expert, but you don't need a deep background in project management methodology or development to understand the concepts.There are 22 chapters in the book, the first six outline the concepts, then four chapters about scrum for industry, followed by five chapters illustrating scrum in different business functions. There are two chapters about scrum in everyday life, which are a little goofy, but may be helpful for people unfamiliar with project management. The book closes with five chapters called "the part of tens," which has 10 steps to transition, 10 pitfalls, etc.Overall, a nice introductory or refresher book with some common sense tips that anyone can adopt.

I used these clips in several locations for a few weeks, including moving them around. I found that they do stick to almost any surface, and they don't lose any of the stickiness if you reuse them in different places. The clips are on a bright colored plastic circle, and are a fun look for an office, desk, or even bathroom.The clips are not large, and will only hold lightweight things. I liked using them near my desk and in the kitchen to hold papers. I also have one inside my bathroom vanity holding some hair ties, and one inside my closet. I was surprised at the different places and uses I found for these, and it appears so far that they will last for some time.

The Lancaster Creme Candy looks like a caramel, which are one of my favorite candies.  However, I usually avoid eating caramels to protect my dental work!  So, I was very interested to try the Lancaster Soft Creme Candy to see if they would fulfill my caramel craving without that dangerous stickiness.These candies are very soft and kind of squishy -- in an odd way, the texture is similar to a regular caramel but without the hard stickiness.  The flavor is light and true, and is not over whelmed with sweetness like some candy.The Lancaster Soft Creme Candy Vanilla and Caramel are a nice choice for fans of caramels and other non-chocolate candy.  I liked these enough that I also bought the Raspberry and Vanilla flavored candies, which are very good.

The Drowned Boy is a simple story of chilling, casual selfishness and cruelty.  Set in Norway, it features Inspector Skarre and the famed Inspector Sejer on a troubling case of a very young boy who drowned in a backyard pond.  The boy, who had Down's Syndrome, was the son of two very young parents -- a couple so young, the wife appears childlike, and they are dependent upon her father for their housing and jobs.An autopsy reveals that the young boy had soapy water in his lungs, so clearly did not drown in the pond.  Inspectors Skarre and Sejer, in a calm and methodical way, battle their own strong feelings about a dead baby and their intuitive view that everything is not quite right with the young couple.  The book begin to alternate with Inspector's Sejer's thoughts about the case, and a diary the young mother writes in daily to capture her feelings.  The reader discovers what happened the day the baby died before the police, and then enjoys a front row seat as the Inspectors have to deal with the young mother's epilepsy, the death of a key person, and Inspector Sejer's concern about his own health.The Drowned Boy is a quiet, simple story that engages the reader with a careful plot design that will have you questioning the thoughts of both the murderer and the police.

I don't think I am very good at artistic or crafty things, so I thought these Avery Kraft Brown Labels would be an easy thing to try.  The first thing you need to do is register for a free account at Avery.com. There is a link to a short how-to video on You Tube that is well worth watching to understand the basics.  You can select a stock design from Avery, modify an Avery design, or create your own.  Once you are satisfied with your design, you can save it online to Avery or to your hard drive.I chose a relatively simple flower design with a pretty script font that I personalized to say Happy Birthday. Be sure to save your design, as you can reuse it on other labels, or, if you are like me, you want to play around with several versions.  The challenging part of using the Avery software is printing, and you'll need to learn how your printer handles labels and/or card stock.  I printed on paper a few times for practice, and I still ruined two labels before I created an acceptable version.  My printer is not very new, so I suspect that a newer printer might do a better job.  Still, you need to be careful to get everything set up exactly perfect.You can create attractive labels for gifts, cookies, place settings, etc. with Avery labels and the online software.  You do need patience to get a professional looking outcome, so if I was creating labels for an important event, I would consider the option of having Avery print for me.

I am always searching for the perfect set of in-ear headphones, so I jumped at the chance to try these new Philips headphones.  For whatever reason, in-ear headphones just will not stay in my ears, I think it is because I have small ears and perhaps my ears have an off shape.  I've tried many different types and sizes -- small, large, foam, hard case, rubber tipped, and none of them work.The difference with the Philips in-ear headphones is that the tiny speaker is oval shaped, not round.  The headphones come with three different sized soft caps, I chose to use the smallest size.  To insert them in my ears, I actually stretch the opposite hand over my head, and that seems to get a good angle.  These headphones will stay in my ears through light activity -- so watching a TV show or listening to a podcast at my desk. They would not stay in for me while running, but if you normally don't have issues in-ear devices, they may be OK for you to use in more vigorous activities.I am not a sound expert at all, but for the average user, the sound is good.  There is not a lot of background noise, no funny noises when you move, and I found voices and music to be clear and true.  This still is not the perfect in-ear headphone, but it is very good and well worth the price.

I have a two year old cat who is always hungry! He's a big cat, both long and tall, and although he's not overweight, he would be if we let him eat what he wants. My other cat is a petite girl, and she is much less interested in food than her brother.  So, my boy cat eats every meal right on time, while the girl will wander down when she feels like it. This led to a lot of kitty anxiety, as my poor boy would be distraught that his sister was eating her lunch when his was long gone.The Wellness Natural cat treats have been a perfect solution. While my little girl cat daintily nibbles, I feed my big guy these treats.  He loves them, and has some fun with how crunchy they are. So, at the expense of a few extra calories, I can give him something healthy and keep him away from his sister's food.

The Murderer's Daughter introduces a Grace Blades, a flawed character that is equal parts empathy and vengeance.  Grace's parents were poor, neglectful addicts, leaving Grace to raise herself.  When her parents die (yes, Grace is truly a murderer's daughter), a social worker sees something special in Grace and goes out of his way to find a supportive foster home.  Grace flourishes in this home, where it is discovered that Grace has a very high IQ and is remarkably brilliant.  Eventually, Grace is adopted by a couple who understand her introverted nature and support the development of her intellect.As an adult, Grace becomes a psychologist who treats patients dealing with horrific life events and grief.  Grace has become very wealthy, and lives life on her own terms, which includes finding men in bars for casual sex.  One encounter turns out to be completely different than what Grace was looking for, and she is drawn into a game of psychological cat and mouse, with strands to tragic events in her childhood.  Grace's internal moral compass is somewhat outside the ordinary, and she takes justice into her own hands.As with all books by Jonathan Kellerman, The Murderer's Daughter is well written and engaging from beginning to end.  As a heroine, Grace reminds me of Kathleen Mallory, and anyone who enjoys the Mallory series will like The Murderer's Daughter.  I am eagerly waiting for the next installment in Grace's story!

I'm an adult, not a baby, but I really like this Burt's Bees Balm. I carry the balm in my purse and use it when I get dry patches of skin on my face, on healing cuts, and have even used it on my lips (first putting it on my fingertip).  My favorite use is on my nails and cuticles, the balm really works to keep them moist. As advertised, the balm is fragrance free, soft, and smooth to apply. It's a great item to carry around for children and adults.

I really like the ECOeverywhere notebooks, I've bought two or three a year for the past few years.  The size is perfect to slip into my iPad case (my case is an American Airlines amenity kit case) so I can easily carry it to meetings.  The paper is smooth, and all types of pens flow nicely over it.  There is a small green leaf on every page to remind you of the "eco" theme.These are great notebooks for business people, students, and writers, and I highly recommend them.

This greeting card is lovely, and perfect for special occasions. The card is made from a heavy, creamy yellow paper that is rich in appearance. The embroidery on the front is really unique, it's not overdone but it isn't too simple. It's clear that the embroidery is flowers, and they are generic enough to be suitable for just about anything except the most somber occasions. As stated in the description, it's a black card so you can write your own message. I would definitely recommend this card for any time you want to send a special or formal message.

I Regret Nothing is a light, fun, and enjoyable book.  For everyone who has read Jen Lancaster, you know a bit of what to expect--humor, honesty, sarcasm, and a healthy degree of self awareness. What I really enjoyed most about the book was the focus on "what comes next?"  Jen, like many of us, has lived through her thirties, experienced some difficult times, and has enjoyed some success. So, she has done a lot of things, but not everything, so how do you choose what to do now? Like all of Ms. Lancaster's stories, what ensues is funny, not nape cessation deep, but always relatable. The only part of the book I did not enjoy was the scorn for other Americans vacationing in Rome. I'm sure there were plenty of polite Americans there as well, and it seems a bit mean to pick on this stereotype. (By the way, I travel globally, and people everywhere wear white sneakers, or now, neon colored ones--it's not just an American thing.)Overall, a fun summer read, and a book I enjoyed from an author I faithfully read.

There are a lot of positives about this Contigo Glacier Water Bottle. The most important feature is that it keeps your drink cold for hours, really for just about all day.  The bottle itself is sleek and shiny, and it fits in my car's cup holder. It has a wide mouth opening, which I greatly prefer to bottles with permanent straws. Part of the cap folds up to become a small, ring shaped handle.The only negative for me is that I have small hands, and I found the bottle a bit unwieldy and heavy to drink from. However, it works great to make 20 ounce of ice tea or ice coffee for work that I pour into smaller cups during.

Kitchens of the Great Midwest uses two plot techniques to tell the story of Eva Thorvald, a woman with an exquisite palate.  The first technique is the story of Eva's life is told via the narrative of other people in her life--her father, her cousin, a boyfriend, a rival, her mother, etc.  The second technique through colorful, rich, loving descriptions of food.The story takes us from Eva as a small infant to a successful chef / business woman, running a series of exclusive and expensive popup dinners.  Eva's path is not always a smooth one, but throughout, her passion for food only increases.  She is a difficult woman to know, and as she becomes successful, Eva tends to hide herself away, surrounded by friends who defend her privacy.Kitchens of the Great Midwest is a wonderful choice for anyone who loves cooking, or food, or has an adventurous palate and likes to try new things.  Each chapter tells Eva's story from a different perspective, and I found these connections were too loose, and I had to go back into the story to try to figure out who some of the narrators were, and what their connection was with Eva.  For me, this unevenness took away from the plot and the story, and made it a bit difficult to really connect with Eva.

The Nia 24 Rapid Depigmentation Serum has a very light texture, and is quickly absorbed by your skin. Just two pumps will cover your face and at least part of your neck, and then you need to follow the serum with a moisturizer and sunscreen (during the day). This was fine, the serum is so light that I could comfortably wear all three products.My face is prone to breakouts, and unfortunately, the Nia Serum did make me start breaking out.  However, I started using the serum on the back of my hands, which have more dark pigmentation spots than my face.  After about 10 days, these spots did begin to fade--again, using the serum plus a sunscreen.  I'm going to continue to use the serum on my hands, and if the improvement continues, purchase the serum.  Although the serum is not inexpensive, people see your hands all the time so it would be great if the serum improves their appearance.

I've been using the Colgate Enamel Health Whitening Toothpaste for a few weeks, but I doubt that is long enough to experience all the benefits. I wish the package stated "within X weeks" or something similar!I use the Colgate Enamel Health Whitening Toothpaste with a Sonicare toothbrush once or twice a day. Simultaneously, I'm using Sensodyne as I usually brush my teeth three times a day. This Colgate paste has a mild mint taste, it's not overwhelming when you brush and the taste fades pretty quickly. I didn't find it very effective after eating onions, but otherwise, it was fine. My teeth did feel smoother after brushing, there wasn't any of that grainy feeling you get with many toothpastes.As I said, it's too soon to tell if this paste strengthens my enamel, but all indications are that it will have some impact. I have sensitive teeth, and some pain after an accident and some dental work, and the Colgate Enamel Whitening Paste did not cause any problems for me, so I'm going to continue to use it and see if there are some long term benefits.

The Woman Who Stole My Life tells the story of Stella Sweeney through a series of events at different points of her life.  There is the Stella who is married, with two children, and relatively content in her life.  There is also a Stella who is in Ireland, unhappy and evidently poor, worrying about her son and her ex-husband.  There is a very ill Stella, hospitalized for months with paralysis from Guillain-Barre syndrome.  Finally, there are glimpses of a different version of Stella, living in New York City and on a book tour across the US.The story brings us back and forth in Stella's life, using these different phases to explain how she ended up where she is, although it is not clear exactly where that is.  Along the way, Stella meets new people and finds friendship and love in unexpected places.  The Woman Who Stole My Life is primarily a love story--Stella's love for herself, her family, her friends, and a new romantic interest.Marian Keyes is one of my favorite authors, and I never miss one of her books.  The Woman Who Stole My Life is a good book, but it is slightly too long, and I did become a bit impatient a few times, wishing that it would pick up the pace to the point.  Overall, I would recommend the book to fans of Marian Keyes (and similar authors), and think the book will make a good summertime read.

The skyn Iceland Hydro Cool Firming Face Gels have a lot of benefits, but you need to have realistic expectations, they are not going to cure your fine line and wrinkles.The package contains four pre-soaked masks for your forehead and four pairs for the outer corners of your mouth. You remove the backing from the mask pieces, and gently but firmly press them on to your face. The masks cling nicely, I was able to do other things and didn't need to stay still. The moisturizer has a pleasant, fool but not tingly feel and almost no scent. After 10 minutes, you remove the mask-- I rubbed the moisturizer in a bit, and the rinse. Those areas of your face will be moisturizer and a little bit brighter or more luminous. Any reduction in fine lines is a result of your face being more moist.Overall, I found the skyn Iceland Hydro Cool Gel masks a nice experience, and one that'd be even nicer on a hot day. I'm going to look for a full size version of the mask for my entire face.

Eeny Meeny is a dark, chilling, thriller with a fresh view and remarkable twist on an active and sometimes overworked genre.  Detective Inspector Helen Grace is fully committed to her career in the police force, working long hours, keeping herself fit, and avoiding the pitfalls of drinking or over familiarity.  DI Grace has been quickly promoted through the ranks, and is admired by many of the other female police officers, although they note that DI Grace doesn't have much of a life outside of work. Driven to excel, DI Grace has a troubled past and secrets, but she keeps to herself and no one guesses at her inner turmoil.DI Grace and her team are assigned to the case of particularly brutal and cruel serial killer, whose method of operation is to hold two people captive without food or water, but with a gun containing one bullet.  One of the two people must die, and the other can go free.  The ultimate betrayal is, of course, that no one really goes free, as the life of those who live is ruined.  This theme of betrayal runs throughout the book, as DI Grace identifies that someone on the police force is leaking details of the case, betraying the team.  In turn, she betrays her officers, accusing several of them of being the leak until she finally identifies the real culprit.  As the serial killer continues to murder victims and taunt the police, DI Grace finally finds what links the murders together in a horrifying discovery that threatens her career, her sanity, and her life.Eeny Meeny is a dark story, one where the reader sympathizes with a flawed leading character who is hiding many facets of herself.  The plot line of the serial killer is slick and frightening as it wends it way to a bloody conclusion, and the additional plot line of the police leaking information is smoothly linked back to the case.  The plot will capture your attention from start to finish, and I am looking forward to the US publication of the second book in this series.

A Murder of Magpies is a smart, funny, modern mystery story.  The primary character is Samantha â€œSamâ€ Clair, a mature woman who has met with some success a book editor in London.  Sam is relatively happy in her lifeâ€”she enjoys her career, is adept at office politics and managing her authors, she lives in a lovely apartment, and has a close relationship with her mother.When one of Samâ€™s favorite authors, and friend, writes an a tell all book that exposes money laundering, Sam faces the challenge of publishing the book while still ensuring her firm is not exposed to any legal risks.  When the author suddenly disappears, Sam realizes the risks are greater than she thoughtâ€”potentially life threatening.A Murder of Magpies unfolds with a series of characters, intrigues, clandestine meetings, and double crosses.  The money-laundering story line is a bit different, and very interesting.  One of my favorite characters is Samâ€™s mother, a razor sharp successful attorney who is willing to stretch some legal boundaries to help Sam.  Sam also discovers romance during the story, which is written in a realistic and tasteful way.Overall, a Murder of Magpies has a lot to offer.  The heroine is smart, pragmatic, romantic, and kind.  The scenarios she encounters are realistic, and the crimes are complex enough to require some thought by the reader.  Samâ€™s co-workers and friends are great additions to the story line, as is Samâ€™s mother.  I enjoyed that the strong plot with very minimal use of obscenities and violence.  Hopefully, this book is the first in a series.

Jane Green tends to write books that seem to be about women you know, or would like to meet.  In Summer Secrets, the woman is Cat, a recovering alcoholic who, after many relapses, is attempting to fix all the broken pieces of her life.From her very first drink, alcohol was Cat's friend.  A drink, or five, helped her achieve that elusive sense of belonging she desired.  Eventually, the norm became five or more drinks, with blackouts and severe hangovers a common occurrence. Tired of being hungover and embarrassed, and pressured by her friends, Cat attempts to quit drinking--time after time.  She even starts a relationship with another alcoholic in recovery, but her stealth drinking is just another example of her inability to stop.When Cat discovers shattering news about her parents, so many things become clear to her, and she begins to understand her troubled relationship with her father. Given a chance to connect with a family she had not known she had, Cat does what she always does--ruins it with bad behavior during a drunken binge.Fast forward a few years, and Cat is finally sober, divorced, and a single mother.  She begins trying to make amends, but discovers it is not always quite so easy, and that hurt and bruised feelings can last for many years.  Of course, many things do work out for Cat, and she begins to see hope in fixing some, if not all, of the relationships she treasures the most.The story of Summer Secrets is told from the perspective of Cat, the recovering alcoholic, making the book one-sided and a bit difficult to connect with in some places.  Much of Cat's behavior when drinking was omitted or glossed over in an attempt to get the reader to champion Cat's attempt to make amends.  For me, it did the opposite, as it didn't seem Cat realized, or truly regretted, the hurt and harm she had inflicted on those around her.  Summer Secrets is an OK, enjoyable read, but a few too many steps away from the reality of what having someone with alcoholism in your life to meet its potential.

Although I'm aware that Debbie Macomber is a best selling author, I've never read one of her books until now. I did not know what to expect, and the best way I would describe the book is that it is a romance novel with substance.First, there is a plucky heroine, Cassie, who has paid dearly for her youthful mistakes and is now a financially struggling single mother.  Cassie meets a potential love interest, Steve, at Habitat for Humanity.  Steve is, of course, a nice guy with a good job, but suffering still from the deth of his wife. Cassie and Steve start off by getting on each others nerves, but we all know they are denying the attraction they feel. To add more tension to the story, Cassie is contacted by one of her two estranged sisters, and the three women slowly renew their bonds.Last One Home is a nice story--it's sweet, there are happy endings, and it is well written. This is a lovely book to escape with, it will gold your attention in a gentle, winning way.

I like to read memoirs, and my favorite sub-genres include medicine, psychiatry, and hospitals. The Real Doctor Will See You Shortly is a fine addition to the many books written about physicians starting their careers.Dr. McCarthy brings a fresh perspective, firstly because he is both very smart and very personable.  I usually assume most doctors are smart, but not all doctors are humble or possess empathy. Dr. McCarthy is very open about his challenges in learning to relate to all types of patients, and how hard he had to work to keep his mind centered on the present. It was a delight to read as he developed both his technical and interpersonal skills, and I felt that I was learning new things about how some doctors think.As many of us know, medical residencies are brutal, with long hours, challenging work, learning, and the stress from fearing mistakes. Dr. McCarthy portrays his residency with grace, highlighting how it formed him as a doctor, but not shying away from his fears and insecurities. When Dr. McCarthy must deal with a potentially life threatening disease, his words express express his anxiety and hope, paralleled with how this helped him relate to his patients but without any condescension or assumptions.I enjoyed The Real Doctor Will See You Now, it is both a great memoir and insight into the brain and heart of a physician. I hope the Dr. McCarthy has one or more follow up books as his career progresses.

I drink two or three large cups of coffee everyday, and I almost always use a flavored creamer or get a flavored latte at Starbucks.  However, I don't always feel like drinking hot coffee in the summer, and I lack the motivation to make iced coffee at home.  More importantly, I go to the gym for a 6:00 am working most days, and at the end of my session, I am hot, thirsty, and really wanting coffee!So, I tried the Skinny Cow Creamy Iced Coffee Drink by bringing them to the gym.  These aren't something I would drink while working out, but they were perfect for immediately after.  The size is perfect--small enough to take with you, but large enough to quench your initial first.  To me, the chocolate taste was stronger than the coffee, but that might be a personal preference.  The drinks are a bit sweet, so if I was at home, I'd probably use ice to dilute them a bit.  All in all -- I like the taste, the 120 calories, the natural ingredients, and the convenience, so a win.

I have used a Clarisonic Mia brush for more than two years, and although I like it, I've read that the Clarisonic brush can be too harsh.  So, I was interested to try the Philips PureRadiance brush.  First, the differences:1.  The Philips PureRadiance brush has two speeds, one is gentle and the other is a more intense option.  This is a good feature, as in the winter when my skin is dry, a gentler speed is better for my skin.2.  The Philips PureRadiance brush has rotating bristles plus an pulsing feeling.  The brush head is smaller than Clarisonic, so it is easy to use in small areas such as between your nose and mouth.3.  Similar to the Philips toothbrush, the PureRadiance brush has three timed sessions of 20 seconds each for three zones of your face.  This is beneficial if you have a tendency to over scrub or irritate your skin.4.  The PureRadiance brush is smaller and lighter than the Clarisonic.The PureRadiance is a different experience from the Clarisonic.  It's not bad, just different.  If this is your first facial brush, I think you will like the PureRadiance quite a bit.  If you currently use a different brush, you'll need to compare features.  If a gentle, light, easy to use brush is what you want, the Philips PureRadiance is a nice choice.

I was unable to chew gum for about six months (due to an accident that injured my face and jaw), so I was happy to have the opportunity to try this Juicy Fruit Starburst Strawberry gum.  What I like about the gum:1.  The taste is strawberry or strawberry and cream, pleasant without being too sweet.2.  The flavor lasts for an acceptable amount of time.  (No gum has flavor that last long enough!)3.  When the flavor starts to fade, the gum is still a pleasant, mild version of the initial taste with no off flavors4.  The texture of the gum is the right mix of soft and elastic, and the gum didn't get tough or an odd texture over timeMy husband and I both enjoy the gum, which is remarkable as we usually have different tastes.  I am a big fan of non-chocolate candy, but with my jaw injury, I don't know if I'll ever be able to eat Starburst candy again, so finding the gum was fun for me.  The only disappointment?  I wish Juicy Fruit Starburst was available in lemon or lime!

Sam Dryden was living a quiet life, working on remodeling houses to sell and slowly easing into a social life when he receives a call from Claire Dunham, an old friend.  Claire is one of the few people Sam trusts implicitly, and her message is brief and clear--Sam needs to leave his house immediately, and come meet her.This single phone call draws Sam into a tense and bizarre situation where the "bad guys" always seem to be one step ahead, and Sam is forced to believe the unbelievable. It is difficult to review this book without any spoilers!  It is full of action, suspense, chasing, hiding, smart solutions, and a bit of science fiction.  I don't usually care for the type of bizarre science fiction this story contains, but it is well written, and handled in a scientific way instead of just being a plot technique to allow the writer to do crazy things.Overall, if you enjoy suspense, mysteries, lots of actions, and a bit of a thinking story, you'll want to read Signal.

Dangerous When Wet is an entertaining memoir which, despite being very revealing, still skitters lightly over some emotional minefields.  The positives about this book is Mr. Brickhouse is a very good writer, and his sheer enjoyment of his life in New York is a pleasure to read.  The reader doesn't need to agree with Mr. Brickhouse's lifestyle to appreciate how he throws himself into love, casual sex, work, and alcohol.Parts of Dangerous When Wet focus on Mr. Brickhouse's relationship with his mother, a strong woman who included her young deeply into all parts of her life.  Young Jamie loved his mother, and wanting never to disappoint her, struggled with revealing his homosexuality.  In adulthood, as his addictions spun his life out of control, his relationship with his mother shifted but never achieves complete honesty.The cover blurb saying Dangerous When Wet is "blistering funny" does the book a disservice.  This memoir is not funny, but is amusing and touching as the author shares his, and his family's, frailties.

My husband and I have pasta for dinner once or twice every week. We've tried many different brands and varieties, especially looking for versions that would be more nutritious than regular pasta. Some of the pastas we tried were not very good; usually gluey or too chewy. We prepared this Barilla Veggie pasta with our home made red sauce, and it tasted like regular pasta.  Nice consistency, no odd tastes or texture. So, we would definitely buy this, and plan to try using it in other recipes.

I have been diligently using this SK-II Essential Power Eye Cream twice a day for a few weeks.  The positives:1.  It's has a light, creamy texture2.  There is almost no scent3.  It does not sting your eyes or make them tear4.  It absorbs quickly and does not clump up or make your make run5.  It does moisturizeThe downsides:1.  I didn't find it moisturizing enough, albeit it is winter, and had to supplement with another cream in the corner of my eyes2.  Did not noticeably change the small, shallow lines around my eyes3.  Has quite a high cost for what it deliversOverall, this is a nice eye cream with a lot to offer, but it does not deliver on the more optimistic product claims.

The Art of Baking Blind is a warm and gentle novel, one that will leave readers with a happy glow. The story centers around a baking contest sponsored by a grocery chain, with five amateur bakers competing. The competition is nothing like the brawls of reality television, but rather a genteel match between very different people.One of the most important characters in the story, Mrs Katleen Eaden, participates in the story only from excerpts from her famous 1966 cookbook, The Art of Baking. Mrs Eaden, who has recently died, was married to a supermarket magnate, and the baking contest is to find the "next" Mrs. Eaden.  The contest will be judged, and there will be You Tube videos of the winners of each round.The baking contest brings together five very different people, who find themselves baking in Mrs. Eaden's country home. There is a middle-aged housewife dealing with an empty nest, a perfectly turned-out and poised wife terrorized by her past, a naive single young mother determined to build a future for her daughter, a widower with two children just beginning to come back to life, and a young mother who has abandoned her career to focus on raising her son. Although these contestants have little in common, they begin to bond over their love of baking and desire to accomplish something.Of course, the baking and baking contests are metaphors for love--love for your children, spouses, parents, but also self love. The Art of Baking Blind is great choice for readers interested in a warm and uplifting book. You don't need to know how to bake to be enthralled by the thought and effort the contestants put into making their beautiful creations.

This is a pretty soap dish.  I like the rounded edges, the color is nice, and the design will ensure your soap doesn't turn into a drippy mess.  However, both my husband and I had difficulties getting this to soap dish to stick, and once attached to the wall, stay there!  We tried multiple surfaces in the kitchen and bathroom, and we followed the directions carefully, but couldn't successfully keep the suction working.  It was a disappointment, as I found the dish attractive and a good match for the hardware in one of the bathrooms.

Monday's Lie is an exceptional book written entirely from the viewpoint of one character, Dee Aldrich.  Dee is the epitome of normal--she's married to her college sweetheart, they both of enjoyable jobs, live in a nice house, and are considering starting a family.  Close to her mother and brother, Dee is happy to have her terminally ill mother spend her final days in Dee's home.Then, small cracks appear in Dee's marriage, starting with their difficulties in starting a family are because Dee is taking birth control pills.  Dee's ambivalence about having a baby is partly explained by Dee's own child hood, when her mother was a secret agent who disappeared for work reason's, one time for months.Dee's suspicions of her husband lead her to investigate him, and then to dig more deeply into her mother's past, longing for a deeper understanding.  Monday's Lie has the reader inside Dee's head every step of the way, as the story unfolds in surprising ways.I enjoyed Monday's Lie because we get to know and understand Dee's flaws and her braveness.  The plot moves at its own pace, sometimes almost real time, and then flying through incredible situations.  This is a must read for anyone that enjoys books with strong female protagonists, darker plots, and brutal surprises.Disclosure: I received a free copy of this book from NetGalley, the opinions in this review are my own.

Almost Dead is the fifth book in the series featuring Lizzie Gardner, a private investigator.  This series tends to be a bit gritty and dark, and Almost Dead continues in that vein.  Lizzie is depressed and reeling from a violent gun attack at her wedding, which has left her fiancÃ© on life support.  Unable to process everything happening in her life, Lizzie returns to work but is living with two of her co-workers / friends to avoid going home.Almost Dead has multiple plot lines.  Lizzie is engaged to find who is targeting the members of an elite, bullying high school club--years after graduation.  This case sets Lizzie up with a worthy protagonist, drawing a parallel to Lizzie's own desire to lash out at anyone who has hurt her.  At the same time, Lizzie feels watched or stalked, but can't imagine who would be motivated to do so.The case, Lizzie's personal concerns with her fiancÃ©e and a potential stalker, her living arrangements, and concerns about her co-workers all add up to a book that almost collapses under the weight of all the plot lines.  Although the ending brings everything together, and sets the stage for what Lizzie chooses to do next, I think this could have still been done with a somewhat simpler plot.As typical with this series, the book ends with a slight cliff hanger, and I think how T.R. Rogan approaches the next phase of Lizzie's life will make a tremendous difference to how the remainder of the series unfolds.Disclosure: I received a free copy of this book from Netgalley for a review.

She Has Your Eyes is a pleasant, enjoyable book that leaves the reader with a warm feeling.  For me, the book is primarily about families and love, and that these both exist in various forms.Firstly, this is the story of a marriage. Andi and David are together, happily ensconced in her house, married in every way except the actual marriage.  Why?  Well, part of the reason is Andi's first husband died very young, and she has some residual reserve about marrying again.  Andi's adult life is also colored by a cool, remote relationship with her mother.  However, Andi and David are clearly a close and loving couple, and the reader can't help but to think things will work out for them.Then, of course, life happens.  David is surprised to find he's the biological father of a teen-aged daughter, one who seeks him out and simply appears at his home.  His daughter comes encumbered with teen-aged angst, a happy family reeling from her desire to find her father, and an apparently jealous biological mother.  While trying to figure out what this daughter means, Andi is emotionally tempted by an ex-boyfriend, one of "the ones who got away."  In the midst of this, Andi's mother suddenly has a need for Andi's time and attention, and Andi is grappling with all types of different feelings.I've said She Has Your Eyes is a bit of a love story because we see Andi and David's love face challenges, we read of how they develop a love for a girl they didn't even know existed, and how their definition of family grew to include David's daughter and the new relationship between Andi and her Mom.  The plot line with the ex-boyfriend was a little slow, but well used to show Andi's confidence become more stable and help Andi face the new challenges in her life.

Memoirs are one of my favorite genres, and I read a fair number of them.  Gone in a Heartbeat was a surprise for me, as it is a rather unique memoir.  By his own admission, Dr. Neil Spector had an easy early life, continuing through college and medical school.  He loved treating patients, but also was energized by doing research that could lead to cures or at least the relief of symptoms.  Challenges entered his life when he and his wife lose two unborn children and Dr. Spector's experienced serious and mysterious health issues.The book blurb focuses on how Dr. Spector felt dismissed and discounted by the medical teams treating him, and that it wasn't until Dr. Spector was able to self diagnose that he received the treatment he needed.  This was interesting, and unfortunately, the rest of us without medical degrees don't have this ability.  I think that anyone who has struggled with balancing what doctors are telling you versus your body will be able to relate, and find some odd comfort that even doctors experience this from their peers!However, I think the blurb leaves out some of the best parts of the book.  Dr. Spector is also a poet, and includes some of his poems in the book. I am no judge of poetry, but I enjoyed this aspect as it showed another side of this smart, driven, but very ill man.Dr. Spector receives a heart transplant (this is not a spoiler, it is in the early pages of the book), and I found his writing about this experience to be exceptional.  He is able to bring together his medical knowledge, his own terror and frustration with his health, and empathy for the person whose organ donation allowed Dr. Spector to live.I would recommend Gone in a Heartbeat to anyone who likes memoirs, medical books, or who is open to a somewhat different reading experience.Disclosure:  I received a free copy of this book from Netgalley, and the opinion is the review is my own.

I wore this lipstick off and on for about two weeks, to give it a fair trial.  The best I can describe it is that it is a light lipstick.  It's not shinny or sticky like a gloss, it is not sheer, but the coverage is lighter than a regular lipstick.  I found that is lasts for just an hour or two, but that might also because I didn't use lip primer or anything underneath the lipstick.Unlike many other lipsticks, this has a pleasant smell and taste.  I'm not quite sure if it tastes similar to anything in particular, but it is quite inoffensive.  I like the color of the case a lot, it is a pearly, pink-purple that stands out in your cosmetic case.I received petal pink to try, which I don't think worked with my dark hair and eyes.  I think the color would be lovely on a blue eyed blond with pale skin though, and also appropriate for a young teen.

Apple Clusters are round, crunchy clusters, slightly sweet with a tiny taste of citric. These are a snack, and not a substitute for an apple!  I am fond of sweets, and sometimes a small, crunchy snack is just the right thing to satisfy a craving. The peeled Snacks Apple Clusters are a good choice for an after dinner "something."  They are sweet enough to feel satisfied, but not something I am going to over indulge in and eat the entire bag. These are a nice choice for some mindful snacking.

Run Holly Run is a wild book, mixing family, friends, community, ghosts, paranormal activities, and accolades to some previous classics.  The book is wild in the sense that there is always something happening, and Holly is always on the move.The story starts with Holly and her parents temporarily moving into a house touched by tragedy where there are mysterious happenings, and something isn't quite right.  Holly is fortunate that one of her friends from school lives nearby, and together they discover that many of the townspeople are behaving strangely, and others are missing.  Even some of the animals are acting out!The reader has glimpses of what is going on, and so remain slightly ahead of Holly.  The book goes on to mix in ghosts, spaceships, evil people, crop circles and types of crazy things, including sly references to Alice in Wonderland, 1984, and perhaps Close Encounters!Run Holly Run is fine for older children, there are a number of characters to keep straight and some of situations may be to scary or confusing.  However, this also makes the book more interesting to older teens.Overall, a fun book with some new experiences.  Some of the dialogue is a bit stilted, and overall, the book may have been improved by one less subplot, but an enjoyable read nonetheless.Disclosure:  I received a free copy of this book to review; the opinions in this review are my own.

Someone to Watch Over Me is a wonderful thriller that will keep the reader engaged from beginning to end.  The characters, the setting, the plot, and even the weather all come together in a suspenseful, well-written story with neatly handled sharp plot turns.The setting for Someone to Watch Over Me is Iceland, shortly after the financial crash.  People are stunned at the sudden financial changes, jobs are scarce, prices are rising, and there doesn't seem to be any relief in sight.  Being Iceland, it's also cold, snowy, and icy.  In this tense atmosphere, Thora Gudmundsdottir, an attorney, is hired by a convicted criminal to try to prove the innocence of another young man who has been convicted of setting a fire in a group medical home that killed several people.  This young man also has Down's syndrome, thrusting Thora into the world of care and rehabilitation for young people with mental or physical disabilities, including those who are also convicted of crimes.As Thora proceeds with the case, she finds a variety of half-truths, cover-ups, and lies.  Interspersed throughout the book are chapters about a young wife, recovering from a tragedy, who believes her home and her garden are haunted. This part of the plot is presented in an eery way, and it's difficult to see how the story will all fit together, but it finally does.Thora progresses with her research, taunted by provocative texts and hostile witnesses.  At home, her parents are in financial ruins and have temporarily moved into her garage, and Thora's boyfriend is struggling to find. work.  Ms. Siguradottir has been able to find exactly the right mix of work on the case, Thora's office, her personal life, and the environment in Iceland to create balance and atmosphere.I've enjoyed the other Thora Gudemundsdottir novels, but found Someone to Watch Over Me to the best yet, and I highly recommend it.

There are no single right (or wrong) way for companies to innovate, the only answer to the question "What is the best way for a company to innovate?" is, it depends!  Sometimes, organizations are innovating with a view to the far future, which we see for example in pharmaceuticals, chips, and cellular research.  Other times, companies are looking for good innovations that they can execute now.  The Innovator's Hypothesis is for these times, when you are looking to quickly assess, implement, or move on.The fundamental theory of the book is called the 5X5 X-team approach--give a diverse team of 5 people no more than 5 days to come up with 5 business experiments that cost $5000 or less each and can be done in 5 weeks.  The approach is fast, inexpensive, and low risk.  Assuming a company tried all 5 experiments, their cost would be $5000 and people's time.  Equally important, the 5X5 approach avoids the big, strategic ideas that cost a lot of time and money, and by the time they fail, no one remembers whose idea it was.  OK, that may be an exaggeration, but an innovation that requires 5 years will grow and change, while in 5 weeks you are likely to stay on course.I like the 5X5 approach for several reasons--I believe it will appeal to many people who are eager to make an impact, allowing for 5 ideas per team gives enough space for risk taking, and it avoids the huge, strategic, bet-the-company ideas that never get done.  There is risk to the approach in that not all members of management will be comfortable with fast experiments, and organizations trying out the 5X5 approach need to ensure the experiments, at least initially, are supported by receptive parts of the organization.The Innovator's Hypothesis is a must read for anyone involved in innovation, if only because you can never have too many good ideas about how to innovate.  This low risk, low cost model can be tried by any size company so at minimum can be viewed as nothing to lose, but strategically, can help to break the pattern of big, expensive, strategic, warm and fluffy ideas.

I received these as a gift (so it doesn't show as an Amazon verified purchase) and am very happy with them!  My wrapping skills aren't very good, but I've been trying to improve the attractiveness of the gifts I wrap.  I recently decided part of the problem was I don't have the right tools!  These scissors make it much easier to cut wrapping paper in a straight line, and to cleanly trim off some of the excess bits of paper.  It is a small thing, but well worth the relatively low cost to make wrapping easier to do and easier to make attractive.

The Cap Hangup Organizer is a simple, ingenious device!  My husband and I each have several baseball type caps--I always wear one when I run, and he has both cold and warm weather versions.  Usually, we store our caps in various places around the house.  Some are on a hook in my closet, and I'm embarrassed to admit I hang the cap I wear most often on my bathroom door.  My husband keeps some in the front closet, one or two in the garage, and one or two in the vanity in the guest bathroom.  I never really thought much about organizing the caps, and just accepted the one on my door knob as the price for ensuring I did not forget to wear it.The Master Craft Camo Cap Hangup Organizer is brilliant in its simplicity.  It's a stiff fabric back, with a series of hooks made from velcro, with a metal hook on the top.  I was able to put all of the caps we wear most often on the organizer in just a few minutes, and then hung the entire thing on a hook in the coat closet.  It works perfectly--the velcro hooks are easy to use, the organizer doesn't take up much room, and our caps are hung up near our coats, which will hopefully remind us to wear them.

She's Leaving Home is a British police procedural set in London in the 1960s.  The Beatles are hugely popular, unrest about the Vietnam war is increasing. young people are rejecting the perceived constraints and hypocrisy of their parents, and everyone seems to be rushing towards change.  "Paddy" Breen is a policeman, struggling with the impact of the recent death of his father, an out of touch boss, and Paddy's overwhelming unpopularity amongst his colleagues.The primary plot is the murder of a young girl, her body found abandoned on a trash heap.  Paddy is partnered with a woman trainee, which in the early 1960s, is shocking--she's not allowed to drive the police car, is assumed to have loose morals, and in general, is viewed as competent to make tea, and not much else.  Searching for the girl's killer leads Breen and Tozer (his female partner) into the world of bankrupt rich people, art dealers, and the civil war in Biafra.As the case to find the girl's killer evolves, the reader is immersed in corrupt and incompetent police work, racial slurs and prejudice, and the scorn for women that existed in the early 1960s.  Paddy learns more about himself, and his parents, and eventually finds comfort in becoming more open to some of the positives these new times offers.She's Leaving Home is a first rate police procedural, filled with a complex plot, colorful background, interesting sub-themes, and multidimensional characters.  I would highly recommend this book to anyone interested in police procedurals, British crime, or fiction set in the 1960s, and I'm looking forward to the next book in the series which is to be released in early 2015.

Lane Changes is the first in a (potential) series written by a new author, S.L. Ellis.  The book is an engaging story, with a promising set up that will give the author plenty of characters and situations to write about in future installments.  The main protagonist is Cassie Cruise, a former private investigator in her forties who has moved to a Florida neighborhood where most of the inhabitants are senior citizens.  Her best friend in the neighborhood, Janice, is a senior citizen who has recently sold Cassie a tattoo shop due to a mysterious illness Janice has refused to name.  So, a neighborhood full of retired people plus a tattoo shop offers a wide variety of characters and scenarios.In Lane Changes, a young woman named Lane has also moved into the neighborhood, and this is where the trouble starts.  Lane hires Cassie to find Lane's birth father, which draws Cassie deeply into a wider story of betrayals, abuse, and family conflicts.  Cassie's near inability to control her nosiness and need to "not let people get away with things" keeps her involved in the case even after everyone involved and her friends try to divert her.The strong parts of Lane Changes are that there is an opinionated heroine who isn't perfect but is aware of her flaws.  The surrounding characters, particularly her friend Janice and other people in the tattoo shop add variety and interesting sub-plots.  Cassie's romantic life is turbulent enough to also play a strong supporting role in the story.  However, the story is also overly complex, with too many stories thrown in, and as a consequence, becomes confusing and a bit contrived.Lane Changes is a worthwhile book for fans of women sleuths, especially anyone looking for some fresh ideas in the genre.  It's not a perfect book, but it's a very good initial effort from an author who shows promise.  I'll be looking for the second book in the series to see if the writing has tightened up a bit, and if it has, I believe this can become a successful series.Disclosure:  I received a free copy of this book from NetGally in exchange for a review; the opinions in this review are my own.

The objective Dear Investor, What the Hell are You Doing? is not to tell you how to invest or details how to build a portfolio, but focuses on the things an average investor should not do.  For me, the first thing you should do when reading a book with financial advice is to research the author and try to understand their perspective and biases.  Ken Weber is the owner of Weber Asset Management, a boutique investment advisory firm that specializes in creating portfolios of Fidelity mutual funds.  So far, so good--Ken Weber has many years of successful investment experience, and as Weber Asset Management is a boutique firm, the book is not a blatant commercial.Much of the book is common sense that all investors should know.  Have reasonable expectations, understand your own biases, don't fall for the hot stocks and quick wins, don't chase performance or make emotional decisions.  I particularly liked Chapter 5 on planning, which points out the advice telling you to start saving early is only partially correct.  For example, even starting saving at 25 years of age, you need to ensure you are saving to reach an inflation adjusted goal (or, $1 million isn't what it used to be).The book is divided into six parts: Getting on Track; Eyes Wide Open; Stocks, Bonds and Common Sense; Are You Getting the Right Advice; Beyond the Stock Market; and The Path Ahead.  Each part covers a myriad of bad ideas, poor advice, and misunderstandings that you need to avoid.However, I disagree with some advice in the final part.  It starts off fine, advising no load mutual funds over individual stocks for most investors.  In the sections about index and Exchange Traded Funds, the author states that index funds are "un-American" because they target mediocrity or are average while a well-managed fund can deliver better than average returns.  It is correct that a well-managed fund can deliver better than average returns, but historically, many of them have not.  It is entirely possible that Weber Asset Management can actively manage a portfolio funds that outperform the average, but many investors do not have access to this type of individualized advice.  The intent of investing is to make your money work hard for you, not to beat a benchmark or demonstrate American spirit and pride.  The book would have been better served pointing out that no one approach, portfolio, or type of investment is perfect, and managed funds should be considered as part of your diversification strategy.I would recommend Dear Investor, What the HELL are You Doing? to anyone interested in investing and how professionals in the financial industry thing.  Reading all the things investors should not do in one book is refreshing, and a powerful message.  Investors shouldn't expect to rely on any single source for information, but seek out multiple (including opposing views) to better understand their choices.  Dear Investor... is a good source that deserves a place on the investors bookshelf.Disclosure:  I received a free copy of this e-book from NetGalley, and the opinions in this review are my own.

This may be "just" a pencil sharpener, but it's actually pretty cool. I use a lot of colored pencils for taking and marking up notes, as well as using regular black pencils for diagramming. Between traveling to different offices, open seating plans, and working at home, it's become very difficult to find a decent pencil sharpener. I have a few of the simple ones that are cone shaped with a blade, but as we don't have individual trash cans in our open offices, there isn't anywhere close to discard the shavings. So, the first good thing about the Bostitich sharpener is that it holds the shavings in a small plastic case. It's only large enough for a few sharpenings, but that's OK.  The case is a smooth oval shape, and it's easy to hold and twist to sharpen the pencil.The interesting feature is that you can choose a pointed or blunt finish for the pencil, which I really like and immediately sharpened my pencils to a blunt tip--no more breaking tips in my bag or when writing!I appreciate this relatively simple and ordinary device far more than I ever expected. It's nice when something you use all the time does its job superlatively, and the Bostitich sharpener is a great product.

Clothes, Clothes, Clothes.  Music, Music, Music.  Boys, Boys, Boys: A Memoir--a great title for a wonderful memoir!  The title is based a comment by Viv Albertine's mother when Viv was a teenager, saying all Viv was interested in was clothes, music, and boys. Although I suspect that is true for many teenage girls, Viv stands out by how she throws herself into punk fashion, music, and the boys in the bands.I know only a little about the 1970s musical era in this memoir, but that didn't impact my enjoyment of the book.  Viv's drive to learn, to play, to experience music and life is timeless.  For the first part of the book, Viv is young, reckless, and free, surrounded by music and boys.  In the second half of the story, a more mature Viv has sought out stability, created a family, and struggled with her health.  But underneath her carefully constructed life, there is still a flicker of desire to be more, do more, and learn more.Clothes, Music, Boys is a well-written and engaging memoir.  One doesn't need to be a fan of 1970s music, early punk fashion, or girl bands to appreciate the coming of age story of a creative, sometimes lost, woman.

This is the perfect running jacket for travel. It's light, so it folds up nicely in your suitcase. The thumb holes on the sleeves help keep you warm, and the pockets (which many jackets don't have) are essential for hotel keys, a phone, and some money. With a long sleeve ruining shirt underneath, this is perfect to about 40-degrees.

i wear these at the gym, and liked them so much, I've purchased them twice. Typically, I am a size small in a woman's shirt, and these fit fine in size small.  I wash them in the machine in cold water and hang to dry so they won't shrink, and they are holding up well.

How to Be a Heroine is a medley of what the author did and did not learn from heroines in classical fiction. Ms. Ellis explores a variety of major female characters in fiction, ranging from the Little Mermaid to Anne of Green Gables to Lizzie Bennett to the four women in Valley of the Dolls. Context for each exploration jumps from the personal life of Ms. Ellis to the times and lifestyles of some of the authors, with no discernible pattern.Ms. Ellis is a very talented writer, and her skill keeps the reader engaged when the topic becomes slow and dragging. Although it's always enjoyable to re-visit favorite literary heroines, and to see them from another's perspective, the point of this book is primarily the author's enthusiasm for the topic and the aforementioned writing skills. Otherwise, it's a bit thin and tempting to skim.

Using resistance tubes was new to me, although I do spend time at the gym and work with a personal trainer a few times a week.  So, I started off being in relatively good physical shape, but needing to learn how to get value from the resistance tubes.  What I liked about the Bionic Tube:1.  There are a variety of exercises, some of which are easy to learn2.  It's portable, and doesn't take up any space3.  I might be able to carry this with me when I travel4.  You can work on isolated musclesWhat I didn't like:1. It's difficult to do some of the exercises exactly correctly.2. It can be difficult to tell if you are doing some exercises correctly or not.3. The tubes can be an addendum to other types of workouts, but I don't think they can be your only strength building toolIf you need an inexpensive or portable muscle / strength builder, these will do the job (even with buying the handles separately).  Some of the poses provide a nice stretch.  For me, however, this isn't enough work or enough feedback to be more than an occasional work out.

The Olay Pro-X Even Skin Tone Brightening Renewal Cream is an OK moisturizer, poor to fair at improving the tone of your skin.  My facial skin is pretty clear, with one or two brown spots. I am prone to dry skin, especially in the winter, and I've tried a variety of moisturizers. The positives of this cream is that it is very lightly scented, and it absorbs into your skin in just a few minutes, without any greasy feel.  To reduce sun or age spots, I think you would have to use this cream as part of a regimen, including a good sunscreen.The negative if this cream is that it is in a thick, plastic, non-recycleable jar. There are plenty of products available in glass or #2 plastic which is preferable.

I've been using the Juice Beauty Blemish Clearing Peel for nearly three weeks, and have had a positive experience.  I have dry skin, and I don't usually have many blemishes or acne.  However, I am using a prescription antibiotic cream on some facial abrasions, and when the cream touches any other part of my face, I'll break out.The label directions say to leave the peel on your face for 10 minutes, but as I have dry skin, I tested several different times.  I found that 3 minutes was not long enough, but between 5 - 7 minutes worked well.  It's most convenient for me to use the peel directly after a shower, but I think your skin will be less sensitive if you wait.  The peel tingles a little bit, but that stops in a minute or less.  Then I just gently remove the peel with warm water and followed with a moisturizer.The small, red blemishes I had virtually disappeared, and some of the newer / larger blemishes were smaller and less red.  By the next day, the marks from the smaller blemishes were gone. This exceeded my expectations, and although I doubt the result would be the same on severe acne, it demonstrated to me that the Juice Beauty Peel made a material difference.I also like that the product is USDA organic, which may be a marketing claim, but still---better to be organic than not!  The peel is in an easily recycled glass jar, and not a #5 or #7 plastic, which is great.Overall, I would highly recommend this product, just be sure to test different times and follow with a moisturizer.

The Cana Mystery is a smart, fast paced thriller, and meticulously detailed.  Ava Fischer is a graduate student, leading a peaceful but intense academic life when an former boyfriend, Paul, contacts her and asks for her help in solving an ancient code.  Intrigued by the challenge, and with Paul's working relationship with a very wealthy corporate executive, Ava jumps on a flight to Yemen.  Unknown to her, the code and the ancient artifacts holding it are being pursued by more people than just Paul and his boss, and these other pursuers are brutal and ruthless.The plot unfolds quickly, with a very deep theme relating to Catholic history and pending election of a new pope.  Ava and Paul cross country and cultural borders in their pursuit of the truth and to get away from the pursuers, they are helped by a diverse group of people--a friend of Ava's back in Boston, two young boys with a boat, an anonymous computer hacker, Paul's boss, and members of the Catholic church. Equally, they are betrayed by people in their network, and fearful of trusting or endangering anyone.The Cana Mystery is full of wonderful details about the church, archeology, the bible, ancient languages, and geography.  It's not a difficult read, but it does require your full attention to make sure you don't miss a single detail or riddle.  Highly recommended!Full Disclosure:  I received an electronic copy of this book from Net Galley to review; the opinions in this review are my own.

The Rosie Effect is the follow up novel to The Rosie Project -- and if you are one of the few people who have not read it, stop reading this review and instead read The Rosie Project right now!With the assumption that everyone still reading has read and enjoyed The Rosie Project, the The Rosie Effect is the next step in the lives of Professor Don Tillman and his wife Rosie.  Don is a professor at a University in New York City, and Rosie is a doctorate student.  Don has made some accommodations in his rigid life rules, and Rosie has learned to live with some of Don's idiosyncrasies.  Real life has begun to intrude into the honeymoon, as Rosie is stressed about completing her doctorate and Don's philandering friend appears headed for divorce.In the midst of this, Rosie announces that she is pregnant, and Don is stunned with surprise, unknowns, all all the variables that need to be managed.  Don begins to both live inside his head, researching parenthood, and focusing externally on his friends and their issues.  As in The Rosie Project, Don inadvertently gets himself into all types of trouble, but his logic and charm rescue him.With the pressures and distractions, Rosie begins to question her marriage and Don's suitability as a father, leading Don first to panic and then to try to apply logic to a situation ruled by his heart.  This part of the book was a bit of a muddle for me--was Rosie over reacting due to stress and her pregnancy?  Knowing Don, hadn't she considered what his reaction would be?  Is this just a technique to make for an engaging plot?  Or is it just the natural progression of what happens when these delightful people grow up, grow old, and need to deal with what life brings them?Either way, in the end, The Rose Effect is still a good book, and a must read for anyone who enjoyed the Rosie Project.

I've had a Kindle since the very first one, and I loyally upgrade every time there is a new one. I am so disappointed in my Kindle Voyage! The screen keeps getting "stuck," and the top navigation bar floats in the middle of the text. I also ke gettin a screen that is 60% white, 40% black, and then I need to reboot. I've rebooted this Kindle more than all my other Kindles combined. I'm not sure what to do--I gave my paper white to my husband, but I fear this Kindle is just going to freeze and not be usable.I usually love my Kindle, but as I said, the behavior and stability of this one is terrible.

It might seem a bit much to "love" kitchen towels, but I've written this review rating these Calphalon towels relative to other kitchen towels.  What I like about the Calphalon towels:1. They are slightly wider than some of our other dish towels, which is helpful for drying some larger objects.2.  The colors are a bit modern, and they go well with my granite counter tops, especially compared to the green / blue / white towel set we have.3.  They are cotton, and soft.  My husband thinks the synthetic towels are better for drying, but I prefer these as they are simply nicer to use.4.  I've washed these 3 - 4 time, hot water and hot drier, and they've kept their shape and color.I can recommend buying these towels to anyone, and I am will be looking to see if they come in any holiday colors to buy.

Now that most office are open plan seating, it's become impossible to find basic office supplies.  I travel a lot, and really try to pack only what is absolutely necessary, but finally gave in and bought this stapler.  It works as expected, it probably will staple 6-8 pages. I really like that you can store extra staples in the bottom, plus there is an attached staple remover.  This little stapler has earned its passage in my carry-on bag.

We have a 47" Vizio television, and have been considering getting a sound bar or speaker to improve the quality of music and movies.
