The Bose CineMate 15 is very easy to set up, we did it in less than 30 minutes.  The sound bar itself is an unobtrusive black rectangular box that fit easily under the wall mounted television.  The subwoofer is larger than I'd like, and takes up  bit of floor space.  I think one of the challenges is that the wall mounted television is a clean, sleek look and any peripherals look messy.At first, the sound was different from the television speaker.  Not bad, just different.  Once we became accustomed to the new sound, it was fine, with a much better bass.  The sound is really good for movies, ball games, and some music.  We do not play many games on our TV, but I can see this speaker being great if we did.The only downside of this speaker system is that it is another remote.  We chose to keep using our TiVo remote, as it is what I am used to, and then take an extra step to turn on the Bose.All in all, this speaker system is the high quality sound that you expect from Bose.  The easy set up of the system is a real plus, and it wasn't terribly over packaged.  I can highly recommend this to anyone looking for a quality home theater system.

I have one tooth / spot in my mouth that is sensitive.  My dentist has looked at this a few times, and he finally cured the worst of the pain by correcting my bite.  However, a small amount of pain and sensitivity has remained, and it gets worse when I am stressed and grinding my teeth at night.I followed the directions and applied the Sensi-Stop strip to the approximate area that bothers me.  It can be difficult to tell exactly which tooth, but the strip is big enough I knew I was close.  The first strip didn't seem to have an impact, so I used another strip about two days later, and that worked.  It wasn't a cure--I won't be putting ice or anything cold directly on that tooth anytime soon, but it was enough to relieve the small pains that I would feel in general every day.For me, the relief lasts about 14 - 17 days.  I suspect that the efficacy depends on how painful your tooth is, what you eat, and your overall dental care.  My tooth doesn't bother me so much that I have to use this, but I do appreciate when it is not quite so sensitive and I think using this produce 2 or 3 times a month a good value.

I had read about Hyaluronic Acid, and had wanted to try it, but wasn't sure where to fit it in my routine.  The advice I was given was to apply the OZ Natural Vitamin C Serum, wait a few minutes, apply the OZ Naturals Hyaluronic Serum, and then moisturizer.  I tried this, adding sunscreen at the end, and it didn't quite work.  I found that I need to be careful that my sun screen didn't pill, and also that I was getting some dry and peeling patches.  However--I was trying this product while I was recovering from an accident where I bruised and cut my face, and perhaps that had an impact.Separately, I tried this Serum with the Vitamin C Serum and a heavy moisturizer or just this Serum and a heavy moisturizer at night, and I liked that better.  This Serum helps your skin absorb the moisturizer, and when I woke up, my skin felt soft and not at all dry.  I suggest you may get the best results trying a few different things that work for you.  I really like the Vitamin C Serum in the day, so I'll continue to try different moisturizers (maybe a moisturizing mask?) with this at night.  I was happy with my initial results, but I think there is the potential for the product to do even more if I find the right routine.Note:  I was provided a sample of this product by the manufacturer to review, and the opinions in the review are my own.

I had the opportunity to try this Vitamin C Serum, the Hyaluronic Serum, and the OZ Eye Gel all at the same time.  Unfortunately, a few days after I started using all three products, I was in an accident and scraped, bruised, and cut my face--including stitches and some bad abrasions.  However, after a week or so, I had enough clear skin on parts of my face that I could begin using the products again, and lucky for this review, could do my own comparison of my skin with and without the OZ Naturals.I like the OZ Vitamin C Serum a lot.  You just need a small amount on your face and neck, and then I rub whatever is left on my hands.  Sometimes, it makes my skin feel a tight, but a little moisturizer fixes that. The best way I can describe it is the serum made my skin glow and look clear and smooth.  It didn't make me break out, and after a few minutes, you don't even feel it.  I added moisturizer and sunblock on top of the serum, and everything worked fine.  The glow lasted most of the day, and it was cumulative, getting better the more days in a row I used the serum.At night, I tried the Vitamin C Serum plus the Hyaluronic Acid plus several moisturizers.  In the morning, my skin felt soft and moist if I used a heavy moisturizer.  I suspect that this combination will be a good one to re-try in the winter when my skin is drier.It was wonderful for me to have some nice facial skin surrounding my cuts that were loaded with greasy antibiotic ointment!  I will keep using this product, and I can't wait until I can use it on my entire face.  I have previously used Prevage, which also did a nice job for me, but I hated the wasteful packaging.  The OZ Naturals is 1/3 of the cost of Prevage, had largely the same affect, and is in a glass bottle I can recycle.Note: I received a sample of this product to review, and the opinions in this review are my own.

The Perfect Stranger has all the components of a good beach read, but falls slightly short.  The theme plays upon some common fears--a group of women who blog about their experiences with breast cancer, find each other on line, and become virtual friends. The terror of the disease, the occasional hesitation about sharing your innermost thoughts with strangers, and the close relationships with women that you really don't know for sure are who they say the are creates an atmosphere of normality mixed with unease.The bloggers represent some broad categories of women--the affluent, happily married mother, a schoolteacher with a tendency to drink too much socially and make poor choices, a lonely woman whose life is driven by her unloving, distant mother, a secretive woman who carefully hides her personal details, and a kind, older matriarch that ties the group together.  When the matriarch is murdered, the women travel to her funeral, meeting each other in real life for the first time.The Perfect Stranger unfolds as the women get to know each other better, decide to spend a weekend together, and then each begins to worry about the who, what, and why of the murdered woman.  Here, the book escapes any strands of credibility, with the murderer actually contributing to the dialog, the secretive woman has an explosive past, and most of the women decide to spend a weekend together.  This plot tactic is ridiculous--who invites strangers you've met once to your home for  a weekend when one of your group was recently murdered?The Perfect Stranger is an OK, quick read, you can skip over some parts without losing the plot.  It would have been better if one or two of the side plots had been eliminated.

Somewhere Safe with Somebody Good continues the story of all the Mitford characters we've come to know.  Father Tim and his wife Cynthia have just returned from a vacation in Ireland, and are attempting to define what they want from their retirement life.  Progress has not entirely skipped over Mitford or its residents.  There are new politics, new shop keepers, and Dooley (Father Tim's adopted son) is growing up and focusing on a career and marriage.Somewhere Safe with Somebody Good is exactly what we have come to expect from a Mitford novel.  The pace is slow, the characters are mostly nice, sad things happen but everyone pulls together in the end.  If you are a fan of the Mitford novel, you must read this just to find out what Father Tim and his friends have been doing.  If you are new to the series, you'll enjoy this book much more if you wait to read it and instead start at the beginning of the series.

I have several microfiber dusters, all of which are long withe short fibers.  The OXO Delicate Duster has a poof of long fibers, similar to a dandelion or the hair of the mascot of a certain fast food chain.  The long fibers and relatively short handle let you gently dust your various delicate dust collectors.  I sued the OXO Delicate Duster to dust some small vases, a paper filigree, and two lighting sconces.  The "Good Grips" refers to a rubber handle that helps to prevent the duster from slipping in your hand.I quite like the OXO Good Grips Microfiber Delicate Duster.  It allowed me to quickly (but still carefully) dust some decorative items.  I cheated a bit (as I am recovering from a bad fall) and used the duster on a few coffee tables and hard to reach areas, and it also worked well.  The head of the duster is washable, although I'd probably just rinse it in the kitchen sink if necessary.  The only thing I would change is that I wish the manufacturer would mark the name of the replacement head on the handle.  It was on the product tag, but that will be long recycled by the time I want to buy a new duster head.

Dear Daughter: A Novel is entirely from the perspective of Jane Jenkins, but what a perspective that is!  Jane, or sometimes Janie, or sometimes Rebecca is an heiress and a former convict, released from prison on a technicality.  Her crime? Killing her cold, distant, and mean-spirited mother. although Jane has no memory of doing this.  Equally, Jane was convicted of being an odd, entitled, sarcastic, and also somewhat mean wealthy teenager.Once out of prison, Jane has just a few slender clues to try to find out what really happened the night Jane's mother died.  These clues also may lead Jane to learn more about who her mother really was, and even perhaps finding Jane's father.  Jane ends up in a small South Dakota town, where she meets a varied cast of characters while under constant pressure from her own mind, a blogger who taunts her, and a public who is willing to expose Jane to ridicule and trial by the popular press.Dear Daughter is a very well written first novel, although a bit uneven.  Some parts are truly gripping, while other parts are a bit rambling. The ending all comes in a bit rush, and doesn't quite deliver on the initial promise.  However, if you are looking for a new author, or a fresh view, Dear Daughter is certainly worth reading.

The LiquiSeal Travel Mug does a good job keeping your coffee warm.  We turned the mug on its side, and it didn't leak! You can also unscrew the stopper for cleaning, which is a real plus. One of the features is a one click button that opens and closes the opening for drinking, unlike other travel mugs that you need to hold the button to keep the lid open. If you are looking for a utilitarian mug that doesn't leak, this is a good choice.This mug could be improved if you could wash it in the dishwasher.  More importantly, it's a bit difficult to click the button to open the mug one handed.  If it's resting in the cup holder in your car, no problem, but difficult if you are holding the cup.

I'll Drink to That is a memoir by Betty Halbreich who after created and then ran personal shopping at Bergdorf Goodman.  The book starts out with Betty's affluent, coddled, but lonely childhood.  Her parents were often too busy for her, but always made sure Betty had fine food and beautiful clothes.  Shortly after the end of WWII, Betty is swept away by a handsome, fast talking and fun living New Yorker.  Caught up in the after war frenzy of fashion and partying, Betty constructs a luxurious and proper home and lifestyle.As her children grow up, Betty becomes frustrated with her lack of purpose and empty marriage, and after asking her husband to move out, has a nervous breakdown. Fighting to save herself, she falls into jobs in her comfort zone of helping women to dress well.  Not one for cash registers or actual selling, Betty proposes the concept of personal shopping at Bergdorf Goodman, starting a 40+ year career helping all types of women find the clothes to help them look their best.  But often, Betty is more than a shopper, helping women build their confidence, display their inner strengths via their clothing, and offering advice of all types.I enjoyed I'll Drink to That the most when Betty wrote about the fashion extravagances after the war, and the time earlier in her career when women's clothing was distinctly different by designer, and of high quality, and not the mass produced trash offered to most of us today.  If you enjoy fashion, or books about retail stores, you'll find much to interest you in I'll Drink to That.

I have been using a Philips Sonicare Toothbrush for at three years and will never use anything else! I like these brushes so much, I have two.  One is a more expensive version, with multiple speeds and a sanitizer.  After having forgotten this brush at a hotel once, I was not willing to bring it on any more trips.However, I do travel a lot, and now that I'm used to the Sonicare brush, I hate using anything else.  This brush is perfect for travel--it's just the brush and a small charger.  I put the clear plastic cap over the bristles, put everything in a water proof pouch, and this is ready to travel the world.  The best part is this new version has a charging indicator.  I have several devices to charge when I travel, and hotel rooms never have enough convenient outlets.  So, be able to know if the brush is charged or not is great, and a big improvement over earlier models.I can't recommend this brush enough, I've gotten everyone in my family one! Not only does the brush clean your teeth, it helps prevent you from injuring your gums with vigorous brushing. Everyone should have a Sonicare, and this model really has everything you need at a reasonable price.

This book is one of the best publications that I  have encountered in the past many years.  The attributes are as follows:  Firstly, and most important is the fact that in  the use of the word LOW  in describing the vocal  range of a book, it has often been the case that the keys of the song are more geared to voices on the high side; like Mezzo sopranos who are comfortable singing in the upper part of the staff: E, F, F#, G and sometimes higher.  This book is actually low and more geared to the Contralto and HALLELUJAH  for that because there are not many books that qualify for the really low voices.  In addition, the songs are quite interesting, much variety, less difficult Barber than many of his later songs such as most of the Hermit Songs, whose low book I own, but low in name only.The package includes an excellent CD that includes both performance and Accompaniment  The performance performers are:  Mezzo soprano, Kathleen Sonnentag; baritone, Kurt Ollmann and Piano, Richard Walters.  Two of the songs are world premiere:  "Mother, I cannot mind my wheel" and "Hey nonny no!".  There is one song from the Hermit Songs: :" The Crucifixion", two keys lower than usual GREAT!  It is a very nice collection and demonstrates Barber's gift for writing lyrically for the voice.Also included is information about Barber as well as comments and detail about each song!  All you seekers of something special in vocal publications, go for this one!

Being that confirmed Bach-a-holic I can unequivocally say that for me it is an absolute fact!!!!And if I wasn't totally convinced before I listened to this disc, I AM NOW. It somewhat distresses and surprises me that for this particular recording there is only one review and yet for many others by this group there are several.  Could it be that there are still individuals who relate anything that is performed by a symphony orchestra  as BORING!!!!! Well, not so.  If you out there are really country music fans you will love the selection of music on this disc. BECAUSE the program itself has much variety;  it includes classic country songs such as "Cool Water", "Yellow Rose of Texas", "South of the Border", "Back in the Saddle Again", "Happy Trails", "Tumbling Tumbleweeds" and that great song first recorded by Vaughan Monroe many years ago "Ghost Riders in the Sky".  There are a couple of interesting Medleys and much humor in the dialogue.  The Nashville Symphony is an added plus and for you who THINK that you don't like classical music there really is none on this disc.BUT the best reason to listen to this recording is because it is superbly performed:  great vocal renditions with words that are well-pronounced with clean articulation and smooth phrasing.  The instrumentalists are more than capable in their contributions and I (A Bach-a-holic) loved every note and I think that Bach would have enjoyed this music very much for he had lots of upbeat compositions of his own.  Why don't you try some of them!  You know the commercial: TRY IT YOU'LL LIKE IT.I am very grateful  to having met Sally Green (Ranger Doug's daughter) about a month ago in Nashville.  She is a charming girl and having heard her description of the Riders in the Sky I was anxious to hear them perform. She sent me this recording and it was a good choice; the combination of a symphony orchestra works very well. The following quote from Alan D. Valentine, President & CEO of the Nashville Symphony states: "The idea of pairing a group of cowboy singers with an orchestra isn't all that outlandish.  After all, both outfits use a violin-the only difference is that in country/western music, it's called a fiddle.  And symphonic music has been a part of westerns since sound came to motion pictures...."He states several other reasons but buy the record and you can read them all!  Even though I have had it for only a short time I have listened to it multiple times.  GREAT ENTERTAINMENT!This is first class traditional country at its best, unsullied by 'pop', 'rap' or any other junk that has come along.  I  hold nothing against other forms of music  BUT COUNTRY SHOULD BE CLOSE TO FOLK MUSIC; BECAUSE IT IS AMERICA'S FOLK MUSIC.

An exceptionally well-written, thoroughly documented biography covering the complete and unfortunately short life of George Butterworth (1885-1916).  All of Butterworth's surviving works are discussed along with an examination of his friendship with Vaughan Williams and the poet Housman from which he derived several of Housman's poems, the most notable of which are the setting of the six songs from The Shropshire Lad.  It was this cycle that led me to find out more about Butterworth; it's incredible beauty combined with Housman's very attractive poetry makes the entire package irresistible to the singer, as well as the audience as later proved by the wide popularity of the song cycle.  This, combined with the pathos created by the fact that this talented young composer just beginning his career was killed three weeks after he joined the Army by a German sniper along with several others of musical potential.  WHAT A DEVISTATING LOSS TO THE MUSIC WORLD.  And this "the war to end all wars"!But the book does not dwell on this aspect, but instead  gives us the succinct picture of Butterworth's background, both family and education.  The author uses many footnotes, more than I used, but I did check what  I considered to be important in the overall picture.  I was really not much interested in his heritage, but many no doubt would be interested.  It did focus on the three periods, short though they were of his composing life and I learned a great deal by this portion of the book , which also included detailed examples and explanations of his individual compositions.The Folk Song era for Butterworth was the 2nd compostion period which I found particularly fascinating be cause it spoke of his association with many of other well-known composers interested in the Folk Music Revival; Cecil Sharp (also killed in the war), Vaughan Williams and several others.  Since I knew little or nothing about this period in music in England, it made for interesting reading.  Included were comments about the relationships and some were quite humorous.  One that I will include herein was made by the poet Housman when he discovered that Vaughan Williams had omitted two verses from is musical setting of the song "Is My Team Ploughing?" (This is one of the Shropshire lad Songs in which a ghost is communicating with a live friend-  A WONDERFUL SONG).  In The V.Williams setting he leaves out the words:  The goal stands up, the keeper Stands up to keep the Goal;  The composer's view was that any poet who had written such lines as those should be grateful to have them left out, a remark not made directly to Housman, but to a friend; Housman's response was "I wonder how he would like me to cut out two bars of his music."  Even the 'greats' can go at it!!!!!!The book moves forward clearly and at a reasonable pace; it stays with the story and includes many photographs of Butterworth and other involved in his life.  If you are a singer, especially a baritone, for that's what the songs were written for, but of course he did write instrumental music as well.  The last composing period was when he focused on instrumental writing and before he was killed wrote two significant instrumental pieces, as well as many other musical compositions.  All are listed in the book.  Everything you want to know about George Butterworth is herein."In all of Butterworth's output, the man and the music are inseparable.  He was very much a man of the English countryside, as was Housman whose verses so fired the composer's imagination.  ......Butterworth was no innovatory composer, nor was his music very influential, but he will remain an important minor figure with a reputation based on a handful of works, the sincerity and musical value of which assure him a place in the history of English music."

The book of Contralto songs has been in my possession for many years and I have long enjoyed its particular song material.  I could not believe my eyes when I noticed on Amazon that the accompaniments are now available. They are indeed well-recorded and well-performed by the accompanist.  Go for it if you use this book at all.  It is probably well-used because there are not many collections of this type for the contralto voice.  Take note that this particular edition does not include the songbook.  You have to order that separately!

What a disappointment this book turned out to be!  There's nothing wrong with the writing, but the story, lacking any sort of plot, meanders on and on in a 'gossipy' style which some may find interesting, but I found dull and witless.  Perhaps my original perception of this book based upon reviews, not only on this website but throughout my research, was obviously erroneous. As pointed out by a previous reviewer, the book does not center on Handel, per se.  In fact, although Harry is telling his story, albeit in a very lackadaisical and somewhat confusing manner, it failed to whet my interest and I painstakingly waded through it all.  What a waste of my time and Harry's.  But as you can see there are many who did enjoy reading it, but I did not (c'est la vie).

This recording "American Polyphony" features highlights from the choral repertoire by twentieth-century American giants:  Samuel Barber(1910-1981), Leonard Bernstein(1918-1990), Aaron Copland(1900-1990), and Randolph Thompson(1899-1984).It heartens me that Stephen Layton has produced such a fine recording of American contemporary works.  He has chosen well his program and his small choir has more than done it justice. It seems that the "Brits" with their esteemed history of excellent choral singing has scored a great victory for twentieth-century American music.New to me were the four motets by Aaron Copland which I found very interesting in their construction and sound. The reason has to do with the fact that he actually composed these as exercises in his three year sojourn in Paris while studying with the eminent teacher Nadia Boulanger.  Each of the motets are settings of Old Testament texts and each maintains a distinct personality -  from the gently rocking serenity of "Help us,O Lord" to the rousing and upbeat jubilation of "Sing we praises to our King". Copland said of these motets that they are not his best work, for that was yet to come.  Interestingly enough, for me personally, I prefer them to some of his later works.  At the Conservatory where I studied these many years ago most of these composers were in their prime, so thus my opening caption about 'memory lane'.Samuel Barber was part of a composer's forum while I was a student, so I had the privilege of singing in the chorus directed by him for the concerts.  It was a memorable experience to be able to observe how a composer treats his own works.  Of course, the Agnus Dei was the high point. To hear it again and performed so beautifully was really a great listening experience for me and I think for many who know this work well and even if they never heard it before it's hard to resist it's 'pull' on the senses.Layton and the choir Polyphony gives an absolutely marvelous rendition of Bernstein's "Missa Brevis".  I have never sung this, but I have heard it many times, mostly in concert.  However, the voices on this disc far surpass any other renditions in my experience.  The two countertenors in their lengthy solo sections are producing wonderfully placed tones of great beauty and strongly implemented. I must name them because they deserve to be noticed:  David Allsopp(has appeared on many other recordings with similar results); Christopher Lowrey(I am not familiar with his background, but he sang well on this recording).  Their voices were important in the overall scheme of the composition and they acquitted themselves very well indeed.  I love this work by Bernstein, moreso since I heard this choir perform it.Who has not heard of or sang the great "Alleluia" of Randall Thompson!  It is one wonderful piece of music and what a great way to open this recording!  I must confess to not having any experience with  his work "Fare Well", but it was a great way to END this recording!TWO EXPERT COMMENTS;  ENCORE MAGAZINE, USA: "Possibly the best small professional choir in the world."GRAMOPHONE:  "Stephen Layton's Choir (Polyphony)have become renowned for both their sound and versatility - whether in early music, or contemporary works such as those of Eric Whitacre, they embody the remarkable tradition of British choral excellence at it's finest."

The composer, Phil Klines' comments concerning this recording:  "The ritual of the Mass itself is a kind of spiritual portal through which one can become part of a universal body...in the process of discovery I wished to pass unburdened by a rigid plan, formal or stylistic.  This is NOT a "blues" Mass any more than it is a  medieval one.  My  concept was to set the traditional Latin Ordinary (parts of the Mass that remain the same from week-to-week) for Chorus alone, and to add my own set of Propers (the parts that change from season to season) using a variety of texts, and to have these sections accompanied by the string quartet."The chosen texts suggest a narrative of redemption in a blighted world, the origins of which are from the Old Testament, including two from the Lamentations of Jeremiah.  Interestingly, rather than choosing the New Testament apocalypse of Revelation, Kline chose from the American poet David Shapiro, whose image of indifferently falling snow recalls the ashes falling from the skies of Lower Manhatten; thus emerges the text for the Movement #6 "The Snow Fell".  Samuel Beckett's monologue emerges as a prayer in the Movement #8 "The Unnamable" which magnificently portrays the struggle of the mind in present times.  Movement #9 "Dark Was the Night"  has no audible text; it is a fantasy on Willie Johnson's 1927 recording of an old hymn depicting Jesus' doubt at the Passion, paraphrased in wordless meaning.Bookending the Mass are Kline's settings of two Early American shape-note hymns from THE SACRED HARP:  Northport & Wondrous Love.  Kline states the "they stir the vestiges of an unforgettable and mysterious beauty, the sound of strong emotion, unconditional and utterly lacking in malice", that he recalls from the rural religion  he witnesses as a child in Pennsylvania and Ohio.The performance of this glorious music is absolute PERFECTION!  LIONHEART, a six male American Ensemble sings with clear and concise diction; every word distinct and all sounds produced perfectly placed and blended with each other's sounds; always with emotional fervor.  The accompanying string quartet "ETHEL" acquits itself with equal skill and much expression.This recording has made a profound impression on me and every time I listen I get something I haven't heard previously. That is one indication of a talented  composer who has much to offer. This recording goes at the top 2 percent  of my vast record collection accumulated over a period of 50 years.  Listen for yourself.  The musical world needs more of Kline's inspirational influence.  There is no libretto and there really  is no need for one.  With Lionheart's excellent word skills you won't miss a thing. BUT KEEP IN MIND THIS IS NOT BACKGROUND MUSIC!!!!But entertaining???YOU BET!

"Laments (Latin:planctus) have existed in all cultures for as long as there has been song.  They express affection, joy, sorrow and grief for people, places, or ideas that have gone from our lives.  In essence, lamentations are how we deal with loss.  This album is a compilation of laments I have performed since 1993 in conjunction with the passing of people who were significant to my life and work." Michael Collver, 2006After almost 50 years of record-perusing and collecting it is not often that I find anything that unusual or surprising BUT this one packed me a powerful punch.  It is so incredibly moving and possesses some of the most interesting sounds such as:  Collver's very unique vocal tone qualities.  Although he is labeled as a counter-tenor and he IS that indeed, his voice throughout this recording makes a multitude of sounds at all levels of its registers.  This is particularly obvious in Track Two "The Silver Swanne" by Martin Amlis-1980, where he with the speed of light bounces back and forth from head to chest and sometimes in between. ABSOLUTELY AMAZING!  The final track "Lamentation" from Leonard Bernstein's Jeremiah Symphony also brings forth many tone colors.His second talent that increases the enjoyment of this recording is his use of the violin and piano in assisting the drama and pathos of the music herein.  Collver uses excerpts from the music of:  Guillaume de Machaut(Track 3)1100, a French song about lost love, and interprets it in his own way using voice and organetto; Robert Kyr,1993,A lament for the unnamed, sung in English with voice, violin and piano;  Martin Amlin(mentioned above), Gottfridus de ST. Victor (1180) Planctus ante nescia, Latin for unaccompanied voice.  There is information about each of the 8 selections on the record packaging which you will certainly want to read before or after listening.  Thus I did not list all the selections for this review would be much too long.  Suffice it to say the overall mood is a bittersweet sadness combined with the absolute fascination provided by each rendition of the music.The performers are highly skilled and are:  Michael Collver, countertenor- Peter Sykes, keyboards- Kinloch Earle, violin.  All American from Massachusetts.  The arrangements are exotic gems and priceless for the music listener. This is a hauntingly beautiful song cycle of Medieval and Contemporary Laments for countertenor voice, organetto, vox humana, violin and piano.

Antoine Brumel(c.1460-1515), a notable contemporary of Obrecht & Josquin, was a top composer in the Franco-Flemish tradition; and is historically significant as the first truly French composer to be associated with the court of Burgundy.  His output was considerable by any standards, ranging over French songs of great charm, many motets, including fully-developed settings of complete psalms, and at least 16 Masses.  His settings, while exhibiting great contrapuntal skill, is nevertheless the work of a composer free in spirit.During the Renaissance, it was considered normal procedure for a Mass composition or Motet to make use of pre-existent material, and by the late 15th century, sacred music sometimes drew upon popular, folk or art songs.  Antoine Brumel's  Missa Berzerette Savoyenne takes its title and much of its distinctive material from a French chanson by Josquin with a text about a young man courting a shepherdess ( a song of seduction, as it were). Thus bringing into the church some of the frolicking quality and vigorous humor of the countryside.  This Mass is a lucid and gripping work and it is somewhat amazing to me that a composer can base an entire Mass on a seduction song.  But Brumel hides nothing for in the Kyrie the melody is clearly evident in the top line; later it is in the Tenor, but always audible.  Each movement presents new ideas, and the final Agnus Dei has an unbelievable number of repetitions.  As a piece of devotional music, it is questionable, but as pure enjoyment it is delightful.The Motets, especially the Heth, Cogitavit Dominus, were the best sung on the disc, but still left a lot to be desired which was a disappointment because I have never heard anything by Chanticleer that was not perfect.  My complaint herein has mostly to do with the balance of the voices, especially in the Mass.  The treble sound which is produced by four countertenors could have been better sung by two.  The voices of Randall Wong and Joseph Jennings and Louis Botto are usually aligned well with the other voices and blend well. It may be  that the other countertenor, Steven Rickards may be the one with the voice, sounding very female, and not well-blended. However it may be that having fewer countertenors would have solved the problem.  The group in addition to the 4 ct's, includes 3 tenors, 2 baritones and 3 basses. The first selection had at least one poor entrance (out of sync with the ensemble).  To say that the disc is not worth hearing would be a great mistake, and I will listen to it and enjoy hearing the music of BrumelRecorded in 1991-includes brochure with program and brief comments.  Liner notes include Latin to English translation.

This recording is comprised of musical gems from  13th & 14th century Italy. St. Francis of Assisi, born in 1182, was responsible for the eventual development of the LAUDE.  Franciscan humility,  devotion, joy and mystery find characteristic expression in the 'lauda', or song of praise.  Over the years the lauda incorporated new ideas of harmony, counterpoint, and form.  Laude soon began to be composed in two and three parts, then four and more.  Manuscripts from Bologna, Florence, Trier, and Venice serve as sources of 14th & 15th century polyphonic Laude for this program.  Finally in the 16th century, lauda musical texts began to appear with the names of their composers.  In 1508, Ottaviano Petrucci  published two printed books of laude the first of which consists of 66 compositions attributed to Innocentius Dammonis, 4 of which are included on this disc, a Monk of the congregation of San Salvatore in Venice.  No other music by this Renaissance master survives.The music on this recording is at times, hypnotic, exotic and erotic, but always engaging; I could not stop listening the first time I heard it.  It consists of five categories of happenings:  PROCESSIONAL (3 SELECTIONS); VIRGIN & CHILD (3 SELECTIONS); THE ANGEL'S MESSAGE(3 SECTIONS); BETHLEHEM(7 SECTIONS); EMMANUEL: GOD WITH US(7 SECTIONS).  The words are Latin and there is no translation, but it is not difficult to figure out what the songs are telling us!  But even if you can't the music itself is hard to resist.The ensemble Lionheart:  6 male singers with glorious voices and a marvelous sense of ensemble.  Their accomplishments thus far in the musical world are almost miraculous: perfect blend, precise diction, superior tonal resonance, smooth and correct phrasing and a host of dynamic subtleties characterize their singing.  A really excellent representative for the early music world.There is a brochure that gives some very useful background information of the material on this recording.  If you enjoy this group, there are several other recordings on line; I have reviewed all but one.  Go for it!

Hans Leo Hassler (1564-1612) highly esteemed in his lifetime, was a contemporary of Schutz, Shakespeare, Byrd and Cervates.  He spent a year and a half in Venice as a pupil of Giovanni Gabrieli.  His musical style is lucid, luminous and transparent, easy to follow and enjoy.  Although Orlando de Lassus (1532-1594)was Hassler's model,Hassler forged his own style which was full of grace, restraint and a complete understanding between extrovert texts and reflective music.  This recording demonstrates all of the aforementioned attributes.  This music definitely displays a metrical and proto-chorale-like style.The four-person Penalosa Esemble, founded in 1996, clearly performs these compositions in the manner Hassler required.  Their enunciation is careful, precise, measured, fully in accord with Hassler's reserve.  Moreover, their approach is well-researched and considered, presenting this music in an open and plain style.  The very fine singers are:  Susan Eitrich, soprano; Sebastian Mory, male alto; Jorg Deutschewitz, tenor and Pierre Funck, bass.  They sing with perfect balance and an excellent sense of ensemble, that is as one.The theme of this collection of pieces (eight of which have not been recorded:  Tracks 1,12,18,19,20,23,26) is the period from Annunciation to New Year.  The "Super Dixit Maria" is a parody mass and on the disc it follows the single short song on which it was based.  The disc also includes narrative and celebatory works as well as the eight part Magnificat (Tr. 18) very exquisite and wonderfully performed.Listening to this for the first time was incredibly enjoyable and gave me a TRUE Christmas feeling, not to be acquired with much of the music via radio, TV holiday specials, malls etc etc etc.  The package is accompanied by pertinent information (including the text) in German and English.

Thus prints the Herald Times of the Concord Ensemble, to which I heartily agree.  Founded in 1997 as an a cappella all-male sextet of superior quality, the Concord Ensemble herein presents their first recording of Voices of Renaissance Spain.  It is a stunning testimony to their ability to deliver an exciting and entertaining performance. They join the ranks of other American small Early Music Ensembles such as Chanticleer and Lionheart. Unfortunately, there are only two recordings listed on Amazon that are available, both are Dorian recordings.The very fine singers in this ensemble are:  Paul Flight,countertenor;Pablo Cora,Tenor,countertenor ; N. Lincoln Hanks and Daniel Carberg, tenors; Sumner Thompson, baritone and Daniel Cole, bass; guest artist, Bruce Remaker, countertenor.  Some of the composers featured on this disc are:  Mateo Flecha(1481-1553), De Morales (ca1500-1553), Juan Vasquez (ca1510-ca.1560)and De Victoria(1548-1611).I enjoyed most of the selections and especially the opening number "La Guerra"s by Mateo Flecha sung with enthusiasm and excitement as the subject required.  But my absolute favorite was Victoria's "Missa Dum Complerentur", but in fact the entire program is enjoyable.  The accompanying booklet includes pertinent information and word translations when needed.

All the pomp and pageantry of eighteenth century Europe come vibrantly to life in this well-researched novel of the life of Carlo Broschi whose stage name was Farinelli, a male soprano who was the most celebrated castrato of his time. Alive with court intrigues, clandestine romances, and the horrors of the eighteenth century Spanish Inquisition, THE CASTRATO is a powerful example of historical fiction at its very best. I have read dozens of books concerning the circumstance that created the idea of the castrati; the main reason being that the Pope in the 17th-18th centuries forbade women to appear in public in a performing capacity.  This was based on St. Paul's commentary in the Bible. This topic has unfortunately supplied many fiction writers to attempt to spin their tales, most of which are totally of their own making, but there are a few books I have read that approach the subject much more intelligently and this is one of them.The author, Lawrence Louis Goldman has had 25 years of writing experience, covering all phases of the profession.  I was interested in why he chose this topic and he stated:  "Listening to Beverly Sills (opera singer) appearing on a Dick Cavett program...I heard two jokes about castrati.  I looked up the subject and became fascinated by Farinelli's life."And indeed this is a fascinating tale of tragedy, glory, love unrequited, pain and injustice perpetrated by royalty as well as the Church at that time.  IT'S AMAZING, SHOCKING BUT IT'S ALL TRUE!!!!  It is consoling in this day and age that women may appear in performance, but there is a whole generation of male falsettos who produce what I believe is similar to the castrati of old, and it is done naturally with the high false voice that men can produce, though not all achieve success in attempting to do so; just as in other voices, male or female.I include a quotation from the book:  "So subtly that none could tell the exact moment, the silence gave way to sound.  A single high, clear tone impinged on the strained ears....Now one thought of a bird, but who remembered a bird which voiced as this one?...Constant in pitch, still carried on the same breath, it built in volume with the imminent arrival of its source....The listener, carried along, felt hair prickle on the back of the neck...felt his heart quicken and his own breath stop in a yearning to help, in some impossible way, the singer still concealed from view..."If you are a true lover of music histoty and the voice itself, this novel is for you.  Otherwise, avoid it!!!!

In 1976, at the age of 33 years, David Munrow hanged himself, supposedly because he was depressed over the death of his Father and Father-in-law.  But he left behind a musical legacy focusing on medieval and renaissance music that is unsurpassed, especially considering his short life span. He brought medieval and renaissance music to a wider audience through books, television, radio and the 50 recordings that he produced.  His knowledge of instruments was vast and he played many of them from bassoon to shawm to crumhorn to recorder.My first encounter was his recording 2CD "The Art of the Netherlands", which was recorded in April,1975 shortly before he died.  I was immediately impressed by the quality of the performance as well as the knowledge and scholarly approach of the entire effort. This present disc was recorded in November 1975,even closer to his demise.  What a waste that a man of this ability should succumb to depression!!!!But no matter there is much we can grab onto that he has left behind.This disc contains about one half hour of instrumental and one half hour of vocal that is lightly accompanied.  The instruments as you might expect are varied and in the instrumental portion are uniquely arranged.  Some of the instruments are:  cornets, sackbuts,  recorders, percussion, dulcian, shawn, crumhorns, violins, viols, chitarrone, organ, baroque guitar and harpsichord. There are three voices included in the six vocal selections:  James Bowman, countertenor; Martyn Hill & Paul Elliott, tenors.  Very fine singing from these notable personages!.  Two familiar names in the instrumental line-up are Christopher Hogwood & Nigel North.The highpoints for me were the second group of five dances (Track 5) by Mainerio; they reminded me very much of what I might hear from an oldtime square dance in the USA .  Vocally I really liked all but especially Track 6 by Porta "Corda deo dabimus"  and Track 11 "O Beate Benedicte" by Grandi.The  performance was impeccable and inspirational, certainly to the Early Music lover.  The accompanying information is all-inclusive and translation supplied in English when necessary.

The ensemble Voces Aequales is comprised of six male singers who came together in 1993, under this name to perform the sacred vocal music of the Renaissance.Valentin Bakfark was a Transylvanian composer and  an outstanding lutenist in the 16th century.  Although his output  was rather small, his fame spread from the French court and all the way to VILNIUS and many places in between.  His lute music is in the form of intabulations which originate from pre-existing polyphonic vocal pieces for the lute.In this recording, the vocal ensemble Voces Aequales takes an unusual approach to Bakfarks' intabulations; the latter are performed first by lutenist, Istvan Gyori and are followed by the vocal original performed by the vocal ensemble.  These are alternated throughout the disc.One must give 'kudos' to the Voces Aequales for skill and creativity, because what they have done is produce an album of lute music for the voice.  However, no matter how faithful Bakfark's intabulations are implemented, they sound nothing like the vocal originals. I am presently searching for an album in which Voces Aequales performs in a more traditional manner, for their skill is obvious!The accompanying booklet  is in English, French, German; and includes the words to all the songs.

The influence of Raphael (1483-1520)has probably exceeded that of any other painter in history.  For centuries his works were revered as perfect models of grace and harmony, to the point where every kitsch Madonna felt obliged to plunder his manner and techniques.  On this CD, the world of Raphael is given a musical perspective with a selection of pieces that he might have heard frequently in his era.Well into the 16th century, the musicians at the Northern Italian courts were mostly French or Flemish.  The native Italian tradition is represented by songs known as "frottoli", with their melodic top part, instrumental accompaniment and strong harmonic bass; a form which would eventually develop into the Italian Madrigal.The music on this disc mixes frottoli with the more complex French Chansons.  The two more familiar composers represented are Alexander Agricola and Josquin Desprez.  There are 7 other composers who have made excellent contributions to this recording and several anonymous selections are present.  They are all quite unique and entertaining with very interesting combinations of instruments and voices, both in combination and in solo spots.Some of the highpoints for me are:  Track 6: "je suis d'allemagne-je suis trop" an exuberant solo voice singing over a sustained string tone.  Track 10: "Carro della morte" features the unaccompanied entire solo vocal ensemble; beautiful to hear.  AND  Track 14: "Non e tempo" entire ensemble with light string accompaniment.  In truth there was one only instrumental selection I did not like; no need to mention it because YOU may like it.  This is really a 'listening gem'.The singers and musicians of Ensemble Unicorn perform infectiously with much gusto when needed and display all the qualities of sensitive and musical individuals.  The accompanying booklet is quite informative with translations of the libretto when needed.

The pieces on this recording reflect the constant glacial movement of longing that found expression through the images of women in medieval England:  women as sacred, women as beloved, women as regal, women as hunted, women as sorrowful, and women as triumphant...and the kaleidoscopic tensions ensuing from the yearning to express.This disc dates from 1996, and was one of the first opportunities for the world to hear the American vocal ensemble Lionheart.  It was constructed as something of a concept album-quite rare in some respects-of 'Images of Medieval Women.  The images being: The Beloved, The Unfathomable, The Maternal, The Desired and The Triumphant.  Within these categories one will find music by  composers such as: John Dunstable, William Cornysh, Richard Pygott, John Browne along with several Sarum Chants and anonymous contributions.Interspersed throughout the disc are movements from the Sarum Chant, which was the prevailing Catholic Plainsong in use in England with until the time of the Reformation.  The Plainsongs serve as the disc's connecting theme in the exploration of the feminine images.Lionheart, a six member male is ensemble is notable of the purity of its articulation and for the tonal blend and balance it puts forth.  These traits allow the singers to respond  with the special sounds required in both the Sarum Chant and the bawdier settings.  Though the composer Cornysh is responsible for the most emotional utterances as in 'Adew mes amours', it is John Browne's contribution, which is the 14 minute setting "Oregina mundi clara", that is the most moving of all.  And Lionheart sings all of this music with much feeling and skill that makes for inspirational listening!Of all the male vocal ensembles I have encountered recently in my Early Music searches, this one pleases me the most! From my first hearing of the album 'Tydings Trew', I was 'hooked'.  GO FOR IT, especially if you love Early Music.  The accompanying booklet is in English and includes pertinent information as well as the libretto.

This two CD package is the 7th volume of vocal music in the series of recordings that comprise the work of Dietrich Buxtehude (c1637-1707)from acclaimed early music specialist Ton Koopman and Amsterdam Baroque.  It features chorale settings, arias, ciacconas, concertos and a cantata.These vocal works of Buxtehude showcase all major genres used in the Lutheran Church during the last half of the seventeenth century.  Included are particular chorale settings, concertos on biblical texts, arias on contemporary sacred poetry, dialogues and composite forms such as concertos, arias and cantatas.  The performers, both singers and instrumentalists, are highly skilled and together have created an excellent and enjoyable program.  There are six singers:  Sopranos are A.Dieltiens, G. Samann,  D. Wolgemuth;  male alto Maarten Engeltges; tenor Tilman Lichdi, and bass Klaus Mertens.  Engeltjes is one of the best countertenors of the younger generation; his sound much like his teacher Michael Chance with whom he has studied and may still be.  Bass Klaus Mertens has long been outstanding in his contributions through the years.  There are seven instrumentalists who play:  violin, viola, viola da gamba, violone,dulcian, lute and organ.There are many interesting vocal combos as well as solos that comprise these two discs.  Some of the highpoints for me were: Track one on disc one:  the selection for alto, tenor and bass "An Filius non est Dei" BuxWV6. The music itself is incredibly attractive and was sung with much vigor by Engeltjes, Lichdi and Mertens. On Track 5 was Klag-lied sung with much feeling by Engeltjes. This BW76 is a  strophic aria setting with a highly expressive melody for voice, strings and continuo, on a text written by Buxtehude on the death of his father.  Engeltjes more than did it justice.  On Disc 2, track 2 Lichdi, tenor sang the "Quemadodum desiderat servus BuxWV92" gloriously!  There were many other highpoints for me but I am sure if you purchase this album you will find many of your own!The accompanying booklet includes pertinent information and translation in English, German and French.  This is a quality recording as the BBC Music Magazine states:"Koopman and his Amsterdam forces get the scale of the music just right, providing a compelling example of how less can be more.  Voices and instruments.....weave a seductive skein of tender music-making." February, 2014.

With the Hilliard Ensemble's retirement in sight you can look for many reissues and combinations of recordings from the past and there are MANY MANY  of these.  These three discs are as follows:  CD One=  Johannes Ockeghem:  Requiem (Missa pro defunctis) & Missa Mi-mi(1984) with the corps group of singers who are:  David James (countertenor),  Roger Covey-Crump, Leigh Nixon & John Potter (tenors); Michael George, David Beavan (basses) and Paul Hillier baritone and director. A welcome addition to the group was countertenor, Michael Chance, whose mellow lush sounds took away some of the harshness of James's usual tone quality.  This exact recording in its entirety is still available on the Marketplace.CD TWO =  Josquin Desprez "Motets and Chansons"  This is really a group of selections taken from two recordings (still available) entitled Josquin Desprez: Missa Hercules Dux Ferrariae and Josquin Desprez: Motets and Chansons.  (1983). The singers on this recording are:  David James, Ashley Stafford (added personnel) countertenors; Covey-Crump, Leigh Nixon & Paul Elliott (added personnel) (tenors), Michael Goerge (bass), Paul Hiller, bass.CD THREE (MY personal favorite).  Orlande de Lassus :  "Penitential Psalms"(1985)  However, this is only the second disc from the original two disc recording.  This inludes only Psalms 4, 5, 6, and 7. Thankfully on this recording Michael Chance is assisting David James on countertenor making a great contribution to the overall sound quality of the treble.  The only  other added personnel appears to be Charles Daniels on tenor (another welcome addition) and Gordon Jones on baritone.  The original recording of the entire Penitential Psalms is available on the Marketplace at the moment at a reasonable price.  But it changes from day to day.  Even though I already own the Ockeghem and the Lassus I decided since my recordings are of long standing it would be prudent to purchase this combo.I cannot honestly say that this group has always been one of my chosen ensembles, but for many listeners, that may not be the case.  I simply find that unless the treble sound is modified by the addition of a more pleasant sounding voice, I can't deal with it for very long.  But let me end with some comment from GRAMOPHONE MAGAZINE who are surely more skilled than I am in assessing these recordings.GRAMOPHONE MAGAZINE: " To be treasured by anyone who wants the best of Renaissance music authoritatively performed....The blend between the voices is finely controlled, the tone mellow and the tuning spectacularly accurate, giving rise to an organ-like sonority that is genuinely thrilling."

Of course, I am referring to that six-male ensemble "LIONHEART". My first encounter with this group was by way 0f the Recording "Tydings Trew" which was noted by the New York Times with the following commentary:  "rich true tones and flawlessly blended harmonies...superb articulation and impeccable sense of rhythm". And it's all true: to hear an American ensemble with this absolute perfection in performance is a marvel, for most of my years have been spent buying European ensembles (which I will still buy, for there are many quality ensembles all over the world).  But for a long time in USA the one outstanding ensemble was Chanticleer which remains on my excellent list.On this disc "El Siglo de Oro" (The Century of Gold), Lionheart explores the seldom performed sacred music of 16th century Spain related to the eclectic, multi-cultural city of Toledo: from the worldly sounds of Cristabal Morales to the roguish Andalusian exuberance of Francisco Guerrero. This intense, mystical music thrived in the Old World and gained wide acceptance in the New World.The six very fine voices in this group belong to:  Lawrence Lipnik, countertenor; John Olund & Michael Ryan-Wenger, tenors; Jeffrey Johnson, Richard Porterfield, baritones and Kurt-Owen Richards, bass. Their blend is uncanny, the balance is perfect, the diction precise, the phrasing exceptionally musical, the dynamics appropriate to the music;  the overall effect is very entertaining to the listener; especially those attuned to the Early Music era.The booklet includes pertinent information in English which includes the translation of the libretto.

Cain is beating a dead horse as the saying goes, when she keeps reviving the evil Gretchen and aligning her with Archie, who, in my opinion lost his mind a couple of books ago. This book overdoes the sex, the perversion, and includes action that at times is so absurd as to be surreal.  Even at the beginning of the story I lost interest in the entire scenario; it was mundane and unoriginal.  Moreover, the story plods along just waiting for the next vulgar and boring development.  It's time to go in other direction, probably with new characterizations.  This book left a really bad taste in my psyche!

"This music is at once mystical and earthy, romantic and aloof, surreal and mundane, gay and morbid by turns drenched in (as the famous Spanish  expression says) 'son y sombra' - sun and shadow".  Spanish and Portuguese Music of the Golden Age.  The design herein is in the form of a three-act play using as music songs and instrumental pieces typical of the time.  This should please the historically minded listener with its evocation of the Iberian nations at the height of their imperial splendor and also the world music listener with its instantly memorable melodies and highly infectious rhythms from the European culture.The Waverly Consort is outstanding for its ability to assemble  highly varied and interesting programs, and this disc is certainly speaks to this ability.  There are selections six of which are completely instrumental very cleverly arranged and immediately engaging.  The instruments used throughout the disc, also including the accompaniment are:  recorder, harp, gemshorn, percussion, vihuela, baroque guitar, citole, psaltery, bass viol, kemence, vielle & violone, that require the skills of four players.Varied combinations of voices are used involving the following singers:  2 sopranos=Phoebe Alexander & Shannon Anderson; mezzo soprano=Carolann Buff; countertenor & baritone= Bruce Rameker;  tenors=Wm. Hudson & Andrew Ranson; Baritone= Gregory Purnhagen.  The voices are very open-sounding and energetic as befits this type of music; great performance from all the singers.The Waverly Consort on this recording performs overall with its customary style providing their usual vigorous and tuneful interpretations.  There is an excellent and highly detailed booklet  that includes pertinent information as well the complete text, which you will definitely want to read before listening to the disc. The Spanish text is translated into English.I could not resist including the closing paragraph of the colorful booklet which so wonderfully incorporates and describes the upbeat and delightful music that is on this recording:  " Now we invite you to our "Comedia de la Vida" - a play about Life.  You will meet highborn people: brave 'cavalleros' - knights in exile or on chivalric missions - and the women who love them in their absence.  Elsewhere there are not so noble: peasants, country bumpkins, and their amorous companions.  And of course, there is dance music; chaconas, canaries, villanios, jacaras, folias, cumbees - Ole!"

"A leopard on familiar terrain, he moved  on silent feet through still rooms and along airless corridors. Not once did he have to pause, uncertain, and feel his way forward in the darkness; the route was one he had played out in his imagination a thousand times.  His eyes burned in their sockets, and a maniacal grin distorted the curve of his jaw into a twisted demonic parody of joy.  Already, in his mind's eye, he could see Strozzi's startled eye springing open, wide in terror,as the sudden hand clamped over his mouth and, a second later, the honed blade sliced through the cords....It was to be the sweetest moment of his  revenge."  from 'The Last Castrato'.The above paragraph is the brand of excellent descriptive writing you will experience if you read this novel, and you MUST read it if you are of the ilk mentioned in my introductory heading. There is nothing trite about this novel.  Rather it contains all of the best attributes: a plausible and unique plot that moves forward and not once bogs down;  good characterizations that are well-developed but not belabored; and a satisfactory ending of it all.  This for me was an "I can't put it down novel"..  And it's one that I will hang on to and definitely read it again in a few years.  And you certainly can't balk at the present price.  Even If you decide you don't like it (which I doubt) you haven't lost much money.  So 'Try it , you'll like it'

'these selections are Spanish works that were widely copied in the Old World as well as the New, and there's none of the African or Amerindian influence that began to creep into Spanish music in Central and South America.  However, it is no less interesting and it even offers some of the fascinating mixture of sacred and secular elements that makes the New World repertory so unique.  The Spanish were quick to copy Italian trends thus making these pieces hard to distinguish from Italian solo cantatas from the same era.The composers represented on this recording are generally new to non-Spanish audiences, and form a chain of teachers and students beginning with Diego Xaraba y Bruno, born around 1650;  director Banzo hypothesizes him to be the composer of the only keyboard work on this album.  The other three works are sacred cantatas that correspond to Italian works from around the time of A. Scarlatti to perhaps the end of Vivaldi's lifetime.  The two composers are:  Joseph de Nebra (1702-1768);Joseph de Torres (1670-1738).The text and the music of these cantatas spawn a perfect fusion of sacred and secular. The  music, in fact, is quite sensuous, the flavor of which makes the listener want to hear MORE!  Countertenor, Carlos Mena, with his deep dark and somewhat sensuous voice is a perfect choice to sing this deep dark and sensuous music.  He is able to capture the music's occasional dark shadings and the indefinable philosophical tone that mark Spanish music.  Mena and the String Ensemble Al Ayre Espanol together are perfectly attuned to each other as well as to the various stylistic threads in the music.The disc is accompanied by a detailed booklet that includes the text in German, English and French.  The text takes some time to comprehend and though it is possible, I read it through just once ,  then ignored it and simply listened to the music, which is expressive and elegant and very well performed!

The music selected for this recording belongs to the great repertory of the late fifteenth century Spanish Renaissance making use of several composers, the most familiar being Tomas Luis de Victoria (1548-1611), Francisco Guerrero (1528-1599), Alonso Lobo (1555-1617), Cristobel de Morales (1500-1553), Juan Esquivel (1563-1613), Francisco de Penalosa (1470-1528) and Juan de Anchieta (1462-1523).This program is presented according to the fourteen Stations of the Cross that is included in the Catholic Encyclopedia.  These stations are used to signify a series of pictures representing certain scenes in the Passions of Christ each corresponding to a particular incident with each representation.  This form of devotion is carried out by passing from station to station with certain prayers at each meditation with various incidents in turn.The disc itself is a musical pilgrimage, in which every station is connected to a Motet.  Daria Tabbia (direction) explains in the brief booklet notes IN German & English;  " the texts have been chosen imagining each motet pronounced by a character present at the stations of the cross".  This means that we must hear -apart from Jesus, himself - Pilate, Simon of Cyrene, Mary Magdalena, Peter and Judas, all mentioned in the Gospels , but also Veronica and a wayfarer, mythological figures which don't appear in the Gospels.  The text is set by Julian Romero, a contemporary composer who has also set the text and composed the music for the Introduction and the ending.  Romero's music is modern, but not too far out of step with the rest of the program.The five excellent singers of Daltrocanto are:  Alena Dantcheva, soprano; Alessandro Carmignani, male alto; Gianluca Ferrarini, tenor; Marco Scavazza, baritone.  The ensemble gives a fine performance of these notable composers' selections; their voices blend well and the individual singers are highly responsive to the varied styles of composition.  Listening to this was an inspirational experience for me, personally and may be for others also.  This group has really not made many recordings; at least I haven't located many others.  Maybe somebody out there can enlighten me!

Michael Chance has done it again: rendered to us a Master Performance of lute songs that is truly an emotional ride that includes precise and accurate diction accompanied by the highs and lows that the words demand, and all delivered with his strong and resonant tone quality.  This is musicianship at its highest level and what I have always expected from him for the last forty years, since I first heard him in 1973 with the King's  College Choir.  If there is such a thing as the X Factor, he more than meets it.  I have another recording of the complete works of John Danyel recorded in 1994 sung very well indeed by Nigel Short accompanied by a fine lutenist David Miller.  And I may still pull it out every now and then for comparison purposes.  However, Chance just engages me immediately no matter what he sings.The path of John Danyel (1564-1626), born one year after John Dowland (considered by many to be the greatest of the English lute song writers)is very similar to that of Dowland.  Danyel published his songbook in 1606, the very year that Dowland returned permanently to England from Denmark, and it is curious to see just how closely Danyel's work follows that of Dowland's third book. The excellent liner notes with this package go into much detail in this comparison.Danyel's songs run the gamut of emotions:  "Can Doleful Notes?" (Unmeasured grief); "Eyes Look No More" (pessimism-affliction-hopelessness); "love in all its forms and moods "Coy Daphne Fled", "Drop Not Mine Eyes",  and the more recorded songs by other singers: "Like as the lute Delights", "Grief Keep Within", "Stay, cruel Stay" .It's really quite a mixed bag of sentiments and Chance is an expert at conveying them to you and to me.Don't miss out on this terrific lute song presentation, also featuring Paul Beier (American)an expert who plays a tasty lute.  He has also recorded a stunning disc with  Chance, M. Huggett, B. Dickey entitled : "Con Gratia Et Maniera", weird title but a totally engrossing recording.  Just hearing Bruce Dickey on cornet does it for me!EARLY MUSIC REVIEW, DECEMBER, 2013:  "Danyel's songs represents the very best of this wonderful repertoire...Chance takes great pains to articulate every word beautifully...undoubted artistry."MUSIC WEB INTERNATIONAL, January 2, 2014: "These performances are very much aligned with the tradition of voice and lute...The gain, I suppose, is a greater sense of sheer intimacy, and other musicians have taken this path as well.  In that respect there are few better guides than Michael Chance. He has a feeling of awareness for Elizabethan and Stuart lyrics second to none."

Three totally diverse personalities both in life and in character contribute to this highly entertaining recording.  EMMANUELE d'ASTORGA (1680-c.1757) , a self-taught composer who never held a musical post, managed to compose chamber cantatas that were very well liked in the 18th century, the STABAT  MATER (on this disc)  accounted for much of his popularity, that actually accounted for a veritable Astorga cult in the 19th century..  Many tales are included about Astorga's life style in the informative booklet that comes with this package.FRANCESCO DURANTE (1684-1755);  his prolific output makes him the most considerable Italian church music composer of the late Baroque, and he was a gifted and influential teacher; in fact Pergolesi was one of his students.  GIOVANNI BATTISTA PERGOLESI (1710-1736); no other composer has achieved so much of permanent value in a public career of barely four years.Though different were their lives, and contrasting their characters, they all had one thing in common: their affiliation to a locally defined manner of composing generally described by historians as the "Neapolitan school".  This designation refers to the fact that the Naples opera influenced greatly Oratorio and church music in the 18th century.  Tunes were taken from secular music; harmony was dominated by clear major-minor tonality.  Such characteristics are to be found throughout these three compositions in the Neapolitan style.Hengelbrock's unique, often offbeat, but always scholarly approached and researched, manner is refreshing in a musical world that too often has a 'sameness' about it, not only as to programming, but also as to manner of implementation,  This disc is a good example of originality both in content and performance.Hengelbrock's choruses are beyond excellent; balance is superb; all parts are clearly heard; sound quality with his penchant for using male altos creates a solid harmony at that level without the treble overwhelming the inner parts;  this makes for an incredibly rich and solid sound.  They sing expressively, all parts resonant and diction clear.  His soloists are usually taken from his Balthasar-Neumann Chorus.  Exception on this album is the soprano:  Ann Monoyios.The package is accompanied by an excellent booklet with pertinent information in English, and German.  This music is truly a joy to hear!!!!!

This disc consists of 22 landmark selections from  Hesperion  XX's various programs of music of the 12th to 14th centuries.  Notable composers represented:  Alfonso X El Sabio, Guillame Dufay, Eustache Du Caurroy, Orlando Lasso, Francisco Guerrero, Christopher Tye and Cristobal De Morales;  several anonymous works included also.Several instrumental selections, various vocal combinations, but not enough to satisfy me.  The vocalists, although  quite skilled as one would expect from Savall's offerings, did not have much to contribute , except for Montserrat Figueras, soprano, whose singing combines lyrical spontaneity, grace and a certain melancholy quality in her superb renditions.The Ensemble "La Capella Reial de Catalunya"  was featured in only two of the twenty two composition, which was a great disappointment to me, although perhaps not to everyone.  But for me, alas, this is  not a five star disc.  Also, the booklet, unlike Savall's usual packaging includes limited information about the music and no text whatsoever.  Booklet language is French, Spanish, German and English.  I did recognize several selections from other recordings that I own.  I can't say the performance was poor, because it was well-done  I just didn't like the program!  But many would like it I am certain.

CRISTOBAL DE MORALES (1500-1553): wrote music of an austere manner for the Church as heard on this disc via "Officium Defunctorum" , "In Secundo Nocturno" and "Missa Pro Defunctis" performed herein by:  La Capella Reial De Catalunya= four countertenors, four tenors, four baritones and two basses.  Accompaiment  Hesperion XXThis disc is my personal favorite mainly because the music is so smooth with no sharp treble edges; take note all the singers are male ( I do like female voices, but not in this type of setting.  Each disc in this package varies the singers as well as the instruments.FRANCISCO GUERRERO (1528-1599): wrote secular pieces as well as the usual sacred works; this disc includes only his sacred compositions such as "Ave Maria", "Pater Noster" and "O Laudate Dominum", mostly short works. Vocal ensemble includes: two sopranos, one mezzo soprano, one male contralto, three countertenors, four tenors, one baritone and two basses; accompanied by Hesperion XX.TOMAS LUIS DE VICTORIA (1548-1611): wrote only sacred music; his first twenty masses are among the finest examples of Renaissance music, and his Office for Holy Week has a drama and poignancy rarely equaled during the 16th century; this disc includes some very familiar works such as his "Ave Maria", "Salve , Regina" and "O Magnum Mysterium".  Most examples are short works with all sorts of vocal combinations present  Vocal Ensemble: two sopranos, one Mezzo soprano, one contralto, three countertenors, two tenors, two baritones and one bass. accompanied by a smaller group of Hesperion XX.As is usual with Savall, the packaging is beyond reproach including as it does all details of the recording:  who is performing when and in what framework.  JUST TERRIFIC!  And the implementation beyond belief in its perfection.  Booklet languages: Spanish, English, French, German and Latin.  I really can't get enough of playing these discs!!!!!

These four CD's must not be missed by the serious music lover and indeed those who love to hear both the familiar and the unfamiliar in Christmas music.  In short, there is absolutely something for everyone in this package.  The performers are tried and true:  Alfred Deller and the Deller  Consort and Musica Antiqua of Vienna.  The spirit of heartfelt tribute to the miracle of this festive season pervades the four discs.CD ONE= comprises carols most beloved in England and United States today;  second half of this disc contain carols in England from Medieval times through the Stuarts, including the earliest known carols such as the 16th century song "Winter-Rose" and the 14th century "IN Dulci  Jubilo"..CD TWO=the universality of Christmas is reflected in the wealth of folk and popular carols included in this disc and becomes a musical revelation as these fine performers recreate a sense of history with their unique interpretations of such carols as "Deck the Hall"," Hark! The Herald Angels Sing" and the" Lute-Book Lullaby" to list just a few.CD THREE=The unifying theme is this disc is the Nativity and the adoration of the Virgin Mary which include such carols as "Nowell, Nowell; Tydings True", "Blessed be thou Heavenly Queen" and "There is no rose of such Virtue".CD FOUR=this disc illustrates the blossoming of European music from the Middle Ages to the Renaissance; some of the works include "In Nativitate Domni" for 4 voices by Pedro De Escobar(16th century), "Sancta Maria"  by John Dunstable (15th century) and "Maria Zart" by Ludwig Senfl (16th century).The Deller consort on these discs included: Alfred Deller, director and counter-tenor, Honor Shepherd (soprano), Mark Deller(countertenor), Robert Tear (tenor) and Maurice Bevan (baritone).  Fine singers all singing in solo position as well as in many other vocal combinations; all glorious!,MUSICA ANTIQUA OF VIENNA Dr. Rene Clemencic, director.  Recorders, cornetto, mandora (a lute type instrument), trombone, pommer, krummhorn, fiddle, organ, bells and drums.This  is definitely my favorite purchase for this past Christmas season, and I still am listening off and on.  Is accompanied by a very detailed booklet all inclusive containing a vast amount of interesting information IN ENGLISH.

If any of you recall the film of several years ago about Mozart entitled "Amadeus" in which the Emperor in responding to whether he liked Mozart's latest opera replied: "too many notes".  This came into my mind after wading through about half of this book.  The story fascinates for a while but nothing new occurs without paragraphs and paragraphs of repeated information reiterated by different characters.  It distressed me that I had  to skip and skim entire pages in order to move the action forward.  I "hung in there" to the end and wondered why I had bothered at all.However,  having been part of the Music School scene for many years I did appreciate the author's insight as to the inner passions and conflicts that can and do take place in this type of setting.  I think a good editor could make this book much more palatable.  Just my humble opinion.

Michael Chance has done it again:  rendered to us a Master Performance of lute songs that is truly an emotional ride that includes  precise and accurate diction as well the emotional highs and lows that the words demand, and all delivered with his strong and resonant tone quality.  This is musicianship at its highest level and what I have always expected from him for the last forty years, since I first heard him in 1973 in the King's College Choir.  If there is such a thing as an X Factor, he more than meets it.  I have another recording of these same songs (the only other one,by the way) recorded in 1994 sung very well indeed by Nigel Short accompanied by a fine lutenist David Miller.  And I may still pull it out every now and then for comparison purposes.  However, Chance just engages me immediately In whatever he sings.The path of John Danyel (1564-1626) , born one year after John Dowland, who is considered the greatest of the English lutenist songwriters, is very similar to that of Dowland's ,  Danyel published his songbook in 1606, the very year that Dowland returned  permanently to England from Denmark, and it is curious to see just how closely Danyel's  work follows that of Dowland's Third Book.  The liner notes go into much detail about the similarities of specific songs, that the interested person can peruse.Danyels' songs run the gamut of emotions:  'Can Doleful notes?" (unmeasured grief); "Eyes Look No More" (pessimism-affliction-hopelessness).;  love in all its forms and moods "Coy Daphne Fled',  "Drop not mine Eyes' and the more recorded songs by other singers:  "Like as the lute delights", 'Grief, keep within' , "Stay Cruel Stay".  It's really quite a mixed bag of emotions and Chance is an expert at conveying them to you and me.I reviewed this from a CD, not purchased from Amazon, because they haven't listed it in this format, and I was tired of waiting. so I ordered it from England where there are several dealers selling, not as inexpensive as the Marketplace, but I don't know if it will ever appear here.  Don't miss out on this wonderful recording also with Paul Beier, an expert (American) who plays a very tasty lute.  He has also recorded a stunning disc with Chance, Huggett and Dickey entitled:"Con Gratia Et Maniera", a weird title but a totally interesting recording.  Just hearing Bruce Dickey on cornet does it for me.

"In the beginning was the Word''..Actually, in the beginning there was the voice, the instrument of communication, communicating to each other everything , in short, that which characterizes man's feelings.  And uniting all of this with music have come secular and religious works: chants, canticles, hymns, psalms, motets, cantatas, airs and songs.  Vocal music is a reflection of its time, crossing the centuries to reveal emotion, particularly its religious side in which it forms an obvious prayer.  Thus, on this recording which begins with Alfonso X. El Sabio all the way to Mozart and Haydn, the Vox Aeterna (Eternal voice)  speaks to us, moves us, making itself the intermediary of our own feelings.Jordi Savall and his various ensembles have shed new light year after year showing many works to their advantage.  In his quest for authenticity, rereading of manuscripts, the choice of instrumentation and his innovative interpretations, he has uncovered hidden treasures for all of us.
