His recordings are astounding in their implementation and provide the listener with highly interesting aural experiences.There are 12 selections on this disc each of which is totally separated from each other as far as performers and composers.  I will list them because unfortunately Amazon does not bother to do so.  WHAT A SURPRISE!!!!1. ALFONSO X EL SABIO:Pero Cantigas De Loor in which all participate.  2.  GUILLAUME DUFAY: Veni Sancto Spirito featuring Monserrat Figueras, soprano and Kar Wessel countertenor  3..EL CANT DE LA SIBILLA  Sibiilla catalane  featuring Figueras and complete ensemble.  4..CRISTOBEL DE MORALES  Lectio II  Ensemble  5. FRANCISCO GUERRERO  Ave Maria soloists 2 sopranos, I male contralto, one countertenor, 2 tenors, 1 baritone and 1 BASS.  6.  TOMAS LUIS DE VICTORIA  O Magnum Mysterium  ensemble  7.  MONTEVERDI  Ave Maris stella  with 2 sopranos, 1 countertenor, 3 tenors, 1 baritone and 1 bass.  8.  CEREROLS  Missa pro defulnctis with 2 sopranos, 2 tenors, 2 baritones and one bass.  9.  CHARPENTIER Prelude to Salve Regina (instrumental) and Salve Regina with the magnificient voices of Gerard Lesne, ct., John Elwes, tenor and Josep Cabre baritone.  THIS SELECTION WAS OUTSTANDING IN EVERY WAY!!! 10.  BACH  BWV 1068 Instrumental (not my favorite Bach rendition)  11.  MOZART Requiem Aetermam  instrumental well-performed but again not my favorite Mozart delivery/  12.  HAYDN Seven Last words with vocal speaker; very impressive.This recording is a work of art though it is a compilation from other discs, but for the most part I liked the contents.  Very little information came with the recording.; only a booklet with the program listing with the participants and one page of introduction; in English, French, Spanish, German and Italian.

This early release ( 1982-83) is entirely devoted to dual specialties by the ensemble Chanticleer from San Francisco:  THE RENAISSANCE  and CHRISTMAS.  The music  consists of holiday and sacred music drawn from the canons of DesPrez, Byrd, Di Lasso and others of this caliber.  Rather than the usual fare we are dealing here with more subdued texture and mood of chant or counterpoint as in De Lasso' s "Resonet in laudibus" glorifying the birth of Jesus.  This composition contains several sections that have distinct rhythmic shifts and complex countermelodies;  it expands in dimension with each listening.  Taverner's "Kyrie" implies the subtle majesty of a processional, the melody ascending in supplication.Two selections I particularly enjoyed:  William Byrd's "Sing joyfully unto God" a jubilant motet whose vocal lines dance to the text and climax in a trumpet-like fanfare before returning to the stately close;  AND Giovanni Nanino's "Diffusa est gratia" a sophisticated antiphon to the Virgin which sets its sensual psalm text with classic High Renaissance style and spirituality.However, what really caused me to buy this particular Chanticleer disc ( I have many)  was the quality of the singers, my main interests being the top voices that can be very harsh and overpowering in music of this type, but not these guys.  In both groups the lead top singers (countertenors) are Louis Botto and Randall Wong and they are SUPERB in every way; good blend, good sound, good interpretation;  the other singers are also high quality and though not all are present in each of the two groups it makes no difference for it's all wonderfully sung.  This first group has 12 singers and the second group has ten singers.If you are an Early Music lover don't miss out on this very fine recording; who knows how long it will be available????But keep in mind that this is not your usual Christmas Fare!

Orlando de Lassus (1532-1594) was one of the most prolific and versatile composers of the High Renaissance.  He excelled in every branch of vocal music, sacred and secular;  his numerous compositions included French, German and Italian polyphonic songs, about 60 Masses, four Passions, over 100 Magnificat settings and about 500 motets which are generally regarded as his finest works.  His religious writings were serious, meditative and almost somber, as witness his moving setting of SEVEN PENITENTIAL PSALMS (an excellent recording of this work is by the Hilliard Ensemble 1985 EMI).This astonishing work LAGRIME DI SAN PIETRO (the tears of St.Peter)may be one  of his greatest compositions.  It is a setting of a twenty verse poem by the Italian poet, Luigi Tansillo (Pub. 1560) to which Lassus added a final motet.  The poet Tansillo imagines the grief beyond grief that Peter feels after he has actively denied Christ three times before the cock crows;  an intensely emotional thought for contemplation!  The final motet is the response of Christ while on the cross to St. Peter, the final words being:  "And though the outward pain be great, the internal agony is graver still when I find you ungrateful".  Thus for St. Peter there is no ecstasy following his agony.This work is Lassus' swansong, for at this point in his life he was suffering from depression and frequent bouts of 'melancholy', a condition which involved many physical and/or emotional manifestations..  In addition, he was much concerned about his declining health; understandable given the fact that his sense of musical mischief and taste for scandalous subject matter, abundant, especially in his French secular music, may have put him in a penitential mood as he came closer to his demise.  This final composition reflects an unclothed confessional manner as well as an architecture that reveals a series of devotional gestures.  It is as if Lassus in this modern day was driving in the country and saw one of the many road signs posted here and there that say: PREPARE TO MEET THY GOD!As one listens to this work there is a sense of sameness of style; there are no sharp edges of sound.  The musical phrases echo the natural rhythms of speech, which do not include florid embellishments or melisma.  Lines of text are repeated for emphasis, and are sung antiphonally (between alternating groups of singers) where it is appropriate. As compared to other Lassus compositions it seems bland and I guess I miss the occasional touch of humor that appears in many other of his compositions, both religious and sacred, though in this work it would indeed be difficult to find a spot for any form of levity.The word Gallicantus means song or cock crow as derived from the ancient Monastic office held just before dawn.  It evokes the renewal of life offered by the coming day. Gallicantus is a seven voice all-male choir (most of the time); their members come with a wealth of experience in this genre of consort singing.  They as well as their director, Gabriel Crouch, are bound by a shared love that draws unifying themes within diverse repertoire, a difficult task to be sure!  To their advantage they have in the ensemble two very fine countertenors, namely Marc Chambers, who possesses a non-invasive but solid soprano sound, and David Allsopp, who has a refined and elegant lower register.  This, of course, adds greatly to the overall blend and balance of parts by not allowing the top line to disturb the polyphonic balance.This is the fourth recording by this group which I have been following since the first disc released in 2009.  All are listed on Amazon and I have reviewed all of them.  They have given me an inordinate amount of pleasure. FANFARE MAGAZINE QUOTE: "England is blessed with a multitude of fine Early Music ensembles but this one (Gallicantus) immediately rises to the forefront."The accompanying booklet supplies excellent information in English ;  text & translation to English included.

(re-release of a 1997 DVD at a much cheaper price)Even after three centuries, the music of Monteverdi glows with the passionate genius of a musical prophet.  He was far ahead of his day in his conception of music as a dramatic, expressive art, and in the realization of that conception.  The score of L'Orfeo, first printed in 1609, records the events of its first performance at the Mantuan court in 1607. A unique aspect of the score is the wealth of information about the development of the 'continuo orchestra'.  It is this combination - the human voice of Orfeo and the 'heavenly lyre' which accompanies him - which  established opera as an art form that continues to fascinate us today.  But beyond the enchantment of Orfeo's 'heavenly lyre', is the immediacy and truth of his human voice that rivets our attention and moves our hearts.The opera begins with the character 'La Musica' the allegorical embodiment of music, presents herself to the princely company and announces a drama in which the power of music will occupy the center of the stage; it is the story of Orpheus who conquered the Underworld with his lyre and his singing.  As this 'fable in music'(as Monteverdi called it) unfolds, we are exposed to the entire gamut of emotions, from the most euphoric to the most dejected, presented in musical language that is perhaps closer to human speech the recitative has ever been, before or since.The story of Orpheus has been done and redone by many composers through the centuries, although it remains essentially the same: Orfeo;s beloved Euridice dies and Orpheus goes into the Underworld to find her. He is escorted there by "La Speranza" (Hope), who leaves him at the gates of the Underworld to be met by Charon, the boatman who ferries him (albeit while sleeping) across the river to the realm of Pluto, where he pleads for Euridice's life. Moved by the singer's lament, Proserpine, Pluto's wife, convinces Pluto to allow Orpheus to take Euridice back, but with the condition that he not look back at her while she follows him,  or she will return to Death (what a silly condition!).  And, of course at her pleas for him to look at her, he losses her permanently.  Bu t in this version  Apollo, the father of Orpheus, comes down and invites his son to ascend with him into Heaven, where he will know joy and peace forever!  Not bad I Say! (I prefer Gluck's version in which Orpheus gets another chance and succeeds in getting Euridice returned to him).All performers acquit themselves skillfully with the singers providing excellent characterizations, but why not for they are mostly all experienced in this genre:  ORFEO-John Mark Ainsley, EURIDICE-Jaunita Lascarro, LA MESSANGIERA-Brigitte Balleys, APOLLO -Russel Smythe, LA MUSICA -David Cordier, LA SPERANZA-Michael Chance, CARONTE-Mario Luperi.  Tragicomedia, the accompanying ensemble, also experienced, perform neatly and accurately.  The choral group Concerto Palatine provide spirited choral renditions throughout the  opera.  An intense and refreshing performance by an expert cast sustained by the lead John Mark Ainsley  directed with obvious affection by Stephen Stubbs, provides us with some great Monteverdi music.  The beautifully styled, evocative stage production, rich with Pierre Audi's trademark accentuates the solemn serenity of Monteverdi's most famous work to create a moving and timeless audio-visual experience.Sung in Italian with English, French, German, Spanish, Italian and Dutch subtitles

NOT YOUR USUAL CHRISTMAS CHEER, but entertaining nonetheless!LIONHEART is one of AMERICA'S leading ensembles of vocal chamber music.  There are six male singers: one countertenor, two tenors, two baritones and one bass, all of whom sing individually with skill and intensity.  As an ensemble they perform with perfection with superb balance and blend.  Their diction both in the old English and the Latin is flawless as they render these highly interesting Medieval English Carols and Motets.  I didn't even need the liner notes to know what they were singing.While Christmas recordings these days lean heavily on Renaissance and Baroque works wanting to create an atmosphere that is quaint and warmly inviting, Lionheart herein presents a program focused on Medieval England that contains Hymns, Carols and Motets that go back to the 13th century.  They are sung in Latin and Old English, all of which is translated in the liner notes which are excellent and explanatory.  This is not simply a Christmas program, but a tour of the twelve days of Christmas, with pieces celebrating the various feasts and other commemorations that occur between Christmas and the Feast of Epiphany on Jan. 6.As I have indicated in my heading, it is not all seasonal cheeriness.  For example:  Two songs for the Feast of St. Stephen, honoring the first Christian martyr; Carols for the Feast of the Holy Innocents recall Herod's slaughter of children; and the colorful "Seynt Thomas Honour We" pays tribute to Thomas Becket, the Archbishop of Canterbury, and commemorates his murder by knights of King Henry II on December 29, 1170.  One must acknowledge that this is obviously not standard holiday fare, but a glimpse if traditions and attitudes of a distant era.  But having said all of this, I hasten to add that most of the music is indeed celebratory, just not in the ecstatic, commercial style of modern carols, rather in a more devotional and reverent way.There are some that you will find familiar, arranged somewhat more creatively than one usually hears; one such carol is "Lully lulla" which enchanted me in its implementation; just exquisitely presented.  The arrangements are quite unique and display a very arresting variety of techniques.  Sometimes small vocal ensembles begin to sound the same and  often it's because arranger/s seem to lack inspiration or whatever it takes to be able to present new ideas when confronted with a small ensemble that sings an extensive repertoire.  That's not a problem on this recording.WHAT A GREAT LISTEN THIS IS FOR THE EARLY MUSIC LOVER AND PARTICULARLY THE CONNOISSEUR OF MEDIEVEL MUSIC!NEW YORK TIMES-Allan Kozinn:  "Lionheart's vocal blend is as finely calibrated as ever, and the singers perform this repertory not as antiquarian curiosities but in a way that makes it sound vital and of the present."KANSAS CITY STAR-Mickey Coalwell:  "Lionheart's accomplishments appear almost miraculous. Perfect blend, tone production, phrasing and a host of dynamic subtleties characterize their singing.  Lionheart embodies the best qualities of the early-music movement..."

DE'LICIOUS, DE'LIGHTFUL, DE'LOVELY!  SINGPHONIKER'S CHRISTMAS CONTRIBUTION.Those of you looking for something new and different, check out Die Singphoniker's warm-hearted and clear-eyed performance of Christmas favorites hailing from all over Europe from Catalonia through Norway with , naturally,  many  songs from Germany.  Interspersed throughout the disc are three gently played harp solos by the skilled fingers of Irmgard Gorzawski.Die Singphoniker is a six-man vocal group which has been in existence for 25 years and has made nearly 30 CD's.  They have a wide-ranging repertoire from Gregorian chant to pop music.  Unlike groups such as Chanticleer and King's Singers their vocal make-up is more bottom-heavy having two tenors at the top rather than the two altos that the two former groups have.  However, the two tenors also double up on the alto when needed.  On this particular disc there are two guest basses in addition to the harpist.  The singers are:  Alfons Brandl (tenor); Hubert Nettinger (alto/tenor)on this disc for the most part sings in the alto range and I must commend him for his ability to switch from falsetto to chest voice even in mid-phrase, with ease and without a hint of a gear-change AND with a lovely tone quality on both sides of the divide!; Ludwig Thomas (baritone); Michael Mantaj (bass-baritone); Christian Schmidt (bass); Willi Pirzer (bass); Berno Scharpf (baritone); and Irmgard the harpist.The program consists of some familiar carols and some not so familiar, but all are arranged to please the ear and even the ones you might know are refreshingly unique.  The only one that does not seem to fit the overall plan is the American carol by Jester Hairston "Mary's Boy Child".  And there is one word change in the last line that is major because it changes the entire meaning of Christmas; it is sung as 'Man will live forever more because it's Christmas Day'  and it should read 'Man will live forever more because of Christmas Day.  I don't think it detracts from the recording, but it is noticeable to those of us who believe that mankind will survive because of the birth of Christ.  I think it was simply a mistake in the translation and I heard it and forgot it!Some of the notable carols are:  "The Green, Shining Tree": Edward Greig, Norway;  "O Sanctissima" ( O Most Holy, Italy);  "Il est ne, le devin Enfant" (He is born, the Holy Child-France); "Quanno Nascetto " (When the Child is born,Catalan) note the whistling in this one, very well done;  "We three kings of Orient Are" (England);  "Vom Himmel hoch" (From Heaven on High) Germany.  In truth all of the carols are delightful to hear and I especially enjoyed the unfamiliar examples.Overall the CD is interesting, well-performed and well recorded AND highly entertaining.  For the most part the song material is unique, and refreshing; the familiar carols are cleverly arranged and the unfamiliar carols charming.  The booklet notes are translated from German to English.Once you have heard this group you will no doubt be seeking out more of their recordings. Two that I have enjoyed and reviewed are :"Orlando di Lasso-lieder, chansons and madrigals";  "Hymnus-Orlando di Lasso".  This is all great fare for the Early Music Lover!

THE SEVEN PENITENTIAL PSALMS OF ORLANDO DI LASSUS WITH ALL THEIR GRANDEUR AND UNIQUENESS FORM ONE OF THE GREAT PEAKS OF 16TH CENTURY MUSIC.The ancient tradition of penitential prayer goes back to the early Middle Eastern civilization; it is deeply rooted in Jewish religious practice, from which it was adopted into Christianity. Duke Albrecht of Bavaria commissioned these psalms and in fact liked them so much that for a time he reserved them for his ear alone!  AND expressed his gratitude to Lassus in a very practical way by presenting him with several thousand gulden, enough to pay for Lassus's large house in Munich.The curious fate and unique character of Lassus's Psalms ensured that music history never lost sight of them throughout the centuries.  Such theorists as E.T.A. Hoffmann and A.F.J.Thibaut praised  this work 'for its simplicity, loftiness and majesty of expression', and stated 'that they were at a loss to imagine how even today these psalms could be better set to music.'  And with that statement I heartily agree!The penitential psalms are nos. 6, 31,37,50,101,129 and 142 in the enumeration of the Vulgate, and nos. 6,32,38,51,102,130 and 143 in most Protestant versions of the Bible. There is in the accompanying booklet a complete description of this work from which I have drawn some specifics.The performance mandates a small choice ensemble of handpicked virtuosos, capable of rendering every nuance of Lassus's expressive music, and the furthest remove from the massed choirs and giant orchestras of some performances in modern times.  The Hilliard Ensemble along with the Kees Boeke Consort fulfill this mandate to the letter, and beautifully so!The outstanding singers are:  countertenors=MICHAEL CHANCE, David James, Tenors=ROGERS COVEY CRUMP,John Potter, Leigh Nixon, Philip Cave, CHARLES DANIELS; baritone=PAUL HILLIER, Gordon Jones; bass=David Beavan.  Consort: viola da gamba=Kees Boeke, Charles Medlam; cornett=BRUCE DICKEY; tenor trombone Charles Toet; Bass trombone Richard Lister; theorbe STEPHRN STUBBS.  A really superior group of performers. (recorded in 1986)The expression on this disc is powerfully enthralling and quite consoling.  This music truly conveys the spirit of penitence; the emotions of a strong and noble soul.  With great sensitivity does Lassus bring to life the soul-searching that many of us experience in our lives.The booklet includes pertinent information and complete text translation in English, German and French.  The present price on this listing is very reasonable.  And the price does go up and down constantly, so if you like it today this listing has the lowest price; there are not many available.

AN OVERALL MOOD OF DARKNESS PREVAILS IN THIS RECORDING DRIVEN BY THE TEXT, BUT MUCH OF THE MUSIC BELIES THE MOOD!In 2008 NMC records produced a five disc set entitled NMC Songbook which contained the works of several of Britain's new composers.  Joseph Phibbs's selection "The Moon's Funeral" appeared on one of the discs and it is included on this one.  Sir Peter Maxwell Davies, NMC's Debut Discs Ambassador states:"In a world where composers face so many hurdles to ensure their music is heard, NMC's unwavering commitment to them and to building an unrivalled catalog of the UK's classical music output means that composers are not overlooked..."After hearing this recording I am grateful that Joseph Phibbs was not overlooked, for his music is refreshing and creative showing an awareness of all that is needed to put together this program of chamber music involving both instruments and voices.Though his music contains a definitive British flavor that can be compared to the likes of Elgar, Vaughan Williams and Britten, it transcends any components of nationality - its language is universal.  When listening to contemporary music one must concentrate fully; it is usually so different from what many of us perceive as music, but through the years I have learned that repeated hearings frequently bring out the true worth of the music, OR NOT! One example of success for me was a composition by Alexander Goehr "The Death of Moses".  One of my unsuccessful attempts to adjust and enjoy a composition was the opera "Taverner" by Peter Maxwell Davies; I finally gave up on that one!The first work on this recording is instrumental(piano, flute, violin and cello):"FLEX" demonstrates absolute virtuosity by the performers.  Despite the presence of dissonance in Phibbs's music along with its far-out harmonies, he manages to create moments of lyrical loveliness that might rival some of the conventional masterworks.  His instrumental textures are unique and his rhythmic design is ably conveyed by the ensemble.  The dance-like movement of the piece would make an excellent modern dance scenario.Two songs from SHADES OF NIGHT sung by tenor, Ben Alden, accompanied on piano by Andrew Plant:  "Sleep my body, sleep my ghost" which is a commentary on the mounting anxiety in Europe during the months before war broke out.  Thus uncertainty and fear is depicted throughout the piano accompaniment, which is played skillfully by Plant.  The second song "Hush-a-ba, birdie" is a traditional Scottish lullaby, and is set here like an imaginary folk song.  Alden sings with confidence, clear diction, perceptive phrasing and with the correct emotional involvement.THE CANTICLE OF THE ROSE is the centerpiece of the disc; it is an extended song cycle for soprano and string quartet set to verses by Dame Edith Sitwell.  Phibbs's music in this work is compelling, sometimes 'jarring' and occasionally painful to my ears, but the text is by turns exciting, depressing, morbid and maniacal, so the sounds are true to the text.  However, for the most part, it held my interest; the six movements were varied in tempo drastically at times; thus my psyche went back and forth from highly engaging to quite dull. One major obstacle to enjoyment has to do with the very fine soprano who had an almost impossible to sing part which she managed to sing magnificently, the problem being that the diction much of the time was lost because of the character of the music.  I tend to think that if one listens to this composition and mentally places the soprano on an instrumental basis as one of the five participants and is not  concerned with the text, this work becomes quite palatable and indeed enjoyable.  The strings are marvelous and perform this very complex music perfectly.  The third time I listened I discarded the text and found it to be most entertaining and marveled again at how superb were the performers.FROM SHORE TO SHORE combines countertenor, Michael Chance with guitarist James Boyd  It sets a series of old and new poems on the subject of the sea.  The essence of the centrality of the sea to British and Irish cultures is explored in this song cycle. The text was extracted from the works of the American poet Sara Teasdale and British writer Nicolas Heiney, both of whom committed suicide at  a young age.  This work was composed for Chance, one of the world's great countertenors and one whose talent for the 'song' and word commentaries is unquestionable.  Take note that though his songs are difficult, no word is lost; he is a master of communication.  He is adroitly and sensitively accompanied by Boyd, a skilled guitarist.  Chance sings these songs with undiminished eloquence and beauty of tone; the ethereal quality of his voice is ideal for Phibbs's music.  He sings the final selection on this recording "The Moon's Funeral" an exuberant portrait of a warped and rejected nature;  Plant is the accompanist.In the brief work AGEA, in which the musical vowels of George Vass's name (for whom this work was dedicated), Phibbs makes us aware of how much he knows about the musical capabilities and effects of the stringed instruments.  Their performance is beyond belief when one perceives the complexity of this music.  Kudos to them!For me this work will take many more listenings before I completely settle in and eke out all their is to obtain, but the music is certainly worth the time and effort and the performers MORE THAN WORTH THE TIME. The package includes good information and explanations by the composer, Phibbs. The text is also included, all in English, of course.THE SUNDAY TIMES: "Phibbs's sheer accomplishment as a composer is unmistakable here.  Every idea is telling, every phrase beautiful."BBC MUSIC MAGAZINE, September, 2013:  "The relatively Spartan textures of these pieces are more convincing than some of Phibbs's writing for larger ensembles.  These works draw you in with a well-judged pacing of their sometimes frenetic activity and mesmerizing stillness."

And so it begins...At the core of Beckett, Blake, and Cole's relationship is absolute trust and devotion. They may not be related by blood, but they're true brothers in every since of the word, helping each other to feel like they belong and giving one another a way to be more than they were.Through the battles of loneliness, fear, and pain, the brothers have stood by each other, never leaving anyone behind, believing in one another and paving the way for them to survive their messed up pasts and maddening presents.The Quiet OneThe Broken OneThe Reckless OneAll three damaged in irreparable ways but somehow moving forward out of sheer will and desperation. Blake's issues leave him seeking solitude away from the light, shrouding himself in darkness in order to keep the monsters at bay. Cole loses himself in his psyche in order to endure his tormented memories and shield himself from the pain. Beckett is clearly their leader and he's the perfect choice because he goes out of his way to take care of those closest to him and do the kind of things that may not make him moral and honest but it definitely illustrates how he protects his own at all costs to himself.The brotherhood Beckett, Blake, and Cole share is one that was established early on in order to survive foster care, but it continues because they willingly fight in each other's corner. Nothing is more important than protecting their bond and being available at all times so they never have to endure anything alone. And, this idea is meticulously illustrated throughout Poughkeepsie Begins.Regardless of the situation, everyone chooses a path to follow and Debra Anastasia provides readers with how the Poughkeepsie brothers decided which way to go and for what reasons, allowing us to understand what led Beckett to a life of power and crime; Blake to his music, and Cole to his faith.Never Alone. Brothers Forever. No one gets left alone.A complimentary copy was provided in exchange for an honest review.4 Poison Apples

A life for a life. Thatâ€™s the way of the mob, and unfortunately, thatâ€™s a deal that Logan knows too well, and itâ€™s an idea he refuses to allow to touch Elle because regardless of how quickly their relationship progressed, sheâ€™s his, and heâ€™s not willing to sacrifice Elle for anyone, including himself.The stakes are high in the conclusion of Kim Karrâ€™s The Tainted Love Duet, and the outcome could go either way because there are a lot of players in the game, both known and unknown, who serve as a threat to the happiness that Logan and Elle seek. The truth is definitely not what it seems, and until Logan can unravel the clues and be released from the sins of his past, both Logan and Elle can be crushed, not just by the acts of others, but also from their own fears and anger.I knew that Logan and Elle were going to have to overcome a lot of obstacles to truly be together in the end, but I never imagined all of the secrets, lies, threats, and danger that would become a constant as the days continued, and Logan worked to secure their safety once and for all.Kim Karr weaves a meticulous story of suspense, passion, and heart stopping action. Thereâ€™s a lot on the line for both Logan and Elle, including their relationship, and readers get to see firsthand what and why theyâ€™re willing to risk it all for those they love.Logan has intrigued me since the very first meeting, and he becomes even more dynamic in Crush. His dual life had the power to defeat him, but his role as protector helps him to not drown in his mistakes and do his best to ensure that he has a future with the woman he loves. I loved watching his mind work as he struggled to understand the truth behind the lies and deception. Loganâ€™s strength and confidence allowed him to keep fighting even when the world around him was turned on his side, and he was forced to deal with events and actions that would have conquered a lesser man. Elle comes into her own as well in Crush. She uses Loganâ€™s love and strength to help her unleash the warrior inside her and not allow the fear to consume her. Itâ€™s not easy for her but as long as she knows Logan has her back, she pushes forward.Iâ€™ve always loved Kim Karrâ€™s writing, but her Tainted Love Duet truly proves how gifted of a writer she is. Thereâ€™s never a dull moment in Logan and Elleâ€™s story and readers are on edge throughout the entire text wondering how the actions and truths of others will affect them, and if theyâ€™ll make it through all of the danger that threatens to destroy them.A complimentary copy was provided in exchange for an honest review.4.5 Poison Apples

Staying on Course is the perfect title for Devon and Bryceâ€™s conclusion because it implies that there is a definite path theyâ€™re journeying down, but that the road is sometimes tenuous due to external circumstances, forcing both Devon and Bryce to remain strong despite the distance, the jealousy, the miscommunication, and the time spent apart.Devonâ€™s character will both endear and frustrate readers due to some of her actions and her inability to think clearly at times and see the big picture of Bryceâ€™s devotion to her and their life plan. But sheâ€™s inexperienced when it comes to relationships, and Bryce has been the object of her affection for so many years that Iâ€™m sure the reality that he is actually hers is a bit hard to grasp at times. One thing I absolutely love about Devon is that she does everything she can to be her own person and follow her dreams/passions despite her insecurities. Sheâ€™s so talented and a career is important to her, which keeps her in check for the most part because thatâ€™s one path she will follow until the end.Bryceâ€™s devotion to Devon and the love he has for her is truly amazing. He knows he messed up in the past and heâ€™s aware of whatâ€™s at stake and refuses to do anything to jeopardize his relationship. With every word and action, readers can tell how much Devon means to Bryce and how much he wants to give her the world and show her that sheâ€™s his.Quinn brought humor into the story and helped ease the tension on more than one occasion. I love how much of a straight shooter she is; sheâ€™s Devonâ€™s rock and she proves that she deserves the title of best friend on numerous occasions.I've always loved how Ahren Sandersâ€™ writing flows; it feels almost seamless, and it's quite easy to become absorbed with her stories because there's no unnecessary content. I will admit that Devon kind of annoyed me at the beginning, but then I had to remember her age and what she'd already been through with Bryce, which made it easier to accept and see it from her perspective. Levi â€œPainterâ€ Brooks is the epitome of loyal biker brother. He has his brothersâ€™ backs, putting the club first since he patched into the Reapers MC. But Painter also takes a fall for his club, changing the dynamics of his relationship with Melanie and spending a significant amount of time trying to make amends for the choices he felt he had to make.Because Painter and Melanieâ€™s story spans a number of years, there are a great deal of hardships that they must contend withâ€¦frustration and hurt are two emotions that always seem to surround Painter and Melanie as they try to work through the obstacles that threaten to destroy any chance they have of truly being together.What I love most about Joanna Wyldeâ€™s Reapers MC series is that she marvelously weaves two story lines together â€“ one that deals with the ups and downs of the hero/heroineâ€™s relationship and one that focuses on the threats to the club and the path that the members must go on in order to protect the brotherhood. Nothing Venturedâ€¦Nothing GainedThis motto has served Colin Sloan well as a venture capitalist, and heâ€™s hoping heâ€™ll have the same success with his biggest risk of all - his heart.Elle Mariano made a promise to herself and her son to not take unnecessary risks and to put the needs of her son before her own. Just One Taste is an interesting title for Eric and Deenaâ€™s novella because those words have very different meanings for the Dom and submissive in training.For Eric, one taste of Deenaâ€™s body is all he needs to know sheâ€™s the woman he wants, and as long as heâ€™s patient and can tear down some of her walls, sheâ€™ll be his to indulge in forever.For Deena, all she wants is a tasteâ€¦a physical release from a bad boy who will please her physically and leave her emotions intact. Some Sort of Crazy is a realistic look at how two people can seemingly want very different things in their lives, but somehow, due to their connection...what they give and get from one another, they can't imagine not having each other in their lives and what that leads to is a whole lot of sex...a significant amount of growing up...and heroine who just might have found the live she's always wanted by veering off her planned path.Readers will absolutely relate to Natalie Nixon and her sensible and responsible lifestyle; she thrives on order and control, stubbornly following all of her decisions until the very end, which in most cases allows her to follow her dreams and her passion, but in one aspect of her life, itâ€™s slowly impinging on her happiness.Enter Miles HaasMiles is everything that Natalie is not - he lives for fun, never allowing feelings into play, focusing, instead, on living free and easy with as many women and good times he can pack into the hours of the day.Both Natalie and Miles seem unwilling to bend or change, refusing to acknowledge that their sex only agreement isnâ€™t enough. Because regardless of their minds telling them anything more between them is impossible, their bodies and their hearts seem to disagree, causing Natalie and Miles to wonder if cataclysmically altering their lives will give them the happiness they thought they already had or if it will not only mess up a friendship but destroy any hope of a future with anyone else, even for fun.I absolutely love Melanie Harlowâ€™s characters; theyâ€™re definitely flawed, but they also epitomize the various types of personalities and attitudes that exist in our society. Sometimes people refuse to see whatâ€™s right in front of them, never acknowledging that their life plan might actually be a mistake and that everything they thought was wrong for them is actually what they need to feel alive.Some Sort of Crazy is a fantastic story about giving into what your body craves even if your head doesnâ€™t agree; itâ€™s about freeing yourself from a plan that doesnâ€™t seem to end the way you wanted and finding the courage to make a decision that may completely upend your life, but it will be one hell of a journey on the way.Everyone needs a little crazy some time!A complimentary copy was provided in exchange for an honest review.4.5 Poison Apples

Triple Nipple FudgeStroke n PokeClam JamNibble My NutsEven if youâ€™re not really a fan of ice cream, like me, I could totally see myself diving into one of Ryleigh Phillipsâ€™ smexy concoctions and licking the bowl clean;) Because anyone who can come up with interesting dessert combinations with names that give them a sexual undertone definitely deserves to be appreciated.Boy did I need this sweet, sexy, and hilarious read. Itâ€™s a difficult genre because itâ€™s hard to be unique and stand out amongst the rest, but Brooke Blaine flawlessly delivers a highly entertaining and sexy story line in Licked!A complimentary copy was provided in exchange for an honest review.4.5 Poison Apples

Truth and Justice...two powerful and valuable ideas that are, at times, taken for granted, and in Unlawful Justice, readers are shown first hand what happens when there are differing opinions about how those two ideals should be carried out.The title itself is extremely paradoxical because at face value, it doesn't seem like justice is served when illicit means are used, but in some cases, the only way to get to the honest truth is by going perhaps a little around the law because sometimes there's more to the truth than meets the eye.K Langston and KC Lynn tell a powerful story about racism, an eye for an eye, and the consequences of reactionary actions. Amidst the turmoil and degradation, there is also a love story that allows readers to keep hope even when it seems like there's none to be found in the little town where the story takes place.Olivia Bradshaw and Grayson Taylor embody the idea of tolerance down to their core, but their faith is tested numerous times throughout Unlawful Justice, so much so that Grayson wants to take justice into his own hands and eradicate the evil and hatred that has embroiled the lives of almost every citizen in Harmony Falls.â€œSeek the truth and you will find justice.â€Those are definitely words to live by, but in a society that currently thrives on retribution, itâ€™s extremely difficult to toe the line of justice when injustice, vengeance, and distrust are barreling in from all sides.There are so many lessons in this book, and even though they're ensconced in a place of hatred, prejudice, and heinous acts, readers will understand the authors' messages and leave the text understanding what's at stake when wrong prevails over right and injustice threatens to supersede justice.A complimentary copy was provided in exchange for an honest review.5 Poison Apples

Dylan,I didn't know what to expect from your story but then I should have known it would be something amazing because the quiet ones always have the most to say but they feel as if their actions are more important.I have to admit...there were times as I read the text that I didn't like you very much...I couldn't understand how you worked so hard to prove that other people were enough but then you took that idea away from them when you got lost in your silence not listening to the words that had always been there.I'm so glad you found your calm even though you had to fight your demons and your anger in order to get it. Through the fear, guilt, and grief, you found your way back and the silence no longer unhinged you and the voices allowed you to move on.Lance Corporal Banks, you are truly a remarkable man - one of Mayhem, of silence, of honor - and you are definitely ENOUGH!Jay,I used to 100% agree with the idea that actions speak louder than words, but in the case of your storytelling, I have to disagree. Your words bring so much meaning to so many lives...whether it is having red letter days or coasting through life, the messages of your stories resonate with so many readers, which truly illustrates the power of your words and the remarkable gift you have as a writer.Your MORE men and women are an amazing group of people who have each other's backs regardless of the situation and that is what makes them family not only to each other but to your readers as well.Thank you for sharing your gift with us and I hope you know how deeply your words affect the people who read them!A complimentary copy was provided in exchange for an honest review.5 Poison Apples

Once again, Emma Hart meticulously weaves a story that is suspenseful, sassy, and sexy. What I love most about Tillie Coleâ€™s storytelling, especially in her Scarred Souls series, is that she allows her readers to see and feel EVERYTHING that her characters endure. She forces us into the darkness, fighting alongside her heroes and struggling for just one moment of lightnessâ€¦for a way to be more than what they were made intoâ€¦more than a numberâ€¦more than beast. And, as her characters are brought to the depths of hell, readers keep their eyes and minds open because we need to understand their suffering; we need to be able to visualize the mistreatment, the torture, the pain; we need to realize that Raze and 221 were turned into killing machines. But when Zaal enters her life, she finally feels whole because that primitive man becomes everything to her in such a short amount of time, and itâ€™s her love, her strength, and her commitment to him that allows Zaal to become more than a programmed killerâ€¦more than a fierce monster. Talia allows him to become free in every sense of the word.But Reap is not only 221â€™s story; itâ€™s Lukaâ€™s as well because he is not whole even with everything that heâ€™s done and received since he escaped. No one becomes fully healed in such a short amount of time when they endured years of brutality and darkness. It still lives and festers in Raze, threatening to destroy all of his progression because no matter how much he tries to remove that part of himself, the part of a killer, he canâ€™t do it. So Reap is also Lukaâ€™s struggle to find a balance in his life as the Russian Mafia prince but also as a man who needs to release the rage inside him for the sake of himself and those he loves.Tillie Cole delivers a well-crafted and complex story line each time she releases a book; from her first text to her newest one, I am in awe of the power she holds over me every time I enter one of her worlds, and I canâ€™t wait to see what she has in store for her readers next.A complimentary copy was provided by the author/publisher in exchange for an honest review.5 Poison Apples (The Fairest of All Book Reviews)

Deanna MaddenJess ReillyPsychopathCybersex QueenKillerEvilInsaneBrokenQuiltyThis is the sum of all of Deanna Maddenâ€™s parts, and if you dare to look inside her mind and attempt to understand her fragmented psyche, youâ€™ll be left with a menagerie of conclusions that donâ€™t realistically define all that Deanna was, is, and might become due to her past, her own mind, and her afflictions.I know every time I enter a A. R. Torre novel, Iâ€™m going to be thrust into a world that is manipulatively twisted and deliciously dark. Much of what readers see throughout the story is merely a facadeâ€¦a small part of a much bigger puzzle and the jagged and disjointed pieces must be whittled down and understood at their core in order to solve the riddle that Torre lays out for her readers.Deanna Madden is one of the most complex heroines Iâ€™ve ever read, and itâ€™s due to how Torre constructs each part of Madden. Torre is meticulous in allowing readers inside Deannaâ€™s tormented mind; I suspect itâ€™s a bit like being in purgatory because Deannaâ€™s stuck between the good that Jeremy brings into her life as well as her drive to be  normal and free and her thirst for blood, death, and destruction. As soon as she makes gains in her lifeâ€¦in her controlâ€¦in her resolve to toe the line, she finds herself regressing and yearning for a release that only she can find with her hands around someoneâ€™s neck or one of her knives slicing through tissue.Torre marvelously depicts how conflicted Deanna is and the steps sheâ€™s willing to take to ensure that Jeremy gets everything out of life, even if it means playing a part that has become such a part of her that she canâ€™t tell the difference between whatâ€™s real and whatâ€™s pretend. â€œYour life is on the track it is meant to be on. This is not a contest or a race. Donâ€™t compare yourself to others, only to the person you were yesterday.â€Thereâ€™s such wisdom in this statement, and itâ€™s bound to make sense, logically, but most people whose pasts have left them broken and hopeless canâ€™t understand why their â€˜trackâ€™ is such a struggleâ€¦why they canâ€™t lead a life without abuseâ€¦without feeling forgotten or cast aside. And, itâ€™s incredibly difficult not to loathe who and what theyâ€™ve become because the self-hatred is consuming and belittling.Lachlan McGregor can be described in numerous waysâ€¦Rugby player. Philanthropist. Lone Solider. Survivor. But at his core, he still feels like the lost and broken boy who was forced to find his own wayâ€¦forced to endure a life where no one truly saw the pain beneath the surfaceâ€¦where no one tried to see him for who he really isâ€¦A Beautifully Broken Scottish Beast.Kayla Moore is a complex person who doesnâ€™t truly belong to anyone, not even her friends because Stephanie and Nicola are now part of a couple and sheâ€™s merely the tag along, which leaves her feeling much of the time like the odd man out. Sure, sheâ€™s free with her mouth and her body, but sheâ€™s so much more than her man-eater persona, which is clearly illustrated through Kaylaâ€™s internal musings and her delicate â€˜black heart.â€™ Thereâ€™s a depth to Kaylaâ€™s personality that she doesnâ€™t allow anyone to see because she doesnâ€™t want to appear vulnerable or lacking.Although Kayla is not close to being as broken or as lonely as Lachlan is, thereâ€™s a connection between them that stems from more than just attraction, and thatâ€™s why they gravitate towards each other and soon find themselves giving into their desires for one another. But thereâ€™s a mountain of obstacles to overcome, both personally and as a couple, which, at times, seem insurmountable, and other times, seem to only make them stronger.The Play is an extremely emotional read about two people who are searching for their track and wind up on one together, struggling to put themselves back togetherâ€¦to figure out their passion, and to not allow the past to dominant the present and destroy the future.Lachlan and Kaylaâ€™s journey is a tumultuous mix of pain, frustration, agony, desire, and love. Karina Halle gives readers two characters who tightly hold on to hope, but, at times, itâ€™s a tenuous grip because thereâ€™s so much darkness to contend with and Lachlan has seen and done too much to not feel like itâ€™s pulling him under. But heâ€™s a fighter and Kayla has proven her scrappiness with her words and actions, so if there are two people who can make it work despite Lachlanâ€™s past, his addictions, and his insecurities as well as Kaylaâ€™s fears and struggles, itâ€™s those two, and even if the track theyâ€™re on together seems disjointed and rough, thereâ€™s more than enough love between them to give them what they need as long as theyâ€™re together.I canâ€™t believe Iâ€™m saying this but Lachlan McGregor just might be my favorite dirty talking Scottish alpha male because thereâ€™s something so powerful about a man who has the heart and fight of a lion and a passion for helping the cast aside and forgotten because he understands their demons and wants to give them a small sense of hope/peace.A complimentary copy was provided in exchange for an honest review.4.5 Poison Apples

Coup de Grace is an interesting name for Michaelâ€™s story, and the fact that it is the last book in Lani Lynn Valeâ€™s Code 11-KPD Swat series seems fitting for the title as well as the man because as coup de grace implies, a finishing blow is madeâ€¦a decisive event occurs that settles conflict, alleviating the intensity of a situation.Michael is definitely a conflicted man; his nickname is â€˜Saintâ€™ because he comes to the aid of those in need, protecting children at all costs, but he refuses to have children of his own because he fears passing down his bad genetics to them; he doesnâ€™t want to ruin anyoneâ€™s life as he feels his life has been due to his bi polar disorder and depression.But what Michael doesnâ€™t seeâ€¦what he canâ€™t even begin to grasp, because heâ€™s too messed up with what heâ€™s suffered through himself, is that he has the biggest heart and a massive amount of strength and determination to succeed at anything he puts his mind toâ€¦as evident by his skill set as a cop and the fact that he could have been an excellent doctor.Nikki sees everything good in Michael, but he hurt her deeply with his mixed up declarations, and the simple fact that he could walk away from her without looking back. But now heâ€™s looking to make amends and the love that Nikki feels for Michael never faded away, so she just needs to figure out if sheâ€™s willing to risk her heart again and with Michaelâ€™s current actions, Nikkiâ€™s ready to ride the ups and downs with him as long as heâ€™s willing to give her what she wants and needs.Michael and Nikkiâ€™s story, like all of the previous couplesâ€™ stories, has a great mix of steam, suspense, and drama. Nothingâ€™s over the top or unrealistic and Lani Lynn Vale does a great job of discussing mental illness, illustrating its difficulties without diminishing its effects on everyone involved.Iâ€™m sad to see my Swat alpha malesâ€™ stories end, but I know theyâ€™ll stop by for a visit or two in Valeâ€™s new series, but she finds a way to cross over story lines and give her readers a glimpse into whatâ€™s happened to their favorite leading men and ladies.A complimentary copy was provided in exchange for an honest review.4 Poison Apples

Feelinâ€™ reckless?If it means having a shot at Cam Strickland or Gannon Burgess, Iâ€™d definitely take the risk, but too bad for me that they only wanted one another, and despite some big obstacles â€“ the fact that they are direct opposites and have some pretty heavy baggage from each of their pasts â€“ theyâ€™re both willing to gamble on each other in order to find someone to be devoted to instead of just their jobs.An adrenalin junkie and a brainiac â€“ Cam and Gannon couldnâ€™t be more different, but in a way, thatâ€™s what makes them work because theyâ€™re able to even each other out. Neither has had an actual relationship because theyâ€™ve been too busy with work and life, but regardless of that fact, the attraction they feel for one another is something to build on and by going slow and getting to know one another, Cam and Gannon are working towards something that will last as long as Cam can deal with his fears and Gannon can deal with not being in control of Camâ€™s feelings and actions.I absolutely love Nicole Edwardsâ€™ writing, especially when she puts readers into the heads of two alpha males who want to strip each other naked and show one another how strongly they feel. The steamy scenes between Cam and Gannon illustrate the connection they share and the risks theyâ€™re willing to take to be all in for each other. Their relationship is definitely not easy, and there are times when I wondered if they were too different and had too much individually to contend with, but through all the ups and downs, the one thing that was made crystal clear is that both Cam and Gannon are worth it, and they deserve to find that one person they canâ€™t be without and itâ€™s clear that itâ€™s to each other that they belong.The collection of characters that readers will meet in Reckless are all significant people in the lives of the main characters and the camaraderie and love felt amongst them definitely adds to the overall feel of the text. Roan, Teague, and Dare all have stories to be told, and I canâ€™t wait for them!A complimentary copy was provided in exchange for an honest review.4.5 Poison Apples

Iâ€™ve been waiting for another charismatic, sexy, and full of himself hero from Nelle Lâ€™Amour ever since her That Man series finished and Mr. Blake Burns found his girl, and Lâ€™Amour definitely worked her character development magic with her newest cocky alpha male, Brandon Taylor. Like Blake, Brandon has a way with the ladies and oozes sex and douchiness at the same time. Heâ€™s in the entertainment industry just like Burns, although Brandonâ€™s in front of the screen not behind it. But the one astonishing similarity, which makes me a little ill just to think about it is that they both have one woman in common - a certain conniving self absorbed witch who is definitely up to no good again in Unforgettable.Nelle Lâ€™Amour definitely knows how to get inside a male characterâ€™s head and tell it like it is, but this time around, Lâ€™Amour has the challenging task of crafting Brandonâ€™s words and actions to represent who he was before the accident and who heâ€™s becoming after it. But hereâ€™s the thing, everything readers have heard about Brandon has painted quite the douchey description, which makes it difficult to understand exactly what Zoey Hart, Brandonâ€™s assistant, sees in the guy, especially when his choice of a girlfriend/fiancee is a money hungry skank who is definitely using Brandon for his bank account and celebrity status.Iâ€™m not quite sure what to think about Brandon or Zoey at this point because itâ€™s hard for me to witness Brandon continue to give into Katâ€™s outrageous wedding demands and bitchy comments while Zoey stands there and puts up with both of their mistreatment of her.Itâ€™s easy to see the chemistry between Brandon and Zoey from the first time they are reintroduced to each other, and if Iâ€™m not reading too much into the clues that Nelle Lâ€™Amour seems to be giving when it comes to crossing the lines between reality and fiction, things are about to get more complicated than they already are with a man who canâ€™t remember his last ten years and a woman whoâ€™s pined away for her boss since she started working for him but believes sheâ€™s completely invisible to him or anyone else unless sheâ€™s Katrinaâ€™s punching bag.Both Brandonâ€™s agent and fiancee seem to be playing their own games on Brandon, but until all the puzzle pieces fall into place and Brandonâ€™s memory comes back, readers and Zoey are left wondering whatâ€™s next.A complimentary copy was provided in exchange for an honest review.4 Poison Apples

Ethan Dexter - an NFL center who â€œanticipates, adapts, and protectsâ€ his quarterbackâ€¦his friendsâ€¦his girl - if he can find the right one and let himself take instead of overthinking every move he makes.Ethan is quiet, and he keeps to himself. No one sees him fully unless he wants them to and the only person heâ€™s ever willingly allowed fully in is the one person who could send his calm, cool, and collective self spiraling out of control - Fiona Mackenzie.But regardless of how different Ethan and Fiona may be and despite the distance that stands in their way from truly making a relationship work, what they give to one another during the times they are together is definitely worth fighting for and finding a way to build on their attraction because feelings like the ones they have for one another deserve a chance to grow.Throughout the course of the story, Ethan helps Fiona find her joy and stop running, and every step of the way, he proves he's the best thing that has ever happened to Fiona. Regardless of how inexperienced Dex may be, with everything that he gives to Fi, there's no doubt that he is the man to tame Fiona and make her feel alive, and sheâ€™s the woman to breakthrough Ethanâ€™s rational mind and release the beast within in every delicious way possible.Dex is definitely in the running for my top favorite book boyfriend of 2015!He is the complete package...he's a gentleman...he's an alpha. He's a giver and a pleaser. He is AMAZING!I wasnâ€™t sure if I was going to like the Fiona/Dex connection, but surprisingly, as Fi fights for what she wants and stops running long enough to see whatâ€™s standing right in front of her, she grows on me and has me supporting her decisions, cheering for her to get her man once and for all despite how exposed she may be by being Ethanâ€™s girl.Kristen Callihanâ€™s Game On series is one of my favorite sports romance collections out there because her heroes may be flawed, but they are willing to change for the right girl, and her heroines are not docile women - they refuse to be pushed around and arenâ€™t afraid to take control.  The story lines are also realistic in what the characters must deal with due to the football god status of the heroes and the back stories Callihan provides for her characters bring a sense of understanding to their current actions and it makes it so much easier to stay strong for the couple as they work through the chaos because thereâ€™s no doubt they want and deserve to be together.A complimentary copy was provided in exchange for an honest review.4.5 Poison Apples

I'll never be ready to say goodbye to my favorite alpha Aussie Cowboys and their kickass women, but if it's time to move on then I'm glad Kasey Millstead gives readers final look into their lives, their love, and the friendships that have lasted decades.Eden and Jackson will always be my favorite couple because they're the ones who started the series and brought readers into this tight knit community, but the rest of the twosomes added their own brand of steam, romance and drama, which kept us coming back each time, learning more about each couple and what they were willing to endure in order to be together.What I love most about Cowboy Endings is that readers get to see each of their favorite couples over a decade later and immerse themselves in the reality of life with growing older, having kids who are teenagers or older, and going through situations that all couples may go through at some stage in their relationship.Each novella is perfectly imperfect which speaks to the realities of life and the possibilities, both good and bad, of spending a lifetime together.A complimentary copy was provided in exchange for an honest review.4 Poison Apples

Any book that discusses Dawsonâ€™s Creek, Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles, mullets, and a forever kind of love is absolutely a book I want to read, and this is exactly the kind of story that Tessa Teevan gives readers in Fusion.We live. We laugh. We love.Three of the most simplest sentences out there but also three of the most consuming and complicated ideas that even with a lifetime to experience them, no one will truly understand how meaningful they are unless they give themselves fully over to someone they canâ€™t live withoutâ€¦to someone who was there since they were kids.Sierra and Jeremyâ€™s story began when they were eight years old and didnâ€™t really know what friendship or love even meant, but regardless of that fact, what they found in each other all those years ago was a forever kind of friendship and love that may have taken them awhile to figure out, but once they recognized what they could mean to each other and the life they could make together that was all it took to alter their lives in the most blissful and worthwhile ways.Where you go, I go.No truer words were said by Sierra and Jeremy to each other on multiple occasions than these ones. It represents what they are to one another down to the core and what theyâ€™re willing to do to ensure their connection remains despite the distance or hurdles they might experience.What I loved most about Fusion was how easy it was to see from the very beginning of the story that Sierra and Jeremy were meant to be together and how easy their relationship progressed once it started. Donâ€™t get me wrongâ€¦they faced obstacles and darkness, but it was never anything that would tear them apart because they were part of each otherâ€™s soul and that never changed despite a few times when they lost their way.The reality of Sierra and Jeremyâ€™s relationship in the book was a testament to the kind of people they are and how much better they were when they were side by side, taking on every aspect of life, and Tessa Teevan does a fantastic job of illustrating the ease and depth of their connection even when they were blind to how they truly felt about each other.In Fusion, readers are granted an insiderâ€™s look into Sierra and Jeremyâ€™s twenty year friendship and a bond that every couple hopes for but very few hold on to, which only makes other couples wish to emulate what they have even more.A lifetime of memories with times of pain and heartbreak as well as extreme joy resonate off the pages of Sierra and Jeremyâ€™s story, and I loved being a part of every moment, both good and bad, because each one is real and honest and pure and they are a testament to a life and a love worth EVERYTHING.A complimentary copy was provided in exchange for an honest review.4.5 Poison Apples

Thereâ€™s only one Buck Butterson, and Helena Hunting illustrates that thatâ€™s not necessarily a bad thing because heâ€™s definitely a handful, but what I also love about Pucked Up is that because itâ€™s told through Buckâ€™s perspective, readers are able to see the man who hides behind his manwhore statusâ€¦a guy who takes a vested interest in helping those in need and doesnâ€™t look for anything in return.Both Sunny and Buck are unique individuals who are a bit awkward and unpredictable, but thatâ€™s what makes them work. It was always going to take a special woman to tame the yetiâ€¦to see beyond his past anticsâ€¦to understand that even though a picture speaks a thousand words, sometimes, theyâ€™re the wrong ones.It was interesting to see how distorted situations can become when theyâ€™re taken out of context and the fact that people are judged relentlessly based on their past actions is definitely an idea that is strewn throughout the course of the text, and although Buck didnâ€™t make the best/right choices throughout his career and with the puck bunnies, he canâ€™t redeem himself when every time he goes somewhere, it gets out of control and his past dictates the conclusions others make.Relationships are hard, especially with someone as inept as Buck is with how to make one work. But if thereâ€™s one constant feeling I had as I read his story, it was pride for Buckâ€™s relentless attempts to redeem himself and prove that heâ€™s not the manwhore that he used to be and he has more positive qualities and intelligence than anyone would ever expect.I love Helena Huntingâ€™s Pucked series and her imperfect heroes and quirky heroines. The over the top and hilarious antics make it an easy and lighthearted read that will keep a smile on readersâ€™ faces every time they think of Huntingâ€™s Pucked men and women.I hope Vanceâ€™s story is next because that playboy needs to be knocked down a peg or two, and I think I know just the woman to do it.A complimentary copy was provided in exchange for an honest review.4 Poison Apples

Webster dictionary defines FRICTION as â€œconflict or animosity caused by a clash of wills, temperaments, or opinions,â€ and that explanation aptly describes the type of love/hate relationship that the main characters in Sawyer Bennettâ€™s newest release, Leary Michaels and Reeve Holloway, find themselves in, in both the bedroom and the court room. Their clients are on opposite ends of the spectrum, which means one is fighting for voiceless and the other is leading the charge for those who refuse to pay for their misdeeds simply because they have the clout to do so.But how can a relationship exist between two people who are sworn enemies in the courtroom without the personal and professional lines crossing? Strife. Conflict. These words epitomize Leary and Reeveâ€™s interactions but so do Flirty. Filthy. Sensual. And, it seems as if the dichotomy of their feelings for each other is exactly what solidifies the passion and intrigue that exists between them.Friction is another fantastic read from Sawyer Bennett. Itâ€™s as if we are one of the spectators in the room watching the case play out in real time and feeling the electricity that exists between Leary and Reeve.Itâ€™s a great story that clearly shows that thereâ€™s more to the truth than simple black and white answers, and thatâ€™s the idea that leads Leary to fight for the right outcome of her case and her relationship with Reeve.On to the next case!A complimentary copy was provided by the author/publisher in exchange for an honest review.4.5 Poison Apples

What happens when a feisty princess marries the naughty king?A whole lot of sexual tension, blurred lines, and one hell of a complication to a situation that has already spiraled out of control.Add in a meddling best friend and a controlling board who has a clear path for King and his company, and readers have the makings of a highly charged and a bit volatile showdown between two people who are sworn enemies but canâ€™t keep their hands off of each other.Feisty Princess picks up right where Naughty King left off, and the fallout from Alexander and Margoâ€™s drunken night has significant repercussions for both of them in terms of their plans to undermine each other and get what they want, and when other people get involved and threaten to expose the façade of their relationship, the princess and the king need to decide whatâ€™s real and whatâ€™s fiction and what theyâ€™re willing to do to be the winner in the end.Feisty Princess is a great follow-up to book 1 and it sets the stage for whatâ€™s to come in Dirty Royals. â€œThe good of the many takes priority over the good one.â€This is the code Hancock lives by; a belief system that has no room for feelings or emotionsâ€¦no place for mercy or conscience. Iâ€™ll admitâ€¦Honor and Hancock's story started out a bit slow for me, but once the hunt begins, the pace of the story shifts, and readers begin to understand the mission that Hancock and his team are on and just how much Honor alters every aspect of it.Maya Banks does a fantastic job of illustrating the emotional and physical torment that Honor goes through at the hands of a man she thinks is helping her and those men who wish her bodily harm. As Honor slinks further into herself and the darkness thatâ€™s consuming her with every lieâ€¦every volatile act threatens to immerse her fully, I couldnâ€™t stop crying. It was almost as if I could feel Honorâ€™s devastation and the numbing consequences of those acts against her by the men who want her dead and the man who seems conflicted at what he exactly wants from her. I couldnâ€™t read fast enough during this part of the story because I needed Hancock to redeem himself, and I needed Honor to be okayâ€¦to do more than survive, but I didnâ€™t truly see any way for that to happen with everything that went down with Hancock as well as Bristow and Maksimov.A sacrificial lamb or a redeeming angelâ€¦a cold blooded mercenary or a man with a conscience.  Throughout most of the story, I couldnâ€™t quite decide what Hancock would decide to do with Honor, especially when time after time, Honor proves that sheâ€™s so much more than a pawn in a deadly game. But like the title implies, thereâ€™s going to be a hell of a lot of darkness and evil before redemption can find its way out into the light.A complimentary copy was provided by the author/publisher in exchange for an honest review.4.5 Poison Apples

Everyone has heard of the saying â€œactions speak louder than words,â€ and while thatâ€™s definitely true in most cases, sometimes, words mean EVERYTHING, and when theyâ€™re not said, the devastation is deep and pronounced, so much so that there might not be a way to come back from whatâ€™s remained unsaid.Tobias Jackson loves words - thatâ€™s why heâ€™s an English major, but when it comes to being able to say how he feels and lay everything on the line, he falters for a number of reasons, but the biggest one is that he refuses to get close enough for anyone to hurt himâ€¦anyone to walk away from him like his mother did and like his father does on a regular basis because he refuses to talk to his son or even get to know him.Levi Baxter has always been the guy of Tobyâ€™s dreamsâ€¦the one who stars in his late night wet dreams. But that Levi was always way better than the real Levi - the one who treated his brother and Toby like crap and always thought he was better than them. But time away from the small town of Coburn has changed both Toby and Levi, creating a sizzling connection between them and leading them down a path where they have to hide their attraction from those closest to them as well as deny their true feelings for one another because itâ€™s too scary a situationâ€¦too much changeâ€¦too much of a chance of getting hurt.A Hundred Thousand Words was my first read from Nyrae Dawn, and what I loved about it is that even though it's in the New Adult genre, there's a uniqueness to the storyline that makes the text more meaningful. Toby and Levi both have issues to work through and find solace in one another, and even though their problems don't go away, and they probably should have faced them awhile ago, they lend an ear to each other and teach each other what it means to care for someone else and willingly risk everything that scares them.â€œFor someone who loves words so much, you suck at using them when it really matters.â€And Levi matters, so Toby better find the words - no matter how many it takes - or else heâ€™s going to be exactly like his father - a man of few wordsâ€¦few emotionsâ€¦few close relationships.A complimentary copy was provided in exchange for an honest review.4.5 Poison Apples

FineThe Webster dictionary defines it as â€œgood, acceptable, or satisfactory,â€ but based on its societal use, we learn to see fine as anything but â€“ more so said as a way to avoid getting into anything too personal, but clearly indicating that life is not good at the moment and the person who said it doesnâ€™t want to go any further than that even though itâ€™s clear that things are not well.For Levee Williams and Sam Rivers, those feelings of being fine lead them both to a cross roads in their life, unsure of how to rebuild, refocus, and reenergize when all they feel like doing is succumbing to the pain, the pressure, and the sadness by falling into the darkness.GreatFrom an onlookerâ€™s perspective, Levee and Samâ€™s lives are wonderful. Sheâ€™s a pop princess with droves of fans and more money than she can spend, and he does something he loves by repurposing furniture and selling it at a high price. But beyond the faÃ§adeâ€¦beyond the smoke and mirrors, are two people who are consumed with sadness and depressionâ€¦two people who donâ€™t know where to turn in order to feel something besides pain because thatâ€™s whatâ€™s wrapped around them, refusing to let go and taking them further down in the process.Can Levee and Sam be each otherâ€™s great? Or are they destined to keep plummeting, free falling without any chance of survival?How does one Fall Up? Well, if everyone had a Sam Rivers in their lives, they would easily understand how itâ€™s done and why Levee never questioned giving in and climbing up. But the way itâ€™s described is not easy, which is clearly illustrated through Leveeâ€™s internal conflict and quick reactions as well as her struggle to admit that she needs help.Aly Martinez does a fantastic job of putting readers inside both Levee and Samâ€™s heads and forcing us to feel every single emotion and hear every single dark thought. Martinez gives us the insight into Leveeâ€™s mind that no one else can see because if they did, they would have stepped in long ago because she is anything but fine, and the only way that Sam can recognize Leveeâ€™s pain is because he feels the same way albeit due to different circumstances, but itâ€™s still something that defines him as much as it defines her, and Samâ€™s recognition and caretaking attributes are the only things that can catch Levee, but she has to be willing to walk back down with Sam, which is a decision that Levee wonâ€™t be able to make until sheâ€™s ready to admit whatâ€™s going on and deal with it head on, and thatâ€™s the journey that Aly Martinez takes readers on, and itâ€™s a ride weâ€™ll never forget.I absolutely loved the message of The Fall Up! Everyone who reads it will definitely feel a connection to what Sam and Levee go through, even if only in small ways. Aly Martinez is such an extremely talented writer because her words mean more than she probably even realizes, which is why she's one of my favorites!Canâ€™t wait to see what Aly gives readers nextâ€¦maybe a book for Henry???4.5 Poison Apples

In baseball, triple plays are a rarity; it takes extreme precision and teamwork in order to execute a play with multiple players involved. But itâ€™s also more than thatâ€¦everything has to be moving in tandem because one slip up can destroy a carefully constructed unit.Iâ€™m not usual one to discuss life using a baseball analogy but it only seems fitting for Drewâ€™s story because itâ€™s titled Triple Play and that is exactly how many people are involved; although, itâ€™s not on the baseball fieldâ€¦In reading the previous two books, I had a good amount of background knowledge on Eric and Drew, but Bryce was still an unknown character. But from the start of the text, I knew, in a way, that Bryce was going to be the one that solidified everything between the three of them because he had the emotional strength to do so. He took charge and pushed when he needed to in order to make both Eric and Drew see that societyâ€™s view on things didnâ€™t matter because what they felt for each other and what they gave to each other worked for them in a way that made sense and felt right so to hell with anyone who disagreed or looked down on them for their choices.But having three people exist in one relationship can get messy and stressful; there are a lot of different emotions to take into account and handle with care, and for an author to explore three varying perspectives, it's sometimes difficult to present a full insider's view of the main characters' thoughts and feelings when there are three people involved and equal exploration needs to be provided in order to truly see how their polyamorous relationship works. At times, I found it difficult to truly understand how Drew, Bryce, and Eric made everything work despite their dominating personalities and tense reactions to situations because I didn't feel privy to all three perspectives at the various intense moments. I wanted to experience more of the development of their feelings and truly witness how it went from just fooling around and having fun to deep rooted feelings between all three, and while at times, I did feel like I got a pretty good look at some aspects of their commitment to each other, there were other times that I wished for more.That being said, I truly enjoyed Drew, Bryce, and Eric's story because of the lessons taught through Drew's ordeal as well as Bryce's commitment to help LGBT teens who have nowhere to turn or live. It filled me with a sense of pride to see three strong gay men work to help those who needed their support and do more than throw money at the issues. The latter part of the book truly illustrated how the three men had grown and transformed through one anotherâ€™s guidance, pushing, and commitment, which is all anyone wants to experience in a relationship.A complimentary copy was provided in exchange for an honest review.3.5/4 Poison Apples

The British are coming! The British are coming! And, boy are readers ready for them, especially when they come in the form of two deliciously, irresistible twin hotties, Declan and Dax Blay. Declan is a swoon worthy hero who has so much heart and fight in him that there isnâ€™t any obstacle he canâ€™t overcome, which is good because heâ€™s going to need that determination or no quit attitude to claim his Unicorn girl regardless of how much she tries to push him away.I read a lot of college romances, so when I find one that becomes so much more than the qualities of its genre, I revel in its story line and complex characters, which is exactly what I did with Dirty English.Iâ€™m a high school English teacher, so I know all about Jane Austenâ€™s Pride and Prejudice and Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy, and I love to see classics modernized in a way that allows current society a small glimpse into Austenâ€™s world and the passion and drama that she put her characters through in order for them to learn and grow. Ilsa Madden-Mills gives her readers a much more contemporary Elizabeth Bennett and a more manly Mr. Darcy in Declan Blay, but at the heart of Elizabeth and Declanâ€™s story is the realization of what kindred souls can give to one another and how faith and self-worth can be restored by opening oneâ€™s heart and taking a chance despite the potential heart break. Elizabeth and Declanâ€™s love story may be more angst riddled and more dramatic, but it still holds true to the ideas and values that Austen wanted her audience to realize â€“ hope, second chances, and a way to set oneâ€™s heart free.Elizabeth Bennett is a heroine that readers canâ€™t help but love because her fortitude is inspiring. No one should have to endure the events that Elizabeth has, but even though the darkness threatened to consume and break her, she continued to fight, and she made herself rise above the pain and heartache despite wanting to give up on multiple occasions. Elizabeth wasnâ€™t entirely healed; in fact, she worked hard to close herself off to almost everyone in order to avoid any further devastation, but Declan gave her no other option but to allow him into her life and eventually into her heart and heal her through his compassion and strength.Declan Blay is a scarred hero as well; he might not be fighting the kind of demons that Elizabeth is, but heâ€™s still been put through the wringer in a way that has made him overly cautious of women and his faith in them has been all but destroyed. But thereâ€™s something about Elizabeth Bennett that draws Declan in from the start and even though he fights with himself over pursuing her, claiming sheâ€™s not the one for him, he canâ€™t deny he wants her in every way possible and heâ€™ll do what it takes to restore them both.Mr. Darcy has nothing on Declan Blay; in fact, with his tattoos and fighting skills, Declan easily surpasses Mr. Darcy and epitomizes every imaginable connotative meaning of Dirty English!Boy do I love Ilsa Madden-Mills â€“ her writing, her characters, her sexy scenes, her angst filled torment â€“ EVERYTHING about her stories works for me in lasting ways, and I canâ€™t wait to see what sheâ€™ll have for readers in Daxâ€™s story!A complimentary copy was provided in exchange for an honest review.4.5 Poison Apples
