The title of Nikolai and Maya's book holds multiple meanings for both of them, and it also represents what could become of them if Nik doesn't figure out a way to protect Maya from her monstrous father and his end game if Maya's memories resurface.Readers first met Nikolai in Elude, and we could tell from his first appearance that he was harboring a multitude of secrets and walking a fine line between what he's supposed to do and what he wants to do. This idea is expounded on in Rip and the many layers of Nik's personality are peeled away little by little with his interaction with Maya and his realization about what it will take to free himself and Maya from her father.Nik may be a master manipulator and pride himself on his control and ability to keep people at a distance, but Maya's a game changer for his purpose, his familyâ€™s legacy, and his identity; in fact, their first encounter when she was 16 solidified what she would come to mean to him, and there was really nothing he could do to prevent her from either destroying or redeeming him.Mayaâ€™s in a precarious situation not of her own doing, and so as her conflicted feelings for Nikoali lead to rash actions and unlocked memories, sheâ€™s even more confused about Nikâ€™s position with her father and if heâ€™s truly a monster who means her harm or the only person who can save her from the danger thatâ€™s coming at her from multiple sides.Like all of Rachel Van Dykenâ€™s mafia books, Nikoali and Mayaâ€™s story is consumed with mysteries and unanswered questions, and they are slowly revealed and answered throughout the course of the text, keeping readers caught up in the manipulation, seduction, and destruction that threatens everything thatâ€™s building between Nik and Maya and everything Nikâ€™s been working to tirelessly to protect.I absolutely loved RIP; Van Dyken continues to dazzle me with her dark, dangerous, and deadly Mafia men â€“ guys who will do anything to protect those they love and those who have their backs. The Russian/Italian connection in the book although tenuous leads me to believe that that alliance will come into play some time in the future in the Eagle Elite series, and I canâ€™t wait to see how Van Dyken incorporates it.A complimentary copy was provided in exchange for an honest review.4.5 Poison Apples

I love the connotative meanings that go along with the title of Quinn and Tazenâ€™s story, Hard to Break, because there are a multitude of positive and negative experiences that they go through both individually and as a couple that definitely demonstrate what it means to splinter, fracture, and come unhinged.Since her motherâ€™s death, Quinnâ€™s life has been like fighting an uphill battle that always sends her tumbling down, but that hasnâ€™t stopped her from trying to move forward, relying on only herself to keep a roof over her and her father and keep the shop open and out of the red. All of these are daunting tasks, but through it all, Quinn refuses to break; she refuses to quit, and one way or another, sheâ€™s going to prove that the garage is where she belongs no matter what the cocky son of b***h says!Tazen Watts - the name oozes sex and charm - too bad none of his smooth talking wins Quinn over; in fact, his demeanor and attitude grates her nerves and turns her crush on him into an all out war of barbs and antics.The volatile nature of Taz and Quinnâ€™s relationship goes from bad to worse when Taz takes the one thing Quinnâ€™s always had, threatening to unhinge her entire life and forcing her to fight dirty in order to maintain some sense of what defines her. But when everything plays out, who will break whom and what kind of fracturing will it be? The kind that draws people together or tears them even further apart?Even though Hard to Break is a slightly predictable enemies to loversâ€™ story, I still enjoyed watching Tazen and Quinn rev each other up until they both blew in a variety of ways! I love the fact that Quinn is a phenomenal mechanic and lets her work speak for itself. Sheâ€™s exactly who she portrays herself to be and to me, thatâ€™s why Taz is drawn to her even though they come from completely different worlds. Taz is also quite surprising once Quinn gets underneath his tough exterior; heâ€™s actually quite sweet and knows what Quinn needs as their relationship progresses. Thereâ€™s some angst but not an excessive amount. The primary focus is more on Quinnâ€™s refusal to stop fighting and how Tazenâ€™s realizes her unbreakable spirit is exactly why heâ€™s falling for her.A complimentary copy was provided by the author/publisher in exchange for an honest review.3.5 poison apples

I absolutely loved the deliciously dirty talking Aidan Burke, and Jessie Law is the perfect girl for him because she refuses to allow him to control her, and she is more than happy to put Aidan in his place.Every lie begins with truth.Every legend was borne of reality.All readers have probably seen the effects of a lie and the fact that it can instantly fester and spread is not unusual, and that is exactly what happens when Aidan forces Jessie to pretend to be his girlfriend. But what happens when small glimpses of the truth sneak into the lie - can the truth ever out power the lie or is there no way to push past the deceit solidified so much so that no one will believe anything but the fabrication?The deceitfulness of lies and the mess they make is a huge topic of discussion in Dirty Lies...but another just as important issue is what crazy fans and online keyboard warriors do to the lives of the famous and those they love, and depending on how the celebrities are able to handle the chaos/gossip/altered facts determines whether or not they can be in a relationship and make it or watch it burn out due to lack of trust and understanding.I love enemies to loversâ€™ storylines, especially when thereâ€™s a rich history between the hero and heroine. This is exactly the situation that Aidan and Jessie find themselves in when he steps in to help her and ends up setting social media on fire, which in turn, brings out Jessieâ€™s witch mode, which I adore, and sends them down a rather tumultuous path of secrets, lies, and hard truths.The way Emma Hart plays out Aidan and Jessieâ€™s fake relationship is brilliant because itâ€™s completely realistic, and as the saying goes, thereâ€™s a thin line between love and hate, which definitely proves true for these two.There are multiple layers to how Aidan and Jessie feel about each other and because Hart allows both of their perspectives to be heard, readers understand Jessieâ€™s concerns, Aidanâ€™s outlook, and the reasons theyâ€™re both denying how much they actual work.Jessie Law is one of my favorite heroines because she doesnâ€™t give a ratâ€™s a** about what other people think about her and she has never been afraid to do her own thing. Sheâ€™s a passionate woman who is easily wound up by Aidan, but she also knows how to give it right back to him.Dirty Lies is a phenomenal read; itâ€™s sexy, angsty, and dirty, which is a perfect combination - one that Emma Hart continues to master!One more Burke boy to go!!A complimentary copy was provided by the author/publisher in exchange for an honest review.4.5 Poison Apples

Iâ€™m a bit torn about Kit and Noahâ€™s story. Now that Iâ€™m privy to Noahâ€™s secrets, I completely understand the destructive steps he took to push Kit and his feelings for her away; his tortured soul and self disgust would not allow him to clearly see what Kit was offering him and because he felt like he didnâ€™t deserve her, he destroyed both of their hearts in the process. That being said, though, I had a hard time witnessing Noahâ€™s missteps, and I couldnâ€™t quite grasp why he would willfully crush Kit because I didnâ€™t know what he was hiding until close to the end of the story.I understand the reasons for Nalini Singh not wanting to expose Noahâ€™s past right away, and I also know that there are clues along the way, but without truly knowing what demons Noah was battling, I didnâ€™t feel a connection to him, which prevented me from keeping an open mind about Noahâ€™s actions and actually made me question why Kit was willingly putting herself through the pain and torture of trying to be Noahâ€™s friend again. Iâ€™m all for a tortured hero proving himself and doing what it takes to get his girl and show her that heâ€™s changed and he can be who she wants him to be, but Noahâ€™s cruelty was reprehensible and it was difficult for me to see past it.Hereâ€™s the thing, though, even though I didnâ€™t like Noah for much of the text, Singh does do a fantastic job of showing readers how conflicted both Noah and Kit are; she allows us inside their heads and we can clearly see how much Noahâ€™s betrayal tore both of them apart and destroyed a relationship that both of them felt necessary in order to make it through their crazy paparazzi filled lives.Rock Redemption has a slow building plot line. What Noah broke had to be fixed and that kind of damage canâ€™t be repaired over night. I do appreciate that Singh didnâ€™t immediately reunite Noah and Kit because thereâ€™s a lot to work through both individually and as a potential couple. But I would have liked a bit more at the end of the story, illustrating who Noah and Kit are now and how theyâ€™ve changed since everything happened and the truth of Noahâ€™s past came out. Hopefully, readers will see more of them in the next book, but it seems like Abe will have plenty of turmoil of his own to deal with if his story is told next.A complimentary copy was provided in exchange for an honest review.3.5 Poison Apples

Tortured. Conflicted. Damaged. Broken.These are all perfect descriptors of what Harrison has become after he lost the love of his life and their unborn child at the hand of a group of bikers. Since that day, Harrison has battled his rage and vowed revenge on any biker, classifying them all as dangerous and despicable people who have no redeeming qualities.Harrison is his own worst enemy because his hardened heart keeps him from moving on and giving his heart to anyone else. The man who prides himself on control and requires full submission from his sexual partners will share his body with them, but heâ€™ll never give them any other part because besides his need for a release, he has no other feelings but pain and anger.Harrison needs someone to save him from himself and help him to move forward instead of staying in the past, but there arenâ€™t many women strong enough to endure his controlling ways nor his hot/cold demeanor, and regardless of how much Eva loves the way Harrison gets her to submit to his every sexual command, she doesnâ€™t know if Harrison can be saved, or if she even wants to take responsibility for that arduous task after dealing with her jerk of an ex and the damage he did to her.Can a person so devastatedly broken be fixed?Can a man who hasnâ€™t cared about anything in such a long time learn to care with the help of the right woman?Can a couple who has only ever given each other their bodies commit to more?These are the questions that Jani Kay answers in Tormented, and because theyâ€™re complicated issues, Kay takes her time in offering the solutions that her readers want because Harrison will have to seek his own absolution before he can fully give himself to Eva and Eva might not be able to wait as long as Harrison needs.Harrison and Evaâ€™s story is a dark and volatile journey that takes them both to hell and back in more ways than one. They experience highs and lows throughout their relationship, and they both wrestle with their true feelings for one another and what that means for their future. Harrison needs to get out of his head and realize that his past doesn't have to define his relationships/feelings in the present and no one else can accomplish that feat except Harrison, and once he does, heâ€™ll be truly free to explore what he feels for Eva, but thatâ€™s a difficult step for him â€“ one he might not be ready or able to take.A complimentary copy was provided in exchange for an honest review.4 Poison Apples

If youâ€™re the son of Cash Mayson, youâ€™ve heard the stories about your father and his brothers finding their BOOM, and whether you believe the tales or not, a part of you has to be waiting for that feelingâ€¦that moment when everything comes together and the girl youâ€™re supposed to spend forever with is put in your path. Iâ€™m sure Jax never would have thought heâ€™d come face to face with his BOOM in the situation that he does, but one thingâ€™s for sure, once he lays eyes on Ellie Anthony, he feels EVERYTHING that heâ€™s been told he would, and regardless of if she knows it or not, Ellieâ€™s his.No female can prepare for or contend with a Mayson male when he has his sights set on them and who would want to? Even though Ellie doesnâ€™t know how to deal with Jax and his persisting, claiming ways, it doesnâ€™t mean sheâ€™s adverse to them; she just doesnâ€™t know how to handle his advances because she hasnâ€™t led that kind of life. Ellieâ€™s innocent to a lot of things in life, and sheâ€™s not used to someone looking out for her and having her back. Since she was 19, sheâ€™s relied on only herself in raising her daughter and living life with very little. Aurora Rose Reynolds does a fantastic job of illustrating how overwhelmed Ellie is by Jax and his entire family. Ellieâ€™s in a complicated situation because there are things she hasnâ€™t shared with Jaxâ€¦things that could completely change his view of her, and she doesnâ€™t feel ready to expose those secrets because in her mind, Jax is still a wildcard due to his past with women.Jax is an amazing hero; the way he steps up for both Ellie and Hope is swoon worthy. Through his words and his actions, Jax proves how much he wants Ellie to be his and the steps heâ€™s willing to take to make her believe that what he feels and what they could have are real. Jax is a Mayson, so it goes without saying that heâ€™s had his share of women but just like his father and uncles, he knows when he first sets his eyes on Ellie that sheâ€™s the only one for him, and he goes about making sure everyone around them understands that as well.Until Jax is a sexy and sweet story that continues to prove why the Mayson men are the epitome of the alpha hottie. Every time Aurora Rose Reynolds introduces readers to a new one, they can rest assure that the journey to their happily ever after is going to filled with smokinâ€™ hot scenes, jealousy, and a bit of drama, which is a combination we just canâ€™t get enough of when it comes to these ultimate men.Bring on the next BOOM!A complimentary copy was provided in exchange for an honest review.4.5 Poison Apples

Chelle Bliss does a great job of giving her readers a true alpha male in looks, attitude, and perspective. In Unlawful Desire, Bliss tells Frisco Jonesâ€™ story through his own eyes, so readers get to truly understand his reluctance in getting into any kind of relationship more than a sexual one due to his past with his cheating fiancÃ©e. We also get to witness the bond that Frisco has with the other members of the ALFA Private Investigation Team and his brotherly friendships with his crew from the Neon Cowboy.Frisco Jonesâ€™ hesitancy to start anything with Georgia regardless of Sunshineâ€™s persistence and his obvious desire for Georgia makes perfect sense; heâ€™s broken from his last relationship, which is clear from his internal thoughts and outward hot/cold actions, but what I had a bit of a hard time with was the fact that Frisco worked so hard to distance himself from Georgia but then he quickly goes all in and canâ€™t get enough of her â€“ their ping pong relationship gave me whiplash at times. Donâ€™t get me wrongâ€¦I do understand Friscoâ€™s reactions and his ultimate decision to be with Georgia, but Iâ€™m not sure if I just didnâ€™t feel a solid connection between them before he was all in or the fact that it felt like Frisco was more pressured into starting it in the first place that I couldnâ€™t wrap fully wrap my head around his change of heart.As separate characters, I loved Frisco and Georgia; theyâ€™re both straight shooters who are a bit jaded from their past relationships. Regardless of their age difference and Georgiaâ€™s innocence, her sassiness and playfulness get under Friscoâ€™s skin and make him rethink numerous times in the beginning that he should just give into his desires for her. But as a couple I struggled because Frisco seemed to be fighting against her through the first half of the story and then when they reach a point that heâ€™s willing to try, it gets deep quickly, which I had a hard time with because it never felt like a foundation was built between them to have such deep feelings.Regardless of my feelings of a missed connection, I enjoyed hanging out with Frisco, some of the Gallos and his buddies from the Neon Cowboy. The one feeling I always have when I read one of Blissâ€™ books is that thereâ€™s definitely a sense of love and camaraderie among the lead/secondary characters, which is illustrated through their banter and the playful antics they get into on a regular basis. A sense of family resonates off of the pages as they all willingly work to have each otherâ€™s back and even step over boundaries thinking itâ€™s for the otherâ€™s own good.I really hope Bearâ€™s story is up next because heâ€™s definitely an interesting character who has a lot to say regardless if anyone listens.A complimentary copy was provided in exchange for an honest review.3.5 Poison Apples

The Secretâ€™s Out is another great biker book from Lila Rose! It's a bit different from her other MC reads, which isn't a bad thing, and it actually fits the dynamic of the story quite well. The pace was a bit slower, but that part  also makes sense due to Josie's need to go slow and Pick and Eli understanding that fact and doing everything in their power to put her mind at ease while still showing her how much they love her and want her to be theirs.A relationship with two people with dark pasts and haunting demons is bad enough, but when you throw another person in the mix, one who may not have had as horrendous a past as the other two, but doesnâ€™t truly know the feeling of love, complications will arise and complex feelings will have to be dealt with in a way that doesnâ€™t alienate any of them.What I find most interesting about the dynamics between Josie, Pick, and Eli is that it actually seems like the only way a relationship will work between them is if itâ€™s all three of them - only two doesnâ€™t work because thereâ€™s too much darkness that could consume them; the right amount of light and feeling of home can only be provided in a triad relationship and Lila Rose does a great job of illustrating that fact throughout the course of the text.Josie Alexander is an interesting heroine; she may not be as confident or have a backbone like Roseâ€™s typical heroines, but the way she is able to survive and live on her own for so long dealing with the horrors of her past and the torment of her present proves how much of a fighter Josie is. And even though Josie didnâ€™t have to go it alone, I give her credit for wanting to prove to herself that she could.Pick and Eli - itâ€™s amazing how effortless it is for them to give Josie everything she needs not asking for anything in return. By having Josieâ€™s back together even when they thought there was no way for either one of them to have her as theirs is a testament to the type of men they are, despite the abuse Pick went through as a child and the loveless childhood that Eli had. I do wish the relationship/feelings between Pick and Eli was explored more; they had a few encounters and comments about how they felt for one another, but I wanted to feel their connection more...understand what it is that they gave one another without Josie in the middle.Regardless of my desire for a bit more from Roseâ€™s alpha men, The Secretâ€™s Out is a great spinoff of Roseâ€™s Hawks MC Club series, and I canâ€™t wait to see what she has in store for more of her tough and tortured heroes and kickbutt heroines.A complimentary copy was provided in exchange for an honest review.4 Poison Apples

I knew Ren and Ashâ€™s journey to their happily ever after was going to be a tumultuous one because their entire relationship has been a battle of wills - each one wanting to dominate and unhinge the other one, but I didnâ€™t expect them to self destruct with minimal interference from others.Ren and Ash have both fought their personal demons, and they seemed to have overcome them, working together to support and encourage each other regardless of the set backs or frustrations that came along the way. Through all of the hardships and tests Ren and Ash have been through, their desire and love for each other has only evolved, but when Ash, once again, deals with his issues of abandonment and unworthiness alone, not allowing Ren to help or even know whatâ€™s going on in his head, the old wounds and worries rear their head again, forcing both of their volatile feelings to spike and leading them down a path that they may not be able to come back from unless Ash once and for all allows Ren completely in and Ren finally stops running away and starts fighting for her man.Iâ€™ve truly loved witnessing Ren and Ashâ€™s relationship from the very beginning. Thereâ€™s no one else that can give each other what they need, but thereâ€™s also a lot of obstacles to get past in order for them to have a fighting chance at making things work. Amity Cross allowed readers an insiderâ€™s look at the darkness within both Ren and Ash and how their easily provoked feelings could either be their saving grace or end up ruining any hope of being together. Both of them are fighters, which is clearly shown in their tenacity and work ethic, but Ren and Ash have short fuses and when things go down that they donâ€™t have control over, itâ€™s hard to determine how they will act and what those actions will mean for them when the dust settles.Spike brings Ren and Ashâ€™s story to a conclusion that readers will be satisfied with because Cross ensures that their ending still holds true to who Ren and Ash are at their core, which means that passion and all consuming sexual encounters dominate how they show each other how they feel and fierce fighting is how they work out their frustrations.A complimentary copy was provided in exchange for an honest review.4 Poison Apples

Lucas Titan is a man who gets what he wants, when he wants it, and allows no one to stand in his way, but he's finally put in his place by a sassy, strong woman who refuses to allow the scars of her past to rule her present. She will not cower to Titan's demands nor allow him to rule her life, but regardless of her disdain for him, her body wants his, and once they start, they just might be the only person for each other who can see beneath one another's regrets, pain, and facade.Holy Hell is Lucas Titan one arrogant jerk, but hereâ€™s the thing, he has EVERY right to be that way because heâ€™s a self made man who looks only to himself to build and grow his empire. Lucas thrives on control, power, and dominance, but he realizes that he also likes the challenge that Yve brings into his life, and as they give into their physical attraction for one another, Lucas and Yve slowly start to realize beneath each otherâ€™s tough exteriors is someone who longs unconditional love and someone at his/her back because regardless of how much they abhor asking anyone for help, they truly deserve respect, care, and comfort from someone who understands their scars and sees past them.Yve Santos has always been a bit of a mystery in Meghan Marchâ€™s Beneath series. But readers could tell without a doubt that sheâ€™s lived through a horrific past that puts her on edge, exacerbates her fears, and keeps a voice in her head that brings her to her knees with worthlessness. But Lucas Titan brings out her sass and bossiness, allowing her to gain back some of the control that she lost at the hands of her ex husband.I absolutely loved Beneath These Scars, and Lucas Titan is by far my favorite of Meghan Marchâ€™s heroes because he is who he is and he doesnâ€™t give a carp, at least externally, what others think about him. He may take drastic and underhanded steps to get what he wants, but thatâ€™s because heâ€™s used to taking care of himself and fighting tooth and nail for what he wants. His scars come from his relationship with his deceased father and every step he has taken since his fatherâ€™s death has been to prove that heâ€™s a better man than his father ever was in terms of his intelligence and drive to succeed. I never hated Lucas in the other books in the series because at some level, I understood his game plan and I saw that there was more to him than his duplicitous ways.I love the fact that readers get to witness Lucas and Yveâ€™s story through both of their perspectives because it allows us to truly see underneath all of their actions and attitudes; their love to hate relationship is both comical and incredibly hot because their explosive feelings are translated into sexy and spiteful interactions, making for one heck of a fun read.I dare readers to be introduced to Lucas Titan in Beneath These Scars and not find his take charge attitude and demanding personality hot as hell and totally worth his dominating ways!A complimentary copy was provided by the author/publisher in exchange for an honest review.5 poison apples

DesperateTo forgetTo pretend thereâ€™s no longer heartacheTo have someone whoâ€™s safe and constantDesperateTo dispel the demonsTo reinvent herself and become a better versionTo no longer feel guilty or ashamedChancesTo be redeemedTo fight for what is wantedTo let go of the pain and look forward instead of backThese are the desperate chances that Gracie Cook and Mitch Abrams cling to a year after one night of sex destroyed their friendship and turned them into strangers. But even after all that time, the regret and anger still controls them, forcing them to react instead of listen with the only conclusion being to remember what they once had and acknowledge that it will never be that way again.Boy did Gracie and Mitch frustrate me throughout most of their story! By allowing regret and betrayal to consume them, they never fought for each otherâ€¦they never tried to make one another understand what was at stake by walking away. Both of them are to blame for the outcome of that one night and the circumstances they now find themselves in because neither was willing to see the big picture, to understand the issues that drove Gracie to make a decision that tore Mitch away from her, and regardless of how blatantly obvious it is that Mitch is with Sophie for the wrong reasons and Gracie is now ready to give herself fully to Mitch and try again, neither will step up and fight for what they want, which led to even more lashing out and miscommunication.Mitch and GracieGracie and MitchThatâ€™s how itâ€™s supposed to be - not Mitch on one side and Gracie on the other, forcing their friends to feel the awkwardness of the situation, but sometimes people give up too easilyâ€¦.sometimes people overreact before really thinking about what theyâ€™re doing and then any chance they had was gone and all they have is what could have been.A Meredith Walters illustrates the ill effects of lost chances and the reality of desperate acts; she proves that settling and taking the safe route is never the best option when itâ€™s not what someone wants or needs. Regardless of the mistakes that Gracie and Mitch made, the time they spent apart allowed Gracie to reinvent herself â€“ to become a person who could prevent herself from self-destructing and with a clear mind, understand her truly feelings for Mitch and work to be the woman Mitch has always seen her as, even after all the time apart.A complimentary copy was provided in exchange for an honest review.4 Poison Apples

To be a Casey, Hannah must exude perfection in order to keep the facade in place that the Caseys arenâ€™t anything but a respectable family. But thatâ€™s not the truth; in fact, itâ€™s far from it, and when tragedy strikes the Casey family yet again, the fractures start to show until it seems like itâ€™s an open sore, festering and oozing pain, sadness, and heartbreak. And all of those feelings threaten to suffocate Hannah until she learns to deal with whatâ€™s underneath the surface and the messy reality that sheâ€™s left with when everything is said and done.Even though Anything But Broken is told through both the hero and heroineâ€™s perspective, this is Hannahâ€™s story, and Joelle Knox does a great job of illustrating everything that Hannahâ€™s had to deal with by being a Casey and what it means for her future to simply be Hannah. Hannah is definitely a product of her parents' mandates and being exposed to that type of environment for so long forces her to lose who she really is, which is what she's desperately trying to figure out in Anything but Broken, but that canâ€™t occur until truths are revealed and a plan is put in place in order for her to realize that she no longer has to impress or work to not disappoint her family.Anything But Broken is definitely character driven, and thereâ€™s a lot to unpack and learn about Hannah and Sean, both individually and as a couple. Hannah trying to have a relationship with Sean, someone who knows all about the Casey family secrets, is not going to be easy especially since Sean has been on the receiving end of the Casey mandates.Hannah and Sean's issues will definitely resonate with readers and the emotional turmoil felt does illustrate what Hannah's going through, but I still didn't feel completely connected to the characters - I felt like their issues werenâ€™t fully examined; there were steps taken towards Hannah reclaiming herself and Sean letting go of past regrets, but I needed a bit more insight so that I could clearlyunderstand everything that had to be dealt with before the new Hannah could be completely born.Even days after reading Anything But Broken, Iâ€™m not sure how I feel about Hannah and Sean's story. At times, it was slow moving and I felt lost in Hannahâ€™s despair and the way she was coping with that feeling. Other times, Hannah and Seanâ€™s torment resonated off the pages and I was right there with them dealing with the aftermath of harsh revelations.  Both Hannah and Sean are dealing with large amounts of regret and guilt, but they find solace in each other despite their shared pasts. Joelle Knox makes it clear why they find comfort by being together, but I just didn't feel like they dealt with their individual issues enough for them to move forward together. I guess I felt like it was more a work in progress and thereâ€™s nothing wrong with that, but I just wanted to feel like Hannah and Sean were going to make it no matter what, and I didnâ€™t.A complimentary copy was provided by the author/publisher in exchange for an honest review.3.5 poison apples

For a man who doesnâ€™t do complicated and avoids distractions like theyâ€™re the plague, Jake sure knows how to muddy the waters when it comes to a certain woman and her 6 orphaned nieces and nephews. Sure, he fought his attraction to her as best he could because he knew getting involved with Chelsea and the kids would be a major disturbance to his neat and easy lifestyle, but thereâ€™s definitely more to Jake than his defense attorney persona, and thatâ€™s the man that Chelsea and the kids allow Jake to be, which is exactly why Jake Becker just might be my favorite Emma Chase alpha male!Readers all know that Emma Chase creates amazing male characters who may be a bit tarnished and rough of the edges but theyâ€™re also men who refuse to settleâ€¦who do what it takes to get the victory each and every time, and the ultimate win for them is finding a woman who fits them and their lifestyle and isnâ€™t afraid to fight back for what they want. Jake Becker epitomizes that description even if he doesnâ€™t really realize it until later on in the story.Because Sustained is told solely through Jakeâ€™s perspective, readers are privy to all insider information. We understand his perceptive and intelligent mind and how it worksâ€¦we clearly see how much he cares and sympathizes with others and what heâ€™s willing to do to fix things when no one else seems to want to step up. Jake may be a criminal defense attorney who â€œoutsmartsâ€ and â€œout maneuversâ€ his opponents with ease, but thereâ€™s so much more to him, and with his interaction with Chelsea and her clan of kids as well as his internal musings about them and the situation he finds himself in, we truly get to know the real Jake not just the tenacious lawyer hellbent on a win.Chelsea and her nieces and nephews definitely stole my heart. Iâ€™m a sucker for books with kids in them, and Emma Chase does a fantastic job of illustrating Jake and Chelseaâ€™s interactions with them. There are multiple kid moments in the story where I was swooning over how Jake handled them and other times, my heart broke for the pain those kids felts in losing their parents and trying to cope. The kids added a whole other layer of greatness to the book and made readers feel like a part of their family.I absolutely loved Jake's story; it was amazing to witness Jake's transformation, and while there were setbacks, and I wanted to punch him a time or two, he steps up in really big ways and learns to love the idea of commitment and more.Emma Chase once again proves why she reigns as a writer of the male pov, but even more than that, her character and relationship building in Sustained is phenomenal, and itâ€™s part of the reason why Iâ€™ll always read her stories!A complimentary copy was provided by the author/publisher in exchange for an honest review.5 Poison Apples

Griff's story has two plot lines that center around his past catching up with his present, both in ways that will definitely change his position in Storm as well as his need to keep women at a distance, not allowing any attachment on his or their part.Club business and past misdeeds are to blame for the trouble brewing in Storm and a certain honest and sexy woman is responsible for Griff reconsidering getting in deep with another woman again, but Griff's got his work cut out for him in order to fix his mess with Storm, and with Sophia, he's going to have to realize that not every girl is like his lying ex.The Storm MC is at a bit of an impasse - the clubâ€™s loyalty is split; Scott and Griff are fighting like hell to bring Storm back to a united band of brothers, but thatâ€™s easier said than done when not everyone agrees with Scott or Griffâ€™s position in the club. Adding to that is Griffâ€™s reasons for becoming a member of Storm and the revelations that can not only put Griffâ€™s membership in question but it could also mean adding to the crap thatâ€™s already going down around the club.Sophia is my kind of heroine. Her life has not been easy, but she tries to put her past behind her and focus on what she wants and deserves in the present. Sheâ€™s a rambler who gives nothing but pure honesty in every encounter. What you see is what you get with Sophia, which is exactly the kind of girl Griff needs in his life.Sophia and Griff donâ€™t hit it off right away because Griff doesnâ€™t see her as being someone who can deal with the no strings approach that he has down to a science, but soon, Sophiaâ€™s turning the tables on him and he finds that her lightness might be exactly what his darkness needs.Nina Levine definitely brings the feels in the newest installment of her Storm MC series. Readers feel Sophia and Griffâ€™s heartache over their pasts as well as their tension and frustration when they have to deal with people/situations from their past invading their present.Levine does a great job of moving Storm MCâ€™s issues forward and what Scott and his brothers are doing to make that happen. A lot goes down with the club in Illusive as well as with Griffâ€™s personal life, and the two story lines work well together, giving Griff something to fight for outside of the club and realizing that the past doesnâ€™t have to be the only part of your story.Thereâ€™s mention in the text about what Harlow and Scott are dealing with, and since the 6th book in the series, Command, finishes their story. Iâ€™ll anxiously be waiting to see how everything works out between them and what new situations the club will find themselves in with chaos coming in from all different directions.A complimentary copy was provided in exchange for an honest review.4.5 poison apples

Slammer is the ultimate jacked up read, and the journey to the truth and heart of who and what X, Christopher Jacobs, was and became is deliciously dark, erotic, and all kinds of messed up.Itâ€™s true that prison is its own black hole; it controls, manipulates, and tortures its inhabitants, even those who are not behind bars. Itâ€™s a place where personal convictions and morals have no place and physical freedom is only part of what the darkness takes away from the convicted who dwell there. Regardless of the the type of monstrous men the criminals were on the outside, being locked up feeds the beast, unleashing its fury in a multitude of messed up ways.One of the things that I love about Slammer is that Tabatha Vargo provides both perspectives of prison life at Fulton Rhodes Penitentiary - those who are the convicted criminals and those who are there to protect, treat, and keep the prisoners in line. But what she also illustrates is that sometimes those lines blur and those who are meant to protect and serve wind up only serving themselves and their own vile vices.Vargo doesnâ€™t sugar coat anything when it comes to the actions and words of the murderers and rapists who are contained in each cell. She provides a realistic look at the deprive souls and how much further theyâ€™ve gone into the darkness of their souls by entering prison - a place that is kill or be killedâ€¦an environment where if you donâ€™t belong to someone, thereâ€™s an x on your back from the startâ€¦a territory that exists and functions by its own set of rules and where everyone must prove their worth in one soulless act or another.This domain is where Christopher Jacobs became X - a beast of a man with enough anger built up inside of him that could destroy anyone in his path. Heâ€™s the man to take down in prison and heâ€™s always up to the challenge. As much as Fulton creates X, Lyla, the new registered nurse at the prison, allows small glimpses of Christopher to still break through the monster mask, and this is where the storyâ€™s complexity builds because how can a young, innocent woman be attracted to someone who brutally murdered two people unless there were qualities about him that showed a different side of who X is?The growing attraction between Lyla and X is clearly illustrated through their limited time in the infirmary and the risks theyâ€™re both taking to act on those feelings, but the complexity of their relationship is just not the fact that itâ€™s occurring inside the prison walls where X has been sentenced to life in prison, but itâ€™s also in the risks that Lyla takes to prove X is so much more than a convicted murderer. This part of the story is extremely well written; itâ€™s fast paced, mind bending, and dangerous, and readers will not see/understand how it ends until theyâ€™re forced to face the truth of the situation and then looking back, theyâ€™ll wonder why they never thought of that conclusion. These kinds of stories are the ones I absolutely love because I can form various theories and feel like Iâ€™m on the right track, which keeps my interest in the story steadfast, and then when itâ€™s revealed, Iâ€™m completely blown away because I never anticipated it!Is Slammer not for everyone? Absolutely! Readers definitely need to heed the Vargoâ€™s warning! Itâ€™s a dark read that provides perspective on the inner workings of dangerous criminals and what they do in order to claim some kind of status in the prison. When morals donâ€™t factor into the equation of actions then anything goes and that is exactly the case at Fulton Penitentiary.So go into X and Lylaâ€™s story knowing that you will be privy to sinister and disgusting acts, and they absolutely will make your skin crawl and your stomach nauseous, but Slammer will also rock your world with its well crafted and intriguing plot line and its complex characters.Itâ€™s a definite mindjolt but in the best way possible!A complimentary copy was provided in exchange for an honest review.5 poison apples

Felicity's story is definitely not what I expected from the synopsis and title, but the way J.J. McAvoy delivers it and the information that is revealed - facts that I never saw coming - makes Sugar Baby Beautiful a fantastic read about so much more than having someone provide a lifestyle simply by looking good in his/her presence.Felicity Harper is quite the enigmaâ€¦from the very beginning, readers can tell that thereâ€™s more to her that what she allows people, even readers, to see. Sheâ€™s hellbent on concealing her past by not allowing anyone to know too much about her. This is how Felicity copes with the life sheâ€™s been dealtâ€¦from a mistake that forces her to punish herself by losing things that she loved. Even though Felicityâ€™s not content with how sheâ€™s living, she canâ€™t risk moreâ€¦she canâ€™t handle giving herself to someone because sheâ€™s scared at what might happen if she does.But Felicity never counted on meeting Theodore Darcy - an alpha male whoâ€™s used to getting what he wants, and he most definitely wants Felicity in his bedâ€¦in his lifeâ€¦any way he can have her. Thereâ€™s a lot to know and understand about Theo, and J.J. McAvoy slowly unravels the mystery behind the possessive billionaire and what heâ€™s willing to risk to keep the woman whose made him come to life. But Theoâ€™s not the only one with layers to his personality; in fact, Felicity seems much more elusive, and as clues to her past filter into her present, itâ€™s still extremely difficult to construct a big picture understanding because thereâ€™s parts to her that still remain unknown.Sugar Baby Beautiful is my first read by J.J. McAvoy, so I didnâ€™t quite know what to expect from her writing style or characters, but I have to say that I love the fact that nothing is transparent in her storytelling. McAvoy takes the story in one direction, but then turns it on its side in order to progress the way that she wants, and she does that with her characters as well. All of the characters seem to hold their cards tightly to their chest, never giving everything at once, always making people work to see who they are and what theyâ€™re all about, and to me, those are the best types of characters because readers get to experience the charactersâ€™ evolvement, and as revelations are brought out, because weâ€™ve been watching everything seamlessly unfold in the way that McAvoy wants it to, the ah ha moment astonishes us - at least at first - but then when we take a moment to rewind the events of the story, we see small clues sprinkled about just waiting to be acknowledged, but they canâ€™t be until McAvoy allows readers to see a clear picture, which she does by building the story the way that she wants to and making it intriguing as itâ€™s constructed.Canâ€™t wait to dive into more stories by J.J. McAvoyA complimentary copy was provided in exchange for an honest review.4.5 Poison Apples

Nicole Edwards writes fantastic books; there hasnâ€™t been one that I havenâ€™t enjoyed. Sheâ€™s definitely the Queen of menage, but sheâ€™s also one of my go to authors for M/M reads and the solid writing and fantastic character development in Never Say Never is one of the main reasons that I canâ€™t get enough of her hot alpha males who fight hard and play even harder.â€œNever Say Neverâ€ - itâ€™s definitely a good motto to live by, and for Zachariah â€œZâ€ Tavoularis, itâ€™s one that allows him to weather the storm that his long time crush and boss, Ryan Trexler, forces him to go through as RT fights his attraction to Z because he refuses to mix business with pleasure ever again after the debacle that occurred three years ago with Kevin. But the heart and body want what they want and as much as Ryan forces himself to not allow emotions/lust to influence his decisions, Zâ€™s pull is too much for him to combat, but if Ryan doesnâ€™t get out of his own head, it might just ruin the best thing to ever happen to him before it ever really begins.Most of the time, Iâ€™m a first person point of view reader; I don't usually feel like I get inside characters' heads when the story is written in third person, but Edwards always manages to reveal everything to readers through her meticulous character evolvement. Readers actually learn more about Z than his co workers and friends know about him because heâ€™s such a private person so theyâ€™ve had to establish their own views on his life, which are definitely a misrepresentation of who Z is and even Ryan is guilty of this skewed view.The secondary story line is the whole reason Ryan and Z are forced to face their feelings for one another, and itâ€™s a great backdrop for them to consider what risks theyâ€™re willing to take in order to have the man they want.Z and Ryan definitely sizzle when they're together; theyâ€™re both control freaks, so itâ€™s interesting to see how they both attempt to top from the bottom. The way Edwards writes their sexual encounters as well as their lust filled foreplay is enough to make any reader weak in the knees and wet in the panties.I canâ€™t fault Ryan for his uneasiness in pursuing a relationship with Z even one of a sexual nature. Edwards definitely makes it clear where Ryan is coming from, but that doesn't mean his actions didn't frustrate the heck out of me. His hot and cold demeanor and the pain it caused Z definitely didnâ€™t sit well with me.I have to say that I love Z and everything that makes him who he is; heâ€™s an incredibly trustworthy and caring man who everybody wants to be around because he has a certain charisma about him that pulls people to his side.Never Say Never is a sexy, angsty and suspenseful read whose main and secondary characters know how to have a good time and get the job done. I was rooting for Ryan and Z from the very beginning, but I knew that Ryan was going to have to work things out for himself before he woke up to what he was missing out on by resisting Zâ€™s charms.I canâ€™t wait to see which alpha is up next!A complimentary copy was provided in exchange for an honest review.4.5 poison apples

Cocky Bastard was not the book I expected it to be....well, it was because Chance definitely is one self assured son of a bitch, but there's so much more to this story than his swagger - the second half of the book shows a much different Chance than the first half, which only adds to his magnetism and appeal. Don't get me wrong, Chance still delivers the one liners and sexual innuendoes, but readers also observe his determination...his persistence...his need to make amends for what happened even if his plan doesn't pan out, and that's the Chance that readers will swoon over.Both Chance and Aubrey are at a crossroads in their life, and although they have very different reasons for feeling adrift, they go into their cross country trip with every intention to make the most of it - fainting goat and all. But once the adventure is finished is when everything gets complicated, and itâ€™s up to Cocky and Princess to figure out whatâ€™s between them and what theyâ€™re willing to do to keep their exploits going.Cocky Bastard is a highly entertaining story about adventure, second chances, redemption, and finding oneâ€™s true path. The second half is a bit angsty, and some of Chance and Aubreyâ€™s actions drove me nuts, but mistrust is a significant obstacle to overcome and thereâ€™s bound to be mixed signals. I like that the first half of the book is told from Aubreyâ€™s point of view because sheâ€™s the one who has made a life changing decision and itâ€™s her chance to find herself, but then the second half turns to Chanceâ€™s perspective, which also makes sense because heâ€™s the one who now has a chance to change his life forever and heâ€™s bound and determined to do so.Penelope Ward and Vi Keeland are must read authors in their own right, so putting their fantastic minds together in Cocky Bastard makes for a book of hilarity, steam, and drama!A complimentary copy was provided in exchange for an honest review.4.5 Poison Apples

Holy Hell! Officer Ben Kelly and his pretty girl, Mia, have to be one of the hottest and sweetest couples I have ever read about. Their affection and desire for each other resonates off of every page! They're it for each other and their life is everything they hoped it would be...except a little one on one time is definitely something they could use more of;)I loved getting more of Ben and Mia's story and their growing family. Nolan is still as precious as he was when he was three, and he loves his brother, Chase, something fierce. The idea of finding time to be a couple when you have kids is definitely something readers will relate to; I'm sure everyone has been c**k blocked by their children one time or another, and sometimes people have to get quite creative in order to have sex. The sizzle between Ben and Mia is as hot as ever and J. Daniels illustrates their connection with their dirty comments, need to constantly touch each other, and the internal musings about how lucky they are to have each other.I adore this series and J. Daniels is one of my must read authors!I can't get enough of the Kelly family and Daniels' Alabama Boys series, and I can't wait for Riley and CJ's story!

Forsaken - the title of Chadâ€™s story is quite fitting, in both positive and negative ways and on a number of levels. For six years, Chad has felt abandoned, almost giving up hope that this deadly game heâ€™s been playing will ever have the outcome he needs to keep Amy out of danger; heâ€™s foregone getting close to anyone that can be used against him, learning the hard way that everyone has their own agenda. Chad has  also given up his quest for money in his treasure hunting endeavors, taking up a new agenda - one that is for more than just himself, which is definitely out of character for him as a treasure hunter but not as the man who vows to protect those closest to him. Chad is a lone wolf so to speak on this journey to outwit those who paid him to find the cylinder and heâ€™ll continue to go it alone until he figures out a way to keep it out of their hands.I've been anxiously waiting for Chad to come out of hiding and end this war, so he could ensure his sisterâ€™s safety. I love that Lisa Renee Jones wrote Forsaken in only Chad's perspective - itâ€™s his warâ€¦his wrong to rightâ€¦his payback for what happened to his family. Gia definitely is an important part of the story line, but I see her, in a way, as Chadâ€™s redemption, because his journey to this point is tainted with mistrust, secrets, and a large amount of danger. Gia humanizes Chad, forcing him to see beyond this war and what he could have when everything is said and done.Enemies are coming from multiple directions, and Chad needs to decide what the best course of action is, forcing him to go outside his comfort zone and put trust, even it is a bit forced, in someone other than himself. Chad is full of guilt and rage and that drives him forward to end this game and find a way to protect his sister and Gia as well as the treasure that everyone wants to get their hands on. Chad's circle of trust expands in Forsaken, but as much as it seems things are headed in the right direction, there's still work to be done and bringing Liam Stone into the equation seems to be advantageous for everyone, including readers, because Iâ€™m sure weâ€™re all dying for more Liam!Forsaken is romantic suspense at its finest. With all the twists and turns the story takes, itâ€™s hard to know for sure who the good and bad guys are, but by the end of the text, it becomes clearer the steps that need to be taken to allow Chad, Gia, Amy, and Liam to have a life outside of the protective walls they have created.I canâ€™t wait to see how everything comes together in Unbroken!A complimentary copy was provided in exchange for an honest review.4.5 Poison Apples

There's no such thing as perfect timing, but for Grace and Matt, time was just one variable not working in their favor...missed opportunities, outside interference, and a multitude of regrets and what ifs have led them to 15 years of wondering what the other is doing and why they just couldn't get it right.In a way, Before We Were Strangers reminds me of the movie Sliding Doors. The heroine faces a decision that could lead her down two paths, and those journeys are shown in a parallel way throughout the film. Grace and Matt have personal and professional goals that could lead them down a path as a couple or one as individuals working to make a name for themselves in their fields of choice, but it seems as if the option they choose will categorically define them for years to come and force them down very different roads.After Grace and Mattâ€™s connection in college was torn apart, their lives went down parallel tracks that for many years never intersected, but through all the time they were traveling their own roads, they never stopped thinking about one another, leading them to believe that their story wasnâ€™t finishedâ€¦that the ending they had all those years ago was not supposed to be the conclusion to their relationship.But Grace and Mattâ€™s second chance at love is a rather bumpy one that leads to moments of rejection, despair, and life changing revelations. They both have to learn who they are now and not hold on too much to who they were before because looking back wonâ€™t move them forward.Renee Carlino does a great job of meticulously weaving Grace and Mattâ€™s present and past, examining the emotional impact for both of them. The reality of their situation is hard for them to accept, and readers will feel the exact same way because a love like theirs - one thatâ€™s real and seems so seamless - should not have been destroyed so easily. But what Carlino shows as well is that life is messy and choices made have a domino effect, in both positive and negative ways, and perhaps, the only way Grace and Matt could reunite and have a second chance at love is for them to have parted and lived separate lives, allowing for growth and understanding and forcing them both to realize that even when they were apart, they were never truly strangers because they still held each other in their hearts.A complimentary copy was provided by the author/publisher in exchange for an honest review.4.5 poison apples

King, Doe, Bear, and even Preppy's witty back talk are present in the follow up story to King and s*** definitely gets messed up in immensely dark and dangerous ways, but if readers have learned anything about King, itâ€™s that he comes alive when his backâ€™s up against a wall.Heâ€™s the King of the Causewayâ€¦the notorious Brantley Kingâ€¦the mother ***ing bad guy, and heâ€™ll do what he has to do to reclaim the girl who owns him and make everyone pay for taking her away from him by any means necessary. King has had his life messed up enough and heâ€™s going to damn well make sure that whoever messes with him and his pays for it in the harshest way possible.There's a lot on the line for more than just King and Doe; all the players involved have different objectives, meaning secrets, lies, and mayhem are the name of the game. King not only as to contend with Doeâ€™s father double crossing him, but he also has blow back from his actions in King. T.M. Frazier does a great job of demonstrating that Kingâ€™s lifestyle comes with repercussions, so as much as he wants to focus on Doe, he ultimately doesnâ€™t have that luxury because the s***  heâ€™s stirred up is ready to explode. But this is when King is at his best, allowing the darkness to consume him and do what needs to be done.In a way, King was about King's recognition that he's more than just a criminalâ€¦that he actually has a heart, and Doe allowed him to figure that out. The book proves how complex King is and how being with Doe opens up a part of himself that he had beaten back because of the s***storm that was his life. Tyrant is more Doe's transformation. She can no longer be HER, but she also can't completely be who she was with King because as her memory comes back and everything becomes clearer, Doe comes to a new understanding about her life and the direction it's heading and who will be with her for the ride.T.M. Frazier is truly a gifted writer; her ability to weave a story that is both dark and dangerous as well as witty and charming is a feat that not many authors can perfect and she does it every time she crafts a tale. I canâ€™t get enough of her multi-dimensional characters who are complete enigmas for what theyâ€™ve been through and how they react to their circumstances, and to me, Preppy, is the ultimate sidekick who continues to be felt and heard even after he goes off to have his own party!The EPILOGUE about ruined me! Itâ€™s everything I wanted to happen, and it plays out in the best way possible.I canâ€™t wait to see what T.M. Frazier brings her readers next because I know itâ€™s going to be absolutely amazing!A complimentary copy was provided in exchange for an honest review.5 Poison Apples

Iâ€™m a bit torn on this one. The book started a bit slow for me, and I had a hard time understanding the true connection Vaughn and Smoke have other than their respective lust for one another. It seems like they settle everything by having sex, thinking it might be their last encounter.  I needed a bit more discussion and insight to fully feel the intensity of Vaughn and Smokeâ€™s feelings; I wanted to be shown the progress of their relationship, and in a way, I felt like it was told to me instead.Donâ€™t get me wrongâ€¦I enjoyed reading Vaughn and Smokeâ€™s story. Both characters worked for me as individual heroes struggling to find their own way and be comfortable with themselves and their choices. Lee does a good job of exploring that idea and forcing them to question what really matters and the cost of not owning up to who you are, but the various threads of the story line didnâ€™t work that well for me; there was enough to figure out just based on the environment these two men were a part of and what they felt for each other so some parts of it felt like forced issues. But I also understand that Lee had a certain vision in mind, and she used the avenues that she felt would illustrate her points best and even if I didnâ€™t envision it the way she did that doesnâ€™t undervalue Vaughn and Smokeâ€™s story because big picture wise, I liked it a lot, and it shed light on issues the definitely deserve discussion in todayâ€™s society.The Darkest Flame was actually my first book by Christina Lee, and one thing I learned about her writing is that she sure knows how to write some hot as hell m/m sex scenes! Both Vaughn and Smoke are alpha males who need control and that commanding presence is acted on in the bedroom. For two men who wanting to do the owning, though, they also felt owned by one another, which made their sexual chemistry sizzle.If youâ€™re looking for a book with two sinfully hot alpha male heroes who canâ€™t help but crave one anotherâ€™s touch despite everything that seems to stand in their way then Vaughn and Smokeâ€™s story is definitely one to one-click!A complimentary copy was provided by the author/publisher in exchange for an honest review.3.5/4 Poison Apples

One's ability to let something go regardless of how big or small the situation is says a lot about the strength and character of that person. Whether it be letting go of regrets, guilt, or hurt feelings, life is a lot freer if someone is not burdened with those dark feelings. But being able to let go is a lot easier said than done because even if it makes sense logically, the mind is a complex part of the human body and when emotions are involved, people tend to allow those feelings to consume them.This principle holds true for the main characters of J.A. Redmerskiâ€™s newest release The Moment of Letting Go, and while Luke is the handsome and carefree guy who wants to help Sienna not to overthink and fight her fears while sheâ€™s in the lush and beautiful island of Hawaii, Luke himself needs those reminders as well because his ability to move on after a significant loss is something that is definitely holding him back from living his life to the fullest.On paper, Luke and Sienna couldnâ€™t be more different. Luke is a risk taker who finds a sense of freedom participating in extreme sports and releasing himself from the confines of the business world. Sienna overthinks everything and lives to work because she is defined by her success at her job and not much else.Luke and Sienna take one another outside their comfort zones: Lukeâ€™s walls start to break down as Sienna becomes someone important to him; someone who makes him feel more than he wants to because the fear of letting her in and her not accepting him is not something he wants to endure. Sienna starts to question everything about her life and if she has the confidence to let her old life go and move on to something that would satisfy her completely.Thereâ€™s a great message in Luke and Siennaâ€™s story about finding a way for people to unburden themselves and live life to the fullest. But in order to do something so grand, thereâ€™s definitely going to be conflict and tension, especially for two people who donâ€™t know each other well and live completely different lives.Iâ€™m a huge fan of J.A. Redmerskiâ€™s writing; her ability to write in multiple genres illustrates her diversity as an author. Her New Adult stories carry significant themes in them about life and how it should be lived regardless individual situations. The Moment of Letting Go is thought provoking and uplifting because it proves that life is about so much more than work and money and in order to live instead of merely to exist, people need to experience EVERYTHING life has to offer before itâ€™s too late.A complimentary copy was provided by the author/publisher in exchange for an honest review.4 poison apples

I am darkness. I am pain. I am mother f***ing death.Flame absolutely epitomizes darkness; he gets off on pain, and he thirsts for blood.  They provide him the release he needs and subdues the voice thatâ€™s constantly fracturing his mind. The voice of the devil himself; the one whoâ€™s responsible for creating a man who purges the flames inside him with one of his many knives.Maddie had her innocence stripped from her, and itâ€™s something that has forced her to shut down and become a recluse, living her life on pages instead of in reality,  fearing a manâ€™s touch and the simplest interactions. Her light was taken from her, which makes the fact that she found some bit of comfort and protection from a dark and tortured soul.Flame and Maddie's story was everything I had hoped it would be. Tillie Cole does a fantastic job of vividly illustrating how Flame and Maddieâ€™s separate journeys brought them to a place where they felt safe enough to mend the shattered fragments of their bodies and minds.  Cole expertly demonstrates that regardless of how fractured someone isâ€¦regardless of the fear and rage that dominates his/her entire being, as long as there is someone who sees that person as s/he truly is - a clear perception that is not distorted by nightmarish memories or twisted words - thereâ€™s hope that the flames and darkness will not truly destroy, and by the end of the text, readers will understand that Maddie has the power to keep the flames calm and Flame is the only person who can help Maddie to feel safe.As the other books in Coleâ€™s Hades Hangmen series, the subject matter and situations are not for the faint of heart, but they are essential in understanding everything that Flame and Maddie endured at the hands of deplorable men. There is no way to truly grasp the irreparable damage that was done to them without capturing it through meticulous description, which is exactly what Tille Cole provides her readers. Through Flame and Maddieâ€™s memories, every demonic act vividly comes to life, forcing readers to feel everything that they felt and endure the pain, torture, and cruelty that was done to them.As dark and painful as Flame and Maddieâ€™s story is, itâ€™s also a beautiful display of courage, trust, and transformation. Maddie is an amazingly strong character  a â€œpint sized warriorâ€ â€” someone who can withstand the flames and save the man who from the very beginning claimed her as his Maddie. Itâ€™s hard to define the kind of man Flame was made into due to what happened in his past, but whatâ€™s clear is that with Maddie by his side, he grows to understand that being different is not the same as being evil, and as much as he is an instrument of destruction, Flame also has the power to bring someone back to life.Souls Unfractured is writing at its finest. Every part of the story is essential to its plot line and the text clearly demonstrates Flame and Maddieâ€™s transformation. Itâ€™s evident in every word thatâ€™s written that Tillie Cole poured her soul into writing Flame and Maddieâ€™s story and that she left a piece of herself in there with him and thereâ€™s not a reader out there who wonâ€™t feel like they left a part of themselves in there as well. Absolutely phenomenal!A complimentary copy was provided in exchange for an honest review.5+ poison apples

Overtime is definitely an emotional read, which makes perfect sense because there's a lot of pain and scars to try to heal between Jordie and Kacey, and Toni Aleo's writing makes readers feel EVERYTHING!Overtime is seamlessly written...all of the struggles, on both sides, were completely realistic and written in a way that forces readers to fight through their own emotions while reading Jordie and Kacey's story. There is a bit of outside interference that threatens to undo all of the work that Jordie and Kacey accomplish throughout the duration of the text, but for the most part, Jordieâ€™s recovery and making amends as well as his and Kaceyâ€™s growth as people and as a couple are the driving force of the text.Toni Aleo captures Jordie's torment so well through her word choice and characterization. I sensed his anguish, his desperation, his desire to change. Readers can feel is struggle resonating from the pages, and the torment that threatens to seduce him back to his old ways of coping, but the one overpowering characteristic that illustrates Jordie besides all of the negative ones that have owned him for many years is his determination. Jordie doesnâ€™t want to fail again; he doesnâ€™t want to bring anyone down, especially Kacey. The new Jordie, the one heâ€™s hellbent of becoming, owns up to his mistakes and makes good on his promises.Kacey is just as conflicted as Jordie, but in a much different way; she loves Jordie with everything that she has, but she canâ€™t forget how he treated her and casted her aside so easily. She also has her own demons to navigate through and those fears and doubts play a big role in Kaceyâ€™s hot and cold demeanor around Jordie. I canâ€™t blame Kacey for her trepidation and hesitancy. Like Jordie, she has a lot to lose if they canâ€™t make a go at a new relationship. Toni Aleo does a great job of illustrating all of the negative thoughts that overwhelm Kaceyâ€™s psyche, and for much of the story, she allows those ill feelings to consume her and to drive her to make decisions that are definitely not in her best interest.  But just like Jordie, Kacey has to learn for herself what itâ€™s going to take to move forward instead of holding on to the baggage of the past.Jordie has a huge battle to win, for himself and for Kacey, and it's not an easy journey, and it shouldn't be because addiction is all consuming, and it dominates and destroys. But this is Jordieâ€™s last shot with Kacey and in the final minutes of a game, thatâ€™s when Jordieâ€™s the best at what he does, so he knows heâ€™s got this because he refuses to allow his demons to once again obliterate what he needs to live!I've read a lot of Toni Aleo's books, and I think Overtime is her best book so far. I devoured Jordie and Kaceyâ€™s story, and as frustrated and angered as I was with Jordieâ€™s actions in Wanting to Forget, in Overtime, I was in absolute awe of his determination and dedication at becoming someone he and his family could be proud of, and boy does he make his overtime minutes count!A complimentary copy was provided in exchange for an honest review.5+ Poison Apples

A sweet and dirty girl whoâ€™s looking to settle down.An alpha male who fights fires and protects his heart with casual hook ups.Two weeks. No strings. No future.But what happens when feelings become part of the deal and threaten to consume both of them? Will they allow their agreement to fizzle out or will they keep it burning long after the two weeks is up?Travis and Caraâ€™s story is a quick and steamy read that shows what happens when two people who have always shared a connection refuse to accept whatâ€™s staring right in front of them. Thereâ€™s not a whole lot of angst, which is good because forced drama in a story doesnâ€™t work for me. The story is more about why Travis is afraid to commit and why, if he finally decides to give into his feelings, Cara is the perfect choice.Right from the start, readers can sense the sexual tension between Travis and Cara and their true desires that are just below the surface. Lauren Blakely does a great job of illustrating how compatible they are by their witty banter and passionate encounters, and Blakely brings readers along to experience every consuming moment Travis and Cara share.Consumed By You is a great addition to the Fighting Fire series because it proves that some fires shouldnâ€™t be put out; they should actually be stoked, increasing the heat and sizzle to the point that itâ€™s scorching.A complimentary copy was provided by the author/publisher in exchange for an honest review.4 poison apples

I knew as soon as I finished Priest that I needed to get back to Sierra Simone's writing as soon as possible, and when this beauty of a box set was offered up for review, I couldn't wait to delve back into Simone's complex and conflicted characters immersed in a connection that is perverse and immoral by society's standards, but it's also one that the main characters can't get enough of because regardless of how wrong society deems it to be, it's what they crave and need in order to feel whole.In Victorian Society, appearance and social status mean everything - at least that's the facade that must be presented to the eyes of society - those who wield the power to help a woman rise or fall in terms of society's approval. But behind closed doors, individuals' baser needs are explored - it's a place where nothing is deemed uncouth because no one is there to judge - they are there to experience, experiment, and hold nothing back because the constraints of society do not matter.This is the sensual world Ivy Leavold is thrust into when she becomes an impoverished woman without a home, and her cousin's widower takes her into his home, Markham Hall. It is a place where Ivy is awakened, educated, punished, and reborn, and readers are privy to everything that Ivy welcomes and endures as she gives herself over to her wildest desires and finds the other half of her soul in a man who both loves and wants to tame her wildness - Julian Markham.But carnal sins are not the only transgressions to occur in Markham Hall. There's a darkness and mystery that surrounds the manor and its owner as well as a plethora of rumored indiscretions and dangerous tendencies.  Ivy has wholeheartedly given herself over to Mr. Markham's teachings, but they come at a price and have Ivy questioning everything that makes her feel alive, forcing her to become introspective and understand if what she wants and needs is truly worth the risk.Sierra Simone explores the human condition at its rawest and most carnal, and I love that she does so in a society that holds themselves in such high regards in terms of their standards and perceived way of living. Ivy is the perfect woman to become the explorer of this unspoken society because she has not been forced into the moral ways of the times. She's been fairly secluded from everything due to the loss of her parents and the ineptitude of her now deceased brother, so in a way, she is ripe for the picking, but only those who have a side to them that is drawn to the kind of impropriety Mr. Markham and his friends partake in can be lured as far in as Ivy goes.Julian Markham is quite the mysterious character through much of the first book, but once Ivy is immersed into his world and has given herself over to his teachings, readers learn more of his baser needs and desires and the reasons behind his dark and dangerous demeanor. It made perfect sense to me why Simone held off on providing readers with Julian's perspective until Ivy had committed herself to him. We could not be privy to all that is Julian Markham until he got what he wanted from Ivy. Once readers do gain that insight, though, things seem to get more complicated and further questions arise as to his choices and dalliances, but what we also see is that Ivy is truly the woman who completes him...who allows him to show all of himself and not be judged or scorned for what he needs.Sierra Simone clearly illustrates what both Ivy and Julian get out of their painful/pleasurable encounters and proves that something that allows them both to experience love at its rawest and most basic form should not be judged by others because it's a huge part of who they are and what makes them feel alive.I absolutely adored the Markham Hall series; it is an intensely provocative and captivating journey that Simone takes Ivy and Julian on, which also contains a good amount of mystery, deception, and drama. I'm so glad that I read the series when it was completed because I would have been incredibly frustrated by where the books stopped, which is a bad thing for me, but it also shows that Simone's writing and character development leave me wanting more, which is never a bad thing!A complimentary copy was provided by the author in exchange for an honest review.5 poison apples

Flash Bang is the perfect title for what happens to Rowan Callahan when a complete power grid failure sends the United States into a post-apocalyptic situation. Good thing for Rowan, her father is a doomsday prepper, so she knows exactly what needs to be done in order to survive and head back to her family home. But on her way, thatâ€™s when her life takes a new direction, and she finds herself wanting a relationship that she would have never considered before - one that would be considered taboo in modern society, but with what has happened to society, it seems only fitting that people rely on their own desires to find happiness in the chaos that has ensued and thatâ€™s exactly what she plans to do - peopleâ€™s opinions be damned.I absolutely loved Rowan! She is a kicka** heroine who can hold her own in almost any situation. When she arrives on Castle Creek Whitetail Ranch, she has every intention to flee and make it home to her family - the people she has let down far too often in her life - despite the fact that there are two strong and handsome men who stake a claim for her body and her heart.Zach and Graham are the perfect pair for Rowan because they bring different qualities into their relationship. They are definitely both alpha males and take know how to take control, but they also play off of each otherâ€™s personality, enabling both of them to get what they want. Zach is more of a carefree guy than Graham is, which works well because Graham is a bit high strung. But regardless of how quick tempered Graham is, heâ€™s also incredibly protective and yearns to have someone put him first for once in his life.I love that Meghan March keeps Rowan a snarky, witty, and stubborn woman throughout the story despite her affection for the two alpha males in her life. March has also created a great cast of characters to surround her leading woman and men with and hopefully their stories will be told as well.It's an interesting setting that this menage story takes place in, and I'm sure it's only going to be more intriguing as the US tries to regroup and seek help from those who can provide it. In a post-apocalyptic environment, rules and regulations are a thing of the past, so as word spreads about the ranch, Graham and is men are going to have to protect their group as well as their land, and itâ€™s not going to end well for some of them.A complimentary copy was provided in exchange for an honest review.4.5 poison apples

Hard Charger is a super quick read that illustrates Lia, the woman Rowan helped rescue in book 1,  having the strength and the confidence to slowly rebuild her life after she succumbed to the darkness of what happened to her.Liaâ€™s story begins about 9 months after she became a part of the Castle Creek Whitetail Ranch; sheâ€™s coming out of her shell more, but there are still things that trigger her memories and force her to draw inward again.But what Hard Charger also demonstrates is Liaâ€™s determination to move past what happened to her and feel alive and safe in the arms of the two men who had her back since the beginning - Cam and Travis.Cam and Travis are interesting heroes who remain a bit of a mystery even at the end of the text; readers donâ€™t learn much about them except for the fact that they both want to give Lia what she needs, and while I understand why the focus is on Liaâ€™s transformation, I had questions about the two men in her life that were left unanswered.Liaâ€™s need and love for two men does make sense to me because of what she experienced at the hand of a group of vile men, but Lia as well as Cam and Travis are new to a menage relationship, so I felt like there needed to be more insight into why they chose this journey.Regardless of my need for more information, I really enjoyed Hard Charger. I love the world that Meghan March has created due to the power grid failure and there are multiple ways this series can be extended, leading to more suspense, angst, and passion.One key idea that seems to be strewn throughout the Flash Bang series is that it may be unconventional but in the world that now exists on the outside, it's all about making oneself happy and not giving a damn who doesn't approve.A complimentary copy was provided in exchange for an honest review.4 poison apples

There's a lot at stake for Gracie and Raide in Hard to Fight, and it's up to them to decide what they're willing to fight for and what they need to let go of in order to make things right.Bounty Hunter vs. Bail SkipperOperation Bring In RaidePlan A: SeducePlan B: ChallengePlan C: ???I absolutely adored Gracie and her bada** bounty hunting self. She's an amazing heroine who puts a lot of pressure on herself to be the best because she's working against a lot of people and gender prejudice to do the job she loves.
