She finally gets a chance to prove herself, so she knows she needs to up her game because bringing in someone as big as Raide is going to require finesse, but as readers witness in the first half of Hard to Fight, sheâ€™s having a hard time putting her plans in action, which is well played by Bella Jewel because Grace finds herself in a rather precarious position when it comes to Raide and her conflict is played out well by how unsuccessful she is with him.Raide is a bada** alpha male who's dodging the law while trying to exact his revenge. He's a complex man - he's way more than just another criminal Gracie has to bring in, and she realizes that early on and walks a fine line while trying to reel him in. I would have loved to get a bit of Raideâ€™s perspective throughout the story; itâ€™s not that Grace doesnâ€™t describe him in ways that readers will understand who he is, but thereâ€™s things below the surface of Raide that I wanted to understand from his viewpoint not just through Graceâ€™s eyes.Gracie is definitely a fighter, and Raide has proven his determination to seek justice, but there are some things that occur in Hard to Fight that regardless of how much they try to fight against them, they can't, which is a huge problem for them because it takes them off their game plan and forces them in directions that they werenâ€™t prepared to go, but it also allows them to experience life in ways they never thought they would with how drastically different Grace and Raideâ€™s lives were.Hard to Fight is a fantastic start to Bella Jewelâ€™s Alphaâ€™s Heart series. The cast of characters, both lead and secondary, are entertaining with their banter and chemistry and the plot line flows nicely with the various strains running together as the story gets closer to its ending.Bring on the next Alpha!A complimentary copy was provided by the author/publisher in exchange for an honest review.4.5 poison apples

I finally got a chance to put this umbrella through its paces (not that I was looking forward to it). But I have to say, this umbrella held up wonderfully. And, seriously, there was some serious rain and wind going on. I had to hold the handle and the stem just to make sure it wouldn't fly away, but there was some strong winds blowing about. This umbrella went above and beyond what I expected!This umbrella gets four stars for one reason, the handle. As soon as I held it it just felt off to me. It has a limited space in its crook for holding but the handle itself is extremely wide, making holding it feel secure but my fingers were really bunched. I found them overlapping in the handles crook when I finally felt as if I had the most secure grip. It wasn't uncomfortable but I haven't held the umbrella up for more than a minute or so. What also works in the handle's favor is that the umbrella itself feels very light.Overall, this is a more than solid umbrella. I want an umbrella that feels like a workhorse but doesn't carry the weight of one. This ShedRain does feel light in the hand overall, but the handle adds a balance to it because it does have a bit of weight to it. I wish it was more ergonomic but that is just how it feels in my hand. The handle is bright red, I actually like this, making it easy to find in your bag/purse (medium/large in size). You get your standard sheath for it as well. And the opening/closing mechanism feels really strong and durable. Used it 25x in a row just to make sure ... I really shouldn't did that before I had this umbrella in the shower, could've spared my bathroom walls/floor.

This is a gorgeous cast iron pan. The green is a muted hunter green with a lovely finish that can easily go from the stove to the table without any worry that your guests might be mortified. It is not a huge pan, I was able to fit three medium size swordfish steaks with enough wiggle room for each piece. What I do love about the pan is the weight. I've always loved that about cast iron, you're not going to get the pan shifting while flipping the food. It stays put. I also like the fact that it has two drip wells to run off the excess fat. My husband didn't want swordfish and I ended up grilling up a quick steak, just had to wipe the pan down with a tissue and grill away.I am trying to think of a complaint and can not come up with one. It comes in a lovely box that is so slick that I wouldn't even bother to wrap (has nothing to do with me being bad at that sorta thing, honestly ... nope, not bad at all). Also, inside the box is a little instruction pamphlet, giving cleaning instructions. I truly can't think of a single negative. The price might be a deterrent but cast iron can truly last a lifetime, making it more than worth the money.

Yeah, these aren't that great. First, they only offer 10 grams of protein compared to Quests' 20. And on top of that they have 11 grams of sugar. Nope. Quest's sugar content hovers in the low single digits, but it does contain sugar substitutes. Now that we have the amount of protein out of the way, how about the taste? Um, yeah. It doesn't taste good. I found the bar extremely greasy tasting. It left a nasty coating in my mouth when I was done. And for something that is supposed to give the taste of dark chocolate â€“ not getting it. Not at all. I really wanted to like this bar, I adore coconut. But this bar wasn't filling and left a horrible taste in my mouth.

I thought the top notes of ginger and pepper would give this cologne a lot more kick but I can't smell either. Instead, what I do get is a really mellow vibe that comes off as synthetic and cloying. This should smell a lot more raw and earthy. But I've never come across a Calvin Klein scent that does. If you do like something a lot more mellow and don't mind the slightly unnatural smell then this might be something you would like. I'm just not a fan of it.

These scissors are sharp. They are recommended for ages 6 + on the box but if your little kiddie is a runabout then I would wait a year or really supervise due to the fact that these have a pointed edge. Yep, and that edge is pretty sharp. I've used a pair for sewing and these scissors were able to worm their way into a leather corner and handle it pretty quickly. It made me leery about giving them to the little ones that are around the age the box recommends. In fact, I couldn't. I'm going to hold off. But, if you have a kid that's responsible, go for it. These scissors are extremely well built and have just the right weight to them so their little fingers won't cramp and get tired. I can just cringe remembering the horrible cheaply made scissors I used to use in school that caused that red ring of pain around my thumb.

Go into this knowing what you're getting, a nice looking bathroom set that is above average in quality, but not stellar. The colors on the show curtain pop, and are vibrant and printed pretty well. They aren't bleeding into each other. The hooks are decent, but so have  light cheap feel to them. Overall, the quality of the curtain is more than acceptable for a dorm room or even just a regular bathroom. The star for me is the mat. I know, weird. But it is really well made. Soft. And I've already washed it, a habit with anything new. And it didn't bleed or pill. What I really like about it is that is a hemmed edge and doesn't just use a marrow machine to do the job that can fray and cause the mat to look cheap and tacky, the little details matter. Now, is this really a 14 piece set? Technically, yes because they count the shower hooks as individual pieces. That's right. You're getting the shower hooks, mat, and curtain â€“ nothing else. And for the price, you're actually getting a pretty good bargain.

The little guy in my life wanted to use this as soon as he saw it. I have to say, it is adorable. The little wings as holders â€“ so cute. They are textured and help him with gripping. They also bend, helping with the cups overall durability. Love that he's already dropped it several times and nothing not even a crack. It's also BPA free (YES!) and has already held up to several washings in one day. I hope the little design of the penguin with balloons holds up after repeat washings as well. It caught his eye very quickly. Ugh, this cup just does everything right.

This is an excellent coffee machine, if you're willing to make the trade-offs. I love the intent behind it. Having the ability to have an excellent cup of coffee using a tried and true measure, pour over, should produce awesome results â€“ and it does. But it comes with some serious complications. I don't drink coffee often, only on weekends. But when I do, I use the pour over method. Yes, it is tedious. Yes, it is time consuming. Yes, it gives you some dang delicious coffee if done correctly. The issue I have with Kitchenaid's model is that it just hovers below what it should be able to do. Getting the water into the reserve is my main issue, such a tiny slit of space for an action that you just want to be done away with quickly. It adds too much time to an already tedious process, this machine already calls for a longer brewing time (heats the water before brewing) based on method alone. But this can be seen as a negative or a positive. You're not heating and slowly pouring the water yourself. But for the wait time, you might as well be.The design of the machine is beautiful. It looks extremely 50s to me. But it also has a few nagging issues. I hate the handle. If you have a larger size hand be leery, your knuckles might touch the carafe when gripping. Also, the carafe itself can cause unwanted spillage. I pour my cups over the sink with the carafe's opening kissing my mug. The footprint is great. It is not a counter hog. But by no means is it a small machine. It is workable in an average size space. But getting to the buttons in a cramped space might be an issue.So, why four stars? As I stated before â€“ the coffee this machine produces is EXCELLENT. Rich, layered, HOT ... I can't get enough of it. It seriously is making me reconsider making coffee part of my morning routine instead of a weekend treat. Just know, you're here for the excellent taste this machine produces â€“ not how quickly it'll make it.

Eh. I really can't taste the difference between this coconut water and something cheaper. What I'm really not a fan of is the price â€“ come on, really? Coconut water already isn't the cheapest thing out there and for its much hyped benefits, something you can get in regular water, I can't see why the price would be so high. I don't taste any extra exotic or multi-layered flavor that I may have missed with a cheaper coconut water. Also, a negative about coconut water is the sugar content. If you drink the entire container then you looking at 20 grams of sugar.

This headphones would be perfect, but â€“ the earpieces are fixed! I don't know who thought that was a good design decision to make?!  It causes one to constantly make subtle shift of the headphones on your ears to get them just right. Thankfully, these headphones are light and you won't really mind, but it can become nagging. I wish this wasn't so because these Creative Sound's are near flawless when it comes to sound quality! They could stand toe-toe with headphones that are triple the  price. The soundstage on these are so open that the music just breathes and doesn't tire you out. You get a wonderful mid-range and the clarity is nearly bell like. I can't say enough good things about the sound quality. They just don't sound great for a pair of bluetooth headphones â€“ they sound great for any pair of headphones. Also, they do more than an adequate job when blocking out noise, you don't have to worry about winding the volume up with just the slightest noise, the isolation works here. Oh, these headphones are nearly perfect ... if only they had just did something about the fixed earpieces.

Now these are awesome. They truly do go unnoticed. I have in the past, sadly, have found the need to adjust the model I've worn for years, scurrying off to the bathroom. But these stay put, feel as if they aren't even there and are just truly comfortable. They also are truly unscented. Usually, a bit of a manufactured smell lingers on a liner. I have yet to notice that smell. Highly recommended.

I love the light this bulb emits. I have I placed it in a room just off my kitchen that I use for a quiet reading space. First, the room is white, a prior LED bulb cast a nasty grayish haze that I had to live with. The bulb was expensive, just couldn't justify replacing it. But I was more than happy to give this GE one a try. It is great. There is no grayish overcast, and it casts such a lovely almost gold like haze. I don't find the light too warm at all. Usually, I can find something to complain about when reading for long periods of time where light is concerned, but not with this bulb. I found myself reading for long periods of time with barely a hint of eye strain, highly recommended.

Far Cry has always been a solid series. I worshipped 3. But Far Cry 4 just seems a little too over the top for me, just a little. But there is fun here, tons of it. Far Cry 4 is not even remotely trying to take itself seriously. The plot, if you can call it that, really doesn't matter. What does matter is that you're treated to an awesome bad guy that you don't see again for long stretches of time. But who really cares about any of that - the weapons are awesome, you get to ride an elephant and - um, you get to ride an elephant! Nothing beats slinging around a few baddies by the will of a trunk! It has to go down as one of the best gaming moments that I've had of this year, coming pretty dang close to playing GTA 5 in first person for the first time.Is Far Cry 4 perfect? Nope. It is buggy as all get out. I found some random glitches here and there. But nothing that took away from my overall enjoyment of the game, from what I've finished. I'm pretty deep into it. Another thing, is the playing time, like most games these days, with not much luck, you can beat it in under 20 hours. And that includes if you're pretty dang sloppy with your gameplay. Another thing, this game, at times, can be stunning with its visuals ... just wish the story was tighter.A solid purchase.

I love this liner. We had the old fashioned one in a kitchen cabinet ... well, up until a few weeks ago. It was pretty tattered and when I went to rip it up â€“ nightmare. The adhesive was tacky and the liner came up in really tacky shreds that took way too long to remove. I didn't even know liners like the kind DII make even existed. My alternative was to go to a fabric store and by yards of clear vinyl. Thankfully, this is way easier to use than my thought of alternative. The color is beautiful, a nice neutral beige that does have a bit of pop to it. And even though it doesn't have adhesive, it doesn't shift when placed down. I'm a fan.

I really enjoy these bars. My wife isn't a fan, feeling the sugar content is too high. But I work out pretty regularly and for a very long duration and the sugar content is a nice balance for me. I do prefer them over most energy bars, I can actually pronounce most of the ingredients. As for the taste, not bad at all. It has kind of chewy cookie consistency with a nice tartness provided by the cranberries. You know something tastes great when you feel as if it's gone too soon. Well, they are pretty small in size. But they are a great energy boost. I wouldn't go as far as to say they would make a go-to meal replacement. But for a burst of energy, nothing wrong with these, nothing at all.

I love these gloves. First, they are truly lightweight and thin. I have run in these gloves nearly every day this fall/winter and they have taken on the temperature like a champ. I wasn't too sure if they could handle it. I had a rather expensive pair last winter that just didn't cut it and I found myself running in a pair of backup fleece gloves that looked like oven mitts. They kept my hands warm but they were not ideal. These Salomon's are doing great. I've been running in about the low/mid 20s this week and they've kept my hands warm. Like any pair of gloves, stay out too long and you can feel a bit of the cold creep in. But I'm out for a run for over two hours and no problems. I've actually stopped to get coffee afterwards and folks have asked about them, and I have nothing but good things to say. I wouldn't wear these for long stretches of time. These aren't made for that purpose, long stretches of extreme weather. But these gloves, due to their sleekness, allow for mobility. They run true to size and seem to be snag resistant. If you're looking for a longer pair of gloves, you might want to look elsewhere. These stop a little bit beyond the wrist on me. But that might be OK if you're running jacket is longer in the sleeve.

I need to carry a power brick. I am at work for over 12 hours and my phone (LG G3) just doesn't make it that long. I have an older one that well, might as well be a real brick. It is really on the thick and heavy side. This model kinda floored me. I was expecting to be really lightweight and small but it was truly unexpected, the footprint is just amazing. It can fit in the smallest pouch of my briefcase where I keep my phone with no issue, prior brick couldn't do that. The LG G3 already charges pretty quickly when plugged up to an adapter and I am happy that this gives the same results. Another thing i love is that the cord isn't long and fits snug into the brick. If you want to charge this through an outlet, you'll have to supply the needed adapter yourself. It only comes with a USB to charge this brick with a computer, but still I can not recommend this enough.

This is a dang good dartboard. Right off the bat. I am really happy with the quality. My old model, one which was a gift, was OK. It was not up to snuff to the regular amount of abuse that it got and I wasn't really willing to buy a new one. Mainly, used for fun when family/friends come over, I couldn't justify the investment. But this Winmau board reminded me why i fell in love with the game in the first place. First off, I'm a light/mid thrower, I need a board that has a good stick to it and this more than fits the bill. After a hit, the board heels nicely, and you truly have to inspect it up close to find the points. I know this isn't going to last, but it is a testament to the build quality of Winmau. The cheaper the board, more visible the scars. Also, you get that nice soft thump that comes from a quality board, not that hard almost gunshot like one that comes from a cheap board. Note: you might want to invest in some quality darts to match. I will also like to point out how bright and bold the colors are. The red frickin' pops! And the black, nice and inky. I really have a love for this board.Great board, excellent quality.

Gorgeous! I don't now how else to put it. These are great every day earrings when you want to just spice up your look. They are also so well made that you can easily dress them up with a few accessories, say a nice necklace. I have to admit, wasn't expecting much. But the cubic zirconia really plays with the light and catches the eye. A nice contrast to the black stones. The snap posts also don't feel cheap. I've purchased my share of shoddy jewelry, but the clasps that grab the posts on these hold nice and firm. I can't think of a single complaint with these earrings. I was so pleased with them, I put them on immediately and trucked it out on a few errands ... I have no shame. It is truly nice to find a great value in jewelry, knowing that you didn't break the bank but still are left with a quality item.

I thought my niece would love this (1 1/2 yrs). After all, she's kind of a human garbage disposal (runs in the family). I used two packets. One packet just isn't enough, cooked it in the microwave, stirred - and was shocked that she took one bite and refused the rest! I actually thought I may have done something wrong with the preparation and prepared it again the old fashioned way; nope, didn't like it. Then I decided to give it a taste ... there's no taste. You suffer with a dry consistency and non-existent flavor until you get a tiny, dried, sad little blueberry that truly doesn't have the flavorful snap of a fresh one ... I can see why she refused it. This gets one star for its easy preparation ... but the price, you would be better off buying any brand of oatmeal.

This is a great set. The best thing about it â€“ it doesn't feel cheap! You're getting a good value for the dollar. Sure, you can buy separate pieces, but it truly is unnecessary. Together, this is a sleek and well made set. The standout for me is the carafe. It's simple, duh, as it should be, and kept a lovely bottle nicely chilled and pert. It feels good in the hand, as well, with a lovely balance around the neck. The aerator is great, too. It pushed out a nice, full flavor of the wine. Sure, it takes of bit of time for it to actually get through the aerator itself but it is worth it. The corkscrew functions as any other. My one complaint is that it is a little weak. By no means does it feel cheap, but it just doesn't feel as sturdy as higher models. But this corkscrew is not an embarrassment, doing the job adequately. The stoppers are standard, but aren't most?Again, this is a great set by Metrokane. It would make a lovely gift for others ... or for one's self.

This is a beautiful kettle (never thought I would ever utter those words). The color is a bit of a brick red but it pops a bit more. It looks very 50's. But looks mean nothing if a product doesn't work. And I am more than happy to report that this works wonderfully. I love the handle. It's easy to hold and balanced, something very necessary when pouring out something extremely hot. It is a two quart kettle, meaning you can get about eight cups from each use. I tried this, and you can. I can't think of a single issue. I do hope that it holds up against rust. Most tea kettles just don't. But this one seems pretty well made. If it does rust, I will update.

Well, these taste pretty horrible. They have a sort of granular texture and once they get going it turns into a sort of doughy consistency until you swallow. Not really a fan. I really can't see the target market for this product. It has way too much sugar (12g) for children or people dealing with say diabetes, so I'm not sure what's the point. I can't even throw into the occasional treat category because of the mouthfeel. I haven't even gotten into the flavor â€“â€“ there nearly isn't any. I sort of get a hint of blueberry but nothing else comes through, not the raisins or the white chocolate that's listed on the list of ingredients. This just doesn't offer any sort of value for me.

Yeah, I don't really see the point of this. The sugar content creeps up a bit too high and there isn't enough product in this package to warrant buying it. If you want to spice up your salad, you'd be better off buying nuts and berries separately and throwing them in. Also, I'm not really feeling the texture of these. They are a bit unforgiving to chew. I placed a bit in my salad and they have a bit of a hard consistency. I'm used to eating walnuts, raisins, etc in a salad but these are just way too noticeable - and sweet! I can't recommended these, not even for a snack. A handful of nuts are great to add to your diet, not so much these.

Amazing. I love this band. First: really well made. It doesn't feel cheap at all. And because it is so thick, I can get a really good grip on it and maneuver it in ways that I am more than comfortable with. I can go full extension on my legs (something I really don't do. I like a bend in the knee) and get a good burn. The band feels really strong and supportive. You can play with finger placement to adjust the intensity which is nice. If you want to really concentrate on key areas. Holding the bend at an angle and just working my wrist gives my forearms a really nice workout.I don't mind the lint and dirt that some have had a problem with. Honestly, I'm glad that this is cleanable. This comes really close to my face for some exercises and above my head. I think it's pretty solid that I can run this puppy underwater/soap and get it clean for use.This is a solid buy. And you can comb the net for exercises if you wish to help you develop. You don't have to spend a ton of cash for a toned body.

This is a really good kit! Seriously. I have a way more expensive set that claims its worth is in the dollar value â€“â€“ this kicks that set's butt! Can't say this often but â€“â€“ what a bargain! What I like most about this set is that it just seems way more comfortable to use. The handgrips just feel a lot more comfortable to hold, letting you concentrate more on the exercise and form instead of on how comfortable or how well you have a grip on the handles. Also, with your trust in the handle, you get over the apprehension of band-snapping (not gonna happen) and you losing an eye ... yeah, I'm a chicken.It comes with a link to get some moves off their website, but you can also do your own video searching for that and come up with some awesome results. Oh, how I wish I didn't own that other set. Bands just work for me because I can get a great extension out of them after doing some serious cardio and not have to worry about the heaviness of weights, more a mental issue. Transitioning from cardio to bands just is so much more pleasurable than tackling a weight set.

This is an excellent sewing machine for beginners. The reason I say this is because of the foot pedal. Usually, you don't get much resistance with a higher model, say a more expensive model from Bernina, but with the Brother there is more than enough tension that you feel as if you're in more control of the needle. I do love that about this machine, but if you have been sewing for many years, you might find this annoying and time consuming.The XR3774 is an extremely well crafted machine. It's pretty lightweight, under 15 pounds. And doesn't suffer from poor build quality. This machine also has beautiful stitch quality. I know, I know, I should've mentioned stitch quality sooner. The XR3774 excels in this area. It covers 37 different stitches. I have not tried them all, and honestly neither will the most advanced sewer just looking to make garments. But if you want to dip into more decorative stitching, such as for quilting, you have some great options here. I have tried the most commonly used from straight to zig-zag and they are just perfect without the need to constantly readjust tension. Nothing is more annoying than having to adjust tension when switching between fabrics on the same garment. The XR3774 handled moving from cotton to satin on a zig-zag stitch without an issue. I am especially pleased with this due to the fact that I was using a pretty worn needle (I'm not ashamed of that) and there was no snagging. The hitting that the machine provided is pretty dang good!The LED is great. I was able to sew in dim light and get a really good view of the nooks of a hidden zipper. Also, the bobbin didn't jam, happens often with cheaper models.Again, if you're buying your first sewing machine, I highly recommended this model. Heck, even if you're looking for a steady work horse, this is a solid choice. I wasn't too familiar with Brother in this category. I have been a Singer/Bernina girl for ages. But this machine has opened my eyes.

I am a huge fan of KitchenAid's cookware. I've used different versions of their non-stick pans for many years. One thing I dislike about them â€“â€“ and to no fault of KitchenAid â€“- is that they don't have a terribly long shelf life. Some of my pots and pants, especially my cast irons, have been going strong for many generations. What makes KitchenAid a dang good cookware set is that you truly do get cookware that heats EVENLY! That is the number one thing I look for. It can make and break so many dishes from frittatas (first thing I made in the pan, turned out wonderful and slipped right out onto the plate) to french toast.Another great advantage to this set is the weight. These are not light pans. You don't have to worry about them shifting about the burner, helping in your food to cook evenly or not to have yolk go to heck on you and break. Something that I'm not really fond of are the handles. They are sturdy and are set really well, but they can get rather hot. I've had other sets from KitchenAid where this isn't much of a problem. But this set causes a bit of a mental error, tricking my mind into thinking if you've used one KitchenAid handle you've used them all â€“â€“ not the case.If you're not very familiar with anodized sets, just do yourself a favor and pick up a set of silicone utensils to use with it. You don't want to cause any sort of scratches on it. If you do, with time, you'll see more than your share of rust that'll gross you out as it pushes its way through the scratches you've caused. I wouldn't recommend using wood utensils either, I've learned from experience that they can do just as much damage as metal.This is a great set of cookware. It'll do well for a single person to a medium to large family. The pans are deep enough that you can get some truly great thick sauces going without the risk of heavy splatter. And the seal on the lids are tight enough that rust, again that dreaded word, won't make a speedy appearance, if at all. You'll do right by this, if you're in the market for great cookware.

I run through storage baskets pretty quickly. Usually, I buy wood ones. And someone will open something, say a lotion, without putting the top back on and it will leak onto the wood, causing it to eventually seep through and ... we all know the rest. I was really looking forward to these baskets for one main reason -- I could wash them! But I was a bit disappointed. They aren't sturdy. They came foldable and without anything to give them a solid base. Standing them up doesn't offer enough support and they sort of droop ... well, they droop. I don't know how long these will last or be able to even resemble storage baskets after repeated washings (that has me a bit worried). I'll shop around to find something to support the bottom or maybe cheap plastic baskets that can fit inside, these would make lovely covers.

I have purchased this for my family in the past. A bottle his size lasts quite a while. I think it's awesome. It lathers really well and it leaves my skin clean without it being overly drying. Now, I am the only one in my family that loves it. My husband is not a fan. He claims that it still leaves him dirty. I've felt his skin afterwards and it just feels extremely soft. I think it is something he is not used to. He doesn't even like to apply lotion after a shower, eek. The oddly great thing about this product is that I've used it after doing some very serious work around the house. I've even used this product after doing a small painting job and it removed the paint and left me well moisturized! Sometimes, you just can't convert the masses, my husband, but Dove's Deep Moisture Body Wash is amazing!

To be perfectly honest, seeing the film first and then reading the book, it was only then I fully became aware that it was "for children" and what made it so.  Not being a review of the animated feature (but being a huge fan) I would say the book is more obviously for kids, and the lessons are a lot more unavoidable compared to the excitement the film brings to life.
A perfect fit and at a great price, no one has an excuse to be without a sack of spare vacuum backs around.
Works well for a knock-off replacement, this particular phone does not see heavy use so it will be difficult to gauge lifespan, but I have had good luck with this product line in the past.

It looks great in photos, but right out of the box â€“ no, even in the box the weight tipped me off this was not really what I expected- barely 7 ounces. For anything other than a sub-$40 unit Iâ€™d expect a little heft. Actually, right in that price range at full retailâ€“ even less here- you can find what looks to be an equal if not superior Delta model. Looking at it I could see why I found the spray pattern selector tab of the Moen is difficult to operate, itâ€™s oriented in a way that makes it pretty much require both hands, while on the Delta itâ€™s located right where you can easily support the back with your fingers and flip the lever with a thumb. The Moenâ€™s is located perpendicular to the radius and moving it only tries mo rotate the entire assembly..Maybe itâ€™s not even a reflection of itâ€™s construction or performance, but I was disappointed never the less. The description says "metal" but not "all metal construction" so I assume they are referring only to the attachment fitting, or possibly the plating, which is certainly a good thick deposit, but would only technically considered "metal". But in the end, I couldn't resist, took a needle file to the upper side and scraped my way down to what definitely seems to be plastic.When I installed it, I found the ½â€œ pipe end is neither knurled for good hand tightening and presents only a 3/16" wide flat surface for a 7/8" wrench; (good luck with that) thereby leaving you only the choice of pliers or a pipe wrench to tighten- neither a very professional method. I suspect it might also be the only part of the head made of metal.  When I replace it I will perform an autopsy and provide and updateAnd once secure to the shower arm, the head barely can hold itself up- even tightening the nut further is clearly not a solution, not only is it not possible without damaging the surface (or worse) but the design is not a typical ball-and-socket or collet, where the movement tightens up as you snug it down.This continues to be a problem when flipping through the headâ€™s 4 settings, it is clearly a two-handed operation- while not uncommon and found in many other I have used, itâ€™s not because the mechanism is tight and secure, in fact it rotates quite easily and snaps clearly into a detent- for now- but the head is just so loose it wiggles around too much. I developed a method to hold the head in my palm and flick the lever with a finger, but itâ€˜s awkward and sort of uncomfortable, especially if you have grip issues.The settings are:  a small inner circle of 4 coarse jets from the center; a wide spray using most of the outer ring, a combo that uses the first two settings, and finally a second set of nozzles that put out a wan massage. I am reasonable certain it's a turbo-thing, you can hear it whirring even in the video (as soon as Amazon decides to attach it here). Now it is true I operate at 40 PSI, I donâ€™t doubt the overall effect would be improved by another twenty pounds of pressure, but I have tested many heads that deliver a lot more punch with the same flow. Including my most recent unit, which may be returned to service if the frustrations of the Moen continue to get to me. Oh, and it's even harder to adjust and aim with soap-slippery hands.The outlets are rubber tipped for easy cleaning, but they are also flush with the face of the head, not the type that protrude, so it appears it would be only to slow erosion of the plastic nozzles and perhaps resist hard water mineral growth a bit more successfully than plated plastic. To be honest, the water here is so alkali I have seen no plumbing fixture claiming to â€œresist hard waterâ€ to be any more effective than one that does not.I'd say the chrome unit is right on the edge of being overpriced, the "nickel" and "oil-rubbed bronze" are well into it.

Photo shows top to bottom:Lexar 128MBSanDisk Cruzer 4 GbSanDisk Flair 64GbThe Flair is a very cool case design, I really love the look and the slim waistline. It is a lot smaller than I took away from the photos, but a look at the specs would have cleared that up. The latest iteration of tiny flash drives continues to amaze me that way.The transfer rates are as advertised, and even trying a USB 2 port itâ€™s still faster than anything else I have tried, thereby establishing a new â€œnormâ€, thereby obsoleting everything else. I usually use USB drives to transfer non-entertainment files, but the capacity and transfer speeds of this one has changed that, I can now easily and quickly store hours of video.Included with the drive is â€œSanDisk Secure Accessâ€ â€“ a simple encryption program to create a safe â€œvaultâ€ of selected folders. Win 7 and above only, of course, and you have to download the Mac version  (I read somewhere that in a survey at a major airport over 90% of USB drives recovered were unencrypted). Also found was â€œBack Up Your File To The Cloudâ€ which is actually a one page PDF ad for Carbonite.

Although my days of air travel are mostly behind me, I still put a lot of miles on the road in a small pickup, where cabin space is probably equal to carry-on. I have never considered top-end luggage, but now I can see why itâ€™s more like buying a home than a bag- Tumi continues to uphold itâ€™s reputation with a bag such as this.I am only familiar with the typical, simple garment bags like I have seen through the years carrying slung over a shoulder,  I never had enough need to bother with the extra burden but the Tumi was a revelation. It must be part black hole, it seems to hold everything I can throw into it. I rarely need more than 2 sets of â€œniceâ€ clothes on the road, now it is so much easier to stow them in one of the compartments and still have the rest of the bays for my usual, three pairs of work clothes.It is an amazingly well designed and constructed bag, well beyond the reach of any other garment bag I've ever seen or used. â€œBallisitic Nylonâ€ not merely because of the material, but the construction is bulletproof (no, not literally) and I found virtually no flaws in function or form. Well, the zipper that closed the shirt-tail flap was a little tricky, but you could get used to it. The entire liner appears to zip open for maintenance, but like they also say, â€œno user serviceable parts insideâ€ so the pulls are well hidden. The rest of the zippers are so well laid out that they are not really under a lot of stress when operated, even though they are high quality and well built, a design that puts less strain on the whole track usually means a much longer and trouble free life.The side-edge pull handle telescopes in 4 sections down to almost nothing, but is quite solid and when collapsed tucks into a zippered compartment. I found the different center of gravity  a little odd after years of the usual drag-along two wheeled sort, but I got used to it quickly and find a 4 wheel system is a whole lot easier to manage, especially parking it somewhere4 side pockets cover the outside flap,  they zip only along the top and side edges- this probably to prevent overstuffing. The lower pair only have a top zip. The flap itself opens and pulls outward with a divides compartment, might be good for a book or magazine, a tablet maybe.The bag secures well when closed with nylon snap buckles, and it is scarcely different in appearance from a normal suitcase. There are 2 removable zippered clear bags that nestle in the top corners of  one half for toiletries or gadgets, although itâ€™s usually tough to squeeze my old kit in anywhere, downsizing and switching over to the Tumi might make things a lot simpler. Unfortunately, while they snap out easily enough, reinstalling them is difficult, there are only 2 small snaps to secure each one on each side.  I donâ€™t know if an easier arrangement could be imagined, but since they canâ€™t really be accessed while the bag is hanging, Iâ€™d plan on a few extra minutes to pack if you remove them.Comes without any sort of proprietary hangars, (with space for at least 4 tube hangers) and a clever snap lock, plus the requisite chain and hook for your destination.Ad copy says 4 wheels are recessed, but not fully and dangle a bit whilst carrying or stowing. Still, the casters themselves are stout and durable, with double tires and a solid axle- nice to see, I have had blowouts on at least 2 of the bags I have used.While described as a â€œgarment bagâ€, itâ€™s a long way from that that appellation suggests- a big, floppy plastic thing my uncle used to use to carry his suits, difficult to manage and more at home just hanging up as a protective bag.Not so the Tumi, which is road-ready and accepts your formal or business wear as designed, stores and retrieves without a wrinkle. ). If you are thinking about upgrading to a high quality carry-on garment bag, look no further.

Perfect fit 1995 Toyota pickup. Back in service in minut4s, even came with a pair of grommets. I suggest priming the device before testing.I checked local outlets, 3 day wait in some cases and more costly. I read reviews carefully, and while this particular unit fits a wide variety of vehicles, I wanted to be sure before I ordered. If you are looking at this you know it's fall down easy to install, and I was more surprised to actually notice an improvement in pressure. But, after 20 years I should not be. 4 stars because it's hard to "love" an auto art, I am just thrilled it was so easy to find here and in my mailbox in 2 days.

Installed an Orbit timer Orbit 62040 2-Dial Digital Hose Faucet Watering Timer which has a quick acting valve and the 40 year old 20 foot 3/4" copper supply line nearly slapped the bottom of the house first time it closed. It obviously bothered the customer, and could lead to damage on older joints, so I cut in and added a reducing tee, then the arrester. Took about 10 minutes. I should have but did not wrap the device with a heat sink, just soldered it in with minimum heat. The results were immediate and exactly what was expected; no banging at all. If you have trouble with precise heat control in your pipefitting, get one of these Sioux Chief Mfg 660-2 1/2-Inch MIP Thread Mini Rester Residential Water Hammer Arrester use threaded fittings where you can and simply screw the thing in.

I chose this model as a simple solution to ease in the crossfade between a 40 year old conventional home sprinkler system and a contemporary drip. Not wanting to put all the eggs in one basket I began in phases and chose this timer as it seemed simple and reliable. It also needed to be light enough to not cause concern about excessive weight on what could be a wide variety of less than ideal hose installations, some I have seen extend a length of Â½â€ copper way too far, hanging a device at the end of it and then a hose would be unwise in these situations. But the Orbit offers a relatively compact interruption.And so far it has proven to be so. Installation is obviously about as simple as it gets, just disconnect your hose-threaded supply end and screw the Orbit in between. I was wondering about how the angle of the typical hose bib would be for presentation of the control, but it seems acceptable. I have read in other reviews (among other issues I have not encountered) that this model does not work in the horizontal position, but I would speculate most customers will use it as intended.After running the new soakers and emitters I programmed the unit and began tests. Here I discovered a minor flaw, if you care to call it that, being the most simple clock chipsets you could imagine. Very retro, both the time of day and runtime setups are forward only, hold the button for two speeds- sort of fast and then usually too slow. And then you miss the moment and have to spin again. I got the hang of it after a few tries, it just took practice. Explains the lower price than some of the more complex units I evaluated.Putting it into use could not be simpler, once the time of day (not the date) is set, just pick a start time and thatâ€™s it for the digital. From then on two rotary dials let you choose run time (5, 10, 15, 30 and 60 minutes) and frequency (Daily, 2nd Day, 3rd day, up to weekly) and thatâ€™s it. Snap on the (hopefully) waterproof clock cover and off you got.Alterations on the fly are easy enough, but try to get your start time right the first time, itâ€™s just a bother compared to more contemporary clocks- even ones with a simple â€œbackâ€ arrow)In operation it snaps on and you know itâ€™s on. At the designated off time it also snaps shut, sincerely, so much so that in 2 out of three installations I had to install a water hammer arrester, the shock to one rather shaky Â¾â€ 20 foot copper run was alarming, to say the least. But after I put this in Sioux Chief Mfg 660-S 1/2-Inch Male Sweat Mini Rester Residential Water Hammer Arrester it was barely detectable. Just a snap and the hiss off water in the pipes.Sioux Chief also make a model designed for washing machines, Sioux Chief Mfg 660-H 3/4-Inch Female Swivel Hose Thread by 3/4-Inch Male Hose Thread Mini Rester which involves no soldering, and oddly enough itâ€™s the same cost or cheaper than the solder-in type I used. You'd have to contend with some radical angle changes normally used in a washer setup, but it might be a lot easier for most users to install.So far after 3 stations running for 2 months I have encountered no problems at all. Assuming it ever rains this year in CA, I will probably shut them down and pull in for the season, I donâ€™t see any compelling reason to leave them exposed, and the waterproof cap is not altogether convincingly secure. But Iâ€™d give it a try without fear, they are well designed in most other aspects so why not.

0:12 Mins Without getting into another long-winded recollection about how far storage has come since my first computer, with perspective or not, the Samsung  is still the smallest and fastest and relatively capacious memory device I have ever used. And itâ€™s cheap. And Samsung.(OK, it's 400 times capacity of my first hard drive, and the size v. cost.. never mind)I canâ€™t have long dongles on the laptop, this one is about the size of the Logitech receivers with a protrusion thatâ€™s safe from accidental abuse and nearly undetectable, yet easier to hook with a fingernail and slide out. Itâ€™s also white, making it somewhat more easier to spot, at least on my laptop..I rarely use my old 4â€ long ones, I never went larger than an 8G, simply because for large files itâ€™s easier to plug in a Passport or other small portable HDD.But this Samsung makes it incredibly easy to have semi-permanent place to store files awaiting transfer and just about the right capacity for the information I collect on my weekly business trips. Itâ€™s so easy to just leave it in and then transfer to the base to bring the files home.About the only drawback I see is also its biggest plus: the size. If no other piece of hardware you own demands a decent, dedicated travel bag itâ€™s this one, at less than 1/4 the size of the smallest I have used and would be easy to lose in places you didnâ€™t even know you had.If no advanced use problems pop up, I see no reason not to get a few more of these, even the 64G size is a bargain (but really $2.00 more- is it that much slower?) , and properly cared for they are an ideal solution for a problem that has always been with us- a place for my stuff.â€œSamsung 5-Proof Technology makes the flash drive waterproof, shockproof, temperature-proof, magnetic-proof, and X-ray-proof, so you can bring it everywhere with the confidence your data will be safe.â€

I never get tired of Son Volt- Jay Farrar and any of his incarnations. Unique in a way of presentation and songwriting, he offers music nearly too challenging to be considered mere entertainment, but history, philosophy, or just deeply cutting observations. Even though at times his voice can strike me as monotonous, nasal and vaguely irritating, it never bothers me and what he has to say is so important and so well executed it rises beyond any issues I may have with his music. And in fact. I have none, a;though even now I am having a hard time keeping some of these tunes out of my mind as I try to write. And not just earworms, his songs intellect-rousing  works of art. For example"Sultana" reminded me of the greater picture that was and remains the greatest American maritime disaster ever, and made me want to know more. He is more than an entertainer, much more- he is a spellbinding songwriter and an educator.The first song of his I remember hearing was "Medication, happened to be while I was doing my own 28 days, and it became nearly anthemic: Put it on loop, and I have never looked back.

A generic is a generic is a ... perfectly fine replacement for the Liftmaster battery backup system I was repairing, Liftmaster 475LM Evercharge Battery Back-Up System and it's actually rated at a higher capacity than the original, which is nice. Had to fab some pigtails, but overall saving my mom about $150 makes for a fair exchange. After I installed and tested the pair all seemed well, but after one test the "charge" light on the unit started flickering.  It returned to normal after about 15 minutes and has been fine ever since, so I remain unconcerned. Can't beat the price, shipping was reasonable and fast.

Ask anyone about my fashion sense and they will tell you I was born without one. Take away the Tumi logo (and the manufacturerâ€™s $225 suggested retail price tag) and ask me to evaluate this bag- Iâ€™d say it was just another small nylon backpack, although made with a  smoother than casual black nylon, somewhat ostentatious gold zippers and D-rings, and somewhat above-average constructionIâ€™d guess it would be in the same category as a lovely SF Giants backpack I just bought at a sports shop for about $30.00. Strip the orange, put the Tumi badge on and tell me what itâ€™s worth and Iâ€™d have to pause and think for a moment about fashion.But this is not an essay on that matter, or thoughts on how Tumisâ€™s more significant items of luggage reflect a higher standard- just a comment or two on what is actually a quite lovely little bag, a purse in schoolboyâ€™s clothing. And  somehow itâ€™s feminine enough not to make it into the Murse category; I am pretty sure not too many men I know would find it so.It has a reasonably capacious main cargo compartment for the big things, and a pouch in front that should hold most of your I need it now stuff, we find an outside slip-in pocket at the top thatâ€™s perfect for a phone, right behind it on the inside you find a another one backed up to it, but itâ€™s a lot larger and could hold a small tablet or paperback. Inside the main compartment on the innermost side thereâ€™s another zippered slot thatâ€™s almost hidden (except for another Tumi tag) might be good for flat things, paperwork, cash, a travel pamphlet... or just somewhere to hide things and then forget where you put them.I rather suspect this fine item would ever be filled to capacity and ever worn as a backpack, even though itâ€™s design suggests it could, the single sling would make that unlikely, but it is light, solid and attractive enough to serve in any way the design and your preferences dictate. The nylon material used throughout seems not quite delicate, but has a fine grained appearance that suggests it would show marks and scuffing too well, not a durable ripstop doorstop, but then itâ€™s not trying to, either.A weighty, gold, Tumi (and only Tumi) nametag sheathed in leather hangs prominently from the top of the bag, just because, you know, Tumi. But, thereâ€™s also another tag for a personalized monogram enclosed attached to a zipper. Have fun!.

I have found external batteries to be a lifesaver, especially in the case of using a dead old iPhone (for entertainment purposes only) with a more or less completely dead battery- it is on life support but still useable.I rely on 2 others I have been testing, which both are rated over 4000 mAha, they are both flat and relatively bulky. Both are rectangular, which is fine for slipping into a pants pocket but ungainly if you are one-handing it.Now we come to the HP, which seems tailor made for single-handed survival options rather than emergency on the go recharging. I didnâ€™t think having a battery in a cylinder would be that big of a deal, but it is- itâ€™s hugely more comfortable to carry, a lot more manageable with one hand, and certainly not as dorky looking as carrying a large, flat heavy thing. Large, flat heavy devices are bad enough, so I would have to say any doubts Iâ€™d have had about the shape making a difference are resolved (although it more closely resembles a concrete vibrator, if you have ever had the opportunity to see one of those at work.) I am not enamored by the color, the dull silver finish is enlivened by the resolute â€œHPâ€ logo but the appearance doesnâ€™t seem to be a negotiable point with this unit. It is actually a flattened cylinder to prevent it from rolling away. Both input and output ports are at the same end, allowing it to stand on its own although this one is so light it doesn't seem all that stable, even though the included foot-long cable would allow it to be used this way.

The door-mounted broom holder is great, I have used variants but this one is a snap to mount and gives a decent grip, although it seems to not take too well to really skinny handles utensils. It''s a less expensive variant than some I have seen, but the principle is the same, a cam-lock ball traps a broom handle in a slot. Skinnier handled tools are not held quite as snugly, but so far I have not found this to be a major problem. Smaller plastic hooks sprout off the end of each cleat, which is extremely handy for hanging those last minute things that just don't seem to have a permanent place to live.- - - - - - -The bag dispenser is a great breakthrough for those who can't quite get it together enough to save all their old produce and meat bags to haul to recycling, but can't bear to part with them either. I am one of those types, and find it a major relief to now have a spot those pesky bags can call their own. This is a clever solution, shove the bags into the slot at the top and somehow, you'll always be able to peel on out of the "mouth" at the bottom and find it in great shape and ready to go. It comes in two pieces, the backing plate (I mounted mine inside a cabinet door) and the ovoid dispenser which is supposed to snap over the base when it's in place.Unfortunately, the base plate as I received it was rather warped and wavy, and since it's a fairly stout plastic there was no way to get it attached to the surface and have it lie flat enough to then let the dispenser snap into place. Simplest answer was to rip a small piece of 1/4" plywood to jut over the outside dimensions, and then using an air stapler attach the base around the outside edge with a few in the middle for added security. I then screwed the wood to the door, slipped the plastic dispenser over and locked it in place, and filled it with bags. It has been happily dispensing them ever since.Both very handy products to utilize underutilized areas of your kitchen and pantry.These products were provided in exchange for the words of comment you have just read.

It would not expect you to believe me if I said there is absolutely nothing I donâ€™t like about this unit, so weâ€™ll get that out of the way first: the color. The canister head is a distinctive orange-bronze while the motor section is a fairly sincere deep shade of brown, We donâ€™t buy vacuums for their color combos.. or do we? Better than Day-Glo green certainly, but even matching the top to the motor could have been a better choice. Everything else- yes. From the quality of materials to the clean design to the ease of use- a winner. It was easy to assemble, I had it together in seconds without any assistance from the instructions- and only a glance at the box for the only even slightly tricky part- the accessory tool holder- It attaches to the handle, and could possibly be installed inverted, but youâ€™d notice it works a lot better positioned so the tools point upward. And I have never seen a simpler or more effective onboard storage scheme.(I would suggest a reading of the manual in any case, there is a surprise or two, as well as, for me at least, a lesson in the correct terminology of bagless vacuums.)All of the other snap together pieces are so simple, they may be assembled clearly either one way only, any way, or just as happy in a 180Â° out orientation. All fit together without the slightest hint of anything but a good, tight and trouble free connection, the one that will stand years of abuse, imagine what life youâ€™d get with good care.On the job- oh, that-  it's not as kick-ass as some of the way more beefy units I have tried, obviously without a dedicated power rug extractor it can't deep clean carpets as well as some. I found for most purposes it was more than enough, and certainly so on hard surfaces- especially hard to get at hard surfaces the power is more than adequate. I rarely encountered anything the Bissell could not handle. It is not loud or intimidating enough to scare a sleeping cat, but the power is there (If you doubt it, judge the sound of the motor with the canister removed) and given its dexterity and solid construction I do not think I would see it as a huge compromise.Accessories there are few, it is unpretentious that way, rather than a panoply of stuff to lose if comes with the basics: a small brush, a crevasse tool, a â€œuniversalâ€ floor head and a hard-floor only head. The former is smooth surfaced for gliding over carpets, and has no beaters. I can live without that, the air driven type are almost always useless, and running power through the hose it always a weak point.The hardwood head does have vacuum (â€œturbineâ€)-powered brush, and on a smooth floor it works quite well. A release plate that you can operate with a thumbnail allows for quick field removal of the roller should you ingest and jam a large objectA small bypass valve in the top of the canister will pop open if the main filter clogs, it makes a fairly unique sound and I would suggest that if you hear it stopping immediately before something makes it into the motor inlet filter.Thereâ€™s only has one way to store the wand, and thatâ€™s only with one of the floor attachment on, it clips onto a small hook at the lowest part of the canister handle. Itâ€™s not the most secure arrangement, and  would not suggest trying to maneuver the unit around this way, but itâ€™s a convenient place to park the hose while working.The hose and attach points are strong and solid, apparently built knowing they will spend most of their time taking most of the punishment as you drag it around the house. And without a complaint. The large rear wheels means itâ€™ll pretty much roll over anything, including its power cordI would say it doesnâ€™t seem too happy to be upended and isnâ€™t too stable that way, but once the chamber begins to load the extra weight lowers the CG a little and it seems more balanced.The body of the machine is as simple and refined as you can get: All solid and built for rugged use:  a housing for the motor and fan, wheels, the cord and 2 switches- power and the cord retract mechanism. A large light illuminates when suction drops below the pre-set level, and should probably be regarded with respect..The business end is simply a 5 foot hose, no stretch but very well built and swivels well. Unlike an upright, you control the whole proposition wit authority choosing either hose or sweeper, changing on the fly is literally a snap. The connectors, as I have said, are easy to use and stout as well. Plug one end into the motor, attach the 45Â° hand piece/extension /hose holder and youâ€™re almost ready to go. An extension wand, nicely finished in brushed stainless, extends and retracts smoothly by releasing a barrel in the middle, the length goes from 22â€ to 34â€. The wand extension release barrel may also be slid slightly upwards to break the vacuum briefly in case you suck up a string rug or small animal, a feature common on most older vacuums but one I havenâ€™t noticed in awhileChoose a floor head or the brush or crevasse tool and thatâ€™s it. I would like to have seen either of the two smaller tools plug directly into the end of the hose to more easily get into tight places, but I donâ€™t think finding a small barrel to make an adapter would be a big chore.The clear plastic vacuum chamber â€“ AKA â€œdirt cupâ€ cradles perfectly in the motor housing, and is literally a snap to remove and service- a thumb catch at the top of the canister and you can pull the assembly free, which another thumb catch opens the hinged bottom side and releases the debris into your place of choice (The instructions also make the comment that â€œallergy sufferersâ€ may wish to do this with the canister inside of a plastic bag- how thoughtful)Further cleaning  necessitates a twist of the handle which separates the clear plastic dirt cup housing  for a more thorough washdown. And this too can be further broken down with another twist which frees the â€œcyclone shroudâ€ from the main cyclone assembly. Pay attention, it will only go on one way, and the alignment arrows are small and a bit difficult to spot. (Practice while itâ€™s clean. I put a small alignment dot on both parts to speed reassembly until it becomes second nature.Filters are essential to the long life of a vacuum, and the Bissel is proof- in addition to the cyclone chamber, its carry handle is also the release catch to pop up the lid and give access to the â€œdirt cup filterâ€- I would say it is in fact the canister exhaust filter, a five inch ring of padded gauzy material which is the last stop before the actual motor pre-filter, that being a 1.5â€ X 3â€ ovoid piece of coarse ScotchBrite-like  material, clearly the last stop before the fan. Both may (and should) be regularly removed and cleaned by blowing off and washing.Further, in a masterful stroke of design, the motor exhaust filter (â€œpost-motor filterâ€) lives inside of the left wheel and is a 5â€ x 1â€ pleated paper affair in a green plastic housing which releases with an 1/6th turn. This is also key to not only motor happiness, but air quality- and nothing is skimpy about this unit. RTFM-  I might never have known of its existence of not for a study of the book. (câ€™mon, itâ€™s only 5 succinct pages long.)Details like this elevate a machine beyond my taste regarding whatever color someone thought was attractive into the range of high quality industrial design.If you really feel the need, the fifteen-tube pickup assembly can also be separated from the heat with 4 snap tabs, but barring a major failure, I canâ€™t imagine why anyone would want to do this, and do not recommend it unless necessary, the tabs are not intended for a lot of use. I find that when a machine can be broken down this far you have the capability to really keep it clean, and that is the key to a long and healthy vacuum cleaner life.TL/DR, I know, but I like this machine. I have always been impressed by Bissell, after a little Butler model hung in (and still hangs in) 15 years after being purchased solely as a woodstove vacuum, I remain impressed by the quality I found in this model. A lot, and thought you might enjoy hearing why.

This is a great book if you are more into keeping notes about your days than just planning them. An 8.5X11â€ format gives you three days per page, and more than enough room for filling in the details. Itâ€™s not broken out by hour, so more than a scheduler, it seems better suited as a journal, I have used many such as this in the past. A 2 page monthly calendar divides the 4 weeks, with plenty of room for more truly â€œat-a-glanceâ€ planning.But essentially it's just a demarcated spiral notebook, while this design allows for easier writing, but it does not seem to have as much strength as others in the more upscale At-A-Glance product line, the front and rear boards are not that much heavier than said spiral notebook, in fact merely from shipping one corner has already endured some bending. Itâ€™s not tabbed as some I have seen, so you â€˜re on your own for navigating. I have doubts about durability through heavy use, but if you care for it, it will serve you well.

If you are looking for an easy to use w-fi repeater, this is about as simple as it gets- plug it in, turn it on, clone via WPS buttons and youâ€™ve got another 75-100â€™ of range. The Aukey does not stop there, however, and also can be configured as a WAP and may be configured in a variety of was. All are simple, work as advertised. I found the somewhat small instruction manual to be easy to follow and all I needed to get going.I have been trying various extenders/repeaters for a while, and many of them, like this one, were provided by the manufacturer in exchange for evaluation and review. But unlike several of the others I have tried, this is one I would recommend to any user.While it is capable of all the usual tasks required of a device like this, I found the simple chore of extending your range should be just that-= a simple chore.Itâ€™s a nice clean design, wall hugging and not too wide. The US power adapter is a snug fir too, suggesting others are available from Aukey as well. Controls and ports on the bottom edge could not be simpler or easier to hit. A surprise and somewhat unusual feature but one I appreciate a lot is the simple addition of a power switch, I am sure itâ€™s not that uncommon but being able to power off a wireless device without physically removing it or risking losing settings is a good thing.For my test I first cloned the MAC via WPS and then relocated to the furthest point from my router, which would be in the shop about 80 feet and several walls away. Using an old iPhone 5 (possessed of not the most powerful WiFi I have seen) using Radio Paradise I was able to get a decent signal as I walked nearly 100 feet in a direction that is not covered.. The Aukey held on even further, but once the signal dropped I could not reconnect, walking back uprange I found it again around 75 feet. This is true line of sight, as it says in the finely printed but easy to understand manual, â€œis mainly used for providing free wi-fi service in a big area such as a factory, community, street, and etc.â€. The book also wisely avoids speculating on range, as they say, YMMVThe device can also be accessed and set up via a browser or cable, and may be configured as a repeater or WAP. I have a perfect use for one of these at my moms, where I can use an existing 6 port switch and the Aukey to add wi-fi in a location far from the router, while I am sure the glut of these devices will grow, the ones that have such simplicity of use will always find my favor.

0:41 MinsKitchen thermometers have never been a part of my basic cooking tools, I have always gotten by. But a device like this gives a lot more control over a kitchen situation, and I found it to be in a price range that would make it hard to resist, just through testing it out (for which it was provided to me in exchange for this review) I learned a great deal more about how it can let me be as busy as I want in the kitchen and still not forget about something in the oven. The temperature memory allows you to pre-set your desired temp, when reached the alarm sounds. You can scroll through them with the up/hr down/min buttons - there are 6 built-in default temps, each illustrated with a little icon of the animal you are preparing, in case you lost your FDA chart. Some overlap, but, whatever.Choices are - 185Â°  (chicken) 170Â° (pork and well-done beef) 160Â° (a ham, I am guessing, and beef medium) 145Â° (rare or fish). The mfr has included their own chart which gives different names to the icons, but the whole scheme is  probably OK for most uses, and certainly better than the kind I have been using- an analog dial probe.Should you desire to enter a custom temp, just select one of the presets and  dial it in with the up/down button. The range starts at 32Â° with the upper end at 482Â°, which is also listed as the max end for probe safety reasons.So if you are into candy making or (like me) dialing in a deep-fryer temp, you won't be left out. The alarm only works in the uphill direction, so if you want to use it for ice cream or testing HVAC stuff, sorry. This is undoubtedly why it is sold as a "Food Thermometer".During the test with my fryer, I just guessed the upper end and discovered one thing that might not be annoying to many- when the temp hits the setpoint and the alarm sounds, there is no way to quickly silence the alarm- you must either turn the unit off with the power switch on the back, pull the probe and wait, or in my case, dial the temp setting up further until it's off. I find this a bit inconvenient, but I would have to say my needs and testing methods usually exceed those of your average user. Not a deal-breaker, but it's a nice point to know. It also tracked the unit's temperature with enough accuracy to judge the cooking temp of the oil to monitor it or re-calibrate the controls. (The cycling shown in the video as the alarm sounds is unedtited.)Testing accuracy,  both 32Â° and 212Â° registered and held within a 2 degree range, which is better than one of my more elaborately calibrated but much older general purpose digital thermometers. I noticed ambient temps were often off by about 4-6 degrees, but since it was designed for accuracy at the higher end, I don't see this as an issue uncommon in lower end thermocouples.Not only is it a useful cooking thermometer, it also functions as a countdown timer which may be used in conjunction with the temp settings. It's pretty basic, but also not the main event here. It can be set to up to 24 hours, but only up- no backing out. Same with minutes, of course up to 60.Powered by a single AAA cell which is always a convenience, although mine was DOA.It's a nice little unit, not exactly overbuilt but looks like it will sustain some moderately  rough kitchen duty. A pair of magnets on the back is only too logical when placing the thermometer, but they are really weak and will barely let the unit hang onto a smooth steel oven door, although it seemed a lot better on a textured surface like my refrigerator. And making more challenging, the cable adds a little more weight and helps it destabilize. Easy enough to fix, but still..It also has a small fold-out plastic stand, but I found the nature of the probe cable makes it take a little bit of a balancing act to get set up just right. A piece of non-skid material along the bottom edge might help it stay in position better.The meter-long braided SS probe has a mini-plug connection and while a little stiff at first, still holding shape from being folded in the box, appears to be shaping up to be more flexible. But unless the probe is buried inches deep in a thick roast, a little care should be given to have it all balanced and safely positioned. The probe itself is bent at about a 20Â° angle, which I first thought was shipping damage, but a check of the item photo shows me all is well. This angle probably improves the placement of the tip, but I discovered it also tends to bake more firmly in place. Which in itself is not a bad thing, but it makes removal a two-hand task.A backlight would have been useful, but I found the lack of a way to quickly silence the alarm while on the fly quite annoying.It's not that hard for an experienced cook to get things done just by smell or feel, or in some cases just instinct, but when trying something new, or for the inexperienced, or for those wanting to adhere to strict safety rules, at this price point you can't beat the ThermPro.

Love the concept.. say, when I get fully suited up in brush clearing mode, there is not a pocket left or space for another string or cable around my neck, I tend to pile the safety gear on to the max. The Bluetooth Sun Hat Music is perfect, it tucks under my safety visor and even backwards the earbuds reach perfectly.The earbuds, are on the low end of the quality spectrum, as is the microphone.  I would never think of violating my states no headphones while driving rule, but if someone wanted to there is scarcely an easier and more covert accessory available, except for what I learned after a few long tests. . But, did I say easy to use? Pairing and phone receive/pause/play functions are all what I would call standard, or even better- simpler. The buttons are really easy to hit (and best, remember)- well, all the buttons are - handles answer, hang up and redial quite easily. Here again, the hardware shows it's weakness, the mic is barely acceptable, in fact I was able to leave unintelligible messages, get hung up upon, and not even be able to navigate a simple voice menu while driving. The convenience of using it while in a car (NOT driving, of course!) is indisputable, and a lot more convenient and comfortable than wearing one of my BT earpieces.It just doesn't really work very well. Range is tragic and seems to be about 15 feet, line of sight. Fine if you can carry it in your pocket, but thi sis not always the case.The hat is decently made, despite quite a few cut and raw edges. The concealment flaps and straps do a nice job and the "guts" can be removed for washing. I mean, so you can was the cap.Battery is permanently stored on the board, charged via the included cable (how many micro USB cables do you suppose are out there these days?) and the instructions are in lovable Engrish:"Knitted material of hat, it is warrn keeping and fashion, You can answer the phone Bluetooth function of it in cold winter.""Low Power Warningz:"The device alarming as "Dong Dong" while is working seems the power not enough, need be charged."This product was provided free in exchange for this review.

0:50 Mins I love this thing. But as a flashlight enthusiast since 1967, it's hard not to be overawed by the selection and range of lights that are now available. It's a good thing I don't have a real job, or I'd spend all my disposable income on gadgets like the Sunree CC Rechargeable Camping Lantern.In fact it just came into service at a time when setting up an alternative would have been too time consuming. I was working in the alcove behind my refrigerator, all I had to do was drive in an oversized sheet metal screw and the magnet in the base took care of it- more than enough light for the job. It's not the largest or most powerful magnetic base I have ever seen, but if the surface you want to attach it to is flat enough it's perfectly adequate for the weight.The primary means of support is a pop-up plastic carabiner hinged to the base, you can clip it to just about anything with a loop in the end, or use the additional two provided carabiners to find even more attach points, it makes it easy to find a home wherever you areCompact and solid, it has a nice heft to it and appears quite well built, the charging ports are covered by a hinged plastic pop-out tab that looks a lot more long-lived than the usual rubber band.The light is powered by a hefty battery that can of course be used to charge just about any device you might have along on you camping trip, although a mini and a full sized USB poet out seem to be the norm these days for anything with adequate battery capacity, which is nice.The power switch is located on the backside, it would be considered the base if you used it on a table, but as this is clearly intended to be suspended, call it the top. Press it once and a row of blue LED's light up to show charge level, twice brings medium brightness, then again high, again for low. Seems an odd way to do it, but you get used to it. The penultimate button-push before "off" sets the light a-blinkng, which is primarily irritating, but could have some emergency location use for which I have not yet had a need. Unfortunate; it's an unhelpful and annoying feature for normal use.Charge time is quick, battery life on any setting is above average. I live in an area know for spotty electrical service, not only have I been a flashlight collector for years, now I have justification.I have not tested it for waterproof-ness, truth is I'd rather not find out the hard way that it was actually "water-resistant" than "water-proof". But it is well enough sealed that I believe it could take an accidental dunking and fare rather well.It's a great little package, we get the light itself, a very lightweight USB to mini charging cord, 2 extra carabiners and a little "Ding-Dong" Hostess Ding Dongs, 2 Cakes (Pack of 6) -like case to carry it all. Except- and to voice my only complaint, it doesn't. It's a tight fit with just the lamp, and just too small to get everything in. When I tried, the zipper got halfway round and broke. So, don't over pack and you'll be OK, but that reduces the handiness.This Sunree would be right at home anywhere, in addition to being at the ready in emergencies, I am already finding lots of uses in ordinary life, practically everything except camping, although when the power goes, it's not much different.(note: This product was provided by the manufacturer for review purposes.)

While they are packaged and sold as "shipping labels", these are actually the dream come true for lovers of all things Avery. Just an adhesive backed 8.5X11" blank sheet that can be used for just about anything. In fact, the size is a lot larger than I would consider necessary for most of the things I have found myself shipping, but finally you can  make a label with no limit to the layout.I also gave DVD disk labels a try, it worked quite well- rather than dealing with a half-dozen templates for as many different brands of DVD specific labels available (Stomper, Memorex, Avery, generic, etc.) and never printing with anything approaching consistent accuracy of alignment, I found it to be a lot faster (and only requiring a reasonable amount of advanced motor skills)to simply print as many as will fit on a page and trim by hand. And, you can get at least 3 on a sheet instead of the usual wasteful die-cut 2.They cut easily and do not leave much of a residue on scissors, but I would suggest a razor knife or guillotine cutter- if you are reading this you probably have both. It was fairly simple to cut down to the backing, peel off the label as needed, and even re-use the sheet with just the remainder. My latest printer, the redoubtable Canon Maxify iB4020 Canon MAXIFY iB4020 Wireless Office Inkjet Printer with Mobile and Tablet Printing and Airprint and Google Print Compatible ,Black didn't have a problem with these no matter how many bald spots were left when I sent them through. Assuming they were relatively flat, of course.Avery watermarks on the full backside of the peel-off section is a really simple and highly visible solution to avoiding mis-loading these labels in your printer.The uses for a full sheet label are so many and so tempting it would be easy to blow through a box of 250 without restraint, irrespective of the intended use. Packing boxes, file cabinets, protest signs- have a ball.

2:30 Mins Not to say it's to be considered avoidable, but for reasons described here and hopefully shown in the video, the Bora saw plate did not really live up to my expectations. After using my shop-built 8' shooting board for years and with no complaints, (other than the inherent unwieldiness of such a thing) I'd often wondered if one of the Kreg devices might be easier to manage. So, some me time ago I acquired a Kreg Rip Cut Kreg KMA2675 Kreg Rip-Cut and found yes indeed it was, but with the limitation of the saw being guided strictly by the edge of the workpiece rather than a true straightedge device.I then happened upon a Bora Edge Clamp 50" Clamp Edge Saw Guide Bora 543050 WTX Clamp Edge.
