Locking Handle Heavy Gauge Saw Guide for Straight, Precise Cuts, and while it was relatively easy to use, it made sense only for quick and not necessarily dead on cuts, just a way to keep the saw relatively guided when accuracy wasn't too important. Calculating the offset as well as the tedious manner of accurately and squarely clamping the bar still remained a deterrent, as well as the unsuitability of the length for anything longer than ripping a sheet of 4 X 8 in half. Without the optional extension, obviously.So I thought the  Bora 542006 would be a good companion to the Edge Clamp despite its 50" length (and my unwillingness to upgrade to an extension)I eventually got through the absurd clamshell package and evaluated the parts. In some cases, there is no need to even look at the instructions let alone be bothered by them enough to complain; you simply slide the hex head bolt into the only place it will go- a hex-shaped relief on the underside, and then stuff the spring and saw plate clip on the other side held in place by the wing nut. (One thing about negligent instructions, they may leave you wondering about how to assemble something, but if you do anyway and get it to work, you'll never have to wonder if you followed them well.)But beyond that it did not look too encouraging, the bracket is light gauge and it didn't strike me as either being in the right spot to grab the footplate of the saw or really provide a tight grip. It didn't.The front end of the saw plate tucks into the two front clamp things after you have slid them into alignment, basically any place they can get a bite. Run down the setscrews and hope for the best- my saw- an old but stalwart Makita worm drive- has a rolled front edge and the slotted setscrews could not find a perpendicular bite, instead tightening down at an angle. At maximum depth the slot disappeared into the threaded brass insert and would have kept going, due to the nature of trying to tighten a point vertically into a curve. I was then able to more or less find the best spot for that rear bracket, but even after I found about the only spot where I got a relatively solid 3-point mount, it was disappointingly wobbly. It's held in place more by suggestion than a positive mechanical connection.It must be incredibly challenging to design a device like this that attempts to be compatible with so many saws that have only rudimentary similarities but so many specific differences. I tried the Bora plate not only on the Makita, but an older Skilsaw circular and even older Black and Decker, the results were consistent. Whatever the primary target saw they had in mind was will remain a mystery. I am sure if you own that saw most of my complaints will seem petty; although with such lightweight materials and only a 3-point mount I would tend to doubt it.And that 3-point mount lets the outside corner of the plate droop when not in contact with the work surface, I realize the assembly is meant to be used with the weight of the saw making everything lie flat, any thoughts of being able to keep the plate attacked to the saw when using it for other purposes vanished. Not only do you lose nearly an inch (7/8") of cutting depth due to the thickness of the plate, it's just not secure enough.The pointer- is it an afterthought? Since the rail must follow one pencil mark and the blade/pointer another, do you draw two or try to position the guide based on the correct cut line? Is this about speed, or accuracy? Initial tests show me that it's neither. The offset of the blade from the bar ended up as a fraction, while I tried to get it to offset to a round, easy to remember number like 4", it would have been impossible given the limited mounting point choices.One could probably try to make a sacrificial cut through the plate to achieve this, but given the already dubious nature of its structural integrity, I feel getting it perfect without destroying it would be more trouble than it was worth, as I am not yet convinced this is the solution for me.I persevered: after it was good to go I took a practice slide down my melamine faced worktable and it was accompanied by an alarming screech. I would add unexpected, but I did see mention of it elsewhere. Still, while fingernails on a blackboard might be one way to describe it, it wasn't that bad, but it seemed louder and more unavoidable. I thought at first it was the slick surface of the melamine set vibrating the 15 edges of ribbing in a nice harmonic wail,  but I suspect you'd find this on any sheet goods, except probably something with a texture like OSB.If I were ever to depend on this thing more often than I expect, I would definitely stick a piece of adhesive backed felt on the bottom side and hope to not use it on very rough surfaces. I am trying to avoid a direct comparison to the Kreg, but they manage to avoid this situation by using a flat plate that is of different construction, and engineered to slide with the wood, not bully its way across it.I admit my test cut was on a board that would not be typical, I thought a try at squaring up an ratty old slab of quarter ply would be a good test. Plus it was a scrap anyway, and as it turned out (and as you may see in the video) the cut was not exactly the sharp square edge expected by a guide tool as flimsy and inexpensive as the Bora plate.To be fair, I will drag it out next time I need to rip a sheet for a few more passes, but for most situations the Kreg will do, and as I have found for years, if that falls short I can fall back to the good-ol' reliable shooting board.

I have eaten Nature Valley frequently in the past, I would say these bars a an improvement over the ones I preferred in those days, but not by much. Rather than dry and brittle, the Simple Roasted are quite gummy and adhere nicely to the package, but won't fly all over your car when you take a bite. They taste great, maybe a little too salty, but: peanuts, ya know? The nutritional info puts the sodium (115gm), sugar ((6gm)and protein count (6gm) in the "average" category, while the price seems to be slightly "above", especially with only 4 - 1.17 oz bars per package. They taste great, nutty, salty and just enough sweet, but are still somewhat of a compromise between flavor, texture and nutritional content.

As you can see by that photo., the definition of a â€œbackpackâ€ has changed somewhat over the yearsBut the product behind the name Kelty has not, as proven in this fine, as we used to say, â€œday packâ€ (or even â€œrucksackâ€). This unit is a lot lighter than expected, the nylon involved in its construction seems to have been rendered even thinner than the lightest ripstop I recall. It compresses and can hold itself into near flatness, a nice feature when storing or traveling with unfilled, maybe in a real travel back as indeed a day pack.Iâ€™m not sure who the target buyer may be, perhaps student, but the clever little â€œaction pocketâ€ designed for POV selfies with a cellphone camera would indicate adventure of some sort, although school is still always an adventure for most. Maybe itâ€™s for a bully-cam.) Either way, not having a smartphone  Iâ€™ll never know, but even if I did, I see the little wallet has no rear access so operating it remains a mystery.It seems designed to be mounted on the two chest straps to shoot while you hike, I imagine you turn it on before snapping it on. If that doesnâ€™t do it for you, it can also be folds into a tent-shape construct secured with built in Velcro as a sort of back-country tripod.Overall the pack is more than adequate for any demand you might place on it- or in it. Light weave pads rest against your back, the front straps both have pockets at the lower edge which can be convenient for holding small objects to forget about. I find the twin chest straps odd, they are small (to fit the Action Pocket) and both have tiny clips, not the fastest to fasten or detach.The back flap has an exterior back flap which can be unfurled and held fast with 4 runners than unfurl from the main bag, ideal for jamming oversized goods within, a sleeping bag or something.Under that one is the top flap opening, revealing 3 mesh pockets, two of which have Velcro closures. Below them another flap exists to fold and keep the whole pack flat for light use or storage, pull it open- and itâ€™s not that easy to access- but you now have opened the pack to its full capacity.Itâ€™s well made and has enough room for anything I can imagine, depending on your mission. Simple and durable, I can think of many.

2:10 Mins And I do mean with enthusiasm. OK, so they are actually a Bengal/Ocicat mix known as Cheetohs, even as such still have fairly particular dietary needs and tastes. "Nature's Variety" has been on the approved list for them since they were kittehs, and they love most of the varieties. And better yet, so does their fussy digestion. Even though they love almost anything in that "special" pouch, you can see for yourself they are now fans for life. There are enough healthy ingredients here that I should consider adding it to my diet, but I still have a small scar from the last time I tried that.Pricey- around $3.50/oz but packed with good stuff and already such a hit with the crew, it will be hard to dole this out in the relatively small portions dictated by the budget. And at the mfr. suggested 24 1/8-cup serving per meal for the mid-sized cat, it adds up fast.Leon was a little reluctant to embrace the treats, but he came around in a very short while. (At about $3.50 an ounce, maybe he thought he'd end up footing the bill) But if your tigers do not immediately try to help you open the package with great enthusiasm, I am sure they will soon as well.

With off-market brands going for the cost of these two OEM's, what's not to like? For a 20 YO refrigerator I was pretty sure it crossed over correctly, despite a few physical differences it mounted no differently than any of the others I have used. It did seem to take a lot longer to purge than I recall, and the water tap ran on and then dripped before eventually shutting off normally, but this icebox has not seen a lot of service over the years. Works fine now, no trace of filter residue, and the flow increased (yes, I measured it before and after) by about 30%.

1:21 Mins It's nice to find a starter package like this, but it limits a few things- like, how much you will spend to be sure you get the right air tool for your particular use, that you will in fact choose the correct pair (or trio) and writing a review in fact requires three times the information in a space where buyers usually have patience for the minimal amount of information merely for one. These are each decent tools that deserve more space to explore, but for a buyer, taking time to absorb meaningful details on all three from a single article is unlikely.So the grouping is somewhat arbitrary: We can start with the compressor, the heart (obviously) of a pneumatic arsenal. The BPFPO2012 is a low-end diaphragm pancake unit, perfectly adequate for casual use. No frills, nice quality. Even though it is a small thing, having a cord winding cleat and snap-lock plug clip is a nice touch.When I was making a video to compare the sound levels and pump up time to my funky old 8 gallon piston unit, it seemed like the Bostich was taking an unusually long time to fill. And was lots louder as well. When the piston unit shut off, I could hear the Bostich was leaking air, (as you may see in the video, straight out of the box.) When I saw the crimped on hose from compressor to tank, I feared the worst. Turns out it was just the tank drain valve left open by the factory, a quick twist and that was that.The compressor has a simple but decent regulator, again, with such low-end capacity you don't really need much more. Two outlet chucks facing left and right off the front panel are provided. From flat, the diaphragm pump complains its way to full in just under three minutes. Perfectly reasonable for a low CFM unit, but the sound kept reminding me of a 12-volt emergency tire inflator.There's really not much to know about an air compressor, even if you are new to them- where the drain is, how to use it, the power switch sort of stuff, but I always like to browse the book just to learn new things. In this case, the manual is a road map sized fold out sheet thing that suggests just how how much they want you to keep and use it for reference. I tried to find a printable booklet online, but it seems Bostich offers no manuals (and scarce product information)of any kind. I do not obsess on it, after a lifetime of avoiding them I eventually realized knowing some operational parameters can be helpful. Like, why there is a drain in the first place (but you already know that.)As far as the set as a whole, the notion of grouping tools like this is also reflected in the packaging and instructions- I have one older Bostich air stapler (and two other brands) that came in lovely cases having room to store an Allen wrench for service, the manual and a decent selection of fasteners- and in one case even a small oil supply. This pair came in cardboard sleeves.The instructions on the other stapler I have were concise and informative; the one provided here groups six staplers into one 13 page booklet. The model of each stapler is only to be found on a small sticker attached to the magazine, along with the size and range of fastener required. Both of these numbers are quite important, I would suggest a buyer take note, for at very least, you must keep in mind your model number when searching for info in the manual.The compressor is noisier and slower than my old one, but a lot easier to carry around. While my little one was actually capable of running my plasma cutter for brief intervals, I will not be looking at the Bostich for anything more than stapling. A few quick blasts of air to blow dust, filling a low tire, or even just changing tools will cause enough pressure drop to make the pimp run a lot more often than I would like. If you plan to do so, consider an additional tank, Torin T88011 Air Tank - 11 Gallon Capacity while shortening the life of the compressor ultimately, at least you will be able to maybe run an air ratchet or grinder for more than 3 seconds before it kicks on.It comes with a lightweight low-end hose that kinks easily, the couplers are permanently crimped on; if you're serious about getting into the air tool word, put it away and save it for an emergency.Speaking of the couplers, the tools also come with the male end installed- if you use the Milton standard (there are many) these are "A" type. Naturally, all my stuff is "T", so that definitely is another strike against the hose since the ends are crimped on. I have not purchased anything major in a long time, but any commercial and professional tools I have seen or bought come without. I suppose that's too inconvenient for DIY'ers, but if you're already set up on one standard (there are way too many) then it's a pain, or you have and have to use adapters already, which is also a pain.The bigger stapler here, the SB-1664FN is a bulky yet more business like finish nailer. I don't really care for the way ammo is loaded in the magazine, you pull back the follower and insert a clip of nails down into the magazine, then release the spring. I have used a few other guns that have other ways of loading, this is not my favorite- removing nails to change sizes is a lot more difficult, and God help you if you ever load the incorrect gauge. While the front end has a tool-free release to swing up the hood, it's nearly impossible to clear a jam if it's the wrong size.As far as the SB-1850BN, it fares slightly worse but for a different reason- the side cover slides back to load and access the nails, but in the event of a jam, the front plate must be removed with the (not included) Allen wrench. And if you need to do this, take careful note of the parts, part of the safety trip device is a small rod with a bushing that lays on an intermediate plate that will likely roll off and disappear when you disassemble. While I deliberately mis-loaded to see how it was to handle jams, as with many nail guns it is also really easy to do not on purpose, especially once your fasteners begin to migrate from their original packaging and you can't be sure of differences in length and but especially gauge.The trigger pads on both are fairly large and hard to place on edge with a great deal of accuracy, but it's not too difficult to overcome. The trip bars themselves can be held manually with moderate effort, as these are both sequential trip devices. Again I am puzzled by the manual, each method of firing is described for each gun, but not specifically assigned by model. I guess if you have to ask you wouldn't understand. Both have adjustable depth settings, something previously accomplished by varying the air pressure.As far as the function- oh, that- no complaints. But, nothing particularly unique or worthy of note, they are after all, essentially just air powered hammers that cut assembly time of repetitive and routine chores down by huge measures. They are also considered by many to be a replacement for real fasteners and a bit more skill in entirely inappropriate situations, but that's just my opinion. I have a decent assortment these now join, including a higher end Bostich, and apart from being able to dedicate one to a specific sized fastener, I really can't say I prefer the Bostich over, say, that "purple" brand.If you or someone you know wants a jump start into air fastening, you could do worse, but I would prefer to build an arsenal of tools individually based on specific needs and individual quality.

I have tried nearly all the brands offered here and many that are not; after 20 years of cutting firebreaks over an acre of extremely challenging terrain with almost every other brand, the Husky blows them all clean away. Literally. The landscape is littered with different colored lengths of just about every other brand out there, and they all have one thing in common: they aren't short. I have yet to remove a Husky string from the head that had more than about 2" left, and even then usually only because of a change in foliage or terrain.Rocks, asphalt and cement bring a typical amount of more rapid wear to the line, but this is no surprise. It is well balanced, over balanced even by the extended cutting time the Husky line gives me. I used to re-line about 3 times (or more) per tankful, now it's almost one-for-one; if I am cutting in nothing but high dead weeds I will almost certainly wear out before this line does,I am using the .105 line on a Husky 225 and while have used most sizes down to .065, I feel that the biggest line the machine can swing comfortably is the one I should be using, and while not hitting peak R's until a little wear has happened, it is still quite effective. And, it was the only size that was in stock locally, I was in the middle of cutting and could not wait for Amazon. Next purchase- whatever year that will be- I will likely try both sizes from Amazon, now that I am convinced this is the best line I have used to date. I have a feeling with this brand I could drop to the .095 and realize little difference for the same price. I have always encountered too much line spitting with smaller sizes, after about 14 hours of cutting with the .105 this has not happened, not once.I usually cut lengths to 9.5", and it did seem a bit more than the trimmer liked, I can't believe the line is that much more dense than the others as to make a difference, but it does. But as long as the demands on that first inch are not too severe, it really allows me to stay at it longer, I just have to be more careful about planning my attack to be able to take advantage of the apparently different properties.A lot of the cutting is around rocks of all sizes, and re-lining was usually frequent, annoying and expensive. I also edge a 1/4 mile asphalt driveway, which is mainly clearing the surface of detritus and encroaching dirt- this will usually wear any other line to nubs in just a few minutes. Not the Husky- I gave up before it did, and moved on to other types of cutting so I could test it more thoroughly.I gave up on bump heads a long time ago, and a fixed-head can be irritating, but then so can rewinding. especially so often as the rough terrain can necessitate. But even that chore seems simpler with this line, it does not back out from the clutches appreciably and the ends just slide out as well and in reloading. I can even do it begloved, which also cuts the time way down.If I do find the smaller size adequate and Amazon does not offer the .102, I would have no problem committing to the longer roll. I can't say it makes cutting fun, but nearly- it goes so much faster, cuts even in a straight line or scything in either direction, it also really "cuts down" on the effort. I can also put in overly-long pieces, and use them as an "air broom"; the breeze is wide and effective enough to blow clean the porch or walk.

Prior to seeing this device, I really had no idea the stem thing atop strawberry was referred to as a "hull". Hull sounds like that of a pea pod, or a walnut, or a boat, obviously. Of course, "hull" is the vulgate for "calyx", but this was even more obscure news for me. Is the top part of a tomato called that too?Speaking of tomatoes, I was glad to see another reviewer had success with that fruit. (Vegetable, whatever) I did not, but this leads indirectly to a point about the Oxo: it doesn't work all that well on smaller items.But on the larger ones, I was quite impressed. Not ever being  previously inclined to hull a berry, I usually just dug the stem out with a spoon, fingers, anything handy.No more. The Oxo has shown me enlightenment. Used properly it makes a lovely space in the top of a berry, quite perfect for filling with ice cream, whipped cream, sugar, your favorite thing to put on- and now in strawberries.At first I found the stainless blades to be rather flimsy, and seemed a bit wide spread to be able to dig into a berry top without destroying it. As I mentioned, this is true with smaller berries. The larger the better, just align it, stab and twist- out it comes. A push of the green button releases the stem- hull, sorry- and once you catch the rhythm you can decimate a basket in minutes.It seems to remove a rather large cone-shaped piece, but that's what leaves that space. And my wife enjoys nibbling on the divot. (But she likes apple cores too, so there's that)Another gadget I never know I needed, but as I do not often buy strawberries, it will be living in the gadget drawer along with the likes of its cousin, a cherry pitter.  Westmark Cherry PitterWhich also works quite well, but as it works so nicely on olives it will probably continue to see more use than the Oxo, but barely.I am sure there are more "pro" hullers out there, but if you, like me, have an overflowing gadget drawer, you will certainly able to make room for this affordable, useful though diminutive tool.

I was really curious about a whitening product that promised results in two days. Probably like a lot of people who try this system, I was facing it with a combination of hope and a complete lack of faith.After two weeks, I can't say I see significantly noticeable effects- though it seems I still feel something is happening and in my case it might be wishful thinking at best, at worst it will just take a while longer.I have my favorite toothbrush and paste, and the Colgate is not an acceptable substitute. The paste is extremely potent in a powerful minty way, the gel in the tube is somewhat slimy, but I primarily object to the brush. It seems cheap, with the bulk and fancy, pointless over stylization of most modern plastic goods, but designed primarily to allow the tube to be stored in the handle but lacking in every other aspect. It seems flimsy, it is a "soft" so I have already noticed bristles blowing out, and it isn't exactly overpopulated to begin with.The core of the brush is not bristles, but soft stalks of some foamy material that is supposed to spread the toothpaste more effectively. But strangest of all is an extruded pattern on the back of the head that seems to mainly irritate your mouth and palate as you work around your brushing, I can't see what role this plays in the process.So for now, all I can do is offer my results to date.  Time will tell. Just don't expect a miracle.

So I had to reverse the title, sorry, Glenn.*(So maybe I should have gone with "Amazing bass, how sweet the sound..?")But I'm not kidding. Physically bonding the bottom end- literally and figuratively, if temporarily- of a speaker to a resonant surface produces astounding results. This may be the one we have been waiting for, or at least the first of what may soon become commonplace. Or for that matter probably already exists, but the Jam is the first to cross my path. Higher end component speakers try to minimize physical contact with surfaces that would produce sympathetic frequencies, the Jam exploits them in a surprisingly effective way.In the "Storm" mode, the base conducts bass like a heat sink, transferring low frequencies to whatever it's sitting on. I have long wondered why no one has yet done this, and even for the relatively low  price of this little unit, it delivers a huge punch for the size.Since I happen to be working at my desk while writing this, I tested where it sat. I built a desk out of ¾" oak plywood, and it is large. The speaker was just sitting here, and as soon as it paired, Radio Paradise fired up, pencils and paperclips began wildly dancing around. The cat fled. It was loud, but I had to see, yes it went louder until the helpful voice told me, "Maximum Volume". The voice itself is annoying as usual, and can also annoy you in 4 languages. All too loud, and all too mechanical sounding. Includes a small "key" mounted to a custom plaque (in case you can't find one of those paper clips) which is inserted into a hole next to the power in port and pressed to change the language.A fifth choice sets the usual tones, in this case sounding like a snippet of a commercial.A sixth choice should have been "silence".Unusual speaker, very unusual packaging; enclosed in a semi-oval plastic shell (with a tin bottom, no less) we have the 3.5" drumlike speaker sitting- no, attached to with a lens cap-like thing actually threaded onto a Â¼" protrusion on the bottom which is about 1-1/4" in diameter. It sticks through one end of a little plastic shelf, the accessory box sits beside it. The charger is a hockey puck shaped flip down prong type, slightly larger (and maybe harder to find wall space for) than a typical adapter.  It charges at 9.5 volts, and the cable has unique ends, so I suggest keeping both safe. It has become so convenient to use the ubiquitous 5.5 volt to USB adapter, but the higher voltage requirement could also suggest higher output. The cable is flat and tangle-free, as it is called, so they both might stand out a bit better.A smaller than usual "quick start" type guide seems to be the only literature, and not only is the print about the smallest I have seen that was intended to be useful. It also has that cheery, hip, flip attitude that I find so embarrassing in tech writing. It doesn't work for me.Absent also is an audio cable-I see the Jam has no aux input, a sign of the times, but still, so far, always a minus in my book. But, hey, they after all call themselves "Jam Wireless Audio", let's call it a draw.It paired immediately with my phone, (I had less luck with the true test of my funky old iPod and Sennheiser dongle) and will re-pair automatically after wandering out of range, but still requires a re-start of the source- not unusual.The speakerphone is OK, perhaps average for a device that must include a feature most people will likely choose to ignore. I tried my usual tests, voice recognition, answering machine quality.. true, I have no friends I might actually suffer to endure a live test. After using it with my old flip phone, I had to "forget" the device and re-pair to other devices, but this has happened before and is probably no big deal.The can-shaped speaker, with its little round base looks like a lot like an early satellite, wrapped in flat black wire mesh, nicely blended logo and Bluetooth symbol illuminating with a soft gray glowThe controls are atop the unit, and are a darker gray, rubberized material, a concentric ring has volume, pause, forward and back- I am not sure what the middle button does, but it has the Storm logo, like the control functions, embossed in that rubbery top. it sits in another pool of that gray glow and looks cool.  Pressing it controls the "storm" feature, obviously, which is the spectacular bottom end.Unfortunately, once again I have to wait to memorize the functions or use glasses before I will grow comfortable operating the speaker in low light. Plus, the - well, bottom end is kind of wiggly, which is just what it does whenever you press it or even just bump it thus making a different, more sensitive touch required to operate.Range is pretty good, about 50 feet straight line, maybe half that through a wall or two. Can't comment on battery life, it came ready to play, I rarely run one down for a review test, but 12 hours now seems to be the standard as advertised.*"It Must Be Jelly ('Cause Jam Don't Shake Like That) The music was written by Chummy MacGregor and George Williams and the lyrics by Sunny Skylar. George Williams also arranged the song. A version was also recorded by the Army Air Force band under Glenn Miller.

0:06 MinsOr as you might infer, "Camping Shampoo"Long time ago there was a much discussed and advertised product very similar to Herbal Essences Dry Shampoo called  "P-S-S-S-S-S-S-T". (I think I spelled it right.) And I believe it was made by Clairol at the time. Oh, here we go- Wikedpedia: "Psssssst Instant Spray Shampoo Not to be confused with Pssst*."  I used it from time to time, and to the young uneducated oily-haired person not always shower-ready, it worked great. It is still available and has no doubt changed hands a few times.Seems like Clairol Dry Shampoo is an update, with the same methodology and results. I have since become more educated in hair product, at some point marrying an Aveda salon operator and beautician who generally prefers to see the house filled only with Aveda products.But I wanted to try the Clairol, and it does exactly as expected. Takes my rather thin and oily (and greatly thinned) hair on a no-wash day and gives it fluff and bounce, I can see this being in the desk drawer of busy office types, a backpack, or even a bathroom for the great unwashed.Containing as the main ingredients isobutane, alcohol, propane and tapioca starch, it's pretty clear how it works. In addition to putting your head in an extreme fire risk situation for a little while, the propellants must act as a solvent while the starch helps absorb the oil and as it dries, lend a somewhat unnatural fluff to your coif. Overly scented, looks not so bad, feels a lot better. If you are blessed with naturally stringy hair, you will probably be able to appreciate the results.I must confess I do not care for the scent, it reminds me of cheap deodorant. But the product works and could be quite handy. I can see just dusting your head with cornstarch for a similar result, but this is quite a bit more convenient. While the results are fine, I found it difficult to remove and it took two washes with fairly strong strippers to remove all traces. (That would be hair product strippers, unfortunately).Keep a bottle in your desk drawer, your backpack, your locker, wherever- it will come in handy when you really need it.* "Psssssst Instant Spray Shampoo is a no-water substitute for traditional shampoo, popular in the 1970s; its popularity was widespread enough that it is considered a pop culture icon. The Nanny season 1 episode "Maggie the Model" featured a character who modeled for Psssssst during the 60s. It was produced by Woodridge Labs. Its history may date to the 1950s. The company recently began making Psssssst again. The back label of a recently purchased can reads: "Between Shampoos- On Camping Trips- After Sports When Ill Any time you can't use water. Psssssst is the convenient, quick fresher-upper for your hair."

At first glance I was a little bit disappointed at opening the Allen light, but after a closer look that soon faded. Most of my reaction was due to the seemingly, shall we say, "lightweight" construction of the mounting hardware, especially when compared to the lights themselves Until attached, of course, when it proves less can be more and it proves quite sturdy.It's mostly all lightweight plastic, rubber, and stainless, durable enough but clearly no more than need be, I realize there's not much point in putting too much weight into a part of a product that for the most part could be considered disposable. The clamps are quick to install and easy to adjust to any desired position, requiring only a slotted screwdriver and enough attention span so that you do not lose the tiny black plastic worm gear on the rear clamp.Both lamps attach to their clamps with a push-tab quick release and can be swiveled through 360Â°, the front through ratcheting detents, the tail just by friction.But the lights themselves are superb, very nicely made and finished. I try to avoid riding at night, but in some trials of this system, I was favorably impressed. The headlight throws a very powerful yet diffuse cone, it can be adjusted somewhat in size by sliding the barrel fore and aft. Shoved all the way forward it what might be called the "spot" setting, it projects an image of the PC board LED up close, sort of an interesting optic trick.I found the lens holder and the body were so well fit it slides with precision and smoothness, so tight it feels like it's pulling a vacuum. It is quality machining, but makes it a little bit hard to adjust while riding, should one need to. I suspect it will loosen up in time, but not so much as to become too slippery.Each click of the headlight on/off pushbutton at the back end of the case cycles through 4 modes: low, high, and flashing. You can also press partway to switch between modes. The taillight consists of a ring of red button LED's set in a reflector and is controlled similarly.I live well up a rather twisty country road, and it is not really true to say "I wouldn't be caught dead riding here at night", since that is actually the most likely scenario. In fact riding anywhere that is not amply lit for vehicular traffic has never, especially in recent years, seemed to me a very good idea. I feel both lights offer a significant presence to traffic of any sort, but it did not seen to really have a lot of power to punch far ahead, if you come to look for that in your cycling.I have also found the headlight to be quite handy in a number of other applications, living in that area that is on the twisty dark road, well, power events are common, so a useable but compact battery floodlight I always nice to have around, the Allen has a beam that serves equally well in many places.The center of the barrel has a rubberized surface which has nothing to do with use while riding but rather provide a solid hand grip. The plastic quick-release pad has recessed screws, and makes a great resting surface for the light- something rarely found in most flashlights, they just roll around in that loopy circle when you set them down. Another well-though out feature (or a happy accident)It also fits the hand perfectly and carries the shape, end edges and weight of many other small devices that have been shown to be quite effective in self-defense.I have seen many headlights- not even kits- in the $300 and above range, and of course many far cheaper than the Allen- but few in this zone of affordability that appear to be as well designed and manufactured.

It would have never crossed my mind to invest in a sound bar, I have always found the TV speakers were fine for 80% of my viewing, and the Denon surround system was more than adequate for the rest.  So a low end compromise like this was interesting to explore.And to realize, in the end, it could serve a far better purpose than trying to enhance a system not really in that much need.One thing that was not refurbished was the box; the original Vizio plain brown box and egg crate inside supports clearly had a few miles on them, but then the shipping box did as well, if selling "refurbished" items is going to catch on I would think a little better presentation is in order. The owner's manual looked like a 3rd generation scan of an enlarged copy of a quick-start guide.My first impression was that the sound was improved, but not by a very large factor. The ability to easily add a sub-woofer improves it's role as a go-between audio solution, but this too has drawbacks. As I played with balance and bias I began to appreciate some improvement. 2 inputs makes it extremely simple to attach an external device without getting involved in the surround system or an aux in to the TV.The Vizio is definitely low end, but I have few complaints. The controls atop the unit are small and almost impossible to see, due both to the way they blend into the case so well, but most likely any installation you may end up choosing. Hence the remote, which is also somewhat hard to see, it's thin, glossy black and not terribly well marked. It's assumed once you get it dialed in, you would use the TV control for audio, despite the fact using the Vizio remote could lend more flexibility to the use of the speaker.It's almost overcomplicated for what it is, and while I love using it, I wouldn't miss it if it went away. The price point is hard to beat, even  though I do not buy refurbished products and am not likely to start. It would be nice to see a tag indicating just exactly what was repaired, a warning for future problems perhaps. I would have to say it's a compromise- relatively improved sound volume and quality at the cost of the mess of another plastic box jammed in the space, six more cables, another wall wart, and another remote control.Actually, I think a more practical use at this point would be as a bedroom speaker, I would think a sound bar tucked behind the footboard, maybe even a small sub-dub down there would work out quite well. As long as you can hide the cables.In fact, as a real footnote, I accepted that in the entertainment console, the bar and cabling and added clutter of dubious merit, not to mention the virtually unusable remote were just not going to work out in the long term.This realization led me to mount the bar atop the folded jumpseats in the rear of my truck cab, which has only a stock 1995 Toyota stereo.I have been trying portables for years and only found one acceptable solution, the Fugoo Tough Bluetooth Wireless Speaker (Black/Silver) but it just couldn't cut it when combining a low input signal and the windows open at road speed. The Vizio, in what I would expect to be a not uncommon repurposing, has already passed the tethered trials with earsplitting success.I picked up the least expensive inverter I could find locally, wired it all together and propped up on the jumpseats for a test. It passed, exceeding my expectations, so I bent up a pair of acrylic brackets and had it semi permanently mounted in minutes. On the road it's ideal, I can finally hear just about anything I choose to play with decent clarity and response. Definitely better than the stock radio, and to keep volume control management simple I wired the radio output to the 2nd input on the Vizio. To cut down on cabling, I tried a Bluetooth setup BlueAnt RB-BKBL-US Ribbon Stereo Bluetooth Streamer- Bluetooth Headset - Retail Packaging - Black/Blue but found it caused a significant drop in output and volume. Contrariwise, when cabled the quality at highest volume definitely begins to break up, but I'll settle. A sub-dub tucked away somewhere would help enormously, just not likely to happen soon.I remain quite pleased with this inexpensive alternative to a whole new stereo setup- or even a new vehicle.

It is a simple enough scheme, have an all-in-one disk that can either be worn as a pendant, carried on a fob or in a pocket, or snapped into a wristband and worn like a watch. Included band is sturdy, durable, inflexible and ugly black rubber. Did I mention uncomfortable?The most significant function of this device was that I was at last able to place it in front of my mother and let her have a hands on examination. But it was immediately evident that this device is not a practical choice for a person of her situation. It brought the matter into focus for her and once again opened the discussion of the need for a device like this, but once again after evaluating nearly all the options, even an apparently simple solution such as this takes a little too much management to be even close to practical.For one living alone with part-time caregivers, but still at large risk from falls, even a minor accident could become a life threatening event. In a situation like that I would prefer to stick with the simplicity of a call-center monitored device, and one that has some type of voice capability. The V-ALRT has the ability to respond to a bad situation, but only via the app and the phone, 2 more things to manage, two more weak links- and with it learning, programming and to a certain extent maintenance, which runs counter intuitive for the truly needy.  Unverified receipt of the SOS call or text is the scariest. And if you are on the receiving end? â€œHey, I got this call from Mom but no one was thereâ€¦â€. Not to mention unknown issues that can truly be discovered only with a real-life test or two, something no one wants to experience, let alone simulate.I do not think this is the best choice for the usually thought of demographic, but perhaps to reach a new one- this being someone like myself who frequently work alone, in high places and remote areas and doesnâ€™t always remember to carry the phone on the job.

An LED alternative that is essentially everything it claims to be. Or that I could wish it to be; even the price is not unreasonable.It hit 110Â° today about 4 PM. My 3"X3" office closet is never a pleasant place to be, but when the house cooks for a few days in three-digit temperatures it is a walk-in oven. And that's without the light on.Which was until recently a 75 watt eyeball-style can fixture. I installed a dimmer just to keep the heat down. I had never considered CFL mostly due to light color temp and non-dimmability, even the "dimmables".So the GE LED flood was a welcome surprise and an immeasurable improvement.I have been wanting to try a replacement for PAR flood and spotlights for a long time, but they have long been out of the price range. The GE has dropped somewhat since their introduction, and the quality in almost all regards has contrariwise risen. For a great number of reasons, although not checked out any competing models, I was immediately impressed by this "bulb" and immediately recognized a few significant reasons to consider an upgrade.One thing puzzles me, with so many screw-in replacement LED floods available, are there that many cans that a simple solution will not fit? LED floods tend to run a lot smaller than incandescents, so I imagine this is one way of addressing the situation. I appreciate the design of this unit, but unless there was a glaring need to retrim a can I would probably go with the simple bulb change first.Changeout was a snap, the "bulb"- it is actually a self-contained fixture- comes with a light socket pigtail that mates to a molded body 2 pin connector. For a standard PAR-30 screw-in it would be as simple as removing the old lamp, pulling off the trim, screwing in the pigtail then pushing the device up into the can. The color and temp of the light is perfectly acceptable and nearly identical to the one that originally occupied this fixture. I compared it to the few remaining original fixed fixtures- milk glass lenses- and the difference was subtle. The LED is not as diffuse as the lens, but then it is also not a piercingly hot flood, either.The instant-on of the LED is still noticeable to one who has a lifetime of only the millisecond warm-up of a filament, but that's just me. I notice it in new autos as well, and it reminded me of incandescent that run on 220V.I know what happens when you run a 110 bulb at 220v, but whatever an LED might do will remain a mystery for now.The box lists a number of dimmers that are compatible with the fixture, which of course I did not read. I use the same switch throughout the house, and as with the bulbs themselves, a major retrofit is not likely. They performed acceptably, a bit notchy perhaps- probably just due to a combination of the age of the switch and the way that the LED reacts to a simple rheostat-type controller. But it works well enough, and while in this application will likely not be dimmed often, it was still a good test.I was concerned that the spring clips on the GE might grab something that they might not want to release at some point in the future, but this was not the case. They slid in perfectly and held tightly, but pulled right back out with ease.All of my fixtures here are 8" diameter, but the GE is 7.5"- not really a problem, but if I were planning a large scale upgrade I would certainly want to check the old cans first- I am sure an adapter ring could fill the void, but it would also cut down on the ease of installation quite a bit.Drawing 10 watts instead of even a dimmed 75 is an obviously huge savings. Whether or not it will ever reach a payoff point of course depends on use, and would certainly be aided by replacing all the fixtures in the house.Of which there are many. The designer went nuts over recessed lighting, I count 22 in the house. All sucking energy like it was 1969.In any case, for now, I do not have to think about that again, at least not in my closet. When the price falls and more varieties are available, I would not think twice about retrofitting all of them. Especially the ones in the 14' ceiling. (Say goodbye to The Giraffe!)WAGIC 21316 Giraffe Light Bulb Changing System

All of the fluorescent fixtures in my house use 2 or 4 tubes, 4 and 8 feet all are (except the ones since failed) at least 15 years old. I assumed (as hidden in the literature somewhere) older ballasts would not work with an LED tube, but I was fairly confident I would not mix an LED with a gas tube on the same strip. Both proved true, so I could either buy another LED tube just to test, or pick up a one-lamp fixture, which I did.It was interesting to note that single tube fixtures are much less common- and significantly more expensive than even multi-tube ones with more features.I attached a temporary cord and switch so I could carry to from room to room and simulate an installation, see how the color temp and brightness fit into each location. While obviously not providing as much light as would a full 2 or 4 tubes, it rendered a fair representation. I do not know how many LED color choices are listed at this time, but it seems it should be a simpler issue to provide a good solution for any room.I liked the idea that although more flexible, the tubes are so much safer; and noted that when these catch on a whole subsection of manufacturing will take a hit- whomever it is that makes the plastic safety shields for hazardous location glass tubes will need to be repurposing.There is no start up or flickering, typically a feature of older and moribund tubes, (and one that will be immediately un-missed) and I suspect the LEDâ€™s will be operating pretty much the same in ten years as they did for this test. One small surprise- when powering down, the tube actually briefly fades out, not unlike an incandescent.It should have been no surprise to note that the LEDs fire in one direction only, what is now the backside of the tube was covered with labels. Unshielded, non-reflector fixtures seem to no longer be used in many places, so the loss of essentially half the light from an old gas tube will not likely be missed, and certainly helps the power savings.While by no means definitive, and conditional as much on the ballast as the tube, a quick check with the Kill-A-Watt shows the Philips, listed as a 14 watt replacement for a 32 in fact drew 19.The â€œcontrolâ€ bulb was a 40W Sylvania that in fact drew 27.Upgrading even a small fluorescent installation will not be an inexpensive proposition, the price of tubes does not seem to have taken as dramatic a tumble as other types of bulbs. Since the cost of operating fluorescents has never bee as outrageous as incandescent, (donâ€™t forget- they have always been touted as an institutional and inexpensive alternative to filaments- hello, CFL?) the biggest attraction may be the service life- although come to think of it, some of my tubes are still at it after ten years.And not usually mentioned is what I feel to be the biggest advantage to using alternatives is disposal. (Funny how for so many years the tubes would just sort of vanish. Or stood in as the earliest light sabers in mercury-dust choked duels. Who knew?) And now some services charge what can only be considered outrageous disposal fees.But between the â€œindefiniteâ€ life of the LEDâ€™s and the as-yet unknown (but presumably simpler) disposal methods, this is a consideration worthy of note.(Years ago, I was having a meeting with my employer-at-the-time, we were discussing spares storage. I was standing close to some new cases of 8 foot fluorescent tubes, stored on end. Too close. One box fell over in slow motion, as it hit the floor the sound was impressive. When the dust settled, all he said was â€œThink any made it?â€ )But still: I bet the private use market is a challenge for the manufacturers right now, selling what may be a once in a lifetime swap for most people, and while it may not have a blindingly fast payback, at least a reduced need to change tubes in difficult locations will be quite alluring.

It is said "to a hammer, the whole world's a nail." To a cat, the whole world's a toy.I thought the gang would flip over this, but not so. The noise didn't bother them, and while the flying projectiles momentarily required their attention and warranted a chase and a sniff, that was about it.So I was left to experiment on my own.An 8 chambered dart-holding "barrel" resembles a minigun, but that's where any similarity to anything real ends.It has two little fold-up wings that are intended to provide some measure of protection for a shooter, rather than shields they more closely resemble a Star Wars craft. Once I folded back the flaps and played with it a minute or three, I pulled them off, set them aside, and lost them immediately. I do not consider this a great defensive setback.The Blaster is an overt expression of why we love guns, all festooned with clever molded red, blue and gray plastic shapes that give it a space (or Nerf, or S.Soaker) sort of appearance. And have nothing to do with the action.Which is somewhat odd and a bit tricky to master. After stuffing your darts into the 8 chambers, the grip (and half the aim) is maintained by the rear handle. Pulling back the front one charges the firing mechanism- spring loading? then releasing the dart at the full pull, presumably whilst you are attempting to lock in aim. On the front stroke the barrel rotates to the next dart.Although it comes with a target, this gun is not for target practice. Accuracy can be learned, but it takes a lot of effort and does not seem to be the main point, which is most likely to have a bunch of your friends over and just unloading on each other.The included target is only about eight inches square, the whole backside is coated with an adhesive of unknown permanence. I would be careful where you place it, it might be there awhile. I used 3M mounting tape at the corners for now, which might affect it's dart-holding power.Which is another thing: probably the most amazing feature of the toy is the darts- the business end. They are tipped with a soft rubberize substance that adheres to the target surprisingly well, and comes off with a bit of reluctance. The rubber stretches and distends as you pull it off, I am mystified what might be that compound. The tip returns back to the original shape no matter how stretched out it became. I have experimented a bit and have still not come up with anything to which they will likewise adhere.Well made for a toy gun, I am not a parent (that should be apparent) so I can't say if the price is reasonable or not, but seems so. There are accessories galore, (and eye protection does not seem to be a bad idea.)The method of propulsion is unclear, but it takes a lot of pull to crank one off. the construction of the darts is a 2.5" hollow light plastic stem, which would suggest compressed air, but this does not seem to be the case. Only a field strip would answer the riddle, and I am still having too much fun with it for now.The darts are also extremely easy to lose, I would pick up a spare set or two if you are serious. I noticed the open ends are fairly delicate, after a few shots (or maybe a "Cat Scan") the edge became slightly damaged and caused a hangfire situation.They do not fly exactly 75 feet as claimed, the best I could measure (indoors) was about 50. But that's plenty, and requires a bit of windage to achieve even that.If you plan to rapid fire, do not plan to be accurate to less than about 5 square feet- the effort to cock and release the projectile is significant, and while seeing the barrel spin as it's blowing through a whole clip looks pretty cool, it really waves the thing around a lot. It's also impossible to shoot with one hand, which may or may nor be a bad thing.

The prevailing impression I have of this  camera is that it is identity challenged. On one hand, it is absolutely full of high-end features when combined with the overall quality of both construction and performance make for a solid high-end workhorse. But there are other aspects that donâ€™t fit- essentially the aspect of marketing itself to the pop crowds, the casual user for whom selfies are a main function.Then there are the colorsâ€¦.  Fun and unique but in my narrow mind not much more than silly. Let the personalization come from the images, not the device that makes them. .It would for all intents seem to be yet another purse/pocketable aim-n-shoot, but it is far to good just for that, (not to mention pricey) and the detaching- and somewhat protruding included lens makes that even more unlikely. The included lens is a good choice for starting out, but I have noticed other variants of this package come with an additional lens â€“ usually a telephoto - that adds a bit more flexibility to your photos.For a semi-pro camera trying to bridge the gap to the casual user, this is not a bad unit. The picture image quality is outstanding (said one coming from using a 6 MP Sony) the balance and ease of use is somewhat above average, but it struck me as a compromise- not enough to really be considered truly high-end, and still laden with features those using a purse or a pocket for a camera bag might not ever have a use for.First experience with a Samsung camera, and while I would not necessarily choose this for myself, it does have the requisite number of features jam-packed into it. I have spent much time trying to remember the hundreds of the features and functions of several DSCâ€™s, and usually end up falling back to just the few needed to produce the shots I am after.  I shot film SLR for a very long time, and found the simple functions found therein never left me wishing I had anything more.The Samsung as offered does not zoom, so in a way I canâ€™t consider it a drawback, but if anything demonstrates a leaning to the professional. â€œseriousâ€ user. (Just like the colored bodies. And the flip-around screen for selfies.)Most recently, my needs run to a convenient, bullretproof all-in-one package, so I find the Samsung to be somewhat unsuitable. I think at this price you had better be sure of what you are buying, many other more complete â€œconsumerâ€ models nay be had for less.The lenses are of course available, along with an adapter ring. I have not seen this accessory needed as a separate purchase in other cameras, and when I have needed to use them I have usually bought two- there is no bag included, I have not carried my bulky Domke case for years, and I would prefer to not have to stuff the uncovered lens- no lens cap, either- into a pocket.  Lenses run from a budget $26.95 to well over $1000.00

Did I actually buy this? Amazon's list of items for review goes embarrassingly far back. Though I have not seen this since- well, since well before my last VHS player died, my recollections are hazy. I was working at a brewery at the time an thought it might be amusing to see another take on the booze factory besides "Strange Brew" and the beginning of "Lavern and Shirley". I like Robert Hays and Barbara Hershey, and still think any movie based on a country novelty song should be viewed with caution.

Great solution in making an amplified TV audio system for my mom. We can crank the amp I rigged, then she can dial in the best sound level to her headphones or speaker. Probably not the most common use of this device, but she loves it.

Setting up a remote listening station for my mom, this was an obvious choice. Such are usually made by price or name brand, I felt one justified the other in this case. While not overbuilt, it so far has proven durable enough.

Otherwise I might not have recognized the name. Remember the episode where Cartman gets a new Trapper Keeper that blows Kyle's out of the water and . . .No, nevermind, it wasn't the same one anyway.As I am presently "between jobs" and have a folio case I drag around to exams and interviews and I hate it. The zipper broke and it's as worn out form the process as I am. I thought it might be interesting to actually try one out.a TK, even if it would not have been my first choice, it seems one can always find a better deal on office supplies in the student section. I find the divided folio paper sections a time travel device to when I was in school, and its taking some time to put to perfect use in the retasking, but I have already found it's handy to simply keep notes for each prospective employer with a lot less hassle than the single-page notepad my old case had. I tend to scribble a lot, so it's working out well.While not geared for the (ahem) business user, it has little space to cram in handouts publications or resumes, but there are two slots on one page and one in the front, they work just fine.  I am sure that in the years of development this thing has had it has it has been developed and refined to the needs of the customers, whatever size and it seems to reflect that.My old one had a business card holder, a credit card holder and a sticky note dispenser that are not present in the Keeper, but I also have not missed them so far.I imagine compared to your average Target fall special it could be considered pricey, but there is of course that allure of a name this well known.It's certainly not whatever executives or wanna-be's may be carrying around today, some might chide me on my choice or recognize it as practical (or immature) but in any case I find it is a great all-around organizer that is solid, durable and not burdened by features that look handy but are never used.But, while I have since abandoned this particular application of the TC, I have no doubt it will carry on as the binder of choice being carried into the classroom.Oh, OK: "Cartman gets a new Trapper Keeper Futura 2000 that blows Kyle's Trapper Keeper out of the water. When he finally stops bragging, a stranger informs him that it will eventually fuse with other computers into a powerful super being, take over the world and destroy humankind if they don't destroy it first. Cartman refuses to accept that he must live without his Trapper Keeper and becomes infused with the high tech folder. Kyle must do anything he can to separate the two and destroy the super being."

There, I got that out of the way.Even though I have not previously heard of Kenco- not being a very active participant in this type of optics- they were unknown but soon proved to be very high quality of construction and optical clarity. They are considered â€œwater-resistantâ€, not waterproof, so I imagine that would suggest they are suitable for use in rainy or duck-blind like situations, they might not cut it on a dunk surf or poolside. No big deal, I rarely travel to any of those.But for me, while not really powerful enough for long-range spotting of my canyon environment (and with only one intrusive neighboring house about a mile away) I found they were great for peeping closer at the abundant wildlife- notably, and obviously birds at close range. Crystal clear and lightweight, they are a lot less bulky and steady than my big Costco Bushnells and allow for extended viewing without causing tired muscles or cramping hands, something about which I had never thought.Focusing is fast and simple, using a rocker between the barrels. Before use the eyepieces must be twisted in position, I am not clear why, but compactness might be a reason. It took me a few seconds to figure this out, my stupid, but the instructions seemed to be of little use, I mean, how simple could it be? The only complaint I could muster was the eyepiece lens cap is a whole cover, and did not fit well at all, no matter what position the binoculars were folded. This does not seem to be a one-off situation but a design flaw, hopefully Kenco will read some of these reviews and attend to the problem. The front fit fine, but they snap inside the rim of the lens and are sort of cheesy compared to the rest of the binocs, of the lens. As with most lens covers I have encountered, could easily disappear in a matter of minutes.To one ignorant of the lineup of manufacturers, the pair seem pricey, I have not yet shopped very much for comparison but I have reason to suspect this could also be a sign of that higher quality I am incapable of appreciating. They work well.Included is a soft pouch case, like the lens caps a bit low-end for the price and compared to the main feature. Even the packing box seems cheap, especially if you have ever seen a higher-end pair of headphones in this range which are more like little shrines. A nylon strap and cleaning cloth, scarcely worthy of note round out the package. .

It works, works not merely better than I expected, but dependably and reliably and at a price anyone  simply should expect. The most unexpected feature was how much more quickly and easily it found and joined my home network. I recently added an AC extender which, no matter how configured, just confused my laptopâ€™s built-in card. I usually had to do a â€œrepairâ€ to get it going. Not so the Netgear, it sees and joins almost as soon as I have the lid opened .Perhaps this sounds trivial to more contemporary demands, but I was pleased by this improvement.After trying a few other brands of Wi-Fi adapters manufactured by relatively new companies who seem shameless at borrowing the â€œfeelâ€ of an established company name or design, I had pretty much decided to limit my future purchases to the more familiar brands.And not without reason- the last no-name USB adapter I tried did not work at all. But it was cheap.. So, returning to a known dependable make was in fact safe bet.The Netgear installation CD ran quickly, and even though it took awhile to search for non-existent online updates, this is still an optional feature. Which in any case I always find amusing with a connectivity product, suppose you are replacing a failed one and donâ€™t yet have a way to connect? Well, thatâ€™s just picking nits.After running the CD and rebooting- another vestige of the old days, inconvenient with older, slower machines- in this case an older Lenovo XP laptop, but it always makes me feel like something has actually been installed. The control panel for the unit showed up unobtrusively and proved simple and easy to operate. I like having other dashboards to let me know about the state of connectivity, relying on one could throw the bias on whichever manufacturer created it. Using one or two others gives the user a different opinion and means to control any of the devices, as well as check performance, obviously.Plugging in the adapter gets you going and runs automatically, the dashboard is activated from the system tray or a desktop icon.This one is simple, showing available networks and status thereof, speed, signal Internet connect info and control options. The adapter offers a basically automatic connection to your useable network, as well and the WPS button push method of connecting to your router, or entering your info manually. Really nothing exceptionally remarkable, but itâ€™s uncrowded and easy to use.Which is great, at least for speed of connection and range, even though I have a gigabit router, 300M seems to be the upper limit. Might be also impaired by the no-name AC extender I am using as well as its own speed limitations. I am not that well versed in shopping by numbers, it is usually based on what I can afford, and anything in that category that promises to be an actual improvement.It seems to connect more quickly than the on-board adapter, which is hardly surprising, and switches easily between the two. I find the dongle a little longer than others I have used, but my mouse plug protects it nicely- unless I am mouseless and using the touchpad. But, not much to do about that, with only 3 ports I am used to guarding them, not only physically but in rationing them as well. I carry only a skinny hub, good for portability but not for power or data transfer.I see that many users of newer machines and OSâ€™s seem have a lot to be unhappy about, so maybe this can now be considered a â€œlegacyâ€ device, which would explain why it works so well for me bit not they. And these days this is all too well, I imagine because of the continuing and die-hard XP user base this could become a niche market- like the manufacture of replica vintage car parts.So, despite a lot of less than pleasant experiences as indicated by other reviews, I had no problem at all with the Netgear and would certainly still keep that brand in the forefront.

I usually despair at reviewing software, in order to do it justice it takes almost a concerted daily effort to at least become familiar with as many of the features as deadline allows. But I had already become so frustrated in quite a few areas by lack of a PDF product that I was able to put Nuance Power PDF to work without hesitation.Off the top: a feature I have been needing of in a PDF utility made it worth the price of admission almost immediately after installing Nuance PDF Pro Basic: I can now convert printable only  PDF forms- usually employment applications- into online fill-ins in a matter of seconds. Many organizations- not just potential employers will accept only a PDF. Not only does this save me at least an hour an app but I have also noticed, when submitting in person, a neatly typed application is often more warmly received than my normal penmanship.(On the other hand, some employers demand the application be filled out on premise, by hand.)The alignment in boxes is not always perfect, but then my handwriting seldom is; the checkboxes look pro.One also has the ability to keep editing the form, i.e under "Shift Wanted" you can add an "any" box where none existed in the original.  Or just throw in some whimsical field just to see if anyone notices. I wish I'd had this years ago. The result is clean and professional, and really easy to accomplish. My main hopes were that it could easily convert my resume and letters to a PDF, which is the only accepted  format by many employers. Maybe just to pose another challenge to the supplicant. I mean, applicant. Sorry.But I digress. Again.Another amazing but simple touch by Nuance solves the age-old (OK, 25 years maybe) problem of transporting software to new computers. Nuance simply allows the user to de-activate the registration, install it on the new (or restored) machine then re-register. Genius.I did have a fit at first when installing, despite the Amazon description as being XP compatible, the box did not. I have seen this go either way sometime, so I took a breath and let the install rip.No problem. Which simply means that these days of dwindling XP support it will take a little more research to be certain you- we older users can run the software.It does hijack the default opening program and change the association, which is a minor issue, and can always be changed back should the differences be annoying enough. In Explorer, new PDF commands are added to the right-click menu. There is also added what seems to be the Nuance hue, a weird shade of purple which shows up everywhere.It seems to take longer to open files than the reader I was used to, but clearly a program with this many capabilities has a lot more going on. It also installs an icon in the system tray (if you still know what that means) but to me it means something is running in the background I probably would not miss and so disabled it.And new toolbar buttons will appear in all Office apps, I am not sure if I will be using them with any frequency but I really don't know how handy they will be in fact, or if the continued use of older Office versions will pop up as a problem. Seems one way or another we will all eventually be compelled to upgrade. But, if so I suspect a re-install will allow me to remove anything I find unnecessary and possibly resource consuming- I know some parts of Dragon can slow things down and I have learned to work around them as well.The forms, menus and toolbars are familiar looking, but just slightly odd enough to remind us that this is not a Microsoft boot-licker. Some other products- most notably from our neighbors to the north change the look so radically it takes even longer to adapt. While Nuance presents different appearance, it is not particularly a challenge to master. And if it is indeed, as another reviewer pointed out, a deliberate finger in the air to MS, then so much the better.Almost any feature a typically frustrated non-power PDF user may run into can he handled here. At one point I was able to use Adobe Acrobat, basic versions can be had as low as about twice the Nuance version,  it worked as well as you might expect, but I also have discovered the Nuance version to be adequate and if you're on a budget, quite satisfactory.I have also used Nuance's "Dragon" apps, and been suitably impressed by both the features and design, and am now discovering the integration between the two might find me reaching for my headset when filling in these job applications, being able to dictate the oh-so repetitive information has just gotten easier, I am not altogether uncertain I may soon be able to directly import info from my Excel database. I am also preferring to believe at some time in the near future I may no longer need to participate in this process at all.But in the bright side, it has allowed me to perform several urgent real-time tests, and you can be sure I am working my way through as many of the features as possible and keep discovering more helpful ones.Another feature I have longed for since I was first exposed to scanners and OCR is the ability to convert an already-scanned graphic-only image of a printed page into an editable document, be it Word, Wordpad, Notepad- whatever. Power PDF handles this, although it took a fair amount of stumbling around to accomplish. The help was really not very helpful, (offline help would not even open) but I think with use this will become much easier and truly useful.I keep discovering many features as I explore- one will convert any item on the Clipboard to a PDF, I tried it with a random JPG Facebook card-thing, and while it did not leave the text editable, it was able to make it searchable- something I have wanted to do from time to time but never thought possible. It might also be it can be edited by further manipulating the image and I just haven't discovered the method.You can add watermarks, something else that has long been possible for me, but never really that easy. Or absolutely necessary, but now that I can, I will. I also had a slight bobble, when I opened a PDF file by clicking it in Explorer, it did so with the "Nuance Demo" watermark imprinted and asked me to activate/register. I already had, but before I called Nuance I found it only happened if I opened a file this way, not through the main menu. It doesn't bother me that much, but it also isn't right. If it happens again will be making that call.While it also claims to not support anything older than Office 2007, which will limit my testing a bit, I was able to get one test sheet converted (as well, of course, as simple DOC to PDF conversions) using my hobbled copy of Office 2003. As I mentioned I do not know what other obstacles I may encounter, but it is, after all, essentially a PDF-centric product, Office integration (beyond document conversion) was not really on my mind when I began to use this. It also has its own scanner drivers and software, but as I am recently just recovering from a loss of my original HP software, I am reluctant to try it without a system backup in case it also hijacks it, I somehow got an earlier version of the HP ware restored and I find I prefer it for most tasks. Still, I look forward to seeing what they've accomplished, my split between photos and OCR is about 90/10, so I am in no hurry.I will not simply list features off of the box, I will continue to explore and play, and now that I have solved a few pressing problems, it's fun. Like learning new software used to be. It is considered a typical method of dodging the responsibility of writing a truly in depth (or even superficial) review to say, "I'll list more features as I discover them" and of course never come back to do so. Whether or not I do edit this to be even more absurdly long, I know I will keep finding new things in Nuance PDF Pro Basic to get enthusiastic about.

I had hoped this would be a video review, but alas, not are our gray squirrels apparently too smart, another Havahart product previously applied Havahart Critter Ridder 3145 Animal Repellent, Ready-to-Use Spray, 32-Ounce seems to still be working quite well. Or, my choice of peanut bitter for bait was not to their liking. Not to mention, there are so many of the little buggers about that trapping one would be for research purposes only (and OK, maybe payback for the torment they have given my cats); releasing one into "the wild" around here would be not only pointless and scary (they're fierce), but contrary to County ordinance.The trap is about the right size for the smaller models of rodent, and would probably also do nicely with some of the mega-rats I have encountered, but they are relatively uncommon. Other sizes are available with attendant scariness at the prospect of bagging a larger prey.Nevertheless, I have examined and closely tested this device, it is superbly crafted and at a really reasonable price. The trap doors can be opened at either or both ends by simply looping the draw cable for one over a conveniently placed hook, a large and easy to use handle then draws both doors open with a very light effort.It is also sprung with a light effort, I measured it about 3 ounces, but it is more the rattling movement of the target that helps set it off with very little fuss. I noticed if it is tipped very far to one side or the other it is even more sensitive, but I can't see this affecting operation.I am not sure how you and your local animal control fell about the "release" part of a live trap, but if it is not a problem I could scarcely imagine a better built and more reliable trap than the Havahart.

They arrived quickly and as described. I purchased these to replace our one remote that stopped working. We own a 1999 Ford Explorer. It was easy to program and they are both working great! The price was affordable and I even splurged on One Day shipping to get it faster. I would definitely recommend World Wide Remotes. Thanks for the great product!

Every coffee I have tried from Pooki's Mahi has always been good but this Kona Hazelnut is definitely top 2! It's a medium blend and has a very pleasant aroma. I use a Keurig mini brewer and these single cups works great in them. Each cup is individually packaged which I love because I can take 2 with me in my lunch bag to work. It has a smooth, nutty flavor with no bitterness at all. I am a repeat customer and the quality of their coffee never let's me down!I purchased these kcups at a discounted price for evaluation purposes. I do not get paid or compensated in any way. A positive review is never a guarantee, just an honest review of my personal experience with the product.Overall I give it 5 stars for tasting great and being consistent in their quality.

1:47 Mins I wish I would've had something like this when I was in high school and college. It would have made note taking so much easier! This is a very easy to use USB voice recorder. It's just like a regular flash drive. It has an on/off switch to start recording. When you turn it on the light will blink red to let you know it's started. Once you're done just switch it to off. I have the turquoise case with the blue mandala design and it's beautiful! The colors and design are very eye catching.
