Love the premise of this hat/earphone combo. My son was very excited to try it out and I immediately had him give it a go. I have a TON of hair and after trying the hat on, despite the fact that it fit I decided it was more for him than me. I found it a little uncomfortable for me. I couldn't get it to sit the way I wanted it to, I'm used to adjustable hats, but really it was more about my OCD than about the hat.Anyhoo, back to the hat/earphone combo, my son linked it up with his phone in a matter of seconds, he tells me that the sound quality is great and that the buttons are easy to use. He likes that the headphones are connected to the hat and can't be dropped while he's biking. He's had to swing back and retrieve his other wireless headphones a couple of times while on his bike, so this is an issue for him. He's even lost a set because someone saw him drop them and they swooped in and grabbed them before he was able to. He liked that the hat doesn't have a plastic adjuster near his ears, so he can wear it in cold weather without fear of his ears freezing too. He even sprayed the hat with a water repellant in hope that it would help in the rain. He rides his bike year round, so this will come in handy for him.He states that this is a great hat, with quality headphones and that for the price it's somethine he would have invested in for himself. The hat fit him comfortably and he states that it doesn't chafe, or make him sweat also. I did receive this item in exchange for a fair and honest review.

I love CoverGirl products and have used them for years, 28 years this Christmas to be exact ;) My first eyeshadows were a CG and a gift from my mom!I was drawn to these colors immediately and was excited to try them. I was very disappointed with the lack of pigment however. I used primer prior to applying, and despite this after applying all the colors were so similar there was really not enough contrast to make them "strikingly" different once they were out of the compact and on my eyes. Once applied the shimmer is more pronounced than the pigment is and I'm just not impressed with this particular set. Perhaps if the colors were matte, or had less shimmer I'd be more impressed. I honestly have to say this set will probably sit on the shelf more than it will be used.

Many folks find discussing their intimate toys intimadating. I find it liberating, especially at the airport when my suitcase is being explored rather thoroughly by the TSA and gentleman who finds my intimate toy is too embarassed to continue searching my bag and steps away and asks his partner to continue the search. I immediately begin discussing the merits of said aid with the fine TSA agent and she jumps right into the conversation and begins asking questions! I kindly let her know that this is hands down one of the better aids I have owned, I love the fact that it's quieter than most of the items I've purchased in the past and it's waterproof so "Pete" as I've named him can join me in the shower or bath. ;) He's soft to the touch, and not in that icky way that the older models were where they would get sticky after one wash, despite using the correct cleaning agents. I shared with her that Pete has a variety of pulses and intensities and his batteries last forever, unlike a typical male hehe. This definitely made her male partner blush. I told her how he came in a cute little gift box with an included velveteen bag that I had obviously forgotten at home, or he wouldn't have poked his purple head out of my side pocket announcing his presence to the world. After several awkward minutes for her partner the nice TSA lady helped me repack my bag and asked where I had gotten my partner Purple Pete the Warlord and I explained I had gotten free in exchange for a fair and honest review, but that she could purchase hers here on Amazon. We both agreed that for the price on here, compared to other places Pete was a cheap date!In all seriousness though, after having my secret friend exposed in such a public way, I can honestly say that this unit really is one of the better ones for the price. It's a great quality, and the perfect size and fit. The grip is comfortable and I would definitely purchase it for myself had I not already received it.

I love, love, love silicone pastry sheets! I bake a LOT and while I don't mind using parchment paper, I would really rather use something that I can throw in the dishpan and use over and over again! What I love best about these Silpat sheets is that they are marked for other pastry uses! You can roll out and measure and cut your puff pastry, pie crusts and fondant on them too! I use them often to roll out biscuit dough, cut out cookies and and knead bread to safe scraping my counter top too. I use them on my half sheet instead of parchment paper for certain recipes, others just don't crisp up the way I like when I use silpal sheets, but you'll have to judge for yourself which you want to use them for and which you don't. We all have different preferences. I love these sheets much better than several other sheets that I've paid a LOT of money for, just because of the measured circles on them. Since you get two, I think the price is great, even for one the price is phenomenal when compared to some of the high end name brand ones I have purchased in the past!I received this item in exchange for a fair and honest review.

Not all selfie sticks are the same. Some are so chintzy that they literally fold in two the minute you put your phone in them. LITERALLY :( Trust me, I've tried a LOT Of them over the last several months. Some of them make me want to step off a cliff, throw myself in a river or jump in front of a car. They are frustrating because you must charge them, use a remote that never works or click a button that always breaks at the most importune moment.So when I received this item, I really didn't have high hopes. Imagine my surprise when I realized all I had to do with this one was plug it into my phone's headphone jack and "Voila" I was in business! It was sturdy, it held my phone, it didn't bend AND it was PINK! Well, I actually didn't give two squirts that it was pink but all four of my nieces LOVED it and squealed a LOT. :P Anyhoo, It worked great, we got some really fun shots and I gifted it to the niece who gave me the best and most compliments that day. She's 5, she said she likes my ears because they aren't huge like her moms :) Bless her soul!I received this item free in exchange for a fair and honest review.

Same spice you pay $7 for the tiny bottle of at your local grocer's. I was shocked when I realized this was $1 an ounce on Amazon! I use a LOT of this spice, year round in my baking so it was a godsend to find it so cheaply priced! When I opened it, it was nice and fresh and tasted such when I baked it into my first recipe! Why pay three or four times the price for a tiny bottle!

I love to cook, and I'm in the kitchen a LOT in summer canning. A good vegetable peeler for a cook is like a great pen for a writer. This particular vegetable peeler is fantastic! There is just enough heft to it that you don't have to dig it into the vegetables, you can run it towards you or away from you. The great debate of peeling vegetables amongst cooks ;) I personally am a pusher, my husband is a puller. We both found it equally easy to use and liked it with potatoes, carrots, turnips and even tried it on tomatoes for good measure! I would highly recommend this peeler to anyone who peels a lot of vegetables. The quality is amazing and it will last you years to come. They come in a package of two and are well worth the money!I received this item in exchange for a fair and honest review.

I absolutely love this case. I have a job where I'm in several offices in several cities every week. When appointments get cancelled I sometimes have a lot of time on my hands and my internet usage on the company computer is monitored. I love stashing my iPad mini in my bag and bringing it with me so I can surf the net, or read my kindle books. This case works great to protect my iPad and prop it so I don't have to hold it in my hands. The color is cute and the quality is great. I love how easy it is to get on and off, which isn't always the case with many covers for the iPad minis. Some covers are more of a pain to get on and off than they are worth. This one is affordable and cute!I received this item free in exchange for a fair and honest review.

I purchased this dispenser through Prime Pantry when it was on sale and there was a coupon. I wanted to see if it was cost effective. I have to say I was really pleasantly surprised not only at how long the jar of soap lasted, but at the quality of the soap! I have OCD and wash my hands constantly, and the soaps are easy on my hands and don't dry them out at all. I will be using this dispenser for years to come!

I purchased this super sized bottle of Elmer's Glue to do a crackle finish on an old dresser to "Prim" it up. I LOVE the finished product! Who knew that Elmer's School Glue was good for more than construction paper, making your hands look old and eating?!

My favorite feature of these child cabinet locks is that I didn't have to keep opening the cabinet for my husband!! We had previously tried a set of cabinet locks from Walmart, that were name brand and kind of expensive, and he couldn't work the things. I was always having to get up, go into the kitchen and open cabinets for him. Seriously.These are easy enough for the husband to use, but confusing enough for the kids to not be able to figure out. They were super easy to install, even for me ;) I can't recommend them highly enough!!I received these cabinet locks in exchange for a fair and honest review.

I absolutely LOVE these latches! I have four nieces and nephews that visit often and they are all under the age of 6. I have used one lock each on my refrigerator, a freezer, a cooler we use near the pool and my screen door that leads to the pool. Believe it or not, they worked equally well on each item! With a house that previously didn't need to be baby proofed I was in a dither to make sure we were safe when the kids came over. We often babysit and to be honest we just weren't prepared to have four toddlers in a house with so many every day items that they want to get into or out to! The refrigerator is a never ending source of snacks and drinks, and the freezer is a matching upright so they assume it too holds drinks and snacks. The cooler holds the drinks near the pool and they are always wanting to help themselves and of course they always want to go out to the pool when you aren't looking! While the latches weren't specifically advertised for doors, it works great to keep ours from opening when the kiddies are here and gives us a few extra seconds to catch up to them and reroute them back to a safe zone! Well worth the price, and I will be ordering more of these latches for more applications before the next babysitting adventure. First I need a nap :)I received these latches in exchange for a fair and honest review.

In theory this item is great, hook a fob to your keys, phone, purse or whatever you lose frequently and find it with the main key fob by pushing the button associated with the lost item. In practice the item isn't so great. The smaller fobs are nearly impossible to turn to the on position. In fact I was afraid I would break the "on" switch off the fob when I turned it to the on position. There are no assigned buttons to each fob and the directions are spotty at best. I have yet to be able to figure out how to configure the smaller fobs in order to use them. I will revise my review when I am able to figure the items out, if I'm able to. I think with a little tweaking to the directions I would have been able to give this item a four star review, but the difficulty of turning the switch to the on position would still have prevented me from giving it a five.I was provided a free sample of this item in exchange for a fair and honest review.

I received these earbuds in exchange for a fair and honest review... With that being said I have to admit I really like these a LOT. The switches are a lot easier to toggle with my "giant man hands" as I like to refer to them ;) I don't know if I really have over large fingers for a chick, or if I'm just particularly clumsy, but I have a set of wireless earphones with the switches on the earbuds themselves and I just can't work the buttons. I either end up deafening myself or not being able to hear a thing. :(Anyhoo, I love the waterproof feature for when I want to walk in the rain. This is an added perk, my other pair are NOT waterproof and I always worry I will fry them so I tuck them away when it starts to rain. The battery life of these is also much longer than my other set which is a perk. I only have to charge every four or five days as I only use them when I walk in the mornings.I find them more comfortable than my other buds too. Overall they are a perfect 5 stars for me, I couldn't find a single flaw for me. I know others said when they turned their heads they worked loose or tugged, but I didn't have any issues like that. They fit snuggly without being uncomfortable and only come out when I take them out. I would definitely purchase these for myself or a friend!

I have used other touchless soap dispensers in the past, the type you have to purchase special soap inserts for. While I like the convenience of the no touch dispensers, I HATE having to pay upwards of $3.50 for the tiny amount of soap you get with their inserts!I was offered this item in exchange for a fair and honest review and I jumped at the chance! I have to say that I am VERY impressed with the dispenser. It comes with a tray so you can mount it on the wall, and I immediately mounted it in my TINY downstairs bathroom on the wall. What a joy to not have a soap dispenser constantly falling into the sink, or a bar of soap melting all over the tiny vanity that's in that bathroom! This dispenser works GREAT! It takes 4 AAA batteries and holds a HUGE amount of soap. I filled it with my favorite liquid soap and it dispenses just the right amount! I love that the wall mounted tray has a spot that catches any drips in case you pull your hand away too quickly too! It's great for when the little ones are over, as they often to pull their hand away to quickly.I HIGHLY recommend investing in one of these high quality soap dispensers rather than wasting your money on name brand soap inserts for the other automatic dispensers! I wish I had known about this item before I purchased the other dispenser, I'd have one in every bathroom and the kitchen too!

I received this item free in exchange for a fair and honest review.While I'm not exactly a "techy" person, my son is definitely a gamer. I figured he could use this and let me know what he thought of it. He was somewhat more than impressed with it. He states it's easy to use and keeps his controllers charged. He uses only one at a time, so while he's "killing" one he has another one "juicing" up. He really liked the extra USB ports and thought they were a great addition to the unit. He also states the sound of the fans isn't "distracting" at all.Let me take a moment to point out that I could run through the house on fire and naked and not distract him from his games. I have literally stood three free from him and told him "Dinner is ready" repeatedly for 15 minutes in three languages and haven't been able to distract him. I have carried on one sided conversations with him about the pros and cons of granny panties and not distracted him. How this grown man could say that the sound of a fan on a cooling station for his video game station isn't distracting just amazes me. The end of the world couldn't distract him.Needless to say he endorses the product whole heartedly...
These goobers were wonderfully fresh and tasty.
Great item, much better quality than I expected and it fits wonderful!

I LOVE these make up removers! I have chemical sensitivity issues and my eyes are super sensitive. I use a lot of make up products that are waterproof and these are the ONLY make up removers that not only remove all my eye make up with no scrubbing, but they don't burn my eyes!

Who knew it was so hard to find lava rocks for a smoker or grill? I checked Walmart and Lowe's in our town and neither place carries lava rocks in the store! Since I purchased a smoker for my husband for Christmas he's used it to the point that he had to replace the rocks. These were perfect and the price was great.

Wow.  Good story.  But C.J. Box has always been a good storyteller.  His actual writing seems to have improved with fewer grammatical errors than I've noted in previous books (where are editors these days?).Get ready for a thrill ride on The Highway.

Everybody doesn't need a $150 knife.  Everybody doesn't even want a $150 knife.  This Dozier design folder is cheap but worthy of consideration if all one wants or needs is a basic locking knife that doesn't cost a fortune.  Lightweight due to the linerless design, sharp due to the good quality AUS8 steel of the blade and ergonomic by design.I own a lot of expensive folders and honestly don't carry this knife.  But, being a collector, I bought one just to see if it's as good as people have reported.  It is.  It won't replace my expensive knives but I like it.

I was worried about quality when I bought the Fire Stick since we have the "economy" high speed Internet service at home.  I had been warned that the picture could freeze and make the viewing irritating.  Didn't happen.  I've only used it to watch about 10 hour long features but it hasn't frozen once.  The picture is not as sharp or high rez on the 52" TV as the normal picture but it's not really bad.  Kinda like watching a lower quality HD production but not really as low quality as some of the non-HD movies channels on Dish.  On smaller screens like the iPhone, Kindle and small TV the picture looks very good to superb.Easy to set up...pretty much plug and play.  We've been watching several Prime features and Amazon productions without paying extra.  I'm happy with it.  Especially since I got it for $29.99 with the $10 off promotion.

Better quality than what I've gotten at the local supermarkets and at an excellent price.  These Medjool dates are delicious and huge.  They aren't gummy like the grocery store brands and they're not desiccated like the unbranded bargains found in bags or bins.  They do have pits so don't bite down on them hard as you snack.

I bought this strop from the Knives Plus website sometime back and I've gotten great use from it.  A little expensive as sold through Amazon but it's really an excellent strop.  I've used it for more than a year and bought a second to keep in my RV.  It's well made with soft leather glued permanently to a piece of lightweight wood composite with melted polishing compound and oil impregnated into the leather.  The green polishing compound puts a fine mirror polish on the edge of my knives.  If the leather starts to dry out, rub a little olive oil onto the surface and let it absorb.  It's back to new again.You can make your own strop from an old leather belt or scrap leather glued to a board but this is the easy way to get a quality leather strop.  A mirror edge is not needed for all knives (depends on the steel and the job you're doing) but for those that can benefit from a stropped edge, the Knives Plus Strop Block is one of the easiest ways to get there.

This is a gritty adult Western drama that seems semi realistic.  The cast is impressive and the story gets off to a running start.  I've heard of this series but never had a chance to watch it until now.  I was looking forward to seeing it free with my Amazon Prime account.I only have one gripe.  I'm not offended by nor do I shy away from obscene language.  But, really, this crap is over the top.  No character in this series seems to be able to carry on a conversation without using a half dozen obscenities or repeating variations of f*** three or four times per sentence.  The action takes place in the 19th Century in the Dakota Territories, not in a 21st Century inner city with background rap music and gang banger babble.  After listening to this dialog for 15 minutes, I found it repetitious, distracting, tedious and simply boring.  I haven't decided if I will continue to watch or not.  If not, too bad since the series seems promising otherwise.

Really good production.  Based on Phillip K. Dick's novel, this original production is well produced and well acted.  I did not read the original book but I am familiar with the story.  The first two episodes of this series have me hooked.  Looking forward to future episodes.

Surprisingly good knife in almost every respect.  I bought one of these around the same time as I bought a Benchmade Stryker with the drop point blade.  The Stryker cost over 50% more than the HK Axis model yet the knives seem to me to be nearly equal.  The HK is even a little heavier duty with a thicker blade, D2 steel and heavier Axis lock components.  If Benchmade sold these as "Benchmade" instead of "HK" the pricing would be significantly higher.The only apparent nod to economy in this model is the spine of the knife was left rough and unpolished prior to applying the black coating.  It has no bearing on function and it is hardly noticeable.  Straight from the box, the pivot was a little rough as well.  I washed it in hot water and dishwashing detergent, using an old toothbrush to get into the lock and pivot area.  After it dried, I used a Q-tip with oil and lightly lubed the blade tang, pivot and Axis lock.  The HK pivot smoothed out and has been as smooth in opening/closing as any other Benchmade ever since.  The knife was sharp on arrival but not as sharp as I like.  Most people would be thrilled with Benchmade's edge grind.  I improved on the factory edge with Spyderco ceramic stones and a leather strop loaded with green polishing compound.  D2 steel is hard stuff.  It holds an edge well but it's slow to return to sharpness when dull.  I like it but I know how to sharpen stuff.  If you're not good a sharpening you can always use Benchmade's Lifesharp service..  But you have to ship off your knife to take advantage of the free sharpening.  My advice:  learn to sharpen your knives yourself.One other point.  Every Axis lock knife I've owned has eventually developed a loose pivot.  According to Benchmade Company, they purposely make the pivots loose so the owner can adjust the deployment tension to suit themselves.  The owner will need to remove the pivot screw, put a drop of Loctite (I suggest either blue or purple) on the screw threads, adjust the tension to preference and let the Loctite set up for about 12 hours.  Once this is done, the pivot is unlikely to need further attention.  Of course, if you prefer to do so you can just retighten the pivot as it loosens.Really a good knife for a hundred bucks.  I'd dock it 1/2 star for the unfinished look of the blade spine but otherwise it's a 5-star piece of cutlery.

Nice looking shoe.  Appears to be well made and I like the styling a lot--understated solid white with a wonderful, non slip gum rubber sole.  A little squeaky at first but that stopped after one day of wearing.I went by the Amazon recommendation for sizing but had to go up a size to a 13.  Amazon's fit computer recommended a 12.5 but the shoe doesn't come in a 12.5 size.  Much too big.  Returned the 13 and ordered a 12.  Fit is okay although kinda narrow--but I have fairly wide feet.  Most brands of sneakers have to be ordered a size larger than I normally wear to accommodate my wider feet.  My normal shoe size is 11EE but I have to order a 12 in sneakers that only come in medium widths.  If a 12.5 was available in these Romas, they would probably give me a smidgeon more toe room but, honestly, the size 12 fits pretty close to my normal size 11 in length, just a little tight in the width.Wish more sneaker makers would offer widths in their shoes.  I like the retro styling of Adidas Samoas, Onitsuka Tigers and these Puma Romas but they never fit me as well as a New Balance or Asics in a wider width.

Nice enough belt but it stretches like crazy.  I've worn one in rotation with two other belts for the last two years and I'm about to have to punch another hole in it to keep it tight enough to hold up the pants.  And, no, I have not lost any weight during this time.  It's made with one layer of leather, without any reinforcement so it's prone to growing longer and longer over time.

I have both the satin, plain edge and the black, partially serrated models of this knife.  They are very good knives overall and I have only one major complaint which I'll get into later.I'm a Spyderco fan and the hole in the blade is very familiar to me.  The Pika II also shares the nested full steel liner design used in several fiberglass reinforced nylon handled Spyderco models.  It's also a back/mid lock design--shades of the Delica/Endura, etc.  The Pika II is a Chinese made knife whereas most of the core traditional models from Spyderco are Japanese in origin.  The Pika II blade is 9Cr13 steel where Spyderco uses VG-10.  Of course, the Pika II is NOT a Spyderco.  It's a Benchmade brand.  Being made in China, Benchmade is able to market these knives at a much lower price than their US production.  I must say, I'm impressed with the design and build of these knives.  I like the blade shape and grind--it reminds me of the sadly discontinued Benchmade AFCK--and the odd looking grip pattern seems effective enough to keep the knife in your hand during chores.  The grind is a hollow saber type with a nice swedge that adds to the aesthetics.  The blade is very pointed and thin at the tip, a design that makes for good penetration but perhaps a little fragile for some aggressive users.  The handle is very ergonomic and it's long enough for a solid grip.  The Pika II allows tip up or down carry for both right and left handers with the moveable pocket clip.  I like the clip a lot.  It's effective without being overly strong and the design is pleasing to the eye and solid.  The finish of the blade on both the black and satin knives is virtually flawless--well polished in the satin and uniformly coated in the black model.Okay then.  Is this the perfect folding knife?  Not quite.  While there are lots of very good to excellent points to these knives, both of them share one major fault.  They are both difficult to open one-handed.  Loosening the pivot and adding a drop of oil does nothing to help.  I initially thought a little wearing in would fix the problem as it has done in other back lock knives I own.  Well, it helped a bit but it has not resolved the issue.  Apparently the pivot area is not among the most smoothly polished surfaces on the planet and the back lock spring is very stiff and strong.  A little playing around with finger placement when opening the knives helps with leverage but they are VERY stiff and not easy openers at all.I like these knives despite the stiff opening issues.  If a little better finishing in the pivot area and a little less strong springing in the lock were used, these could be outstanding knives in their price range.

Right after I bought the satin blade version of the 710, I found a black coated, partially serrated edge version being sold as "used" by a dealer.  The knife really wasn't used, it was brand new and appeared to be a demonstration model or a sample that had been sold and returned.  Generally, I prefer non-serrated edges on white blades but the price was too good to pass up and, besides, I had already bought the satin, plain edge 710.  Initial examination showed the black blade was a hair off-center but this didn't bother me much considering the price.  As is often the case with Axis lock Benchmades, the pivot loosened in short order.  A little Loctite applied to the pivot screw threads with a toothpick fixed that immediately.  Since I got the knife for such a good price, I decided to carry it as a "beater" model and subject it to every type of use and abuse while saving the satin 710 for future uses.  Over the relatively short period I've owned this knife, it's been a slicer, trimmer, chopper knife as well as a light duty pry bar and screw driver.  The black coating on the blade has worn significantly and the G10 has picked up a few minor scars--both conditions were expected given the treatment the knife has been subjected to.  The knife is holding up perfectly and I'm more than satisfied.  In fact, this "bargain beater" 710 has become one of my favorite and most used knives.While D2 steel is noted for being a bear to sharpen, it holds a sharp utility edge for a long time without dulling.  I can sharpen it to hair splitting sharpness but such a fine edge is a bit fragile for most of the cutting tasks I've performed with this knife.  That small serrated section of the blade really makes some tough cutting a lot less tough.  I make sure I don't use up the edge completely before resharpening, otherwise it's a slow process to bring a D2 edge back from dull.  The 4" blade is a bit longer than I'm used to but the knife carries as easily as any 3.5" model I own.  I also really like the narrow blade profile that adds to the ease of carry.  Overall, this is one versatile pocket knife.

Good, heavy denim material with plenty of stitching.  Should hold up to heavy use.  The biggest negative for me is the baggy fit and the overly long inseams.  Like all denim, it will stretch as the pants are worn.  Normal fit jeans stretch to fit better after wearing a while but these full fit jeans already fit loose and the stretching just makes them looser and baggy.  I have to tighten my belt a notch to hold them in place.  Plus they are too long...they pool up around my ankles and drag the floor with flat soled shoes.  This gets worse with extended wearing.  Fresh out of the dryer, they fit much better.For general wear, I think I will stick to relaxed or traditional fit jeans.  The loose fit Carhartts are a little too loose for me.  If you're buying for use on the job site and want the loose fit, order them shorter than normal or be prepared to roll them up or cut them off.

I'm kind of a Spyderco guy.  I own a number of them and I consider Spyderco some of the best knives and most appealing designs on the planet.  Benchmade makes good knives and I own several of them as well.  But only few Benchmade models really appeal to me.  The 710 is one that does.  I'm glad to report that I am not disappointed with my recent purchase of the 710.Lots of good things to report here.  D2 steel is good stuff.  Not stainless steel but it's "near" stainless due to the high chromium content.  It is rust resistant but real corrosion requires neglect on the owner's part.  D2 will stain with use over time.  D2 steel is hard and some people just cannot get the hang of sharpening it.  The secret is patience and persistence and maybe the judicious use of diamond stones.  Best idea:  don't let it get dull to begin with.  I use Spyderco's ceramic stones and keep my knives sharp and DMT diamond stones to bring them back to sharpness.  But the 710 came surprisingly sharp to begin with so normal touch ups should be all that's necessary for a good while.The handle is G10 and I like it.  It's not aggressively textured but it's not slippery either.  The Axis lock is strong.  Sometimes a spring will break in the Axis lock but it's not a common occurrence.  Opening the knife is silky smooth.  The shape of the handle is excellent--narrow, thin and well shaped.  The blade is 4" long which is a bit longer than I usually like to carry.  However, the blade manages to fit into a handle of a length you usually find on a knife with a 3.5" blade.  Since the whole package is thin and narrow, this knife carries so easily it doesn't feel like a 4" knife in your pocket.  Just be aware that a 4" knife might not be legal to carry in some of the places you frequent.As for negative points, there is only one I've identified--a complaint fairly common to Benchmade knives with Axis locks.  To clarify, I actually own two Benchmade 710's.  My other is a partially serrated, black coated blade model.  I bought it about the same time as the plain satin blade model.  Although I like the looks of the satin model better, I've been carrying the black model daily for about a month.  It gets a lot of frequent use.  It's kind of a beater knife since I bought it new as an "open box" deal for a good discounted price and I don't mind using the heck out of it.  The main concern I've found is how the pivot gets loose with the frequent opening and closing this knife goes through.  The issue is not a deal breaker because it is completely resolved with ease.  To do so, follow this procedure:  Back out the pivot screw with a Torx wrench until a good bit of the threads are visible.  Wipe off any excess oil with a Q-tip.  Apply a drop of Loctite to a toothpick and apply the Loctite to the pivot screw threads--a drop or two should be enough.  Tighten the screw until the blade has the amount of tension you like and let the knife set up until the Loctite dries.  Once this is done, the pivot screw should no longer loosen with normal use.The 710 is a smooth operating knife that keeps getting smoother as you use it.  Aesthetically, it looks good and it's not as threatening-looking as many 4" knives.  (Of course, some people feel threatened by anything sharp and pointed so this point is subjective.)  It feels comfortable in >my< hand and fulfills >my< needs well.  It's expensive, yeah.  If you can justify the expense and want a high quality knife, I highly recommend the 710,

My introduction to Marvel Mystery Oil came about in the 1960's.  My mother's Ford Galaxy 500 developed noisy valves and rough idle.  My mom was worried something major was wrong with the engine.  I took it to the dealership for her but the head mechanic (we called them "mechanics" back in the 60's, not "technicians") told me to buy a bottle of MMO and give it a try.  He said he could repair the engine but it would be costly and he thought MMO would do the same thing for a couple of bucks.  I did as he said and the engine smoothed out and quieted down almost immediately.  I've been a believer ever since.My current vehicle is a diesel Ram 3500.  I add a few ounces of MMO and Power Service Diesel Kleen every time I fill up.  The truck is over 10 years old now and runs perfectly.  I also noticed an improvement in mileage when I started using my additive cocktail.It may not cure the common cold or make you head of the class but this stuff does a pretty good job of cleaning the engine and fuel system of vehicles.

Unlike some of the other reviewers, I've never had a problem with these brushes shedding bristles.  I own two of them, one for home and one in a travel kit.  They are easy to maintain--I just use standard shampoo to wash them when they begin to get a little oily and collect dust.  They show no ill effects from doing this.  I like how they glide through my hair, unlike other plastic bristle brushes that can pull.  My hair is now thinning and I've started wearing it short (goodbye to my once long, flowing mane) and these brushes seem made for shorter hair.Considering the low price and good quality, I highly recommend this brush.

This is a generic charger, available under various brands.  I have them branded STK, Maximal Power and Vivitar for four different models/brands of cameras.  They are two-piece units with the top sections being different to accept the particular battery design they are to be used for.  I really haven't noticed but I expect the lower section is the same on all the units with the top section being wired for the different locations of the battery contacts and, presumably, the variations in voltage. Some come with USB outlets, some with European adapters included and all have various versions of car plugs to use while traveling.All the chargers I have seem to work fine although none of them are my primary chargers.  For that purpose, I use the camera brand charger and keep these generic chargers as backups.  Since these chargers are for backup, I've only used them briefly and I cannot judge how they will work if used frequently over a long period.  For the brief periods I've used them, they appear to function well.I have used off-brand batteries for my cameras in the past and I've had no problems with any of them other than having a shorter charge/lifespan than the camera branded batteries.  I suppose there could be some incompatibilities involved in some brands.(Some have complained of difficulty removing the battery from the charger.  You have to pay attention to the instructions on the unit before inserting the battery.  The instructions are covered by the battery once it is inserted.  Do it once and you'll find it's really simple.)

In 2015, television can boast of the finest productions in its history.  There is outstanding writing, acting and production that, in the past, was only seen on the big screen.  Indeed, movies seem stuck in the mire of special effects and computer generated imaging having forsaken all semblance of creative substance.  Yes, TV is the current bastion of quality dramatic productions.  But "Texas Rising" is not one of them.I looked forward to watching this mini-series on the formation of the Great State of Texas.  But early into the first episode, I was confounded by the worst writing and acting I've witnessed on a purported "major" production.  Nevertheless, the DVR continued to record this POS and I continued to watch the train wreck for the sheer entertainment value of pure incompetence.Being of the Baby Boom generation, I've been subject to the history of Texas in various forms for decades.  Most of it was from movies and TV and books of fiction and I'm sure most of it has been myth.  But all this exposure has led to some familiarity with the core facts involved.  I'm also very familiar with the geography of Texas, having spent a great deal of time visiting most of the areas of the state over many years.  I wish the people involved in "Texas Rising" had spent a little time becoming familiar with the state before rushing into making this travesty.History is frequently twisted by poetic license.  I can accept that a dramatic presentation of an historical event will contain fictional elements.  But the writers who came up with the peripheral characters and events in "Texas Rising" just recycled writing elements that I thought had been tossed out in the 1980's.  The characterizations are so stereotypical and predictable it adds to the whole comic atmosphere of incompetence.  As for the truly historical characters portrayals, the writers apparently felt the legends and myths surrounding these real people has more validity than their actual lives.  Take Emily West, for instance.  History indicates Ms West was an indentured servant of mixed race who was held captive by the Mexican army as it was engaged in the fight with the Texas rebels.  The writers of "Texas Rising" turned her into a former New Orleans whore who spied for Sam Houston (her lover) by becoming the mistress of Santa Ana.  This, of course, should make for interesting theatre but, instead, made for a series of totally unbelievable episodes without really adding anything to the plot.While some have criticized the acting, I'm going to cut them some slack here.  The cast seems to just be crew members of a sinking ship.  They're doing their job as best they can so they can draw their paychecks, hit the life rafts and make it home intact.  This is a truly awful production but most of us have worked at bad jobs before.  We did it for the pay, not the satisfaction of performing an important role in life.  It's an embarrassment to the actors because their faces and performances are on display.  That's sad because there wasn't much they could do with this wretched job to make it better.The real stake through the heart of "Texas Rising" is the locale.  All the action for the events portrayed happened in Southern and Southeastern Texas.  This is not desert country.  Repeat >NOT< desert.  This is really a geography of lowlands, bayous, coastal plains and woodlands.  At the Battle of San Jacinto, Santa Ana was trying to escape through a swamp when he was captured by the Texas army.  San Jacinto is adjacent to the current city of Houston and this is NOT in the desert.  But "Texas Rising" was filmed in Mexico and in the Mexican desert.  In "Texas Rising", Santa Ana is captured while meandering around boulders through dry, rocky terrain.  The rationale for the shooting location is beyond me.  Again, this adds to the comical ineptness of the whole production.In summary, "Texas Rising" is truly an awful mini-series and a waste of all the resources used for the production.  It's a great example of incompetence and, if for no other reason, it might be worth watching just to see how not to do this type of work.

When the DVD/CD burner in my MacMini started rejecting all discs I tried, it was time for either a new computer or an external DVD/CD burner.  Since the computer still functions and drives sell in the under $40 range, I went for the external disc drive.  I've only used it to copy a few music CDs to upload to the Amazon Cloud but it appears to function perfectly.  It's "plug and play" for the Mac...the software disc included is only for Windows.  About as easy to set up as a new desk lamp.  The whole unit feels flimsy and it's thin, lightweight plastic but modern plastics are incredibly strong.  The ability to handle mDiscs is a plus since I intend to use them to archive a lot of photographs I have stored on portable hard drives.Unless something unforeseen comes up, I've very satisfied with this device's features.

These Henley collar T-shirts are typical of traditional original fit Carhartt work clothing--well made and cut full and loose to allow non-binding movement.  I've been a buyer of the standard Carhartt T-shirts for quite a while now and these Henley models are the same cut and fabric.  I love the knit fabric weight and the way they fit.  Generally, I buy T-shirts a size up from my normal size to allow for shrinkage over time and due to my dislike for clothing that clings and binds.  Fact is, I probably wouldn't have to do that with these shirts since they're already a little over-sized to begin with.  If you prefer a tighter fit in your T-shirts, go down one size.  As for shrinkage over time, there's not really much to speak of.  They shrink a little but not a full size.I wear black T-shirts almost exclusively.  They don't show soiling as easily as lighter colors and they go with any other color perfectly, looking nice under a casual sport shirt.  The Carhartt black shirts will fade over time with normal laundering.  They seem to fade a bit more than other brands I've owned but I don't mind this.  The older shirts just get worn when I'm doing the dirtiest chores, the newer shirts for light tasks for just hanging out.  If you can't abide fading, don't get the black shirts or just buy something else with polyester in the fabric.Where the Henley collar T-shirt really comes into it's strength is in the heat.  It's been in the mid to high 90's around here with humidity well above the 50% level.  A standard T-shirt with its tight knit collar can become a bit warm due to trapping body heat.  Unbuttoning the Henley collar on this loose-fitting Carhartt shirt allows a little more air circulation for cooling.  It's not Carrier air conditioning cool but it's a help when you're outside in the hot weather.I haven't found another brand of knit cotton shirt with the quality of fabric and fit that compares to Carhartt's Work Wear.  The Henley's expand the styles beyond the traditional T-shirt and I like them a lot.

This is my third pair of Mexico 66s.  I really love these shoes, especially when I can find them at a good price.Why do I like them so much?  First of all, they are a little wider in the toe box than many other athletic shoes.  Since I have wider feet, they fit me more comfortably than the medium width of other companies.  They're not New Balance or Ascis wide but the Onitsuka "medium" is not really narrow like some sneaker brands.  I wear an 11 in street shoes but I take an 11.5 to 12 in sneakers.  With the Onitsukas, I go with a 12 although I think an 11.5 might fit okay.  Twelve is a little too long for my feet but it allows plenty of room for my toes to wiggle around.  I also like the soft, thin leather that quickly conforms to the shape of my foot.  They are comfortable without having a lot of padding or excess material in the upper.  The thin sole contributes to the feeling of being barefoot but it protects the bottom of the foot well.  They offer some arch support but mostly they are flat soled shoes for normal feet.  The insole is glued in place but it could be ripped out and replaced if desired but it would be better to just buy a different shoe if you plan to do that.  These shoes are lightweight and feel insubstantial, however, they seem to handle wear very well.  They also look nice.  These are not overbuilt athletic shoes, they are comfortable everyday sneakers with a retro look.The downside is the price unless you find them at a bargain in your size and an agreeable color.  Amazon has been a good source for me to find Tigers without spending a fortune.  The only other downside I can think of is the fact that the thin sole means some of my pants run a bit long and drag the ground when wearing these shoes.Sometime back in the late 1970s, I had a pair of Adidas Samoas that I dearly loved.  The Mexico 66 shoes remind me of those old Adidas as far as looks and design philosophy.  I have the current Samoas and they are like the originals in name only.  Today's Samoa is made of synthetic leather with a thick, built-up padded sole and thick insole and a huge, ugly toe bumper.  They're not bad shoes but the best Adidas Samoas  you can get today are the Onitsuka Tiger Mexico 66 models.

Fits fine but it's kinda bouncy in my heavy duty truck.  I've replaced it with a model that fits the CD slot and it seems to ride more solidly with less vibration and easier adjustment of the jaws when mounting/dismounting the phone.  This mount is okay and will serve me as a back up.

I was tired of making do when grooming the family dog.  This table works perfectly although it could be just a little taller to accommodate my six feet height.  The table is solid, doesn't budge at all while using it.  The arm works okay but most of the time I don't need to use it.  The texture of the non-slip surface is superb.  It's a heavy table so I usually just leave it set up on the back porch, ready to go.  This is convenient for brushing and combing the dog frequently and it can be folded and put away when necessary.  The material used in the table top seems to be humidity resistant, a good thing since I live in a hot, humid climate.  A great buy for the pet owner who grooms their dogs at home.

I have fairly wide feet and I was pleased to see some non-gaudy sneakers available in wide widths for sale.  I'm cautious, however.  Sizing on today's sneakers is a joke.  Despite these shoes coming in wider widths, I ordered a full size over my normal size just to be sure they would fit.  They didn't.  Not even close.My shoe size is 11EE.  I ordered 12 2E.  Could not get the shoes on my feet.  They looked like a "B" width.  Since I couldn't get the shoes on my feet I cannot tell if the length was anywhere near correct.Do sneaker manufacturers live in an insulated world that doesn't recognize standard sizing?  They sell sports shoes, fer cryin' out loud!  Do pro basketball, football, soccer and baseball players all have narrow width feet?Anyway...these are nice looking shoes that appear to be well made.  Unfortunately, they do not fit the human foot of the size specified.

It doesn't stop our pup from pulling but it does stop choking her when she pulls.When the leash was attached to the two separate points (shoulder and chest rings), our puppy immediately figured out how to defeat the set up by wrapping her front legs around the leash and refusing to walk at all.  We then just used the double leash attached at the shoulder point and let her pull.  At least now she wasn't choking herself and possibly damaging her throat.  Over time, maybe--just maybe--she pulls a little less but that could just be her maturing.  She is, after all, a puppy getting used to walking on the leash.Our dog is a medium sized breed but, being a puppy right now, we got the small size with the intention of buying the medium size if it works okay.  Actually, the small size appears to be the better choice even for an adult of her breed.  As she has grown, we have adjusted the harness and there's still plenty of adjustment left to go.  She is not expected to get much larger than she is now (at seven months) so the small size is probably the best choice.It's a little difficult to adjust the harness to fit properly, especially at the beginning.  Once you figure it out and get it properly adjusted, it fits well and further adjustments are relatively easy.  Our dog is a growing puppy and a few adjustments have been necessary over time.  If your dog is a fidgety little terrier like ours, putting it on can be frustrating since the bottom strap can flip upside down or twist and prevent the clips from attaching.  Pay careful attention and save the frustration.  One thing I like about this harness is that it doesn't tangle the dog's hair as it tightens.  In the past, we've tried other harnesses that would leave the dog's hair tied in knots after every walk due to the movement of the straps.I've found a longer leash works better with our dog than using the double leash included with the harness.  You can, of course, just use the included leash by clipping one end to the harness and one end to the handle, thereby making it double length.  The longer leash thing may just be unique to me and my puppy, however.  I don't do "heel"--I'm not fond of having my dog underfoot when walking and I prefer the dog walk in front.  If that's a bad training technique, so be it.  My dog, my preference.This harness is a little better than just "okay".  I like that my puppy is no longer choking but, really, it hasn't had much effect on her pulling the leash.  I give it 3.5 stars.
Not much to report here.  It fits, it works.  Costs too much for what it is but that's the story on photo accessories.

These are very nice little compacts.  They're not as difficult to use as others I've tried.  The problem I have with compacts is the eyepiece (ocular) lenses are always small with a very narrow beam of light and these eyepieces have to be placed and held directly over the center of the eye.  Higher power compacts such as the 8x21 and 10x21 models are virtually impossible for me to use since that beam of light is even narrower.  The 6.5x Papilios are a bit brighter and easier on my eyes.  To anyone who hesitates due to the lower magnification, don't sweat it.  A 6.5 magnification is pretty decent and it's easier to hold steady, especially compared to 10 power models.  I doubt you'll see much difference between a 6.5x and a 7x.Their claim-to-fame is that the Papilios focus very close, necessary for butterfly and insect watching, but handy also for birding.  Take it from someone who has done birding with the venerable old Leitz Trinovid 10x40 models in the past.  Those binoculars had a "close" focus of about 25 feet and that can be a handicap when birding in deep woodlands.  The old Trinovids were superb for open country but too claustrophobic in tight spaces.To my eyes, the optical quality of the Papilios is just fine.  They're sharp with good contrast and a pleasing color rendition.  These binoculars are lightweight, perhaps a bit too lightly built.  They appear to be all plastic construction with a rubbery gripping surface that allows good handling.  They are small binoculars so that means there's not that many places to put your fingers.  Those with large hands might find them difficult to manipulate until they adjust to this small size.  I was a little surprised at how loose they are.  The focus knob and the body hinge are quite loose and a little bit too easy to adjust, in my opinion.  I'd like these controls to be stiffer so you don't inadvertently change the settings.  Eye relief is just enough for me as an eyeglasses wearer but there's no eye relief to spare.Overall, nice binoculars but I wouldn't want them to be my only binos.  They're not good for low light and they probably won't handle the banging around most binoculars get during normal use.  For those uses you really should have standard size binoculars in your choice of magnification, either porro prism or roof prism.  The Papilios are good for travel, to keep in your vehicle or to back up the main binocular.  As a compact, I really like them.

I've been a big fan of Michael Connelly's Bosch novels for several years and the Amazon production of "Bosch" has won me over.  Well acted and photographed with excellent reference to the Bosch books, there's no real downside to the series.  Television truly has become the home of quality film-making.  Movies today seem to gravitate to action and effects while TV has more excellent scripted dramas than ever before.  "Bosch" is a winner.

Friedlander has been a strong influence of my own photography for the last 40+ years.  These photos allow a look into his family life over time, a more expanded look than his previous book on his family.  This book is also a companion to his recent book of self portraits "In the Picture", another must have.The photos here are expressions of joy and pain and everyday life.  Viewing them makes me feel like a family member (albeit a very distant one) looking through the family album.

I'm a fan of the series so I had to order this shirt considering the low price.  It's a decent T-shirt at a decent price.  Nothing special as far as fabric is concerned--pretty thin, lightweight.  Others advised it runs small so I ordered considerably larger than my normal size to allow for being undersized and for shrinkage.  And it does shrink.  Order large.  If you're really tall, you might want to forego this shirt because it shrinks a lot in length after several washes.  Doesn't fade much and the design doesn't wash out so the size is the only real concern.

Spyderco simply makes excellent knives in a wide range of designs.  The Native Lightweight has a lot going for it as a daily carry--thinner profile than most Spydercos, light in weight and highly useful blade shape and design.  While this is one of the pinned models, there's no reason to fear the design over the screwed-together models.  I own 20+ year old Spydercos that are of the pinned design and they continue to be as tight as the day I bought them despite daily use for a number of years.  This Native model is silky smooth in opening and closing.  It came with a bit of a glitch in the lockup.  It locked tight but the lock bar would catch on the back of the blade tang a little bit.  That resolved with using it and frequently opening and closing it.  It wore in nicely and it's now as perfect a fit as possible.Design-wise, the Native has been around for a long time.  I have an old Native III with a serrated edge.  It's about 10 years old.  It was made in Japan with VG10 blade and a contoured grip instead of the now-standard flat grip design.  It also had one of the early wire clips that I never liked much.  I never used the Native III a lot because I didn't find the serrated edge as useful as a plain edge for everyday tasks.  The contoured grip was also a little to fat in my pocket.  The current Native production is in Golden, Colorado.  The blade steel is now S30V, hollow ground, and the FRN handle is flat with a spiderweb-like Bi-directional grip surface.  Thankfully, the clip is now flat metal instead the original wire design.  One of the features I have always liked about the Native is the swedging of the blade--it looks nice.  The thin profile (compared to most other Spyderco models) doesn't take up a lot of room in my pocket.Of all the Spyderco knives I've owned, the Gayle Bradley and the Dragonfly have been my absolute favorites, both worthy of 5 stars.  I own multiple samples of both models.  I've not owned the Native as long as the other two models but it is proving itself daily.  The size is just about right--smaller, lighter and easier to carry than the Bradley yet larger and capable of a wider range of tasks than the Dragonfly.  There's no reason not to give it 5 stars, even at this early stage of ownership.The only problem is the model has been discontinued.  It is being replaced with the Native 5 Lightweight, a screwed-together design with a full flat ground S35V blade.  The swedge that gives the Native a distinctive and custom look is now sadly gone.  These changes are considered upgrades and I will likely buy one of those as well since the overall design has so much going for it.  However, the standard Native will remain one of my favorites, especially due to the now sadly departed swedging.

I bought both a 7K and 8K to give the Emerson design a try rather than buy one of the expensive Emerson-built folders.  Glad I did because the design does zero for me.  I don't like the disc or the wave opening and the chisel grind on the 8K just sort of escapes me as to the "why?".Kershaw's 8K version is also a disappointment in construction.  The blade is off center and has side-to-side blade play.  Tightening the pivot to center it and stop the side-to-side movement makes it nearly impossible to open.  Not standard Kershaw quality.I've owned several Kershaw models over the years.  Most have been exceptional for the price but not this one.  I wouldn't like it based on the design alone but the poor quality assembly makes it even worse.

Recommended by the mobile RV repair guy who installed them in my driveway.  They seem to be okay...clearly an improvement over the worn out shocks on our RV.  One of the shocks didn't have the fittings enclosed in the box but a trip to the nearby hardware store took care of that.

I couldn't get into this.  Lots of typos and spelling errors as well as more "Me" than Eggleston.  The cover photo is pretty weak and shows signs of deterioration due to poor handling over the years.  Take that as a metaphor for the contents of this book.

ZT overbuilds knives.  This is no exception.  I like it but it's a monster to carry.  Very heavy and thick.  It's a heavy use working knife that should handle just about any job.  Some complain about the recurve shape of the blade being hard to sharpen but I've had no difficulty using a Spyderco Sharpmaker and leather strop mounted on a block of wood.This is not a quick flicking knife although it has a flipper.  The blade's just too thick and heavy to be zip out quickly for those who love flipping their knives around for show.  This is a serious hard use knife.Because of its size and weight, I don't carry it much.  Definitely not an everyday knife but a good knife for its intended use.

It's a little too small for my purposes but it's a well made Spyderco mini knife.  Would fit nicely on a keychain but it's a little difficult to grip and handle when you have large hands.  I like it but doubt I'll ever carry it much due to small size.
Used one of these on our bag to help recognize it when it came off the plane.  It was helpful.  Appears to be well constructed.

Bought this for a recent 5-day trip.  It held up well to airline baggage handling and easily handled all the clothing and accessories both my wife and I needed for the trip.  I didn't need the suit bag that's included so I removed it when packing.  We also did not use the outer pockets since there was more than enough space inside the main compartment. The material and construction seem more than adequate for the task.  Rolls easily and the expandable handle rises to the right length for my six foot height.Since almost every bag you see at airports are black and look similar to this Travelpro, I would suggest attaching some colorful handle covers and maybe a luggage tag with a bright colorful design.  Having done this, it was relatively easy to pick out our bag when it rolled off the carousel at our destination and upon our return.  Without those markers, it would have been frustrating locating our luggage.I can't say how this will hold up to extended use.  Other reviews indicate it's at least average in the durability department.  I'd say it's a really good bag for the price so I give it top marks.

I didn't use the included compound.  Instead I used some green polishing compound of the type I normally use on my knife strops.  The leather used here is not consistent in texture and not of very good quality.  It works okay but it doesn't take compound easily.  When stropping, the knife kind of bumps along.It works okay and it's cheap.  There are better strop blocks available if you shop around.

This is one of the original Spyderco lightweight Clipits.  It was introduced in 1990 and it and the Endura were the knives that really put Spyderco on the road to their success.  I had one of the original models with the molded-in pocket clip and one of the later models that had the screwed on metal pocket clip.  Neither of them were nearly as good as the current Delica 4.  This knife if more ergonomic and better designed, with screwed together construction, a full internal skeletonized steel frame and a longer, grippier handle for better manipulation.  I think the first knives might have been made with different steel but it was soon changed to VG10, an outstanding Japanese super steel at the time.  This knife still uses VG10 and it's still an outstanding steel that resists corrosion, takes a great edge and sharpens relatively easily.  The VG10 is a keeper.Spyderco built knives before the Delica and Endura appeared but nothing really shook up the world of knives like those knives did at the time.  The design was radical with a hole in the blade.  People screamed about how ugly they were, how they lacked a solid steel frame and scoffed that no one would buy them...that they were just a fad that would fade away quickly.  Yeah.  Right.  Spyderco is still with us and so are the Delica and Endura, upgraded through the company's Constant Quality Improvement program.  Where are those critics?  It's not easy to argue with success.Spyderco makes excellent, outstanding knives.  They cost more these days but you get your money's worth.  Except for the fact that I own some of the more deluxe Spyderco models, I would have given this knife 5 stars.  As it is, it's a classic and it easily gets 4.5 stars.

I've only had this knife a short time but it's already competing with my beloved Gayle Bradley folder for pocket time.  And it has won most days.I'm gonna keep this short.  There's been very few criticisms of this knife.  It's consistently one of the most talked about Spyderco knives on internet forums.  It has been in constant short supply for some time now.  The prices have gone up accordingly.It is well made.  The compression lock works well.  The knife fits your hand like a Spyderco.  The S30V blade comes sharp (but mine needed a little stropping) and very "pointy".  The full flat grind is superb for slicing.  The G10 grips feel great and "grippy".  The digital camo design in the semi-translucent handle looks really good (and I usually avoid camo patterns in everything).  It's not heavy but it's well balanced.  The clip is shiny and can be placed for right/left and tip up/down carry.  Fit is typical Spyderco.I still consider the Gayle Bradley folder to be as near perfect as any current pocket knife I've ever used.  But there's no denying the Paramilitary 2 a 5-star rating.  If you're thinking about buying one...just do it.

How did I miss this?  I've used various Spyderco knives since the original Delica/Enduras and I've owned about a dozen of them over the years.  They've been great knives although I've liked some of them better than others.  Somehow I dismissed the Dragonfly as a tiny little toy knife that wasn't worthy of consideration.  Boy, was I wrong.The first thing I noticed when I opened the box was that the Dragonfly 4 was very small and light in weight.  I opened it and immediately realized how well it fit my hand despite the size.  I have kinda large hands, by the way.  Of course Spyderco knives are all about ergonomics and the DF4 is one of the older Spyderco patterns, updated through their Constant Quality Improvement program.  Examining the knife closer I could see how such a small knife felt so much bigger and fit my large hand so well.  It's all in the choil and the choil's placement.  The choil is the half moon cut out halfway in the blade and halfway in the handle.  It's there for your index finger to rest and guide the blade.  Not only does the design and choil placement aid in manipulating and controlling the knife in use, it adds to the overall grip length.  I measured from the front of the choil to the rear of the knife and came up with about 3.75" of usable grip length when the choil is included.  Furthermore, most of that grip length is made up of Spyderco's FRN handle with its bi-directional pattern and ergonomic shape.  Hard to describe but the thing just snugs up to the crease in your palm, sticks there and your fingers fall into the sweet spots without even thinking about it.  Ergonomics.This DF4 has a blade made of ZDP-189 steel.  This is the new super steel that has all the knife knuts going gaga.  I'm no expert on steel but I recall the main characteristic of this steel is the ability to hold a very sharp edge for a very long time while being used very much.  The downside of this is that it requires a lot of time and effort to resharpen once it gets dull.  As stated, I'm no expert on steel and I'm not a steel snob.  This is my first ZDP knife.  I only got the ZDP version of the Dragonfly because it was the cheapest knife available with that option and I wanted to give it a try.  Thus far, I have not used the knife enough to make any judgements.  It's sharp, most knives are these days.  I keep my knives sharp and try to never let them get really dull.  I doubt I will see significant benefits from ZDP but you never know until you've had enough experience.  Simply put, the standard VG10 steel used in Spyderco's Japanese-made knives is excellent and most people would be served just as well and at less cost with a VG10 bladed Dragonfly.This is a great little knife.  I've taken the wire clip off mine because I can't imagine carrying it anywhere except deep in my pocket and I'm no fan of Spyderco's wiggly wire clips.  I love Spyderco's hole in the blade opening but the DF4 is a little difficult for me to manipulate due to its size and the fact that my finger joints aren't as mobile as they once were.  I carry it in my left front pocket and just open it two handed.  If I need a knife and only have one hand available, I usually have another Spyderco clipped in a right hand pocket that's larger and easier opening for an old guy like me.Spyderco says this knife first came about in 1994.  It went under my radar for 20 years but I've spotted it now.  It may be my constant companion from now on.  Easily 4 stars, working toward more.

This is a small but heavily built little knife.  In comparison to the size of the overall knife, the liner and lock bar are massive.  This increases weight but it also adds to the safety of the lock.  It has good quality Chinese steel for the blade material.  Steel snobs will look down on it, knife users will just keep it sharp and use it and not think about steel formulations.  The grip panels are G10.  Nice stuff for holding onto.  You get a real full sized pocket clip instead of a cheap wire clip on this knife--that's a definite plus in my book.What are the negatives?  Not many.  The handle is kind of short for people with big hands and the weight will turn off some people (but not me).  I've noticed the Chinese Spyderco knives (Ambitious, Persistence and Tenacious...and that other one that I can't remember what it's called) tend to be a little less ergonomic than I'm used to with other Spydercos.  It's nothing to really complain about but it would have been nice to have finger choils cut into these knives for a better handling experience.  Compare the Ambitious with the Spyderco Cat G10 model (about the same size knives) and you will find the Cat just feels better and more secure due to its choil.  But the Cat also has comparatively thin liners and a thin lock bar and, overall, feels less a little less well built.The Ambitious is a good little knife at a very good price.  I certainly like it.

I thought I had reviewed the Sharpmaker before now.  I should have.  I've been using either of two models since 1990 and I've never found them to have a single fault.I don't know when Spyderco originally started building the Sharpmaker.  I've read that Sal Glesser, the owner of the company, used to travel around the country to gun and knife shows demonstrating and selling a version of this device long before the company really took off in sales.  My first model was the 203.  I bought it along with a fully serrated Spyderco Delica at a gun and knife show in 1990 and I promptly lost the Delica.  When the next show hit town a few months later, I returned and bought a fully serrated Endura.  The Sharpmaker kept that knife scary sharp for over 10 years of daily use and also worked perfectly for every other knife I owned.  The 203 model only had 40 degree inclusive angles so it was actually of limited use.  Even so, I managed to keep my knives working sharp with it.Along came the 204.  This model has both 30 and 40 degree inclusive angles.  Not only does it enable you to keep your knife sharp, it allows you to reprofile your edge as it wears down with repeated sharpenings.  This is a much better system than the old 203.  My original 203 came with an instruction book.  My 204 came with a VHS videotape.  I understand the current 204 now comes with a DVD.  Plus there are numerous videos online showing how to use the Sharpmaker.  The best ones I've seen are the series made by Sal Glesser himself, demonstrating the various uses of this device.  It's an eyeopening series of demonstrations on what this system can accomplish.While I am able to free hand sharpen okay, the Sharpmaker is so much easier to use I seldom go back to the old methods.  The Sharpmaker is also simple--much simpler than any of the current popular sharpening "systems" available.  I like simple.  The Sharpmaker has no moving parts or clamps to adjust or angles to set.  The only moving part is your hand and the clamping and angles are already adjusted in the device.  Nothing is simpler in design save for a single whetstone but the whetstone requires a learning curve and good hand/eye coordination.  After a little experience with the Sharpmaker, most people find it remarkably easy to work with.  And today you can buy both diamond rods and ultrafine ceramic rods to augment the standard medium and fine ceramic rods that come with the Sharpmaker.  This allows you to reprofile an edge or repair a damaged edge with the diamonds and to put a very fine polish on finished sharp edge with the ultrafine stones.  Most people can do just fine with the standard rods that come with the Sharpmaker, however.  Personally, I have those extra rods but I usually just use the medium and fine ones and finish with a strop to polish the edge.The more expensive sharpening systems will get you a sharp knife faster.  No argument there.  Using whetstones freehand can be very satisfying.  Agreed.  But the Sharpmaker is an outstanding tool when you want something combining simplicity with effectiveness and cost.  It's just about perfect.

There are no real down sides to this knife.  I've owned several molded, unlined FRN handled Spyderco knives and they have held up well to hard use.  The Stretch is fully lined with skeletonized stainless steel, so it should be even stronger.  The bi-directional texture on the FRN handle is very grippy and, as usual, Spyderco puts a functional grip shape on the knife that conforms to the hand.  The blade steel is Spyderco's standard Japanese VG10.  This is an outstanding steel and my personal favorite.  It's easy to sharpen but holds an edge very well under normal use.  It's very resistant to staining and rusting.  As usual, Spyderco provides the knife with excellent sharpness although the edge on mine shows deep machining marks.  This is simply cosmetic and it does not detract from use whatsoever.  The flat grind and relatively thin blade makes for a great slicer.  The Stretch uses a solid hourglass shaped clip that can be positioned for four methods of carrying.  Thank you, Spyderco, for not subjecting us to another knife with the cheap and flimsy wire clip.The Stretch has been around a long time.  The design apparently is a favorite of Sal Glesser, the owner of Spyderco.  The blade carries his stylized "SAL" signature.  It is made in Japan and there is nothing to complain about anywhere in the materials or manufacture of this knife.  I read the review about a "warped" blade but I don't understand the terminology.  Blades can be bent or twisted or, in cutlery terminology, "crinked" to fit properly but I've never heard the term "warped" used in regard to blade steel.  The blade in my sample of the Stretch was perfectly centered and had no contact with the liners.  Opening and closing was smooth although a bit stiff at first.  This loosened up with use and the Stretch now glides open.I'm a huge fan of the Spyderco Gayle Bradley and the Stretch shares the same drop point blade shape design and general overall look.  Both the Bradley and the Stretch feel good to hold but the Bradley is heavier in the handle which makes it better balanced in my opinion.  But the steel liners in the Stretch help it to have a good balance and the shape of its grip will probably feel better to most users who are familiar with Spyderco knives.  The Stretch is not as perfect as the Bradley but it's really good and a good solid user knife.

I'm an admitted knife aficionado.  I love all types of knives and I own quite a few.  Among modern folding, one hand opening knives, the Spyderco brand totals more models than all the others in my collection.  I've used Spyderco knives since the beginning of their Clipit model introduction nearly 25 years ago.  Spyderco knives always offer high quality and excellent value, even though the prices of their knives have increased a good deal over the years.  As a hedge on increased production costs, Spyderco came out with their Byrd brand of Chinese made knives several years ago and many people discovered that a knife made in China did not always have to be poorly made of poor quality materials.  As time has progressed, Spyderco has continued to have knives made for them in China and the company now uses their original company name on some of these models as well as retaining the Byrd line.The Persistence is one of four related knives in their Spyderco brand value line.  The others are the Ambitious, the Tenacious and the Resilience.  The Persistence is the medium/small model, measuring 4.125" closed with a 2.75" blade, G10 grip panel and a Walker liner lock.  The blade steel is 8Cr13MoV, a very good quality Chinese stainless steel that can take a very sharp edge and can be resharpened fairly easily.  The blade shape is that frequently used by Spyderco "leaf" design with a slight drop point.  It comes with pretty nice blade jimping for the thumb but no blade choil for the index finger.  Cutting edge is the full 2.75" length of the blade.  The 4 inch plus length of the handle provides enough space to get a good handle on the knife for control.  The pocket clip is one of Spyderco's hourglass shaped models in bright silver and it a four position design.  The pocket clip looks really nice and contrasts with the black G10 panels.  The blade is 3mm thick which is pretty thick for such a short blade.  The liner and locking bar is also fairly thick which gives the knife a substantial feeling that I personally like.  It feels like this knife can stand up to anything for which you would use a short 2.75" blade.I have no real complaints against this knife.  It's well made of good quality material and the fit and finish is really good.  Since it's in the same size category as the much more expensive Sage 1, I really feel like it's fair to compare these knives.  They may likely be put to the same types of uses.  The Sage has a 3" blade that is 3mm thick and a 4.188" handle, making it a little longer than the Persistence.  The blade steel is S30V a deluxe US-made stainless although the knife itself is made and assembled in Spyderco's Taichung, Taiwan, factory.  The blade design is the leaf shape and it has a choil integrated half into the blade and half into the handle where the index finger rests comfortably.  Jimping is present in the spine where the thumb is placed.  The cutting edge measures 2.265".  The Sage handle is a carbon fiber overlay to a G10 layer underneath.  The carbon fiber really looks outstanding and offers an excellent wear resistance and grip surface, a surface that's not as abrasive as bare G10.  Spyderco uses their wire pocket clip for the Sage 1 which I think is a mistake because it looks cheap and flimsy and only allows tip up carry although it can be changed from right to left hand with a single screw.  The Sage 1 incorporates the same Walker liner lock design as the Persistence, however, the liner and locking bar of the Sage 1 is a bit thinner than the Persistence.  Despite the thinner metal, the Sage lock up feels secure.The things I like better about the Persistence over the Sage 1 are the thicker, sturdier liner lock, the better quality and more adaptable pocket clip and the cutting edge that is a half inch longer than that of the Sage despite the Persistence's blade being one quarter inch shorter in overall length.  The Persistence also costs $36--almost 1/3 less than the Sage.The things I like better about the Sage 1 are the carbon fiber panels for appearance and blade choil for ergonomics.  The Sage looks better and actually feels much better in the hand.  The Sage also uses more expensive deluxe steel for the blade (although it should be pointed out that S30V will require more effort to sharpen if you let the knife get dull or you damage the edge).  Those improvements make the knife worth the extra cost in my opinion, however, the Sage 1 currently sells on Amazon for $102--2.8 times the cost of the Persistence.When considering a knife that will be put to a lot of use, a knife that likely will get beaten up and come out with scars, a knife that needs frequent sharpening, the Persistence compares very favorably with the Sage 1.  It's built heavier with a blade that is easier to sharpen.  It doesn't cost a lot and can be replaced painlessly should the user lose it or manage to break it.  It doesn't have the excellent ergonomics of the Sage 1 but the Persistence is entirely useable without any really significant limitations.  It's hard to overlook the value of the Persistence.  It's a good high quality working knife that one might buy and consider disposable if necessary.  It lacks the refinements of the Sage but it gives up nothing in practical use.
