I personally consider the Sage 1 as just short of perfection in a modern folder of its size, however, I really like the Persistence and I have to say I like it just about as much based on a completely different set of criteria.

I'm leaning more and more toward smaller (but not too much smaller) knives so the Sage series got my attention.  The resemblance of the carbon fiber laminate handle to the Spyderco Gayle Bradley was the first thing I noticed.  After buying the knife, I have to say it is a damn nice knife in the 3" blade category.  Overall, the Sage I is pretty close to perfect but not quite as perfect as the Gayle Bradley model, in my opinion.What you get in the Sage I is a knife with a 3 inch blade and a well designed 4 inch plus handle that makes it easy to use.  The blade is Spyderco's leaf shape in S30V steel.  S30V is one of the "super steels" that is now ubiquitous in upper quality modern folding knives.  The steel is no longer the shining star of super steels but it's still got a good glow going for edge retention with just a little extra effort needed in resharpening.  In my opinion, there are lots of good steels in use today and all of them are excellent with not enough difference in performance to really make much difference for the average knife buyer.  As is usual with Spyderco knives, the Sage I came nice and sharp.  I ran it over a stop with some green polishing compound and this resulted in an even sharper edge.  Can't complain.  For anyone who buys a really nice knife, you should know the trick to retaining a razor sharp edge is to never let the knife get dull to begin with.  After using it, touch up the edge on a hard Arkansas or ceramic stone and then strop it.  You will be rewarded with a contantly sharp knife.  If you let the edge dull or you damage the edge, you can expect to spend a good bit of time with S30V steel to return the edge to razor sharpness.The handle has a good ergonomic shape and the panels are made of a carbon fiber layer laminated over a layer of G10.  This makes for a great feeling grip that looks incredible.  It's the same material used in the Gayle Bradley and I believe I said in my review of that knife that the carbon fiber looks "just lovely".  Ditto here.  Fit and finish is about as good as it gets.  Spyderco's Taichung Taiwan facility is well known for their superior craftsmanship and they certainly deserve praise for this model.The Sage I uses a liner lock.  Liner locks and frame locks are sort of "in" right now and that's okay--they work well if they are well designed and well matched to the blade.  Here is the first point that knocks the Sage I out of the perfect category.  The liner on the knife is fairly thin and, correspondingly, the locking bar is also pretty thin.  On a smaller knife, it's not necessary to have a massive liner with massive lock bar like that on the Gayle Bradley (damn... I can't stop bringing up that knife!) but I really wish Spyderco had increased the thickness of the steel liner in the Sage by about 50%.  This would make the locking bar a little heftier and rigid and I, for one, wouldn't mind the extra weight.  It's not as thin and flexible as the Cat G10 liner lock bar but the Sage liner could stand improvement.  I can detect just the tiniest amount of movement in the Sage's lock after lock up.  But the blade on the Sage has zero movement on lock up, unlike my copy of the Cat G10.  I'm probably nit picking about the liner and lock bar since it actually seems pretty solid.  Unlike the Gayle Bradley (there I go again!), it's easy to access the lock bar release with the thumb of the dominant hand.  This should appease the inveterate blade flippers out there.My only other nit to pick on the Sage I is the wire clip.  I've criticized Spyderco's use of wire clips before and I continue to dislike them.  They look cheap, especially when used on knife that costs over a hundred bucks, and they don't feel as secure as Spyderco's other flat metal clips.  The clip on my Sage I moves around side-to-side when applying light finger pressure.  That's just wrong for a knife this expensive.In summation, I rate the Sage I as a 4.5 star knife.  I admit I'm getting more and more critical of items I review and most people who buy the Sage will totally love it.  Not perfect but worth every penny you pay for it.

This is a first impression based on limited operation of the Epson WF 3620.  I have experience with Epson based on my ownership for about two years of the wonderful Stylus Photo R3000.  If the WF 3620 continues functioning as reliably and with output quality comparable to the R3000 (as a standard printer as opposed to a photo printer), I will be a most happy camper.The WF 3620 is a standard size printer/scanner/fax/copier for small office or home use.  The quality of Epson prints are excellent and the printer appears to be very robust in construction.  Setup was simple and pretty frustration free.  I must admit I'm not very much attuned to technology so it's nice when a process is kept simple.  I'm using the printer with a standard USB connection although it can be run with Wi-Fi.  No problems are encountered with operation this way and, since the printer is located adjacent to the computer, there's no overriding reason to go wireless.  I have not yet set up the fax.  I don't really have much use for the fax feature so it's not a priority.  The other functions are working fine.Since I've only had limited experience with this printer, I can't say how it will perform in the long term.  I expect it to work fine, given my past experience with Epson.  Unless something unforeseen happens, I can recommend it.

I received this in exchange for an honest review.I had been using another wireless mouse, but it was not working very consistently, so I decided to give this one a try. First of all, let me say that if you use a laptop and you use a mouse with a wire, or you use the trackpad, wireless is the way to go. It is much faster than the trackpad, and it is much less bother than the wire.So this one seems to work more smoothly than my previous one, and I am very happy with it. The ergonomics are great. My only complaint is that it came in a box with no instructions or explanation, and a new user might not know to look for a little usb thingy that you plug into your computer to send the signal for this. I did know, but I looked all over the place, in the box, in the shipping bag, and in the trash, looking for that small little device. Then I opened up the battery compartment to put the batteries in, and there it was! Maybe everybody but me knows that little parts are hidden in the battery compartment, but I didn't know that, and it caused me confusion.But once I got that straightened out, I am very happy with this product. Note to tech companies: people don't always know as much about your product as you do. Try to tell them, in plain English and size 12 font, what is going on!

I have a weird interest in reading about diseases, and this book is one of the very best in the genre. Quammen writes for National Geographic, and he goes *everywhere.* If there was a disease outbreak in the Central African Republic in 1987, chances are, he has interviewed the doctor who first spotted the disease, the locals whose family members died, and the BSL-4 researchers in Virginia who analyzed it, and he probably also climbed down into a cave where the bat that spreads the disease roosts. This book is better than The Hot Zone. It dispels some of the over-blown language used in that book (people do not dissolve inside from Ebola.) and it is arguably just better writing.Quammen keeps the balance between travel and adventure writing on the one hand, personal interviews (of the "His desk is piled high with papers, and he's wearing blue corduroy slacks and a black turtleneck and wire-rim glasses" type), and real science writing. You learn a lot about diseases from the microscopic level to the human story of what it's like to have the disease, to the incredible courage and dedication of the people who fight the diseases, whether in the clinic or in the lab.Realistically, most of us are at essentially zero risk of dying of Ebola, but Quammen balances that with insight into things that might really harm us--SARS, AIDS, and the good old flu, which could still come roaring back as a killer.I was sorry when it ended.

Whether you will like this or not depends on your needs. It is large--about the size of a deck of cards, I'd say. The digits are large. You can read it from across the room. It is loud! If you are two rooms away when it goes off, and you have the tv on, you will probably still hear it. So it sort of has the feel of a product designed for the elderly. But if you are elderly, or impaired in any way, or simply like your technology loud and proud, this is a great product. However, if you want something subtle, maybe use it as a meditation timer, or in a classroom setting, no, this will not be your best choice. For me and my husband, who has a hearing impairment, it is a great choice.

The back cover says "Up In the Air" meets "Inception" I will add, yes that, plus Kafka's "The Castle." I enjoyed this very much. His descriptions of the blandness and soothingness of hotels and the sameness of conventions and conferences is spot-on. And the writing is extremely well-done--I was struck by this phrase: "the underachieving light of a failed afternoon." There are many such tiny gems.At the same time, the two references mentioned above are both films, and yes, this is very cinematic. I can very easily imagine it as a movie. At the same time, it is a psychological thriller of a sort, and also a meditation on the meaning of life and the emptiness of much that passes for modern life, especially global business life. Also, at times, he exactly captured the feeling of many bad dreams--you try to run, but your legs feel like sausages, nothing works, nothing is where it should be. The science-fiction elements worked for me.Was the final outcome completely satisfying? Maybe not. But by then he had me in the palm of his hand.

I received one of these for free in exchange for an honest review. Unfortunately, I cannot give it a very positive review. I have a battery-powered skin-cleansing tool already, and I thought this one might be something new, different and better. It is different--the brush is super plush and super soft--it feels like velvet, and the individual bristles are extremely fine. And the vibration is extremely fast and gentle.The net result is that it feels like nothing on your skin! It is so gentle that it doesn't feel to me like it will have any effect. A brush against your skin cannot pull anything out of your pores, so the only way I can see for a product like this to work is if it removes a layer of dead skin cells and thus opens up your pores. But this seems far too gentle to have any effect--like scrubbing your face with velvet! If you have very smooth clear sensitive skin, and other scrubbers are too rough for you, you could try this one.The price is very low. The packaging has no explanation of anything on it. You have to figure out how to open it, and you have to provide your own AAA battery. The look is very sleek and sturdy. But I would not buy it.

Wallace does an excellent of making this journey come alive, and he raises the very questions that haunted me while and after reading the book: what, exactly, is the point of traveling deep into the jungle set aside for uncontacted tribes of Amazonian Indians? The journey was grueling, and extremely dangerous, and any contact with the tribal people would have possibly deadly consequences for the uncontacted people as well--so why walk right into areas they are known to live? One man on the expedition actually walked through a village of Indians. The risk to both sides (searchers and those hiding from them) seems out of proportion to what is learned--yup, they're still there! And yes, their lands are threatened by others who search for oil, lumber, and other commodities. But bringing men from other tribes, semi-Brazilianized Indians who themselves are only a generation or so from uncontacted status seemed to me like asking for trouble. Still, a great read! It is fascinating to realize that there are people alive on the planet today who have not yet learned to use bows and arrows, and club their enemies (and prey) to death. The bow and arrow is pretty basic technology--how can they not have gotten the hang of it? And why do they succumb so dreadfully to common germs? Are we all walking germ-dispensers? It's a puzzle to me. They live in an environment we would find absolutely forbidding, and yet they are so vulnerable. And so easily tempted by aluminum pots and machetes.
I received this as a free sample. I took it for several weeks. It tastes very good. But I do not thinkit is of any help in losing weight. I have no way to judge if it had any other health effects.

I bought this for the knitted-animal patterns, and since it was very inexpensive, I am satisfied. The patterns are: a simple doll's body, a sheep, a horse, a chicken, a pig, a cat, a donkey, and a duck. These are highly simplified shapes, meant to evoke a child's imagination. They are not realistically detailed. Many of the other toys are also very simple, such as a piece of wood hand-carved to make a doll's chair.

The first thing that needs to be said is that the writing here is first-rate. Ellen Feldman can evoke character and place and a time period as well as anyone. And the time period she evokes is the time just before I was born, and thus the backdrop to my childhood, things I heard and half-understood. (The story begins in 1948; My parents married in 1949 and I was born in 1952, But her milieu--upper-class, literate, Jewish Manhattan--is a long way from mine --Irish-Catholic working class small city.) The narrative begins on November 22, 1963, which of course is the day Kennedy was killed, and then goes back to fill in the context. This date feels highly significant to the story, but unlike Chekhov's gun, as far as I could tell, it was never actually used.While the Cold War and the Red Scare and the CIA is background, the story is not really about them. It is about a marriage, and a woman's perception of it. IN the end, I felt that was both the story's strength and weakness. I expected it to be, and it is set up to be, a political story, but in the end, it really isn't.And while her writing is Feldman's greatest strength, I also felt that she took a short-cut in having a different narrator untangle much of the unwittingness that is the basis of the story. A found diary is a clunky way to present a different point of view, and it broke my willing suspension of disbelief.I did enjoy reading, and I think it's an excellent evocation of the time and place, and of a marriage. But there's something fundamentally disjointed about it.

The narrative style in this novel is great. Cassella pulls you in and maintains a clear and engaging story-line. The writing is confident and professional. My only qualm about the book is that it rambles too much. Two interlocking stories that take a long while to intersect, and once they do, the dual narratives become a little hard to follow. Some of the subplots don't seem to be organic to the story. And the twin aspect of it, which I expected to be a major part don't come into play until the very end, and even then, it's not actually a twin. But I enjoyed reading the story and it kept my interest to the very end.

I received this as a free sample in exchange for a review. I am eliminating carbs from my diet, and I miss having spaghetti to top with yummy meatballs. I previously bought a vegetable-peeler type juliener, and have used it quite a few times to turn zucchini into "zoodles." So I was eager to try this.The packaging is excellent. Also, the design is sleek, but the metal pieces on the sides, which look like they might be some sort of cutting blades are actually handles. That seems like a misstep, because they are actually a little sharp. I used it for the first time today, and it's very easy to use. You insert the zucchini in the top and turn it like a pencil sharpener. A hint: press the zucchini to one side, not centered as you would do with an actual pencil sharpener, to maintain the most smooth contact with the cutting edge. There is less waste than with the previous type I used, and what's left comes out as a neat little "cob." It takes less pressure and is all-around neater and more efficient.However--the end product was long continuous slivers of zucchini, and after I cooked it up, I found it a little hard to eat. INstead of  6-8" segments of "zoodle" there is yards of it! So you have to bite through the noodles. A minor point, but worth a mention. Next time I might cut the noodles into a more manageable length.Would this work with other vegetables, other than zucchini and summer squash? I don't know. Carrots are a lot harder than zucchini and I haven't tried them.Along with this, I received a free gift of a round device that slices vegetables into decorative designs. It looked like an asthma inhaler, and there were no instructions, so I had to email the company to figure out how to use it. There's a button in the center that you rotate sideways and then use it as a lever to turn the blades. Until I figured it out, I felt that the design was very dangerous, because there are sharp teeth that I thought I had to use to move it from one position to the other. Anyhow, they need to include instructions!If you want to cut carbs, this is a worthwhile tool. (I would not call it a HULK, nor a pasta maker.)

I received one of these for free in exchange for an honest review. Unfortunately, I cannot give it a very positive review. I have a battery-powered skin-cleansing tool already, and I thought this one might be something new, different and better. It is different--the brush is super plush and super soft--it feels like velvet, and the individual bristles are extremely fine. And the vibration is extremely fast and gentle.The net result is that it feels like nothing on your skin! It is so gentle that it doesn't feel to me like it will have any effect. A brush against your skin cannot pull anything out of your pores, so the only way I can see for a product like this to work is if it removes a layer of dead skin cells and thus opens up your pores. But this seems far too gentle to have any effect--like scrubbing your face with velvet! If you have very smooth clear sensitive skin, and other scrubbers are too rough for you, you could try this one.The price is very low. The packaging has no explanation of anything on it. You have to figure out how to open it, and you have to provide your own AAA battery. The look is very sleek and sturdy. But I would not buy it.

I received a sample of this oil in exchange for an honest review. This is the most intense lavender scent of any lavender essential oil I have ever used. It seems to be highly volatile, which means that molecules of lavender essence are readily emitted and enter into your body. Even though the bottle was sealed and wrapped in bubble wrap, the scent permeated the mailer. I cannot verify whether it has better healing properties than other lavender, but it does seem more intense. I will enjoy using this very much.

This book is three linked short stories--three separate cases in which the Yarn Woman, who is a sort of Sherlock Holmes type character, who can deduce a person's height, weight, and hobbies from seeing his cast off sweater, helps solve a mystery. There is an intriguing bit of magical realism mixed in--not everyone in the story is actually a living human being!  The fiber knowledge aspects of the story work well for me, as a fiber-lover. But I think the stories would have a wide appeal. These are not typical knitting-cozy-mysteries at all. They are more adventurous and unusual than that genre. I found them quite captivating.

Some folks just don't want to believe this, that fat could possibly be better for you than whole grains. But I think Nina Teicholz has done a remarkable job of showing just how weak the evidence for low-fat eating ever was. The old common-sense view was that "starchy food" made poor people obese. That was overthrown, and instead red meat and full-fat became the bad guy that everyone just "knows" is bad for you.But at the same time that Americans, on an overall, statistical basis, have been eating fewer eggs, less whole dairy, less red meat, more grains, and more fresh vegetables, we have also been becoming more obese. This is a fact that no amount of nit-picking can deny. We have all seen it with our own eyes, if we have lived long enough (I am 62.) The counter-argument is that the low-fat diet hasn't been rigorous enough. We just all need to eat more kale.But the fact is that humans need 1500-2000 calories per day, and you cannot get that from leafy greens. You have to get adequate calories either from a lot of carbs, or from meat, dairy, and eggs.This idea is never mentioned in her book, but it led me to wonder if the autism epidemic could be related to the low-fat diets of women before they get pregnant. while they are pregnant, during lactation (she does mention that breast milk is changed in women who eat little fat), in baby formulas, and in young weaned children. Brains need fat, and is it possible that those who obey the culture's demonization of fat the most, conscientious middle to upper-middle-class women, are actually harming their children. It is a fact that autism is more prevalent in upper socioeconomic levels of society. The only correlation that doesn't fit is the gender variation, but I don't know of any possible cause for autism that would explain why it's more boys than girls. Maybe their brains just needed more fat.There is no need to posit a "conspiracy"--Nina explains how well-meaning people with no axes to grind could come to believe weak to bad science. It is now accepted that hydrogenation of oils into fats turned out to be a mistake, again with no intentional bad guys.  Crisco and margarine were touted as health foods, purer than animal fat, but pretty much everyone from the FDA on down now concedes that they are certainly worse than oil. Total cholesterol was also once seen as conventional wisdom's bad guy, which later was revised to "good" cholesterol and "bad" cholesterol. Mistakes, serious long-term ones, can and do happen in science, and if opposing views are suppressed, they can remain unchallenged as consensus for a long time.I'm putting my money and my mouth on plenty of leafy greens topped with plenty of fatty meat and butter, and I went out and bought some lard ("manteca") at the Hispanic market near me, to experiment with cooking without corn oil.

This may be more  background info on the philosophical origins of deism and what it really meant to people at the time than you want, but if you're tired of Christians trotting out quotes from Ben Franklin, Thomas Jefferson, or George Washington that make them sound like evangelicals, you should make the effort to get through this.The writing is clear and fairly snappy, but the author traces every line of the intro to the Declaration of Independence back to the ancient Greek philosophers--Why "we hold these truths to be self-evident"? Who is this "Creator" who endowed us with rights? What does "the pursuit of happiness" mean?It turns out that "Nature and Nature's God" might just mean "nature," and deism is more or less the equivalent of atheism, in his parsing. And it turns out that Ethan Allen was quite a revolutionary indeed, and in fact all the founding fathers were trying not just to separate from the British motherland, but to create a whole new sort of society, never seen before in political history.Well worth the effort.

I am not a believer in Tibetan Buddhism, though I am interested and positively inclined towards the Tibetan people. I read this book because it popped up after I read another book about the concept of the terton, a "treasure finder" who magically discovers scrolls, statues and revelations. The previous book was so credulous that I couldn't take it seriously, but I found this book much more interesting because the writer maintains a somewhat skeptical stance towards the things he is told.Thomas Shor interviewed dozens of people who had first-hand experience following a guru who claimed that he could gain them entrance into a beyul, a concept of an earthly paradise on which Shangri-la  in Lost Horizon s a somewhat bastardized version. The concept is not unlike western religious believers who sell everything they own and wait on a mountain-top for the Second Coming--and so far have always come away disappointed, though usually still believing. These Tibetan folks also got "close" to their promised land after walking away from all their earthly possessions, but their take-away seemed even more positive than that of let-down followers of Christian prophets. They seemed forever changed by even approaching the entrance (high on a glacial mountain) to a land of perfect comfort and earthly attainment.Not everyone will enjoy the story, but I did and so I recommend it if you have a somewhat skeptical but open mind towards Tibetan supernatural events.

I found this tedious and in the end I just skimmed to get to the conclusion. I enjoy knitting, and mysteries, and cooking, so I expected to like it, but the narrative was poorly done and the set-up works badly, in my opinion. The set-up is that Casey is in charge of running a Sheep to Shawl retreat, but she doesn't really know anything about sheep, or shearing them, or spinning, or even knitting beyond garter stitch. This is handy for the author, since it gives her a reason not to actually *describe* any of these activities. To me, this ruins the whole concept of a "knitting mystery." As a knitter (and potential spinner) I choose a novel like this in order to enjoy the imaginative experience of the shearing, the prepping, the spinning, and the knitting. All of that is missing--the retreat center declares sheep-shearing off-limits, so they just pick up some already shorn fleeces, and then everything else along the way is sort of skimmed over as well.In addition, the main narrative drive is that Casey is running here and there, making and delivering cupcakes, baking desserts for various establishments, and having unpleasant conversations with several different people--all of which was just tiresome to read. Casey was stressed throughout the weekend, since she didn't know what she was doing, and ready about someone's stress-filled life is just not enjoyable to me!Also, the book seemed not to know what genre is was supposed to be--is this a mystery or a romance novel? As much time was spent on Casey's complicated attractions to a couple of different guys (or lack of attraction, in some cases.) At times it felt more like a set-up for a romance novel than a mystery.And then there were some details that were just unpleasant--an ongoing "joke" about the fact that Casey's cat like canned tuna cat food, which is referred to over and OVER again as "stink fish." I'm sorry, but those are just unpleasant words. There was also a plot detail about moldy, mildewed clothing. Again, when I read about stink fish and mildew smells, and then about eating cupcakes on the same page, it is unpleasant. Not cozy!In the end, the pay-off was just not worth it. And the pattern for a shawl with no picture or sketch of what it will look like is not enticing either.

I received a free sample of this product to try and review. I am very pleased with it. It is a clay-based skin mask, so the color is naturally a bit odd--a sort of greyish green color. I like that no unnatural coloring is used to "mask" the color of the clay. There is a touch of eucalyptus in the formula, which gives a very mild tingle. The product is very nearly odorless, again a sign of its all-natural ingredients. I smoothed it on with my fingers and it has a nice texture and goes on easily. As it dried, it seemed to sink right into my skin and disappear, unlike other clay-based masks that end up looking like an old clay pot! After washing my face with warm water, the product came off readily, with no need to scrub it away.And the result? My skin feels soft, smooth, and yes, refreshed! The jar is generously sized, and I think the price is quite fair. I am 62 and have skin that is dry in spots but still oily and prone to whiteheads around my nose, and this product is very useful for me. I will gladly continue using it, and I am glad the maker approached me and asked me to try it.

It's hard to know how to rate this book. It is probably really excellent for what it is, but what it is is not suitable reading for most people. This is the life story of a Tantric mystic who lived in Tibet in the 19th and early 20th century (died 1926). His claim to fame is that he was a revealer of hidden (physical) treasures, such as statues and scrolls that had been hidden by the founder of Tibetan Buddhism a thousand years before. The problem with reading the book, as a general reader who is interested in and sympathetic towards Tibet, but not a believer, is that the book takes all his wonders at face value. And I just can't. It seems to me that he must have been some sort of a magician, in the sense of fooling the eye. He opens holes on granite walls and pulls out statues. I cannot just take that as a fact. Also, there are many many names and rituals included in the book, and unless one is deeply familiar with Tibetan Buddhism, you cannot take it all in.What is valuable about this book is that it gives a view of Tibetan Buddhism from the inside, as it is experienced by Tibetan people. The world is filled with demons and spirits, many of them malicious, and one has to overpower them and bring them into subjection to Buddhism. It's easy to see the Dalai Lama's benign countenance and forget that this is the underside of Tibetan thinking.I find it puzzling, however, that people who are not from that background of belief, people for whom the world is not seething with demonic spirits and guardians of sacred landscapes would imbibe that view and pass it along as fact. My understanding of the end goal of Buddhism, including the Tibetan variety, is to come to understand that all these demonic forces are in fact just illusions created by one's own mind, and that conquering demons is done by recognizing their non-existence. For people steeped in an animist world-view, living in an extreme environment and always under threat from outsiders, it makes sense to incorporate their view into Buddhism. But for people from a materialist, rationalist, critical-thinking background, it makes no sense to me to first submerge in the animist worldview, and then attempt to overcome it. And that's what this book (and this author) seems to do. There is no common-sense or rationalist explanation for any of what Terton Sogyal is supposed to have done. The story is told entirely from within a Tibetan point of view.The author spent 15 years writing this book, visiting all the sacred places and learning from a person who is believed to be a reincarnation of Sogyal. I simply couldn't enter into the point of view that he espoused, and unless you are already deeply immersed in Tibetan studies, I doubt if you will be able to either.

Longer than a magazine article, but shorter than a book, this is a great example of how and why digital publishing makes sense, despite the author's complaints in the Op-Ed pages of the NY Times. I ordered it after reading his essay, and I enjoyed reading it. I don't accept his premise that he was somehow cheated when his e-publisher went under--at least with amazon, he could publish it himself and find an audience. Which he has!The story is fascinating at times, with descriptions of the hellish landscape that an oil boomtown creates. It is also a little boring at times, as it is as much a travelogue as an expose. He does do a good job of presenting the unvarnished opinions of people on both sides of the controversy--yes, the pipeline creates jobs, and yes, we need the oil to keep our economy going, but also, yes, it makes a hideous mess, even if it works exactly as intended with no leaks, and yes, it may be hastening climate change, which might make our other problems all pale by comparison.I'm sure that if we had lived in Birmingham England or rural New England in the 17th century, we would also have been appalled at the lovely landscape being marred by industry--the industry that makes modern life possible.Or is this a whole different order of damage, not only aesthetic but ultimately destructive on a scale that is hard to imagine? Most of the people who stand to benefit, short-term, can't bear to even ask that question. If we don't take the oil out of the ground, someone else will, they reason. And that is true.Thought-provoking as well as readable. A nice piece of work.

I keep up fairly well with research in the field of psychology and learning in particular, so much of this information was not entirely new and surprising to me, but Benedict Carey does a great job of pulling a lot of different research together and presenting it a practical way. This is more a guide to what is known than a self-help book, but it will definitely be of use both to teachers and students who want to understand how to study more effectively.A couple of take-aways--half-forgetting and then re-learning, especially by trying to remember, make the thing you are trying to learn really stick. So as a teacher, when I start class on Monday and ask students to recall what it was we were working on last Friday, that is not just review--that is learning. It would be best, I suppose, if instead of asking the whole class and letting one or two students do the hard work, I had everyone try their best to write down what the remember about passive voice or the subjunctive.That brings up another great point that he makes--that testing, quizzing, and self-testing are highly effective ways not of evaluating but of actually learning. This helps to overcome what he calls the Fluency Illusion, and what I have long called the "smile-and-nod" level of understanding. IN other words, when the teacher is doing math problems on the board and you are watching, you understand--you smile and nod and think, ok, yeah, sure, I get it. It is only when the tables are turned and the teacher says, Ok, now you try it, that the gaps in understanding are revealed.So if you are studying for a test on state capitals, let's say, and you see Georgia: Atlanta, you think right, sure. But it's not until someone says Georgia and you can say Atlanta that you actually know it. And each time you test yourself, or have someone else test you, you are retrieving and then re-storing that memory, making it more salient. I would go so far as to suggest that one difference between middle-class kids and poor kids in school is that middle-class parents often quiz their kids on their school-work. "Let's go over those state capitals together," and less-educated parents probably don't. That could be enough to make a big difference, since this is such a powerful learning tool.He also reports on interesting work on how location and distraction can help rather than hurt our learning--studying in a variety of places, with varying amounts of distraction can help us remember more. And spaced practice works better than intense practice. IN other words, if you have one hour to learn the capitals of all the countries in Europe, or the parts of the hand, it would be better to do 3 20-minute sessions, especially if you sleep between at least two of the sessions, than to do all 60 minutes at once. And what about cramming? We don't really need research to tell us this, but yes, it works if your only goal is to pass the test, but if you actually want to learn the material, it is worthless. You forget it as fast as you "learned" it.One great point to this book is that he covers widely diverse fields of study--from physical skills like a golf swing or a tennis serve, to complex skills like flying a plane, to rote memorization, such as vocabulary or state capitals., to comprehension of difficult concepts like economics or physics. Many of the techniques he describes apply across the board, and others are more particular to certain types of learning. For example, for physical performance (a piano recital or a baseball tryout, you do better if you sleep in a bit, getting plenty of the kind of sleep that occurs towards morning. For memory like a vocabulary test, it's better to get plenty of the early-stage sleep, so go to bed on time and get up early in the morning to review. Your brain does a lot of memory consolidation while you sleep, and specific types in specific stages.One point that he doesn't directly address but that I am familiar with the research on is whether it's better to memorize large things as a whole or in chunks. For example, if you are an actor, or you want to memorize a long poem or speech, should you work on the first sentence, and then the second sentence, and so on, or should you go through the whole thing each time. The answer is that you should do it whole--it will feel like you're not getting anywhere at first, but suddenly, the whole thing will be in there This fits with what he says about inter-leaving---practicing a variety of different things in each session rather than chunking it all together--master skill A before moving on to skill B. No, it's better to do some A, some B, and some C, even though it will feel like you aren't making progress at first.I recommend this book to every teacher of any subject, and to anyone who is a student at any level, and to parents, who worry that their kids are too distracted and unfocused in the way they study--turns out that distraction and lack of focus can serve you well!

I feel that this novel had the potential to be a great story, but the narrative is not well-handled. The story begins on V-J Day, but then jumps back a year, then two years, so that we are following the point-of-view of a 7-year-old girl (Wally). It's not easy to make such a young child believable, and I didn't find this attempt particularly successful. Then the story shifts focus again, and now we're following the thoughts and actions of the girl's mother (Stella), including some fairly explicit sex scenes. Then finally, half-way through the story, we get back to V-J Day, and a shocking, but to me not credible, turn of events. Her mother may have been "unstable," but her action was so sudden, so unprepared for, that it was not just shocking, it was out of character and simply not believable.We also focus in on Wally's childhood friend, Ham, the son of the family maid, and on the maid herself (Loretta) and there are odd parallels between the secrets of their lives and the secrets of Wally's life. But these secondary characters, Loretta in particular, were very one-dimensional to me.The imagery of the secret life of ants was supposed to work in much the same way as the bees in The Secret Life of Bees, but this book pales by comparison to that book in every way. I have read The Secret Lief of Bees and taught it in class for 7 years now, and it continues to reward re-reading. This book has none of the charm, or depth of characters, or effective narrative style. It might also be compared to To Kill a Mockingbird, but only in the sense that we have racial issues, and a very young child as the main point-of-view character.Most unsuccessful of all is the way the book moves forward in time at the end, bringing us to Wally as a young woman of 20, and like her mother, entangled with two different men. The ending aims to be lyrical, but it simply didn't work for me. Too much territory is covered in 292 pages--if you want to write a multi-generational saga, it's going to need 500 pages to do it. If you want to tell Wally's story, the book needs to be much more tightly focused.The time, the place, the set-up are all promising, and I was interested to know how the story was going to turn out, but all in all, it was unsatisfying.

This is an absorbing story, and the writing is just outstanding., It kept me up at night reading, and I was sorry to see it end. The voyage itself doesn't actually get started till over 100 pages in, but the background information was fascinating in itself.Perhaps the thing about this story that surprised me and will stick with me the most is how recently it was that human beings finished exploring this planet: in 1879, educated scientists actually believed that the North Pole was in an open polar sea of temperate climate. One theory as to why the arctic was ice-free (surrounded by merely a "girdle of ice" which could be smashed through) was that there was a hole or vent from which interior heat kept the water warm. Or maybe the Kuro Siwo (Black Current or Kuro-Shio) from Japan, the Pacific equivalent of the Gulf Stream, reached all the way to the pole. Ninety years later, man walked on the moon--the rate of increase of our knowledge has certainly been exponential!In addition to the sheer adventure and adversity of a ship aiming for the pole and becoming ice-bound, there is a love story underlying the main plot which will tug at your heart. And the captain, DeLong, seems to have been a man of most superb character who maintained discipline and the spirits and safety of his men against incredible odds.This story would be suitable for young people, as it is inspiring, challenging, and not offensive or depressing throughout most of the story. A classic story of human courage and the human spirit. (I don't want to spoil the story, but I will say that dogs have to be shot, which would be disturbing to some, though the scenes are not gruesome.)I will definitely be reading Hampton Sides other books--this is meticulously researched and elegantly written.

My uncertainty about these sheets stems from the fact that they're not cottony. They feel like satin, or sateen. They are rather slippery and they make a rustling sound. But in the summer, they feel cool.

Thomas Beller, the author of this book, is clearly a gifted writer in his own right. This book manages to tell quite a lot about JD Salinger while seldom addressing the topic head-on. Instead, Beller wanders here and there, describing his quest to capture the essence of who Salinger was, but also revealing quite a bit about himself, about the people who knew Salinger, but at the same time respecting the essential privacy of Salinger.He also muses on the contradiction that is implicit in a desire for privacy--by escaping, Salinger created that much more curiosity about just what it was that he wanted so much to hide. Beller quotes a sentence from Time magazine, in which neighbors of Salinger "could stand it no longer" and climbed the fence to get into Salinger's property. He wonders at the word "it." What was "it" that they could stand no longer?And then, Beller does a bit of sleight-of-hand, insinuating that Salinger's relationship with children and young adults was not quite healthy, that he may have had the mind, at least, of a child molester. He does this mostly by having other people either hint at, or deny, that this was the case. And this makes me wonder about the focus of Salinger's work. I recently read an early work by John Updike, also a favorite in The New Yorker, a decade or so later than Salinger, and it makes me think about how adult Updike was, even as a quite young man, and how adolescent Salinger's attention was.It's an odd book, writing about writing about Salinger. But I found it quite enjoyable, and I may have to pick up Nine Stories again and re-read them, as an adult myself this time.

Some of the recipes in this book are for simple salads that pretty much anyone already knows how to make, or can find online--tuna salad, a Greek salad, bacon-lettuce-tomato salad. Others, quite a few, are salads only in the sense that they are served cold--perhaps the most outrageous "salad" I have ever seen is one made with six (!) Snickers candy bars chopped up and mixed with apples, a container of Cool Whip and a box of instant butterscotch pudding and then garnished with caramel syrup. If that sounds like a "salad" you would enjoy, then this is the book for you.The photos of the salads are very attractive, if small but the lay-out leaves much to be desired in the kindle edition as the font for recipe names is large and runs to several lines and most of the recipes run onto adjacent pages, so unlike in a well-designed hardcover cookbook, the recipe is not on a single page. There are 40 recipes in total, and while there are a few that I might like to make, most are either obvious ones that I already know how to make or goopy concoctions of canned fruit, cool whip and pudding mixes.  Honestly, the cover is the best thing about this book!I received the kindle book for free in exchange for an honest review, and I feel bad to have to write such a negative review, but I have to have some integrity is what I say. These days, with so many free recipes available online, a cookbook has to be pretty special for me to want to buy it, and this does not measure up, in my opinion.

I generally buy the bags with actual zippers, and this bag does not have that. You press together two colored lines and they change to a third color and you know it is firmly closed. In a way, this is easier and less likely to give out after multiple uses. On the other hand, it is maybe a bit less easy to use. The thickness of the plastic is good. The opening is wider and therefore a bit easier to load than the bags with zippers. The quantity is such that this order will last me for years.

I don't know how to determine if this syrup actually has immune-boosting properties or not. I bought something similar before, and it did seem to help, but it's hard to be sure. This version is thicker and more intense in flavor than the one I had before. The taste is really delicious. I mix a spoonful with sparkling water and drink it when I feel a cold coming on. It could be a placebo effect, or it could be effective. IN any case, if you want to use Black Elderberry, this is a great choice.

An oral history gathers up what people choose to say about their own lives and experience, but I would expect some analysis or commentary on the part of the historian. This book held my interest, but in the end, I was disappointed at how shallow or unreflective these cloistered women seemed to be. I don't know whether that is a result of their years of silence, that they simply can't find the vocabulary to discuss their inner struggles, or whether the author didn't ever press them to dig a little deeper.These women comment on the fact that they will not have children, but they never comment on the fact that they have also foresworn sex, which surely, for women who grew up in the secular world in the 70s,, 80s or 90s is a thought that must have crossed their minds. One of the stories, about a woman who was in an active order, hints at a personal love between herself and another nun, but no reflection on that possibility is included either.They all comment on the fact that things were "hard" or "counter-cultural," but without any personal analysis of why they persevered through such difficulties. In the end, it was an oddly surface exploration of a deeply interior life. They come across as inarticulate, and I don't know whether that's due to some sort of mental damage (they live, after all, under circumstances that otherwise would constitute a form a torture), or inability to express their true thoughts, or the inability of their interviewer to help them express themselves.And yet--I couldn't stop reading. It was hard to differentiate between one woman and another, and they all seemed very similar in their thoughts, but it still kept my interest.

I read all of Dorothy Sayers canon about 30 years ago, and I loved the depth, the characters, the wit, and the historical and geographic background. In this book, the characters come alive, now parents of high school children, and still very much in love, and dealing with the disappointment that any parent might feel at a child going in a direction different from one's own. So I enjoyed that aspect of the book. And I also enjoyed the Oxford setting, the feeling that I am seeing what goes on behind the scenes in that exalted and storied place.The murders take place as a result of an academic squabble over an ancient manuscript which may or may not have been annotated by King Alfred the Great, and which may or may not be worth a lot of money and save the college's finances, and may or may not be a forgery.  So again, like in Sayers' original books, you console yourself that this is not just a mindless cozy murder mystery, but you are learning things. However, the plot was fairly hard to follow, especially since there was no meaningful character development of the Oxford dons who might be involved in this mess.I did not have a clear recollection of the plot lines of Harriet Vane's books, so the link-up there didn't give me any thrill of recognition.Nevertheless, I found myself unwilling to leave the largish paperback at home when I took a plane trip recently, and all in all it was a comforting read.

I may not be the best person to review this, since I have no experience with french presses to compare this to. I received this free in exchange for an honest review. On the positive side, it is an extremely handsome-looking pot--it is shiny and seems very sturdy and well made. It came well-packaged, as well.On the downside, the instructions for how to make coffee in it were rather sketchy on the side of the box, and since this was my first time, I felt that I had to go online to look up more detailed instructions.The rest of my comments are based on French press vs. an automatic coffee-maker that I usually use. I purchased fresh coffee that I ground at the store in order to try this out since I usually use a very fine grind. According to what I read, the temperature of the water is crucial, so I used an instant read thermometer to check (and re-check) the heat of the water. That means that I had to measure out water, put it in the microwave, set it for 5  minutes, check the temp, do it for a couple more minutes, check again, and so on. Then I poured it over the grounds. I was unsure how long I should wait before pressing, and again, my online source said that this is important. Finally, I pressed, and it worked smoothly and easily. Then I had to pour off the rest of the coffee into some other pot so that it wouldn't over-brew.Finally, I tasted it--and meh. It reminded me of percolated coffee from my youth. Maybe I'm wrong, but I am accustomed to the taste of drip coffee, and I like it. This was not notably better, and it was far more effort--effort that I am in no way prepared to make every morning before my first cup. I like the ease of a Mr. Coffee maker, and the taste of this is not enough to outweigh the inconvenience.And then I had to clean this thing, which meant using a spoon to dig out a hockey puck of loose coffee grounds, again much less convenient than simply removing a paper filter full of wet grounds.So I appreciate the free coffee maker, and I do think that if you like making French Press coffee, this is a good choice for you. But it's not for me.

I am not an economist, and in fact I've never even taken a course in basic econ, but over the past 6 or 7 years, I have tried to make up for that gap in my education by listening to Planet Money and Marketplace and reading Paul Krugman, along with a dozen or so books on economics in general and the crash of 2007-08 in particular. So I was interested in this book, which claims to tell us what money really is.The book covered a wide swath of history and philosophy, as well as business and finance, but it does so in as accessible a way as possible. It begins with the most fundamental question--what is money anyhow? The author uses the framing device of a conversation with a friend who is an entrepreneur and businessman, and gets the standard answer--a story about bartering, the inconvenience of exchanging chickens for bushels of wheat, and the substitution, over time, of money (coins) as a substitute for actual commodities. In this view, money is at root a thing, a commodity, and gold or silver are the real money, with paper just a less-awkward symbol of it.And then he goes on to show that this is not and never has been true. There are and never have been barter-based economies, of whatever small scale you would want to imagine. He uses the remote island of Yap, with its infamous huge stone wheel money to show that money is and always has been a social, not physical phenomenon, a way of keeping a tally of credits and debits. Money is at its root based on debt, not chickens or codfish. In the absence of money, what you find is not nature but an alternative social system, such as sacrifices made to gods and then shared by the tribe, or feudal arrangements in which one class owes certain amounts of labor to another class, which also has social obligations such as defense to those who support them. In the end of the book, he compares money to language--something which no one individual controls, but which gets its meaning and power only from social agreement as to what it means.From there, we travel through ancient Mesopotamia (which was a form of control-economy and had no money) to ancient Greece, which had a much less advanced society, but which had the concept of each member of society as being equal (allowing, of course for the fact that women and slaves were not counted as members of society--see the founding of the United States for a similar point of view.) and on to the development of trade in medieval Europe, when methods of buying and selling throughout Europe developed, requiring ways to standardize what was owed by a buyer in Belgium to a seller in Genoa.The surprise villain of the story is John Locke, who reintroduced the idea that money should be immutable and gold-like, thereby leading to the laissez-faire theories that allowed Englishmen to clear their consciences while allowing a million Irish to starve to death rather than weaken them with charity. The only good government is a small one, and the smaller the better, so that business can advance without tiresome duties to society as a whole. And now it starts to sound familiar.In the end, Mr. Martin has an aim in mind--to argue that by allowing banks to profit without control, while backing them, by necessity not only from failures of liquidity (a bank run) but also failure of capital (due to assets that were misvalued.) It is the familiar "profits are privatized while losses are socialized," and his whole history of money has been pointing towards an explanation of money as always social, not a simple fact of nature. Therefore, taxing profits to protect society, or inflating money or cancelling debts in order to maintain the social order and "liberty and justice for all" is not some sort of unnatural act, taking from wealth-producers to give to lazy takers, as Mitt Romney would see it. Instead, money has always been a means to an end, and that end is a just society.At some points in the story, the argument becomes a bit abstract and not always easy for me to follow, though he does his best to keep it as concrete and anecdotal as possible.One point that I take from this book is that my own understanding of money as a means of keeping score is essentially correct. It makes no more sense to rail against "fiat money" than it does to rail against the points awarded in basketball, and to complain that those 3-pointers were made up out of thin air, and to ask, where are those points coming from?Certainly a book well worth reading, for anyone who has ever asked, What is money anyway, and how does it get started?

After Jason Padgett suffered a brain injury as a result of his mugging, his personality changed from a frat-boy type to a shy, studious guy who suffered from OCD, agorphobia, and PTSD. The personality change is surprising, but the rest of that description is not. But what is most amazing is that he began to perceive mathematical patterns everywhere, and became obsessed with drawing visual representations of pi and prime numbers.This story is quite well-written, in my opinion. With the help of a co-author, Jason uses his own narrative to also fill us in on a great deal of scientific research into synesthesia (associating numbers and letters with colors, among other things), TBI (traumatic brain injury), savant syndrome, and more. The way the science is folded into the narrative is quite expert, and the book is not only a personal memoir but also a primer on many topics in neurology, told in an approachable way.What is most intriguing to me about the changes in Jason's brain is the question of whether his altered way of perceiving the world is giving us insight into the actual structure of the physical world, or only of the human brain itself. In other words, people with savant syndrome have unique and impressive skills, the ability to correctly calculate dates on the calendar in an instant, or to perceive the prime factors in a large number, or to compose complex music or draw detailed renderings of nature. But when Jason sees the matrix that underlies reality, is that because he has some unique insight, or because all human brains are attuned to the reality of the structure of the universe, or is it just a brain artifact? How is it different (or is it different?) from psychedelic-induced visions of colored music or writhing snakes?I also somewhat wish that he had waited longer to write this book. Apparently at the time of writing it, he is still a student at a local community college. As a community college professor myself, I respect the hard-working students that attend community colleges. But is he a genius? He is fascinated by math, but how good is he at it? If he were attending MIT and sharing his insights with his professors, I would be ready to believe that he is a genius, with profound new insights. Yes, it's amazing that a head injury made him *better* at math than he was before--but is he, as the cover claims, a "mathematical marvel"? That part is not yet clear.Quibbles aside, this book is well worth reading, it it will challenge your ideas about how our minds function, as well as give you great respect for this guy's courage in overcoming the downsides to his injury.

I teach ESL, so non-native speakers, and this book is not intended for that purpose. It is aimed at teacher-training programs for native speakers who will have to teach English grammar to their students. As a person with an MA in linguistics, I highly recommend this textbook. It explains what "standard English" requires, while also explaining where the rules break down and how people actually use English. I would love to teach a course using this book.

I have long argued that what underlies the opposition to taxes and government in general is the sense on the part of whites that government is for Them, meaning originally blacks but now also immigrants as well, especially Hispanic immigrants. So I was pleased to find this erudite scholar making the same point. His arguments are a bit abstruse, especially when he discusses the import of color-blindness and post-racialism. Color-blindness is the pretense on the part of whites, mainly conservatives but also progressives, that race doesn't even occur to them. Lopez shows how this seemingly noble point of view is actually very destructive and allows racism to continue, unacknowledged and unchallenged.I had a little more difficulty understanding his point about post-racialism, which is Obama's position. I would be hard-pressed to try to paraphrase what post-racialism means and how it is different from (false) color-blindness. As a disappointed Obama supporter, I did appreciate his clear explanation of how Obama went wrong right at the start of his presidency, by failing to openly avow liberalism and instead using the power of government to help in a crisis in such a subtle way as to strengthen the narrative that taxes are the enemy of the good life and government had best get out of the way. I agree with him in wondering just how progressive Obama really is, and to what extent his embrace of conservative ideas (such as school choice) is from the heart and how much is to avoid being seen as "the black president."The final chapter, in which Lopez supposedly offers ideas on where to go from here was likewise not as clear and powerful as I could have wished. His main point is to continue to speak up on race and how it is always there. As he well notes, this incites rage on the conservative side of every issue. He does a fine job of showing the racial jiu-jitsu by which conservatives manage to make it seem like it is liberals who are the real racists. But he is less clear on how his proposals will overcome this flim-flam,Well worth reading, and helpful to younger readers who do not have a personal recollection of the Nixonian Southern Strategy and the way Reagan played the dog-whistle like a master.

This longish novel starts out perfectly normal--the writing is clear and the plot line is easy to follow. Gil Martins is an FBI agent and his marriage is on the rocks. His wife leaves him because he has lost his faith in God, and her religion is that important to her. Gil is a former Catholic and more recently an evangelical, but he no longer believes any of it and has taken to reading books about atheism.But then about three-quarters of the way through the book, it just takes a turn towards the supernatural and the unbelievable, and the whole thing falls apart. It gets quite scary for a while, but in the end, it is just plain unsatisfying.I don't know who would like this book--it has plenty to offend Catholics and evangelicals, but it also will not work for atheists either, Heck, even the FBI would probably find it disturbing. I don't know whether Philip Kerr wants us to take his thesis seriously, or if it's part of his actual argument for atheism. He concludes the book with several pages of biblical quotes, supporting his view of God as essentially demonic.Since I am a former Catholic and former evangelical who has also lost faith, I was with him most of the way, but then this just went way off the rails. Even the writing got bad, as people do the things they do in horror movies--is there something scary going on? Well how about if I walk out of the relative safety of my house and wander around outside in the dark, where, of course, my cellphone has no reception, and oh darn, I lost my gun in that fall I took and the electricity is out, so it's pitch dark, except for that glowing light where a demon is glaring at me.Sorry, not a prayer here.

It does take a bit of nerve for a white Southern woman to write in the voice of an African-American slave, but Oprah is on board with it, and I think she makes it work. The historical aspects of this book, with the real names of real people, Sarah and Angelina Grimke, the main characters, Lucretia Mott, Denmark Vesey, William LLoyd Garrison, blends seamlessly with the wholly imagined parts, the lives of the enslaved women. Kidd manages to capture the style of both the young woman who is supposed to "own" a slave and the equally young woman who is enslaved, and she makes them both believable. The connection she makes between the slavery experienced not only by enslaved people but also by women could be offensive, but I think she makes her case that the lack of voice, the lack of choices, the lack of educational opportunities, and the inability to own property in their own names that even upper-class women experienced was, in its own way, a form of oppression that, while not the equal of what enslaved women experienced, was also true oppression,. Even her inability to extricate herself from slave-owning is oppressive to Sarah Grimke.My one disappointment with the book was the abrupt way it ended. I was reading it on a kindle, and I had no sense that I was nearing the end, and suddenly I turned the page to find out what happened next, and it was the author's note. I think the story was not complete, and maybe she has a thought of carrying on the story in another book. I hope she does.

This book straddles the line between psychological thriller and a more literary genre, and it works as both. The quiet voice of the first section, as we are inside the head of the headmaster, who is speaking in first person, calmly and seemingly rationally about quite irrational and shocking behavior, is eerie and tension building. Than the point of view shifts, in a way that is puzzling and fascinating, and the story is told again, the same but utterly different. And finally, the denouement makes sense of it all, but leaves you still a bit dazed.The setting is elegant and charming, and the characters are superbly well-drawn. The writing style is smooth and flawless. This is one of those books that you want to stay up late to finish, but you also don't want it to end. Just a great piece of writing. I will be looking into Thomas Christopher Greene's previous books, because this one is first-rate.

What a mesmerizing story! No, really! The twists and turns of this murder story kept me totally engrossed. It is hard, at times, to believe that this is fact, not fiction, because the story seems so unlikely--a rotting corpse is found, and after painstaking (and smelly) investigation, it is determined that it is the man who has famously gone missing from Paris. Why was there so much press attention to this murder? Why is so much detail still available, over 100 years later? It's hard to say, but the story is completely captivating and compelling.The crux of the story is the personality of Gabrielle Bompard, the "little demon" of the title, and she also seems more like a character from fiction than any character from real life, and yet every detail is backed up by detailed research. In her early 20s, tiny and undeveloped enough to pass herself off as a young boy from time to time, yet alluring enough to captivate both the murderer and the murder victim, as well as all of France--who *is* this vixen?And was she a hysteric (a psychological malady that was all the vogue in last Victorian, or Belle Epoque, times) or was she in fact the hypnotically-controlled puppet of a vicious madman? How did a proper young lady, raised mainly in convents after her mother died and her father took up with the governess, end up roaming the streets of Paris alone and becoming the mistress of the unappealing M. Eyraud, a professional con-man more than twice her age? Or is it possible that she was the mastermind, controlling him?And can a person be hypnotized so thoroughly that she will commit murder on command? Shades of the Manchurian candidate!The writing in this book is top-notch, the narrative never flags, and the atmosphere of France in the 1890s is entertaining. A worthy companion to the similarly named and similarly well-written Devil in the White City, about murder in Chicago of the same era.I loved it, and you will too!

This book, by the great-nephew of MFK Fisher, captures a time and place and a lifestyle that is quite entrancing to imagine. Fisher, an early-to-mid 20th century food writer, spent several months with her sister in Provence France, and mingled with Julia and Paul Child, James Beard, and several other notable food authorities, while considering her relationship with France and the French way of life and eating. This one season in 1970 was a turning point for her personally and for several of the other writers as well. They had been extolling the glories of France and the French approach to food and to life for decades, but their writing had had an influence on America, and thus the superiority of all things French and the inferiority of everything American was no longer quite so true--America had learned a lot and was beginning to value good food too, so what was the point of a rather elitist and nostalgic clinging to all things French?The book is an almost moment-by-moment (and bite-by-bite) account of the events in Fisher's time in France, as well as equally detailed accounts of what James Beard, Richard Olney, and the Childs were up to, based on the detailed, daily letters and journals many of them kept. Barr documents every sentence, indicating his source for every recollection of a fish stew or lemon tart. The writing is smooth and elegant, although there is some repetition as we see the same scene from different points of view, or in anticipation and then in recollection. The story from 1970 is framed by an introduction and conclusion set in the present, as Barr re-visits the places his family once lived.There are no recipes, per se, and this is certainly not a travel guide. It is a remembrance of things past, a third-person memoir, and quite entertaining as that. It does inspire a desire to make a good bouillabaisse and sit out on the patio and eat it slowly with friends, while drinking good wine and talking on into the night!

What would matter most to me about this product is the price, which I don't know. They work fine--a smallish moist towelette to cleanse after using the bathroom. I imagine there are many similar products on the market, and if I wanted to use them regularly, I would rather have some sort of larger container, like baby wipes. These I would use mainly for travel or away from home, since they come in individual foil packets. They are soft and have a mild, non-irritating scent and feel.

See warning at the end of the review!First of all, I borrowed this for free through Amazon Prime, after reading Moonwalking with Einstein. That book showed that an average person can memorize (which is not quite the same thing as remember) a surprising amount of material, through a specific technique called the Memory Palace. I had heard about this method before, and gave it a half-hearted try, but like many people, I felt that it was too much trouble--learning a bunch of random stuff in order to learn the actual target material seemed like twice as much work.But even half-hearted attempts seemed to work, at least for a while.And after reading the Moonwalking book, I figured, why not? I'm 61 years old, my Dad just died of Alzheimer's this year, anything that can give my brain a workout is worth a try.The plus of this book is that instead of explaining the memory palace technique, it just jumps right in and demonstrates it. It does all the imaginative work of walking you through a scenario with the crazy associations elaborated for you in print. And if you pay attention, form clear mental images as you go, and have a few functioning brain cells, it should take.What I found is that after one reading, I did *not* have all 37 of Shakespeare's plays committed to memory. But what went wrong was very illuminating, because the ones I screwed up were the ones that I didn't really put in a specific enough location in the first place. The parts that I imagined clearly were firmly imprinted. The ones where I went, "Ok, corner of my street, wait, no, maybe the next street would be better, um, ok, let's say the house next door..."--those slipped away. But the corner of my bedroom, the door to the bathroom, the front porch, in front of the movie theatre, those were as clear as a bell.So I see that indeed, this system will allow me, with some practice, and mostly, with clear image-making (imagining) in the first place, to memorize lists of various things.I must admit that I am an English major and college English teacher, and I couldn't have told you even how many plays Shakespeare wrote, much less which one was first, or last, or how many of those damn Henrys he wrote. And now I can. (Also, Dickens wrote a couple of books I've never heard of.)I was on Jeopardy about 7 years ago, and I tried to learn all the presidents, using another method, but I never got them all in place. Now I think I will finally, with some time and effort, get my presidents straight.So yeah, the book is short, there are a couple of grammatical oddities, but it's worth $3.99 for sure if you're interested in using this method to memorize things.EDIT: WARNING! Do not memorize the list of presidents given here! John Tyler and James K. Polk are missing! (They belong between Wm. H. Harrison and Zachary Taylor). Maybe the author's memory failed him? Maybe he really does need an editor? Now I wonder if the list of Shakespeare plays that I have memorized is actually correct! (Gotta remove one star for this error.)

The facts that are reported in this book are undoubtedly correct--the corporate culture of America is a mess, with exhibits from Madoff to Goldman Sachs to prove the point. And the solution will require people to start behaving better.But this book annoyed me from start to finish. First, let's look at the price of the book--the list price is $39.95, discounted at amazon to $27.95, and available as a kindle edition for $19.99! For a book that claims to advocate the virtues of thrift and the decadence of highly-paid executives, that's way out of line! But if the book had included real research, maybe I would be willing to pay the price, However, it doesn't. The main part of the book is a re-hash of articles from websites available for free. Many chapters have notes that go on with ibid, ibid, ibid for pages--in other words, they're just restating what someone else already wrote. In addition, the editing is pitiful. Rivier College is referred to as River college, vicious circles are called viscous circles, and Lehman Brothers is spelled both correctly and as Leman Brothers in the same paragraph. The English usage is also frequently awkward and cliched. If you're going to write a book about the importance of integrity, hard work, and personal responsibility, I would hope that you would show a little more integrity than this, for $40! (Full disclosure: I received this book for free in exchange for an unbiased review.)Then, there's the intro, or rather one of several intros, in which we are treated to a lecture delivered by Sir John Marks Templeton on how capitalism and Christianity go hand in hand. Templeton (known for his Templeton Prize) also states (falsely, I believe) that capitalism, or "the capitalist institutions of property, trade, and cooperation" have always existed. In fact, capitalism is dependent on the ability to lend money for interest, a practice which was condemned as usury by the Judeo-Christian tradition that both Templeton and the authors of this book claim to champion.The next intro sets up the thesis of the book, which is that the root of our problem today, and the cause of the 2008 financial crisis, is the 7 deadly sins. The authors go through quite a few contortions trying to demonstrate that various sins, such as gluttony, pride, lust, and of course plain old greed are the reason that the economy tanked. They add moralistic terms such as these to their narratives over and over again. For example, in discussing Madoff, it's not enough to say that the guy was greedy. His besetting sin is diagnosed as lust, because he had topless waitresses at parties he threw. Gluttony is the charge against corporations that conducted too many corporate mergers. And so on. If someone is going to turn out to be a bad guy, even his youthful successes will be described as "prideful" or "greedy" or "gluttonous."In some cases, their accusations don't even make sense. They condemn Bear Stearns for exhibiting pride by hiring a guy named Jimmy Cayne on the basis of his bridge-playing ability. It was Cayne who brought about the destruction of this formerly great company, because he didn't have the right kind of education to lead a company--even though they themselves also note that Cayne was hired in 1969, and the company had its first quarterly loss in 2007! Undoubtedly, Cayne, and Bear Stearns, were derelict in focusing on a bridge tournament when the company was circling the drain. But if the guy worked there since 1969, surely he had acquired a few skills along the way, and whatever it was that he was doing seemed to work for 38 years! Yet they end the chapter by saying that "Cayne's hiring alone demonstrates that the firm was long on bravado and short on rational pragmatism."The final section of the book, in which the authors offer "a way back" comes across as simplistic and naive. The primary author, who gives his name as Theodore Roosevelt Malloch, is eager to point out that he is "a distant relative" of President Theodore Roosevelt, and he thinks that TR is a useful model to look to. Mr. T. R. Malloch has what sound like very respectable credentials, but it's hard to take seriously a section heading called "A Dummies' Guide to Save the SEC" that takes up less than a page of the book. They criticize the SEC for calling in (and paying for) consulting firms, and offer to do the job for free! Their handy bit of wisdom can be boiled down to two things--hire smarter people and pay them better, and create an "ethics hotline." All right then.They also give us the following in-depth analysis of theories of prosperity and wealth creation:"1. Wealth is viewed as the product of magic, alchemy, or wizadry, poof!"2. Prosperity is the product of tribal or national conquest. Guess what? You have it and I am taking it."3. Prosperity is rooted in the value of human creative capacity" (p. 224)No, really, those are their exact words. I'll take door #3, of course! But does this go any ways towards explaining why the creative capacity in Haiti and the Congo seems to get people so much less than the creative capacity of Wall Street traders? Does it explain why the creativity of trash pickers in India, and our own inner cities, leaves people still impoverished, while a clever guy like Jamie Dimon gets rich? (Interestingly, they praise Dimon on p. 200-201 as showing shrewdness and good judgment, despite the fact that he's hardly a paragon of their favorite virtue, thrift, with (according to Wikipedia) "$23 million pay package for fiscal year 2011, more than any other bank CEO in the United States."Between the moralizing, the bad writing, and the simplistic solutions offered to complex problems, I found this book endlessly aggravating. Even the title is silly--"The End of Ethics"? What the heck is that supposed to mean? Were people really just of better character back in the 1950s--or did the system have different incentives, and more equitable laws and tax structures? By putting the emphasis on individual character and virtue or vice (words they use over and over again), they take attention away from the lack of regulation that has allowed such "vice" to flourish, although in the end, they prescribe better regulation, not more morality. They themselves are at pains to point out the bad guys' religious backgrounds, and lots of them are noted as being Jewish, but when a Catholic goes astray, it is noted as somehow an anomaly--despite his Catholic education, this guy fell prey to vices.Still not convinced that this is a shoddy book? Ok, have a look at p. 233, in which they discuss "the paradox of thrift." They explain this important phrase as being "a raging debate" about whether there is "some magic number or formulae (sic) for the level of savings in a given country." They contrast Adam Smith's appreciation for thrift as a virtue with John Maynard Keynes's position that "a high savings rate [is] far from a virtue."
