I'm not one of those hard core campers, but I do like to camp one or two nights a few times a year. I've been using those foam, egg crate style sleeping pads, and have been in absolute misery.  I find it so uncomfortable, and I've looked into different options, such as a fold out cot or an air mattress. Well, the last thing I want when camping is bulkier equipment to pack up. That's what made this limit air pad appealing to me. You blow it up (4 breaths for the pillow, and 11 breaths for the body), and it really is effective. It keeps me off the ground without "bottoming out" on the ground. The best part is that it actually rolls up much smaller than my form foam pad.

I'm 5'2", as such, I'm no stranger to stepping stools. I have a nice wooden one that I keep out 24/7 in the kitchen to reach things in cabinets. I was looking for another stool to keep in a closet on the other floors of my house. I liked that this folds up for storage. I find the folding mechanism easy to use, and it snaps securely when it's opened up. I like the non-slip rubber texture on the top too. It has a very utilitarian look though, so I wouldn't want to leave it out full time like my stool I keep in the kitchen, but for storage, I'm very happy with this one.

I've had what I believe to be the precious model of Bose noise cancelling headphones for a year now, and then ordered this pair for my husband. We travel/fly multiple times a year for leisure, and noise cancelling headphones are indispensable. They will not block out all noise, they block out ambient background noise (the roar of an airplane), but not sudden sounds like a baby crying. But because these block out background noise, you can listen to your music or videos better, and with the volume turned down lower, a saving your hearing. For those who don't know, the noise cancelling feature is independent from the headphones. So, you don't need to be listening to anything in order to use it. And it does need a AA battery to operate the noise cancelling feature. The difference I see in these, compared to my older model, is these have a Mic on the headphone jack to use with your phone or when skyping. They also fold up.smaller.

I've purchased goji berries before, and wasn't really liking the taste that much. The ones I had gotten were excessively chewy and had a weird after taste. I reluctantly decided to try this brand just to see if the taste could be any better. People describing these as "plump" and "juicy" really sold it for me. Well, these are definitely better tasting, but I wouldn't describe them as necessarily plump or juicy. They're a little bigger than the standard ones I've seen in stores, and still chewy, but not as chewy as the other ones I had. These were clearly not as dehydrated. I do like the taste of these better, but they're not dramatically different. So if you tried goji berries before and hated them, you probably won't like these either.

I have a small, round dining table meant to seat four. Because of the size and shape of the table, I prefer round placemats. These are exactly what I was looking for. They're a woven type of material that seems sturdy and well made. They wipe down easy and appear stain resistant, which is also nice. I don't think I'd want to risk putting these in the washing machine, but like I said they're pretty easy to clean just by wiping down. I'm also loving this sunny yellow gold color. It's really nice for spring and summer decorating.

I'm what you'd most likely refer to as a "crazy cat lady". Basically I want to do as much as I possibly can for my cats and keep them happy. I have two hard plastic cat carriers already, but this soft mesh one intrigued me. Well, after receiving it, I'm definitely impresses with it. I got the large, which is the same size as my other carriers. I wouldn't recommend getting any smaller unless you're wanting it for a guinea pig or something. Here's what makes this soft carrier better than my plastic ones: It's significantly lighter weight, and I suspect more comfortable for kitty. The soft padding inside can be removed and wash. The biggest advantage is the top unzips so that you can just lower the cat into it and then zip it closes. No more battles to get the cat into the carrier!

This was my first experience with the Doughmaker's brand and I'm now interested in purchasing more of it. The cookie sheet has a 'pebbled', textured surface to make it nonstick without needing any kind of nonstick coating. I was skeptical and did do a light spray of oil before baking some cookies. Well, the cookies did release immediately, and I'll probably try using no spray next time. I would consider this cookie sheet "jumbo" sized, it's definitely the biggest one I've ever owned. But that's nice because I can do a dozen cookies with the one sheet. The lip on the sheet also makes it easy to remove. I'll be looking into buying some of the brands other baking pans as well now. I definitely recommend.

There's a couple qualities I look for in a good water bottle: BPA free, easy to clean, easy to drink from, doesn't drip, and not a huge size. Some fancy water bottles I've had, have tons of silicone seals and opening/closing mechanisms that fill with grime and are hard to get clean. This one is very simple, just push the button and the top opens, despite how simple it is, it doesn't leak. It's also easy to fill because when you unscrew the lid, the opening is as wide as the bottle. This is exactly the same as their "adult" version, except not as big, 17 oz. I was looking for a smaller water bottle that I could fit in my purse and was more convenient to carry around, and so I got this "child size" one. I'm very happy with it,

This product touts itself as a replacement for Botox, "needles no more", and makes some pretty bold claims of "instantly relaxes lines". I do get botox, and not even botox works "instantly" (takes about a week to set in). The thing with Botox, is that around 3 months it starts to wear off, and I schedule my appointments at about 5 months out. So I'm always looking for skin care products that might help stretch out the results or even improve the results. That said, I noticed absolutely nothing from this product. I'm not even sure, reading the ingredients, what in it would be at all effective. It has some moisturizing qualities, and also some acid peel type ingredients. That said, I already moisturize and do acid peels, so this product isn't going to magically transform my skin. The price of this is around $90 for 0.5 oz and will last you maybe 2 months. I pay $250 for Botox every 5 months. So comparatively, this costs the same as Botox, except Botox actually does something for me, and this does nothing!

I had heard about 'bulletproof coffee', that somehow adding an oil to my morning coffee would help me lose weight? Sure, I'll try just about anything. Well, the thought of putting oil in my coffee sounded kind of disgusting to be honest, but in reality you can't even taste the oil at all, so it makes no difference. I've been doing one tablespoon a day for a couple weeks now. I was not sure how this mct oil might affect me, I didn't notice any stomach upset or other side effects. What I did notice, was a very diminished appetite. I've been trying to count calories for awhile now, but because I'd get too hungry, I'd end up cheating and not losing any weight. Well, since I've added this oil to my daily coffee, I've lost 5 lbs because I've been able to stick to my calorie goals or even be under my daily goals and not be hungry.However, I did take a star off for the leaky bottle. When the bottle arrived roughly 2 oz of it had leaked all over the cardboard box and the box was just saturated with oil. I cleaned the oil off the product, but everytime I use it, some oil leaks down the side of the bottle. So, I really love the oil and will continue using it, but I'll have to use a different brand because it's just ridiculous how leaky the bottle is.

I only bake cupcakes a couple times a year, and drawer space us at a premium in my kitchen. That's why I love this frosting dispenser. It's replacing a much larger cookie-press style one I had that required two hands to use, took up a lot if space, and was horrible to clean. With this oxo one, I can hold and dispense with one hand. This is very compact too, only holds about one cup. Obviously you'll have to fill it again half way through decorating, but it's very easy to fill and worth it for the small size. The metal decorating tips are universally sized, so the ones I already had fit this too. I'm storing the tips inside the body of it. It completely comes apart to clean. I can't remember if it says it's dishwasher safe, but I washed it in the top rack no problem.

The claims that this product makes are pretty dramatic claims, stating " relax the appearance of muscle tightening" and "45% reduction in the appearance of wrinkles in 8 weeks". After a month of using this product, I will say that it is very moisturizing, and I like it for that, but that's a lot of money for a good moisturizer when I didn't notice anything as far as relaxing the muscles on my face or reducing wrinkles. I'm in my 30's, and I use Botox to smooth out the lines I've already got and also to prevent them from getting worse. There's a lot of skincare products out there targeting women who are fearful or against trying something like Botox. The claims that this product make, give me the impression that it's trying to be an alternative to Botox, although it does not state that directly. Well, I pushed my next Botox appointment a month out and gave this product a try in the meantime in order to really give it a chance. I love the way the product dispenses, and a little goes a long way. It appears that this product will last somewhere between 2 and 3 months. It is moisturizing and a nice cream for nighttime. After looking at the ingredients, the key ingredient in this cream is Squalene, which is derived from olives, high moisturizing and plumps up wrinkles to reduce their appearance. I don't particularly care for some of the other chemical ingredients in this product, like butylene glycol. The description proudly proclaims it is "paraben free", but people who care about avoiding parabens generally want to avoid glycols as well. So, definitely not a natural product. The price is also pretty outrageous for what it is. You are basically paying for a fancy container. If you want to try the moisturizing benefits of squalene you can search for it on Amazon and find more natural options for $10.  In conclusion, this is a nice cream in a nice package, but too many ingredients I don't care for, way overpriced, and definitely not effective enough to make me give up Botox.

I have persistent adult acne (meaning I've had acne since I was a teenager, and am now in my 30's). I've gotten it mostly under control by supplementing with zinc and also a pretty complicated system of cleansing and treating. I actually make my own cold cream using evening primrose oil, sulfur and tea tree oil, then tone with witchhazel and spot treat with 10% ichthammol ointment when needed. Although my system works, if I could have something easier, especially when traveling, that would be perfect.I read online about this Benzac system before ordering. I read a press release online where the company described the product as "vegan" and "natural". This appealed to me, and I liked that the product uses essential oils  and no benzoyl peroxide (I hate that stuff). When the box arrived, I was dissappointed to read the ingredient list, it has glycols and parabens in it, which I wouldn't consider "natural". And although it doesn't contain any animal derived ingredients (as far as I can tell), the company does test on animals, so that's not exactly "vegan" either. Although I would never order this product again for these reasons, since I had it, I decided to try it out.+First impressions, I liked the foaming cleanser. It uses a foaming pump to make it foam, the actual cleanser is not detergenty or sudsy, which is good as soaps tend to aggravate acne. The cleanser did successfully remove my makeup, and quite easily it seems, although I did not use it around my eyes for obvious reasons.+The moisturizer that comes with it has no SPF in it, which is a no-no for me, I will not use a moisturizer during the day with no SPF. I've been using Murad Anti-Aging Moisturizer for blemish-prone skin SPF 20. But I figured I'd just use the Benzac Moisturizer at night so as not to waste it.+When I first used the spot treatment, I was surprised to squeeze the tube and find that it's half empty, then when you finally got some product out, it comes rushing out as the opening is too big. I'll also add that it pills up when applying makeup over top of it. Not a huge fan of this.In the end I used this system for about a week and then had to stop because it was drying out my skin so bad. The only thing worse then having a pimple is having a pimple and horribly dry skin. Also, every time I'd use any of the products, my eyes would sting even though I didn't apply near my eyes. I think from the salicylic acid fumes or something. I'll speak for all adult women when I say we aren't fans of dried out skin and moisturizers without SPF in them. I also started to break out a little and I suspected it might be this system, although I can't say for sure. I'm posting the product ingredients below so you can make your own decision about them.Ingredients Skin Balancing Foaming Cleanser: alcohol denatured, backhousia citriodora leaf extract, butylene glycol, caprylic/capric triglyceride, citric acid, citrus aurantium dulcis (orange) peel oil, citrus grandis (grapefruit) peel oil, citrus reticulate (tangerine) peel oil, glycerin, glycine soja (soybean) oil,lauramidopropyl betaine, lonicera caprifolium (honeysuckle) flower extract, lonicera japonica (honeysuckle) flower extract, phenoxyethanol, polysorbate 80, potassium benzoate, santalum album (sandalwood) oil, sodium laurylglcosides hydroxypropylsulfonate, terminalia ferdinandiana fruit extract, tocopherol, water.Ingredients Intensive Spot Treatment: alcohol, allium fistulosum bulb extract, backhousia citriodora leaf extract, butylene glycol, butylparaben, cardiospermum halicacabum flower/leaf/vine extract, citric acid, echium plantagineum seed oil, ethylparaben, hamamelis virginiana (witch hazel) water, helianthus annus (sunflower) seed oil unsaponifiables, hydroxypropylcellulose, isobutylparaben, methylparaben, octyldodecanol, phenoxyethanol, potassium benzoate, potassium sorbate, propylparaben, santalum album (sandalwood) oil, SD Alcohol 40-B, tocopherol, water.Ingredients Blemish Clearning Hydrator: alcohol denatured, backhousia citriodora leaf extract, butyl avocadate, butlene glycol, c13-14 isoparaffin, caprylic/capric triglyceride, chlorphenesin, citric acid, glycerin, hydrolyzed algin, isodecyl neopentanoate, laureth-7, lonicera caprifolium (honeysuckle) flower extract, lonicera japonica (honeysuckle) flower extract, methylparaben, phenoxyethanol, polyacrylamine, potassium benzoate, potassium sorbate, proplyene glycol, santalum album (sandalwood) oil, terminalia ferdinandiana fruit extract, water, zinc sulfate.

Whenever I try a new mascara, I apply it to only one eye and then apply the mascara I had been using to the other eye and compare. I do this because all mascaras enhance the lashes to a certain extent and it's easy to be dazzled without another mascara to compare it to. So, up for comparison is this Japonesque "lash loading mascara" and my number 1 favorite mascara so far: Loreal Miss Manga. Both mascaras are about the same size Japonesque is 0.3oz and Miss Manga is 0.27oz. Japanesque is manufactured in the UK and Miss Manga is manufactured in the USA.Well, after applying one to each eye, there's a huge difference in performance and Miss Manga is by far the winner. Lash thickness appears the same, but Miss Manga makes lashes look a solid 50% longer. I'll also say that the Japonesque brush is horrible and I had to pick two clumps off my lashes. By the end of the day I had blacks black smudge under the eye wearing the Japonesque. I would describe the performance of Japonesque as "below average", like something that would be alright if I had bought it at a dollar store. But it's not a dollar, it's $20 which is just criminal!

For the past year, I had extremely dry skin on my nose that would flake and peel. It was embarassing as it made my nose red as well, and I even had someone joke that I looked like an alcoholic... not the impression I want to give! I tried various solutions and nothing seemed to work. I started to suspect that I had seborrheic dermatitis which apparently can only be managed with no permanent solution. I had various, expensive, very heavy and greasy creams recommended to me to use, which seemed to help some, but not completely.I saw this product in the 'natural section' of my base's commissary and since the price was good and I had nothing to lose, I gave it a try. I was surprised by how light weight and quick absorbing this cream is, especially compared to the thick heavy creams I had been using. I put a big glob on my nose and didn't rub it in at all and it fully absorbed. Each time this happened I added more, about 4 times before I went to bed that night just to really give it my all. I will say that that first night of using it, it did sting a little each time I applied it. The next morning I was amazed when my nose did not look flaky at all! I was completely shocked that this product seemed to 'work overnight'. I continued to apply the cream morning and evening and after a couple days I was dismayed to see some flaking return. However, this time was different, over the next week, thick pieces of skin began to peel off my nose, revealing healthy, normal skin underneith.I have been using this cream for two months now and I am happy to say that the skin on my nose now looks completely normal, soft, smooth, flake free, not red at all. I plan on continuing to use this cream as I don't want the condition to return, but as this is a large 4oz jar and I only need a little for my nose, I think this jar will probably last me a very long time.

This book is a collection of short (1-2 page) articles about the ingredients in food and consumer products. The  fact that the articles are so short, yet interesting makes this book great for an office break room, coffee table, or dare I say a bathroom. The author doesn't pass any judgement on the products or ingredients, just lays it out for the reader to make their own decision. Sometimes more interesting than the ingredients is the backstory behind each article when the author discusses the various roadblocks and backpedaling done by the companies he contacts fir research.I'll add that we live in a time where more people are interested in what they're putting in and on their bodies. I'm definitely one of those people trying to live a more natural life. The past 50 years or so, the products in this book were viewed as 'the miracle of science' and an advancement to society. Now, people are starting to think maybe we were all better off before? Definitely interesting and thought provoking articles in this book.

I used to jump on a mini-trampoline maybe an hour a day about 10 years ago and loved it, but eventually the strap connected to the spring snapped and I went crashing to the ground. As a result of that frightening experience, I was hesitant to buy another despite how much I enjoyed it. That said, I recently bought this one because the reviews were good and the price was cheap enough that if it broke I figured it was no big deal. I was once again enjoying having a mini trampoline and jumping about 30 minutes a day, maybe 5 times a week. I'm about 100 pounds under their max weight limit. Well, sure enough, today, after owning this for less then 2 months, I heard a loud bang while jumping on it and discovered one of the springs on the floor. The actual metal of the spring had cracked in half. Looking at the reviews again, I see many 'user submitted photos' of broken springs similiar to what happened to mine. Luckily, there's enough springs on this that I didn't crash to the floor as my previous experience, but it's clear they need to get more sturdy springs for these. I contacted Amazon and they're sending a replacement, which is great, but I'm worried that one also wont last long. In conclusion, I would recommend looking at a different brand to purchase.

I have not completed the program yet, but will update as I go.This book is essentially 3 detoxes meant to help dieters get through plateaus and also to optimize health. The author advises you choose which plan based on either your weight loss goals, how much time you have, or which health issues you want to work on. I decided I'd probably try all three. I'll also add that the plans all look appropriate for vegans, vegeterian and people avoiding gluten or other food allergies. It is, however, not low carb as its a lot of fruits and vegetables. Each plan has you start the day with a smoothie and then two bowls of soup, three glasses of a special tea, and of course lunch and dinner.The three day I-Burn is supposed to target inflamation and water retention in the body, and help you lose up to 3lbs. I found Pomroys writings very inspirational, but even still I felt overwhelmed just writing the grocery list. There is an enormous amount of produce to be purchased, from the common (celery) to the unusual (daikon). I ended up paying $96 in groceries for 3 days worth of food! After starting the plan, I realize a lot is waste as she has you make twice as much of the "burn soup" for no apparent reason. I will say that after completing day 1, I'm not sure how I feel about it. The food is not very satisfying, but I understand I'm eating for the nutritional properties. It is also very hard going without dairy, bread, sugar, coffee and alcohol!Day 2 of the I-Burn. Feeling very unmotivated, I've gained a pound and my stomach feels bloated and constipated. I decided to blend a cup of coffee into my smoothie to try and get things moving. This is going against the detox, but I don't care at this point. I feel like stopping now, but don't want to waste all that food. I will say that after I was able to go to the bathroom I felt a lot better. I also added more red pepper to the soup to make it more palatable.Day 3 of the I-Burn. I again added a cup of coffee to the smoothie to help with feeling so bloated (I suspect the soup is the cause of this). The pound I gained yesterday is gone and I am back at square one. Weighing in tomorrow will show if I lost any weight at all doing this. I had to work today and this plan is even harder to follow at work. I was rushing to make the smoothie this morning and to get my soup salad and tea packed for the day. I have a lot of food left over that was never ate from this plan, and I am upset that I bought more than I needed following her recommended grocery list. I also have tons of tea and soup left over. I will dump the soup as I can't stomach the thought of eating it ever again.Final verdict. When I weighed myself I lost 2 lbs. Pretty good for three days right? Downside is I felt horrible. I was so bloated I couldn't button my pants even after losing 2lbs! I felt light headed, nauseous, and weak. I think it was maybe an electrolyte imbalance because after I had a sports drink I started feeling better. Despite the weight loss, I would never do this again and returned the book.my recommendation if you still want to try is to only make half the soup and design your own meals based on the allowed foods.

I ordered the lime green tank, knowing that it was coming from China and may be a hit or miss. Typically chinese clothes are more petite, but as I'm 5'2" and generally wear a small, I figured I would take the chance due to the low price and as I intended to wear it with pajama pants to bed. Well, this was a definitely miss! The front is very low cut, but I was going to wear it to bed so that's fine, but the scoop style in the front and back is not very flattering or attractive at all. As other's have mentioned, but is difficult to see in the photos, is that the seems are unfinished, in other words, the serged edge on the seems is on the outside, while the tags are sewn on the inside. Looks horrible. The fabric is also very cheap and clingy, I don't expect it to hold up in the washing machine. So, if you're looking to throw away $5, purchase this tank. I'll also note that since it's shipping from China, it took a month to receive.

I've worn mineral makeup for quite a few years now and try and use natural products. I wanted to search for pressed powder as it's not as messy as the loose. This had good reviews so I gave it a try. Well, it's by far the worst makeup I've ever tried. It looks so oily and cakey on my skin. I only used it a couple times and it caused me to break out horribly. My understanding from other reviews is that an older formula used to be better. Maybe that's the reason for so many good reviews? I'm not sure, but I also ordered other Pur Mineral products with this powder and they were all completely awful. Their customer service is horrible too, it took 3 weeks to get a reply to an email and when you call the phone rings and then eventually hangs up, you can't even leave a message. I would advice to avoid this company at all costs. Luckily, I was able to find Tarte cosmetics and love them. I definitely prefer their "Powderful" pressed compact better. And of course, you can purchase Tarte on Amazon.

I normally use ecotools brushes, which I've owned about 10 years and have held up wonderfully. Well, i needed a flat top brush like this one for using with pressed powder. My initial feeling on the brush was that it worked well, but sheds like crazy. After washing it, the problems worsened. a black liquid washed off of it. I assumed this was dye from the bristles. Upon drying, the brush would not return to its shape, its now puffy and splayed out. Sorry, but i need a brush that holds up and is better made. I wouldnt recommend this one.

I'm out and about most of the day for my work, lugging around a mobile printer and everything with me. This stapler is perfect for a mobile office. Its about 2 inches shorter than the standard sized stapler I have at work, but maybe 1.5x's longer than those tiny staplers. I love that it can store extra staples in it and has a built in staple remover. That said, it has all the power and functionality of a full size stapler.

I'll start by saying that my husband has a GoPro, which he's had about two years now, and so I can't help but compare the two due to them being very similiar, and I'm assuming competitors. They're similiar sizes, but the biggest difference is when you're using the gopro, you have no idea what your camera is aimed at because there's no view screen, so you don't know until you've uploaded it to your computer. The way gopro gets around this, is by taking everything 'wide angled' or 'fish eye' to basically take a large shot of everything. This Action Camera is more of a normal looking video, not so wide lensed. The gopro can also be used to take single photo shots, but again, they are wide angled so they look kind of goofy.Basically, I love that this Action Camera comes with the 'live view remote' and takes regular images. It comes with a case for taking it under water, a car mount, and a couple of extra mounts to attach to anything else you might think of, like a back pack strap, a helmet, etc. Both the Action Camera and the live view Remote use mini usb cables to charge, so no weird chargers needed.The only thing I didn't like is that the manual is not very user friendly. it's just one fold out page, with some pictures and so there was a bit of a learning curve figuring out how to use it. The camera and remote have to sync over bluetooth and that was difficult to get working without clear instructions. But now that I've got it all figured out, I'm pretty excited to take this with me when we go on vacation next.

I have naturally wavy, fine textured hair which I straighten daily. Unfortunately, if it rains or is humid, my hair will get super curly, frizzy and just kind of wild. I have tried a lot of 'frizz' products and 'humidity blocking' sprays, and not found any that really work, so I didn't have a lot of hope for this one. Well, it actually works! I've been using it on days when its going to rain/snow, and my hair will only curl slightly at most, and no frizz. Its a pretty drastic improvement. I've only used it as an after conditioning rinse, not the leave-in option, and find that it works well. I'm thrilled, I'll definitely purchase again when I run out.

I bought this locally for $5 because it seemed unusual. I know that "paper masks" are popular in Asia, and wanted to give it a try. Also, I'm a fan of tea tree oil. I'm in my 30's, by have had persistent acne most of my life. By now, I've figured out what works for me and what doesn't, and so I use tea tree oil products daily. I have combination skin as well, with a very oily T-zone and dome dry patches.The key ingredients in this seem to be tea tree oil, witch hazel, lavender, rosemary, peppermint, licorice, and glycolic acid. I like to wear the mask for 30 minutes, then when I'm done I'll also squeeze out any excess serum that was in the package and apply to my face and neck. I find that the next morning, pimples are significantly dried up.

I got these because I've been wanting a solution for visible panty lines. These are really great, and are practically invisible under clothes. I like that they weren't too tight, it's very light control. I don't want to fight with my underwear all day!  Also, the leg openings are not hemmed, it's just a straight edge, so there won't be any visible leg bands under your clothes either. What I didn't like is that the legs are a bit long. I'm 5'2", and they end about mid thigh, so they'd be visible if you wear a short skirt, or even a longer skirt when sitting down. My other complaint is that the waist band rolls down. Maybe it would help if they added some silicone around the waist band. Despite these issues, they're great under form fitting dress pants and smoothes out my figure. I plan on purchasing a couple more pairs.

I've tried a couple different wine preservation systems before and was pleasantly surprised by this. My husband and I drink wine almost everyday, but sometimes don't finish a bottle. Putting the wine in the fridge seems to help but I hate drinking cold red wine or waiting for it to warm up. I was very suspicious of this because surely you can't remove all the air from the bottle without replaving it with something else (like the argon gas systems). That said, it does seem to remove atleast some of the air and create a tight suction. I use this and then leave my wine on the counter and its still good the next day, but I wouldn't try to leave it much longer than that.

I try to use natural products. Normally I use a cream cleanser at night but wanted something easy for nights when I was tired. I bought a pack of these and they're horrible. It took two wipes to get my makeup off and I don't know that my skin is fully cleansed. The time it took scrubbing with two wipes... I could have just washed my face normally. Also, these left some kind of residue on my skin that didn't feel clean. I won't be purchasing.

I bought one of these at Total Wine after my Metrokane one stopped cutting. At first I really liked this one as the wheels were sharp and new. There are several big problems with this foil cutter though. The steel portion is just a veneer, it is not one solid piece, you can kind of see in the picture the black plastic joint. Well, the veneer would constantly pop off. I glued it multiple times, but it just wouldn't stay. The second major issue is that once it's completely closed, the opening is still too wide for smaller necked bottles and wouldn't cut. After a couple months of use the wheels got dull and I'm going to try something else.

I'm surprised no one's reviewed this yet. I got this around 6 months ago on the recommendation of an ulta sales woman. I get very dry skin on my nose especially and nothing was helping until I bought this. It keeps chronic dry patches under control. As thick and hydrating as it is, I can still wear makeup over it. I have extremely acne prone skin on top of those issues and this doesn't break me out. It's great for healing scabs, and I have even put it on pimples to speed healing. I put it on my lips at night as a lip treatment as well. I'm hoping you're seeing the range of uses for this project. One last point, it lasts forever. I've had it 6 months and I'm only halfway through the tub. If I ever run out I'll definitely re-purchase.

I try to use only natural/organic products. That said, I was having a horrible time trying to find a natural mascara that worked well. I've tried every natural mascara I know of, around 5 different products, and they all smudge terribly. The mascara would look like black circles under my eyes, which is not the look I want. I then tried this one. Its not completely natural, you can see from the ingredients, but it doesn't have any of the chemicals I avoid at all cost. So this is the best it gets I think. It stays put really well. It is water proof so can be a little hard to remove, but overall I love it and will purchase more.

I have to say, I was shocked by how big this is when I got it. I was imagining something around the size of a blender, but its actually about 2 feet tall and a foot wide. Not the dimensions in the description. It says its foor home use, but looks professional. Only fault I saw in it was the manual didn't really say how to put it together or take it apart, but I was able to figure it out. Because of how big it is, storage when not in use may be a pain. I'm thinking of keeping mine ontop of the fridge. The size also makes it too big to really take to someones house for a party.So far I have been using this for frozen alcoholic beverages. Its nice to load it with ingredients and then let the machine do the work for you. I also used it to make "coffee coolata" frozen coffee drinks one morning, which was a big hit. Any kind of frozen drink like smoothies or slushies as well is made perfectly with this.

I pray that your office fridge isn't anything like the one at my work. Stuffed to the gills with forgotten food and not very clean. You clean it one day in a massive effort, and the pigs just make it nasty again. Yuck! My previous lunch back was a brightly patterned vinyl type material, very cute, but could not survive the work fridge. Someone pressed it against the light bulb in the fridge and it melted. It picked up stains from the gross fridge as well. People would smash my bag around and things would spill, the old bag was not leak proof and I would pull it out of the fridge and the bottom would be soaked. Enter this tote: the fabric is like a durable canvas type material I am hoping will take abuse better than my old bag. The inside is a metallic type material meant to lock in heat or cold, be leak proof, and easily rinsed out to clean. Size is pretty standard, not too big or too small. The pocket on the front I don't have much use for at the moment, but could hold cutlery, gum, napkins, etc. Overall I'm hoping it will be a vast improvement on my old bag.

I really love the print on this tablecloth. My kitchen is mostly greens, reds, and blues (I like the kitchen colorful), and so this tablecloth goes great. My table is round, about 50" in diameter and the square tablecloth looks amazing on it. I really think I will probably buy some of the other prints. The big test for me was what was going to happen after I washed it, and so I waited to review until today. I washed it cold and tumble dry low. I was expecting it to shrink, but it did not shrink one bit! Even better, it wasn't even wrinkled coming out of the dryer, didn't need to iron at all. I put it back on the table and it looks just as great as before. I'm sure it would get some creases if I folded it up and stored it, but point is it's not a wrinkly fabric.

I have a chin length bob, and my hair texture is very fine and naturally kind of wavy. Just about every morning I blow dry my hair with a round brush and then straighten with a flat iron. So, I'm no stranger to heat styling my hair.First off, the description says this is "4 tools in 1". More like two tools, a flat iron and a hot brush. I've never used a hot brush like this before, but I have used a curling iron. The problem I always had with a curling iron was my hair is too short and so I would burn myself with it quite frequently. What's nice about using this as a hot brush, is the "stay cool bristles" really do stay cool! As I'm styling, I can touch it and it can touch me, and I don't get burned at all. I think it would be pretty difficult to burn yourself with this, which is a nice feature. The problem I always had with flat ironing my hair, is I'd lose volume. Using it as a hot brush, I'm able to just comb it under the hair like a round brush, and it straightens and adds volume.  I have not been successful using it to curl my hair, I think because my hair is just too short.The only issue I have, and the reason why I took a star off, is the lock feature that keeps it closed is not very sturdy. It frequently opens when I'm using it in the hot brush feature. This is annoying and I have to close and lock it again. I'm not sure if the problem is just with mine or a defect with all of them. Overall I do like it though. It heats up fast and I'm hoping it'll last for a long time.
Sorry, I wasn't impressed with this book. It's just the cabbage soup diet, which you can find free all over the internet. The rest of it is simple advice everyone should already know.

I had a similar pair of "hook" style ear buds that I just loved but lost one day. I'm happy to have these. I feel like the hook style just stays on my ears so much better. Obviously they stay on better if you're exercising, but even just sitting or walking around, they feel so much more secure. There's two caveats for why I took a star off. 1) they're a little less comfortable then the old pair I had, as if the look needs to be angled more to wrap around the ear better. 2) it comes with a reinforced cord, which is great, but its atleast a foot shorter than any other headphones I own. They'd be perfect if they just tweaked it a little, but they're good for the price.

I took two stars off because I really don't like the "Autoseal" feature of this pitcher.  Basically it forms a tight suction with the lid. To take the lid off, you hold down the buttons and pry it off. I'm a woman with small hands and really struggle to take the lid off. The elderly or someone with arthritis doesn't stand a chance. I thought this feature might be of benefit to someone with kids, but no. I turned it upside down, and it leaks terribly through the spout. To contrast, I have a glass bormoli Rocco pitcher I bought from amazon. It has a twist on lid to also form a tight seal, but is easy to remove. I tried turning that one upside down and it did not leak. Of course, the main difference is I got the contigo pitcher for the infused stick. I really like cucumber water, or adding citrus or mint, so this is great for that. I imagine the ice core would be great for when you have guests over and want to whip something up real fast. Of course, you will have to teach your guests how to use the thing!

I've been interested in having a memory foam pillow for some years and finally hot this one; I already have a memory foam bed. I should note I've been using a download pillow for about 10 years because I like a lot of memory support. The foam for this is a medium-firmness and supports my head well, but in the morning my neck was a little sore. So I took off one star. I'm not sure if a contour memory foam pillow might give a little more neck support.It should be noted that this pillow is only 4" thick at its widest. So if you like your head elevated,this isn't going to cut it. They sell ones on Amazon that are 6" thick, but they are 2x-3x' s the price (I couldn't find any thicker than that). If you are unfamiliar with memory foam, be prepared for its signature latex paint like smell. It usually takes a couple weeks for it to go away.

This "laundry cube" was horrible. First, it can only fit a couple bras, and I wear an A cup. Second, the zipper consistently opens in the wash, spilling the bras out and defeating the purpose. I had ordered two and both had this problem. I returned them

If you're looking for an inexpensive chalkboard, this will meet your expectations. With this, you get what you pay for. The wood does not have a quality finish in my opinion, the chalkboard portion is that 'chalk board paint' stuff. You could probably make a better onr fairly easily with your own frame and chalkboard paint, but I don't know if that could be done for less than the cost of this one.

I found this locally at a great price of $3.50. I love habanero hot sauce, they usually taste pretty similar. This one tastes significantly different. Like sriracha but no garlic (which isn't a good thing), it probably tastes that way because it's a lot of red pepper paste and not much habanero it seems. It was only slightly spicier than sriracha; and I like it really spicy. So, sorry, I won't be purchasing again.

I've been using mitchum deoderant for around 10 years. I loved that they don't test on animals and that it was effective for sweat and odor. About a month ago, however, they inexplicably changed the formula for the worse. It now says "oxygenated" on the label. The new gel leaves dark marks all over my clothing. I have to wait till it completely dries and then put my shirt on to avoid this. Once dry it starts flaking off and I get white flakes on my pants throughout the day. Because its flaking off, it stops being effective and I've noticed wetness and odor. I can't reapply mid day, because then I'd get the marks on my clothing! The solid version seems to still work, so I'm using that for now, although I really prefer a gel.I hope they change the formula back, because I won't buy it like this. Why did they mess with a good thing???

This is my second emergency radio. My other one was priced slightly more than this one, but also has features I like better. This particularly one, is a nice compact size, about the length of my hand. It comes with a rechargeable lithium battery, but also a slot for 3 AA batteries. It has a very small solar panel which feeds the lithium battery, However, due to the small size, don't expect that solar panel to do much, and the manual says it will not fully charge the battery.. It also has a crank to charge the lithium battery, or the whole thing can be plugged in to charge. The radio has a flashlight, but it's very dim. The radio itself has a lot of static. One final feature to mention is you can hook a USB to the device in order to charge a cell phone. In short, I would probably not recommend this particular model and would advise spending a little bit more for something that works better.

I'll start by saying that I like the Ecotools brand. I use their makeup brushes and have had them around 6 years and they still look brand new. So, that said, I was excited to see this brush. I had purchased a paddle brush with bamboo handle by a different company awhile ago and it was a lot more expensive. I needed to replace my old round brush, but didn't want to spend a lot of money. This brush also has the bamboo handle, with recycled plastic body. The barrel is large, but I like that in a round brush (I have chin length hair), I use a wide barrel to build volume. I didn't notice any snagging or tangling with this brush, but I have been styling with a round brush everyday for around 15 years and have short hair. I didn't notice it necessarily drying my hair faster than my old round brush, but the old one was vented too. The fact that the body of the brush is plastic and not metal, I'm hoping will  be less heat damaging. Over all I'm satisfied and are looking forward to more products from Ecotools being released.

The fabric is not what I expected in person. It looks like bathing suit material, or something you'd make into a a child's dance recital costume. It's that thin, shiny latex type material. Would be nice for lounging in the house, or a BBQ or something, but I wouldn't want to wear it out to the mall or work. The fabric is simply too thin and too shiny.

I use this for work, as I'm out of the office visiting various locations all day. I have a larger organizer, but sometimes I want to have just a few of the essentials and this is good for that. 3 tabs to separate things, and I use the pocket for business cards. I'm not too sure how good it would be for personal travel, as it wouldn't fit in my purse and I wouldn't want to carry it. I took a star off as it seems overpriced. I could buy a portfolio for $14. I went online to price match, but amazon appears to be the only one selling this at this time.

Based on the title of this product, I wrongly assumed this calendar was magnetic and could go the fridge. Instead, the calendar is not magnetic, but comes with two small magnets. The magnets are fairly purposely, because I have no desire to secure something on top of the calendar and be unable to read it. So, I was surprised that I had to attach it with sticky foam pads to the wall. I don't like using that stuff because it's nearly impossible to get it off the wall cleanly.  A solution is to glue some magnets on the back. Other than that, the calendar is fine. It's not very large, so there's not much space. It would be hard to fit more than one appointment on a day, or a detailed note.

I try to use only organic/natural products, so I was excited to use this. All the negative reviews are right, the tube dries up fast and has a short life. The mascara smudges all over the under eye. I'd have to wipe under my eyes frequently to remove the dark circles. I'm currently going mascara-less while I search for another brand as I'm tired of 'looking goth'. I like physicians formula, but encourage them to improve this product.

I've been sleeping with a white noise machine going for maybe 15 years and I love them, they really help me sleep to the point that I take it with me when I go on vacation. Prior to this one, I had been using a Marpac brand 'sleep conditioner', which is maybe half the price of this Homedics one and works fine. With this Homedic white noise machine, instead of just one sound, there are multiple, from white noise type sounds to nature sounds, etc. Once you've selected the sound, you can then adjust the volume and tone for even more customization. It has a little remote that comes with it, but half the buttons don't work on it, and the other half of the buttons don't work on the actual device. So, every time I use it, I have to use both the remote and the buttons on it to get what I want. This seems like a big flaw, and other reviews have mentioned buttons that don't work. The other thing about this is that it glows super bright. Like most people who have trouble falling asleep, I'm sensitive to light as well. You can adjust the dimness to turn the glow off, but even completely off the buttons still glow VERY brightly. I had to tape a piece of cardboard over the buttons to block out the glowing. This device also has the option to set a timer for the sound, from half an hour to an hour and a half. I always turn that off because I want it to play throughout the night. Oddly, even with the timer off, occasionally the sound will suddenly turn off halfway through the night for no particular reason. This wakes me up and then I have to turn it back on. Overall, if this worked right, I would recommend it. However, with all the other reviews saying this sound machine is glitchy and my own experiences, I cannot. I'd recommend one of the cheaper, simpler white noises sound on Amazon instead.

Order your true size, very stretchy and runs big. I order Yellow in Medium after reading the seller measurement and it was too big. I then ordered Blue in Small, fits great, still a bit loose on me. Am 5'10" tall. The skirt is long enough for high wait, am never a crop top kinda chic but this is a lovely combo, even my conservative hubby approves. Pics to follow.Shipping was 2 week, very fast.

DO NOT BUY..I ordered small, what I received was a joke. Too short, thigh high, too short, too large. I was expecting a below the knee figure hugging dress, this is not a dress, more like a t-shirt , also made from very light t-shirt material.
Very nice but delicate.
Very cool and on point!I actually wore it to church and received quite a few compliments.
I ordered Medium as always with Asian sizes. Very figure hugging.  I couldn't possibly wear underwear under this material so commando it is.Am 5'10" tall, 137lbs. I normally wear US Small or 4/6
Beautiful.Ordered Medium, received large but I hand fixed the waist to fit me. Am a Small normal size. 5'10" tall.

This dress had lots of potential but it's a total fail. I laid in next to my 3 year old daughter's dress and it looks like it was meant for a 5 year old girl. If you are older than 5, DO NOT buy this dress. It's pretty, but can't even be worn as a top. I guess i'll fix it for my daughter when she turns 5. I buy from China every other day, this is my first failed purchase.And it's pink, NOT red.

I ordered a Medium, my true size is small. The only photo displayed at the time of me buying was the 1st photo with the model. The skirt ruffles made the dress look fancy. But what i received in the mail is the photo of the dress on the mannequin. Not flattering at all. The top is lace with no lining. It's a long dress but without the ruffles it's just a flat dress. The top is also very big, even for a medium. I do no recommend.

This dress is bright yellow, which is an even prettier color than the eggplant looking color online. It's a lovely dress, except it's a bit snugI ordered small, my true size, I can barely squeeze in, will have the hem taken out to give me a more comfortable fit. I advise you order one size up.

I took a gamble on this dress and it worked.  Ordered Small,  my true size.  Am 5'10", and I order from China every other day and know not to expect a maxi dress to turn out as maxi on me. Buy it is a true maxi. The top part is a bit loose for me, but then am a 32B. The hips are a tad bit tight but I'll get by just fine. The length is perfect, especially when I adjust the straps. The material is VERY see through. ...definitely wear under slip, it's not lined. From the hips going down, it's too baggy for me, again,  I don't mind it too much. The seller description says polyester,  but it's like Viscose to me. Not too much stretch.See my fitting below.I say, order your size. I did.

First, am not showing to be a Verified purchaser because i didn't order it from my account, my husband did and had just do review.So, I see  a lot of reviews about the sizing of this dress being off, I can't understand why. My husband ordered the black dress in Small, my true US size or 4-6, 26" waist. This dress fits like it was custom made for me! I mean..pure perfection! The length too, for my height (5' 10" ), fits right at my knees. Very elegant fit, nice thick material. Very conservative dress but can be sexied up with right accessories, shoes etc.I will post a photo in a while. Buy this dress! Thank you hubby!Here is a photo.

Very sexy in a conservative way, and by that I mean, not revealing at all. I ordered Small, fits great, even still roomy at the hips. Am 5'10" tall and wear US 4/6 or Small. DraftSight is probably easy for people with a background in engineering, drafting, architecture or any other design field where CAD is taught as part of a degree or certificate program. Unfortunately, my background is as a hobbyist who wants to figure out how to accurately make stuff with a CNC machine, a 3d printer, or a laser cutter, stuff like buildings for model railroads, parts for model airplanes and that sort of thing. Besides, I recently took up a project where at least a basic understanding of all things CAD/CAE/CAM is going to be useful.There are a whole bunch of different programs that each do different parts of the things I want to do, so I figure the thing is to just dive into one of the programs and learn how to use it. So, for better or worse, DraftSight is the program that I am going to have to learn...on my own.I wish there was a bit more "Do this, then do this, then do this followed by that" in the first few chapters, but it beats the heck out of the instructional materials available from Dassault.I am a long way from being through with this book, but so far I have been able to do everything explained in the first three chapters and I am beginning to understand how the program works and what it does.CAD is not like word processing, you can't just start drawing crudely and then use the program to begin to do things faster and more accurately. There is a whole bunch of stuff that you have to know immediately to even make a simple line drawing. Anyway, I am going slow, and at the moment I am procrastinating by writing this review rather than working with the program.Back to the salt mines...

I dropped my Earlex gun and put a big dent in the can. It is still tight and works just fine, but I thought a spare would be a good idea. I do wish Earlex would sell a lid to go with the cans so I could keep my preferred finish in the can between uses rather than wasting the finish that sticks to the sides when I pour the excess back into its original container. Still, this does what I need it to do and the price is fair.

I bought this book in 2009. At the time, it was just about the only thing out there to help a non-engineer hobbyist or woodworker seriously dive into the project of building a CNC machine for the home shop. I did begin the process of building my own machine and got as far as cutting out all the MDF parts and obtaining some of the mechanical and electronic parts. But the further I dove into the project, the more I came to understand that my knowledge of things like Scalable Vector Graphics, G-Code, and of digital electronics and computer programming in general were lacking, and also far outside the scope of this book. I started playing around with Arduino, C++ programming, analog and then digital electronics, a local robotics society, and another advanced degree program, and I ended up putting this book aside, but that is NOT the fault of this book. CNC ended up on the back burner while I pursued other projects, but now I am back into it again.Currently I am building an X-Carve machine and should have it running in a few days. That caused me to go back and re-read this book, and to borrow a few others from the library, and truthfully, despite some great advances in the home shop/hobbyiest CNC arena, this is still a pretty good book on building and operating a CNC machine in the home shop. But it is important to realize that learning to use a CNC machine, or any other high technology endeavor is like peeling an onion, no one book is going to answer all your questions or tell you everything you need to know, and each thing you learn inspires a dozen new questions.I view this book as a good introduction to CNC. It will leave you with a clear understanding of how such things work. It will provide you with instructions that a literate, mechanically inclined, person with an intuitive understanding of basic engineering principles can follow. It is NOT a cookbook. You will have to do additional research, maybe even hit the library, the Intergoogler, or your local maker space for additional help. But this book will get you started and allow you to ask intelligent questions as you build a machine of your own.I do hope that Jim Kelly writes an updated version, but this book will set you on your way if you really want to build a CNC machine.

This is an old book and I had to read well into the fourth chapter before I figured out what the author was talking about. Then suddenly I realized that I was holding a guide book to arts and crafts design. I began to see that the author was talking about the proportions and design sensibilities of the Arts and Crafts movement and applying them to everything that might exist in the built environment, from book cases to motor cars. I've long been drawn to Arts and Crafts style houses, cabinets, and furniture, but had trouble creating my own designs to solve modern problems while retaining the lines and feel of the arts and crafts movement. Scaling a classic Stickley design to create, for example, a media cabinet, just wasn't working for me. I knew I needed to work from a fresh sheet of paper and not just copy or incorporate arts and crafts elements to get the Craftsman look.With this book, I have another piece of the puzzle. It is a sort of exercise book that might have been used in secondary schools between the wars. It is hard to follow and presumably the students who used this also had an industrial arts instructor prodding them in the right direction. But after a while I found I really could figure it out, particularly if I read it while sitting at a drafting board with pencil and t-square instead of trying to doodle it out in Sketch-Up.Neat little book.

I use a Shop Vac along with a small canister dust separator to control the dust from my sanders, small power tools, and compound miter saw. I have found it easiest to equip the vacuum with a long hose (20 feet) that I trail to the various machines rather than trying to drag the vacuum and the dust separator through the labyrinth that is my workshop. But this means constantly having to work my body through the maze to turn on the vacuum. Being lazy, or in a hurry, I either don't bother to turn on the vacuum for a quick cut, or I leave the vacuum running between operations, to the annoyance of the household. (Noise doesn't bother me, I'm wearing my earmuffs!)Still, leaving the vacuum running constantly is probably not good for it, and not turning it on makes for a messy shop. I thought about wiring up a couple of 3-way switches to control the vacuum, but snaking the wire and installing boxes is not my favorite pastime. After buying this at W*****t, I came here to torture myself for paying too much.This remote is rated 13 amps which should handle my large vacuum for the long haul. I haven't tested the range of the remote, but the vacuum hose, along with it's extensions can make up 40 feet and the range is at least that. The remote has separate "on" and "off" buttons and is equipped with a key chain. I removed the key chain and replaced it with a nice heavy piece of red white and blue ribbon to hang over pegs near each of the tools, but I still kept losing the remote. Then I added a carabiner and made a permanent home for the remote on a peg near the shop's light switch. Now I come into the shop, flip on the lights and clip the remote to a belt loop so it's handy wherever I am.I'm happy as a clam now...except for 2 little gripes. One is that I wish the remote had larger buttons and maybe molded from green (for on) and red (for off) plastic. I'll maybe fix this with plastic model paint, but a factory job would be nicer. The other gripe is that the base unit has a hang slot for just one screw. It ended up hanging by it's cord and I didn't like that. So I added a strip of "Industrial Strength" Velcro loop tape to the back of the base unit and a strip of hook tape on the wall. All squared away now.Initially I thought that it would be nice to have a manual over ride switch on the base unit. But in practice, I've never felt any need and suspect such a switch would unnecessarily raise the cost. I'm fine without, thanks.Bottom line, it is a great little accessory in my workshop and I am quite pleased with how well it works.

From reading other reviews, I was somewhat concerned that I would not get a well mastered DVD or that this would be in some awkward format. But it sure looks high-def to me, and the movie was every bit as good as I remember from seeing it as a first run in a real movie theater. Seeing Branagh's interpretation of Shakespeare makes it much easier to read the Bard's plays in general, and while Henry V has some tough scenes for kids, I think the language as spoken in this film will help both of mine better appreciate the Shakespeare that I HOPE they are going to get as they proceed from middle school to high school and beyond.

Some people have complained that because this was partly funded by the Koch Foundation, it must be biased. But, while this video avoids taking a stand on climate change, it explains, with a high degree of clarity, how and why we know so much about how the earth is responding to increased greenhouse gas emissions. It is crystal clear from this program that scientists are able to measure and monitor the Earth with a high degree of accuracy and should give most people confidence in the accuracy and truth of the conclusions shared by the overwhelming majority of climate scientists.

Every couple of years I buy whatever recent book Taunton Press has published on general carpentry. I don't build houses any more, but I do like to know how recommended practices have changed as more advanced materials have come to market and as we gain a better understanding of how buildings live and breathe with better insulation, vapor barriers, and high efficiency systems. Plus, knowing a trade paid my way through school and I have a couple of cubs around here that could do with some training up in current best construction practices so they have the same opportunity.This book covers traditional framing techniques quite well, gives great tips to help newer/younger carpenters to work more efficiently. Covers more power and pneumatic tools than earlier books which focused on hand tool work. I compare it favorably to Bob Syvanen and Larry Haun's books. If you are just getting started in the trades as a cub and are willing to do a bit of reading to get up to speed with that grumpy old guy you are working with, this is a good way to figure out what he was trying to tell you as he framed up that rake wall.sed to ask. (Tip, if you are not sure, do ask. It's much better to ask a "stupid question" than to screw up a building and get tagged by an inspector...or your foreman, and while the crew might razz you, most leads will appreciate it if you show that you are willing to learn.)

I bought soft covers for the kid's Kindles, but within a few month I regretted not buying these instead. Had to be patient because they were out of stock for a while. But it sure is nice that all of our reading devices are now securely boxed up in hard shell cases. I was worried because some reviews say it is hard to get to the device controls, but we haven't had that problem. The cases stand up well to abuse, and while I do wish the kids would take better care of their toys, it is nearly mandatory that kids have some sort of device for school use these days and I feel better with them sealed up in Otter Boxes.

If you have a worn ring gear, this kit may be your only option, but this is not the "best quality" cutter set you probably want if you are the sort of person who likes to maintain things instead of contributing to the land fill.It is an adequate replacement cutter, but of lesser quality than the OEM cutter. Description is misleading. Required much modification and time in the workshop to rehab my 1606 sharpener. Fortunately, the 1606 sharpener is built to be easy dismantled, and it is easy to remove and replace the worn parts. It was clearly designed for longevity and for easy repair.Unfortunately, x-Acto/Elmers/Avery DO NOT make the commonly needed repair parts readily available.IF there was a listing for the proper cutter set for my commercial 1606 sharpener, I would have admitted to consumer error in purchasing the wrong set. However, Amazon does not have ANY listing for the proper cutter set, and this is the only listed replacement set that includes the ring gear (gray plastic gear with internal teeth) that was the most severely worn part of my sharpener.My sharpener failed because a student tried to sharpen the wrong end of a pencil and jammed the eraser ferrule into the cutters. This caused the drive gear teeth to shear off of one of the cutters, and destroyed the ring gear that spins the cutters normally. I ordered this set because it appeared from the photograph to be a dual cutter head that matched the existing cutter head in my sharpener and because it contained the needed ring gear. This is the only parts listing I could find that contained the ring gearFortunately, only one of my cutters was damaged, and was easily removed with a screwdriver. Unfortunately, the single cutter in this set is installed in such a way that I had to destroy the frame to remove the cutter and swap it into the still serviceable cutter frame in my machine.

This book would be great for parents of younger kids who have an affinity for chess, but not for older kids and not for kids who already have a moderate understanding of the game. I bought this book and several others to teach chess tactics to my group of gifted students, but the students who already knew a bit about chess were not willing to do the exercises and the kids who didn't know chess preferred to work it out by trial and error, playing against their peers.Anyway, I shelved it with the rest of my classroom "chess library" and the kids do pull it down occasionally to see if they can find some new gambit or strategy. But it's not one of their "go to" sources.Probably if I taught chess to 7/8-year-olds, this would be a great source. But for middle school kids, not so much.
Phone is as good as new with this battery.

People I know keep citing "The Bell Curve" in justification of all sorts of racist, sexist, and other harebrained biases. I figured I'd better read it, and did, a couple of month ago. Throughout the book I kept thinking "uh...no...that's not a valid conclusion..." but not being thoroughly trained in statistics, I couldn't precisely pin down the problems.Fortunately, Stephen Jay Gould DOES have a clear understanding of data analysis. The Bell Shaped Curve is a load of crap and this book clearly explains why.

This is a nicely produced book. I bought it for my students to use for the Science Olympiad and since I have other Audubon field guides that I really like, I decided to buy it for myself and lend it to the kids instead of using the supply budget.I'm not exactly sure why I would want a "field guide" for the weather and am not likely to carry this in my day pack. But for observing present conditions and gaining an understanding of what observations might portend for the future weather, this is a nice little book and I expect to keep it handy along with the bird, plant, insect, and star guides we keep near the back porch door.

Greg Harvey writes well and in this book, he eschews much of the silliness that creeps into other "Dummies" books. It is an outstanding, step by step guide with hands on examples for guided practice to learn and efficiently use not only the main features of Excel, but also the semi "hidden" features that speed up your work and make it easier to build spreadsheets that are easier to use and to read.I am pleased to have the text, but I do regret not having the paper bound version. Kindle is great for reading novels, biographies, histories and the like, but for technical reading, the electronic format, whether on my Kindle, computer, or tablet, is not comfortable. I need to be able to highlight, write in the margins, add sticky notes and spill coffee on my technical books, and you just can't do that with electronic text. I knew that before I bought this, but I was snowed in so the Kindle edition was my only choice.Also, the paperbound version of this book comes with sample files and videos bundled on a disk. Some of the videos are available on the publisher's website, but they are hard to find and not in any organized order. It would be much better to have the disk.Still, this book is well done. Mr. Harvey tells you EXACTLY how to use the features of Excel in excruciating detail that some will find a bit pedantic. But frankly, that is exactly what I was hoping for. Just a couple of the lesser known tricks for using the AutoFill feature for example, have already saved me time and the keyboard short-cut of adding an apostrophe before data entry so that Excel treats a number as "text" instead of a value, is among the many other useful and powerful tips that I simply would not have learned by using a typical reference book.Having started using computers when Lotus 123 was king, I never really forced myself to learn the ins and out of Excel, and this book has already shown me dozens of ways to use the program more efficiently and get things done more quickly.The text is not only worth the price, it is worth the time I am spending to do the exercises.I am giving this book five stars for its content, but adding that caveat that it would have been well worth the wait and the expense of obtaining the bound version instead of the Kindle edition.

Better than the original, and not just because of the length. Securely clicks into the cable port of the I-Pad. Wire is a bit stiff, but this seems to keep the cable from tangling.I am adding 110 volt receptacles with USB power ports at several locations in the house and will probably buy several of these cables to just leave in the places where I frequently use the I-pad...at my night stand, the desk in my office, and on the end table where I keep my reading/writing supplies.

I don't know much about basketball...actually I didn't know anything... but both of my kids love the game and I got tired of watching them play without having the slightest idea what they were doing. Now I know quite about more about the rules and strategies of youth basket ball, a bit more about what the coaches are trying to do, and what the people around me are talking about when they grumble about the referee's calls. The book also provided good guidance when I installed a hoop for the kids and when they wanted me to mark out a court on the driveway. Maybe next year I'll even be willing to help as a temporary junior assistant substitute coach.

I bought my TI-5045 adding machine when I was taking an accounting class in college in 1982. I have never changed out the ink cartridge because by the time the original cartridge began to fade in the mid nineties, I could not find one. The print remained sufficiently legible to find a mis-entry, but not dark enough to photocopy, and I began to ration use of the paper tape. But with this cartridge, the machine prints clearer and better than I can ever remember.I did not realize that the seller would send two, so, even better if I can remember where I store the spare.

Regrettably, I did not buy this at Amazon. If I had, I would have sent it back. As it is, this is a "coffee maker kit" and if you are willing to hack at it, you can make it into a serviceable machine. But it tends to make an annoying mess every morning, and who needs any extra annoyance when you are just trying to get out the door with a hot cuppa in the morning?I bought this to replace a Krups that I have used daily for 25 years. The Krups still works fine, but it is a commercial, two pot machine that overwhelms my small kitchen. As the only coffee drinker in the family, I wanted something a bit smaller.I don't know what they mean by "five cups". A cup is 8 ounces, and the carafe for this machine holds 26 ounces (the reservoir only holds 24) so I would call this a "three cup" machine. But it does fill my 15oz travel cup for my commute and a 10oz vacuum bottle for a warm-up mid morning. It has a timer that automatically starts the machine in the morning, and only starts it if I have prepared it with water and grounds the night before. It makes pretty good coffee. If I'd written this review the day after I brought this home, that's all I'd have to say and this would have been a four star review.The thing is, I really wanted to love this machine and for the first week I worked hard to accommodate or overlook its shortcomings. After that, I decided to put up with its annoyances, but each morning it ticks me off just a bit more and I don't like starting my day ticked off.The first problem is the carafe is drippy. In stock condition, it is really hard to pour coffee without spilling. This is partly due to the lid, its opening is too small. I attacked the lid with a scroll saw, cleaned it up with a Dremel tool and improved it, a bit, but I still spill coffee probably three days out of 5. Unfortunately, I can't just get rid of the lid, it is required in order to open the interrupter valve and allow coffee to drip into the carafe. I'll probably remove that in the next few weeks.The reservoir is equipped with a pair of mostly hidden, and frankly, unnecessary "overflow" holes. I assume that most people fill the carafe at the sink and then dump the carafe into the machine. Unfortunately, the overflow holes are too low. A full carafe overfills the reservoir and you end up with water all over the counter. Other reviews of this machine mention that it "leaks". Well here's why, you can't easily see the overflow holes and the "water level gauge" is essentially unreadable unless you stare straight down into the reservoir with strong light directly overhead, so you only know that you have filled the reservoir when water starts to flow all over the counter.The reservoir fill opening is obstructed by the spray arm assembly, the useless water level gauge, a cheesy "chlorine filter" assembly, and the reservoir lid which won't hinge back far enough for you to position the carafe squarely over the opening when you fill it with cold water. Not only do these obstruct your view of the overflow holes so that you can't see when the water reaches them, but they also make it difficult to pour water into the obstructed openings without splashing water everywhere.I made filling a bit easier by removing the water level gauge. I also removed the unnecessary chlorine filter (Coffee makers use a heat activated pump that brings the water to a boil, aerating it and flaring off the chlorine, so the filter is just a gimmick. Besides, no one sells the silly filter cartridges).The machine is hard to clean. The filter basket, permanent filter, and carafe, can all run through the dishwasher of course, but there is also a basket holder, and other parts of the machine with many hard to clean nooks and crannies that collect scale, stray coffee grounds, and other kitchen grotus. It grosses me out just knowing that there are pockets of guck inside the machine I can't completely clean.Coffee oils tend to condense on the spray arm and while this shouldn't affect the taste of the coffee, again, it's hard to clean and looks grotty.So, today, I gave the machine it's monthly cleaning. I was so annoyed with the water and vinegar I spilled and splashed everywhere while descaling it, and then with trying to clean the nooks and crannies with a tooth brush, that I dunked it (UNPLUGGED OF COURSE) in mild soapy water in the sink and attacked it with a scrub brush. Then I ran it through the dishwasher. It came out pretty clean, but more surprisingly, I didn't kill it.Post dishwasher, the clock, automatic timer, pump and warmer plate all still work. So there's a plus, it's a tough machine.I'll make a couple of plugs out of Sugru to fill the stupid overflow holes. I'll remove the drip interrupter so that it will work without the lid on the carafe. I'll learn to pour with greater care, and I guess I'll run it through the dishwasher every month or so since that's the only way to get it clean.Still, I wanted a simple machine with a timer that doesn't make a mess, instead I got a hobby project.

These are very good quality, heavy duty shelf brackets. They have a sturdy finish. They have countersinks in the bottom that hold screws to secure them to your shelf material, and KV sells prefinished screws that match the finish of these brackets for a professional looking installation.I actually bought these to use as part of a lumber storage rack in my garage. The 10.5" length allows me to use the area along the wall, above the horizontal run of the garage door track for lumber storage. The shorter length allows me to angle lumber up between the door track and the end of the brackets, whereas below the door track I have used 14" brackets.I installed five 48" standards on 32" centers and screwed them to the wall with 3", #12 wood screws. I have six rows of these or the 14" brackets installed on the standards which allows me to have 6 "bunks" of lumber on each standard. I have them loaded quite heavily and have complete confidence in their ability to hold the load.Although I have used these in my shop, I think they would not be out of place in a more finished space such as a craft room or den...they have a sort of mid-century modern look.

I bought this for my daughter who has wanted a pocket knife since her older brother was permitted to have one. She loves it but had to be reminded that it IS a knife and cannot be with her at school. It's a nice little knife with scissors useful for trimming your nails, a nail file, the typical Swiss Army Knife tweezers and tooth pick, and a blade that is just right for opening letters and boxes and maybe whittling a gee-haw whimmy-diddle, or sharpening a pencil.If you were stranded on a desert island, you'd wish you had a bigger knife, but for most every-day purposes, this is a nice little pocket knife.

There are several of these advertised on Amazon. Picking the right one was really a crap-shoot. The product descriptions are all pretty generic and the photos aren't much help. I read the reviews and tried to glean as much product information as I could and I think I chose the best one, but many of the reviews seem to be from people who don't really know what a J-Roller is for.The purpose of a J-roller is to apply pressure to plastic laminate in order to firmly bond it to your chosen substrate. It could also be use to apply pressure to linoleum, sheet vinyl, vinyl tile, rubber baseboards, or any other sort of sheet material that needs brief but firm contact pressure to activate or adhere an adhesive layer between two smooth, flat surfaces. But don't use it for spreading glue or contact cement, you will ruin it in short order, which is what my "helper" did to my last one.Anyway, on this roller, the roller itself is of reasonably pliable, but hard rubber which allows plenty of pressure to activate contact cement. There is an internal "bearing" roller of, probably HDPE or UHMW PE that rolls smoothly on the steel shaft. The roller itself is secured to the shaft with snap rings, so there is a chance you might be able to get it apart and clean it if your "cub" dips it into a can of contact cement. The one piece shaft/handle is of steel and is quite stiff, so you can bear down hard if need be.I understand that inexperienced workers may be bothered by the plastic grips which indeed can slip on the handle, but if the grips are slipping around on you, you are not using the tool correctly. Apply pressure perpendicular to the shaft, not radially or parallel to it.
