Every J-roller I have owned or used had the same "problem".In any event, it is JUST a J-Roller and while I suppose someone could make a ridiculously expensive one with ball bearings and leather grips, that would really be a waste. If you need a J-Roller, this seems to be a good one and unless another helper ruins it, I expect it to be the last one I'll buy.

The roller head on this bottle works well and is about what I had expected. Beats spreading the glue around with a stick. The bottle itself is made of pretty soft polypropylene which makes it easier to control the flow of glue, but I suspect that it could split or be punctured easily if you dropped it or banged it against something sharp, but I'm not really worried about that.The roller cap is removable so you can take it off to clean it and the manufacturer has provided a separate screw-on lid to keep the bottle air-tight between uses.The only complaint I have is that the manufacturer has supplied a small molded plug that is supposed to cap the glue orifice when you are not using the bottle, this is attached to a molded "leash" which should keep you from losing the plug. Unfortunately the leash is stiff and tends to pull the plug out of the bottle. The cap itself is not really well molded and it doesn't want to stay in place. I clipped off the plug and threw it away. But I am not knocking off any stars, the roller has to be removed and cleaned after every use anyway and there is not any reason to try to use the roller cap as a lid for the bottle between gluing sessions.

As advertised, it's an OEM battery for the LG flip phone. We seem to get about 18 months out of cell phone batteries. Our phones are getting really old and I figured that it might be hard to find a replacement battery next time around, so I bought 2 this time. Note that if you do this, Lithium ion batteries don't respond well to being stored in a drawer un-used, so trade them around every 2-3 months, and make sure they have a full charge before you store one away.

Took a long trip this summer and neglected bring the charger for the camera, which left the best parts of our trip a bit undocumented. I thought it might be smart to have an extra battery and a charger for the car, but when I stopped into one of the big electronics stores and saw the prices, I balked. When I found this combination on Amazon, I thought the price was a bit too good to be true, but the batteries seem to work fine and the charger works as promised both in the car and when plugged into the wall. I will probably keep the charger permanently in the car. The HDMI cable appears to work just as well as the factory supplied one. I don't have much use for the extra one, but it does work and seems well made.

These are hefty USB Male A to Micro B Cables. I bought a pair of these to connect to a USB power hub in the car so that the kids could charge their cameras and use their Kindles on a long car trip without drawing down the batteries to 0%. The cables are long enough that the kids could comfortably sit back and read. Other than that, there is not much to say. They are well made, they "click-in" to the devices and the charger port reassuringly and they seem to stand up to my son's tendency to forget he is plugged in and rip the cable out of the wall. He'll need another one in a few months, and will have to pay for it himself, but since these are reasonably priced, it won't be too costly a lesson (unless he breaks the device instead of the cable!)

First, I've had this chip separator for 2 years. I did not buy it at Amazon. It works ok for smaller stationary power tools such as router tables, lunch box planers, and bench top jointers. I upgraded to the most powerful shop vac I could find and it handles my 13" planer if I make light cuts on narrow stock. But run a 2x10 through it, and much of the chip load from the planer passes through the separator and into the vacuum.Still, even on a large power tool, it is more effective than a vacuum alone, and much better than nothing at all. Let's be clear, the Dust Right DOES WORK. I immediately had a cleaner workshop. I went from completing the annoying process of dumping out the vacuum and cleaning it's pleated filter almost daily, to easily dumping the Dust Right once a week.It is MUCH easier to empty the separator than the vacuum and with the separator, you can use HEPA filter bags in the vacuum and only have to replace those about once a year. So, this should be a 5 star review, and it would have been if I'd written it 18 months ago. But I know so much more now!Here are the problems:Some people complain that the lid is hard to remove. But then talk about how hard it is to "snap the lid on and off". This is not a real problem. The lid does not snap on. it twists on and off. It does take a bit of time to get the knack of twisting off the lid, but the lid is easy to remove once you do.Second issue. It is tall and narrow, so it tips over all the time. When it tips over, gravity is no longer on your side and all the chips you have collected go immediately to the vacuum, which is what you were trying to avoid by buying this separator in the first place. So, it's a solve-able problem. Buy a package of clothesline rope, snug the dust right up next to your shop vac and bind them together with the rope so they roll around as one unit. This works really well and will give you a unit that's not much bigger than the very expensive Festool extractor. But wow, it's ugly, and we are craftsmen here, right?So, make elaborate plans to build a rolling cart that will contain your shop vac, the separator, a nice drawer for spare vacuum cleaner filter bags...Ain't nobody got time for that...amirite? Naw...So you rig up a block of 2x4 and cut a couple of radiuses out of the sides to hold the vacuum and the separator in alignment so the tension of the rope doesn't twist everything around.The other problem is that lid should have a wider radius. The inlet should enter tangent to the outside of the lid as far outboard as possible, and the exhaust should be centered. Then the heavier chips and dust would swirl around the walls and then drop to the bottom of the bucket, while the relatively clean exhaust air would be forced to the center and out to the vacuum. Add a Thein baffle and you'd be goldent...but still, it's tippy and that rope arrangement makes it a pain to empty, almost as bad as dealing with the vacuum...The Dust Right is better than nothing at all. In fact it is substantially better, and if you are a handy homeowner or a mere mortal, it may be all you need. But if you are aspiring to seriously gear up and whisper wood, the internet swarms with even better, home built alternatives that can be put together for less than the price of the dust right, and if you are reading this, you are a craftsman, right?

This is not the "Best" of the Moody Blues. It's more like "A few snippets of some of the Moody Blues better tunes, heavily edited so we could cram it onto one CD and squeeze a bit more cash out of our master tapes".If you were alive and listening to the radio in the 1970's, you will probably recognize most of the music on this album. If you liked the Moody Blues, you will probably like this just fine, at least at first. But after a few times through the album, you'll begin to wonder, "gee, wasn't there more to that track..." All of the tracks here...well, except for "Go now", what the heck is that doing on here? are recognizably great Moody Blues, but there is lots of stuff missing that ought to be on a "Best of" album, probably, it should have been a two record set.Another reviewer wondered why this album includes GO Now, and leaves out "Late Lament". I totally agree. The version of Go Now on this albumn sounds like it was recorded by someone in the back seat who had a cassette recorder, and held it up to the radio speaker while Go Now was playing on a distant AM station. Maybe Go Now is important in the history of the Moody Blues, but it sure is a waste of bytes on a "Best of" albumn.

I bought it for her version of Just the Way You Are, but I keep it for everything else. This is a nice album, and while I usually eschew "live" albums because I want to hear the artist, not the room, I really liked the way Diana Krall sings that old Billy Joel tune. Fortunately the Paris crowd was polite and all of the tracks on this album sound good. The crowd actually does enhance the feel of the music, and maybe I should not be so critical of "live" albums...

Filled with great ideas for cool projects on the cheap. While I bought this to use in a school setting, this book is filled with ideas for cool things anyone could do with kids. I plan to offer a series of afterschool opportunities to "make stuff" this fall, and the projects in this book are well suited to using up paper towel rolls, drinking straws, paper clips, interesting food containers, and lots of other "stuff" that you have laying around, or have been saving because it looks like something you could do something with, someday.Improvising, tinkering, fooling around with junk or whatever you want to call it, this book is filled with suggestions of ways that kids can create new stuff from old stuff. Collect the old stuff and put it in boxes or tubs. Give kids some suggestions from this book, or no suggestions, except to build something that (flies, floats, rolls, hops, whatever). Kids will come up with cool stuff to make.Great book.

I took off on a long summer car trip and neglected to bring my phone charger with me...subconsciously, I probably did that on purpose, but nevertheless, I found myself with a nearly dead battery. I powered down the phone, leaving enough juice, I hoped, to make an emergency call if needed. Fortunately, it wasn't.Still, I figured I'd better have a spare charger on hand. But I couldn't find one to fit my practically antique Tracfone. I visited one a big electronics outlet that is famous for having, literally, everything. I found a charger that fit my old phone, but I was not willing to pay $60 for it.Then I found this deal. I didn't really need two chargers, but since my father-in-law has a phone similar to mine, I bought this pair. I gave one to him. It works on both of our phones and just a couple of days ago, I took off on another long trip with a dead phone. I had this charger in the glove box, and in short order, the phone was charged up and ready again.I figure that with something like a simple phone charger, it either works and gets five stars, or it doesn't work and it gets 1. This works. It gets five stars.

Is this an important book? Probably. But it's not as helpful as I had hoped.  Dweck proposes that some people believe they have innate abilities from birth and that's all there is. Once they reach a developmental plateau based on that innate ability, they think they cannot get any better. Others think that with hard work, they can figure out how to get better at anything. Bad at math? With practice I can get better. No good at music? Keep practicing. She is right of course, with practice and study over time, any of us can get better at anything. And while we are, some of us, better suited for one thing than another, our minds are capable of growth in every area. None of us should accept a judgment from anyone, including our selves that we "...just cant do" math, or foreign languages, or particle physics.But anyone who read Johnathon Livingston Seagull already knew this, "Argue for your limitations and sure enough, they're yours." Richard Bach knew it intuitively. But for those who are skeptical of 1970's era new age philosophies, Carol Dweck has done the research to prove it true.But here is my disappointment. I was hoping this book would give me a few strategies to use with kids who tell me that they are "no good at X" or just can't do Y". How do I teach perseverance, willingness to try again after failure, and determination to see the job through even though it seems impossibly hard? I was hoping for some ideas.I'll keep looking...

This is not a bad kit if you are an experienced builder of balsa wood model airplanes. I had originally planned to build this with my twelve year old son, but for reasons explained below, decided otherwise.I have compared the plans and specifications to a number of photos, books, and drawings of the "real" Spirit of Saint Louis, and I think this is a great choice if you want to construct a fairly accurate model of Charles Lindbergh's plane for display, but don't want to build it from scratch. However, if you are wanting a model airplane for a kid to build, this is not a good choice, even if you are willing to sit with your kid and guide him/her every step of the way.For me, this model will become a part of a series of historic aircraft to hang from the ceiling of my science classroom to demonstrate progress in aviation. Each model in the series will illustrate an important technological stride as well as an important milestone in history. As such, I am not building this one to actually fly. But my son and I will research the Spirit of St. Louis together and he will help me build the final display. I will complete this kit while he is working on a larger, but simpler laser cut, radio control model. That way we will have some shop time together, but I won't take over his project. (His model is a .40 Telemaster)While I am builiding my kit for display, I see no reason why a serious model builder couldn't build this into a respectable electric powered, RC park model. With LiPo batteries and the new ultra light gear, it should fly reasonably well, if less than stable, like the full scale prototype. If YOU are so inclined, I would recommend an internet search for "Guillows Spirit of Saint Louis build" to find one of several detailed and very helpful blog or forum entries that describe how to lighten, strengthen, and successfully build and fly a powered RC version of this kit.If you are a parent reading this, you probably WANT your kid to develop patience, perseverance, and a determination to learn MANY new skills and bring a complex project to completion. Model airplanes are a great vehicle for this, especially for middel school aged kids. They teach serious project management, engineering, and construction skills. But even if you are willing to sit with your kid every step of the way, this kit is a bit too complex and is likely to lead to frustration for the kid and a pretty unsatisfactory result unless you take over, in which case...BORING!

Assembling this pole is a huge part of the product and while I normally refrain from downgrading a product due to poor instructions, in this case the instructions are poor and the product is of substandard quality too. I am regretting that at the time I bought this, there were only 2 reviews up, which didn't tell me enough to stay away.On the other hand, it is remarkably hard to find in-ground basket ball poles of any kind out there, so even if I HAD seen some negative reviews, I might have bought it anyway. However, knowing what I know now, I might have gone to the steel yard, bought some steel tubing and then asked the school shop class to weld me up a pole...and that's what I recommend you do.Here's the deal, I spent many years as a carpenter and have probably installed 20 - 30 basketball systems for customers. The assembly instructions for this one are among the worst I have ever seen. Unfortunately, I let this sit in a corner of my shop for far too long and felt that it would be dishonest to send it back. Besides, my 11 year old spent 3 days hand digging the foundation hole so I couldn't very well refuse to install it at this point.The instructions are printed in ten languages and I am not exaggerating. Congratulations to Huffy/Spalding for having such an international customer base, but did you have to try to talk to all of us at the same time? The instructions are like trying to read the blueprints for the Tower of Babel. Each page contains a sparse and ambiguous diagram along with accompanying written instructions in all ten languages. There's a sentence in English, then in Spanish, then French, German, Norwegian, Danish, Swedish, etc. Then they print the second sentence, again in each language, so that as you read the instructions you have to constantly stop, skip over 10-20 lines of text, and then try to find the next line that happens to be in your preferred language.Hint to buyers, get out your highlighter. Go through the whole manual and highlight the sentences in your language. I did this, it helps, but still, the instructions are a nightmare.Hint to Spalding, it's the second decade of the 21st century. There is this thing called the internet and guess what? You HAVE a website. Let your customers download an instruction set in their preferred language, 'cause this multilingual effort looks like the menu from a roach coach on the Plain of Shinar.OK, so after sorting through the language of the instructions, we get to the meat of the assembly.Here are some warnings that Spalding/Huffy neglects to give you:From prior experience I know this -- DO NOT TIGHTEN DOWN ANY OF THE BOLTS UNTIL YOU HAVE STOOD THE MAST UP, FILLED IT WITH CONCRETE, AND LET IT CURE, Otherwise you will run the risk of crushing the pole. Other manufacturers of basketball poles include this warning early on. Spalding/Huffy should have too.Spalding also directs you to completely assemble the pole, backboard and hoop, and fill the pole with concrete before you stand the pole. BIG MISTAKE and we avoided it thanks to prior experience. The pole alone requires a bit more than a full bag of concrete to fill. That's 80 pounds of concrete, 9 pounds of water, and 30 - 40 pounds of backboard and hoop and another 50 of pole and lift assembly...roughly 180 pounds of top heavy, asymmetric load you are trying to swing around, stand perpendicular, dead lift, and tuck into a 3" hole in the ground that has ragged, fragile edges. It took four adults to lift ours into place and that was WITHOUT the concrete.Oh, it really does require 435 pounds of concrete to install this pole. That's a bit less than SIX 80 pound bags of redimix concrete. If your installation uses much less than that, expect trouble.You CAN step the pole without the hoop installed, and I suggest you do. However, the lift mechanism has to be built on the backboard and then added to the pole assembly, meaning you pretty much have to install the backboard before you step the pole. Huffy/Spalding need to redesign this but it would probably obsolete their line of backboards. Bummer.Now, as to the instructions themselves. Beyond the language problem, they are still very hard to follow. Apparently someone at Huffy/Spalding thinks that owning a copy of Microsoft Publisher means they don't need to hire a graphic artist or a technical writer. Hint: Huffy, this is a complex product with a lot of little parts, including many that are un-necessary depending on which backboard and hoop your customer buys. Invest in a graphic artist and a technical writer. Have them assemble the product according to their own instructions and then revise until they get it right.There should be spacers to install on BOTH of the attachment points for the lift balance springs. I'm making some up for my installation but Huffy/Spalding really should supply some.Also, the instructions for the spacers to be installed between the backboard mounting brackets are pretty much opaque, eventually you can figure out where they belong if you stare at the instructions until your eyes bleed but even then, you realize that the brackets should have been drilled so you can install the spacers at the edges of the brackets so they can support the lift assembly. Also the lift assembly would be far sturdier if there were spacer tubes to go between the brackets on the 1/2" lift shaft bolts to keep this assembly from flexing. There is a lot more, but if I am going to give engineering advice to Huffy/Spalding, I want to be paid for it.Finally as to the quality of the product itself. It is made largely of powder coated steel, so it should continue to look nice, but it's pretty light gauge stuff, so it may bend or tear apart under the load of teen-age basketball. My kids are still pretty young, but I am not going to be happy replacing this thing in five years (Hopefully we will be building a new garage on top of the basketball court by then, rendering the point moot.)My biggest concern is that the attachment between the lift assembly and the backboard is pretty flimsy. There are just four bolts on a 2" x 6" layout. The horizontal spacing is only 2", so there is not much to keep the backboard from flapping on the vertical axis. I opted for a spring loaded hoop which will give some relief from movement on the horizontal axis, but then again the so called "elevator tubes" are pretty long and spindly. The manufacturer says very clearly "DON"T HANG ON THE HOOP OR THE NET" and they are probably right. I seriously doubt that the system would hold much above fifty pounds of live load. I don't think it will fall and kill anyone. If I did, I'd not have finished installing, but it won't take much to bend the lift mechanism and make the system unplayable.Annoyingly, the configuration of the lift assembly and the structure of the backboard would allow the board to attach to the lift on a 12 x 12 mounting square which would firm up the whole thing immensely. I may spend a bit of time welding up some new brackets just to accomplish this.The bottom line is that my kids will be able to play basketball and only play basketball with this set. I hope they don't get the idea to tie a tetherball to it, or for that matter a jump rope, and if they shinny up the pole to replace the net, or try to hang from the edge of the backboard, I'm afraid they may pull the lift assembly into a pretzel.Bottom line? I'd suggest you, gentle reader, keep looking.

This is a great little engine for the price and mine ran nicely right out of the box, just from the heat of a hot cup of coffee. It worked well, but made a "click-clack" that drew the attention of that cat. She jumped up on the table and attacked the motor, knocking it apart and spilling coffee everywhere...She is now Cattus non-Grata. I reassembled it and it would not run at all. GRRRRR.I made a careful study of the machine. I ended up taking the motor almost entirely apart and then carefully reassembling it. In the end, I have it running much faster, and more smoothly and quietly. The parts are reasonably well made and there is just enough room for adjustment that you can really make it sing with a bit of effort.Things to look for:The large piston (called the displacer) is a foam disc that is press fit to the connecting rod extension shaft. It is possible to pull the connecting rod up too far and pull the shaft out of the displacer piston. Then the motor will not run. You have to take apart the cylinder by removing the screws and pulling off the bottom plate. Then put the piston back onto the shaft like putting a record on a turntable. Reinsert the shaft into the piston. How far? I'm not sure, the motor operates as long as the shaft is fully inserted into the piston and there is room for adjustment through a 1cm range. There is probably an optimal location but I have not figured out a systematic way to determine it, and it may be dependent on operating temperature. Be gentle. There is a seal at the top and bottom of the clear plastic cylinder walls and you do not want to damage this or knock it loose.The small piston (called the drive piston) appears to be ground glass and you can add some graphite powder to the side of the piston to make it slide more perfectly. I did this, but frankly, it doesn't seem to have made much difference and since it makes the motor a little less pretty, I would not do it again.The drive piston has a spring steel wrist pin assembly that is pressed in. Watching the motor run, I noticed that the connecting rod can move back and forth on the wrist pin. This accounts for most of the "click-clacking" I think. It appeared to me that the wrist pin was not perfectly perpendicular to the plane of the connecting rod. I pulled out the wrist pin fitting with a small hook probe (A/K/A bent paper clip) and then carefully pushed it back in, trying to get it as square as possible in the cylinder. I could not think of any way to do this except by hand and eye.I also found, experimentally, that I could rotate the connecting rods 180 degrees and get smoother operation. The machine is made from light weight materials that can be easily bent or knocked out of alignment and it is a 30 dollar machine, not a 3000 dollar one, so manufacturing tolerances simply cannot be perfect. The trick to getting it to run as perfectly as possible is to tweak what you can so that the errors in tolerance cancel out as much as possible.Anyway, it is never going to be powerful enough to turn a generator or do any other useful work, but it is a fun little mechanism to play with and it is interesting exercise to work out how it operates and tune it for top performance.

I've been wearing one of these more days than not for the past 35 years. My first one was claimed by my son a few years ago. My second remains in good shape, but it's wool and it gets a bit hot to wear in the summer. I bought this one in cotton because I thought it would be more comfortable and I am not disappointed. It arrived this morning, just in time for me to wear it to the annual town parade. I received many complements on my taste in hats.For the first hour or so, the hat felt a bit loose on my head, but in my experience these do seem to start out a bit large. After a few hours of wear they shrink up a bit and conform perfectly. This one appears to be no exception. It already feels just as secure and comfortable as it's predecessor.

I play with computer programming as a hobby. I'm not good at it. I probably never will be unless I decide to take a month to just sit and write code for hours and hours. If I could do that, I think I'd be reasonably competent.But that is never going to happen. Still, Every once in a while I run into a problem that needs code for it's solution, so when I have some spare time, I try to learn a little bit more. I am jealous of my free time and I don't waste it on resources that are not genuinely helpful. Furthermore, I don't have regular access to an instructor that can give me a leg over the fence when I get stuck. So I keep buying books on programming and when I have a bit of time, I dive in. For C++, I have this and Bjarne Stroustrup's Programming -- Principles and Practice Using C++. Both are well written, but let's face it, I'm trying to make up in reading what I lack in the leisure time to just sit and write code until I attain mastery.I read a chapter in this and take a stab at the exercises. If I hit a stumbling block, I read the comparable chapter in Stroustrup and work through his exercises, again, until I get stuck, and then it's back to Alex Allain. I get maybe a one or two hour block of time to play with computers each week. It's not enough, but slowly I'm starting to learn a bit about coding.One of the great things about this book however, is that Alex Allain also has a great website and he publishes a regular programming newsletter which presents a new aspect of C++ programming every few days. The newsletters are not in sequence with his book, but they provide a wealth of background knowledge that slowly comes in to focus as I work on other aspects of programming.I bought the Kindle edition of this book and I keep it open on a second screen as I work through his instruction. The book was well worth the purchase price and is far more than a recapitulation of the website and newsletters. If you are in a place where you can seriously and systematically dedicate your efforts to learning programming, I think this book will help you.

Chris Turney and his team are getting a lot of undeserved criticism for their "eco-tourism" trip to Mawson's Huts last December. This book was published before then and I was in the middle of reading it when the news of the stranding of the Akademik Shokalskiy hit the intertubes. There are determined "skeptics" who will not admit that any sort of Antarctic research is justified, but for people of reasonably open mind, troubled by the stranding of the Shokalskiy, this book just might help you understand that such research is valuable and that Turney's trip to Mawson's huts was entirely reasonable.Every school kid knows, or at least should know something of the Amundsen/Scott race to the pole. But few children, or adults know of the Australian and Japanese expeditions that were unfolding at the same time. Three of the four expeditions were serious scientific efforts that produced a large volume of valuable data. The fourth was a sporting venture, revered for it's success, but it produced less science than any of the other expeditions.Consequently, I find it  a bit curious that modern internet geniuses censure Turney's truly scientific "tourist trip" to the Antarctic yet celebrate Amundsen's trek to the pole.Turney is, in fact a scientist and historian.Amundsen, smart and winter savvy, nevertheless, really was a tourist.

KitchenAid mixers are great, but the epoxy coating on their metal, flat paddle mixer blade isn't, and besides, when you are creaming butter, making pancakes, or mixing up chocolate chip cookies, the metal blade leaves much of the butter/batter/dough unmixed on the side of the bowl. This beater blade solves that problem.Some people complain that this blade is made from "crummy plastic that breaks". Guess what? That's what Maaatha would call "a good thing". Here's why. KA Mixers are tough, but they are not indestructible. KA knows this, so they put a plastic worm gear in the drive train. The point of this plastic gear is that if you grossly overload the mixer, you won't burn out the mixer's motor, you just shear off this gear, which is about an $8 part, much cheaper and easier to fix than replacing the entire motor, and that little old guy who owns the neighborhood repair shop can replace it for around $20 bucks!But wait... that little old repair guy gave it up about ten years ago...and now you have to mail your mixer to the big shi....city for repairs...and they want $!%)...150!!! OUCH! Well, that's why this beater is a GREAT idea. Buy TWO!. WHEN you overload your mixer, this beater will break, saving your motor. Put in your spare beater, add some liquid to your dough and you are back in business. And by the way, if you drive your KA mixer hard enough to break one of these blades, you WOULD have killed any other mixer beyond-hope-dead.Also, replacing that worm gear isn't all that hard, it's messy and time consuming, but not hard and if you bake a lot of bread you probably ought to learn how to do it because those little old guys and their neighborhood repair shops are disappearing fast. If you can't find a video on it, post a comment below and I'll make one.

I bought Sketchup 8 for Dummies in paperback a couple of years ago and keep it in my class room for my students to reference. It got me started with Sketchup, but then I had other things to do and didn't finish.A couple of weeks ago, on an extended business trip, I had some down time and decided to spend it dinking around with Sketchup. Sketchup is pretty easy to learn, but like anything, you have to use it regularly or you just don't remember what you've learned. Since I didn't have the old paperback handy, I sprang for this in Kindle format. I'm pretty happy with the book. It got me back up to speed within an hour or so and by reading through the book I remembered to try, and then to more regularly use a number of techniques that make my use of the program faster and more fluent.

The kids had been propping their music books on a chair, but now that they've shown me that they are serious about learning their instruments, I decided that a good music stand was in order. We've had this for a couple of months now. The only issue I had was that the machine screw that secures the shaft to the base was shipped, already installed in the shafts and I had to chuck the shaft up in a vise to get the screw out in order to complete assembly. But this should be well within the capability of anyone intelligent enough to be able to read sheet music.The stand is sturdy and stable and it gets adjusted up and down for different sized musicians daily. We have had no issues with noise or stickiness in adjusting the stand. As soon as all of the family musicians advance to the point of all needing to practice at the same time, I will probably buy two more just like it.

My Ryobi saw was advertised as being able to use both pinned and pinless blades, so I bought the biggest assortment I could find of Olson pinless blades. Alas, the saw's ability to use pinless blades was more theoretical than practical. The blades however were top notch. So when I found this pinned blade assortment, I bought it right away.Sharp, durable, good quality blades which leave behind a nice smooth cut as long as you match the blade, feed rate, and machine speed to your materials.

I rolled the dice when I bought this because the pictures and description did not contain all the information I really wanted. I bought this antenna to replace one which had an unfortunate encounter with a toddler. Now that both kids are old enough to understand that Daddy doesn't like coat hanger wire antennae on the radios, I'm ready to make repairs.This antenna has a swivel assembly at the bottom. The swivel assembly is a short cylindrical section the same diameter as the bottom element of the main antenna. The end is machined like a clevis which receives a paddle shaped horn fitted to the end of the bottom element. A small machine screw acts as a clevis pin, passing through a hole in the horn and threading into one leaf of the clevis.I was able to remove the comparable machine screw from the swivel assembly and remove the remains of my old antenna from my older GE multi-band radio. Similarly, I was able to remove the swivel assembly from this antenna in the same manner and install the new antenna to the old antenna's swivel. The repaired antenna works in exactly the same fashion as the old one, able to be retracted inside the case of the radio for transport, but be pulled out to the same length of the original, and fully able to be angled or swiveled for best reception.The only "problem" was due to my persnickety nature. The old antenna had a can shaped cylindrical "button" at the tip which was threaded onto the end of the final element of the antenna. This one has a shorter "button" that is welded to the final element. I cut the new button off with a razor saw and then cut 2-56 threads at the end of the element. Then I threaded the old button onto the new antenna, and now the radio is substantially indistinguishable from it's original condition. Once everything was fitted up, I applied a bit of blue loctite on all the threads so that nothing would fall apart.The antenna was shipped in a tight layer of bubble wrap, placed into a plastic mailing envelope. I ordered on a Tuesday and it arrived in plenty of time for me to complete the repairs the following Saturday.This vendor has several other similar antennae in different sizes, and lists the collapsed and extended length and number of elements, so now that I know the configuration of the swivel assembly, I am ready to order two more of these to replace the broken antennae on two other radios that the toddlers got to.

I really enjoyed watching the first few episodes of American Restoration, where they actually delved into the details of HOW these guys complete the restorations. But after the first season, they fell into this creative rut. A couple of beat up old collectibles come in...they take them apart...off screen...Brettly sandblasts everything...off screen...someone fabricates a missing part...off screen...the parts get painted or powdercoated...off screen...some broken mechanism gets taken apart, cleaned up, polished, reassembled and repaired...off screen...HURRY the customer is coming in, thirty seconds after they discover some seemingly insurmountable problem...this is solved, magically, off screen. The thing is delivered, roll credits.In between all of the repairs and refinishing, there is this continual reality show fifth business going on. Brettly gets a dog, Kowboy has a toothache, Ron bought some stupid, unrepairable, unsalable item, Tyler forgot some critical step, Kelly gets miffed at Rick. It's all pretty predictable and hard to believe it's not all scripted.I started watching this with my kid because he likes to take apart and repair old toys and other stuff. Consequently I watched pretty much the whole 1,2, and 3d seasons, but we both agreed that the language was unnecessarily vulgar, the restorations were progressively less interesting, we stopped learning anything useful, and that the details of the American Restorations "family" were sort of not any of our business.Rick Dale is clearly a smart, well skilled, knowledgeable mechanic, engineer, artisan, businessman, and historian, but it is hard to see that through the "Hey, hey, hey, we's all just a buncha dumb hicks out here in the desert, fixin' up this old crap and selling it to people with more money than sense" schtick that the producers have layered over the whole thing. A better program would spend less time on WHAT the Dale family does, and a bit more time on HOW they actually do it.

Assuming you choose the correct splitter for your application, this one is very well made. The plug locks securely into the 240V outlet of the generator and the two receptacles each have a glowing orange neon pilot lamp so you can peak out the window of your camper at night to verify that both of your generator's circuits are churning away merrily. Properly connected this splitter will allow you to safely double the number of devices that you are running off your generator, or, in the alternative, reduce the wear and tear on your machine.Take care to buy the right splitter because there are several types. This review will help you choose.My generator, a Yamaha EF3800, like many in the sub 5000 Watt range, has two standard wall-type outlets with a label reading "20 Amps". It also has a twist lock outlet labeled 120 volts 30 Amps and a second twist lock outlet labeled 120/240 Volts, 20 Amps.This splitter allows me to turn the 240 Volt circuit into TWO 120 volt, 20 Amp circuits. This is neither magic, nor dangerous, your generator is built to do this as long as the total load on each leg is less than 1/2 of the total rating of your generator...and you have appropriate sized extension cords, and you are not doing anything stupid, like trying to use all of the generator's outlets at once. Either use the two regular receptacles, or the 30 Amp, 120V RV hookup, or the 120/240 V, but NOT a combination, and never all three at once, unless you like the sound of tripping breakers and the smell of hot wires.When I bought my generator nearly 20 years ago, I thought I could get 20 Amps out of each of the standard wall outlets. I figured that the others were for plugging in a boat or an RV which I didn't have and that I could ignore them for construction site use. I ran my 12 amp compressor and my cordless tool battery chargers on one outlet and my radio and 13 amp Skilsaw, or drills, etc, on the other, and I got away with it for, what in hindsight was a remarkably long time. This is because I was working alone, cutting, then nailing, but never both at once.As soon as I recruited a helper so that we were each working simultaneously and I fired up the saw while the compressor was running, or the compressor kicked in while I was running the saw, "click" went the breaker. I initially thought that it was because my generator was getting old, not because I was doing it wrong.Eventually I learned more about electricity and how my generator worked, and I "home brewed" a splitter much like this one. Most generators have two power coils, let's call them X and Y, which is what the electrical code, and probably the schematic for your generator calls them. The wall receptacle on my generator draws only from the X coil to deliver 120 Volts, meaning that I was putting all the load on just one coil. The Y coil just sits there all forlorn unless you need 240 Volts to run heavy power equipment, or you use a splitter like this.This particular splitter has a 4 prong NEMA L14-20P (L for locking, 14 for 1 cable/4 wires, 20 for 20 Amps, P for "Plug") twist-lock plug assembly. This means it fits into a 4 prong L14-20R (R for "Receptacle") outlet. Look closely at your generator's outlets, you will probably see a similar set of letters and numbers on your generator. If you don't see letters and numbers (they are small and they are engraved in, not printed, so they are hard to see) look at the actual receptacle. What you are looking for is a receptacle with 4 prong-holes arranged in a circular fashion. ONE of the four holes is L shaped.You need THIS adapter if one leg of the "L" is angled OUTWARD from the circle.If instead, the L shaped prong angles inward, you have a NEMA (National Electrical Manufacturer's Association) L14-30R receptacle, and you need on of theseConntek YL1430520S Generator Y Adapter 30 Amp 125/250 Volt 4 Prong Male Plug To 15/20 Amp Connector instead.Here's a bit more electrical wiring information in case you are curious.The four prongs have names. Looking at your plug and receptacle, with the L shaped prong on top. This is the grounding prong, marked "G" for "G"round. The bottom prong is marked "W", which of course stands for Neutral. The two prongs on the left and right are "X" and "Y". X is on the left if you are looking at the plug, and on the right if you are looking at the receptacle.If you connect your device between X and Y, you get 240Volts to Zap your big old table saw to life. Connect between X and W, or Y and W and you get 120 Volts to run your smaller tools and appliances. "W"hite or neutral is at the same electrical potential as "G" so that if something screws up, all those electrons run safely to the ground rather than through your arms and legs.Whether you need your generator for camping, construction, or just back up power in case of a power failure, use one of these splitters and divide your tools or appliances evenly between the two legs of the splitter. This will evenly load your generator and reduce wear and tear on the machine.Oh, and my home brewed splitter (an electrician helped me) worked just fine but it was scrounged from the trash pile on a construction site, made of bits of BX cable, a four gang J-box, second hand receptacles and the cheapest L14-20P I could find at the time. It looked ugly and anyway, I can't remember (OK, maybe I deliberately forgot) who I loaned it to. This one is much prettier, looks safer with it's nice cushy plastic insulation, is well made, and I am quite pleased with the purchase.

While this book is aimed at students who are gifted in science/mathematics, it contains experiments and activities, and question sets that in most cases can be managed by any kid who has an adequate math and science background. It's the range of rigor in the questions that extend and broaden the learning for gifted kids, making this book a great tool for differentiation in a heterogeneous classroom.

These are good quality gears that are apparently made in small batches when a sufficient number have been ordered. I bought them to construct a drill press extension table I saw in an issue of Shop Notes magazine. I modified the plan quite a bit, but using these gears to relocate the drill table height adjustment crank to the front of the drill press is one of the slickest things I've done to a stock power tool.The 55 day lead time on shipping was a bit longer than I had hoped, but Amazon informed me that these would take 6-8 weeks to deliver and they weren't kidding. Face it, if you need them, you need them and after contacting the manufacturer directly I determined that they were going to take a while to arrive regardless of where I ordered them. I did find steel gears that I could have gotten sooner, but those would have been about 5 times more expensive.I grumbled while I was waiting, but the result was great.

The good thing about this series is that you can load it onto your kid's kindle and they can watch it in the car during that long drive to wherever you are going this summer.This is a survey of a wide variety of aircraft types. The series appears to use exactly the same footage as "Flying Through Time", cut and spliced differently, but with essentially the same narration and even the same soundtrack.There is very little detailed information about the design and development of the various types. Rather it gives a rapid overview and then maybe mentions a couple of operational details, almost as an afterthought. If you are nuts about airplanes and have nothing else to do, then give it a watch. I just let the episodes run as background noise in the shop.Worth watching if you have Amazon Prime, but not worth buying if you don't.

My Ryobi scrollsaw purports to be able to handle "pinless blades", a claim I found only marginally true after buying a good supply of Olson pinless blades. The blades were great, the blade clamps on the saw...not so much.Anyway, I was glad to find these. They fit the saw well and they seem to last much longer than the ones available at LowesTractorValueDepot.I generally don't try to cut through anything much thicker than 3/4" pine on the scroll saw, but my kid pushed a few 2x's through the saw and these blades handled it well enough, not like a band saw, but they do the job.Just to test, I knocked out a little dovetailed box from some 3/8" cocobolo scraps, cutting the pins and tails with the scroll saw. Slower than using a dovetail saw, but the results were just fine.Good blades if you can't use pinless.

If you had absolutely nothing else to do, after trimming your fingernails, cleaning between all the keys on your keyboard, emptying the litter box, descaling your coffee maker, scrubbing the grout lines in your shower with a toothbrush, re-arranging your spice cabinet, alphabetizing the types of pasta in your pantry, and sorting out those three coffee cans of weird screws out on the garage, THEN you might want to watch this movie. The acting was....well, actually, it wasn't....it was as if the actors were reading all their lines for the very first time. My wife chose it, she fell asleep, I toughed it out for a bit longer, then switched over to a documentary on watching paint dry.I'd give this one negative stars if I could.

This is a low cost meter and good value for the cost.It appears to be as accurate as the SPL app I have on my Ipad, they read within 1 dB of each other, depending on sensor placement and orientation.Repeatability is good. It consistently gives the same reading under the same conditions. I tested this by setting it up in the car and recording the reported SPL at set speeds (using cruise control), and at particular mile markers over a period of days.I originally bought it to hack and connect to a data logger but before I got that done, I found an Arduino project that accomplished the same thing, so I just use this in a class room when I teach about sound.

I found these at a farm and ranch store a few years ago. The farm and ranch store quit carrying this pattern (B01), but since then, I have ordered one new pair each year from Amazon. I have them in dark brown, "Carhartt brown", gray and moss. They hold their color well. I've had the oldest ones for 5 years. They are starting to fray at the hem and show wear at the pockets and knees, but no holes and still reasonably presentable after probably 200 trips through the laundry. The pocket liners are tough; I tend to put things like drywall screws, hardware, and small tools in the pockets, but so far I have not put holes in any of them. I like the fact that I can carry a hammer in the hammer loop, and a cell phone and an adjustable square in the side pocket and clip a tape measure to the pocket and not have any of them fall out when I get in and out of the truck.

My son is using this book in his middle school band class. He wanted a copy to keep at home because his old saxophone case doesn't have a good space for carrying his music book. The book is just fine.The DVD is OK too. Unfortunately, I had hoped to be able to copy the DVD over to his Kindle so he could listen to the practice lessons and play along with the accompaniment, but there does not seem to be any way to upload the files to our Amazon cloud player so I have to take off one star.

I bought three of these cord sets, one for a nativity scene, and the other two to install in some small lamps my kids made.They consist of a 5Watt C7 bulb and a bulb housing ("socket") with a spring steel clamp that will secure the housing nicely in a 1" diameter hole in the back or bottom of your project. The spring clamp will nicely snap in to a hole through 1/8" masonite or plywood. The clamp will wedge into thicker stock up to about 3/4". If you need to put it though a thicker base, such as a slab of 2x4, you'll need to drill a countersink.The lamp cord is 2 meters (just over 6ft) long. The rotary switch assembly is located about 1/2 way between the lamp holder and the plug. The plug assembly is equipped with a replaceable 5 amp fuse.I replaced one of the supplied bulbs with a 3 watt LED that puts out light equivalent to a 25 watt bulb. It is very bright indeed.Other reviewers here have expressed concern about the lead warning attached to the line cord. Please be aware that this applies to the lightbulb itself, which, like nearly all incandescent bulbs, has a blob of solder, (a tin, copper, and silver alloy that may also contain lead) on the hot terminal. There is no lead danger unless you allow your kids to put light bulbs in their mouths.These cord sets are ideal for craft projects that require a small light bulb at the end of a 6 foot cord.

I read this in one sitting. It's an easy read, but it was not a waste of time.I learned a lot about Newton. I was confronted with the reality that Newton himself was NOT a Newtonian, which makes his accomplishments all the more impressive. Even the least scientific among us take Newtonian principles for granted. Though many of us fumble to enunciate Newton's laws, they are universally understood, almost as if by instinct or primordial memory. Inertia, gravity, and action-reaction live within us even if we were busy flirting when we were supposed to learn them in schoolNewton on the other hand lived in an age when the laws he discovered defied notice and common sense. As such, it is all the more amazing that he discovered "Newtonian" physics at all. (He missed flirting entirely it appears).This is a nice book to have on the Kindle and I expect I will read it again, probably several times.

If you are trying to convince your administrator or school board to assist your effort to incorporate "Making, Tinkering, and Engineering in [your] Classroom", then this is a good book to have in your arsenal. In fact, I'd recommend you purchase a hardcover copy and lend it strategically to the decision makers in your school. But if you are already convinced of the value of building a maker space, or tweaking an existing school shop in a STEAM-ier direction, have school support for that effort and just need guidance to equip your space and develop curriculum, probably you need something else.Still, this is a great book to have on the shelf if you need to talk with skeptics who think school needs to be all about preparing for the PARCC or SMARTER assessments. Read this, read Shop Class as Soulcraft, and subscribe to Make Magazine, and you will be well equipped to explain that what the 21st century workforce really needs is to be able to handle a soldering iron, program an Arduino, carve a plaque with a CNC laser, and 3d print a dog whistle, and explain it all with calculus. Table saw, lathe and MIG welding skills won't hurt either, even if, or ESPECIALLY if little Janey was down for Tuck at age 2.The 21st century workforce is not learning how things are made. Though children are born with creative skills, we are editing those skills out of them at earlier and earlier ages. Deprived of concrete creative play and creative learning experiences as schools are forced to emphasize the all-mighty tests over all, today's kids will be ill-equipped for concrete creative work as adults. Yet growing world problems will demand extremely creative solutions at the very time these kids are entering the world of college and career.Read this book and help STEM the tide.

About 5 years ago I took my then 6 year old son to a robotics workshop. At the time I had not much more than a basic understanding of electric circuits. I'd built small electric motors and crystal radios from kits as a kid, but in reality, I couldn't have told you the difference between a shift register, a microcontroller, and a 555 timer. Still, I became fascinated with the possibilities of using the brains of the small robots for other interactive projects. A friend mentioned Arduino and I bought a Duemilanove. I learned a lot from it.But many of the projects I've conceived require only one or two I/O ports, and even though Arduino boards are comparatively cheap, it still seems a waste to leave 30 bucks worth of hardware inside a project that does little more than rotate a servo or blink a light in response to an input. I get things made, and then I am loathe to take them apart even though I need the board for another project.A couple of years ago I decided that what I really wanted was to get "much closer to the metal" by breadboarding the projects to test, then wiring them up permanently on perfboard, or as "dead bugs" powered by drycell batteries. Most of the basic Atmel/AVR chips are around a buck and most of my projects don't need more than five bucks worth of other components, so if I could wire and program AVRs directly, avoiding the cost of the Arduino board, I could make up projects that I could maintain permanently, or give away with little remorse about the price of the parts.In my early attempts I bought a USBtinyISPkit from LadyAda and made a start following her tutorials at ADAFRUIT. Ms. Fried and her team do a great job, but I didn't have a lot of free time to hunt down internet resources to help me develop the projects I had in mind. I wanted a nice reference book that would hold my hand through the process of setting up AVRs and modifying my Arduino projects, showing me the tool kit all in one place without the need to fumble around on the 'net for answers to basic questions. The books on the market at the time were aimed at engineers, above my knowledge level and beyond my need. I put the project on hold.But when this book was announced, it seemed to be exactly what I was looking for. I ordered it right away and then waited impatiently for spring break so I could dive into it.I am not disappointed. This book is a great guide. I quickly was able to blink a simple "hello world". I followed Mr. William's instructions to use my Arduino as a programmer. Then I repeated the process using my AdaFruit programmer.Though I already had some experience with Arduino, Basic Stamp, and Picaxe microcontrollers, I don't think any of that experience was necessary for me to get rolling with the AVR using this book as a guide.As a school teacher, I frequently try to put myself in the place of may students and while AVR programming is a bit above the grade level I teach, I am fairly confident that any motivated beginner able to pass algebra could dive straight into AVR programming following this guide. Mr. Williams does not assume a lot of previous knowledge, but on the other hand, he also doesn't insult the intelligence of more advanced experimenters. If you have programming and electronics experience, but haven't messed with microcontrollers, I think you will still find this book useful.Moreover, if you are interested in learning to program but become bored with the sorts of projects you find in a straight ahead programming text, you may find that the blinky light, buzzy beeper, and whirring motor sorts of projects in this book are a bit more engaging than the manipulation of text strings and conversion of temperature tasks that live on screen alone.I have along way to go to become a true master of microcontrollers, and a complex work life frequently causes me to put aside my hobby projects for weeks at a time. But so far, this book is proving to be an outstanding guide to AVR programming.

...read this. If you've read this, read Biplane too.Richard Bach, better than anyone I've ever read, portrays the way that small planes, especially old, unique ones, progress from being a collection of bolts and sheet metal, to friends and partners with personality quirks, needs and demands all their own.When I read that Bach and Puff had clipped a power line last year, I was of two minds: One could have come from the messiah mechanic, Donald Shimoda, "Richard, just visualize NOT snagging the powerlines". The other, a line from Johnathan Livingston Seagull was directed toward Puff, "We don't tackle flying through rock until a little later in the program."Biplane, and Travels with Puff tell similar stories but from opposite perspectives in time. If you like things that fly, both are well worth reading.

Many people who own old machines have noticed their tendency to develop idiosyncrasies, moods and characteristics...personalities if you will, that almost make them seem alive, as if they are actually trying to communicate with their human operators. But I suspect that owners of old airplanes notice this sooner than the owners of, for example pickup trucks and tablesaws.Bach trades his old Fairchild monoplane for an even older, rare antique biplane and spends a few weeks flying it cross county. He and we become acquainted with his new toy, which, by the end of the book has grown from a mechanical assemblage of wood, meta, canvas and wire, into an old and familiar friend.Better than any other writer I've read, he captures that magic moment when a small airplane, rattling and vibrating down the runway, comes alive in its natural element, the air.It has been interesting to compare this book, one of Bach's first, to his latest book, Travels with Puff, in which he completes a similar journey in a much newer, but no less unique seaplane. For people who view airplanes as nothing more than a means of transport, both books may fall flat, but if you are fascinated by things that fly, you will love both.
This is a very good Christian story, I wish it had been longer and more complete. Can't wait to read more about Scottlyn and Mercie.
Very good story, although I enjoyed One Tuesday Morning more.  Jamie struggles to move on after 9/11, she helps others as she herself heals. Very uplifting and inspiring.
A sensitive subject handled very well.  I loved this book, loved the characters. It all seemed very realistic, brings back memories of what our country went through that day and since.

Very good book, Max Holman recently released from prison wasn't the most sympathetic character.  But he grows on you, Max puts his all into finding his son's killer. A lot of twists and turns, and a very surprising ending.

Rick Cahill is a restaurant manager leading a very quiet life, and constantly kicking himself for his past mistakes.  He gets himself involved in a murder, and there goes his  quiet.  Good book, well worth the read.
Interesting book, good start to a series.  Kathleen kept getting herself into some unrealistic situations, but overall it's a pretty good story.
I enjoyed this book, although I did think it was too long.  The author did a good job with her main characters, it was very easy to care and worry about Sophie.
What a sweet, uplifting book.  This is a very fast read, the story flows along. It is religious, but not preachy.

Very enjoyable book, I love books that carry on with characters from previous books. Hannah was a very strong character in  Hour of Need, she continued that legacy in this book- along with showing her vulnerabilities.  Brody was just what she needed. Can't wait until there's a book about Mac.
This is a sweet, cute book - the word that comes to mind is folksy. Another great FERN MICHAELS book.
Loved this book; suspense, romance and great characters.  Rachel had a special feisty spirit, it worked so well with Mike's seemingly calm nature. A very good story!

Romantic, suspenseful and dark equals a very good read.  The story is a little predictable, but the characters are all wonderful.  Beth, her kids, Jack, a psychic uncle and a special dog make for a very enjoyable book.
I always enjoy Mary Higgins Clark books, this one was no exception.  I figured out the killer pretty early on, but was still a very good read.
This is a wonderful Christian book, with a lovely storyline. The story was very predictable, but after meeting Cory it needed to be a happily ever after ending. Very enjoyable!

Enjoyed this book, it was an interesting story. Paul and Sam were sympathetic characters in spite of all the mayhem they caused. I did not like the descriptive medical procedures near the end of the book, skimmed that part.  I will read more Jack Randall books, he is an interesting character.

Of the three books in the series, I liked this one the least- but it was still good. Roarke was all over the place; missing things, not sleeping, not eating. Hope he will be well-rested before the next book!

BLOOD Moon was a wonderful second book after Huntress Moon. Cara is under Roake's skin big time, he worries about her, and at the same time knows he must arrest her. This book was very hard to put down, suspense all the way to the end.

I loved this book, it is a very scary, dark read. The story of Cara and her slain family left me very sympathetic to her, but also appalled at the same time- her killings were horrific. The conflict Roake was experiencing over Cara really made this story.

I really enjoyed this book, it was better than the previous two (and they were both good).  I think it was Gabe's story that made this one so good. I would like to see a little romance in the next book, maybe with Charlie.

I loved this book, I thought it was better than Midnight Exposure (which was also a great read). All of the main characters worked so hard to always do the right thing- all heroes. Can't wait to read more about the Sullivan's.
Very lightweight easy harness, doesn't really stop my dog from pulling but works very well as a harness, easy to put on and off.
Very nice bike lights. Easy to attach to the bike. We ordered 5 they all worked on arrival.It took a very, very long time for them to arrive, but I am very pleased with them.
Nice syringes, small, easy to work with.
I brought this for a friend's puppy, it worked well until he grew out of it. Easy to put on and off.
This came fast and is as described.

This is a great book for pet owners. It really is like having my old vet around, he was just as down to earth and rational.The book is put together in a rather haphazard way, a bit less handy for reference, but I do think it's part of the charm. The book is written as if the old country vet is talking to you, in his own voice, sharing his experience and his wisdom.And lots of nice anecdotes. The book is a pleasure to read.The book itself is quite cheaply produced, cheap paper and print. But it's what's inside which counts. I am happy I brought it.

Great that these books have been re-issued. You don't really need the theory book, but it does help. The book was clearly written for students who planned to teach their own courses. The book is a facsimile of the original nineteenth century one.

Excellent paper for fountain pens. Perfect for Spencerian writing exercises. I do find it quite expensive. After I finished with this one I have been able to find the larger sized books for less elsewhere.
Nice but a very tiny book, looks a tourist souvenir, a few pictures, a few snippets of information, nothing in-depth.

Buy this even if you are not into the Paleo lifestyle! This is a great cook book. The recipes are indeed very easy and quick to make. Some are very original, combinations I never thought of before, they all taste great. I was staying with a friend when I brought it and we had so much fun making all the dishes! I had to leave the book behind and get a new one for myself.My husband loves rice so it's easy: I just add a rice of baked potatoes for my husband or guests, and I myself get to eat perfect, tasty, healthy Paleo.The book is a hardcover, always nice, especially for a book which is going to be used a lot.Actually, I have been using it so much that the leaves have loosened. Although it is a hardcover it's not sewn, but only glued. I did not take a star off for this flaw because I really really love the recipes in this book. I might take them out an have them wire bound, use it for the rough kitchen work, and then I'll buy another one for keeps :)It is great to ''work'' with, The left page holds the recipe, the ingredients, and macronutrient profile, the right page shows a photo of the meal, and the ingredients! I really like that.The book is divided by meal times:BreakfastLunchDinner,appetizers and snacks (yumm)Sauces and toppingsRubsThere are some great breakfast dishes which also work great for lunch or dinner, there are finger foods, one of which is my favorite: Chicken with almond coconut dipping sauce. Trust me, it is to die for! I have made it as the main meat dish for dinners, I have taken it to parties... it is gorgeous.I have invited guests just so I could make an enormous lot of it!And it is super quick.

Let's make it clear, this is not going to compete with my Gillette razor.Here is what I like with it:- It is much cheaper than the Gillette blades.- It manages to shave my mustache fairly well (I use no shaving cream)- The blades rinse very welll- The silicon edges are virtually unusable.Here is what I like less:- It does not provide as close a shave as my Gillette blades. When I insist and shave against the usual side, I end up cutting myself.- It is almost completely made of plastic.In conclusion:If you have the means, keep using more expensive blades, your skin will thank you but if you are on a budget, it does a fairly good work.Edit 10/08/15I have shaved 5 days in a row with the same blade and there is not one day when I did not nick my skin somewhere and felt the razor burn.In comparison with my much more expensive Gillette blades, the shaving is nowhere as nice, fast and close.In consequence, I have changed my rating from 4 stars to 2 stars. No I cannot recommend these disposable razors...

For the money, I would say that it is an amazing multi-plug since it does surge protection in the same time.One thing I like less is the constant red light that the item emits.I am currently using an UPS unit for my computer but I have many electronics I want to be protected without the UPS investment.This 3 outlet wall unit fits that description perfectly.

I have a bunch of Lightning to USB cables but the AmazonBasics are the ones I would go to by default because of their quality and price.This one is long enough to be plugged into the wall at the bottom of my cubicle at work and be accessible on the desk with enough cord length left be remain usable.It has a slightly thinner feel than the others I got previously but it still feels solid.

These gloves have a lot for themselves... They do not smell strongly of latex (normal since they are not made of Latex), they do not have a weird power to be able to wear yet they slide easily in place (again better than latex) and are also easy to take off.They are very strong (I pulled on them hard and they did not tear apart) and they are fit for food manipulation. On the other hand, pulling hard on them will stretch them around the wrists and it makes them a bit loose there. They do not cover much past the wrists.They also work with touch screens. It is at least true for my Iphone.I worked some very sticky dough with them and usually, without gloves, the dough sticks in between my fingers, get under my nails and it is a mess. I tried the gloves and it worked wonderfully. No sticky mess at all. I was able to work until the dough reached the proper consistency (I am preparing some croissants and the dough has to be just right).By the way, they are FDA approved but are not approved for medical use.So with them, you can clean your home, fill up your tank and work on greasy parts of your car, prepare some food and they won't break easily.The only thing I did not like is the first sensation while wearing them, a very squeaky feel but after a few minutes, the unpleasant feeling was gone. I have a same feeling with latex gloves...I had a choice between small and large gloves to review and although my hands are medium, I chose the large ones and it was a good thing because the large ones fits me well. So I suggest you to choose one size above your normal one.

4 times the recommended dose according to Wikipedia but the only side effect registered are that it may give you a nice orangish tan (similar to a high consumption of carrots).Now, according from WebMD: Some people also use it for preventing colon cancer, breast cancer, type 2 diabetes, and heart disease.Since I am wearing contact lenses and working on a daily basis and for many hours on my computer, I figured out that taking it cannot be a bad thing.At this time, it is a bit early for me to tell if it works or not but I do not see why it should not.Now don't get me wrong, it is not going to revolutionize your view but for aging people, taking this pill is not going to be a bad thing.Just be mindful if you are already taking multi-vitamins that they may already contain some as well. In such case, I suggest you to pass on this one.Edit 10/15/15It has been a while now that I am taking this supplement every day, one pill per day as the recommended dosage on the box and to be fair, I am not seeing any benefits whatsoever. No change as compared to taking nothing.... I have therefore reduced my rating from 4 stars to 2 stars.

It is always nice to have an elastic bandage that is long enough, large enough, extensible enough and that stays in place during daily activities.Ace brand Elastic does all of this very well. I like the clip on tool with Velcro that allows it to be reused and placed as one wishes.For these reasons, I gave it 5 stars.The black color suits well my black running shoes too :)

Replacement cartridges are quite tricky. It seems that none can completely and perfectly replace the original ones.I returned another set from a different vendor because of this issue and got this one.Here is what I observed when using these cartridges:- It took about 5 runs of heads cleanup to get the ink to eventually go through fully and nicely.- Once this was taken care of, the quality of the print is great and the ink levels did not go down dramatically (as compared to the previous non-original set I got and returned).- The vendor is warning us to not trust the ink levels indicated on the printer because it may be misleading (cartridges contain more ink than the originals)In conclusion, be patient for the first attempts and you will eventually get there.

I was fortunate enough to be given the chance to review two Wrangler shirts. I chose both in large size and although the other one was on the smallish side, this one fits me perfectly.I love how soft it feels, even after its first washing and it did not shrink at all.The colors are vibrant and nice.Both collars and wrists have another layer to prevent wear and tear.

I was fortunate enough to be given the chance to review two Wrangler long sleeves shirts. Interestingly, although I picked two different shirts with the same large size, this one feels somehow too small for me.I also find weird the very high position of the pockets on my chest.Material wise, the feeling is good.
These are very plasticky but it makes them very light too.They are definitely long enough to be able to use them without bending yourself.The hook on top of it makes it easy to handle.

I bought this one for my kid. He chose it for his Iphone 5.He is very pleased with it. It looks good, seems to provide a nice protection and the swivel clip is a plus.The price is very reasonable.Completely satisfied.

I bought a similar system in France for my wife and decided to do the same for myself in the USA. This one comes at about 1/2 price as the French one (Parrot). They look exactly the same.I installed this one after charging it and I have been using it for a few days now. I can say that I find it pretty nice. There is an audio feedback when you turn it on and off. It apparently turns itself off automatically when you leave the car so one has to remember to turn it back on but since it is battery powered it is better this way.The magnet is powerful enough to keep it safely attached to your sunscreen.The sound is loud enough and my wife can hear me clearly.Pairing was easy.

I am not familiar with Glucose monitors. This one is my first one.Let's start by what I like:- It comes with all the necessary items to start testing almost right away (You still need to charge the monitor for a couple of hours prior use).- It links pretty seamlessly with my Iphone- The readings are simple.What I like much less:- The message was not very clear on how much blood is necessary for the reading to work. In consequence, I wasted about 3 lancets and stabbed my finger about 3 times before to get the first one. The test kit need a good large drop of blood, not just a tiny little as I was getting first.Conclusion:In absence of other systems to compare it with, the Ihealth Bg5 Smart Gluco-Monitoring system is a fairly simple and efficient system to use. I would recommend it.

I was using a silicone brush for my croissants but I could not feel quite happy about the thickness of it. When putting my eggs on top of the croissants before baking them, the result would never be up to my quality threshold.I decided to go back to the classing paint brush type and I have to report my full satisfaction. The may require more maintenance and be a bit harder to clean but it is extremely worth it.

Since the apparition of Beats headphones, paying a high premium for headphones has become as acceptable as for smart phones. And there is a fair reason for that since the price depends much on the quality of the components. The interesting part is that although I consider Beats headphones to be extremely overrated and overpriced, a very good pair of headphones can rarely be found under at least $50.And here I am introducing the Panasonic RPHS34V which are a perfect example for my above claim.At less than $20, these are also much less than stellar. The fit, although comfortable is preventing a good seal and gone are the bass with it. It leaves the listener with very sibilant highs and quite average mediums.One may argue that the music quality is secondary to sport headsets but the pair of IEM I am using are begging to differ. Yes you can get good sonic quality as you are sweating on your treadmill or elliptical machine.There is almost no sound isolation since the buds are not made to create a seal in your ears and there is only one size fits all.The cable is very thin and gives a cheap feeling.The jack is angled (a good point).As I wrote earlier, they are quite comfortable to wear but the poor sound quality would give me a headache in less than 10mn.In conclusion: You should only consider these earbuds if you are exercising outside and wants to stay connected with your surrounding. You would also have to not be too picky of sound quality and be on a tight budget.A final note, for a similar price, you should check the Yamaha EPh-20 which for a similar price are leagues ahead in term of sound quality.

To be honest, I did not have great hopes for this headphone. However it has a few interesting points worth noting.For instance, it has a unique feature so far in the fact that both earspads can be rotated + or - 90 degrees. This is very interesting for DJs especially. For anyone else, it has little interest.Comfort wise, I find these to be quite clamping on my ears and I do not like it much now that I have been spoiled with amazingly comfortable headphones prior to this one.Sound wise, I am not impressed either. I find too much emphasis on the bass (a plague of these days) and a lack of clarity.Now one has to keep in mind that you get what you paid for but I would recommend the reference SONY MDR 7506 much more than these.

I did read pretty much everything from Louis de Bernieres, starting with Capt'ain Correlli's Mandoline and ending with Birds without Wings.What brought me to him is his sense of humor that can make me laugh out loud but also the poignant parts that he manages very well.Louis de Bernieres is always interested in telling a few peoples stories in an alternative fashion and intertwine their respective stories.This is also the case with Dust that falls from Dreams.Although I did like the book, I am not sure that it is my favorite one as the moments of humor are too few for me. The end of an era, with the first World war in the background is interesting but a bit depressing in the end.I preferred much more his Latin America saga and I would recommend to read this:The Troublesome Offspring of Cardinal Guzman, SeÃ±or Vivo and the Coca Lord and The War of Don Emmanuelâ€™s Nether Parts.So in the end, if you have the book in front of you, go ahead and indulge. It is not a bad book by far but if you want to discover Louis de Bernieres, I would recommend much more Captain Correlli's Mandoline or the books I mentioned above.

I did try this laundry detergent without much hope of getting an improvement over my regular detergent and effectively, my lack of hope is verified. I used it with my regular laundry where some T-Shirts were stained with grease spots and the grease spots were still visible after using this detergent.I tried it over a few loads and I saw absolutely no difference against the usual experience so it may actually wash the invisible dirt but I would prefer if it did a better work in cleaning the visible ones.I have to add that it is hard to find new ways to wash cleaner and better than hundreds of other produces that were supposed to do wonders before this one... Marketing has to reinvent itself to keep on selling laundry detergent... I would be so pleased with one detergent that would succeed in removing grease spots from my clothing but this seems to be a feat that only laundry professionals can achieve...

WiFi gaming headsets can be nice but in my view are not essential to video gaming on PC, which is the essential part of the gaming I practice. I personally use an AKG K702 65th Anniversary edition headset to play with an external microphone because I think I get the best quality and I seldom need a microphone. I tried in the past headsets that came with claims of 5.1 Ddolby  with multiple speakers incorporated in the cups and it never convinced me since our ears and brain are doing the job for a good localization.
