Furthermore, you need a real space diversity of transmission to experience 5.1, so to me most of it is a gimmick and the most important part is a good reproduction of sounds for the best experience.I was however given the opportunity to evaluate the Ear Force Stealth 450 Premium headset from Turtle beach and my impressions are as follow:What I like:- Fair sound on PC.- Nice microphone, removable easily.- Good looks- Good with a laptop or a console without a good sound card.- Sound volume on the right ear.- Superhuman hearing can be toggled on/off from the keyboard- Controls choices are voiced in your ears when you make changes with the buttons on the headset. For instance, if you press it once, it will tell you" Bass Boost or Bass and Trebble boost or Neutral sound".- 15 hours listening on one charge.- When I tested the 7.1 setup on my PC, it showed sounds really coming from different directions.What I like much less:- The External USB sound card (that acts as a WiFi Transmitter) prevents you to use the headset as usual. What I mean by that is that it has to be defined as the default output for the sound. With my standard headset, I plug it in my amp and it cuts the speakers automatically. In this case, you have to do the selection in the sound setup and I find it tedious.- As well, the USB sound card output is not very strong. I found the volume not sufficient enough for my own taste.- Comfort wise, my AKG are leagues ahead. The Ear Force are clamping in a way that make me feel that I would not stand these headsets for very long before suffering. Glasses would also not be recommended.- I tried listening to music with the music setup and the sound was much worse than with the game setup. Same thing for the movies.- Super-hearing feature confuses me. I tried it with The Witcher3 and it failed to convince me that I was gaining anything. I may have been trying it with the wrong game though...- If you already have a good soundcard, you will not be able to use it with this headset...- I used the cable to try it with my Iphone and the sound was less than impressive. It was loud but without almost any bass and there were some interference.In conclusion:You should love it if:- You hate cables- You have a laptop or a console but no PC with a good sound card.- You do not already own a good headset.- You plan on using it only indoors.Do not try it if :- You plan on using it with a good PC- You listen to lots of music outdoors.- You already have a good headset.

We just received it, mounted it and went to try it outdoors.The good:- It looks great.- It is quite easy to mount.- It brakes very well.- the wheels are nice and mostly silent.- The kid loves it.- You can set the height of the handlebars very easily.- It has a stand.What I like less:- It is rated for 100Kgs and I am about that weight and when stepping on it, the board started bending in a worrisome way. In clear, I am not going to use it at all by fear of breaking it.- When deployed, the whole thing does not feel completely tight. I verified all the screws and it seems correct but still, it wobbles a bit. My kid used it and did not have any issue with it but this makes me feel unsure about the whole construction quality.In conclusion:- If it was not for the second negative point, this thing is very good! As it is, I am considering returning it or exchanging it.

Key holders are ubiquitous. Everyone uses them but their technology has not improved much in years.This is until the Freekey system came around, at least for me.The use is fairly simple: You press on the small mark and the edge lifts itself for an easy insertion of the key or any ring you want.They are made of high grade stainless steel and should not bend too easily.Now for the parts I like less:- Insertion is easy but removal is not. So you may still chip your nails by trying to remove keys from it.- The smaller rings are not following the same technology and it defeats a bit the purpose since I had to attach many keys to them.- Only 3 smaller rings, if you want more, you'll pay almost the same price than for the whole item.In conclusion: I am keeping it because it makes me feel secure but the main selling part is not as good as the manufacturer pretends...

I personally use my AKG K702 65th Anniversary edition to play or the AKG Q701. These are high quality audiophile headsets but both are lacking a microphone. I got around the issue by adding an external microphone to my configuration.However, my stepson wanted a headset that would be of high quality and include a microphone.So we started searching Amazon for the best option and when I saw that Sennheiser was selling some, I got convinced it would be a great idea to try one.Sennheiser is one of the top manufacturer of audiophile headphones, notably the HD800 which is considered to this day as maybe the best dynamic headphone in the world today. The HD 650 is another reference, more comparable to my AKG but I digress...So we picked the G4ME One and got it the next day thanks to Amazon Prime One day.I tested it immediately with some of my reference soundtests and I got bluffed. It sounds really really good! It is only when I did a side-by-side comparison that I noticed that it is somehow less precise and has some overemphasized bass when compared to the AKG K702 65th Anniversary edition.But to keep things in perspective, it is also about 1/2 cheaper...So here is what I like:- Comfortable- Sold with 2 cables, one for PC and one for MP3 player.- Excellent sound, very close to true Audiophile quality (if it was not for the more bass it presents)- Very good quality of construction.- Open back design makes you  feel that the sound is coming from speakers rather than headphones.What I like less:- The emphasis on Bass. I like headphones to be more neutral. However, this is a personal preference and many will not see it as a con.- Not very forgiving for the quality of recordings, poor recording will sound very poor.- Powerful but may benefit from a proper amplification. Interestingly, these are rated for 50 Ohms but they need about as much power as my AKG that are rated for 65 Ohms...In conclusion, I consider these cans as audiophile quality for gaming and do recommend them warmly.

What's not to love about those? I am using 3 AKG headphones: 1 Q01 Quincy Jones, 1 702 Anniversary Edition and one K7XX and all 3 came with very long cables. So everytime I was using them to walk around I needed to wrap the cables around my shoulders and it really looked awkward.  Not anymore with these replacement cables. 1.2 m is the ideal lenght to go from my pocket to my ears or to use when in front of my laptop.Top notch quality (Braided cables and Gold platted connectors), very affordable price so I bought 2 immediately and I do not regret it.

The power supply is a key component for any high level desktop. Those are quite hard to test over a short period of time since usually they either work or don't. However there are a few key points that can be evaluated from the get go and they are as follow:- Is the brand reputable? In this case, it is a resounding Yes! Corsair is excellent with Power and RAM for my experience.- How silent they are? The RM750i is very silent. I would like to add that most Power supplies are now fairly silent so this is not frankly exceptional.- Are they modulable? The option to not have all cables connected is a great plus because it removes the clutter in the tower. That's a great thing,- How much power do they deliver and is this power value reliable? 750W is plenty. It should be sufficient to provide power to the most demanding computers, including Video Cards used in SLI and quite a few hard drives. One has to keep in mind that not all the components are drawing constant power. For instance, hard drives will only draw much power when in use. It is the same for the video cards. So for most people, 750W is overkill.On the other hand,  few power suppliers are claiming peak power and not constant power so the knowledge that this unit is 80 PLUS Gold certified is another advantage.- How many cables are provided in the Box. Plenty in this case but in line with most power supplies.In conclusion:If you are a gamer and use recent video cards and hardware, the CORSAIR RM750i is perfect for you. If you are a real hardcore gamer with more than 2 video cards in SLI and lots of hard drives or older equipments that consume higher wattages, you may want to upgrade to a 850W or higher. In my case, with one Geforce 970, 6 hard drives and a bunch of USB connected items (like steering wheel), this unit delivers plenty.

Here is what a quick search on internet yields:CLA is technically a trans fat, but it is a natural type of trans fat that is found in many healthy foods like grass fed cows or dairy.Is it claimed to have many beneficial virtues and to have a positive impact on health as well as for weight loss.This is the claim made with CLA coming from eating the real food.However, CLA supplementation has been shown to cause fat loss, but the effects are small, unreliable and unlikely to make any difference in reality.There is also a risk with the dosage that could lead with health issues like diabetes or high amount of fat in the liver when taken in high dosage so the recommendation is to get the approval from your doctor before taking it.One can also experience unpleasant side effects like gas, nausea, diarrhea, stomach pain...I have started using it anyway (since it is FDA approved) and I have not experienced any of this yet but neither have I seen any change in my body-fat composition (I check myself every day). It is a bit early to tell if there is any benefit, good or bad so I will get back and update this review every week to tell about my progress.Update: 10/26/15I have now been taking 4 pills every day, two in the morning and two in the evening. So far, nothing... It has not helped me with any weight loss or even metabolism boost whatsoever. Even worse, I have been working out, weight lifting 3 times a week and doing cardio twice a week and I have not lost any fat at all... Can I blame it on the CLA? That would be assuming a lot since regular food intake has to be taken in consideration. So I won't.But as far as the benefits are concerned: Nothing I could observe, at least for me...

I have 4 external hard drives that I use to back up my computer, all of them being Seagate USB powered. One of them started misbehaving so I looked for a replacement and I found this one.It is about half the size of the previous ones and works great with USB3 ports. I saw writing speeds reaching 150MB/s with it for very large files.Excellent!

I hate silverware that feels like made of cheap metal and can bend easily (specially the forks). So I was in search of a solid set of silverware that would feel heavy in my hands and the Lafayette 20 pieces is exactly what I was looking for.The only thing I am on the fence about, especially when comparing it to a previous Ikea set I did like, is that the desert spoon and forks are larger than expected. The dessert forks are about as large as the forks I wanted replacing.In any case, I do recommend this set.

As the title says it, I already own an Omron 7 serie (BP652) which I have been using since 2014 and which I verified against my doctor's office's conventional system. I was given the opportunity to review this newer model and I jumped on the occasion.Before running the comparison, let me remind you that the placement of the monitor is of utmost importance in both cases, otherwise one will read completely different numbers. The sensors of the units have to be aligned with the area where one would normally take the pulse on the wrist, about 1/2 inch below the wrist bone.Here are my findings when comparing the two:- Readings are not exactly identical between the two. The BP654 (Newer model) tends to give me higher readings than the older model by a few points. Nothing too big but it tells me that I may need to experience more about careful placement to find similar results. For instance, a reading just a minute ago for the two:- BP652: 116/76-71(HR)- BP654: 124/69-65(HR)- BP654 is completely silent as compared to BP652 that was making an inflation sound. If it was not for the inflating pressure, one could think that it does nothing.- SIze is about 1/2 of the BP652. It makes it easier to carry.- BP652 has no Bluetooth connection with any phone, unlike the BP654 that connect pretty seamlessly to my Iphone6 (after installing the app).Another way to look at it, here are the things that the BP654 does that the previous model do not:- Bluetooth connection and automatic transfer of all the readings.Here is what we have lost with the newer model:- Only one user possible. BP 652 had a guest setting.- Strap is better in the BP 652 in my opinion because the placement is quite intuitive. In comparison, the strap on BP654 will accomodate for gigantic wrists but can be inducing less precision on the placement.In conclusion:I hate it when an upgrade loses things in the process. It makes me unsure of which one I want to keep on using. Both have their pros and cons but remain high quality blood pressure monitors. If you hate tracking your data manually and will not share the unit, opt for the BP654, otherwise the BP652 is a very good option, especially if you want to share its use with someone else.Interestingly, the BP652 is currently more expensive although older than the BP654. It may just be a weird thing with Amazon pricing system.

I bought this steering wheel while in France (Thrustmaster is a French company, previously called Guillemot and specialized in making joysticks) back in December 2012. I have been using it ever since. It is a wonderful piece of hardware. I previously owned a Logitech G27 and before that the Microsoft side winder or something like that. Every time, my driving scores have improved with the upgrades.What's to like:- Serious hardware with 3 motors and amazing quality. The pedals are made of metal alloy and extremely heavy and sturdy. The resistance of the pedals is very good and simulate those of a real car.- You can set the pedals two ways, rF1 and GT depending on your preference or room available.- The pedals are very heavy and will stay put when you drive, unlike other plastic ones that constantly slide on carpet.- The driving sensation is very good and my driving performance increased when compared to Logitech.- Excellent and strong force feedback. This thing set to the maximum FFB will get your arms sore after a while.- Stay put when attached to your desk or table and placement is not as limited as the Logitech wheels.What I like much less:- I thought I had bricked it twice while upgrading the firmware. There are some workarounds to get it back to life that are not too difficult to follow. I am by the way using it with a PC, not with a console.- Price is high.- No stick shift attached. You can still use the manual gears but you will have to use the pads behind the wheel. You can buy a very good one but for another 150 bucks...- Fan can get loud at times.

It is indeed a multi-function shower head. I has 3 positions:- 6 holes only with the most pressure.- Many many smaller holes to simulate rain (that's my interpretation)- A mix of both.And it works pretty well. The installation was very easy and simple. Added to it was a sealant tape to avoid leaks.I would maybe have liked a slightly stronger pressure but it is not the fault of the item but more of my plumbing.It only misses and extension to be perfect.

There's a great, haunting 300-page story buried somewhere within--unfortunately there's another 300 pages of padding to wade through. I have nothing against epic-length works if the story demands it, and I love descriptive writing, but Spjut gets a bit excessive here, describing every mundane detail of the characters' lives, as well as every object within their general vicinity, and it breaks up the flow and the tension far too often to keep me totally captivated and engaged. But hidden within the pages and pages of description, there's a pretty freaky story that mixes the everyday with the mythical. I'm not very good at skim-reading through parts that don't hold my interest--I force myself to read every single word--but for those who can, there's a very good supernatural thriller here that fans of Neil Gaiman's and Clive Barker's "hidden world"-type horror-fantasies may appreciate. For me, while there were a few scenes that will most likely haunt me for a while (such as the eerie Prologue), it was just a bit too much work to get to "the good stuff," and I had to force myself to keep reading at times, though the ending made it all somewhat worth it.

My 20 month old niece loves this doll, and can spend hours giving it water and watching it come out the other end a short time later. She may be slightly too young to play with it by herself, as it can make a bit of a mess, with water getting everywhere (she prefers to give the doll water without the diaper on, so she can actually see the water come out). Also, it only comes with one diaper, so after a couple uses, you'll have to buy more. Still, my niece has a lot of fun with it, and it can be used as a teaching tool when it comes time for potty training, by placing the doll on a training potty to encourage the child to try herself. It was definitely worth getting just to see the enjoyment she gets out of it.

These Huggies Pull-Ups are great for little girls who are potty training. They're actually very absorbent for trainers (though not as absorbent as diapers of course), good for at least a couple accidents, and the velcro sides allow for quick checks, without having to totally undress the child every time. The designs fade when wet, making it easy to tell if she needs to be changed. And what 2-year-old girl doesn't like Sophia, Minnie, and Cinderella? Recommended.

My cat is usually a pretty finicky eater, but he's been scarfing these down, sometimes not even waiting for me to finish putting it on the plate and just hopping up on the counter. It's gotten to the point where he won't even attempt to eat other brands, which means I'm stuck for now with having to pay $1.50 per can. It's worth it, however, considering how much he loves it. With other brands, I end up wasting a lot due to their lack of consistency. Friskies and Fancy Feast  pate's are sometimes soft and moist, and other times they're harder to chop up and not very juicy. Sometimes my cat loves it, other times he won't touch it. So far with these Purina Chicken and Liver Entrees, every one has been nice and juicy.

I see a lot of people here didn't care for Fine's "holier than thou" hipster attitude, but that didn't detract from my enjoyment of this book at all. In fact, it added another layer of authenticity, considering that seemingly everyone into indie (i.e. "college") rock at the time had a somewhat snobbish attitude (and not much has changed since).This book really brought me back to the DIY, pre-internet days of fanzines and MTV, when if you wanted to check out a new band that wasn't pushed on the radio and MTV, you had to either shell out $15 for the CD, or just go check them out live for like half the price. Fine's humorous, philosophy-laden stories of life on the road were great, and made me nostalgic for those bygone days, even if I was a little too young to fully appreciate the scene at the time.Recommended for fans of 80s and 90s underground rock, and for those who would like to vicariously experience life as a struggling musician in the 80s.

This Brinks door handle/lock looks really nice, and makes it really simple to open the door while your hands are full (of course, you still have to unlock the deadbolt). It's also very solidly made and secure, though the installation process requires more than a simple screwdriver. It's still not very difficult, but you will have to drill an extra hole. Not a big deal, but it means the hole will have to be filled, most likely, in the event that you ever decide to get a new door handle. Also, you must already have a door with a deadbolt, or else you'll have to drill a hole for the deadbolt as well. Still, the push/pull/rotate technology is nice and convenient, the handle is quite aesthetically pleasing and comfortable, and I doubt I'll be needing a new one anytime in the near future.

Anyone who's ever had a flea infestation knows just how much of a hassle it can be to get rid of them. With this Black Flag Extreme Flea Killer, you can get the job done easily, without having to leave your home for hours at a time while the house gets flea-bombed. It's safe to use on carpet, baseboards, and furniture (but not smooth floors), and the earlier you catch the problem the easier it will be to take care of, as you don't want to wait til the fleas have had a chance to lay and hatch their eggs. This will still break the cycle, you'll just have a larger problem to deal with. Just point and spray the problem areas, and your house will be free of fleas in no time. Recommended for households with outdoor pets.

This safety gate is great for wider spaces, such as hallways and stairways. It's quite sturdy, simple enough for adults to open, but requires just the right amount of force so that a child couldn't. There's nothing fancy or ornamental to it, just a nice, solid gate. Installation is pretty easy, taking about 25-30 minutes or so. It's best to have another person to help set it up and make sure it's level. Also, keep in mind that it's only 26.5" tall, so most cats can easily jump over it. Overall, it works great and I'd recommend it for those who aren't worried about aesthetics.

Middle books in trilogies have the difficult task of laying the groundwork for the final novel, making sure all the pieces are in place, while still having some sort of climax in IT as well. Not all writers are able to pull it off, as there's a tendency toward over-expanding the scope, by adding too many side-characters and side-plots in an effort to maintain reader interest after the novelty -- or "newness" -- of the opening volume has worn off. Sometimes this is at the expense of narrative momentum.'The Bone Tree' does fall into these traps periodically, as there were times the book felt a bit too overstuffed with plots and characters that weren't always of equal interest to me -- as is usually the case with these types of sprawling epics -- but Iles successfully pulls it off in the end, imo. It does start to slow down a bit in the middle, weighed down by the constant shifting back and forth between settings (just as I'd be getting into a reading groove with a certain character), but toward the end it picks up in intensity to the point that I was immediately ready to begin reading the final installment, and it's going to be difficult to wait a year or more.But, as a fan of the notoriously ponderous George RR Martin, I'm just grateful that the conclusion will actually be here in the near future.

This Thomas the Train toy (so I take it he's not "Thomas the Tank Engine" any more?) is perfect for toddlers who have recently learned to walk. And if they haven't learned to walk yet, the handle comes off so it can be pushed around while crawling. My 20 month-old niece loves running around with it, and I constantly have to hover over her and tell her to slow down. About the only thing I wish were different would be the amount of balls within the clear plastic bubble. As it is, there are only a handful, so they only *pop* every few seconds or so, and sometimes not for a longer time. With a couple more balls they would probably pop more often. Still, this is a fun, durable toy for toddlers, one they should get a lot of use out of.

Drawing directly from Ed Shames, the last surviving Easy Company officer, 'Airborne' richly details his experiences in WW II, giving readers an in-depth account of his training at Camp Toccoa, the Normandy beach landings, various battles in Germany and Holland, and more, including a great story about Shames snagging a bottle of Hitler's cognac while at Eagle's Nest. The book focuses mostly on Shames' perspective in all this which, while narrowing the focus somewhat, creates a much more intimate and personal story.It's very moving at times, and even though I could never imagine going through what these guys did, author Ian Gardner does a very good job capturing what it would be like in the middle of a war zone. I didn't think my respect for military vets could get much higher, but I was wrong. The book touches on things not covered in the TV miniseries, so it makes a good companion piece to the show, and I for one highly recommend it to WW II buffs, history aficionados in general, and people just looking for an excellent story, one that just so happens to be true .

This jump rope is light and easy-to-use, with good grips, but after nearly a month of use, the kinks in the cord (the jump rope comes all folded up) are still there. The description on this page says kink-free, and it's not. It's still quite functional, with an adjustable cord and swivels on the handles to keep it from getting all twisted up, and the lightness of it allows for very fast rotations, but it's a little clumsy and shoddy-looking due to the kinks. Other than that, it's a nice jump rope for the price.

My 19-month-old niece loves this, though I agree with other reviewers here who say that those much older than 3 probably will not get as much out of it. It allows young toddlers to use their imagination, and learn the names of various animals while having fun. The different rooms for each animal teaches them to remember where each one goes, matching up the animal with the picture in the room. My niece has been playing with this toy for well over a month now, and shows no signs of tiring of it. She especially likes dropping them though the top of the silo so they come crashing down. She thinks that's just hilarious for some reason. As a bonus, it's also very easy to take with you wherever you go, since it folds up and has a handle.Overall, a fun, well-built toy that's perfect for toddlers under 3.

My niece may be a little young for these (she's only 19 months old), but she likes magnets, and absolutely loves these, though I have to keep a couple of the smaller pieces away til she's older. Plus she's still too young to learn about swords and skulls, at least according to her mother. She'll sit at the fridge and play dress up with them for an hour at a time sometimes, all the while naming each piece of clothing that she puts on. Of course, she needs some help with it, but I still think it's a great toy for kids younger than the advertised "3 and up," just make sure you keep an eye on the smaller pieces so they don't try to put them in their mouths. Overall, a great, imaginative toy for toddlers.

I've used Frontline for years on my cat, and the one time I didn't (I used Sergeant's Gold instead), my cat had a severe reaction that caused him to twitch and breathe heavily...even growl, which I've never heard him do, before or since. I ended up having to take him to the emergency vet, and I felt really bad for a long time for trying to save a few bucks. So I was a bit apprehensive about going with a brand other than Frontline, but I'm happy to report that with Sentry Fiproguard, my cat didn't even really notice that I was putting it on, and was fine for the rest of the day. I did catch him trying to lick at the spot a couple times, so make sure you put it between the shoulder blades where they can't get at it. It seems to be working great so far, but I'll have a better idea as it gets closer to summer, so I'll report back then if there are any changes. So far so good though.

This Munchkin Auto-Close Safety Gate was very simple to setup, taking only about 5 minutes or so. The instructions aren't very good, but for the most part it's not hard to figure out. There are two extenders on the sides that allow you to fit it to various-sized doorways. It's very easy for adults and older kids to work the handle, but it's definitely toddler proof. Also, the auto-close feature comes in handy if you have forgetful family members who don't remember to close it. The gate is quite aesthetically pleasing as well, with nice, sturdy wood that goes well with the metal, and just looks nicer than some of the other safety gates I've used, some of which can be a little bit of an eyesore. Overall, it's definitely worth the extra $$, if for nothing else than the auto-close feature.

As a fan of William Hjortsberg's 1978 horror-hardboiled mashup 'Falling Angel,' I couldn't wait to read his return to noir, 'Manana: A Novel.' This time there's no supernatural element, but it's plenty intense, taking you to late 60s Mexico, and into the shoes of a hippie from the states who may or may not have just killed a prostitute during a drug-induced blackout at a party in Mexico. All he knows is he woke up next to her, and she was already dead. Tod is definitely out of his element here, as he's normally just a laid-back stoner, and now is wanted for murder and associating with hardened criminals in order to find his missing wife, who was at the aforementioned deadly party.There are plenty of moments of levity throughout, including one or two laugh-out-loud moments, such as a scene early on where Tod, out and about while looking for his wife, somehow ends up in a knife fight with some hardened Mexican gangbangers. His thought process throughout this is hilarious even though, as a reader, you're scared for him at the same time.Mostly, though, 'Manana' is a straight-up, no-frills, fast-paced thriller, with plenty of unexpected twists and turns along the way, and with lots of memorable characters, mostly small-time ex-cons, including one who reminded me of a gangster version of The Dude, from The Big Lebowski. It's a page-turner that rarely lets you up for air, and one I recommend whole-heartedly to those who think that a mix of Kerouac and Chandler sounds like fun.

"A novel, treatise, an essay, a report, a manifesto, a confession." All of these words are displayed on the cover of 'Satin Island,' and all are crossed out except for "a novel," though any of those subtitles would do. It's pretty much all of those things, and yet unlike any novel I've ever read.The story, insofar as I can tell, follows U., our narrator, a "corporate anthropologist" who is tasked with writing 'The Great Report,' an essay that attempts to capture the zeitgeist of our times. We the reader are inside his head as one thought or idea morphs into another, with constant digressions and side-digressions within digressions. It's seemingly very free-wheeling, very stream-of-consciousness, yet meticulously structured.U. (or McCarthy) comes up with some very cool ideas and concepts, making 'Satin Island' very much a novel of ideas, one that more adventurous readers should definitely check out. The book may be very postmodern, and hard for myself and others to describe, but it's quite easy -- and fun -- to read. And it may just make you start to see patterns where you didn't before.

I have to admit it took me a few days to get used to it, but I now believe it's the most comfortable mattress I've ever slept in. My lower back used to always be a little sore in the mornings, but that's a thing of the past. It's firm yet soft (if that makes sense) and you can even move around and shift positions without disturbing your significant other at all, which is a nice bonus. It's cool to the touch as well, and stays cool even where you're laying.The mattress comes heavily compressed and rolled up. It's rather heavy, so make sure you place it near your sleeping area before you cut off the wrapping, as it will immediately start to unroll and decompress. It takes about 12-14 hours or so to get to it's full size, so if you unroll it in the morning, it will be ready to sleep on by bedtime. Just be warned that there is a weird rubbery smell that takes about a day or two to go away. It didn't bother me, however, but I see that other reviewers here are more sensitive to smells than me.Overall, this is the best mattress I've ever slept in, and recommend it with no reservations.

This is definitely the most comfortable pillow I've ever slept with. It's very cool to the touch, and stays cool throughout the night, so you don't have to keep turning the pillow over to the cool side. Also, the memory foam conforms or "molds" to your head, so it rarely needs adjusting. No more sore neck for me in the mornings, which is nice. It's also great for propping up against for night-reading, offering both support and comfort. About the only negative I can think of is the weird smell it has at first, but that goes away within a couple days or so. Overall, I give this pillow the highest possible recommendation for those who want a good night's sleep without the sore neck.

This is a lightweight-yet-sturdy cover for protecting your lounge chairs during bad weather. The drawstring allows it to fit snugly on chairs of different sizes, and the attached stuff sack makes it easy to store when not needed. I was able to cover all four of my chairs at once (while stacked of course). The material seems thick and hard to tear, yet not so heavy and bulky that it's hard to use. It's sort of like tent material, but with air vents to help moisture buildup, which is nice. Overall I'm very happy with this cover.

As a fan of David Mitchell's more mind-bending, fantastical works, and that sort of fiction in general, I could not wait to get my hands on this book. For weeks before it's release, I thought about it almost constantly, not able to focus on what I was reading at the time. Of course, it'd be difficult for anything to live up to that much anticipation, but 'The Bone Clocks' nearly did. The only problem was that the fantasy elements are what didn't quite work for me. They never really gelled with the more realistic sections, and I wasn't able to totally suspend my disbelief in the same way as I had with 'Cloud Atlas' or 'Ghostwritten.'No one, however, can argue with the fact that Mitchell's prose is beautiful and flowing, with a way of completely drawing the reader in. In my case, I was so captivated that I forgot I was even reading at times, especially in the earlier parts concerning teenage Holly and her adventures away from home. Later, when the magical elements become more and more prevalent, I was sometimes pulled out the total immersion, as those sections seemed a little out of place, and at times even silly, imo, though Mitchell's vision of an oil-depleted future in the later chapters is fascinating. It's almost as if two entirely different novels were crammed together. Of course, these disparate elements are part of what myself and others loved about 'Cloud Atlas,' but here it just didn't quite work as well for me. That could be more my failing, however, and less Mitchell's.Overall, still highly recommended, as a middling book by David Mitchell is still better than most authors at their very best.

I've always been the type of person who gets slight anxiety "attacks," where my heart starts racing and I get sort of shaky, even if there's nothing consciously bothering me at the time. This Muse headband, after just ten days of use, is already starting to reprogram my brain, allowing me to live a calmer, more relaxed life, and not over-analyze everything all the time. At first, I treated it almost like a game, seeing how well I can do at training my brain to just chill. The more cluttered and distracted your mind is, the more windy the sounds get, with loud, crashing waves. It was actually pretty fun, and addictive.After a while, the experience of doing these exercises can be drawn upon in your everyday life, even when you don't have access to the headband. It seems to even help with my concentration, as at times it can be hard for me to just clear my mind and read a book or study for a class if there's too many other things I'm worrying about. Now I have less trouble clearing my thoughts and focusing. The only negative I can think of is that it took me a really long time to calibrate it, which was a little frustrating, as I was like, "This is calming?!?," but I read another review here that said that long hair seems to affect it some. After I finally got it calibrated (without having to shave my head), it's worked wonderfully.I'm not quite ready to call it a miracle cure for anxiety and concentration problems after only ten days, but as someone who thought this was possibly just a gimmick, I'm very happy with it so far.

My one year-old niece is still a bit young and uncoordinated to build with these without help, but the look of wonder on her face when helping me stack them, as well as when she's watching the water trickle down when finished, is priceless, and makes these Mega Bloks more than worth the price. She's slowly learning how to stack them herself, but for now she just enjoys watching the waterfall, "assisting" me with the building process, and playing with the individual pieces, "talking" to them like they're her friends. This toy should be perfect for her in a few months when her coordination is better. The only negative, as other reviewers have remarked on, is that the storage basket is a little small, making it like a puzzle to get all the pieces back in. Other than that, a great, fun toy for toddlers.

Of course, the second part of this duology needs to live up to the staggering promise of the first for the above to become a reality, but so far, so very good.While 'The Abyss Beyond Dreams' is technically the seventh novel in the Commonwealth saga (which began with 2002's 'Misspent Youth'), it still makes for a more-than-suitable entry point into the universe, as Hamilton does an excellent job getting the reader up to speed on all the future-tech and lingo, the history of the Commonwealth, and the nature of the mysterious Void, a black hole-like spatial anomaly about which not much at all is known, other than the fact that it's expanding, and that an ancient race known as the Raiel have been guarding it for a million years. Past expeditions into the Void by the Raiel have failed, as none have ever returned.All the background exposition is seamlessly integrated into the story, which mostly takes place in the same time-frame as the recent Void Trilogy, though it begins a couple hundred years earlier, opening with 90 pages of pure horror. There's an eerie, ominous intensity here that's rarely equaled in modern SF (or modern horror for that matter). Science-team members aboard the giant starship Vermillion -- on a mission to found a new settlement away from the Commonwealth -- are prematurely brought out of suspension to find that the ship has somehow been sucked into the Void, even though their flight path took them nowhere within light-years of it. They don't know how this is possible, but they do know that no one's ever made it out. They soon discover that the Void is exponentially larger on the inside, like a MÃ¶bius  strip, and that basic laws of physics like temporal flow are out of whack. They also suddenly have telepathic and telekinetic powers, able to read one another's thoughts and move objects with their minds. But as fascinating as all this is to the group of scientists, things take a horrific turn when [Early, vague SPOILER] they decide to investigate a strange anomaly/organism floating in space. Suddenly their lives are turned into living nightmares, and no one can trust their crew mates, as they may not be what they seem. They may be monstrous doppelgÃ¤ngers. [End SPOILER]And that's just the opening pages of this inspired, epic novel, which then jumps ahead a couple centuries (to the time-period of the Void Trilogy), shifts from viewpoint to viewpoint, spread across thousands of light-years, and re-introduces the reader to some familiar faces, like the 1300 year-old Nigel Sheldon, possibly the single most powerful person in the Commonwealth, and the bizarre Raiel, the alien race which, with the help of Nigel, may just be ready to once again investigate the Void, due to the dreams/visions of the human prophet Inigo, and their mind-blowing implications. The world-building is exceptional, as can be expected from this author, but what really struck me was the characterization, which was surprisingly deft compared to other modern space opera writers. I cared about the fate of these characters, which isn't always the case for me, particularly in this sub-genre, due to the dissociation I sometimes feel when reading about such far-flung, alien worlds. Hamilton manages to retain the human element amidst all the techno-wizardry.Though I've read Hamilton before, this was my first Commonwealth novel, and yet never did I feel overwhelmed or lost. 'The Abyss Beyond Dreams' does a great job of familiarizing the reader with this fully-realized, immersive world, and unlike some past efforts by this author, its 600-plus pages are tightly-paced and mostly free of bloat, maintaining a high tension level and a sense of wonder throughout, a sense of wonder matched only in my experience by such classic SF novels as 'Hyperion,' 'Dune,' and Neal Stephenson's 'Anathem.' I'm not ready to put it quite at the level of those just yet, as the story's only half-complete, but I do know I'll be revisiting it again and again in the future. Here's hoping the second half of this story delivers.For now, though, I'm off to read the rest of the Commonwealth novels.

The Belkin QODE Thin Type Keyboard Case is very well-designed and easy to use as a keyboard for the iPad Air, with a nice, solid aluminum build that makes for a secure, sturdy case as well, while still being lightweight. The iPad automatically turns on when placed on the stand, and off when taken out, which is a plus, as is the 79 hours active battery life. The keyboard is positioned at a good angle for comfortable use, with great key placement, and large keys that are extremely easy to type on. The keyboard will also work with other iPad models including the iPad Mini, but the case will be pretty much useless. Overall, a great buy for turning your iPad Air into a convenient-to-use laptop that's sleek, light and easy to carry around without damaging.

This is a great case in that it provides excellent protection for your iPad Mini, while still being lightweight and attractive, and leaving the ports and buttons easily accessible, which is not the case with some others. The magnetic latch works well, turning the iPad on when opened, and off when closed, while also leaving the case tightly secured. The silicone base and stand allows you to adjust the angle of your iPad very easily, and though it doesn't lock in place, that was never an issue for me as the base's texture provides a good grip. The sleek black, textured design of the case is an added bonus. Overall, a very well-made case and an excellent value.

What starts out as a humorous and witty --yet pretty mundane -- story, filled with wry observations about the business traveler's life, soon turns into a surrealistic nightmare when Neil discovers that the hotel he's staying in may not be quite what it seems. The mystery of the hotel is intriguing enough to carry the reader through the pages where seemingly nothing much is happening, because it's clear that there's David Lynch/Philip K. Dick levels of weirdness underneath the surface, and the fun comes from trying to figure out just what the heck is going on. This is definitely a book you want to read in a short span -- say a week or less -- in order to maintain the eerie, unsettling mood. It lost me a couple of times early on, with pages of nothing more than observations about hotels and hotel life in general (though they were all generally amusing), but once the story kicks into high gear, there's really no going back if you're a fan of reality-bending fiction.

This sketchbook is definitely worth the extra cash you'd pay in comparison to some other popular ones. The paper is high-quality, showcasing both pencil and charcoal drawings extremely well, and thick enough to prevent any heavy pencil marks from showing on the next page. It says it's medium-weight, but is actually noticeably thicker than other "medium-weights" I've come across. Also, the heavy, sturdy cover provides great support for when drawing while out and about, when no hard surface is available. I was even able to draw while on the el(evated train), which I'd never be able to do with other, slightly less expensive books. You're undoubtedly getting more for your money with this sketchbook.

Ever since seeing Carpenter's 'The Thing' and the original 'Night of the Living Dead' as a youngster, I've never been able to resist the whole "isolated while being hunted" theme. I just love stories where a group of people are trapped, and have to figure out a way to survive while being slowly picked-off. If there's lots of snow, then that's an added bonus. One of the better novels in this vein recently was Ronald Malfi's 'Snow,' which is basically the same concept -- something in the snow hunting unsuspecting people -- only it took place in a snowed-in small midwestern town as opposed to a ski resort area in the mountains.The suspense was pretty well maintained here, and even when pages and pages went by of nothing much happening other than the group of friends hanging out and squabbling in a huge house in the mountains, the tension remained high, due to these chapters being occasionally inter-cut with passages of the horrors taking place nearby. My only issue was that it was hard for me to relate to the characters, as they didn't really have much depth to them. The fact that their idea of fun is quoting Adam Sandler movies and listening to Wang Chung and Huey Lewis & The News didn't help, either. So when the "bad stuff" starts happening, it was hard for me to really care. At times I was even rooting for their demise, never a good thing in a horror novel as far as maintaining suspense.Still, for those looking for a quick, fun read, it is a good late-night horror read, where you can feel the cold up there in the mountains and, at times, feel the terror that these unfortunate souls are experiencing. Just don't expect anything truly new or groundbreaking. I suspect, however, that Ania Ahlborne will be a name to watch in horror fiction.

Aukland, New Zealand's Surf City had already proven they could master both ramshackle garage-psych and shoegazy walls of guitars on their first two releases, 2008â€²s 'Surf City EP' and 2010â€²s 'Kudos.' 'We Knew It Was Not Going To Be Like This' floats freely between these two styles, all while maintaining the influence of their kiwi pop forbears, with results that float from "stellar" to "meh" just as freely.The noisy haze of opener "It's a Common Life" lets the listener know right away what's in store, with the band's patented surf-infused sheets of guitars front-and-center, and melodies that are head-bobbingly catchy yet spaced-out at the same time. Davin Stoddard's lyrics -- "Have you heard the devil's back in town, *bleep* the kids who don't know what's around" -- implies that this is a much more jaded Surf City. They also highlight the fact that the lyrics are actually intelligible on this album, as opposed to the reverb-drenched murk of much of their previous work. So maybe the band was just as jaded before, and we just never knew.I say jaded instead of angry, as the pessimism of the lyrics throughout 'We Knew It Was...' manifests itself more as a bored indifference than anything else as far as the actual music is concerned. Good thing psych-rock isn't really a genre where something so trite as emotions would effect the quality one way or the other. It's about striking that perfect balance between catchy grooves and transcendental bliss. And on songs like the dreamy, wistful ballad "I Want You" and the thoroughly transportive "What Gets Me By" -- nine minutes of swirling, euphoric interlocking guitar melodies that closes the album -- they get it right. But too often, as on the Flying Nun-esque jangle of "No Place to Go" and the rather blatant Sonic Youth rip-off (or homage) "NYC," Surf City comes off like a band that's just going through the motions, which isn't what I expected or hoped for after the 3-year-wait following their full-length debut.Still, if one were to cut those lesser moments, there's still something approaching half-an-hour of top-notch, fuzzed-out psych on 'We Knew It Was Not Going To Be Line This,' making it a worthwhile listen for fans of the genre. Hopefully we don't have to wait another three years to hear what's next, but there are enough treasures here to help keep us occupied in the meantime.(Originally written by me for Earbuddy.net)

Chicago's Disappears may be the premier psychedelic noise-rock band in a city suddenly overflowing with them (seemingly overnight), but they have always been a bit of an enigma to me. Their live shows have produced in me some of the most brutally intense emotions I've ever experienced while at a concert, with the band emanating a raw, haunting energy and vigor that few acts today can match, while still completely transporting me to a zoned-out state of bliss. And yet they've never really been able to capture that visceral feeling on record, instead sounding like a neutered version of their stage self. I'd begun to accept that perhaps it just may not be possible to translate that unique aura into their studio work.While 'Era' pretty much follows the same formula as past albums -- plenty of trance-inducing motorik rhythms, droning buzzsaw guitars, and frontman Brian Case's eerie, booming vocals -- that formula is much more potent here. The three main ingredients all interweave in a way that's just as likely to transport you to a euphoric, hypnotized state as it is to scare the living heck out of you. Opener "Girl" provides the perfect testimony to this fact, with Case's anguished, almost tortured vocals endlessly imploring somebody or other to "wake up, wake up, wake up" over a relentlessly pounding rhythmic assault. I'm never quite sure whether to drift away to blissful inner-spaceland or curl up into a fetal position while listening.There's a paranoia and claustrophobia to these tracks that Disappears never quite fully embraced on past releases, as heard on the sinister-sounding lead single "Power," as well as on the slow-burning, unnerving epics "Ultra" and "New House," but not all the tracks are so dire and threatening. "Weird House" sounds a bit like Wire being fronted by David Byrne, two artists whose only similarities are that they both fall under the "post-punk" tag. In many ways, Disappears are post-punk for a new era, no pun intended. It doesn't always fully work, as on the Chicago house-infused "Elite Typical," which alone would probably give the uninitiated the impression that the band was some mid-'90s British electronic-rock also-ran.Overall, however, 'Era' is an excellent fusion of post-punk song-structure, Spacemen 3-type droning atmospherics, and Krautrock beats, and whether this is the beginning of a new era for Disappears, or the end of an old one, I'd say that the band has a future that's darn bright, even if their sound is anything but.(Originally written by me for Earbuddy.net)

{8/22/13 Edit: After several more listens, I feel obligated to change my rating from a 4 to a 5. The album was definitely a grower for me -- My first listen already left a good impression on me, the next couple, on which this review is based, left an even better one, and now I'm starting to feel it's just-plain-brilliant. I'll let my (still rather positive) initial thoughts stand.}When I first heard, in the months leading up to the release of 'Sleeper,' that the album was rumored to be a laid-back acoustic album, my initial reaction was, "Yeah, good one Ty." The ridiculously prolific garage-rocker's previous two full-lengths (two of three released in 2012 alone), 'Slaughterhouse' and 'Twins,' were both in-your-face psych-punk mind-blowers -- with the former bordering on straight-up '70s-style metal at times -- yet the beautiful psych-tinged folk contained herein seems to be at the exact opposite end of the spectrum. But considering the album was recorded after a falling-out with his mother and the passing of his adoptive father, the pure, unadulterated honesty and pensive emotion of 'Sleeper' may have provided Segall some much-needed catharsis in a way that "psych-punk mind-blowers" couldn't.While he had occasionally flirted with this vibe earlier in his career, most notably on 2011â€²s 'Goodbye Bread,' the wistful, string-laden opening title track here lets the listener know right away that this is going to be an entirely different Ty Segall, one who's more willing to look to Love, Barrett, and even Bowie for inspiration than he is The Stooges, Jay Reatard, and 60s garage, all while somehow still sounding entirely like himself. But, in spite of the fact that he's traded in his amps-to-eleven garage-psych for graceful acoustic balladry, there have always been hints of folk and early British psych-music in even his heaviest material, so maybe all this isn't as massive of a leap for him as it initially may seem. The slow-dirge "The Keepers" continues in the same melancholy vein as the titular track, recalling a more eerie and ominous "Nights in White Satin," without sounding dated in the least. In fact, it sounds totally fresh, and even moving, both lyrically and musically. The '60s and '70s-infused psych-folk on these tracks and others prove that Ty isn't, and never has been, a one-trick-pony.The album isn't all just reflective and mournful folk ballads, however, as the second half is as varied as they come, while still maintaining a sense of unity. "The Man's Man" is a hook-filled rocker...well, at least as rocking as one can get while jamming on an acoustic guitar. Segall even busts out one of his patented fuzzed-out solos near the end, 30 seconds of jagged guitar histrionics that proves a solo doesn't have to be epic in length to get the job done. This song, along with the old-school delta blues of "6th Street" and the country-western twang of "The West"- a song in which the inspired lyrics dealing with Segall's late father and estranged mother transform what would have been a catchy country ditty into a song that's rather touching and heartfelt -- shows that Ty can shift from genre to genre and make them all entirely his own, with the songs never seeming disingenuous or like mere homages.Although Ty Segall likes to change things up with each and every album, and with consistently great results, I can't help but want to see him explore this direction a little further, as it shows a totally different, deeper and more thoughtful side to a songwriter and musician who seemingly has the talent to write top-tier, fuzz-filled garage-psych in his sleep. 'Sleeper' may not be a perfect album but, knowing Segall, his second attempt at a more singer-songwriter-based album might just prove to be a modern psych-folk classic.(Originally written by me for Earbuddy.net)

Nearly every online article I've read about Brooklyn-based indie-pop duo Steel Phantoms mentions the word "proto-punk." Now, "proto-punk" is supposed to refer to the early 70â€²s punk-rock progenitors like The Stooges, MC5, and The New York Dolls. Or even bands like The Who, The Kinks, and The Creation, all of whom had the building blocks of punk in place over a decade before the Ramones released their first album. This EP sounds like none of those. Then I thought, "Maybe those writers are all confusing proto-punk and post-punk," as the EP does contain some post-punk elements. But then again, most every alternative/indie band of the last thirty-plus years contains at least some elements of post-punk. Maybe the writers were just repeating what the band's press kit said. Or maybe Steel Phantoms used to sound entirely different. I'm curious as to the answer, but not enough, at this point, to go and listen to their earlier work.What this EP actually sounds like, regrettably, is the punk-pop from around the turn of the century -- affectionately referred to as "kiddie-punk" by some -- especially New Found Glory and Alkaline Trio. I actually had to look up a lot of those type of bands to try and find just the right comparison. And after sifting through countless online music samples of acts like Blink 182, Good Charlotte, Sum 41, etc., I finally settled on New Found Glory and Alkaline Trio. Which ruined my Amazon profile by the way, possibly for eternity, as my "recommended for you" section is now overwhelmed with bands like that. Now, I have nothing personal against any of those groups, but I was sick of that genre as soon as it hit, maybe even slightly before, and I wasn't really aware that there were actually bands today that look up to and are influenced by that music. In this case that includes replicating the patented yearning, emo-esque vocal stylings and soul-deadening two-chord "hooks." So, I guess what I'm trying to say is this: I may not be the target audience for this EP. Not just because of the genre -- which I could have looked past for reviewing purposes, because I'm a trooper -- but because there's very little here that's the least bit fresh or original, which is something of a pre-requisite for me.But for anyone interested in reliving the late 90â€²s and early 2000â€²s, or for those who may be too young to remember, but want to know exactly what it was like being an MTV-watching kid during those years (minus the obligatory boy bands, rap-metal acts, and The Real World), the 'Steel Phantoms EP' is probably as good as a time machine, and way more cost-effective. There's even a song called "Matt LeBlanc," so you also get some Friends with your punk-pop, making the "back in time" illusion even more realistic.Too bad there are a couple of well-written, inventive semi-epics to break up the Y2K-punk love fest. The melancholy ballad, "Overflow," is a languid-yet-powerful, hazy swirl of dreamy, fuzzed-out guitars, moving lyrics, and strong (dare I say beautiful?) vocals, while closing number "Skin Tone" is a complex, progressive, multi-sectioned anthem that sounds similar to what I'd imagine Green Day attempting to cover OK Computer-era Radiohead would sound like -- in a good way -- again with stirring vocals, and with lyrics that are rather poetic. Also, the video for lead-single "Curtain Call" is rather good, and makes the kiddie-punk vibe of the actual song much more bearable. Too bad it's not included with the EP.In the end, the 'Steel Phantoms EP' is a mostly derivative collection that's saved from "total waste of time" status by two excellent tracks. If, in the future, Steel Phantoms decide to move more toward the direction of those two aforementioned songs, you can definitely count me in. If, however, they decide that maybe it's time to start exploring some different late-90â€²s punk bands next time around, like maybe some ska-punk (which would be a significant upgrade), then I'm afraid I'll have to take a rain check.(Originally written by me for Earbuddy.net)

It seems "alternative rock" is suddenly chic. Not only has every mildly successful Gen X-era band reformed in the past few years in an attempt to cash the big one, many pulling in crowds two or three times as large as during their heday, but more and more current indie acts are looking to '80s and '90s alt-rock for inspiration. Gun Outfit, Broken Water, Milk Music, The Family Stoned -- okay make that the entire Olympia, Washington scene -- are bringing back the sounds of SST acts like Dinosaur Jr., Meat Puppets, and Sonic Youth, while prominent garage-rockers Ty Segall and Purling Hiss have recently been adding a heavy dose of Nirvana and Mudhoney-style Seattle grunge to their psychedelia. Not to mention the nearly endless supply of shoegaze bands that are putting their spin on the walls of bendy guitars that My Bloody Valentine and Slowdive had seemingly already perfected over 20 years ago. And now, New York four-piece Bear Ceuse have released a debut that sounds, at various times, like nearly every American group from the '90s that one can think of.The French Horn-laden "My Friends" and the laid-back fuzz of "All Out of A Hat" harken back to the immediate post-grunge days of Weezer and Foo Fighters, with mellow grooves that suddenly bust out with histrionic guitar solo wizardry that would make Billy Corgan and J. Mascis proud. The alt-country vibe of "Dixie Brothers" could almost be mistaken for a lost song from the Ryan Adams-led Whiskytown, while "OK LE OMA" brings back memories of Semisonic and Fountains of Wayne. The rest of the album pretty much follows the same template, with flavors of other '90s also-rans like Matthew Sweet, Ben Folds Five, and pretty much every non-grunge U.S. alt-rock band of the '90s. However, Bear Ceuse don't totally snub British music of the era, as "Streets of Something Good" recreates Bends-era Radiohead worshiping acts like Travis and Muse almost perfectly. Lead singer/songwriter Cameron Matthews is even able to change his vocal timbre from song to song in order to match the particular artist each song is mimicking.Matthews' wistful, poetic lyrics and yearning vocals throughout 'Don Domestique' suit the melancholy vibe of the album perfectly, and they're probably my favorite aspects of an album that's not entirely original. I have nothing against bands that put their own spin on music's past, but the songs here seem almost like carbon copies of the aforementioned artists. It probably doesn't help that many of the groups Bear Ceuse pay tribute to were watered-down versions or earlier, better ones. Even so, I can look past a band's musical style as long as it brings something new to the mix, but this doesn't. It's too bad, really, as Bear Ceuse obviously show potential for greatness, with an ear for great hooks and meticulously-layered arrangements. Unfortunately it's not 1997, or this would have been huge.(Originally written by me for Earbuddy.net)

Even though Pond have been making their own brand of mind-altering music since 2008, these Aussies are still regarded as "the kid brother" of Tame Impala due to the fact that both groups are from Perth and share two members, with a third who recently quit Tame Impala to devote his full attention to Pond. And while the bands also share a penchant for putting their own spin on '60s psychedelia, Pond feature a much more diverse palette, shifting from '70s prog, to '60s garage, to Zeppelen-esque hard-rock, to T. Rex-style boogie with ease. 'Hobo Rocket,' the band's fifth full-length, may not bring them fully out of the shadow of their big brother, but it does make a strong case for Pond being one of the premier psych-rock bands out there today.Most of the songs here contain multi-parted, almost prog-like song structures. Opener "Whatever Happened to the Million Head Collide?" begins with a couple minutes of swirling atmospherics, shuffling rhythms, and mystical lyrics before erupting with head-banging, "Kashmir"-like guitar riffs that are both heavy and transportive, with Nick Allbrook perfectly capturing Jimmy Page's patented fuzzed-out guitar tone. The intertwining piano, horn-like sounds, and hallucinatory effects keep it from ever sounding like a mere homage, however. "Xanman" and "Giant Tortoise" follow similar Led Zeppelin-on-hallucinogens-type formulas, and to great effect, the latter perhaps being the best all-out rock song in Pond's five year history, filled with classic rock guitar solo wizardry and flanger effects galore, to the point that it may send you off into a euphoric, hypnotized state even though you can't keep from bobbing your head up and down.The album switches things up with "O Dharma," a languid, beautiful folk ballad that slowly introduces more and more tripped-out effects and intertwining melodies until the song becomes an entirely different musical experience by the end, much more prog than folk, proving Pond aren't just a one trick pony. Closer "Midnight Mass (At the Market Street Payphone)" begins with two minutes of heavy Sabbath riffs before morphing into an ambient, Floyd-ian soundscape, ending 'Hobo Rocket' much as it began, and providing an excellent coda to this psych-rock gem of an album, an album that proves that Pond aren't just "a Tame Impala side-project," but are their own band, one that's every bit as adventurous. They somehow are able to make the old and dated sound entirely new, and entirely excellent.(Originally written by me for Earbuddy.net)

Jerred Gummere had already made a name for himself fronting the insanely catchy, influential Chicago garage-rockers The Ponys, and now with Bare Mutants he shifts from the frantic, psych-tinged noise-rock of his previous band to down-tempo, laid-back dream-pop that's every bit as catchy and even more tripped-out, sounding like 50s music you can slow dance to, only with a foggy, atmospheric sheen over everything that gives 'The Affliction' a sound that's both catchy and hypnotic.Opener "Without You" sets the template: steady, languid rhythms; fuzzed-out, two-chord riffs; and droning organ, with Gummere's deep, commanding vocals upfront in the mix, giving the songs a powerful presence that many similar-minded psych and shoegaze-type bands are lacking. While nearly all the songs follow this same formula at first, most eventually morph into heavy rockers, providing an almost euphoric release after the slow, steady buildups.One can almost picture teenagers slow dancing to the girl group-inspired sounds of both "The Fire In Your Hands" and "Crying With Bob" at some sort of high school dance in the late 50s, but in an alternate-dimension, David Lynchian late 50s, due to the eerie, strung-out vibe of the songs. Also, the lyrics on the latter about how "life took a dump on me today" probably wouldn't have gone over well back in the real late 50s. "I Suck At Life" sails along at a similarly narcotic clip, until a great, histrionic guitar solo comes busting through the mix out of nowhere, snapping the listener out of their hypnotized stupor.Not every song is so morose. Bare Mutants organist and backup vocalist Jeanine O' Toole (Also of The 1900s) sings lead on "Nothing Is Gold," a song that switches back and forth between sing-along kids' song and old-school country-western, while "C*nt," in spite of its name, is a fun, upbeat rocker with beautiful boy-girl harmonies and guitar riffs that sound like they came straight from early American rock and roll. Songs like these and the breezy "na na na"-chorused closer, "Scars," give 'The Affliction' a variety that the languidness of its first several songs never hinted at, and makes for an album for both fans of psych-rock and fans of just-plain-great songwriting.(Also reviewed by me for Earbuddy.net)

Considering the fact that, prior to the recording of 'The Light On', Bad Cop guitarist Alex Hartness was pronounced dead following a drug overdose, this EP almost never came to be. At least, it would have sounded a lot different without Hartness's fuzzed-out guitar crunch, a sound that recalls T. Rex, and in turn the T. Rex-infused garage of early Smith Westerns. And much like Smith Westerns, this Nashville band have proven quite capable of creating catchy, '70s glam-infused garage-rock.Opener "The Wind" sets the tone pretty quickly with carefree, energetic vocals over laser beam guitars and a propulsive rhythm that rumbles ahead full bore from beginning to end, bringing to mind MGMT at their very best without ever sounding like a mere rip-off. "Can't Get Enough" could almost be a cover of a song by some '50s crooner, only changed to be fun and up-tempo rockabilly, and with wobbly guitar atmospherics that make for a listen that's both lively and dreamy. "Post McDonalds Punks" is a furious 2-minute blast of straight-up, ramshackle garage-punk, while the laid-back, mid-tempo groove of the tripped-out "My Dying Days" harkens back to the mid-90s psychedelic Brit-pop of bands like Super Furry Animals and Supergrass, again without ever sounding too similar. There's a good chance the guys in Bad Cop are too young to have even heard those bands, anyway.The title track is undoubtedly the centerpiece of this EP, and the most emotionally affecting track here, with singer Adam Moult vividly recounting the night he witnessed his guitarist's near-fatal overdose, with lyrics imploring Hartness not to die over an eerie carnival-sounding organ and Hartness's own spacey guitar effects. While listening to just the instrumentation, it's easy to assume it's another loose and fun, "good times" song, but when combined with the deadly serious lyrics, the effect is rather haunting. It's a song that proves that there's more to Bad Cop than just being the latest in a long line of glam-influenced garage acts. They're actually quite diverse as well, shifting from punk, to fuzzed-out dreaminess, to straight-up glam boogie at the drop of a hat. They may not have an entirely unique sound, but when it's this infectious and just-plain-fun, it's tough to complain.(Originally written by me for Earbuddy.net)

Prior to the release of The Mallard's 'Finding Meaning in Deference,' the group's brainchild, Greer McGettrick, announced that this album would be their last. Considering the fact that she sang and played all the instruments on 2012's excellent 'Yes On Blood,' it didn't seem to me to be that big of a big deal since she IS The Mallard, and whatever project she decides to take on next will still have the same mastermind behind it. Its too bad this album is the product of an actual band, making for an infuriating listen--infuriating because it's one of the best, most haunting and intense psych albums I've heard in recent memory.Whereas 'Yes On Blood' was a nearly 50-50 blend of mid-late 60s garage-psych and early British post-punk, 'Finding Meaning' leans much more heavily toward the post-punk end of the spectrum, especially the eerie, minimalist style associated with bands like Wire and the late 70s Factory Records acts: driving, repetitious rhythms plus driving, repetitious melodies, only with spacey background atmospherics that slowly intertwine with the main hook, which makes this dark, haunting album an experience that's head-bobbingly catchy yet trance-inducing and hallucinatory.The noisy soundscapes of 'White Light/White Heat'-era Velvet Underground are also key touchstones throughout, especially on the perfect VU/Joy Divison fusion of 'Math' and the experimental, fuzzed-out mini-epic 'Iceberg,' a tripped-out mind-blower filled with McGettrick's freaky, hypnotic mantra-like vocals and lyrics backed by a propulsive rhythm and sheets of buzzsaw guitars that nearly bore into the listener's skull. It ends this hauntingly gorgeous album on a hauntingly gorgeous note, a note that's totally enveloping.'Finding Meaning In Deference' is a powerful closing statement from a band that, though its life was cut short while still in its infancy, is one that has left a significant mark in the worlds of garage-psych, post-punk, and noise-rock. Swan songs don't really get any better than this. My only remaining question is this: "Is it too early to hope for a reunion?"(Originally written by me for Earbuddy.net)

When one of the biggest rock stars of the past 20 years basically states that the future of rock and roll rests on your shoulders, you may consider that a hell of a lot to live up to, especially when the statement is made well before you've even released your first album. Noel Gallagher obviously must have been a big fan of Britain's "Madchester" scene of the late 80's and early 90's, as Jono Ma and Gabriel Winterfield of Aussie duo Jagwar Ma have got the 60's-ish psychedelic pop/acid-house dance fusion of The Stone Roses and Happy Mondays down pat on 'Howlin', but with enough new twists to mostly keep it from ever sounding like a mere homage. They may not be the saviors of rock and roll -- at least not yet -- but unlike Mr. Gallagher, I'm not going to hold that against them here, as the album has more than a handful of hypnotic, head-bobbing grooves that seem made for the summer."What Love" immediately sets the tone with deep, throbbing beats and repeating, mantra-like vocals that are slowly joined by more and more trance-inducing effects as the song goes on, making for a song that you can either dance to or trip-out to. While this track may set the tone, it's anything but par for the course, as Jagwar Ma are seemingly able to shift musical gears in less time than it took me to type this sentence. For example, "The Throw" is an epic, adventurous acid-house journey that brings to mind 'Screamadelica'-era Primal Scream, slowly building and building with a kaleidoscopic swirl of synths that weave in and out of the tribal rhythms to the point that it's nearly overwhelming, while their 2011 single "Come Save Me" (included here) looks to the mid-late 60's psychedelia of bands like The Beach Boys and The Beatles, with its synth effects and stuttering electronic beats used to accentuate rather than dominate the song. There are only a couple instances on the album where the band's influences become more than just launching pads, nearly approaching "Stone Roses cover-band" territory on "Man I Need," which almost sounds like it could be an outtake from the Roses' now legendary 1989 self-titled album, complete with similar 'Revolver'-esque backwards guitar-effects. Of course, lyrics about resurrection certainly don't help, and -- though it's certainly not his fault -- neither does the fact that Winterfield's nonchalant vocals are reminiscent of Ian Brown's at times.Still, 'Howlin' is stuffed with excellent danceable-yet tripped-out grooves, with a "good times" atmosphere that's refreshing in an age where many electronic acts are afraid to wipe off their serious face and just let go and have fun. Jagwar Ma's sound here may not be as revolutionary as it was in 1989, but that doesn't make it any less of a euphoric listening experience. It's hard to believe that the multi-layered arrangements here are from a debut album, and that can only mean great things for this band's future.(Originally written by me for Earbuddy.net)

Sic Alps' excellent self-titled sophomore LP from last year found the band cleaning up their rough edges with a more melodic, Beatles-esque psych sound that was heavy on the catchy hooks, but low on the garage fuzz of previous releases. The 'She's On Top' EP retains some of the poppier vibe of that album while bringing back the noise, and really doesn't sound like anything they've released to this point.The songs here actually share more in common with 70's rock than the mid-60's garage and British psych that Sic Alps are mostly known for, sounding like a hybrid of Big Star/Cheap Trick-style power-pop and David Bowie/T. Rex-style glam, with grooves that are more likely to make you want to dance than trip-out to. Huge hooks and swagger-filled vocals gives the EP much more of a "party vibe" than I'd ever expect from this band. We even get some "sha la la" choruses on "Biz Bang," not to mention histrionic guitar soloing that would have made Mick Ronson proud. Yet it all sounds entirely fresh and new.Sic Alps--in just a handful of years--have proven they aren't just a one-trick pony, 'Nuggets'-style garage-psych band. They've already shown they can put their own spin on the British Invasion, and make it sound natural and sincere as opposed to pure posturing. Now they tackle 70's power-pop and glam and make it sound just as genuine. If this EP is a sign of things to come, you can certainly count me in. But knowing this band, there probably won't be a trace of these genres in 6 months time.But it will still probably sound like Sic Alps, and that's a pretty rare feat.

One of the more under-appreciated musical artists of the past 30 years, singer/guitarist Thalia Zedek had already earned her rock and roll stripes with no wave-inspired acts like Uzi and Live Skull in the mid-late 80's before forming Come in 1990, shifting from the experimental, Sonic Youth-esque art-punk sounds of those previous bands to a slowed-down, heavy and sludgy deconstruction of the blues. While many would cite their 1994 sophomore effort, 'Don't Ask Don't Tell,' as their masterpiece, '92's 'Eleven: Eleven' is the one I return to most often, as it was unlike anything I'd ever heard then, and even in the 20-plus years since, the intensity and emotional resonance has rarely been equaled. And now it has pristine sound to match.Zedek's patented damaged, tortured vocals (a vocal-style Courtney Love would soon become synonymous with), when combined with the crushing riffs, gives these songs an almost cathartic quality, especially when they suddenly morph from languid, dreamy slowcore to all-out, blues-infected hard rock bordering on metal. The darkness and dreariness that pervades the music and lyrics never feels like its pure posturing, or forced, and rarely crosses into despair: Thalia Zedek was--and seemingly still is--just genuinely...well, dark. Even downright hostile at times. The listener feels what she's feeling--there's really no choice in the matter--and the result is a visceral, powerful listen.Of course, none of this is possible without a band behind her capable of matching her fervor. The group's rejection of the normal lead guitar/rhythm guitar setup makes for a style where both Zedek's and Chris Brokaw's (Codeine) guitars are constantly snaking around each other, sending the listener somewhere between completely hypnotized and total headbanging mode, especially when you add Sean O'Brien's throbbing bass and Arthur Johnson's relentless, pummeling drums into the mix. Just listen to the slow-creeping, slide-guitar-infused "Off to One Side"-- which lulls the listener into a blissful dream-like state for three minutes before erupting into an "amps to 11," angst-filled skull-crusher the rest of the way, without losing either the slide guitar or the dreaminess--and you'll see what I mean.The sound-quality here is stellar, with none of the clipping (i.e. digital distortion) or loss of loud/quiet dynamics so common among reissues these days--as far as I can tell, at least--even though the volume is a tad louder. There's a little more "oomph" in the bass, which is especially obvious when listening on a decent stereo, though even through iPod headphones it's hard to miss, as the rumbling bass sometimes obscures the other instruments when the equalizer's on the normal "rock" mode (at least on my super-old iPod). But that's easily adjustable, and I'd rather have too much bass than too little. There also seems to be slightly more clarity and separation of instruments, and sounds great even though I'm normally a fan of walls of sounds that blend together. But here the clarity allows the listener to truly appreciate the impressive inter-weaving guitar and overall band dynamics on display, so I'm definitely not complaining.Besides the remastered sound of the main disc (which includes both sides of the 'Fast Piss Blues 7"' not found on the original LP and cassette), there's an excellent live recording from 1992 that--although the sound-quality is very good for a 20-plus year-old live recording--doesn't have quite the same power as the studio recordings, yet still sounds as good as many modern indie-garage bands' studio output.
