It also allows listeners to hear songs that were only ever available on singles, such as "Car," "Last Mistake," and "SVK," all three of which are well worth hearing for those who haven't.All told, the 20th anniversary set of 'Eleven: Eleven' is absolutely essential, not only for fans of Thalia Zedek and Come, but for all open-minded music fans interested in hearing one of the great-yet-forgotten bands of the 90's. This is music you can rock out to, or strap the headphones on and zone out to. Hopefully this reissue will introduce a whole new generation to Come, and the band can finally stop being referred to as "underrated" or "forgotten."Better late than never.(Also reviewed by me for Earbuddy.net)

With their first two albums, L.A.-via-Olympia Washington's Gun Outfit put their own spin on the rootsy proto-grunge of SST Records acts of the mid-late 80â€²s like Dinosaur Jr. and Meat Puppets, and to excellent effect. 'Hard Coming Down' retains much of that sound (a sound that has since become popular with fellow Olympians Milk Music and The Family Stoned) only now it's hazier and more languid, bringing to mind a more strung-out version of Neil Young in some songs, and the country/blues-on-downers feel of underrated 90â€²s bands Acetone and Red Red Meat in others, while not totally abandoning their punk roots. The result is a sublime listening experience that doesn't quite sound like anything else out there today, though Maine's Coke Weed have been giving it the old college try with their latest.The constant shifting of styles here, as well as the alternating male and female vocals that bring to mind their Olympia forbears Beat Happening, ensures that the songs never get redundant. The dreamy, blissful "High Price to Pay" could almost pass for a Mazzy Star or Cowboy Junkies track, with Carrie Keith's druggy, fragile vocals lulling the listener into a serene, hypnotized state. My personal favorite, "Young Lord," sung in Dylan Sharp's raspy, Calvin Johnson-esque drawl, is a country-ish dream-pop gem, with laid-back, head-bobbin' grooves and noodling, hypnotic leads intertwining with the sustained guitar notes perfectly. Keith and Sharp share all songwriting, vocals, and lead guitar work, so it's impossible to tell who did what in these songs (besides the singing, of course).Despite the album maintaining a sort of weary "slacker vibe" throughout, it never approaches total gloominess. The lyrics are smart and well thought-out, even poetic, broaching topics ranging from personal ("My Love is Wanting Me"), to existential ("Young Lord"), to societal ("Another Human Being"), sometimes all within the same song ("Lau Blues"). The combination of the top-notch lyrics and the dreamy, roots-infused textures makes for a listening experience that's cerebral, yet at times capable of whisking the listener away to a wistful dream-like state where no thought is required, as evidenced by the hazy Appalachian folk of "Fools Gold."'Hard Coming Down' finds Gun Outfit really coming into their own as original artists, with a sad, almost slowcore sound with occasional bursts of their original punk-infused SST sounds. They've gone from a band I'd respected at arms length to one that, as a fan of dreamy and tripped-out music, I can't stop listening to, giving me a new appreciation of their earlier work. Even if you didn't care for (or never heard) Gun Outfit before, I recommend all like-minded music fans giving this a go. You just may find yourself feeling the exact same way.

This debut album from Holland's Mozes and the Firstborn passed me by when it was initially released a couple months back. I had sampled a couple tracks on Bandcamp, and when nothing stood out after a minute or two, I moved on. There's just so much music out there that it's impossible to give a proper listen to all the dozens of new garage bands seemingly popping up every week. Well, I sure am glad I ran into an article on these guys the other day, causing me to give the album another shot, as it's a top-notch collection of simple, laid-back, somewhat ramshackle (in a good way) garage-pop.The closest comparison I can come up with is the sloppy-yet-sublime bluesey garage-rock of Nashville's Natural Child and Austin's The Strange Boys, in that the album's filled with similarly loose, melodic, good-time vibes that harkens back to 60s and 70s garage, but without being pure revivalism. Songs like "Peter Jr," "I Got Skills," and "Gimme Some" are nearly impossible to not bob your smiling head to the mellow, Stonesy grooves and "no worries" lyrics.The album moves into more psychedelic territory occasionally, and is at it's most tripped-out on "Party Crasher," which settles into a nice, slow hypnotic groove and slowly introduces some acidy lead-guitar noodling before really taking off into the stratosphere. Unfortunately, the song fades out a little too soon for my liking, but then I'm the type who, when a band gets into a nice groove, wants it to go on forever. The languid "Heaven Reprise" ends the album on a perfectly serene and spaced-out note.If this album is any indication, Mozes and the Firstborn are certainly a band to keep an eye on, especially for fans of garage. The music has a timeless quality about it. It would have sounded good 40 years ago and will sound equally as good 40 years from now. It's not even really my normal style of music, but there's no denying this band's talent for creating pure, unadulterated garage rock.

This Sydney band's Bandcamp page describes the Black Springs sound as "shiny, spiraling, multi coloured and wildly undulating sonic vibrations of gooey lo-fi psychedelic sun drenched country tinged barnyard indie/surf/60s caveman garage rock with delicate lashings of lofty droning pretty dream alt-post neo.... something." I really have nothing to add.But I will anyway. Picture 90's-era Brian Jonestown Massacre's ramshackle 60's revivalist vibe, but with hazy swirls of sound and faint, Spacemen 3-type droning atmospherics that soon worm their way into your brain, and with some nice bright harmonies to boot. It's similar in a lot of ways to the BJM-meets-shoegaze sounds of both The Asteroid #4 (circa 'These Flowers of Ours') and Anton Newcombe's semi-recent label signees Magic Castles, in that it's easy to latch onto the catchy, jangly-yet-hazy melodies and nice harmonies--as well as the good-time vibes--but before long you're in innerspaceland without ever realizing you were being transported. But unlike Magic Castles, the production here is crisp, with actual discernible lyrics, pounding, powerful drums, and less murkiness overall.The 'Sunrise' EP settles into a mellow hypnotic groove right away with the title track, and slowly gains in intensity over the length of the album. Much of it brings to mind The Stone Roses as well, in that the rhythms are both danceable and capable of putting the listener into a trance, but with Black Springs' own unique sheets of intertwining guitars adding to the hypnotizing effect. As a fan of psych music, old and new, to me the EP perfectly meshes infectious hooks and headphone-journey bliss, making it suitable for whatever mood you're in. It also seems impossible to wear out, no matter how hard I've been trying to do just that these past few days.If you're a fan of any of the bands mentioned above, Flavor Crystals, Tame Impala's 'Innerspeaker,' Black Market Karma, or of mind-altering music in general--psych or shoegaze--I recommend you take the trip and see for yourself. For what it's worth, it has my unreserved recommendation, and I have a hard time imagining any similarly-minded psych fans being disappointed in the least.

Though commonly lumped in with the laid-back, beachy dream-pop of Real Estate, Beach Fossils, and DIIV, Wild Nothing's synth heavy sound has much more of a new wave/dance vibe about it, and the 'Empty Estate' EP continues in the direction established on their previous albums for the most part.But while 'Gemini' and 'Nocturne' maintained steadily languid and dreamy moods throughout, this release finds the band branching out in a bunch of different directions while still keeping that 80's feel, from the upbeat and vibrant, 80's Bowie-sounding "The Body in Rainfall," to the New Order-style disco/dance of "Ocean Repeating (Big-Eyed Girl),' to lush, ambient soundscapes that would do Brian Eno proud on "Hachiko" and the 6-minute "On Guyot." "Ride" and "A Dancing Shell" bring it back to 80's British dance territory, complete with hypnotic oscillating synths on the former and a 45-second sax solo on the latter.'Empty Estate' may not forge into brand new territory for Wild Nothing, but it does contain a nice variety of melodic and creative 80's-inspired sounds, all while retaining the dreaminess that got them lumped in with those other dream-pop bands to begin with. But even though this album sounds just like you'd expect a Wild Nothing album to sound, there's no mistaking this for Real Estate or Beach Fossils. This band have got their own thing going here, and I for one am excited to see (or hear) what's next.

Though commonly lumped in with the laid-back, beachy dream-pop of Real Estate, Beach Fossils, and DIIV, Wild Nothing's synth heavy sound has much more of a new wave/dance vibe about it, and the 'Empty Estate' EP continues in the direction established on their previous albums for the most part.But while 'Gemini' and 'Nocturne' maintained steadily languid and dreamy moods throughout, this release finds the band branching out in a bunch of different directions while still keeping that 80's feel, from the upbeat and vibrant, 80's Bowie-sounding "The Body in Rainfall," to the New Order-style disco/dance of "Ocean Repeating (Big-Eyed Girl),' to lush, ambient soundscapes that would do Brian Eno proud on "Hachiko" and the 6-minute "On Guyot." "Ride" and "A Dancing Shell" bring it back to 80's British dance territory, complete with hypnotic oscillating synths on the former and a 45-second sax solo on the latter.'Empty Estate' may not forge into brand new territory for Wild Nothing, but it does contain a nice variety of melodic and creative 80's-inspired sounds, all while retaining the dreaminess that got them lumped in with those other dream-pop bands to begin with. But even though this album sounds just like you'd expect a Wild Nothing album to sound, there's no mistaking this for Real Estate or Beach Fossils. This band have got their own thing going here, and I for one am excited to see (or hear) what's next.

Pure X's 2011 full-length debut, 'Pleasure,' was 37 minutes of laid-back, murky psychedelia awash in reverb and droning atmospherics, with a warm and "floaty" vibe that made for blissful inner space journeys. And while 'Crawling Up the Stairs' retains most of that formula, it has a much darker, more intense feel to it--both musically and lyrically--making for a listen that's not quite as blissful, but one that's much more emotionally powerful.Whereas the lyrics on their debut were lost in the swirling soundscapes, here they're upfront in the mix, demanding your attention instead of providing mere background noise, and they're quite downbeat at times, even ominous, yet done in a way that's rather poetic. The overall sound here is like a cross between Galaxie 500 and Spacemen 3, only much spookier, as evidenced by the dramatic, tortured lyrics and vocals of the otherwise serene "Someone Else" and "How Did You Find Me."The album's not all darkness and despair, however, as both "I Fear What I Feel" and "Thousand Year Old Child" have an almost 60's Motown vibe, with the former even throwing in a bit of funk, which I never thought I'd say about a Pure X song after the hazy fuzz of their early EP's (as Pure Ecstasy) and album. Of course, both songs are still extremely tripped-out--filled with layered, wobbly atmospherics--as is the rest of the album. Only now there are actual hooks for the listener to latch onto, hooks that could even be described as "catchy."The songs here just feel more like actual "songs," so while it's not quite as easy to get lost in the multi-layered depths, the combination of front-and-center lyrics and slightly more traditional song structures makes for an album that could be listened to anytime, as opposed to being saved for late-night headphone journeys. The darkness that pervades the majority of the album may infect the rest of your day, but so will the pure sonic beauty this band so effortlessly conjures up.

Yet another excellent album from a Melbourne, Australia band--so what else is new? And yet, it seems not many people in the States have taken notice of the indie scene down under. Neither had I until last year, so Beaches' 2008 debut totally passed me by, meaning I can't really compare this nearly 5-years-in-the-making followup to that one. What I can tell you is that 'She Beats' is a stellar fusion of noise-rock, psych, prog, and Krautrock, all blanketed in a dreamy shoegaze haze, making for a rather hypnotic and immersive listening experience.Lead track "Out of Mind" lets you know right out of the gate what this all-female group has in store, with progressive lead-guitar noodling and echo-y, reverb-laden vocals surrounded by sheets of noise, and backed by propulsive motorik rhythms, all which combined to put me in a euphoria-filled trance almost immediately. The droning atmospherics and hypnotic beats of "Keep On Breaking Through" and "Dune" kept me in that state, and I pretty much stayed that way til well past the final notes of the album, the kaleidoscopic symphony of sounds still reverberating in my head.Other highlights for me include the late 80's House of Love-style dreamy proto-shoegaze of "Send Them Away," the bendy walls of hazy guitars and mantra-like vocals of "Distance," and the throbbing bass and swirling ocean of sound of the near-epic "Granite Snake." There are no real low spots, and there's much more to the album than just walls of enveloping noise--it's also filled with melodies that are extremely catchy yet entirely unique, and laserbeam lead guitar soloing that tickles the brain perfectly.'She Beats' is definitely an essential listen for fans of the noise-rock of Sonic Youth, the shoegaze of MBV and Ride, and for fans of tripped-out music in general. Beaches definitely have their own original sound, however, a sound that--while owing much to noise-rock and shoegaze bands of yore--is totally forward-thinking and fresh-sounding, and I've got to wrap this review up so I can buy their 2008 album and 2010 EP. But it'll be a while before I wear this one out, I'm sure.

While Mikal Cronin's previous work shared a lot in common with longtime partner-in-crime Ty Segall's fuzzed-out garage-psych, 'MCII' finds him shedding much of the psych and adding a heavy dose of power-pop, and to excellent effect. Mikal has always leaned towards poppier, more hook-laden territory than Segall, but this album finds him really growing into a first-rate songwriter of infectious, just-plain-catchy tunes.The fuzz hasn't been abandoned, however. Songs like "Shout It Out" and "See It My Way" will immediately shift from light, acoustic balladry to all-out, "amps to 11" grungy garage-rock, without ever losing the sunny-yet-wistful vibe that permeates the album. The lyrics, though dealing in the standard "love" and "loves lost" realm, are top-notch (even if a bit sugary-sweet at times), which is something of a rarity among many modern garage acts. Cronin's mastery of loud-quiet dynamics is on full display as well, recalling 90's grunge more than modern garage, as evidenced by the stellar string-laden rocker "Change."'MCII' might not have been the album I was expecting, or even hoping for from Mikal Cronin, but after a few listens there was really no resisting his charming, hook-heavy and harmonies-laden power pop. This album finds Cronin stepping out of Segall's shadow, proving he's an excellent songwriter in his own right. Considering he played every instrument on the album--other than the occasional blistering guitar solo from Segall--he's also an immensely talented musician, almost annoyingly so to someone like me who struggles to play even one instrument.And I have a feeling he'll be annoying more than a handful of songwriters for many years to come.

This is a really detailed set -- it has 433 pieces and, unlike many Lego sets, makes 3 different style houses.It says that it is for ages 7 and up -- this can easily be appropriate for an older child, maybe up to 10-11 years old, as it is more complicated than most Lego sets I've seen.  For one thing, the pieces fit together in more directions than Lego, so the child really has to study the picture directions to figure out if they're connecting it correctly.  It's really a great set -- building the structures and adding the details to the houses is a very educational, time-consuming and interesting process, so it won't be all over in just a half hour.  (Also nice that these don't get confused with Lego blocks that litter the house!)K'Nex will definitely be my go-to Christmas present now -- really nice quality, more like a durable 3D puzzle than a simple Lego set.  5 stars all the way.

These are really cute labels, nice Kraft Brown color.  They fit perfectly on the Ball Quilted jelly jars,min that little oval.Note that these are the permanent labels, so they need to be soaked off (just like a store label would).  I find that this works better, since often the "removable" type don't stick as well, or pop off on the sides of smaller circumference jars.One star off because I didn't have any luck getting the template to work with my printer.  I easily found the right template, but the sheets of labels are smaller than a standard 8 1/2 x 11" size, so I think that's where the compatibility issue may lie -- I just couldn't really get the printing to line up correctly.  I'm not too bothered by that personally, since I mostly wanted them to write on by hand, and I usually can't be bothered to use the printer for just a few jars.  I think if you really know your way around your printer settings, or maybe have a photo printer that you normally print on smaller paper with, you may have better luck.  I do like how there are only 4 labels per sheet, so you don't have to print a lot at the same time.Overall, though, very attractive labels, good quality, and they stay put.

Works much better than aluminum foil for melting cheese on burgers...doesn't blow away with the draft from the grill, and won't stick to the top.  I also like this for covering splattering chicken pieces on the bone...it will cover about 3 pieces of chicken, or 2 burgers.  It would be perfect if it was just an inch or two wider in diameter -- then it would cover 3 or 4 burgers at a time.It could be a little heavier/thicker grade stainless -- it does get dinged a little easily.  However, for the price it's a really good deal.  I like that the handle on top has enough space that it can be easily grabbed while wearing oven mitts -- I hate trying to wrestle things like this off the grill using tongs!  Always ends up on the ground.All in all, a good design -- I even find it coming in handy indoors on the stove.  This will cover high items like large, whole, bone-in chicken breasts, which none of my pan lids will fit over without sitting on the food itself.  Also good for keeping food on a plate warm!

I first bought these in my grocery store -- I'm just a sucker sometimes for new products!  Also, there are times when I'd rather not cross transfer things between my dish sponge or cloth and a different task, such as scrubbing gross stuff off the side of the stove, floor, or washing out the dog's dish.  (Yes, I know, they have less bacteria in their mouths than we do...but that "slime" in the water dish still turns my stomach!!)I also needed (ok, not the right word) these to clean my bathtub -- I have an acrylic bathtub (not fiberglass), and just about no bathroom cleaning product I've ever found says specifically that it's safe for acrylic surfaces.  When I finally contacted the tub manufacturer, I found out that what I'm supposed to clean it with is simple dishwashing liquid (as long as it doesn't contain bleach).  Don't know why that never occurred to me!  Anyway, dishwashing liquid works great on the tub, dries cleanly and sparkly.  These Dawn-impregnated paper towels actually work even better than a sponge and dishwashing liquid did...they really get the tub clean, without a ton of suds to get it in the way (too many suds can make it hard to tell what's been cleaned and what hasn't sometimes).  They are tough, too -- I can keep ringing them out and they really don't tear or disintegrate mid-task.The only problem is that they always have the Dawn in them to some extent, so I still end up needing a plain towel to rinse and wipe things off at the end with just plain water.  This is the flaw in this product -- that they don't replace any product in your house, really.  You still need dishwashing liquid in a bottle (at the very least, to be able to soak things in the sink).  You still need regular paper towels, since of course with these pre-soaped towels, you can't do any soapless wipe-downs, use in a microwave, line a muffin/roll basket, windex your house or car windows, wipe your mouth, dry your hands, etc.  You'll also still probably want a Lysol wipe type product or other cleaning product to do cleaning jobs for which you want to disinfect (i.e., around the toilet bowl, fridge handle and doorknobs) or for jobs that you don't want to produce any suds (wiping off splatter from the wall, floor, etc.).  So it really becomes an extra cleaning product in your house taking up space, that might not come in as handy as you'd think...My biggest gripe about these, actually, is why do they come on a roll at all?  They don't replace your regular paper towels (which likely are on a paper towel holder), and they shouldn't be confused with paper towels, since that could be disgusting or even unhealthy (if food is microwaved all wrapped up in them, for example.).  Guests and children will assume they're normal paper towels.Also, you tend to use them next to the sink, as shown in the video -- so in roll form, they have to just sit there on the counter next to the sink.  If you need to grab a second towel, you have to pick up the towel with often wet hands to do so, which can start to activate the soap on the rest of the roll that you're holding onto in order to tear a new one off.  Also, the whole roll can easily become wet, since it's sitting on the counter where you're doing dishes -- unless you install a whole 2nd paper towel holder for just this product, of course!It would have been far more practical if they'd folded these (like individual paper towels in a school or other public bathroom) and put them into some sort of dispenser box.  That way you could easily take out one at a time, and store them anywhere.  They would also always be labelled correctly, nobody would get them confused with regular paper towels, and you could grab one out with wet hands and not have to pick up the whole thing.  You could just keep the box right next to the sink, and nobody would think that it was a roll of paper towels.So overall, while this product has some features I like, I won't be purchasing it again, at least not if they continue to make it in a roll form.  I don't want to have to keep explaining to people, "Wait! That's not a paper towel...here, use these instead" every time...and there's no logical place to store these where they won't get mixed up with the paper towels.For now, I have actually torn off--one by one--every towel on the roll, folded them, and I keep them in an empty garbage bag box, under the sink...it's the only way I could think of to keep these from getting confused with paper towels!

This size "small" was EXACTLY what I wanted.  At 5x7, it's roughly the same size as an iPad Mini.  It's perfect for me to throw in my purse when I need it -- I use it all the time for everyday stuff, like shopping lists and notes/information from phone calls, etc.  It's not too big and not too small.Note the size you're getting--they make it confusing by showing a full-size notebook in the video!  They should show something to scale next to it, or somehow emphasize its smaller size as opposed to a standard notebook-paper spiral notebook.The cover is plastic and durable, it has a pen holder on the front, and the paper is decent (100 sheets).  The divider inside I was expecting to like a little more...it definitely won't fall out (like a bookmark easily could), but it actually has the opposite problem, where its a little annoying to remove and replace where you want it.  I want to keep moving it to my current page, but it usually gets too annoying to move, so I just bend the page over or use something as a bookmark.  The divider would probably be most useful if you semi-permanently wanted to separate two sections and didn't need to move it around a lot.All in all, it's really fit the bill for what I needed -- a small notebook that can fit inside any bag, glove compartment, etc., to keep miscellaneous information and shopping lists in.Oh, by the way, someone else didn't understand the point of the canvas cover over the spiral wire binding -- let me tell you, when winter hits and sweater season begins, you'll understand!  Those wires can get a tiny bit bent and ruin a sweater in one hurried moment...I love that spiral wire cover!!  Major clothes saver.

"Signature Blend" -- this is a pretty decent, fairly bold, medium roast coffee.  It claims to have a "caramel" taste to it, however, which I do not get at ALL from drinking this coffee!  I have literally no idea what they're talking about.  It must be an extremely subtle caramel!  But that's ok, I wasn't super jazzed about caramel flavored coffee anyway...These have worked perfectly in my Keurig brewer -- I've had the problem with grounds in my coffee from other "off" brand K-cups, but I haven't had a fail with a Cafejo one yet, so no complaints here.I would basically describe the Signature blend as similar to an Italian roast, but not as burnt/dark.  Nice and strong...I'd actually call it an "extra bold," since most coffees NOT labelled that are fairly weak, in my experience.  There is a fair amount of weight to the cup as compared to non-bold K-cups, so I think there's enough coffee in there to be comparable to an extra bold (that's all extra bold means -- more coffee inside the cup).  Anyway, so I recommend this flavor if you like a bold, strong, coffee that isn't too burnt or dark roast tasting.  I think it makes for a very good wake-up coffee...and again, if you're looking for a caramel-flavored coffee, I would NOT go with this Signature blend, despite what the description says!

I was truly shocked when I opened the box -- this is NOT a "Satin Nickel" finish!  It looks exactly like a dull gray spray paint.  It really doesn't even look metallic...just matte gray.  I couldn't believe it -- it looks NOTHING like the pictures!It is nothing special -- it works just fine, the on/off click wheel (inline on the cord) is nice, and there are two different brightness settings.  The halogen bulb is 50 watts, and put out a decent amount of light, although it is yellowish and harsh.The adjustable arm on this lamp is not great -- although they made the base heavy, they didn't make it anywhere near heavy enough to actually hold the lamp in place when you adjust its position.  You have to use two hands whenever you want to tilt it in any direction.  It's not as flexible as I'd hoped, either -- it has a very limited range of movement for lamps like this.Overall, I don't recommend this lamp -- I don't think it's a high enough quality lamp for the price (which was around thirty bucks when I was writing this review).  The dull matte gray finish was truly disappointing and unacceptable.  A product really should look like its photo and match its description.  This is NOT "satin nickel."  They probably aren't doing enough quality control inspections at their factories.

This would be a great curved double shower curtain rod, but it has some flaws, mainly in manufacturing/quality control.First off, the name of the rod I got was "chrome" -- but it is NOT chrome.  It is a satin finish.  I noticed that now, as I am leaving this review, it says that the color is satin...so why is the product called chrome?? (The product box also says "CHROME" in big letters on the front, so it's obviously supposed to be chrome.)  It will not coordinate with chrome bathroom fixtures, which is a shame.  Please change the product name to reflect the truth, or actually make a chrome version.The rods themselves are good quality, but some other parts aren't.  The gaskets that go between the telescoping portions of the adjustable rods do not fit properly and are the cheapest I've ever seen, so they don't stay in place, which looks really bad and makes the shower curtain not glide smoothly over the rod.  I've owned several tension rods, and this is the first time I've seen a manufacturer get that part so wrong.The end caps are too thin, so they arrive dented in a few places, and they will dent easily when being used.  They also do NOT screw on with the included hardware.  The little screw things provided to secure the end caps in place are far too short, and are basically useless.  I am currently using tape to keep them in place!There are odd-looking giant gaping holes in the end caps where the rods enter them, which you can see the black plastic base through after the product is installed...this is pretty obvious in the product photos, but somehow in person I'd imagined it would look better.  It doesn't look terrible, but the eye is definitely drawn to it, and the gaps seem far larger than necessary.  They let lots of water inside...fortunately since the end caps don't screw on, you can remove them to dry it out whenever you'd like.  ;-)There should be, as other reviewers have mentioned, a rubbery quality to the hard plastic "pads" that contact the wall, as with all other tension rods I've used.  No matter how tight I make it, if I bump the rod at all, it moves it, because there's nothing "grippy" on the ends to help keep it from sliding out of place.As for the pros...  I'm a single woman, and I was able to install it myself by following the directions carefully.  It took some time to get it into the right position, but I didn't think it was more difficult than I'd expected.  It would certainly be easier with two people, but one person can definitely install this if they measure carefully and closely follow the instructions.  The trickiest part, I thought, was adjusting the tension on each rod when it's on the wall -- the directions say to first tighten the back rod, then the front, but I found it to work much better if you keep going back and forth between the two rods, adjusting each one little by little, more and more -- that way one doesn't get way shorter or longer than the other, which would cause the rod to slip out of place somewhat.  Also, if they're not appearing to be parallel to each other, it's probably because one is tighter than the other.Anyway, so the installed double rod is generally nice, and I like the extra space it gives me in the shower.  (I put both my decorative and liner shower curtains on the same rod -- the rear one -- and use the front rod as an extra towel bar, which is very helpful in my tiny bathroom which only has room for one short towel bar on the wall.)  However, there are just a few too many quality control issues, with the ill-fitting dented end caps, the poor quality gaskets that will not stay in place where the rods telescope together, and the lack of any grippiness at all on the ends to keep the shower rod in place on the wall.  It would be a great rod if they fixed these issues.

I wanted a diffuser to enjoy a variety of essential oils, particularly lavender at night.  The scent really helps me to sleep, but there's only so much oil one can put on one's skin before it starts to get gross, especially in the summer!This diffuser is easy to use -- it comes with a small "pitcher" which is the same size as the water tank inside the unit.  You simply fill up the pitcher, add 3-5 drops of essential oil, and turn it on.  The water vapor is produced by "ultrasonic" vibrations (not by a heating element), and a thin, steady stream of cold water vapor emerges from the top within a minute or so.  It runs almost silently.This particular oil diffuser also has an LED light...a feature which gives it the ambience of a lava lamp, with all the tackiness of a flashing fiber optic made-in-China Christmas tree.  The LED lights change color constantly every 3 seconds or so between blue, red, purple, and green (in a show I find to be annoying), though most of the diffuser still looks green throughout, because the outer housing is a lime green plastic.  It's just an odd light at the bottom that changes color (the photos are fairly accurate in is respect).  I find it to be a strange combination to have flashing lights with essential oils, which people usually use for some sort of relaxation or perhaps healing qualities...  A steady light would have been SO much better than the flashing.Seriously, the LED light component of it is pretty bad...there are 3 settings that the power button controls: Diffuser on/Lights off, a Diffuser on/Lights on, and Off.  You simply toggle between the three settings.  The problem with this system is that there is no tiny indicator light anywhere on the diffuser to indicate when the diffuser is on, but the LED lights are off...so you can't really tell if it's on unless you make the room quiet and listen very closely (the water vapor stream can be nearly impossible to see in certain lighting and backgrounds, so it often is invisible).I personally always use it with the LED lights OFF, because I get migraines that are triggered by flashing lights (and because I'm not running it in a brothel).  I just really wish they'd just put a tiny LED light somewhere on the unit just to indicate when it's ON, but the blinking LED lights are off.  The best thing to do, of course, is to just unplug the unit when not in use....but that is hard to remember to do consistently, so a light to alert you it's on would be even safer.  I may put it on a timer just to be sure it's off after a certain length of time (it says not to run it for "an extended period of time," but it doesn't define what "extended" is...?  6 hours?  24?  Who knows!)Anyway, so overall, the diffuser works well, the oil seems to be diffused evenly and then scent is heavenly -- it even comes with a 5 ml bottle of lavender oil, which is nice.  Note that you cannot use this to inhale vapors directly (it's not something that's intended to be breathed in when you have a cold).  It is to infuse your home with the scent of essential oils, and it does that well.  It basically works ok (could be nicer, but it gets the job done), the LED light show is truly awful...but if you like flashing lights, you'll love it!  It would be great for a party or something.  I'd upgrade it to 4 stars if there was an "on" indicator, and if the housing was white instead of green, which would be more attractive (I'd actually hoped the green in the product photo might have been just from an LED light, but the whole top is actually green plastic).FYI, I don't think it would work well as a night light (for a child or adult), because the only setting for the lights is flashing, which would be too distracting when trying to sleep.  A soft, steadier light would be nicer, especially if you could choose one specific solid color.

Beautiful tablecloth!  The green looks particularly lovely at Christmastime with the DII red metallic circular placemats...really festive.  The damask pattern is really attractive.I use the tablecloth on a small, 36" diameter circular table, so it hangs over a long way all around -- I wanted it to hide my blue chair cushions, which clash with decorations during the holidays.  I do not actually sit often at the chairs on this table -- if I did, this would be annoyingly in the way!  It is made for a bigger table, but as I said, I wanted the long, hanging look.The tablecloth handles washing well, stains seem to come right out.  It does not wrinkle much -- it may need a bit of ironing just around the hem when it needs to look perfect, but I find that a straightening iron works well in this capacity -- and I don't have to drag out the ironing board!

Do you "need" a special towel with which to dry off your four-legged best friend?  No.  But it's really cute, and it does tend to prevent people from inadvertently using the dog's furred-up towel to dry themselves off after a walk in the rain.  :-)The paw print is embroidered on, and it's done really nicely, actually.  The black embroidery looks quite handsome against the taupe/tan towel color, and it stands out distinctively.The towel itself won't seem absorbent at all when you first get it -- as with most towels, it needs to be washed first to wash off the "sizing" (finishing product on fabric products that make them look nice and travel well to the store).  Wash it on hot, and don't use any fabric softener.  I think it gets most absorbent after a few washes, so I threw it in every time I did a load of laundry at first -- but it'll be noticeably more absorbent after just the first wash in hot water.The size is just right for my dog (a larger Shih Tzu, about 20 pounds).  It wouldn't be big enough for a big dog, except for just wiping off its legs and back, etc., after a walk in the rain or something.  I can mostly dry my dog after a bath (if his hair isn't long) with this, but I usually need a second towel to really do the job.  I have never found that ANY single towel will dry my dog completely anyway, I always think you need two, unless maybe you have a chihuahua or something!  (Plus, I need that extra towel anyway to dry off the 10-foot "shake radius" of water droplets produced, so that's hardly a deal-breaker for me!)Anyway, this is an excellent towel to keep by the door after walking your dog in the rain -- clearly marked with the paw print, it's perfect for this purpose, and it looks attractive enough to keep out all the time without looking odd.Oh, it dries pretty quickly, too -- MUCH faster than a regular bath towel.  Lightweight too, so it's great for travel -- I usually line the dog carrier with it.

I questioned whether or not an air purifier would do anything at all in my home, since a newer furnace boasts that it contains a "whole-house air purifier" within it.Well, clearly the furnace's "purifier" is missing a lot of stuff!  After using this Holmes model for a week, both the black sponge-like filter and the Hepa filter show copious amounts of dust and fine particles it has filtered out of the air.  I moved the purifier between different rooms of the house, and what I discovered is that after it ran in a particular room for 24 hours, I would notice that the room smelled as if it had been "aired out"...I found myself checking a couple times to see if I'd left a window open in a room, forgetting the air purifier was in there.It runs quietly--no issues there.  It has 3 running speeds: low, medium, high.  The low speed is so quiet that I thought it had turned itself off.  The medium speed is so quiet that I can't hear it either if there is anything in the house making any noise at all...i.e., air conditioning, television, etc.  Even without background noise, the medium speed is quiet enough that I completely tune it out, even if it's sitting right in front of me.  The high speed is louder -- much like a white noise machine.  I actually very much like the sound of the highest speed, especially when I'm sleeping.  It is consistent and perfectly "white" and even, no awkward motor sounds, etc.  It's great to sleep with, and it keeps my dog from hearing another dog bark a mile away, so it's made for a pleasant and quiet summer!  :-)I am certain this air purifier is doing a great job of filtering particles out of the air, especially allergens such as pollen.  I only have mild allergy issues, but my dog has significant seasonal allergies.  It never occurred to me that my dog would benefit from filtered air, but ever since I started using this purifier, his symptoms have been significantly reduced -- I am now keeping it close to his sleeping place at night, in fact.  I think it must be filtering out the pollen he brings in on his shaggy coat, which reduces the amount he inhales, steps on, licks off his feet, gets on his belly, etc.  Great benefit I never predicted!

Dimensions:Total length (tip to tip):  6 1/2"  (16.5 cm)Cord length (between tips):  4 1/2"  (11.5 cm)This 6" cord is PERFECT for charging my iPhone with an external battery!  I have a flat rectangular external battery, which is about the size of the phone itself.  It allows me to charge my phone without an outlet, and without carrying the phone in a bulky battery case.  With the 6" cord, I can easily hold the battery and phone together to continue using the phone while charging -- no long 4 foot cord to trip over or get tangled in my purse!It charges extremely quickly -- I think the length of the cord is directly related to the length of charging time...in other words, the longer the cord, the longer the charge time (it's why Apple doesn't give you or even sell a 6 or 10 foot long charge/sync cord).  So this 6" cord charges even faster than the 3 foot original cord (although not a lot faster).The cord itself (gold metallic) is really attractive -- both ends are clad in a matte finished aluminum, with a durable plastic on the inside.  But the cord itself is really beautiful -- it is covered in a sleeve of closely braided gold satin thread.  It has a soft feel to it -- it is not covered by clear plastic or anything, so it actually has a fabric/cord feel to it.  I would seriously wear a bracelet made out of this cord, it's that nice!  It can get "pulls" in it or fray, since it is a fiber, so just make sure you don't plan to keep it near something like a Velcro strap, or similarly rough items that could snag on it.It still has plenty of strength to it -- flexibility wise, it feels slightly more flexible than a regular Belkin plastic cord, and slightly less flexible than Apple's original cord.  It feels like it'll hold up for a long time (which has been my experience with Belkin cords, they last longer than the Apple ones for me).I've had no issues with compatibility with this cord (but I have in the past with others).  One thing I read is that you should plug the cord into your other source FIRST (outlet, charger, computer, speaker, whatever), and THEN plug the cord into the iPhone itself.  That should get rid of the "this device is not compatible" message (for devices you know ARE compatible, of course).

Very handy wipes...love that these come in a 3 pack, so I can keep one in each car and one in the house!  The dog likes to leave nose prints on the windows in all three locations, so this makes for a quick cleanup when it gets too gross.  Previously I'd tried the flat "packets" with the peel-off flap to open, but those always seemed to come open and dry out before I could use half of them.These leave no noticeable lint behind like some paper towels can.  They're also not too wet, so they don't tend to streak or leave residue.  They are not, for example, nearly as wet as a Lysol wipe; Lysol wipes are more of a fully saturated wet wipe, and this is more of a "damp" wipe -- just what you'd normally want when cleaning glass.Only drawback is that the cans could be a little more tightly sealed...I haven't had issues with liquid leaking out, but I have had the cap open and the towels dry out, I think when there were multiple items competing for space and the can got jostled or squeezed in a little.  I now keep a little piece of scotch tape on the lid just to make sure it stays shut.

I love Flair pens!  I write with exclusively either these (which I would call "regular" Flairs) or Liquid Flairs every single day.  I get severe shoulder and hand pain if I try to write with a ball point pen, and these require almost no pressure and little hand strength to write with.The tropical colors are nice -- know that about half of these colors won't be great probably to write with for "official" purposes, because they're too light or lower in contrast-- but they're excellent colors for drawings, emphasizing certain words, color coding, etc.I think the tips on these last a long time.  If you press really hard, they'll get larger and probably won't last as long...but you don't need to press hard at all to write with these, so if you use them nicely, they should last at least as long as other pens, probably longer.  Make sure to snap the caps on all the way.They are not permanent (they're not Sharpies), so you can't use them to write on plastic or magazine type paper, because they'll smear.  They also don't smell bad like permanent markers, and they don't tend to bleed through paper (although they will a little bit, especially with thinner paper, like newspaper or phone book type paper).  I would say you probably wouldn't want to plan to write fully on both sides of notebook paper with these, because you'll probably be able to see through to the other side.  This doesn't bother me, because of the ease in writing with Flairs.  They don't bleed through the paper that checks are made from, so they're fine to write checks with, they won't ruin the next check or anything.FYI, you can't press through to multiple carbon copies with Flairs (or any felt tip pens) -- you'd need a ball point pen for that.  You'd damage the felt tip if you tried, and even then it wouldn't be hard enough to provide the pressure needed.  I find that there are few instances nowadays when you are required to write on forms with carbon copies, so I don't think that's a big problem.  (I have also just written on each of the carbon copy pages individually to avoid shoulder pain from ball point pens.)These usually wash out easily of clothing (assuming the clothing is washable and you don't wait too long or accidentally dry it before noticing the ink...though even then I usually can get it out with an overnight soak in detergent water).  I wouldn't necessarily give them to little kids, though, unless they're wearing old clothes and stay away from upholstery!  :-)Overall, I prefer the Liquid Flairs (aka Liquid Expresso), because they're even easier to write with than these Flairs -- but those are significantly more expensive, and they also take longer to dry, so they can be impractical when you're in a hurry (like with check writing).  The Liquid Flairs can also be more prone to leaks, mostly caused by broken caps...these regular Flairs have caps that never break, in my experience.  I keep both kinds in my purse, on my desk, and pretty much everywhere else I write!

I'd forgotten how Tammy Fay Baker's eyelashes looked...but I remember now!This is some seriously heavy-looking mascara.  I was hoping for more of a voluminous look, sort of like the gel lashes look...but this is more of a "look how much mascara I have on" look.  It's virtually impossible to put this stuff on even slightly normal looking, because of the weird applicator.  I may actually try to put a different applicator in if I find one that fits from another mascara that I use up all the way...I suspect that's the only difference between this and any other (cheap) mascara.It also flaked and smeared...really bad.  Like Wet-n-Wild bad.  I think this is marketed towards teens, because the regular price is slightly lower than other L'Oreal mascara...but I wouldn't recommend it even for club-hopping, because I don't care what your age is, girls want their mascara on their lashes, not smeared on their cheeks and undereye area.It's worth paying an extra 2 or 3 dollars and getting a better mascara:"L'Oreal Double Extend" is great (provides great length, doesn't come off, yet weirdly comes right off all at once with only water!).  Two coats, but worth the extra time.Also nice for making very beautiful lashes is "Cover Girl Clump Crusher" -- not as long wearing as the Double Extend, but makes more of a statement, and is faster to apply.  No flaking.

These pads do seem to have a lot of potential - they really seemed to minimize pores and generally smooth my skin.  (The effects kind of reminded me of when I used to use Retin-A gel.).  The pads felt exfoliating to me, kind of rough, at least with the product on them.Unfortunately, the pads quickly became too irritating to my (sensitive) skin, and I finally had to stop using them.  I could not find a schedule or application method that worked for me.  So, as long as you don't have sensitive skin, these will probably work well...but if your skin can't take products that sting a little, you probably won't be able to tolerate these.

I use this serum on my face and neck -- for everywhere else, I use the Sublime Bronze spray.I find that the tan color matches between this serum and the spray (they're both L'Oreal, so not surprising).  The serum actually colors better and more efficiently than the spray -- there's little or no wasted product, versus the spray, which is easier to apply evenly to awkward areas, but ends up with a large amount of product on the floor.I have fair skin, and I don't need 3 consecutive days for this to look like a nice, light natural color -- I'd say two days is almost always just right.  I reapply (once) after about 3 days, or if I swim, exfoliate, sweat a lot, etc.  I like that it isn't too much, too soon -- easier to correct minor mistakes (uneven application or skipped spots).I would DEFINITELY get a pair of latex or vinyl gloved to apply this, however!  It will stain your hands (hard to wash it ALL off, it always ends up somewhere), and also, you'll waste a lot when it soaks into the skin on your hands.  With gloves, it almost all goes right into your skin, nothing wasted.  I think gloves help to apply it more evenly, too.

I'm overall not impressed with this bacon grilling rack.  The reasons why I WOULDN'T recommend it:- The rack itself is designed with two separate "channels" for grease to drain on either side -- this makes it difficult to drain the hot grease after cooking (since obviously you can't pour hot grease into a garbage bag or can).  You either need to pour it into a very large-mouthed contained (like a mixing bowl) first, and THEN pour it into a grease jar; or you need to pour it simultaneously into two separate jars spaced perfectly apart.  (And you can't just carefully fold the rack back up and THEN drain it all at once from the now-close-together channels, because they tilt at an angle when folded and would spill.)  Also, they could've at least put a small spout at the end(s) of the grease channels to aid in draining them...it is hard to predict which direction the hot bacon grease will pour out.- For a bacon cooker, it doesn't fit many pieces of bacon -- maybe 6?- It's not easy to clean, because the grease draining channels and every other corner of this metal rack is squared off -- so there are lots of deep, squared-off inside corners to try to reach and clean out.  Rounded or curved surfaces anywhere would have been a much better design.  You need a Q-Tip to clean this thing out thoroughly.- You can't flip the bacon halfway through cooking, because it is rigid and v-shaped.  You can flip the bacon much earlier in the cooking process--maybe 1/4 way through cooking--but even that is a little awkward.- The draining channels are not big enough to catch all the grease from any more than a few pieces of bacon (unless you have really lean bacon, like turkey bacon, maybe).  So you'll need to drain this thing halfway through if you want to cook 10-12 pieces.So overall, while it generally works, it is not designed well enough for me to recommend it.  It will cook about 5 or 6 pieces of bacon, but I'm afraid people will burn themselves trying to figure out how to drain this thing, or trying to turn it to get the bacon to cook evenly.  It is also annoying to clean, due to the squared box-shaped grease channels, and folds up a little awkwardly -- seemingly bulkier than it would need to be.I'd keep looking if I were you!

This BB Cream ("BB" stands for "Beauty Balm," in case you didn't know) is basically a tinted moisturizer with SPF 15 sunscreen.  I'm not certain what else a "BB Cream" is SUPPOSED to do, but I can tell you that to me, they perform just as a tinted moisturizer with SPF...so I think it is primarily a newer marketing term.Anyway, this Proactiv BB Cream is both non-comedogenic (won't clog pores) and fragrance-free.  (Note that it is not labeled as hypo-allergenic, however.)  I have very sensitive skin, and this product did irritate my skin a little on days when it was sensitive already (if I'd exfoliated recently, or if it was very hot or windy outside).Anyway, this isn't going to replace a sunscreen if you are OUT in the sun -- it's really better for everyday exposure to the sun, in small amounts, like walking to your car, etc.  Not for the beach (you have to keep from exposing the bottle to direct sun anyway).  Be sure to not get it too near your eyes...apply it AFTER any under-eye concealer.It works ok as a tinted product -- not much coverage, but it also has a nice, natural appearance, unlike a lot of BB Creams I've tried, which tend to make the face look dirty.  It works very well on me as a moisturizer, at least now in the warmer months.  It feels very smooth on the skin, and it felt moisturizing all day.  It doesn't feel greasy, and it feels especially nice and "clean" around the nose area, which can easily feel oily, and is a region where I often feel products don't "sink in" to my skin very well.Overall, I like this BB Cream -- I wouldn't use it if I were to be in the sun a lot on a given day (it warns you to reapply every 2 hours in the sun, and that would get expensive fast!).  I like it for everyday use -- for something like work or school.  I use it instead of a foundation, with some concealer, since it's a lighter product and is not intended to provide a lot of coverage.I have pretty fair skin, and the "Light" wasn't too dark, didn't make my skin look dirty or muddy, and blended well with my (pale, reddish toned, Scandinavian-type) coloring.

I have sensitive skin, and Cetaphil is one of the few face washes that won't break the bank.(During severe sensitive skin flare-ups -- typically during extreme cold/dry weather or when I've been swimming in chlorine -- I use CeraVe, but that doesn't clean quite as well if my skin is particularly sweaty or dirty.)This formula for "men" seems to me to be exactly the same as the regular formula, except for its scent.  It smells slightly like most men's toiletries, but nothing overpowering.  The scent is mild and refreshing.  It doesn't irritate my sensitive skin.  I think it actually smells better than the regular, so I'd either buy whichever one is cheaper, or just get the men's if they're the same.  No reason a husband and wife couldn't both use this product.It rinses cleanly and really doesn't leave a lingering scent behind that will clash with aftershave or cologne.  My skin doesn't feel dry and tight after using it (unless it already felt that way before washing). Works well to prep the skin before shaving, since it removes dirt and oil but doesn't strip or irritate the skin (except in cases where my skin is extremely dry in the winter).The shape of the bottle is nice, because it doesn't tend to tip over or need to be held with the other hand when using the pump to dispense the product.

I thought from the picture that this nail clipper was a wider, unique design, which had a larger area to grip (better for men's hands).However, this is simply a standard, regular nail clipper, which is placed inside of a black sort of "shell" that supposedly catches the clippings.  You lift the clippers out of the black part completely to empty it (which is extremely difficult!)It does NOT catch clippings in the black part, however -- there is not a "reservoir" for clippings in that black area on the sides, it's just solid plastic!  Clippings just get crammed behind the blades, so it will fill up quickly.It takes a lot of force to pull the metal clippers out of that pointless black plastic shell to empty them, too...and then you have to smack the clippers to get the clippings to come out, because they're just packed in right behind the blade.  This takes approximately 100 times more effort than simply getting a garbage can and clipping over it to begin with.The clippers are nice and sharp, but are only on the nicer end of a normal drug store set of nail clippers...they do not work ANY better.  They are the exact same design as pretty much every nail clipper you have ever seen, nothing special.  The black plastic shell is so annoying that it's about the end up in the garbage along with any clippings that it didn't really catch.  Oh, and if you can see what appears to be a metal edge along the side of the black plastic shell...it's just a strip of thin metal trim that has been glued on!  I think it's placed there to make it seem like it's a pull-out file or something useful, or to make you think the black plastic part is integrated into the clippers...either way, just something to fool people into thinking these are nicer than they are.There is no swing-out file/nail cleaner, FYI...kind of surprised they'd charge this much for nail clippers and not even bother to throw in that feature.These are definitely NOT worth the price they're listed for.  Total waste of money (unless they now cost three dollars!)

This review is for "Unstopables Febreze Air Freshener - Fresh" (the scent of the can with the blue top is called "Fresh."  It is a Febreze-containing air freshener, but at least at the time I am writing this review, its product name inadvertently leaves out the word Febreze, unlike the other two scents).This 9.7 ounce can is a slightly larger size than most air freshener cans (the Air Wick can I most recently bought is 8 ounces).It has a trigger-pull style top, however, I should point out that in fact this IS an aerosol can.  The trigger makes it look like a spray bottle (like what Windex comes in, for example), but in fact when you press the trigger, aerosol-propelled air freshener comes out.  It will keep spraying continuously if you hold the trigger, just like when you hold the button down on a regular can of air freshener, or a can of spray paint.  It is easier to spray than a regular air freshener can because of the comfortable trigger style, and it won't clog or need to be tipped in a certain direction when it's close to empty like a spray bottle does...but I wanted to be clear that if you wanted to purchase this product because the can style is better for the environment, the trigger is just for looks and ease of use; it's still aerosol.Anyway, the "Fresh" scent of this air conditoner is actually a pretty fantastic smell!  It smells to me like rain, combined with a sweet women's cologne.  It has a slight smell of Febreze as well, which I like.  It doesn't smell heavy to me, it smells very appealing, and indeed I think 'fresh' is a good word for it.  It does a very good job of covering up odors, in the bathroom or otherwise.  It lasts pretty long -- I'm not sure I can smell it 6 hours later as the can claims, but I definitely can still smell it at least a couple hours after spraying it.  I can use far less of this to cover an odor than most air fresheners...just a very short spray will eliminate an odor completely in most cases.A note on prices...at the time I wrote this review, this 9.7 ounce can was being listed for 3-4 times the cost of a regular 8 oz. can of air freshener -- I believe it was about twelve dollars!  I do not understand why, or if that was an error (maybe it was supposed to be a multi-pack?), but there is nothing that should make a single can of this product cost that much more than a regular air freshener; in stores it is only marginally more expensive, due to its larger size and the Febreze name.  I would think 5 or 6 bucks would be a reasonable upper price limit.

I actually think this "Saggo Worry Eater" is just ok...it's not quite as nice as I thought it would be.He is 14" tall, from his foot to the top horn on his head, and 9" wide from arm to arm.  His zippered mouth is 6 1/2" wide.  He is 90% polyester, 10% cotton.  There are no clear washing instructions -- only on the sewn-in tag are there some of those extremely tiny "cleaning hieroglyphics" that nobody can translate (such as the triangle which has been crossed out...do not put this into a triangle or pyramid of any kind!)  It appears that the only symbol which has not been crossed out is possibly a hand reaching into a basin of water(?)  It's very small, but I think that's what the symbol shows...so I'm guessing it is saying to hand wash this only.  Or maybe to have it baptized.  Your call.  ;-)His tag says he is suitable for all ages, 0+ months.  You must remove the orange plastic loop sewn in at the top if a baby is to be around this.  I don't think I'd be comfortable giving a baby this toy, with a zipper.  I think this toy seems more suitable for a child who is at least 2 years old (but ideally one who can write at some level).It is very soft material, just slightly less plush or not quite as nice quality as I was expecting.  The orange stripes aren't as bright as they appear in the pictures.  On the one I received, the striped material is slightly duller in color than the solid orange material (but neither appear "vivid").  I hate to say it, but I'm sure I've seen a stuffed "Worry Eater" toy like this that used to actually be made in Germany, and was quite nicer...this is now made in China.  It seems mass-produced now...nice enough quality, but not made with the same level of care it once was.The zipper is excellent quality, and the way the mouth is red inside is very cute.  I wish the pocket inside ran the whole front length of the body -- the pocket only extends about halfway down the front of the striped body.  Still, it is big enough to fit a lot of paper -- you'd just need to use small pieces.  Would be cute if it came with a little pad of paper!There is an 2" orange plastic hanging loop, with a break at one end for removal, which is sewn in with a small white loop of cord, at the top of the head, behind one of the "horns."  It is odd that this isn't sewn in behind at the top horn, though (it's behind horn #4, if you count from left to right).  The plastic loop is visible when not in use, and if used, won't hang the Saggo straight.  (Not a big deal, since you can take it off.)The thing that kind of bugs me is that for a "Worry Eater," this particular character (Saggo) seems to exude anxiety, from his stripes to his psychotic eyes.  He looks kind of freaked out...  I feel like if I were a child with a lot of worries, I wouldn't find it soothing to have that strung-out, fearful expression in my bed!  I know, he's supposed to look worried, since he "eats your worries"...it makes sense, and honestly, many kids will probably love him.  I just think many of the other "Worry Eater" characters actually have nicer looks -- they have the same nervous zippered mouth and a worried expression, but goofier, sillier faces (with less frantic eyes!)...I'd pick one of those instead.

I have used many "contractor" bags since buying a fixer-upper of a house a few years ago.  Every brand of black contractor bags I've tried is strong enough to not rip under even pretty brutal conditions (such as broken asphalt tiles, splintered wood), within reason of course.  A nail sticking out of a piece of wood will poke through any bag, including these.However, the other non-flexing and non-drawstring contractor bags have a big problem: they are extremely difficult to move!  They can be filled, but then have to be tied off at the top with a cable tie or large twisty -- then picked up and brought to the curb (or thrown into a garbage can, which is even harder, since construction waste is usually quite heavy).  Unless non-drawstring bags are only half full, I can get a good enough grip on the bag to carry it very far -- so I end up using more of them, which wastes money.With these Ultra Flex drawstring bags, I find it much easier to carry them out of the house or out to the curb, since they have a handle.  I can also fill them up more, both because I don't have to allow room for a loose area of the bag to be tied off at the top with a twisty tie, and because these expand to allow more awkwardly-shaped items inside.So even if these are more expensive to begin with than plain contractor bags (and they're not that much more expensive), I use less of them...even half as many in some cases.  They are also far less frustrating to deal with, I spend less time trying to fit garbage inside them a specific way, because they will flex to accommodate items that are a little too large/long for regular contractor bags.  They are extremely difficult to rip -- even when they tear, it's not usually "all over"...they seem to just tear in one place, but often can still be used.  These also don't open up after they're tied off, so when they're all piled at the curb on trash day, they don't come open if they fall over or another bag lands on top of them.  Saves a lot of headaches.  Highly recommend having a bag of these on hand for any household renovations.

I do not like this set of hooks as much as I'd expected to.  I wouldn't recommend it to anyone.PROBLEM #1: STRIPS SHOW THROUGH!My biggest gripe is that you can see right THROUGH the hooks...you can even tell which way the strips are facing!  These are special strips, made exclusively for these "clear" bath items -- but they made the plastic hooks TOO clear, so you can see right though it to the Command strips behind it.  (Naturally, this has been photoshopped out of the product photos.)  Ugly and tacky!PROBLEM #2: HOOKS TOO WIDE TO HANG MOST THINGS ON!The hooks themselves are too thick/wide to hang many bath items on.  No items I have for the bath that have holes on their handles for hanging will fit on this hook, because the hooks are wide at their tips to begin with, and get even wider towards the bottom.  Items with loops or strings (such as bath puffs or soap-on-a-rope) will fit, but many things like foot files, a back brush, a loofah on a stick, any bottles with hanging holes for the shower -- won't fit onto these hooks at all.  BOO, 3M!  I don't understand that product design decision at ALL, it makes the hooks far less useful.  Loops of string will hang off just about anything, including a shower head, I hardly need a fancy hook set for that...I assumed a specially designed set of bath hooks would also accommodate other hanging bath items.  (You'll notice in their product photo, only items with strings are shown hanging, because that's probably all they could find to fit on these hooks too!)PROBLEM #3: ONLY 1 SET OF STRIPS COME WITH IT!Have you ever bought a Command hook that DIDN'T come with 2 sets of strips (so you could install the hook somewhere twice?)  Me neither.  Well, on the package, this one says "2 Large Strips" -- but guess what?  You need BOTH strips to put the hook up ONE TIME.  So you'd better get it in the right place the first time...no second chances here!  It should have said "One set of strips included" or something clearer.  Especially annoying, because these types of strips are more expensive, and much harder to find replacements for.  Also, the adhesive strips that came with mine had far less aggressive adhesive than comes with every other Command hook I've ever used.  I pressed it on like crazy, but I fully expect it to fall off...FYI, I think these hooks are VERY old (I bought this in May 2015)...the adhesive seems dried up already.  The date on the packaging says 2013.I wouldn't buy this product again.

This is a very sweet, soft all over doll, with a lovely lavender scent.  The doll itself is perfect for sending the little one (must be at least 12 months old) off to sleep...although I don't think the accessories, which include a pacifier, bottle, and lamb, as well as her clothes and the hat (which comes off to reveal a tuft of blonde hair), are a great idea to send to bed, because they just end up getting lost inside blankets, behind the headboard, etc.The pacifier is magnetic and sticks to the baby's mouth, and the BOTTLE is magnetic too!  They don't mention that the bottle is also magnetic in the description.  Very cute...the baby has an adorable smile without the pacifier blocking it.  Wish the pacifier had a clip to attach it to its outfit or something, it's very easy to lose.  Also wish the bottle wasn't white, because you just know that thing is going to end up in an actual child's mount at some point, and it gets a little gross...  But it's nice that even a young child can put the pacifier and bottle in, because you don't have to do anything more than just get them near the mouth, and the magnet pulls it into place!The doll itself is quite well made -- not just a flat, poorly constructed doll like many that are dressed.  It has a round belly, curved legs, a little bum...very cute!The clothes can be taken off -- they have Velcro closures.  They're pretty good quality compared to other doll clothing I've seen recently.  The sleeper is one piece (in the picture, it appears that she is wearing pink booties, but in reality just the bottom soles of the feet of the sleeper are pink).  The diaper isn't as nice, it's kind of cheaply made...real preemie diapers will fit, but they'll be a bit large.  (Stella is potty trained, so she won't make a mess if she loses her diaper.)  ;-)The lamb is cute -- it has an elastic loop sewn onto it, so I'm the package it looks like Stella is holding it in her hand.  The loop is permanently sewn on (it can be cut off if you're concerned your child may put it on their wrist too tight, or on the dog's mouth or something!)The lavender scent is heavenly...they need to make an adult version of this!  I'm not sure yet how long the scent will last.  It isn't overpowering, and I really do think lavender has natural relaxing effects that promote sleep (it does for me!).  I washed it once, and it still has a little scent.  I keep a bottle of lavender oil on hand anyway (only a few dollars on Amazon), so when the scent begins to fade, I will just put a drop on the doll somewhere in a hidden area to "revive" the scent.I should mention, the face is embroidered on, so there are no eyes or other small parts that can come off.  The doll itself is nicely made.  (But again, 12 months and up.)I have washed it in the washing machine on a delicate ("hand wash") cycle, then tumble dried it on a very low setting for a bit, let it dry in a sunny window (just to make sure it didn't develop mildew) -- it did great!  I don't know if you're technically supposed to machine wash it, but I didn't have any problems.FYI, this is made in China.  Hard to find anything that isn't!

This cordless vacuum is a great solution for a large finished basement with multiple rooms, crevices, and hard-to-reach areas, like under/behind a staircase.  No cord to get caught on furniture and fixtures, or knock over lamps!  Also no constant looking for the next outlet that will allow me to reach everywhere I need to vacuum in the next room.  (This is a huge help, since bending over a lot to reach outlets near the floor hurts my back after a while.)It is flexible and small enough on the roller part that it fits nicely into smaller or wedge-shaped areas.  I am not very strong, and this vacuum is easy to pick up and move where I want it.I use it only to vacuum hardwood floor and tile floors (there's no carpet where I use it, except an extremely low-pile little rubber-backed door mat, which is does fine on, although it tends to pick it up off the floor with its powerful suction, like every other vacuum I've used on a door mat).I think this is specifically designed for hard floors, not carpeting.  This is perfect for my needs, and it means the vacuum doesn't have to be as large and heavy as one powerful enough to suck dirt out of thick carpets...so it is light enough to carry up and down a flight of stairs easily.One charge lasts me for at least 30 minutes, no problem, which is as long as I need to use it at one time -- it isn't showing any signs of dying at 30 minutes, so I'm confident it would work for 45 minutes or longer...maybe even an hour.  It does not take long to charge.The detachable DustBuster-like device isn't my favorite thing...I find it helpful in some situations, like getting some dust out from extremely small areas, such as behind the water heater, or vacuuming in a corner that has too many cords criss-crossing on the floor to be able to push the whole vacuum cleaner.I've never tried an Electrolux brand before, but I am impressed with the ability of this cordless vac!  I absolutely LOVE not having to navigate around with a cord.  It's great to use in a situation where there's a room without available or easily accessible outlets.  Also great if there are kids running around (or a spouse texting and not paying attention!) who will trip over unplug the cord by accident (or worse yet, fall and hurt themselves).I also like the freedom the cordless design gives you to vacuum from any direction -- with a cord, you tend to have to approach many areas with the outlet behind you, since if you turn around, the cord is in front and in the way...it's SO nice not to have to keep picking up and throwing the cord over coffee tables and things, or use your other arm as a "cord wrangler"...now you can just hold the vacuum in one hand, and a martini in the other.  ;-)

My dog is 8 years old -- he loves this food, eats it voraciously.It doesn't make him sick (with lower quality food, I've noticed that he will get sick a couple of times a month, on average...I have no idea what causes it, but I believe there is some ingredient missing that he requires to maintain a healthy digestive tract or something).  He never gets sick on this (Purina Pro Plan "Bright Mind") food.I deducted one star primarily because it contains meat by-product, and within the first 10 ingredients.  I would greatly prefer that by-product not be included in dog food -- I was a little surprised to see it in this food, because it is a premium line.  It's a very low-quality ingredient, and I hope Purina considers taking it out.Other than that, I'm generally satisfied with this food...my dog seems happy and healthy.  He does not, however, now have a "bright mind"...but he was born a knucklehead, and he will stay a knucklehead!  He thinks the world is a great place to be, and acts accordingly.  He instantly knows that every stranger he meets is the most wonderful person in the world!  So he just focuses on being happy and giving unconditional love, and leaves most of the thinking up to me.  Come to think of it, he is a pretty smart little guy.  ;-)

These arrived just thrown into a box, no directions.  There aren't directions printed onto the pod covers themselves, either.  However, maybe that's not supposed to be the norm...so I can overlook that and find the information I seek online.The biggest problem is that half of these were spilling open...seed and fertilizer all over the box, things inside the pods now mixed up or no longer at the depth they were supposed to be.I also am not sure these have been stored correctly, which is why I suspect the tops have come off some of them.  There was no protection from water, as they were just sitting in a cardboard box, so if the package got rained on...there's the end of your seeds and peat!At the end of the day, this is just not a good value, even if it does survive the journey intact...for example, zucchini doesn't even need to be started indoors or in a pot, the way tomatoes do.  Zucchini seeds can be sowed directly in the ground...and you can buy a whole package of seeds for each vegetable for the same price as just getting 4 seeds of each here.  Ideally you want to start many more plants such as tomato, because it is a "tender" plant, and you want to choose only the healthiest baby plants to try to get a harvest from...you want lots of choices when you thin them down to the final plants to grow, not one (or four from one pot!)I think this is a gimmick, and not a good value at all.  They give you far too little info as to how to grow these successfully (these included vegetable plants all can't start the same week, for example...tomatoes may need to have been started as early as March if you live in northern areas such as Chicago, for example).  So, if you buy these in May, it's already too late for the tomatoes, but too early for the cucumbers (again, this is an example...if you live in a warmer climate, the rules are different!)Overall, I wouldn't recommend this.  A better gift would be a lovely assortment of seed packets, with all their plentiful information and climate maps.  Include a package of peat pots, a starter tray, etc...you can come up with a much more useful, thoughtful (and probably more successful) gift!

I just got this, unboxed, and already realize I don't like it. I should have paid more attention to the ports and connectors.This battery may be great for power. I don't know and no longer care.The only port on the battery is a female micro USB, which sounds good and standards-based. But the battery uses this port for self-charging (a standard use, much like a phone) but then also uses the same port backwards for powering your dead mobile device (non-standard). You will need a male to male micro USB wire. Ask yourself, how many micro USB to micro USB wires have you ever seen?To make it work with just the one port, they include their own custom wire kit of 2 short adapter wires. One is the fairly standard male USB to male micro USB cable you can use to charge your phone or this battery. The other is a male micro USB to female USB. To charge this device is thus completely standard, and you could use your phone's charger and wire if you wanted. But to USE this battery on the go would require you to carry both the short wires they provide. That defeats the compact and simple nature of a credit card battery.The last one like this I had had a built-in male micro USB wire for your phone and a female port for self charging. It had little power, but at least it was simple.

Description today, 6/4/2012, says:"110-240vAC Input10A or 120W @12v Output2.5/5mm ID/OD Male Barrel Pulg"But unit I received was 12V 2A. I can't use it for my Foscam Fl8919w.************ Update:On the other hand, +1 star for very responsive customer service, and a refund.

I don't like this product. Neither do most of the other reviewers. But bear in mind, we're all adults. My 7 year old seems to enjoy it.and for that reason, I give it two stars. She likes it for making her own birthday cards.OTOH, she bored of it quickly, and it takes up a fair bit of space as it sits unused. The consumables (paper and ink) are consumed quickly, so you need to buy more. My LEDs NEVER worked, so the 3D light show just didn't happen. Although I doubt it looks all that impressive anyway, since our results looked nothing like the promotional pictures. The instructions are very complicated, leading me to think this thing was going to so something complicated. In the end, all that complicated reading amounts to fold black side out, use marker on black side, insert flat or arched, spin, drip solution, dry.
