I was expecting something more!But, like I said, ignorance is bliss. She liked it just fine.

I've never been too happy with Jerry Cans. Usually, there is some spillage as you pour, maybe even a little in your car from the gas station. This one is as good as I have ever tried. The valve truly controls the flow, and you can stop the flow fast.The short nozzle means you will have to aim and hold it steady. But I like it, less nozzle to flap around. The trigger is pretty high tension, so my hand go tired after emptying half the can.The modern laws that require no "vent" on Jerry cans for air return has made most cans flow like @#$#@. This one does a pretty great job of allowing air to return, and flow to continue. I bought the diesel 5gal version, and will probably get a red gasoline one now, since it is so much better than my Midwest brand Jerry. That one has an inferior kind of valve built into the nozzle, and it leaks, and has unpredictable performance, and doesn't have good air return.

Stop thinking about it. If you have a indoor Foscam, and you are spending the time worrying about signal strength, and you have invested your time, money, and wishes on the cameras, just get these antennae for EVERY one of your cams. Here's why:Unless the Foscam is in the same room as the router, an IP cam puts a lot of strain on your WiFi. Unlike web pages or email, a cam streams video, video is high bandwidth, and if you're storing your video on a PC (usin Blue Iris software, for example) the cam is streaming 24x7. Add a few more cams, and that's a lot of bandwidth.As your wifi channel becomes slightly congested, and your signal strength is not ideal, the cameras start dropping data packets, and trying to re-send, and then conflicting with the other cameras which all want to send their video NOW! Stronger signal avoids the lost packets and the resends. Use these, or even better, run Ethernet cable. You won't believe how much better the cameras work on Ethernet.By running all upgraded antennae, you will get better framerates from all cams, more reliable connections, the ability to have more cams on the same wifi network, fewer crashes, fewer bugs, faster PTZ response, etc. That's true even if your system works just fine with the shorties.Here's the downside, which is manageable: these antennas aren't magic. They don't make your signal stronger, they just change the aim of the signal. With the shorter stock 3dbi pole antenna, picture a big donut around the tip of the antenna. That is where your signal goes. Now, with this longer 9dbi pole antenna, picture a flat pancake around the tip of the antenna. That is where your signal goes with this unit. That means you have to aim the antenna in such a way that the wifi AP is on a plane perpendicular to the antenna. If your Foscam is one floor above your WiFi, this antenna will make your signal WORSE if you keep the antenna straight up, and don't "aim the pancake".

Take a look at all the negative reviews, and notice that most of them come from people who have only reviewed one or two products. Usually off-brand toner or ink.I suspect the printer ink industry is sabotaging reviews of aftermarket ink, trying to scare us into buying their overpriced toner. I don't know this, but it looks fishy to me.Have a look at my review history, you'll see that I, at least, am for real. Lots of reviews, lots of different products, over lots of years.I tried this toner, it worked fine for me, and was much cheaper. Color quality was less than the OEM, but good enough.
Very warm, well made, foot pads under feet, and the hood is a nice touch.Five stars because I can't get my kids to take them off in the morning. They wear them until they leave the house.

OK, this one wasn't perfect, but for the price and the fact that it's just a costume, it was a great value. The material is a little thin, but held up to use. It stretched to my 6'2" size pretty well, but clearly would prefer a 5'10" person.It looks REALLY great, and I scared the $$@ out of my kids with it at first. The mask, however, barely goes with the suit. It's a full head covering, and it just looks like a monster mask as opposed to an exposed skull. No problem for me, as I didn't want to wear a mask anyway.

I'm 6'2", and thin, and they were long enough for me, with a 5" inches to spare.They are wide, and the clips are made from rather strong metal. The clips are a little bulky/thick.Mine were slightly different than those pictured, with a split to strap/clip on the back coming off of the patch, and the two front ones.If you're a Wall Streeter looking to dress for success, these might not be your best choice, but if you're just trying to hold up your pants, these are great.

I have this connected to the recommended Blue Iris software, and I am disappointed in the image quality and overall experience.Pro:The camera is made solidly, and is easy to install.Con:Images look a little grainy, day or nightColors off. Maybe adjustable, but default is too red.Washes out with sunlight, can't seem to adjust iris well. The valve works great, easy install, but BEWARE, the photo as of Dec 2013 is inaccurate.The photo today shows a straight water path, with the valve on the side.The product has a 90 degree elbow for the water path.

There are a couple of important scientific principles at work with this spa cover, but most people assume the second-most important one is the most important, and that causes misunderstandings.1) Evaporation barrier. Note, this is not the same as a vapor barrier, which blocks water that has ALREADY evaporated into vapor. An Evaporation barrier can be a smooth impermeable blanket that sits over water, preventing the water from contacting the air above. Such a barrier prevents passive evaporation (not boiling) of your spa water. If you remember your science, evaporation requires heat energy to occur (it's endothermic), so when some of your spa water does vaporize, it sucks heat out of your spa. If your top cover isn't perfectly airtight, that water vapor will leak to the atmosphere, fresh air will enter, and then you'll vaporize some more spa water. This type of blanket almost stops evaporation. And believe me, your spa water DOES want to vaporize -- if you've ever seen steam off your spa, then you can believe me. Every bit of that steam sucked heat energy from your spa as it left. Not just the heat it took with it as warm steam, but additional energy it already stole when it converted phase from water to vapor.2) Insulation barrier. By separating your hot spa water from cooler air above, there is less transfer of heat. This is one thing the bubbles in the blanket help with (floating is the other thing). The insulation component of this blanket is most useful if you don't have another spa cover, and the outside air is significantly colder than the spa water. But if you already have an insulated cover, the role of the bubble blanket is trivial. Think about it: 4" of closed cell foam versus thin plastic with a single bubble: which one is giving you more insulation?For a blanket like this, evaporation blocking is FAR more important than insulation. For that reason, BUBBLES UP IS THE BETTER WAY to install it. The smooth bottom will separate water from air more, and prevent more evaporation. Bubbles down will allow some evaporation, and allow the vapor to escape through air pockets out to the edges, and into the air cavity. Bubbles down does offer more insulation, because the air pockets between the bubbles offer some additional insulation, along with the air trapped in the bubbles. But, as stated, stopping evaporation is what is most important.

Seems pretty good for the price. Not top quality like a Swiss Army or Leatherman, but not bad for sub $15.There is no spring or snap to the main blade, but it does have a "lock open" mechanism. Arrived sharp.I find it a little large for my purposes, which is to add to my keychain. This is 4" long, so a little big for that.Update:  I added a larger key ring that can rotate around the biner, that works well. Also, the biner clip can lock closed, which is useful for using this as a knife, as you can then grip the whole thing and squeeze tight, without the clip bending in. The hand shaping works nicely.

Time for an angry review, since I just wasted the last 4 hours of my weekend on this.I was hoping for a sprayer to aim directly on poop in my RV toilet. Once, installed, this thing does NOT produce a jet, as one would desire for such a product, but rather a "gentle spray". This means it will be rather ineffective at its main task. This, by itself, is enough to rate this produce a one star.It gets worse. On my Thetford Aqua Magic V, which is designed for such a hand sprayer, I cut off the appropriate nozzle, and connected it. This was relatively easy. But it turns out that the way the toilet is plumbed, the hand sprayer will only operate when the flush nozzle is ALSO held open. This means it has to share pressure with the bowl filler, AND that the bowl will fill as you spray. How exactly does this save me water? Remember, this isn't my fault for bad plumbing - I connected the hand sprayer to the correct optional nipple. In retrospect, I WISH I had plumbed a T into the supply line, and connected a cheap unit like this one:Plumb Craft 7635700 Sink SprayerThe product listed here is basically the same, except that it comes with a toilet bottom gasket for re-sealing the toilet in case you need to remove the toilet to get enough space to access the connection point. As fate would have it, that applied to me. So, I spent a fair bit of time removing my toilet, peeling, then scraping off the old (gross) gasket. Then attaching the sprayer, then replacing the toilet, then trying to solve the leaks that came where the water supply connects to the toilet. Because while they gave the big gasket for the toilet outlet, they did not supply a replacement washer for the water supply connection.Now, I have a variety of drips going on back there. One slow one from the bad washer, but one that seems to be caused by thehand sprayer itself. I think the hand sprayer and its hose drain back and out of the toilet valves when the water pump is turned off and pressure drops. Either way, I'm glad I have  my toilet mounted in a "wet" shower in the RV. Cuz it's wet.So, doesn't work for intended purpose, was a pain to put in, seems to cause backwash leak, wastes water, is far more expensive than the same product for your kitchen sink. What's to like?

This camera works great for me. I installed it in my Dodge RAM because the truck is huge, and it's very hard to see what's behind, and also to hitch up my trailers. This cameras is mirrored, and has the guidelines on them that can't be turned off.I plugged this rear cam into a LockPick, a device that allows owners of various vehicle brands to use their factory radio screen to display other video sources. So my cam is fully integrated into the OEM car display. Awesome. I put it in reverse, the rear view image comes up on my screen in 1 second. I bought the Lockpick at Amazon, and recommend it: B008MTYEZS  Be sure to find the Lockpick model for your carmaker, this one is for Chrysler.The camera's 170 degrees is a pretty wide angle, which allows me to see the ground directly behind the truck, and captures the ground below both corners of my rear bumper. A narrower view would be OK, but less useful for avoiding close objects near the corner of the bumpers. I bought and tested a 120 degree camera, but didn't like the width of view, so *before* I installed it, I just bought this one instead.Install is pretty straightforward. I needed some RCA extension wires to reach all the way to the back of my full size crew cab.The image is very good for the price. I don't think it's worth the $300 the OEM camera cost for a slightly better camera. I'm really just trying to avoid hitting obstacles, not watching Avatar in 3D. It is color, it works. At night, the camera works OK just using the lights from the truck. It is notably dim when I look at it while moving forward (a Lockpick option), but putting the truck in reverse turns on even more light. When an obstacle gets close, it gets bright because of proximity to the truck lights, and that makes obstacles easily noticed. At night, you won't see a tree 15 ft away, but you absolutely will see one 5 feet away. Perfect.Here are the cons:Packaging is random. It may come in a box, or in a bag. The pictures here show a box, mine came in a bag. Not a big deal.Camera construction is medium durability. Seems it will last.Camera may get bumped or re-aimed by mistake...although this is the downside of the very adjustable nature of the ball camInstructions are bad. But install is fairly simple anyway.

This camera works great for me. I installed it in my Dodge RAM because the truck has a huge front end, and it's very hard to see what's just in front of it. Front cameras are NOT mirrored, and do not have the guidelines on them. Don't try to use this as a rear view, because your brain expects a mirror image like what we are trained to see in our mirrors.I plugged my front cam into a LockPick, a device that allows owners of various vehicle brands to use their factory radio screen to display other video sources. So my cam is fully integrated into the OEM car stereo display. Awesome. I bought the Lockpick at Amazon, and recommend it: B008MTYEZS  Be sure to find the Lockpick model for your carmaker, this link is for Chrysler.The camera's 170 degrees is a pretty wide angle, which allows me to see the ground directly in front of the the truck, and almost captures both corners of my front bumper. A narrower view would be OK, but less useful for avoiding close objects when turning. I tried a 120 degree camera, but didn't like the width of view, so before I installed it, I just bought this one instead.Install is pretty straightforward. I needed some RCA extension wires to reach where I wanted.The image is very good for the price. Color is good, not much flicker or focus issues. It's not HD, but I'm really just trying to avoid hitting things, not watching Avatar in 3D. At night, the camera works OK, just using the lights from the truck. Makes it easy to see obstacles for sure.Here are the cons:Packaging is random. It may come in a box, or in a bag. It will likely be labelled "rear view camera" even if it isn't.Camera construction is medium durability. Seems it will last.Camera may get bumped or re-aimed by mistake...although this is the downside of the very adjustable nature of the ball camInstructions are bad. But install is fairly basic anyway.

This ball mount is not 14" as these mounts are typically measured. Usually, the length measurement is from the eye of the hitch pin hole to the eye of the ball mount hole. This hitch is 11 3/4" using that standard dimension.I suppose it may be 14" total length, although that is not what matters.It is a little loose. The part that slides up and down sits 1/8" off the metal on all three sides at a time, meaning it is held in place only by the pins, which also are not snug. What this means is easy adjustment, and never binding, but some clanking or looseness. There's pros and cons to the looseness.

On my: Win 7 Acer laptop, Intel i3 processor and video adapter.I liked the idea of just one plug to dock, plus power of course. However, the J5 just hasn't performed. The flaws that I have found:1) Constant buzz in the audio output. Makes it very annoying, so I unplug the audio to my external speakers. So I'm back to laptop speakers.2) Runs really hot.3) Display Adapter drivers did't load w/installer. I can't get the drivers to load, even after a full uninstall/reinstall. That means the video output from the HDMI plug is defaulting to 720x480 or something useless like that. I'm sure there is a fix, but I emailed support for it twice and...4) Support has not responded to my emails now for two weeks. So, I suppose that means there is no support to help me with my video problem, and I should just disconnect this thing and consider it a waste.Since I cannot use the J5 for video, nor audio plugs, and I was not interested in the wormhole KVM function, it serves basically no purpose for me. It did not make my laptop two-plug dockable.

I use two 28" screens with my desktop computer, so it's always been a big hit when I go remote and need to work on my awesome laptop. No matter how good this laptop is, it still only has a 14" screen. With the smaller single screen, I estimate I can be about 70% as effective as I can while working at home. This AOC screen allows me to take *some* of the benefits of a big desk setup with me on the road. I don't carry this for meetings, conferences, or for using at the coffee shop or on the train! But I DO take it when I'm likely to be in the same hotel for a few days, or abroad for a few weeks. It helps me set up a remote office without a big productivity hit.Pros:Simple USB-only hookupcan work off laptop batteries, which drain faster, but still no plug is requiredI plugged it into Windows 7...it found its own drivers, then just workedLightnice built-in standeasy for portrait or landscapesame resolution as my laptopFor sales guys, or people making presentations, it's easy to point one screen at the customer, and the laptop at you.I plugged a single plug into a single USB 2.0 port, and that worked (no second USB plug needed for power.)Easy to shareCons:thicknot protected for travel, you'll need to get a bag or some container, or fit it into your existing briefcaseI don't like the location of the USB port, which is hiding in the slot where the stand retracts. You need to remove the wire to fold in the stand.Some of the ways I use two screens to be more productive:1) I can have email on one window, and a browser on the other, when I click news links in newsletters, it opens a browser and loads the page while I can still continue reading the newsletter. This way, I'm not waiting for web pages to load, I only look at them after they are ready.2) I can be writing one document while viewing source information on the other screen instead of needing to flip back and forth.3) Multitasking, such as viewing a video while managing files or cleaning up an inbox.4) I put one in portrait to view a full paper page of a document, instead of a partial page.5) There are many more little ways two screens helps. It ends up saving a few seconds at a time...but it does it over and over, ALL DAY. It adds up. I put two screens on the desks of all my staff, so they can work better and the response is universal: Day 1: "I don't really need 2 screens, I work fine with one." Day 3: "I see what you mean, there are a few things I can do faster." Day 30: "I will NEVER go back to working with one screen on a regular basis."

Since the information here is so sparse, allow me to make sure you don't make a mistake.This is an extension for the SynJ systems, that is, it is just like an extension handset - it is NOT the base, which is needed to drive the system.However, if you want to have some desks with a conventional wired telephone look and feel, these make fine extensions to your existing SynJ base station.

This product really gassed me. I am aghast at how effectively it moved dust.  But seriously, it actually totally blows.OK, so it does what it says, but I found if you hold it open for more than 15 seconds or so, it seems to freeze up and needs a warm up break of about a minute. As the gas escapes, the can cools down quite a lot, and actually gets frosty. So only buy this if you are in need of short blasts.

This power bar is pretty good, but loses a star from me because of plug orientation:Pros:- good quality- nice mounting hardware included- lots of plugsCons:- Orientation of the plugs is wrong. It is such that your AC adapters will interfere with the next plug. Many people will buy this device to plug in a lot of wall wart power units, and they can get in each other's way. I would rather the plugs were rotated 90 degrees so that I could use ever outlet on the bar.Obviously the reason to get such a big bar is to have enough space to put the wall warts, otherwise we would buy one of the much more commonly available smaller units. This one doesn't quite solve the problem. Still an improvement. The only brand I have seen that have the correct outlet orientation are Prime 12 Outlet Power Strips, but they are poorly reviewed.

This lock is a great upgrade for me. I've had some of the other recoilers for years, and have been satisfied with them. But when an old one broke, I searched for a lighter, smaller model and found this.Like it's bigger competition, it has a 36" cable, seems equally rugged, has an equally strong lock (i.e. not too good, but good enough), and equally strong cable (i.e. can be cut with any wire cutters, but not with a knife or scissors). It's enough security for prevention of "theft of convenience".The unit is about an inch shorter than most similar products. It's about three inches tall. For this reason, I recommend it for mountain sports enthusiasts who like to lunch without losing their boards.

This thing is cheaply made, and an overall disappointment, however, the weak pump motor stands out as the main reason it was useless to me.The pump can inflate the decoration, slowly, if indoors. But outside, if there is a mild breeze, it will blow over. There is not enough air pressure to keep the structure upright.Also annoying, though less important, this is pretty obviously an outdoor display. But the instructions warn against using:- on grass or dirt- in windy areas- in moist areas, or places that might get wet- in dusty areasI'm sure there are better choices.

Summary: This is a great shield for the price. It is a wet install, so takes a few days to look its best. But wet installs adhere better, and are easier to rid of air bubbles during installation.As an industry analyst, I go through a lot of phones and tablets. I usually put on a screen protector, so that I can get top dollar when I sell my old stuff (I keep all the boxes and materials, too.) So I've put on a bunch of screen protectors, and can confidently say: it is always a pain. Dust is very easily trapped, and alignment is always a challenge. Any efforts to clean out dust, or re-position the shield will almost always result in MORE dust.That said, this screen shield comes in a complete kit, with good instructions, good installation materials, and results in a good tight attachment. Unlike dry install shields, wet install shields require time to cure. They look much better after a day, and better still after a week.My advice, follow the instructions, but also do these important steps for ANY shield installation:- close windows, turn fans off, reduce opportunity for dust- do it in a bathroom after a shower (moisture drops dust out of air)- wash your hands first with soap to remove oils- keep fingers wet with application fluid (if available - this kit has it)- Worry about getting alignment right first, worry about bubbles AFTER- work the bubbles out to the sides patiently and diligently. Do it right away, tomorrow is too late.- I like to apply a little fluid on top of the screen guard as I work out the bubbles, so the tool slides better

No reviews here yet, so I thought I'd be helpful and do a quick one.Most RC cars and trucks require an expensive handheld remote to be packaged along with the toy, but a new kind of toy relies on something you might already have, a smartphone, then saves the cost of producing the remote.But smartphones can do more than basic remotes. Because they are expensive computers with accelerometers and touchscreens, the controller can provide battery information, tilt control, touch control and more. This RC truck does all that.I do not yet own one of these, but I tried it at a trade show, and found it lots of fun. There is a similar car product that doesn't handle carpet very well, but this truck model is fairly versatile.The toy does not use the phone's wifi or bluetooth, but instead needs you to plug in a RF transmitter to the phone's port. I'm sorry, but I don't know the range of the controller since I only used it up to 8 feet away.You should probably know that the toy is small. About the size of a fist.I have bought one, and will provide a better review after I receive the shipment.UPDATE:Now that I have one, I can confirm that what I experienced at the trade show is correct. My kids like to play with this. I just charge it up in my USB port or my smartphone charger, and they play with it for 20 minutes or so.

I have a yellowjacket problem. So I bought a few things: Poison 20' spray for the nest, cheap RESCUE! plastic bag baited traps at $5 on Amazon, and this expensive Rescue! WHY unit.The poison seems to have worked well on the nest. Theplastic bag trap worked so well I barely got it hung before they swarmed the thing. Then I prepped the WHY trap. It has way too much prep time compared to the cheap plastic bag. After 24 hours, the dead wasps are 2" deep in the water of the cheap RESCUE!, there are no insects at all in the upper chamber of the WHY trap and about 12 wasps below.The WHY is more complicated, more expensive, and less effective for yellowjackets than the much cheaper disposable bag trap from the same company.I recommend the Rescue Yellow Jacket Control Trap, sold here at Amazon:

I've had and installed a few different front baskets lately, and this one is head and shoulders above the rest.PRO:- Not made of plastic. Most others have plastic mounting hardware.- Has a solid hold-off lever made of metal. Most baskets clamp on the handlebar with plastic, and have some mechanism on the clamp that prevents the basket from "rolling down", that is lowering when loaded, and rotating the mount that is on the handle. Most baskets, therefore, have very little leverage holding the basket up, and so it just pivots down around the handle. This basket uses a separate hold-off, which supports the basket lower down and pushed on the handlebar stock, and is adjustable to suit your bike.- Strong, can carry serious weight.- Easily removal that smartly uses the carry handle to unlock, good carry handle for the store.- Sits lower than the handlebar, so any lights mounted over the handlebar still can project forward.CON:- Somewhat inflexible in the width of the mount on the handlebar. I had an existing light that took up 3" of space at the center of my handlebar. I had to bend the basket mount slightly outward so that it would fit around my light. But it did bend without any breakage.- Like any basket, it will interfere with your brake/gear cables that stick out in front of your handles. Not a big deal, and I tucked the cables in behind the mount so they never get in the way of the basket.

Good:- This unit is bigger than the others. It is 24" wide, when most are 20". I like the extra space for holding those plastic boxes.- Arrived fast- Seems strong enough, looks good enough- Weighs 60lb. Easy to carry by rails with one person and lots of space. For tight areas, may be better with two people.Not so good:- Shipping box, as others have said, seems inadequate. My UPS guy apologized and said I might want to inspect the package. I told him it's OK, the thing is strong metal, won't be broken but will be scratched. No big deal, since it's not fragile, but it should be better.Assembly:- Very easy, I thought. BUT, you are asked to provide a torque wrench - and not just any torque wrench. I have two, and one only goes up to 45 ft-lbs. Only my heavy-duty torque wrench can handle the 75 ft-lbs required by the 3 big bolts of this carrier. However, my thinking is that you could use a regular ratchet/wrench if you are a strong 175lb+ man and just tighten it as hard as you can. (You assume the risk if your bolts don't hold, of course.) Better to do it right at some point, or swing by any mechanic once you have it basically built - but you could use it right away, and fix the torque later.- 13mm and 19mm wrenches/sockets needed.

First off, they must have updated the item, because even though I ordered two of the item FROM THIS PAGE (Ultra Compact High Output...), what I received looked exactly like this other Amazon item: [...]So, my review is actually of that other item, which was shipped to me when I ordered the one on this page.It is well made, nice small size. This single brake is a solid deal at around $10, and was easy to install and use. I use mine on an Adams Trail a Bike, where my bicycle pulls my kid on a bicycle trailer. With my weight, my bike, and her weight and her bike, I needed more braking power down hills into stop signs. By putting a brake on her trailer, she now can both pedal her own weight, and brake it.There are not 3, as in the picture, but one.The sizes, which the description fails to mention, are as follows:-  I put mine on a kid's 20 x 2.0 back tire. Fits easy.-  I measured the distance from the center mounting pin to the long sliding hole mount for the brake pad, it ranges from 3" - 3 3/4.-  The shielded cable run jacket is 43" and the brake cable extends about another 4" beyond.-  The handle lever portion is smallish, a three finger brake for an adult, or normal for a child.People have noted that the instructions are poor. I agree. But not much instruction is needed for this item. Really, if you have an example brake anywhere in sight, you can just look and copy. But here are some instructions, follow them in order:- note that there are extra/optional parts. You don't need to use every part-  - use the shaped washers only if you are mounting to a circular tube.-  - use just one of the bolts, short or long, to suit the size of the bike's post to which you are mounting the brake-  - the s clip is for clipping the cable shield to another existing cable shield if you wish-  - there is one tie-down for holding the cable shield to the bike crossbar. Didn't fit for me. Used a zip tie instead.- mount the handle lever firmly, then the brake caliper firmly, then adjust the pads to the wheel rim, then tighten pads- route the cable intelligently to the caliper-  - put enough slack in the cabling to allow the steering wheel to move freely.-  - cut the cable jacket to size...but make sure you have slid the cable out first-don't cut the cable.- then thread the cable into the caliper, squeeze the caliper closed (use a friend or a clamp), then tighten the lock nut on the brake cable at the caliper arm- test, then adjust last step as needed for preferred operation- cut the brake cable as the very last step, after you have fully mounted, adjusted, and tested the brake. Leave 2 inches and cut the excess beyond that.

***Read my updates at the end...the product has had its ups and downs.I've had my LX1 for about 6 months now (Oct 2010 - April 2011 through the winter in CA) and I absolutely love it. I used to ride my bike everywhere as a teen, until I got my first car. Since then, biking has been relegated to "sport" meaning that I mountain bike with friends for a high-octane workout, but I stopped doing it for transportation.Well, 30 years later, I'm biking for transportation again. And, believe me, it's not because I have more spare time. I always loved biking, but the trade-off versus a car just made the decision simple:- arrive sweaty?- short practical range?- arrive tired?- spend more time in travel?- carry almost nothing?Just about every time, the choice was the gas-burner. But with the LX1, many of those downsides of cycling have gone away. The hills between me and downtown are irrelevant, the time is about equal to a car, and I put on panniers to carry some things if I need.I sweat sometimes when I ride it, but that's by choice. I can pedal as hard or as lightly as I choose. Usually, I decide how hard I want to push the pedals, and just keep that pressure the whole ride. Now, when you're on a regular bike, you simply don't have that luxury. When faced with a hill, you HAVE to push harder. To start, you have to push harder. Not me. I just push steady and let the motor make up the difference.I have pushed this bike's limits, too. I decided that I wanted to bike my daughter to school instead of drive (just twice a week). I bought a bike trailer (trail-a-bike) and attached it. This adds substantial weight when my daughter is included. Anyway, it's great. On my regular bike with the trailer, we took 16 minutes to get her to school, and I took 17 back. 33 minutes, and I was a sweaty mess. With the LX1, it takes 10 minutes each way, I'm back in 20 and am not worn out. That's about 3 minutes faster than a car (because of shortcuts). This is good exercise, but not a "workout".Friends have made fun of me saying that an electric bike is "lazy", but they are missing the point. They are comparing it to a bicycle instead of comparing it to a car. I am out in the fresh air, getting some exercise, not burning gas INSTEAD of sitting my tush in a car. That's fantastic. I now make runs to the store on my bike, trips downtown on the weekend, post office runs, etc. All things that I used to do in my car...and I enjoy it.BTW, it's probably fair to note that I also have an awesome 1000cc motorcycle, which I ride less since I have my LX1. They're both fun in different ways. That's probably why I never ride the LX1 in "throttle mode". If I wanted to just sit and twist a throttle, I'd ride my motorcycle. But my advice to everyone is: pedal if you are physically able to do so. Electric bikes make it easy to "get a little exercise" while you go about your regular errands. Throttle riding is wasting a free opportunity to be healthier.I imagine it would be fun to travel with an LX1, and tour new towns, but with a family of four, it's too hard to carry all the bikes. However, for the motorhome crowd it could be great. Instead of towing a jeep around, just carry a couple of electric bikes. I have also added some really fat seats to my bikes, and baskets on the handlebars. I highly recommend the http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B001947Q44/ref=wms_ohs_product Lund from Amazon - it can handle much more weight than other designs.As for my review of the LX1 itself: It arrived as promised, was easy to get started. After six months of use - no problems. Instructions for the electronics are a little chinglish and unclear, but good enough. The bike is very solid, and appears well made and assembled. The motor is reliable, fairly quiet, and powerful. The controls are simple and clear, and the gears are smooth. The tires seem tough and heavy duty - good thing, because the rear end carries lots of weight. It's a good bike. But it's heavy! Which brings me to my only gripe: I feel like the brakes are underpowered given the heavy bike and rider. That's true with just the bike and my 215 lb. But I really push the brakes when I'm riding with a bike trailer and a daughter, and I live among hills. Going down a hill I always wish I had more braking power. Disc brakes on this bike would have made it a perfect machine.I have never managed to kill the battery. The claimed range is 30 miles, and I tend to ride < 9.Riding as a family was always tedious for me, because I was always waiting for my wife. Now when we go riding as a family, I put my wife on the LX1, and struggle to keep up with her on my regular bike. It actually is a real problem, because even on low power she cannot pedal and go slowly enough for me. With the throttle, she could go slowly, but with the pedal-assist, even if she just pushes feather-weight on the pedals, the motor kicks in (at I guess 60% power)and she will outpace me on a hill. I wish there were a lower setting. Naturally a second electric bike is in my future.============================Update: 6 months later (Aug 2011)I liked it so much I bought a second LX1 and have now had two for 4 months. I actually shopped all brands and models of ebikes again, but still ended up back on the LX1. It just suits me right. I also liked the e-moto brand. On the second LX1, I upgraded the brakes by calling and customizing the order. Now I feel better on big donwgrades. I also added a cheap brake to my kids bike-trailer for just $10, so they can do their own braking, too.For the problem in my last paragraph or the original review, where my wife could not ride slowly enough for me, we figured it out. If you use the pedal assist, you can choose 3 levels of assist. I would guess they are about 60% power, 80% power, and 100% power. None was low enough for me to keep up on a regular bike. But if you use the throttle, the twist throttle over-rides the pedal-assist. So by twisting the throttle just a little, she can add as little as 10% motor power to her pedaling, and then I could keep up. Of course, I solved that problem with a second LX1, and now we bike-trailer our two kids all over. The issue of one spouse being faster than the other on a bike is non-existent with 2 ebikes.The first LX1 continues to hold out with no problems.The second  LX1 had a problem after I assembled it. The motor inside the rear hub made a terrible noise, like skipping gears (which is probably what it was). I called R. Martin, and without much of a discussion at all, "Randy" agreed to ship me out a replacement. It arrived four days later, rear tire, wheel, hub and motor. I just swapped it with the broken one. I called Randy to ask how to ship the broken tire back, and he said "Keep it. Sorry for the trouble." So now I have extra tire, tube, wheel just in case of future problems.============================Update: 18 months of ownership (April 2012)Well, I had to deduct two stars - and I'm very sad about it. Around the time my first bike was almost a year old, and my second was about a half a year (sept 2011), both bikes started to show problems. What happens is that the entire electronic system shuts down when I am climbing a hill. That means you are left pedaling a heavy bike up a hill, which is way harder than a regular bike, which is exactly the opposite of the reason I bought these bikes.When you climb a hill on a fully recharged battery, the battery needs to deliver extra power to the motor. The motor on my LX1 is a powerful 350 Watt motor, not the more common 250 Watt. That wattage puts a high current demand on the battery. During this spurt, the apparent voltage of the battery drops from the full 40 volts down to low 30s. Although this is just a temporary drop, and the battery is still fully charged, the control circuitry interprets the low voltage as a near-dead battery that has traveled 30 miles. The control circuitry is designed to protect your battery from draining (because once fully drained, it cannot be recharged) so it shuts off the whole bike. The only way to turn it back on is to turn off the battery switch (inconvenient when you are mounted), turn it back on, and press the on/off switch again.The battery is clearly not dead, because it will happily run me for another 15 miles on flatter ground, even after cutting out on every hill.So, now I have one battery under warranty sent back to the seller, and they have had it for 6 weeks. I'm not sure what's taking them so long. But my concern is that even if I get a new battery back, the problem is in the control circuit's incorrect evaluation of a near-dead battery condition. If a battery is designed to last through 500 charge cycles, but can only climb hills in the first 6 months of its life, then the bike becomes a big paperweight. I don't need an e-bike to ride on flat terrain, so if it can't do hills, it has lost its main purpose.============================Update: 24 months of ownership (Oct 2012)Good news. I got both my bikes working fully - no thanks to the manufacturer, though. I sent them the battery that was worst, and they evaluated it to be A-OK, and sent it back. But the problem of the bike shutting itself off on any hill got worse. As I said, I tow a bike trailer often, but the battery would shut off with or without the extra weight. Well, with the fall coming, I wanted to ride my kids to school again, and just decided to fix it myself. I did a lot of research on electric bikes, control circuits, batteries, and Battery Management Systems. I was correct in my guess at the problem on the last update. The battery, if not brand new and in perfect condition, is just not adequate to drive the bike up hills so the system shuts down to "protect a dead battery" that isn't dead. That's why I got no help or useful advice from the bike maker: I doubt they would choose to admit the bike was under-powered by design.BTW, I added to the stress the bike needs to handle, too. Now I have two kids going to the same school, so I have a DOUBLE bike trailer that I pull with this LX1 ebike. And it still works!So, here's how I solved my problem, and am now as happy as Lindsay Lohan at a Jack Daniels factory. I went on the big online auction site and bought a second 36 volt lithium battery for each of my bikes. I bought one called "kettle bottle" which is smaller and basically fits on the bike like a water bottle often does. Understand that I did not buy this battery for increased range, but for extra current when climbing hills. Now, instead of one battery unable to provide current and voltage on an uphill, I have two that can share the load. And it works like a charm. Now, the batteries have more than enough power, and will last for years until they only put out 50% of their original peak current.Sure, this represents extra weight (3.1Kg), extra cost ($280 shipped from China), and extra work...but it returns me to my original happy review, above.How does one do this hack? You have to be capable with wiring, but don't need to be a pro. Take the new battery, and it's wiring output, and mount the battery to the bike. Use existing water bottle holes, or drill new ones, or use self-tapping metal screws. Open the control box and find the wires that come in from the existing battery. Add the new battery's wires old by stripping, wrapping, soldering (optional), and then tape thoroughly to protect. Positive wire to positive and negative to negative, use a voltmeter. Don't get positive and negative wires mixed up -- these batteries are powerful. Turn both batteries on and you're ready to tackle any hill.I'm back to riding over hill and dale, alone, or with my two kids on a double Adams Trail-a-bike. It's reliable, fun, and fit.

My keyboard linked up well with my iPad, and I played around with it, testing it's usefulness one night.Then, one week later, I took it to a meeting, and it didn't work. After, I brought it home, and connected it to another laptop, and got the same results. The batteries are fine, the bluetooth connection is solid, but most of the keys on the right side of the keyboard don't register at all on either iPad or Win7 laptop. This keyboard broke and was almost new. I never really used it, it only worked once for my setup test.Separately, I did not really like the typing experience. Yes, it is slightly better than typing directly into the iPad, and it allows you to prop the iPad up, facing you, while typing flat on a table. But it is useless without a table, since it is floppy. On the table, I just didn't like the 'feel' of the keyboard...kinda seems irrelevant since it's busted!!Given how many people have had quality issues, I'd steer clear of this one.REVISED: I bumped my rating up from 1 star to 3 because the vendor was very responsive and sent out a replacement. I'll use it for a while and then revise my rating again based on how well it lasts.

This device worked in my Windows XP machine, but not in my Windows 7 64bit. Windows 7 INSISTS that the card reader is an infrared receiver, and installs the wrong drivers every time. I cannot find the right drivers, even after downloading the 20MB product file from the manufacturer site.

Hi, just a word of caution, I bought this card from Amazon, foolishly assuming it would fit in my PCI Express slots. It turns out it does not. Take careful note of the shape of the slots on this card. There is one wider and one narrower set of connectors (tabs) that drop into your motherboard. For this card, the narrower slot is closer to the rear of your PC, and the wider slot is closer to the front. This, I imagine, is the "PCIe X4" configuration (although I'm not sure). All I know is that my PC has  three PCI Express x1 slots, a PCI Express x16 slot for the graphics, and three PCI slots -- none of them a fit for this card.The slots that I though this would go into, on my PC, were wider tab at the rear and narrower tab to the front. This did not match the card. There are many USB 3.0 cards here on Amazon that fit my PC, this is not one of them. Check your motherboard carefully, and match it to the picture on this page. Make sure it is right before you order.

The very best part of this mount is the suction cup platform disk with special bendable "wings", which can be stuck to your dash with the included 3M adhesive and alcohol wipe. This may seem like a small thing, but it is very important. Most of these disks are flat disks with double sided tape. The flat disk NEVER seems to contact well with a curved dash. But this mount's disk has five "wings" on the underside of the disk, which are flexible and can be bent to the shape of the dash, then stuck to it. Making contact between the adhesive and the dash truly separates this disk out from the pack, and is the difference between staying on, and falling off.This is an excellent universal mount for any kind of mobile device in your car. Universal mounts (IMHO) are better than dedicated (ex: iphone only) mounts, because as you upgrade your phone every 2 years, the same mount can still be used in the car.This mount works fine for my Nexus one, my wife's old iPhone 3GS, and her new iPhone 4. It also works with those phones naked, OR when those phones are in a gel or metal case. The bottom supports easily allow the wide iPhone plug to connect to the phone.The side arms, as in most similar mounts, can open and close to fit many devices. I measured their range as supporting phones with widths of from 1.5" to 3.75". The button to release and widen the side arms (spring loaded) is on the back. I prefer a side button, but I don't use it frequently.The side arms are angled in slightly, so that the phone is wedged up against the back, as well as squeezed in from the sides. I prefer to let the sides be a little loose, and just slip the phone in from the top. This way, you don't have to adjust the side arms.The strongest aspect of this particular product has to be the arm, suction cup, and dash disk portion of the mount. It is far better than many others I have tried and seen. It is very strong and highly adjustable. All joints (ball, pivot) can be tightened by the user, so once set, don't move. The hinge is ratcheting to hold very securely, and the ball mount allows 360 degrees of rotation, as well as swivel. The hinge pin can be removed and the 90 degree arm can be placed in upside-down, allowing for more choices of mounting position. The window suction cup holds strong.

I think this monitor was a fantastic deal, and as such, I bought another one about 6 months later. And I'm buying a third one right now. I keep coming back because I have had no problems with the first two, no dead pixels, and I have found the picture to be:- sharp (I use DVI, but have also used RGB 15-pin)- very bright (I have my brightness set to just 35 on a 100 scale)- huge- very affordable- as sturdy as any otherI use it side-by-side with a more expensive Samsung Syncmaster, and find no difference in picture quality.Negatives:- will take up a lot of desk space. Doesn't fit every desk!- takes longer to turn on from standby. Samsung screen comes in in 1 second, i-inc takes 4-5 seconds.UPDATE:I have now bought 6 of these screens for everyone in my small business. I get more productivity of my staff for a great price. Everyone is happy as can be about their massive screens. I've had no problems with any of the 6.

The sexy French vamp is coming to the south! Christian Duvall, once a child of the enemy, is on his own and making moves to become a Lord. Along with a child of his own, he will challenge the cowardly Anthony and hopefully make an alliance with Raphael.Natalie is a financial whiz, working to discover and understand past financial schemes she is taken aback when the enigmatic Christian walks in the door. An instant attraction and shared goal of removing Anthony from power will help bind these two together in the most delicious of ways.Along with getting to see and interact with almost all of our couples in the Vampires in America series, we get an ominous look into the next book to come.Captivating and brimming with brilliance, Christian is yet another defining addition to the ever-evolving world of Vampires in America created by D.B. Reynolds.5 Powerful Sexy French stars!

Psychiatrist Morgan Winters is on the job. Brought in to try and help her local police department solve a murder case, she is determined to get the job done. Twists and turns along with her own practice and personal issues make Surrender a great addition to the suspense world.There is also a religious/spiritual thread that runs through this read. Morgan has to come to terms with her past as well as recent personal decisions making her take ownership of her own moral code and expectations, all the while trying to navigate the maze of suspects in this New Orleans murder case.The plot is a good one. I was guessing right up until the very end. There are so many twists and unexpected turns to navigate.My only negative, if you can call it that, is I wish there was more: more inner dialogue, more in-depth emotion, and a more fleshed out backstory to the captivating Morgan Winters. I feel as if author Jill Collins is on to something here with her Morgan Jane Winter series, and Iâ€™m hoping for the next installment to be a beefier, more emotionally raw read. She has all the components and I am excited to see where she goes from here.All in all, a solid 4 star read!

I received the ring set very quickly. Within a week of the order being placed.  I have worn them for two days now, taking them off when washing my hands and showering. But for strictly fashion and occasional wearing I am positive this set will work well.I have added pictures of the ring set in lamp light and natural light so you can see just how pretty the setting is.*Item received from Bamoerjewelry

Oh and did I mention its almost Christmas?Bartender Owen sees people drowning their miseries in booze all the time, but when he sees one of his regulars looking so unhappy, he takes it upon himself to try and remedy it.What happens next is that two people really connect. This is a cute little read with some hiccups. Meeting in a comic book store, Reese and Adam strike up a friendship over the development of a comic book. It feels a bit rudimentary in its writing style. Itâ€™s not bad by any means; it just seems to be missing that extra oomph. I wanted to know more of the inner dialogue Reese and Carter would be having in terms of the obstacles their blossoming relationship has. And on that note, I really hope the cover changes. The current cover doesnâ€™t fit the storytelling of what Reese looks like. It needs to be authentic to its character description. I just see a really tan white guy.All in all it is a fun, short read that left me with a smile on my face. I do hope to visit this Hot & Nerdy world again, as I see potential here.

Game On book number three! If you think for one minute that this author has lost her steam, dropped the ball, or even phoned it in, youâ€™re in for a big surprise! I have spent the day with Dex and Fi, and Iâ€™m currently suffering from one of the biggest book hangovers I have had in a while. Un-put-down-able? Sure, that word has been thrown around before - how aboutâ€¦I got carpel tunnel from the grabby hands when The Game Plan is released? A fever was induced when Dex did nothing but stand there. Am I fangirling a bit? Sure I am. I donâ€™t think consistent and improving authors get the credit they deserve some times. Kristen Callihan is headed straight to my insta-click-author list.Fi and Dex are combustible in a slow burning I-will-wait-for-you kind of love. As much as itâ€™s escapism at its best, itâ€™s also a realistic love story, and for me that just ups the game.We also get a welcome look into the current lives of Anna and Drew, as well as Grey and Ivy. If you know me, I am a sucker for a â€œfamily seriesâ€; keep me invested and the gang together!The write up says it all guys, savor this one â€˜causeâ€¦Game On! ; )
Gorgeous earrings!!! A really nice size and a brilliant sparkle! Perfect to dress up any outfit. Every girl likes a little sparkle and these are terrific!

Much larger than I originally thought! And thats a good thing! Great for yard tools as well as brooms and mops.The hooks and holders side back and forth so that you can position larger items if need be. Good feature I also wasn't expecting. Hot sex and great leading men are becoming trademarks of Katana Collinsâ€™s writing. Fun, witty and filled with sarcastic banter, her books are an insta click for sure.Jessica has decided that she will do anything to find her sistersâ€™ killer/killers. Even if it means submerging herself in a world that she never expected to find herself in. Masters and subs play games Jessica just cant seem to get a handle on. Add in drugs and murderâ€¦. Well, youâ€™ve got an erotic cocktail of mystery to solve.There are multiple POVâ€™s. I think I counted five? And without a notice of perspective change, it could be a bit confusing. I found myself re-reading at times just to make sure who was who. Itâ€™s such a good mystery that I didnâ€™t want to miss anything. I feel very much invested in some of these guys and want to know what happens next with them. (to say who could be considered a spoiler)Canâ€™t wait to see what comes next!

The first half of this book was on friggin FIRE! Love, hate, vengeful seething emotions with heart breaking yearning, and a need too strong to ignoreâ€¦ just GAH!! I have never been so turned on and so heartbroken all at once. Itâ€™s a purely visceral read for me in the beginning. I could not stop devouring this book. Really, itâ€™s some of KAâ€™s best work to date.The second half returns to a more subdued feel. Not all tied up in a pretty bow, but diving into the more meat of the Chaos series that has been put on the backburner from the Dream Man Series. I like the stronger return of this plotline. Especially since it brings in more of my other favorite sexy leading men from before.Itâ€™s a total 5 Star read for me. My only wish was that the fire created in the beginning stayed the inferno it was between High and Millie. Cause there ainâ€™t no sex like angry sex!

What an amazing read! Truly, the Guardians of the Realms series has hit its stride. I was absolutely glued to the pages. Its intense, creative, and magnetic coupling of Delia and Drake is one of the best duos thus far in the series.Author Setta Jay is developing a family of characters in her Guardians world that has the potential to become one of the best PNR series around. Mighty dragons, mystical mist, and sultry nights combine into one epic read. Searing Ecstasy is a dark, uplifting, and erotic read and, quite frankly, one of Jayâ€™s best works to date.Oh and P.S. the last paragraphâ€¦. O.M.G!! Book eight cannot get here soon enough!5 STARS~Tanja

Cracking good read! Get it? Cause it's called Nuts! .....yeah, yeah I know :PItâ€™s with a jovial heart that I say that Nuts by Alice Clayton has been one of the most enjoyable reads I have read all year! Easy lovinâ€™, uproariously funny, and so tantalizing itâ€™s impossible to put down! I mean, come on! Farmers have never been so sexy.Private chief Roxie is leaving California for the summer to bail out her mother, yet again. It comes at a perfect time, really. Her job has just hit the skids. One bad night at work gets her fired and soon her client list crumbles. So a long drive cross-country to get her head together just might be the help she needs before Roxie lands back in upstate New York.The small town that Roxie couldnâ€™t leave fast enough after graduation, is now her new summer destination. Only Roxie is seeing things from a new perspective and with a different set of eyes. People arenâ€™t who she thought they were. Truly, are any of us who we were in high school? With growth and age comes a bit of understanding.The one bright, bearded perk of being home is the mouth-watering guy that brings the produceâ€¦ and the fruitâ€¦ and the nutsâ€¦ you should see his zucchini. Organic farmer Leo just made coming home a lot more interesting. A series of bumbles, trips, and falls attributes to the laugh-out-loud introduction of these two.What harm could a little summer lovinâ€™ cause? I mean,who wouldnâ€™t want their own Sandy and Danny moment right? Right. â€œSummer Loving, had me a blastâ€¦.â€The brilliance that created Wallbanger is back and better than ever! A 2015 favorite read for sure, I honestly couldnâ€™t recommend it enough.5 scintillating, uproariously funny, and organically sexy stars!Tanja~

This is my absolute favorite book in the series thus far! Really! The give and take, push and pullâ€¦ the sheer attraction between Lacey and Jake is simply phenomenal. She has resided to the fact this is kind of it for her.A blast from the past, Jake, just showed up out of the blue; the clear blue sky that is. A pilot now, and the only guy Lacey ever really loved. The chemistry is stronger than ever.Itâ€™s a wonderful second chance romance, and one Iâ€™m already excited to read again. Fun, smart and adorable!
Makes me want to start the series all over again. This could totally be read as a prequel. Please hurry January, I need the next book like now :)

* Reader discretion advised. This title contains the following sensitive themes: Dubious Consent, Non-Consent, Explicit Violence, Heavy KinkIt's a short read so I will keep this simple as not to spoil it for you.Beginning on the heals of Sacrifice, we are thrust back into training a set of new tributes. Quickly becoming one of my favorites Kristen Callihanâ€™s Game On series doesnâ€™t disappoint. Nothing is more appealing than good guysâ€¦. Well sexy, smart and charismatic good guys that once they know what they want arenâ€™t afraid to do anything to get it. Or her as the case may be.Gray and Ivy start off their relationship texting from two different countries to becoming face to face friends and slowly turn into much more. Okay guys, if, like me, you havenâ€™t read the Harper Connellyâ€™ series and Lily Bard you may not get the excitement other may feel about this new series. Honestly, I felt that not having read those previous works, I was kinda missing out on some character history. But have no fear, not reading those other arenâ€™t a must. Then throw in Harrisâ€™ trademark murder/mystery in a Podunk town and voila you got Day Shift!Alright, time for the nitty-gritty: sadly I wasnâ€™t instantly drawn in. First, I must say that you are listening to a very biased reviewer. In case you didnâ€™t know, my co-blogger and I are military wives. We have a very up close and personal connection to the men and women in uniform. Therefore anytime we can help or facilitate our armed forces we step up, stand up, and commit. Itâ€™s what we are programmed to do.So needless to say, that when I saw a book by Suzanne Brockmann and then found out that all author and publisher proceeds will go to the Wounded Warrior Project, I was IMMEDIATELY on board.All eight stories center on people in uniform and a love connection. Some are warm, fun, and sexy. Others are heartbreaking, gritty and gripping. War isnâ€™t easy. The warrior has to be emotionally strong while being physically strong as well, and as for the loved ones at home? Well that kind of strength is unexplainable.If you havenâ€™t read some of these authors before itâ€™s a great way to discover the writing style and flow. If you have, itâ€™s a real treat for the fans. Way of the Warrior is an excellent collection of romance in uniform and a phenomenal way to gather attention for an extraordinary cause www.woundedwarriorproject.org5 Always faithful always vigilant stars!

3.5(ish)Starsâ€œSo it's gonna be foreverOr it's gonna go down in flamesYou can tell me when it's overIf the high was worth the painCause we're young and we're recklessWe'll take this way too farIt'll leave you breathlessOr with a nasty scarâ€So yeah, the lyrics to Taylor Swiftsâ€™ Blank Space kind of resonate with my feelings after reading the second and final book of Cassie and Ethan. What a ride! After that cliffhanger for an ending in Bad Romeo I was ready to find out how this would end with these two: forever or down in flames.Again, we spend time in the juxtaposition of past and present. As I said before, I like present Ethan waaaaaay more than past Ethan. Itâ€™s enjoyable to see the man verses the boy. Bold determination is a sexy, heady thing.Itâ€™s also sad and disheartening to see the once spirited and hopeful Cassie so jaded, broken and caustic about life. Itâ€™s an embattled balance of love, heartache, redemption and revitalization. Although, at times I hated the past journey, I needed to experience it to fully embrace the tenderness of the present.â€œI got a blank space baby, and I'll write your nameâ€Couldnâ€™t resist *Giggle snort*

Give me humor with my romance and I will follow you into the deep end of the pool!The Mistake is my kind of NA romance; a little angst, a little sexy and a whole lotta funny. Logan is still crushing on his best friendâ€™s girl when, by mistake, he meets the lovely but quirky Grace. They spend a surprisingly great evening together however the â€œgood byeâ€ ends up being an awkward bit of a mess.For whatever reason, Logan just canâ€™t get over Grace or his somewhat humiliating goodbye to her. What culminates is a fun and fulfilling start to a great friendship/romance. That is, until the lovable yet clueless Logan opens his massive mouth and sticks his ice skating foot right in it.Grace canâ€™t believe she just opened herself up to be the most vulnerable she has ever been with someone and gets slammed in the gut with words she never thought to hear in that particular situation. Have no fear ladies! Our Grace ainâ€™t no doormat! Wellâ€¦. not anymore. She takes her life and her self-respect and pulls herself up and into the woman she can and needs to be. If Logan truly wants her back and wants to prove himself he has to earn it and make amends.The Mistake is a laugh out loud journey. As funny as it is, I gotta say, there are some extremely touching moments. I shed tears for Logan. He isnâ€™t all he seems on the outside. His family life is far from perfect and you get an insight into the kind of childhood that shaped the person he is today.Funny, moving, endearing and a positively terrific follow up book in the Off-Campus Series!

Alright now! THIS. THIS! Is my kind of read. I was laughing so hard at times my husband asked my â€œWhat in the world are you reading?â€ My response? â€œIf the movies Sweet Home Alabama and The Proposal had a book baby THIS would be it!The suave, educated, and sophisticated lawyer, Stanton Shaw, heads home to Mississippi with his friend-with-benefits coworker Sofia Santos. He might be slick up north but down southâ€¦. Thatâ€™s a whole other story.You can read the blurb, it tells you exactly whatâ€™s going on. What I will tell you is that Emma Chase has hit it out of the ball park with this one. Her writing and satirical humor is what made me fall in love with Tangled and it is back with a vengeance in this new series.Itâ€™s best described as out of left field humor. You just donâ€™t see it coming, and then BAM! right in the face. Not to mention itâ€™s an adorably sexy and wildly addictive read.Get it. Read it. Laugh till you ache!5++ Stars!!

Murder, mystery, deception, lies, hidden truths in plain sight, and old loves coming back to haunt you. Forensic photographer and sister of the deceased, Jessica must take an unexpected journey into the darker side of sex to find out what happened to her sister.Twists and turns abound as slowly evidence surfaces. Itâ€™s completely unclear who she can trust. Alone in her sisterâ€™s home, Jessica keeps finding confusing and contradicting information about the sister that she thought she knew. With the added mind muddling feelings she has toward the police Detective ( and her childhood love)Sam McCloskey, deductive reasoning and inference may uncover the truth or will seduction be the key?Itâ€™s a great read and for those of you that have read the prequel, Wicked Shots, it certainly answers a lot of questions. Itâ€™s smart, a bit funny, and definitely sexy with loads of intrigue.

Going in blind with just a snippet from Trick really did make all the difference. I was able to follow the good doctor, Darby Carmichael, along her journey of patient turned friendship turned more. Funny and captivating, Only Trick is a sexy mystery wrapped in intrigue.I really enjoyed spending time with a heroine that refused to be a door mat. She stood her ground and voiced what she would and would not put up with. Just because Trick was beautiful and every woman threw herself at him didnâ€™t change the fact that Darby has a standard of self-preservation. Sheâ€™s not gonna be a doormat or sit idly by, which makes for some amazingly delicious confrontations between these two.Trick was complicated and we get just enough of his POV to make it intriguing and draw more curiosity into who he really is.I know, Iâ€™m not telling you much and Iâ€™m being somewhat vague, but guys, just read it and donâ€™t over think it. It would be easy to spoil it if too much is given away. Sometimes itâ€™s better not knowing and just jumping in.Believe me it's a great ride! 5 Stars

Take some Norse and Viking lore, and then throw in some witches, gods, and demons. What do you get? An epic tale that rivals the best PNR that is out there today guys! So much was crammed into the pages of THE UNLEASHING that it is hard to breathe between the action and adventure.Kera and Vig make an equally amazing couple. Sexy funny has been and will always be my absolute favorite kind of read. Have no doubts that this measures up. I donâ€™t want to give much away, as I feel the best books are better when you go in blind, but I will say the pursuit/stalkerish behavior was just fab!Now, having said all the lovely gushing things above, I gotta say there is A LOT to take in. So go slow, and get your bearings and immerse yourself in this wonderful world created by Shelly Laurenston. Itâ€™s so worth it!

Firstâ€¦ AAAGGGGHHHHHH!! Hi guys of Rosemary Beach I missed you!!! Okay, now that thatâ€™s out of the way; I loved this! Of course I tend to love much of Abbi Glines work. I was worried that this series was starting to get stale. You would think that after eleven books I would I tire of it all. Nope, Nuh-uh, not happening. It is still fun, fresh and hella sexy.Mase Colt-Manning is such a modern day southern gentleman. His inner monologue is as funny as it is steamy. Gentle, caring, and protective is the perfect description for him.As for the lovely Reese, her childhood is a terrifying one. Still recovering and learning to trust, sheâ€™s cleaning houses for a living. When Mase uncovers one of her hidden shames, everything changes. Any adult dealing with a learning disability tends to struggle more so than a child. Especially if it has never been properly diagnosed or addressed. The way in which Mase handles this issue is a testament to the man he is.Beautifully written and caustically sweet, When Iâ€™m Gone is going down a favorite of mine.

Also they have a good cushion around the ear which helps block the noise from the outside making them some of a noise canceling headphones.Bass - â˜…â˜…â˜…Clarity - â˜…â˜…â˜…Overall Sound Rating - â˜…â˜…â˜…This product was given to me in exchange for an honest reviewDesign and Features:As mentioned in the beginning of this review the color collection is very appealing and I believe these are the perfect kids/teen headphones for the reasons below;- Colors - Kids likes colorful things and the bright 12 colors you can chose from can please many tastes.- Long Braided Cable - The cable is braided (made out of fabric and not TPE) and can withstand pulling, biting, snagging..etc so this will last longer with kids.- Music Sharing - The headphones has a 3.5 AUX output on the left side where you can connect another headphones and share the music you are listening too. I have been training for a marathon for the last 2 months and since I have been running almost everyday, I started having pain and soreness in my legs so I was lucky enough to be offered a sample of this product in exchange of an honest review.This cream is perfect for me, since I have tried bengay cream and Tiger palm which are both to much of a burning, or cold sensation for me.The ExcruFlex has a nice hereby smell and feels amazing on the muscle it start the relieving almost right away, and last a long time.One think though if you use it the night before you run or exercise then you go run you will feel a very un comfortable burning sensation so I recommend using it then taking a shower before running again.

These pot holders were received as a free gift. They are silky smooth to the touch and it's nice to have a pair instead of just one. They are pretty to look at and the nubs that provide extra heat guard are adorable little hearts. Without the heart nubs, however, the gloves are fairly thin when compared to other silicone pot holders.I learned the hard way that if I pull something hot from the oven and happen to grip the pan in an area where there is no silicone heart coverage then I will get burned or at least it will be very hot to the touch. I couldn't grip long enough to pull the pan and gently set it on the stove, I had to drop it quickly.It might improve the quality if the company adds more raised nubs to the glove or makes the smooth part of the glove thicker.On a positive note however, these gloves can also be re-purposed for other typical kitchen tasks such as opening jars, putting underneath pots and bowls to prevent slipping, and wrapping the glove around garlic and onions to help remove the peel.

I received this kit for free to review. I must say it is a very comprehensive kit that includes several tools for whatever kind of blemish issues you may have. I was not able to try out the lancet tool at this time, but I must say the point seemed a little blunt.I've never used a spoon shaped extractor before but it looks perfectly sized to squeeze out a blackhead without damaging the surrounding skin. The tools appear sturdy and made of material that will not rust or easily break.I've paid a lot more for a comparable loop extractor than what this entire kit costs. Overall I would say that this is an exceptionally great deal for the price.

2:08 Mins The PECHAM C26 Waterproof Bluetooth Speaker was close in meeting my expectations, but it's not the ultimate rugged Bluetooth speaker. PECHAM c26 looks rugged and it absorbs the shock of a drop, thanks to the rubber surrounding the speaker. However, nowhere in the manual or the product description page was I able to find the actual IPX rating of the speaker. I contacted the company to gather this info and received no answer (I assume poor customer service).â€‹I didn't want to fully submerge it into water so I tested it against a splashing water at the beach and it did great. I am assuming its rating is at least IPX4 or IPX5.Sound Quality:â€‹PECHAM C26 has a total output of 10W which is very loud for its size. When playing music on maximum volume the sound will cover a large room size and a poolside party. There are, however, a few flaws to having big sound without the proper execution. For example when a song has a strong bass the speaker starts to have some distortion when used on high volume.- Clarity of Sound  â˜…â˜…â˜… when the music is only vocals and mid-range the speaker has crystal clear sound, but once the bass starts kicking in you will hear a little bit (very little)  of distortion which affects the clarity of the sound.- Vocals and Mid Range  â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…- Bass  â˜…â˜…â˜…- Overall Sound Quality - â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…Design and Features:Although the speaker has the typical design that many sellers on Amazon use, it looks and feels rugged. I dropped it few times to test it and it survived about 3-5 feet drops. Other features worth mentioning:â€‹â€‹- Flashlight -  This speaker has a built-in flashlight that can be turned on with a press of a button. This is a great addition especially because it is an outdoors speaker.- Water and Shock Resistant - The product listing on Amazon describes the speaker as "waterproof." However, as discussed earlier in this post there is no indication of the actual IPX rating, which could confuse the consumer. Remember water resistant is not waterproof and this speaker is NOT waterproof, only water resistant.- â€‹Overall Design - â˜…â˜…â˜…â€‹Improvements:- IPX Rating - providing the actual IPX rating to the consumer is a very important piece of information. Also differentiating between waterproof and water resistant.- Less Distortion - Sometimes simple is better than over doing, by reducing the bass or using a better passive sub-woofer this speaker will have a much more clear sound quality.I have received this product in exchange for an honest review

What I like about this spray is that it has minimal ingredients which appear harmless for my dog to ingest such as baking soda and Aloe Vera, and contains no alcohol. I also like the quick shot foam which is easy to apply when your dog is not being cooperative. Once sprayed on to the teeth it sticks to the teeth and gums. No brushing is required. What I donâ€™t like is that the dispenser shoots out too much foam which actually dribbles out of my dogsâ€™ mouth onto the floor causing much of the product to be wasted. Also, even though humans prefer the freshness of peppermint and spearmint, I believe dogs would much prefer the fresh taste of chicken. This product works immediately in reducing bad breath, but needs to be used 1-2 times per day in order to sustain breath freshness. Will need to update this review to inform of the effectiveness in reducing tartar and plaque.

The perfect desktop speaker! And by this I mean, if you're looking for a speaker to take to the beach this may not be the one for you. Displays time in 24h with LCD screen. Includes supporting TF card, USB flash disk, and 3.5mm audio port.Easy to use: Simply turn on/off with a switch on the back of the speaker. Enable your Bluetooth setting on your device, pair with the speaker in less than 30 seconds and voilÃ !Sound Quality:As mentioned before, this speaker is not for outdoor use and is better appreciated at close range such as at a desk or in a small room. After experiencing a variety of music, I noted that even though the speakers are advertised as having 3W audio drivers and subwoofer the deep base music lacks some body with this speaker.  Also at maximum volume the sound is not very loud, so if you like to feel your music in your chest, you might be disappointed.Acoustic guitar sounds and vocals, however, come through crisp and clear. The Green Earth Pan by Ozeri is a dream come true. It states it is free of PTFE and PFOA chemicals which are believed to be harmful when consumed.Ozeri has done an excellent job of creating a non-stick coating that is ceramic based. The honeycombed shaped ridges in the pan allow for even heating and most likely also assist with preventing food from sticking.It is important to read and follow instructions to keep the pan in good working condition. I have only used this pan for a few weeks so I am not sure how this pan fares in the long term. Several other users of this pan have commented that the non-stick technology wears off in the long term.I suspect that using the pan on high heat regularly may eventually cause damage to the non-stick coating. Also frequent frying might damage the coating over time. It may be best to use this pan on the lowest heat possible since it is designed to distribute the heat evenly. Also be frugal with the amount of oil you use in the pan, but do use a little bit as mentioned in the directions. I have used this pan to make spectacular omelets. I was worried that the meat drippings and sauce that dried in the pan during cooking would not come out, but I simply soaked it in water for several hours or overnight and it easily wiped off. I own a couple of other ceramic coated pans that are white on the inside, and while they get the job done the Ozeri feels more heavy duty and capable of withstanding larger cooking jobs. I am very pleased with the performance of this pan.
