6:59 Mins The creators at BACtrack are considered heroes for some. They have been working diligently, for more than a decade, on enabling individuals to check their own blood alcohol level.  BACtrack was the first FDA approved personal use breathalyzer, and was featured on shows like The Doctors, Dr Phil, and Mythbusters to name a few.BACtrack Mobile, Why You Should Buy It?The BACtrack Mobile breathalyzer, or any BACtrack breathalyzer in general, is a very practical item to own.  Having the option to connect it to your smartphone enriches the awesomeness, and the ingenuity of this valuable gadget.PROS:- Good visibility -Once connected to your smartphone BACtrack Mobile is no longer restricted to a small built-in screen (which might be hard to see when you are under the influence), but instead will have big, bright, and easy to see results.- Countdown to sobriety-I love that the app gives you the ability to see your past results, and uses that information to determine your ZeroLine, a patented technology by BACtrack which determines how long it takes your blood alcohol level to drop to 0.00%. This feature knows me better than I know myself. ZeroLine  predicted an accurate time frame for me to reach sobriety almost every time I used it. If at any time the prediction was inaccurate it was most likely because I didn't drink enough water.- Small and rechargeable- This device is truly mobile.  It is small enough to fit in your pocket and the included carrying case makes it even more mobile. Recharge it using the included micro-USB cable (battery life varies depending on usage)- Sanitary - It comes with three mouthpieces so you don't share it with people (don't be nasty!) and you can buy more mouthpieces here. Past users have shared that you can use a straw, and it works equally well.- Accurate - Thanks to some friends who work in law enforcement, we were able to compare the BACtrack's results to a device commonly used in public safety. We got the same results! This is because, BACtrack Mobile uses Police-Grade XtendÂ® Fuel Cell Sensor Technology (A fancy way to say it's accurate). To learn more about this technology check out this page.IMPROVEMENTS:One drawback that I was able to find with BACtrack Mobile is that if your phone dies, you're out of luck.  This breathalyzer is practically useless without a phone. However, it is really easy to borrow someones else phone and install the app. It takes literally less than one minute to connect the breathalyzer to any phone after installing the app. Maybe including a built-in screen that can be turned off when the breathalyzer is connected to the phone to preserve battery could fix this.In Summary:The accuracy of BACtrack Mobile is astonishing. The features, the design, and the app are like a team that complete each other.  Remember, BACtrack should be used to determine the alcohol level in the blood to give you a time frame for sobriety and allow you to monitor your drinking habits. It should not be used to determine if you can drive or not, as having any alcohol in your blood can impair driving. For it's practically flawless features, we give BACtrack Mobile the perfect 5 TechPicks stars â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…

There's a saying, "Just because it's simple doesn't mean it's easy," and the inverse of that saying applies well to this book.On the surface, it's a ~200-page novella of short chapters and abundant white space, in which a woman recalls a time in the mid-1980s that brought a short reconciliation with her estranged mother and the chance to be curious and better understand both the family she grew up in and the family she co-created.Strout's gentle, reflective narrative is so easy to read that it threatens to be unsatisfying in an "Is that all there is?" way. But at the same time, its vignette-ish chapters seem oblique and, having read two of Strout's previous books, I knew of course that isn't all there is. And when I paused to be curious, I found subtext and resonance. This is an excellent choice for book clubs, where discussion will reveal much layering and complexity.

Iâ€™m giving this two stars because, on a first sip/swallow, this cranberry/raspberry water tastes lively and refreshing. For some people, that may continue. But for me, it then turned into a watered-down juice with a strong artificial note (the raspberry, I think) that persisted harshly on my taste buds.I use cranberry juice with water and ice when I make cosmo martinis, so I tried one with this cranberry water and it did not taste good (maybe the raspberry aspect; maybe the sweetness). So whether on its own or in the martini, I didnâ€™t get past a few swallows before throwing it away. Since the deal-breaker for me seemed to be the raspberry, I might give the passion fruit or blood orange (two favorites) flavors a try.

I keep this 6-inch cable in my car. It connects through an adapter that plugs into the carâ€™s cigarette lighter and charges my iPhone 6s just fine. Or, it connects to the USB wire installed in the console between the front seats and plays audio through the aux system. In both cases, the cable is just long enough to let my phone lay flat on a nearby surface.To use it during hotel stays (connected through an adapter that plugs into an AC outlet) is slightly trickier. If thereâ€™s an outlet on a tabletop/desk lamp, the cable is long enough to let me lay the phone near the lamp and itâ€™s fine. But if the only electrical access is a wall outlet, the short cable makes the phone just hang -- unless I make a little stack of something (e.g. books, shoes, etc.) beneath the outlet and lay the phone on top of that.Belkin cables are thicker and sturdier than Apple versions, but this one is only slightly thicker, thus more aesthetically elegant than other Belkins Iâ€™ve had. The pink color makes it easy to find. Note: none of the adapters mentioned here are included with this cable.

At first glance, this bookâ€™s shape and organization call to mind the â€œDummiesâ€ series of books, but (thankfully) the resemblance ends with the first page of Chapter 1. Rather than light, silly and repetitive content, this book is a deep (even microscopic) examination of the systems (for example, math and physics) involved in software security (including passwords and encryption), graphics (including screens, games and filmmaking) and web searching. I'm frankly gobsmacked by the people who conceived and continue to innovate software.And itâ€™s readable -- a good fit for a technical reader or a motivated lay reader. It requires significant concentration and engagement and wouldnâ€™t be as good a fit for a more casual reader.

"Mrs. A. was the only real witness of the enterprise we embarked on day after day, the sole observer of the bond that held us together [...] In the long run, every love needs someone to witness and acknowledge it, to validate it, or it may turn out to be just a mirage."I have a fondness for little â€œgemsâ€ of books -- novella-length, with more emphasis on character than plot, and emotionally/intellectually complicated enough to engage me over repeated readings. Some of my favorites are "Tinkers," "Einstein's Dreams," "The Waitress Was New," "The Spare Room," "Glaciers," "Last Night at the Lobster," "The Summer Book." And now, this one.Itâ€™s about a man, woman and young son who face a cancer diagnosis in their household helper and touchstone, and discover the effects that her absence has on their family. As in Giordanoâ€™s previous "The Solitude of Prime Numbers", there is isolation here, and melancholy, and prickly characters. And there is curious, philosophical searching, especially in the realm of memory and reality -- including a passage likely to resonate with readersâ€™ own realities:"The archaeologists of the future [will] not find any photographs; the few we have reside on the computerâ€™s hard disk, which will have already been useless for many years. [...] The testimony of our lives together is dependent upon a good memory, ours and that of a silicon motherboard. [...] [They] will find very few objects and almost no embellishments, not even in Emanueleâ€™s room, which from year to year is being emptied of toys and colors, because everything thatâ€™s important to him is now found in the circuits of a tablet."

This is a sweet, creamy, light-milk chocolate, very fresh, with crunchy hazelnuts and almonds and chewy raisins that give contrasting textures to the smooth chocolate. There are two large bars (each approx. 7 oz.), each scored into 20 break-off sections for nibbling (4 of which equal a portion, 210 calories). Iâ€™m a bigger fan now of dark chocolate, but oohh, this is a fancy and delicious milk chocolate.Its packaging makes it gift-worthy. Talk about â€œunwrappingâ€ -- there are four layers! Inside the shipping box, you first see Amazonâ€™s â€œfrustration-freeâ€ package -- a custom-made little box that provides a perfect shipping nest for the product. Inside that is the manufacturerâ€™s lovely packaging -- the two bars, each in a pretty, individual box, inside which is an overwrap of lush paper and then a final, sealed foil wrapper enclosing the chocolate.Itâ€™s an â€œexperienceâ€ from presentation through eating -- beautiful and delicious.

Since March 2000, Iâ€™ve been using a sealed foil pouch to cook a delicious shrimp/basil/feta/orzo recipe from Cooking Light magazine (search the site, the recipe is still there). In the beginning, I used Reynoldsâ€™ foil oven bags. When they discontinued the bags about 10 years ago, I started making my own pouches by folding a length of heavy-duty foil in half and sealing the three open sides. Not much work at all, yet I longed for the bag every single time and have periodically looked for it in stores.So Iâ€™m thrilled to see itâ€™s back! Itâ€™s approx. 10x15-in in size, fits nicely on a â€œhalf-sheetâ€-size cookie/baking sheet, and is at least as substantial as heavy-duty foil from a roll. Has a slight decorative pattern on the surface. The open end is on a short side, which takes some getting used to: itâ€™s a little clumsier to fill/serve through the narrow end; on the other hand, itâ€™s easier to seal the narrow end. Terrific product!

I liked Campbellâ€™s previous collection of short stories (American Salvage) and I loved this one. No first words of stories have captured me as quickly as each of these, and then held me their whole lengths, with their rural southwestern Michigan settings and lower-middle-class characters. I was chilled by their collective (and a bit repetitive) theme of womenâ€™s and girlsâ€™ vulnerability to men, and more so by the lengths women go to in avoiding and recovering from those harms.Campbellâ€™s stories remind me of Jo Ann Beardâ€™s (The Boys of My Youth), although Campbellâ€™s settings are a little bleaker and her characters a little rougher/tougher (at least on the outside). Readers of one author will enjoy the work of the other. Readers new to both will have a lot of great stories ahead of them.

I use disposable gloves for tasks inside and outside of the house, sometimes even pulled on over fabric gloves. In my experience, latex, vinyl and nitrile are all light and flexible; latex fits best; vinyl is most durable. But these Ammex Xtreme are the Rambo of disposable nitrile gloves; theyâ€™re thicker and have held up without tearing through gardening projects and cleaning my garage.I wear a womanâ€™s M or L glove and these L are a bit big (but still usable). My husband wears an L or XL glove and these L are snug on his hands (but still usable) and the fingers are too short. We can both get by with the L but if we were doing detail handwork, Iâ€™d need the M and heâ€™d try the XL in hopes the fingers were a bit longer.

"---Dad, he says, with a kind swerve in his voice..."I can hear it -- that swerve nearly separating â€œDadâ€ into two syllables. Thatâ€™s Colum McCann, whose lyrical stories practically read themselves.Here heâ€™s assembled a novella and three short stories, each of which explores looking through different perspectives. In the stories, thereâ€™s the mind of a writer as he creates and bends and prunes a story; there's a nun who catches sight of the man, now renown, who raped her decades before; and there's a translatorâ€™s struggle to find, in any language, an equivalent to the Hebrew word, â€œshâ€™kholâ€ (a parent whose child has died), even as she deals with her own missing son. In the novella, a day in an octogenarianâ€™s life is interpreted through the lenses of numerous surveillance cameras."[The detectives] will comb through the [camera] images looking for any random detail [...] The more obscure the moment, the more valuable the knowledge. [...] They work in much the same way as poets: the search for a random word, at the right instance, making the poem itself so much more precise."Again, thatâ€™s McCann, who excels at finding the telling detail. This shorter collection wasnâ€™t as immersive as his 2009 Let the Great World Spin (ten stories linked through shared characters and a connection to Phillippe Petitâ€™s 1974 high-wire walk between the World Trade Centerâ€™s Twin Towers). But like every McCann story Iâ€™ve read, these touch gently on important topics via memorable characters, and each was individually satisfying.

This isn't my highest-rated of the four At-a-Glance planners I've used, but it's my favorite.It's extremely "clean" in design, with a cover that's visually simple but nicely tactile due to a faux sueded-leather that feels like nubuck. The spiral binding allows the planner to lay open and completely flat, or to be folded open, front cover to back, to lay flat at just half the width. I really like the "nubuck" cover, but it does sometimes drag against the spiral binding which makes it clumsy to close.The visual simplicity continues inside, where each tabbed month begins with a 2-page calendar spread of the month, followed by 2-page spreads for each week, and here each day of the week gets its own square-ish box instead of the typical vertical columns. I like that, since my days are currently filled more with task lists and notes than specific appointment times. I also like that Saturday and Sunday each get space equal to the weekdays, and that there's an area for the week's Notes. The pages are white with gray lines and a tiny orange font. Again, though I like that "clean-ness," the font is hard to read and the lack of margins or borders at the page perimeters (see product images) makes it look a bit unfinished.The best feature of this planner is something I haven't seen in my other At-a-Glance planners -- its last page is a clear plastic sheet with two half-height pockets, one on each side! For me, a pocket is essential and if a planner doesn't have one, I make my own and tape it in.In summary, this is an academic-year planner (13 months: July 2015 through July 2016) with a clean, upscale feel that makes me eager for July to get here!

From the authors:"[Graphic d]esign is not decoration but, rather, the intelligent solution of conceptual problems; it is the manipulation of type, image, and, most of all, the presentation of ideas that convey a message."It was from IDEO CEO Tim Brown that I first heard stressed that design is not a tweak, made near the end of a process to fine-tune or make pretty, but rather is a substantive, beginning-to-end way of thinking. It discourages me to see that designers still have to fight that characterization. But this book encourages me, with its collection of Q&As with ~80 designers, and hundreds of full-color examples of their work, that showcase the substantive contributions of graphic design.The subtitle says it's "A Guide to Careers in Design," but I think it's closer to "An *Exposure* to Careers in Design," specifically graphic design. It's not a mind-focusing, how-to book; it's a mind-blowing primer on possibilities. It exposes the potential design student to a wide variety of content such as design genres and sub-genres, print and digital, from fonts to images to layouts and entire installations. It touches on design markets like publishing, packaging, commerce and advertising. It also considers the workplace experience as an employee vs. independent vs. with partner, and how to stay inspired and motivated.As a reader and writer, I enjoy author interviews for their behind-the-curtain peeks at other creatives at work. So it was for me with this book, too, where the designers' curiosity and creativity actually made me feel carbonated!

This is a very attractive water bottle, made of high-quality materials. If you have a zero-tolerance for leaks/spillage of any kind under any circumstances, its design makes it an outstanding water bottle. But if you just want a spill-resistant bottle for use on-the-go, look elsewhere because the design of this one, specifically its cap, makes it very complicated to clean. Moreover, while it seems designed to prevent spills from very young children who will tip, shake and even throw bottles, it seems way too big and heavy for such young children.The bottle itself and the straw, which disconnects from the cap, are simple to clean. But the leak-proof aspects of the cap necessitate countless hinges, valves and fittings that require detailed attention to separate and clean. I've only filled my bottle with water, never anything that could add a residue that supports bacterial growth, and even then the cleaning seems tedious. The bottle is too big to fit in the holder on my bicycle, so I take it to my workout classes, where it's easy to carry on the hook of a finger and I can sip through the straw rather than having to tilt my head back and squirt water from above. It's okay for that, though I prefer other bottles I have that are lighter-weight.

This is a good planner, with semi-rigid plastic (wipe-able) covers and a colorful pop-floral design both on the covers and around the perimeter of the 8.5x11-in, tan-colored pages inside. The spiral binding allows the planner to lay open and completely flat, or to be folded open, front cover against back cover, to lay flat at just half the width.Each tabbed month begins with a 2-page calendar spread of the month, followed by 2-page spreads for each week, and here each day of the week gets its own *horizontal* writing space instead of the usual *vertical* columns. I like that, since my days are currently filled more with task lists and notes than specific appointment times. I also like that Saturday and Sunday each get space equal to the weekdays, and that there's an area for the week's Notes.A feature I don't often see is that each day is designated by what day of the year it is and how many days remain in the year (e.g. December 1 is "335/30"). But note that this planner is for an academic year, so the 12-month coverage is July 2015 through June 2016. At the back, there's a list of holiday dates for 2015-18, and pages for more notes and Contacts info.I'm using this planner to tend to some writing projects, and the layout and lively floral graphics suit that creative pursuit perfectly.

"You might think that the biggest problem in medical care is that it costs too much. Or that health insurance is too expensive, too uneven, too complicated -- and gives you too many forms to fill out. But the central problem is that too much medical care has too little value."Welch characterizes healthcare as a U-shaped curve, with high potential for harm at both the low- and high-utilization ends. He argues against the "7 Assumptions That Drive Too Much Medical Care," of the book's subtitle, specifically that:1 -- All risks can be lowered2 -- It's always better to fix the problem3 -- Sooner is always better4 -- It never hurts to get more information5 -- Action is always better than inaction6 -- Newer is always better7 -- It's all about avoiding death.What healthcare policy book is fascinating? gripping? even witty? This one! Much of it feels counter-intuitive; but when explained, it flips nearly to common sense. My only quibble is that I needed just a little more explanation/documentation to convince me about some of the most surprising material (for example, the low value of mammography).This book is a must-read. I'll read more by Welch.

I don't consider writers to be "Favorite Authors" until I've especially enjoyed at least two books by them. This is my second by Keret, and yep! -- he's been Favorite-d.My first was his latest collection of flash fiction, which delighted me with surreal premises and imaginative twists. This book is a collection of 36 similarly short pieces, but here they're memoir-ish essays about the titular seven years between the birth of his son and the death of his father. They're not only poignantly optimistic, they're often outright funny.His observations from Tel Aviv on family -- his Holocaust-survivor parents, adored older brother and ultra-orthodox sister; his lioness wife and wise, tender young son -- stun me with their guy-next-door universality. They remind me of other writers whose landscape is family and humor, e.g. David Sedaris. But those others don't have stories of family road trips interrupted by air-raid sirens and the need to stop and lie at the side of the road until the bomb explodes, all the while distracting the frightened son by recasting the situation, Life-Is-Beautiful-like, as a game of "pastrami sandwich" where the child is protected between the adults.Plus, it's a treat to read Miranda July's Q&A with Keret in the opening pages. Considering they're two of the most unique writers I've encountered, I especially liked this:"The best trait I got from my mother is her confidence. Not the kind of confidence that makes you lead the rebels' attack on the death star, but [...] that your choices, no matter how strange and different they may be, are perfectly all right. [...T]hat all those people around me who gave me good advice on how to be better [at being myself] were to be taken seriously, while all those who were simply asking me to [change] were to be ignored."I'm eager to read more of Keret's fiction, but now I yearn to read more of his memoir.

"Social Security [...] has an endless assortment of rules, variations on the rules, exceptions to the rules, and exceptions to the exceptions to the rules."I'm not yet at retirement age but my oldest siblings are, and I've grown interested to know the basics of Social Security both for my own financial planning and so I can benefit from my siblings' experiences as they enroll.This is a typical "for Dummies" book in terms of layout (outline organization, section headings, graphics, sidebars). Its content is accessibly written, with lots of repetition, but that allows you to dip in and out of chapters at will rather than needing to read from beginning to end or needing to read the chapters about benefits that are not relevant to you.There's more content here than I'd expected. This second edition (c2015) covers not only Social Security's retirement benefit but also its benefits for worker disability or death AND Medicare's health-insurance benefit. I'm in a male/female/two-income marriage and came away with a good grasp of the basic rules, and a better-than-expected grasp of the variations and exceptions to the rules (e.g. for divorced, or same-sex married, or single-income, or foreign-residing couples), plus a trove of resources and contact info for estimating my specific benefits and planning when/how to file for them. I feel I've gotten a good start.

This is the Reece's you love, in the Miniatures size that I especially love because the Miniatures have more surface area and thus a slightly higher milk-chocolate-to-peanut-butter ratio than the standard-size cups.It's a BIG bag of them (4+ pounds, approx. 200-count), each Miniature individually wrapped and very fresh. My bag indicates a best-by date of 11/2015, and I've divided the contents into smaller, sealed bags that will stay fresh until then ... or until they're gone, which is likelier to come first :)

I'm fascinated with insight and moments of awareness and have been thrilled by occurrences of it in my life. So I was interested to see this book-length work on the science of "what happens in the brain at the instant when a person solves a problem with a flash of insight," and am happy to report that it's both informative and enjoyable.The authors describe insight, an unconscious thought process of quantum leaps that deliver a revolutionary idea in abrupt clarity, and contrast it with the conscious, deliberate, evolutionary process of analysis. They discuss the problem-solving styles of "insightfuls" and "analysts" (and the errors of omission and commission that they make when they run out of time when working out a problem; the insightfuls offering no solutions and the analysts offering half-baked solutions), and use EEG and fMRI data to describe what's going on in the brain and where.Then they devote perhaps half of the book to methods that increase insight, for example, getting as much life experience as possible (so as to better recognize patterns), taking a break/taking a nap (your unconscious will keep working the problem), scheduling your creative work for when you're typically tired (i.e. your censoring analyst is tired, allowing insights to bubble up), and further reducing the censor by developing a positive mindset and an unconstrained, long-term outlook.It's fascinating and a lot of fun to read.

My favorite fiction format is a collection of linked short stories, where characters, settings, events and/or themes appear and reappear in lead and supporting roles in the various stories, and sometimes become more fascinating in the sideways glimpses of their supporting roles than when seen head-on. I didn't know it going in to this book, but this big novel is actually a collection of linked novellas. I loved it.They're linked through the title character, Radar Radmanovic (born in 1975 New Jersey) and a fascinating (and fictional?) branch of puppetry that takes the reader through time, geography, ethnicity and late-20th-century history. The linking is loose, the novellas nearly stand alone, but wow! Reif Larsen can write! His playful, curious, science-based (in this case, physics) narrative reminded me of Jeffrey Eugenides' Middlesex, and his insertion of photos, maps and other visuals amid the text reminded me of Michael Crichton's works. I'm eager to get to his debut novel, The Selected Works of T.S. Spivet.

These 10-in and 12-in stainless-steel nonstick skillets are beautiful -- more beautiful than my Calphalon Contemporary Nonstick -- and I'm thrilled that they also cook well and clean up easily.I tested them with two of my go-to meals: grilled-cheese sandwiches and seared sirloin steaks. The skillets are thinner than the Calphalon, so I was worried about burning and possibly kept the heat too low -- the steaks looked great but didn't have the flavor that usually develops with the sear. (Looking again, I realized only the sides seem thin; the bottoms are heavyweight.) So I admit to being more attentive than usual when I tried the grilled cheese ... and they came out possibly my best batch in 25+ years! -- uniformly grilled all the way to the crusts, beautiful and flavorful, with no hint of overdone. (Plus, the 12-in skillet was roomy enough to grill my three (may even fit four) sandwiches at one time.) No sticking whatsoever, even the melted cheese, and easy to clean (I always hand wash).Do note: contrary to the current information on this page, these do NOT come with lids. Otherwise, a very nice set!

This little timer is simple to program (thankfully without those pull-out pins that get lost) and reliably carries out its on/off duties without a hitch. I have it programmed to light a lamp in an out-of-the-way area all evening, and the area looks so cozy now.Plus, it adds two features that my previous timers didn't have: 1) the instructions are printed on the back of the timer, making them always available (and they're quite intuitive); and 2) to operate whatever is plugged into the timer during the period it's scheduled to be off (without disrupting the schedule or unplugging anything), just slide a switch from "Timer on" to "Outlet on" (and then back to "Timer on" when you're done).I just ordered two more.

I enjoy a glass of wine before dinner most nights and, despite using tight bottle stoppers, do notice the gradual decline in flavor / increase in acidity over the 4-5 day life of the bottle. I was excited (and dubious) about trying this product ... and I'm thrilled with it! It exceeds all of my expectations: great design, easy to use, excellent results.It's a 3-piece set: one hand-pump suction device and two bottle stoppers (for two bottles of wine; they're good, tight stoppers on their own even without creating a vacuum). Just press a stopper into a wine bottle, position the suction device on top, pull up to suction air out of the bottle, and keep pumping until you feel yourself pulling against the pressure of the vacuum you've created. The vacuum holds until you release it by pressing a little button on the stopper, causing an energetic "whoosh" even a full day later. Rinse the device and you're done. I've tried this on two bottles of wine so far and it seems that not until Day 4 can I tell the wine isn't "just opened." My only quibble is that the suction device pulls some humidity as well as air from the bottle, creating drips to wipe up (caution: red-wine dribble might stain). Highly recommended.

If you want to enjoy a hot beverage while being very active, this attractive Camelbak Forge is the leakproof (at all angles), vacuum-insulated mug for you, with a loop that's easy to attach to clothing or gear or carry with a single finger.But if you just want a mug/travel-mug to keep your beverage hot while you sip from it over time, be advised that the cap on this one is fussy and frustrating. To take a drink, press and hold a lever to open the drinking port; when released, the port closes to become leakproof again. To drink frequently, slide a button to keep the port open slightly (and I mean slightly; it dispenses a sip, not a swallow). Whenever the port is opened, by either method, a tiny bit of built-up coffee steam first spits out, so vent it away from your face (or shirt, so it doesn't stain). I tested the mug on hot cafÃ© lattes and hot brewed coffee, with the port open continuously or with it open only for sipping, and the beverages stayed hot for, respectively, an hour and two-plus hours.The cap's low-volume sip, annoying spray of coffee steam, and dozens of threads/crevices to clean afterward make it frustrating for casual use. But when I'm out on my bike, those frustrations are somewhat dwarfed by its leakproof portability.

Excellent product. The packaging has a child-resistant cap that's fairly easy for an adult to open, and a body that's easy to hold in one hand and squeeze to direct a stream of cleaner all around the toilet bowl including under the rim. The cleaner inside is viscous enough to coat the sides of the bowl instead of all draining right down into the water. The scent is mild but the formula is strong; the clean bowl smells fresh and positively gleams.The cling coating reminds me of those "disclosing tablets" from childhood: you chewed them and they left dye wherever you hadn't brushed your teeth well enough, so you'd know to pay closer attention to those areas. This cleaner coats the whole toilet bowl, and you know you've done a thorough cleaning when you've removed every bit of the colored cleaner with your toilet brush.One caveat: in one test, I used the Lysol "Cling" formula on half of my toilet bowl and my usual Lysol "Power" (non-Cling) formula to the other half. The Power was actually more viscous and had a more noticeable blue tint than the Cling. So do watch the relative prices; while both are great products, I don't see an advantage that would justify a premium price for either over the other.

I've been looking for two things in a neck pillow: support and washability. This pillow and its cover offer both.It's made of a very firm memory foam, providing neck support that I'd characterize as "stabilizing," even "bracing," more so than "comfortable." But stabilizing is exactly what my neck sometimes wants; for comfort, I do also have a pellet-filled "Bucky" pillow. My only quibble is that I have to be careful to position the pillow just right, otherwise its "arms" press a bit against the sides of my neck and feel like they're restricting blood flow to my head!The cover is perfect. It's attractive, of wonderfully soft velour, with a zipper that makes it easy to get on and off the foam form. It machine-washed and air-dried beautifully.While the pillow is lightweight, the firm foam doesn't compress much and it would be bulky to pack. It's a good choice at home or in a car.

These Depend seat protectors are better in every way to those blue institutional "chux" pads -- they're attractive, soft, substantial and not at all noisy. They're also more absorbent, but "more" might not actually mean "enough."When I tested one by quickly pouring 1/2 cup of water onto it, the water soaked in and spread to the edge of the pad, threatening to spill over. I tried again on another pad, pouring the water slowly that time, and again it soaked in and spread a bit. Both times, when I pressed on the surface, the water rose up out of the pad -- puddling, never gelling, and when I folded up the pads to throw them away, I could still squeeze the water from them. So whatever is on top of the pad is going to get sopping wet, with the potential of spreading beyond the edges. The good news is that the pad's backing is absolutely leak-proof and keeps the surface beneath it completely dry.These pads will absorb very small spills, and will keep the main part of a larger spill from wetting whatever is directly underneath the pad. They'll also work beautifully as a disposable "towel," either when you want a clean surface to sit on or lay something on, or you want to keep a surface clean from dirt, sweat, sunless tanner that's drying, etc. They're likely the best product available but they're not yet perfect.

America's Test Kitchen shuffles and gathers its recipes into various collections based on themes, and this one interested me: "recipes you can prepare on your schedule" via eight "make ahead" strategies.The ~165 recipes for meat, fish, grain and vegetarian entrees  (serving 4, 6, or 8 people) are accompanied by full-color photos of almost every prepared dish (but without nutrition info). They cover the "expected" strategies, for example slow-cooker meals; big-batch meals (eat half, freeze half); and casseroles or marinades where the time-consuming prep/assembly is done in advance.But there's also a "Sunday Cook" section, where leftover roasts become weeknight soups/fajitas/fried rices/etc. There's a "Shop Smart" section, where a dozen ingredients mix and match over three days into three different meals. And there are sections for foods intentionally cooked ahead and then refrigerated, such as poaches/salads served cold or stews/braises that develop flavors while resting before a quick reheat. Throughout, the editors include tips for ingredients, preparation, storage and freezing that overcome the typical problems that otherwise make such dishes scream "leftovers."LOL my desire is not so much to "cook ahead" as to "cook less often" (and plan/shop less often). So I most appreciated the Sunday Cook, the Shop Smart (every recipe here!), and the big-batch (especially Beef and Bean Burritos) sections.

There are books written *for* child readers, and there are books written *about* children but with a wise narrative voice that also appeal to a crossover audience of young-adult and even adult readers (e.g. To Kill a Mockingbird, The Book Thief). This book is definitely for kids (ages 8-12), with an appealing first-person narrator, 11-year-old Naomi Orenstein. (It will likely grate on older readers, especially when the writing gets "teachy," for example: "Running this fast, I'll be home in a flash, a milli-flash, which is one thousandth of a flash.")HOWEVER. On a light note, the story is full of references to 1960s-`70s pop culture, which children born in this millennium aren't likely to understand. On a dark note, it also touches on bullying, mental depression, child abuse, and death, which may be disturbing and not well-understood by children.It's an accomplished debut novel, perhaps even an important story, and so my recommendation is that parents (or grandparents, etc.) and children read it and talk about it together.

This knife has a good little serrated blade, but the innovation comes from its great handle, which is chunky in size and made of OXO's trademark black rubbery material. That makes it comfortable to hold and non-slip to grip, a bit more so on both counts than the handles on the OXO Good Grips *Professional* series. It's become my go-to knife.

This collection finally assembles English translations of the full 34-story set of Calvino's "cosmicomics," his short stories that riff on science. They're mostly narrated by "Qfwfq," a delightfully friendly, billions-year-old being whose preferred sciences are cosmology, biology and mathematics, and whose preferred riffs are about literature and human nature. There's also a nice Introduction with some historical and publishing context by Martin McLaughlin, one of Calvino's translators.They're my favorite length of short story, 5- to 17-pages each, easy to read in a single short sitting. Calvino's imagination tickles my brain and his playfulness makes me smile. Even if I summarized the "plot" of each story, it would not spoil because the pleasure is in the ride-along with Qfwfq. Highly recommended.

Pink opens by arguing that America's need for left-brain (logical, linear) skills has been largely replaced by software automation (reminiscent of the industrial revolution's replacement of physical labor with machinery) and more recently by outsourcing to less-expensive left-brains in developing countries.Then he describes what right-brain (creative, empathic) thinking adds that now makes it critical to business success. His text is somewhat shallow, but he follows up with dozens and dozens of interesting, playful sources for developing right-brain skills. For a somewhat similar, but deeper, exploration, take a look at Michael Gelb's How to Think Like Leonardo da Vinci.

This is a plastic, covered butter dish. However, it's OXO's version, meaning it has some tweaks in the design that make it innovative and easier to use. For example, there's the trademark black rubbery material on the bottom to prevent sliding around on the counter or in the butter compartment of the refrigerator door, and at both ends to enable a good grip in the hand or even just the fingertips. The clear cover is easy to lift off but doesn't slide off inadvertently. The white dish has raised markings at 1-tablespoon intervals; there are actually two sets of markings, one along each side, accommodating both "eastern" sticks and "western" cubes of packaged butter.When I first started using this dish, I thought it was good; I liked it. After a couple weeks now, I think it's great; every time I pull it from the fridge I appreciate that it's very easy to grip and that the lid doesn't slide off. Five stars.

I keep a detailed calendar and to-do list, but for the big-picture my brain loves an actual picture, which is exactly what this at-a-glance calendar provides.It's adequately sized for the big-picture, with two years (July2014 thru July2016) of monthly calendars, each open-face spread measuring 7-in wide by 6-in tall. Each spread has a nearly microscopic Notes column and last-month and next-month calendars, plus penny-sized boxes for the individual days (pre-printed with lots and lots of holidays, etc.), so you'll need to write tiny with a fine-point pen or hard-lead pencil. (Inexplicably, the center space around the fold/staples [20% of the entire page! see product image above] is wasted space until I figure out a way to repurpose it.) There are also reference pages: dates of holidays 2014-17, calendars 2013-16, pages for contacts and notes.Yet it's okay that it's microscopic, this is my space for placeholders not details. The cover design is pretty and the paper is nice. I'd prefer a one-year rather than two-year, but otherwise I love this. It presents exactly the "analog" image that my brain grabs onto and remembers, or that can be refreshed "at a glance."

"What do we do with knowledge that we cannot bear to live with? What do we do with the things we do not want to know? [...] A female writer cannot afford to feel her life too clearly. If she does, *She will write in a rage when she should write calmly. She will write foolishly where she should write wisely. She will write of herself where she should write of her characters. --A Room of One's Own, Virginia Woolf* "This is one of those vignette-ish little memoirs on how life inspired the writer within, published only by writers of a certain renown (I wish for more). It's Levy's feminist response to George Orwell's Why I Write, in which she writes beautifully about her not-beautiful childhood in South Africa during apartheid, teen years in England, a depressed midlife. I loved it and long to read more by her, to see these inspirations reflected in her fiction.

I've read almost all of Patchett's fiction and nonfiction now, and I liked this, her debut novel from back in 1992, second only to her fabulous Bel Canto.The premise here is of a pregnant woman heading to a home for unwed mothers run by nuns. These homes were typically sources for infant adoption, and Patchett's narrative gives voice to all three parties -- birth mothers, children and adoptive parents. I pulled it from the TBRs after having read the excellent nonfiction social history on that topic, The Girls Who Went Away: The Hidden History of Women Who Surrendered Children for Adoption in the Decades Before Roe v. Wade. Patchett writes beautifully and it paired well with the nonfiction, then blossomed into its own story.

"This never happened."Don Draper says that all the time on Mad Men, and in fact he says it to a character who's in the midst of a breakdown after an unwed pregnancy. Those script writers are good: although they didn't invent the line, it *is* fiction. It did happen, and the women never forgot.Subtitled, "The Hidden History of Women Who Surrendered Children for Adoption in the Decades Before Roe v. Wade", this is an excellent exploration of the social and legal intolerance of teenage unwed pregnancy and motherhood in 1950s-`60s USA, plus a compelling collection of oral histories from those birth mothers.There wasn't much contraception and it absolutely wasn't much available (mostly denied to single women, or accompanied by a big dose of judgment, and condoms were behind the pharmacy counter). Even information about contraception was illegal, and sex education was nil. The 1950s was a period of extreme social conformity and violations came with catastrophic fallout. And it was all on the girl (reliable proof of paternity wasn't there yet), who generally hid it with tight girdles in the early months and disappeared for the latter months to group homes (e.g. Florence Crittenton), typically under the guise of an illness or caring for a family member, and then adoption."They said, 'You can't raise the baby alone.' But no one expects a widow to give up her baby because her husband dies, do they? No. It's punitive."I've always appreciated Title IX of the Education Amendments Act of 1972 for its mandate of equal sports opportunities for women, but until now I didn't realize its provision was broader ("No person in the United States shall, on the basis of sex, be excluded from participation in, be denied the benefits of, or be subjected to discrimination under any education program or activity receiving federal financial assistance"), prohibiting high schools and colleges from expelling pregnant girls and teenage mothers.I marked dozens of passages despite my having lived at the late edge of the time, and shudder at the lifelong burden these women bear."One of the questions that come up when you go to court and relinquish is they ask you if you have been coerced in any way, and I thought it was the height of hypocrisy. Of course you're coerced. You're coerced by your parents, who said, 'Don't come home again if you plan to keep that child. We're not going to help you.' You're coerced by everyone around you because of the shame and the lack of acceptance by society and your community. You're not acknowledged as a fit mother because you had sex before marriage. The judge congratulated me on how courageous I was. I was furious that he would tell me it was about courage. It was about defeat. It was totally about shame and defeat."

Bruno Schulz's The Street of Crocodiles is Jonathan Safran Foer's favorite book, and he likens its existence (amid the destruction of most of Schulz's work) to the fourth wall at the ancient temple site that resisted destruction and became the Wailing Wall. Foer had long wanted to "sculpt" a new book by redacting words from an existing "block" of text, and TREE OF CODES is that, and an homage to Schulz.I went through phases as I read: he's stealing Schulz's story; then: no, he's just using words that are freely available, including in Schulz's work. In the end, it did seem to be Foer's own work, yet with a feeling of the larger original, particularly that so much is a father, mother, family in decline. Most pages are a mere sentence or two, written with the brevity and imagery of poetry. Schulz's work is surreal fantasy and Foer's even more so. Both are books to read and reread over a lifetime.

This is Roz Chast's memoir of her aged parents' decline and death, told in her trademark cartoon format. It's the growing worries about safety and medical emergencies; the move to assisted living; the flip in parent/child roles; the purging of possessions; the end-of-life. Chast is searingly and unprecedentedly open about her fraught relationship with her parents and the time, expense, shock, frustration, surrealism, and sadness associated with their decline. And she's funny more often than you'd expect -- wryly, and usually within the details of the cartoons. This is an accessible volume to give to someone in the situation but don't give it lightly, it provokes a deep response.

This 2009 issue of the UK literary journal is themed on Chicago. There are many good pieces, half a dozen excellent pieces, and I'm glad to have finally sampled Stuart Dybek, Nelson Algren, George Saunders. The low-income housing projects have long fascinated me, and Camilo Jose Vergara's photo essay on their rise in the 1950s and demolition in the 2000s is haunting. The entries focus on the cliches and downsides of Chicago, and altogether it is effective and suffocating. Still, c'mon! ... let's see another side, there *is* optimism and success in Chicago.

Wow what a fun read! Yes the physician narrator is a misanthrope but he fascinated me. Yes there are plot holes and conveniences but this book called to me whenever I had a free minute. I've since downloaded Koch's The Dinner and am halfway through. To Herman Koch and translators: more, please!

The name of this product ("pestemal") flummoxed me at first and I didn't know what to do with it. But now I appreciate that it deserves its own noun -- it's not really a towel or a throw, and yet it's both and a dozen things more. I've used it to cover the worn upholstery of a chair while I waited for shipment of a slipcover and now I have it spread across a table in my sunroom.It's large and of very good quality (soft and absorbent; nicely woven pattern). That pattern and the tassels make it look thicker than it is; it's actually about as thin as a flat dish towel (thus great as a tablecloth, no tipping of glassware; but too thin for a picnic on the ground). I actually expect it to prove quite durable. The product description specifies dimensions of 64-in x 39-in x 1-in, but after three trips through the washer and dryer, mine measures 60-in long (not including tassels) x 35-in wide x 1/16-in thick. There's been no bleeding of color (white stripes and tassels stay bright) and I noticed no lint.Versatile ... looks great ... very festive!

I have a lot of hair but it's very fine and tends to wilt. I've used a Paul Mitchell mousse for years with good results, then for the past year have bumped it up to a gel with great results. But a gel can feel like a lot of "product," so I was interested to see if this volumizing mousse would get me back to a lighter effect.It comes out of the canister as luxuriantly creamy foam, then collapses instantly between my hands to a film that initially seemed to make no difference in the texture of my wet hair. But as I blew it dry, it developed noticeable body. It felt soft and luxurious when I took sections to use with a curling iron. When I brushed it to smooth it into a style, there was a slight drag that felt like ultra-thick hair. Wow! And there's zero flaking. I was so impressed that I bought a little 2-oz travel size of the volumizing shampoo to pair with the mousse, and the two together seemed somehow to lift my hair and make it dry faster.This is the best mousse I've ever used. My only waver is that it *is* a mousse, and doesn't have the staying power of a gel, especially in heat and humidity. But I'm very impressed, and even if I use a gel this summer, I'll look forward to this product again in the fall.

This "Brilliant Glossing Shampoo" cleans my hair well, leaves it soft, and is a real pleasure to use: lots of lather with a light citrus/herbal/grassy fragrance. I was worried that its olive oil would weigh down my hair or make it seem dirtier sooner, but that has not happened. After three weeks of use, I don't notice any increased "glossiness" but my hair looks good.

My credentials don't add up to "audiophile" -- I just want to connect my iPhone wirelessly to a speaker and listen (without earphones) to music, podcasts and audiobooks. This Sharp system accomplishes that using Bluetooth technology.It's a sleek, nice-looking system with two speakers laid out horizontally (overall: 17.5-in wide, 6-in tall, 6-in deep). That width makes it very stable side-to-side; but it's narrow front-to-back, with even narrower little feet-strips that make the unit prone to rolling. It operates on AC only (not batteries). When turned on, the speakers each move outward a couple of inches, revealing center panels of decorative blue light that respond to the system's functions; the light is dimmable and some (but not all) of the light features can be disabled (as I chose to do). It was easy to pair with my iPhone 4S, and (unlike other Bluetooth speakers I've tried) the connection has never failed. There is also an audio jack and a USB port to play/charge other audio devices (my 6th-generation iPod Nano worked fine).Functions are accessible via a tiny wireless remote that has very good range but less-good sensitivity (it needs to be pointed directly at the speakers, the buttons pressed very deliberately and often more than once). Sound quality is good. Bass/treble is good, easily adjustable via the remote over a decent range. The volume is unimpressive; even with my iPhone and the speaker system both set at max volume, it's not as loud as I sometimes want ... which means it's way too quiet for most people.In summary: this Sharp speaker is attractive, easy to use and meets my basic audio needs. But audiophiles will want to look elsewhere.

This pen is a combination of four colored inks (with fine-point writing tips) plus a mechanical pencil and eraser.As with ink-jet printers, I'll likely run through some ink colors faster than others, but they're apparently refillable (I couldn't locate refills but maybe it's because the product is new?) and the pen's casing seems durable for refillable use. It's an attractive, good-quality pen. What tips it toward a 5-star rating is its comfort grip -- not the "squishable" gel grip of some pens; more a "traction" gel grip that keeps the pen from slipping while I'm writing -- but what tips it back to 4 stars is the high price. I'll enjoy using it, and I'd get another if the price were lower, if I confirmed single-color refills were available, and if it were available with medium-point pen tips.

I've used Paul Mitchell Soft Spray for a decade, it's the only hair spray with a fragrance light enough (essentially: none) to please me. And I've used pump-action sprays instead of aerosols for longer than that because chlorofluorocarbon (CFC) propellants were environmental hazards. But now there are new propellants and I was interested to try this product.Pros: I like it. It's light in scent (again, essentially no lingering fragrance), and although there's a "crispness" to my hair immediately after use, that softens while still maintaining good hold all day. I wash my hair every other day, and a huge plus to this product is that my hair continues to smell fresh on Day 2 (vs. my previous spray).Cons: It's expensive. And I remain conflicted about the aerosol aspect. On the one hand, I'd forgotten how much I like an aerosol -- the spray is so fast and sheer. On the other hand, this product's label lists a hydrofluorocarbon (HFC) propellant, which is better than a CFC but not without risk (it doesn't destroy the ozone layer but does increase greenhouse gases). And, unlike a pump spray, the pressurized metallic canister is not refillable. I'll use the product until it's gone and update this review with final impressions about cost and quality.

I've embarked on some WWI reading during this year that begins the centennial commemoration of The War to End All Wars. So far, it's been enlightening and satisfying (for example: fiction such as All Quiet on the Western Front; nonfiction like The Proud Tower and The Last of the Doughboys; and tangential nonfiction like The Great Influenza). But it also feels overwhelming and sort of scattershot, and I began to want to map a loose plan for my reading -- areas of interest where I want to delve deeper, and especially areas of my ignorance where I want to learn the basics.I discovered this book at about that time, and although I've been neutral-to-negative about other Dummies volumes, I decided to see if this one would at least give me an overview that could direct my reading elsewhere. It's given me so much more than that!My complaints about the Dummies series go back some years: 1) the numbing repetition (with little actual content) and 2) the silly (disruptive) tone. Regarding the first, this book is organized like others in the series, so there is that necessary redundancy (see? I didn't sense it as repetition) between the overview sections and the detail sections. And regarding the second, there's silliness here only in the headings that break up the text. The narrative itself completely respects the reader and the topic; it's light and conversational (engaging, never boring) and the flow isn't interrupted by inane asides. Written by a British historian, there's a LOT of content -- the world before, during and after the war, through international lenses of politics, military, technology and society/culture. It's much more a complete treatment than the overview I expected. Highly recommended.

I use both manual and powered toothbrushes because they seem to get at my teeth in slightly different ways, plus a powered brush is a fun change. I still love the Oral B I bought 15+ years ago, but it uses rechargeable batteries and they no longer hold a good charge. So I've been eyeing other toothbrushes like the Spinbrush and was excited to try this one.Pros: I like that it uses regular batteries (2 AA); they're more convenient than needing to keep the rechargables charged. The unit is easy to hold and it's easy to remove the brush head for thorough rinsing.Cons: The motor is louder than the Oral B; the brush head seems to buzz more than actually move (I get less of a fresh feel after brushing); and the brush head is HUGE (not just the bristles but also the frame; very difficult to get around the back of my upper molars). These aren't dealbreakers, but I'll definitely look for a smaller brush head when it's time for a replacement.

This is an excellent anatomical atlas of the human body, lushly visualized through large, full-color medical illustrations (not photographs). It's organized by 11 functional systems (e.g. skeletal, muscular, cardiovascular, reproductive), each section beginning with a system overview and then delving deeper -- in Dorling Kindersley (DK) style, meaning mostly images and minimal text. That said ("functional systems"), keep in mind that this is a book on *anatomy* (structure), not *physiology* (function), and that it's geared to a lay or student audience.I have a special interest in the digestive system so I turned to that section first, and was discouraged that the first page I read defined the appendix as a "dead-end tube attached to the last part of the large intestine, with no function in modern humans." Actually, it's attached to the *first* part of the large intestine, and its function is *unknown* but thought to be involved in the immune system. Both of those errors are corrected on a subsequent page, but that put me on high alert for other errors; I'm happy to report that I didn't find more.An Index and a significant Glossary complete the book. The illustrations are never morbid; rather, they inspire profound awe at how fabulously everything comes together.*NOTE for readers who have other anatomy books and don't want to duplicate: the cover and copyright pages note that this book's content was previously published in "The Complete Human Body."

"...monotonously falls the rain. It falls on our heads and on the heads of the dead up in the line, on the body of the little recruit with the wound that is so much too big for his hip; it falls on Kemmerich's grave; it falls in our hearts.""At school nobody ever taught us how to light a cigarette in a storm of rain, nor how a fire could be made with wet wood -- nor that it is best to stick a bayonet in the belly because there it doesn't get jammed, as it does in the ribs."[About guarding Russian prisoners-of-war:] "A word of command has made these silent figures our enemies; a word of command might transform them into our friends. [...] I take out my cigarettes, break each one in half and give them to the Russians. They bow to me and then light the cigarettes. Now red points glow in every face. They comfort me; it looks as though there were little windows in dark village cottages saying that behind them are rooms full of peace."----------I recently read this classic (anti-)war novel for the first time, and chose this Random House digital edition because I wanted reliable formatting. Narrated by 19-year-old Paul Baumer, a German soldier serving in the trenches near the front during WWI, it's brutal, thoughtful and illustrative not only regarding battle and the dead but how the living are forever changed.I can envision where it inspired other war novels (that first quote above reminds me of the opening of The Things They Carried), and while Catch-22 remains my favorite (hilarious, heartbreaking, imaginative, complex), this is outstanding and so much more accessible. Recommended for everyone ... even urged.

When I subscribed to Cook's Illustrated magazine, I read each issue cover to cover, enjoying every bit of deconstructing a recipe or technique and evaluating commercial pantry staples and cookery tools. And now I devoured every word of this big volume on the science behind 50 fundamental concepts essential to good cooking.Each concept is presented as an 8-16 page chapter that begins with the science/theory behind a technique, followed by a cooking experiment that tests the science, and then much further exploration of the concept via at least half-a-dozen recipes (for generally familiar, delicious, foods). Note: this is not an "illustrated," coffee-table book; there are some graphics to help describe the science, and some simple photos of experimental results, but this is a text-heavy book -- lush with information not visuals.The topics mostly concern meat, eggs, vegetables and baking. All of it feels solid -- the reinforcement of concepts I already know about, the confidence to try techniques that are new to me, and many "aha" moments about the whys behind the science, some of which come to mind even now:* when to cut a food with the grain vs. against the grain (answer: onions and tough meats, respectively; cutting across cells breaks them, resulting in a too-pungent onion but a more tender meat);* the difference between baking soda (which reacts with an acid in the recipe to create CO2 bubbles that leaven) vs. baking powder (which contains baking soda + a powdered acid) vs. double-acting baking powder (which contains a second acid that works later, in the oven's heat) -- and why you ever even need separate baking soda (it leads to flavorful browning);* why adding eggs to a batter one at a time, and alternating the addition of wet and dry ingredients, does matter (both cause ingredients to incorporate faster/better and prevent the over-mixing that toughens the batter);* whether to salt scrambled eggs before or after cooking (before: "Salt affects the electrical charge on the protein molecules in the eggs, reducing the tendency of the proteins to bond with each other. A weaker protein network means eggs are less likely to overcoagulate and will cook up tender, not tough.")If you have an opinion about Cook's Illustrated magazine, that will be your opinion of this book -- multiplied by 50 :) If you're unfamiliar with the magazine, I highly recommend using Amazon's "Look Inside" feature to browse the Table of Contents for the concepts/techniques covered, and then read the "First Pages" (which is "Concept 1: Gentle Heat Prevents Overcooking" and is representative of the book).Enthusiastically recommended!

On paper and in the hand, this product seems terrific. In use, it's okay: it does soften the bright sunlight, but it's clumsy.It's a ~17-in square roller shade made of black plastic-ish mesh, housed in a plastic tube. It mounts on a side car window via your choice of suction cups (included) directly onto the glass or hanging from hooks (included) placed over the top edge of the window. To use, you pull the shade down by hand to the desired length and secure it to the window there with an additional suction cup. When not in use, you can leave it down, or you can retract the shade into the housing by pushing the auto-rollup button and then either leave it in place at the top of the window or pull it off until the next use.In use, the pull-down/roll-up aspect works very well. (*I definitely advise caution/supervision with the auto roll-up because it really snaps up the shade fast and will bump anything in the way.*) In use, the mounting features work less well. I'm in Chicago, and the suction cups didn't adhere to the window for more than literally a second until just now when the air (and the window) have some warmth to them. So instead, I use the clips to mount the housing over the top of the window. But they're a little too thick for the window to close easily and fully, and I fear that forcing it will eventually damage the window seal or mis-align the window track or stress the power motor. So that means the window stays open a tiny bit, which is disappointing. Plus, because the suction cup at the bottom of the shade doesn't adhere to the cold window, the shade hangs loose and flaps around every time I speed up/slow down/change direction. That's a dealbreaker during the cold months.

I've been happily using the MarBlue Vassen cover on my Kindle Paperwhite at home, but have been hesitant to travel with it because its velour-ish interior seems like it would be difficult to clean after use with dirty hands or in rustic environments. So I was interested to see this cover, and thrilled to verify that its plastic-coated canvas exterior and neoprene-ish interior can be easily and thoroughly cleaned. It's exactly what I was looking for.Like many other covers, this one has four corner elastic bands that hold the Kindle extremely securely, a front cover that folds back for one-handed holding, and a supple elastic band along the side edge to hold the cover closed (or open). This unit also has a slide pocket on the inside front cover; I wasn't sure what I'd use it for until the moment I loaded my Kindle and picked it up, and my index finger slid right into the pocket and made holding the device effortless. The stitching is perfect, and other than having a slightly higher price and not having an auto-wake feature, this cover has all advantages and no disadvantages; my only quibble is that the "Jonathan Adler" logo on the inside could be more discreet or attractive.My cover is in the "Bargello Waves" pattern and I may order another in the "Turquoise Mandala." Highly recommended.

I'm an organized packer (think Jack Nicholson in "As Good as It Gets") and these packing cubes are fabulous. I've used these 3-piece sets for two years in three colors (aqua, denim and red paisley), plus the Shoe Bag and the pair of Shoe Sleeves. The top three benefits: 1) they organize clothing (by whole outfits or by types of clothing, e.g. shirts or pants vs underwear/socks); 2) they "contain" the clothing, keeping things folded neatly instead of wrinkled from sloshing around loose in the suitcase; 3) the different colors can visually differentiate whose clothing it is.I use them on every trip and usually live out of the suitcase. But I just returned from a cruise, where you really have no choice but to unpack and use the stateroom drawers, and these cubes were even better there: unpacking took about 5 minutes (I just transferred the cubes from the suitcase to the drawers); the cubes kept everything neat in the drawers; and the cubes provided a hygienic layer against direct contact between my clothes and the public drawer.After each trip, I simply wash them with the rest of the laundry, air them dry, and they're ready for the next trip. I highly, highly, highly recommend!

Soon after I'd enjoyed Waldman's 2009 essay collection, Bad Mother, I heard an interview where she characterized her writing philosophy not exactly as "write what you know" but "write what you *want* to know." Walking the talk, she then described the genesis of her next writing project: she'd Googled keywords of topics that interested her: "Hungary" (she wanted to visit a friend there and liked the excuse of researching a writing project) + "the Holocaust" (she's Jewish and hadn't written about it) + "art" (she was interested) = "a novel about the Hungarian Gold Train at the end of WWII." I was thrilled to learn that she's seen her idea through to publication here."[On the train were] 1,500 cases of watches, jewelry, and silver, 5,250 carpets, thousands of coats and stoles and muffs of mink, fox, and ermine, crates of microscopes and cameras, porcelain and glassware, furniture, books and manuscripts and tapestries, gold coins and bullion, the few remaining precious gems, the liturgical objects, the stamp collections and silver-backed hairbrushes, all the items, valuable and less so, that constituted the wealth of the Jews of Hungary, 437,402 of whom had been deported to Auschwitz over the course of just 56 days almost exactly a year before."A bit like Nicole Krauss's Great House, this novel is written as a series of novellas linked by a shared item, in this case a jeweled pendant. In the first, the pendant is discovered by an American army officer charged with securing the contents of the Gold Train in 1945 Salzburg amid displaced persons and the aftermath of war. In the second, that officer's grand-daughter works with a gray-market art dealer in 2013 Budapest to trace ownership of the pendant. And finally, that owner and her life are explored in 1913 Budapest.I had a couple false starts with this novel; the first section felt wooden and I feared that Waldman's "Googled" premise wasn't going to work. But near the end of that section, she captured me and I felt a story begin and then get better and better. She writes well, the material is always intellectually interesting (the aftermath of war, especially regarding Hungarian Jews; art history; feminism and suffrage), and eventually it also becomes emotionally engaging. And enjoyable! -- in the second section there's a nod to a fairy tale that's a blatant chuckle between writer and reader, and the third section, narrated by a Freudian analyst, has much amusing satire. And the story is important: in the end, it's clear that the value of the stolen contents of the Gold Train is insignificant compared with the exterminated human potential.

On the one hand, this book is, itself, as â€œnice {a} little placeâ€ to spend some time as the title promises of a day at Chicagoâ€™s Wrigley Field. George Will, a Cub fan from age 7, compiles an altogether pleasant -- funny, optimistic, smart -- collection of stories and statistics about the history of baseball, its players and its playing fields.I recommend it ... as long as you go in knowing what is my â€œon the other handâ€: that much of the content is about baseball in general, not the Cubs or Wrigley Field specifically. Also on the other hand, is a wholly frustrating lack of organization to the bookâ€™s content -- the narrative jumps all over the place in time and topic. Still, over the 200 pages, a bit of Cubs/Wrigley history does accumulate. I especially appreciated the look at the business side of baseball and attendance; the lack of standardized field specifications and how teams use their fields to their advantages; and how antiquated Wrigley has become in light of the amenities that fans (and players) expect at a ballpark (its newest owners are beginning to remedy that).In the end, I was disappointed that this is not a satisfying history of Wrigley Field ... and I was entertained and informed by what it is.

We had our sump pump replaced on a muddy day and I had the opportunity to try out these wipes on the clean-up of the basement floor and stairs afterward.They're smaller than I'd expected but still a decent size (approximately 9x9-in square), and drier than I'd expected (but easily remedied with a little water). They're saturated with a cleaner, and the chemical scent is light (maybe because it had dried out a bit) and didn't linger too long after use. They're impressively strong -- a textured surface that scrubs well and a thick, toughly woven material that never tore or shredded even in use on my concrete basement floor -- and cleaned impressively well.My only negatives are one quibble (that they could be better perf-ed to tear more easily; I needed to use two hands and some strength), and one potential deal-breaker for future purchases (that they're manufactured in China, where unlabeled ingredients seem to pop into products; I was careful to wear gloves but that doesn't protect against something that may be airborne). I'll definitely use them on my outdoor furniture come spring.Other than feeling wary about the China aspect, I'd recommend these for tough and/or long cleaning jobs. They're more a disposable cloth than a wipe.

I was excited to see this book since I've enjoyed several others about cartooning and/or The New Yorker magazine (see some recommendations at the end of this review*). Here, Mankoff (cartoon editor at The New Yorker) writes a little about his life; a little about the history of magazine cartoons; about work at The New Yorker; about launching The Cartoon Bank of cartoon art.And he writes a lot about cartooning (he calls cartoons "drawn jokes") and cartoonists, including the basics of humor and where creativity comes from. For example, there are "word firsters" vs "doodle firsters" (cartoonists whose ideas come from, respectively, words or images), and there are cartoonists who riff off those who came before (the so-called collective cartoon conscious) and those who are inspired by real life (e.g. Roz Chast).The book's title comes from Mankoff's best-known cartoon, the caption of which has become a cultural aphorism. His best line in the book has also become an aphorism to memoir fans like me: "[Y]ou can't spell memoir without the *moi*" (though he does veer away from himself often enough that I think the *moi* here is almost as much cartoonists in general as him specifically). He sprinkles hundreds of cartoons throughout the text to illustrate and entertain, and I enjoyed every page of it ... which is satisfyingly long at ~300 pages and I would have read 1000 more.* If you liked any of the following, you'll love Mankoff's book (and vice versa):The Naked Cartoonist -- Mankoff's previous book on cartooning and creativity;The Rejection Collection and Blown Covers -- about cartoons and artwork that *didn't* make the cut into The New Yorker;On the Money -- more serious: cartoons that reflect nearly a century of commentary on social economics; andMy Mistake -- Daniel Menaker's recent memoir that includes his decades as editor at The New Yorker.

This package contains three triple-blade razors plus one trimmer-cap -- essentially a tiny comb that snaps onto the head of the razor and lifts hair so that the razor can cut it.The razor itself works very well, shaves closely and without razor burn or bumps later. While I always nick myself during the first use of any disposable razor, I did not with this one -- maybe it's the blades or the angle of the head or how the handle is shaped to be held -- and that was great.As for trimming, I've been using a Schick Quattro TrimStyle, which has a razor at one end and a battery-powered trimmer at the other, and it trims very well. But I wouldn't mind doing without a battery gadget so I was interested in this Bic. Unfortunately, the Bic functioned more as a "thinner" than a trimmer -- after going over the area numerous times at different angles, the hair was definitely sparser but what remained was as long as before using the trimmer, and there was no way to customize the length to individual preference. I'll stay with the Schick for trimming.

I got this for my 11yr old who is fairly tall and while it's a little big around the torso, it was perfect with the length of the arms. It's going to be a cold winter and this is pretty warm. The color is actually a little lighter than it is here on screen but that doesn't detract from the quality of this jacket. The sherpa lining is all the way through, even through to the hood, so I know he's going to be warm. Once zipped up and the hood is on it really protects his head. Not like those jackets where you put the hood on and your ears are still exposed.Dickies did a great job manufacturing this jacket and I wouldn't hesitate to get another.

I have been using this for about 3 weeks now and I can say that this is about one of the better humidifier I've used in quite some time. Not only does it look great aesthetically wise but it has kept the air in my room nice and moist. In the winter we tend to dry out and we also tend to get lots of colds so I knew I needed something and I needed something that also didn't take up a lot of room. This fit the bill perfectly. I have been sleeping so much better at night knowing that this is working for me. I totally recommend getting this.

I was already an Xbox owner so this was a no-brainer for me. I originally had a Logitech controller which was ok for my computer games but to be honest I've already preferred the feel of the Xbox controller over any other. Even my Playstation controller doesn't compare. If you've been using the Xbox controller for quite some time this is no different. The good thing about this is that it also works for my Xbox One as a wired controller and for my computer so it's a 2-in-1 hit! I've had no issues playing games and the preset settings actually work great for me with most games.

I have a few Invicta watches and this doesn't disappoint. The stainless steel band makes it look expensive. The watch face however didn't really impress me with the dual tone look. Will still make a great Christmas gift for those who love watches. Came nicely boxed so you won't have to worry about presentation. It's only water resistant up to 165 feet so if you're trying to buy this for a professional diver who goes further than this, then I may say get something different. This is a great beginner pro diver watch though.

I've always loved the skeleton style watches and this is certainly no exception. I also own a few other Lucien Piccard watches and they have all stood the test of time. This is truly a beauty and it feels really solid, not like the cheap watches you might buy at the mall counters. I do have to say that the retail price is kinda stretching it a bit but I would certainly pay the price that Amazon lists it for with no problem. Makes a great Christmas gift, birthday gift or even think Father's Day. Presentation is truly there in a nice gift box. You really only need a bag.We didn't have problems adjusting the watch as most people seemed to have but I did take off a start because the "leather" band while it may be leather doesn't seem like it will hold up over time. I'm not a watch maker but I can truly say that this is one amazing time piece and you won't regret getting it.

As huge Assassin's Creed fans we just had to have this cane sword. After all the boys were Assassin's Creed characters for Halloween and we're currently playing Syndicate as I type this. Now first of all you must remember that this is a TOY. It's not a real cane sword but a replicate and a nice looking one too. It's made entirely of plastic but it's pretty sturdy. The hidden blade in the handle is a nice touch but we had a bit of problem with the one at the end of the cane coming out without you "activating" it.This would make a great prop if you have the costume for Halloween or even Cosplay and even would be great if you're a collector of the Assassin's Creed memorabilia. The boys love it and so does my husband who put it together. Came in three pieces and was totally easy to put together even without the piece of paper instruction that came with it.I took off a star because I wish the construction was a little better allowing you to use it as a real cane or that we didn't have that defective hidden blade problem. Other than that it's a great piece of Assassins Creed product.

I blog so that means I take about 50 photos just so I can get 1 decent photo of my subject who is 3. That also means I have a LOT of photos on my computer and the more photos on my computer the less space I have to do other things. This not makes it easy for me download and store my photos but now I can free up much needed space on my laptop. I was able to connect to my MAC with no problems and transferring was a breeze. I've always loved how easy SanDisk makes it easy to do things for even the amateur and this is no exception. For a newbie as myself it was super easy to do the transfer. It does come with the included cable and once again very easy to use. Did I mention how EASY it is! Definitely recommend getting this.

I've always wanted a dehydrator and I've had this for quite some time to really write my review. First let me say that this does come in a big box but it's not as heavy as you would think. I haven't yet used it to dehydrate meats so I can't really write about my experience on that but I have done quite a few fruits and I'll have to say that you'll NEVER buy dried fruits again.
