For my brewing, I stay in the 200-202 range typically during the four minute brew cycle. *** Note - please Google "SCAA recommended coffee brewing temperatures" for some background on correct temps to brew / extract coffee**- Depress the plunger SLOWLY when it is time, doing it too fast will cause sediment. Also, if the plunger seems to get "stuck", lift it ever so slightly, then depress again!- Fill the water level BELOW the spout depression / line in the carafe when filling for brewing / steeping. This will help guarantee less grounds in your finished product.To summarize - now that you have spent the $$ on a top of the line French Press, consider getting a good grinder that can consistently grind on a coarse setting without a lot of "fines" in the grind; considerr purchasing a good temperature probe (like a Thermapen to check your temperatures of different components throughout the process to find what needs tweaking; consider getting fresh coffee beans. This will give you an even better cup in the end... also, search the web for you tube videos, etc on different processes, find out what works best for you. Once you experience a "perfectly" executed cup of press coffee, you will be hooked!! ;-)Thanks for reading, and best of luck in your choice!

How did I go so many years without this stuff in my shop, or in my car, or in my backpack? Every day I think of new ways to use this stuff.... for instance, today - I was filling a small spray bottle with bug repellent for my backpack, and I was concerned about the top coming unscrewed slightly causing a potential leak. Well, I pulled out my clear version of this same tape, and wrapped it around the top where it screws on, now I am confident it will hold.Yesterday, my weedeaters foam grip was cracking splitting - out comes the black Silicone tape to the rescue to provide a new grip for the handle. The day before, my tent pole plastic end cap was not staying on the pole, again, Silicone tape to the rescue.Then, when I was weedeating my lawn, I noticed my trusty outdoor electrical cord took a hit with either the weedeater or hedger, and had a couple of chunks of the outer sheathing missing. I used my Xtreme tape (in the Red color to match the cord ;-)) and it has been holding for weeks and about 4 uses, I don't see why it won't hold for a very long time.Next, both my backpacking and camping tent poles have vinyl or plastic ends on the poles - and after time these loosen up, want to come off and worse yet get lost! Well, not only does Xtreme tape fuse the tent pole ends to the pole, it also reinforces them and makes them stronger and more durable...And then the big test - my garden hose had a pin-hole leak in it, and I applied this tape to it. The key is to make sure you extend the tape on either side of the hole by a few inches (I did three inches on each side of the hole) - and then make sure you stretch the tape very well and evenly around the hose. Also, make sure the hose is on a flat surface, and try to avoid flexing / bending the hose while taping, keep it as straight as possible. Also, give it at least two windings (not just one). It is working fine, if there are any issues I will update.You get it. This stuff is amazing. Once you wind it on itself it sticks like white on rice. Its resiliency is quite good - it is very tough and it will not come unwound unless you intentionally start to pull on the seam. Then, it will rip instead of lose its contact... it is that sticky to itself.The list goes on.... like I said, I keep finding more uses for it daily.I would say just get a roll, and keep it around. You will be amazed at the number of applications this stuff will satisfy.... an easy five star!!Thanks for reading.

Hario claims that the design of it's coffee drippers sets it apart from the competitors - and that the raised helical grooves combined and the larger opening at the bottom result in a better cup.  Now, I am not an coffee engineer ;-), and I am not going to attempt to explain how this may or may not result in a better cup - but I will say that the Hario V60 has become my go to pour over dripper, and I have since given my others away!I currently own the V60 in both the 02 (one glass, one platic) and 01 (palstic only) sizes - I use the 01 and 02 in plastic for my backpacking trips, as it is always nice to have good coffee on the trail, and the plastic versions only weigh 2 ounces and are a lightweight method to make superb coffee in the backcountry!  ALl you need other the dripper is a light paper filter - along with some coffee (pre-ground of course).  I use the glass version at home. I like pour over as an option when I want to be able to choose how much coffee I want instead of having to make full pot, a full press, or something different than a shot of espresso.As most know, good coffee is more about the process of how you make it - along with using fresh ground coffee, and brewing at the right temperature for the right amount of time - there is a lot to consider and pay attention to if you are looking for the best cup - but if you take the time to learn it and experiment, you will be rewarded.  Definitely take the time to search / research how others are making their coffee to supplement your process - you will find what works the best for you, and when you get better coffee, it will only serve to reproduce that cup over and over again. It is kind of fun!Some tips to using the Hario:- Make sure and pre-wet the filter inside the cone before putting your ground coffee in.  I use hot / boiling water with my cup underneath - this serves many purposes - first it pre-heats the cup.  Second, it forms the filter to the dripper.  Third, it takes any paper taste out of the filter.- Grind your coffee on the finer side of the drip range - if it is too coarse, the larger hole will result in the coffee draining too quickly through the dripper, and not interacting with the grounds long enough.  Experiement, and when you achieve a slow drip, and the taste is not too bitter or sour, you have nailed the grind.- Pre-infuse your grinds before brewing.  What I do is first make a small divot / hole gently in the middle of your grounds after pouring them in the dripper. Pour enough water over your grounds to soak the coffee,just to the point where it begins to drip - then stop pouring and wait 30-60 seconds.  For me, if I am making 14 oz of finished coffee as my target, I preinfuse with about 2 oz of water.- Pour SLOWLY, and do it in two or three phases.  I pour about 4-5 oz of water in slowly, let it drip through, and then do it again. After two - three passes, I am done.  I never pour the entire contents of my water in all at the same time.- Try to pour water in that is between 195 and 205 degrees - this range is the optimal temperature range for extracting / brewing coffee.  Google SCAA or optimal brewing temp for coffee for more details.  I utilize a Bonavita variable temperature kettle for my process, it makes keeping the water in the right range very easy.- Some of the ratios I use is 27 grams of coffee for 14oz of finished product, or 19 grams for 10 oz finished product.Try to drink the coffee in the first 10-15 minutes - coffee always tastes the best when it does not sit for any length of time....I would recommend the Hario V60 to anyone looking at trying pour over - it is cheap, has a proven design, is easy to use, easy to clean up, and makes one great cup of coffee.Thanks for reading!

I have found this a versatile tool, and get a lot of use out of it.  Granted, the 600 grit does not make this a finishing grit / sharpener for the finest edge on your best knives, but that is not why I bought it.Here are some of the ways I use this sharpener:- The thin / low profile of this sharpener make it a great tool for gardening tools with curved edges.  My flat sharpeners struggle with the tight confines and curved edges of pruners, shears and other cutting tools.  However, this tool is an excellent choice for those tools - between the flat spot on the round edge and the rounded portion, this makes quick work of my garden cutting tools.- Touching up my fishing hooks and lures - I throw this in my tackle box to give my hooks and lures a new point when needed.  The groove in the rounded side makes quick work of hooks and lures.-  For hiking / backpacking - this tool is lightweight and low profile, and is a good choice hiking, camping and even backpacking for a lightweight tool when you need something to touch up a knife edge, smooth off the corner of a dinged tent pole, or anything where a metal burr needs to be knocked down.- For touching up a serrated edge - the pointed end of this was made for re-honing serrated edges, and I use it for my Spyderco serrated edge, or even for the first pass on my serrated kitchen knives.  The pointed end also works good in tight spots, like low clearance pruners and cutters where it is tough to get other sharpening tools in a tight spot.This sharpener is small enough to stick in a day pack, clip in your pocket while doing chores or on the go. I would recommend this sharpener to anyone looking for something small and compact that needs a sharpener where others might not do the job, or when you want something that packs nicely.Thanks for reading.

I bought this same product 4 to 5 years ago, and was very pleased with the contents, the quality of the outer bag, and the quality of the inner compartment bag.  Well, unfortunately, when I repurchased this recently, it did not match up to the quality of what I purchased previously - read on for details.Since our backpacking party has grown to 3-4 people consistently, I decided to purchase a second kit, mainly for a second bag / contents that I could customize.  I had a choice of getting a bigger first aid kit / bag, and abandoning the smaller Ultralight 5  kit / bag I bought a few years back (same model as this one) - or getting a second Ultralight 5 kit and splitting two smaller kits between multiple backpacks. I chose the latter - namely, buy a second smaller kit like this one, and split it between multiple packs.  (any backpacker can relate - split up the weight when you have the luxury of multiple people in the party).When I received this kit, it was immediately apparent that this was not of the same quality of the  previous Ultralight 5kit I bought.  To summarize my findings and opinion, here is what I found:  -  The outer bag is thinner, not as durable and just plain not as well made as the previous version I bought a few years back.  The bag from the previous version is a joy to use - and has held together perfectly, very well made.  -  The quality of the zipper on the bag is awful - not even close to the zipper on the previous version I own.  This zipper gets stuck, and is just plain hard to open or close without fits and starts. Terrible.  -  The inner compartment bag has a very poor seal, and just does not stay shut.  Realize this inner bag is what provides your waterproofing, so I have VERY low confidence that my kit will be protected from water.  -  THe quality of the medical contents - the packaging, appearance, everything about the contents just looks cheap and just not of the same level of quality of what I already owned.  The bandaids seem cheaper, for example.Like many things these days, the same product you bought years ago has been cheapened, with corners cut to save cost and increase margins.  Personally, I find this very disappointing, especially when it is in the area of first aid, or something you use in case of injury or emergency.  WRONG place to cut corners and skimp!  Shame on Adventure Medical - I know I will look elsewhere next time.Thanks for reading.

The Evernew soft bottle has an edge over the Platypus soft bottles in that the cap stays attached to the bottle when you drink out of it, or fill it. I own most every type and size of the Platypus soft sided bottles - from the 16 oz to the 2 Liter versions, including the Plus bottles! I also own both the Push / Pull and Closure caps on the Platypus - and the issue with both is that it is possible to lose them - especially the closure cap, as when you take it off to fill or drink, it can get misplaced. The push / pull cap at least stays on when you drink,but it has to be removed to fill it.That is where these Evernew bottles shine - the cap stays attached, and it is virtually impossible to lose it! But there are other nice features to the Evernew bottles that make them shine over the Platy bottles IMHO. For instance, the shock cord that is attached to the bottle - this allows you to roll up the bottle and secure it for portable storage. With the Platypus bottle, you need a rubber band, or a separate cord, or you have to supply your own shock cord (if you have it). The shock cord coming attached to the Evernew is a nice touch.Another bonus - the Evernew bottle threads directly on to the Sawyer Mini Filter, or the Sawyer Squeeze Filter! This means that when the crummy Sawyer bottles break (and they will), you can employ these as either your dirty reservoir, or clean reservoir. These bottles come in sizes up to 2 Liters, so if you need a bigger container, you can get one!In addition - I like the feel / durability of the Evernew bottle more than the Platypus. They stand up on their own better with liquid in them, have a stiffer feel, and for some reason they seem to dry faster than the Platypus when empty.And finally, and most importantly - these are priced well for the different sizes if you shop around. Considering I got this size for $8, and the 2 Liter size for $10, it would be tough to beat those prices for the quality you get.I would recommend these bottles to anyone looking for something compatible with Sawyer filters, or for just a standalone soft drinking bottle.Thanks for reading!

There are better sharpeners out there, and there are most certainly worse, but if you are trying to find a good sharpener for a decent price, these might be a contender.  This particular sharpener can quickly give a fine / sharp point, and are a good utility sharpener for utilitarian tasks.  I keep one(or two) in my woodshop, one in my carport near my chop / miter saw.  Note that these create almost too fine a point, but it is definitely sharp and it does it fast.  So if you are looking for a "tougher", less thin point, there might be better options.I have also given one each to my sons in high school for their backpacks - they have a Kum sharpener for their desk, and one of these for their pack.  THe sharpeners at school are not always maintained and sharp, so having these on hand is helpful for them.As of writing this review, these are priced at close to $5. I paid $2,79 for mine, and for that, it is a good balance of price and quality.For what I use these for, the size, shape, durability are perfect. I can drop then in my shirt or pants pocket easily, set them on a workbench... overall a good sharpener for the money.Thanks for reading.

What you keep reading is true - why pay more for cables  when you don't have to - and given the quality of these cables, and the fact you get TWO of them for $8 is precisely why I bought them!I am not going to go into any more detail except to say that Mediabridge has done a good job in most cases of offering cables that give a great level of quality for the price - and offering many an alternative to those cable makers that used to basically rip us off!  (you know who I am talking about).Thanks for reading.

We carry at least two of these on every backpacking trip, sometimes even three on longer trips.  We hike in groups of three or four, and most every one has one in their pack.  The uses for these are MANY, here are a few:- As a large "Dirty" reservoir for our Sawyer Squeeze or Sawyer Mini filters when we want filtered water "on the go".  These thread directly onto the Sawyer filter threads, and fit perfectly.  Having a 2 liter source for the dirty water means less dipping and transfer operations - and these are much more durable and user-friendly than the bottles Sawyer sells.- As a "Clean" reservoir for filtered water / storage when using our gravity filter in camp.  We don't hang our clean water reservoir, we only hang the dirty, and use something like this to catch the clean water.  Sometimes we fill two of these when we are setting up camp to have water for cooking , washing up, etc.  What makes this a decent storage reservoir is that you can put a push/pull cap on it and be able to have controlled and measured pouring...-  As a reserve reservoir for extra water when we might be away from water for a couple of days - when we know we may be away from water for a day or so, we fill our 3L bladders first, then fill this as a reserve in our pack.  Note these are not as thick as a bladder, so store / carry in your pack with care, and keep it protected.I have been using one of these bottles for two years now, over multiple trips, and it is still in serviceable / working condition.  Thus the durability of these bottles is not bad, and they last if you care them.If I had to think of any "Cons" for these bottles, or what I don't like about them:- It takes forever for them to dry after cleaning....the small opening and large volume means you have to find a nice place to store them for 2-3 days as they dry.  I live in AZ, which is very dry, I can only imagine how long it would take to dry in a humid climate!  I only clean these when we get home, I don't ever attempt drying them out on the trail.- The caps are not attached, and can get lost.  This is one of the big reasons I started using the Evernew soft bottles - the Evernew bottles have the cap attached to the bottle!!-  You have to carry a separate rubber band or shock cord to roll them up. Again, the Evernew bottle has a pigtail attached to facilitate rolling them up, where the Playtpus does not.Note that I recently have been alternating these bottles with the Evernew soft bottles - those are a decent alternative to these, and are priced in the same ballpark.  I purchased these Platypus bottles for $9.99, and the Evernew 2L for the same amount.A couple of tips and tricks:- I carry two caps for these - one closure cap, and a push / pull cap.  I do this for multiple reasons, the first one being in case I lose a cap. The Platy caps are not attached to the bottle like the Evernew, and could get lost.  The second reason is that if I am storing the reservoir as a backup water source in my pack, I don't want the tall push / pull cap protruding and screw on the closure cap.  On the flip side, if I am using it for water storage in camp, I use the push / pull cap for easy dispensing.- I got some 1/16th inch shock cord and made a permanent pigtail attached to the bottle so you can easily rollup up the bottle for compact storage.  This is copying what the Evernew bottle did with theirs, and idea which I really liked. In fact, I have other Platy soft bottles, and retrofitted this pigtail on those too!!  If you are wondering what I mean, see the picture.  The Platy is on the left with the added pigtail, and the Evernew is on the right with the stock pigtail.Thanks for reading.

Believe the reviews and the hype about the Para Military 2 --- the size, weight, feel and blade quality of this knife have made it an EDC classic! I had considered purchasing this knife for a few years before finally taking the plunge - now, I have been EDC'ing this knife since the day it arrived, and it is one fine knife that holds a keen edge, and holds it very well. I am really beginning to appreciate the S30V steel on the PM 2. S30V it is a very high quality knife steel!  I liked it so much, I bought both the plain edge and black blade versions of the knife!!  I like the black blade as much as the silver one - at first I was uncertain if the black blade would show scratches more - but after light use it appears to be a very durable coating.  I have read it will show signs of wear over time and use, so I don't expect the black coating to look new forever.I own four other Spyderco's - the Paramilitary 2 Silver Blade, Police Stainless, a Delica FRN and a Lil' Matriarch - and all have a lot of use between home, work, camping, hiking, backpacking, etc. But, the next backpacking trip will have this knife at my side, I enjoy the size and action of this knife a lot. It is very light for its size at 3.8 oz, and it has a very good feeling in the hand with the G10 handle. The balance is very good and most importantly it cuts like a dream. The locking mechanism has a good "snap" to it when opening, and it has just the right amount of stiffness on the action where it opens very smoothly.Owning the Delica with a 3" blade and the Police with the 4" blade makes me realize how perfect the 3.5" blade of the PM 2 is for my hand size. The Delica always felt a little small and I carried mainly for its light weight.... likewise, the Police always felt a tad big, and heavy due to the all stainless construction. Then again, the Police was never an EDC for these reasons, I typically keep that for around the house duties.I am not a big fan of the blade release / locking mechanism on the PM 2, but that is a minor concern and does not even come close to outweighing all the positives about this knife.I liked this knife so much that I also ordered the Camo with the black blade - it is backordered and may take a few months to get it - but it will be worth the wait. I look forward to passing these knives on to my sons' some day....I highly recommend this knife..... Thanks for reading.EDIT: For those concerned about the number of ParaMilitary 2 fakes floating around out there, I thought I would add a few sentences...The first paramilitary 2 I purchased was sold / shipped by Amazon directly, and arrived with the box taped on both ends. (this was the plain edge, non-black version).  This gave me initial cause for concern, as the Spyderco factory does NOT tape the box (I called Spyderco and they verified that). I still have not found who taped the box, whether it is Amazon, or perhaps a 3rd party that might be supplying Amazon (note again, I called Spyderco directly, and they stated definitively they do NOT tape the boxes). Also, even though my first box was taped shut, the knife had definitely been used and handled previously - perhaps a return? I called Amazon, expressed my concern, and they sent a replacement out - which was brand new, never used. However, the box on the replacement was also taped... so my guess is Amazon is taping the boxes shut. The tape job is professional, uses rounded corners and is well done, but just a heads up.Next - as far as real vs fake - I spent a lot of time checking the knife I received from Amazon (both of them) and I am 100% confident that these are authentic. I checked all the known issues with the fakes, and none of them exist here.... this is an authentic Spyderco, so at the time of writing this, the current stock sold by Amazon looks good. Just don't be alarmed if your box arrives taped on both ends... both of the PM2's I purchased Fulfilled by Amazon were taped on both ends.

What more can I say other than I like the White filters more than the Brown filters - I think the Brown filters are imparting just a tiny bit of paper / cardboard taste.Try this if you have both the white and brown filters on hand - set both of them up in a filter holder / cone, and then pre-wet both filters. Do you notice a slight "wet paper" smell emanating from the brown filter?  I do.Note that one of the keys to using these is to make sure you pre-wet them and let the water drip through them before loading with coffee and using them.  Also note these filters are custom made to fit the Hario 02 filter, and will not fit standard #2 coffee pour over cones.By the way, I am using these on both a glass and plastic Hario V02 cone filter, as probably expected.Thanks for reading.

How did I go so many years without this stuff in my shop, or in my car, or in my backpack? Every day I think of new ways to use this stuff.... for instance, today - I was filling a small spray bottle with bug repellent for my backpack, and I was concerned about the top coming unscrewed slightly causing a potential leak. Well, I pulled out my clear version of this same tape, and wrapped it around the top where it screws on, now I am confident it will hold.Yesterday, my weedeaters foam grip was cracking splitting - out comes the black Silicone tape to the rescue to provide a new grip for the handle. The day before, my tent pole plastic end cap was not staying on the pole, again, Silicone tape to the rescue.Then, when I was weedeating my lawn, I noticed my trusty outdoor electrical cord took a hit with either the weedeater or hedger, and had a couple of chunks of the outer sheathing missing. I used my Xtreme tape (in the Red color to match the cord ;-)) and it has been holding for weeks and about 4 uses, I don't see why it won't hold for a very long time.Next, both my backpacking and camping tent poles have vinyl or plastic ends on the poles - and after time these loosen up, want to come off and worse yet get lost! Well, not only does Xtreme tape fuse the tent pole ends to the pole, it also reinforces them and makes them stronger and more durable...And then the big test - my garden hose had a pin-hole leak in it, and I applied this tape to it. The key is to make sure you extend the tape on either side of the hole by a few inches (I did three inches on each side of the hole) - and then make sure you stretch the tape very well and evenly around the hose. Also, make sure the hose is on a flat surface, and try to avoid flexing / bending the hose while taping, keep it as straight as possible. Also, give it at least two windings (not just one). It is working fine, if there are any issues I will update.You get it. This stuff is amazing. Once you wind it on itself it sticks like white on rice. Its resiliency is quite good - it is very tough and it will not come unwound unless you intentionally start to pull on the seam. Then, it will rip instead of lose its contact... it is that sticky to itself.The list goes on.... like I said, I keep finding more uses for it daily.I would say just get a roll, and keep it around. You will be amazed at the number of applications this stuff will satisfy.... an easy five star!!Thanks for reading.

The Evernew soft bottle has an edge over the Platypus soft bottles in that the cap stays attached to the bottle when you drink out of it, or fill it.  I own most every type and size of the Platypus soft sided bottles - from the 16 oz to the 2 Liter versions, including the Plus bottles!  I also own both the Push / Pull and Closure caps on the Platypus - and the issue with both is that it is possible to lose them - especially the closure cap, as when you take it off to fill or drink, it can get misplaced.  The push / pull cap at least stays on when you drink,but it has to be removed to fill it.That is where these Evernew bottles shine - the cap stays attached, and it is virtually impossible to lose it!  But there are other nice features to the Evernew bottles that make them shine over the Platy bottles IMHO.  For instance, the shock cord that is attached to the bottle - this allows you to roll up the bottle and secure it for portable storage. With the Platypus bottle, you need a rubber band, or a separate cord, or you have to supply your own shock cord (if you have it).  The shock cord coming attached to the Evernew is a nice touch.Another bonus - the Evernew bottle threads directly on to the Sawyer Mini Filter, or the Sawyer Squeeze Filter!  This means that when the crummy Sawyer bottles break (and they will), you can employ these as either your dirty reservoir, or clean reservoir. These bottles come in sizes up to 2 Liters, so if you need a bigger container, you can get one!In addition - I like the feel / durability of the Evernew bottle more than the Platypus. They stand up on their own better with liquid in them, have a stiffer feel, and for some reason they seem to dry faster than the Platypus when empty.And finally, and most importantly - these are priced well for the different sizes if you shop around. Considering I got this size for $8, and the 2 Liter size for $10, it would be tough to beat those prices for the quality you get.I would recommend these bottles to anyone looking for something compatible with Sawyer filters, or for just a standalone soft drinking bottle.Thanks for reading!

A while back, I decided to give inserts like these Superfeet a try.... my feet are getting older (I am 52) and I still like to hike, backpack, do yardwork, stay on my feet doing woodworking, etc.  Since my arches are in the low - med range, I thought the best bet would be to try the Black Superfeet as they had close to the lowest arch.  Before continuing on, realize I bought these superfeet some time ago, and I am only writing this review after trying many different insoles of different make, model and manufacture.  I am drawing my conclusions on these and other insoles after literally months of trying, testing and giving them all a fair shake.In the end, and to make a long story short, I am not a big fan of custom shoe inserts - here's why:- In my humble opinion, overall shoe inserts basically take a good fitting pair of shoes and make them too small. When I try on shoes, due to the shape of my foot and the difficulty finding shoes that fit, I tend to spend a lot of time finding the right fit.  And I don't use shoe inserts when I shoe shop, most all of us try on shoes with the stock inserts that come with the shoe. Some theories suggest to buy a shoe a 1/2 size too big to accommodate for inserts later, but I don't subscribe to that theory. Other theories suggest bringing your chosen shoe inserts with you to try on shoes, but again, I don't have a chosen insert, so that does not work.-  The superfeet have a hard plastic heel section that has sharp edges / transitions. I have four pairs of leather lined hiking and work boots, and these plastic heel sections wreaked havoc with my $350 leather lined boots in short time I used them.  I can only imagine what they would do long term.-  Even the black superfeet with the low arch was uncomfortable on my arch after an hour. I tried different sizes make sure it was putting pressure on the correct part of my arch,with the same result.  Some say you have to "break them in" or they take "getting used to" etc, etc,- but one thing I have learned about shoes over the years - if it does not feel good right when you put it on, it is not going to get better.  Period.  Your feet know very quickly if a shoe or boot is right, and even stiff boots that need breaking in still feel good when new....I read a article a while back that everyone's feet are different, and all these companies selling off the shelf, one-size-fits-all inserts in theory should not fit anyone correctly out of the box!!!  Stands to reason. And the makers who claim that there inserts are heat treatable and "mold to your foot".... well, I tried those, and although there was some molding, for the most part the plastic was too rigid to truly form to my foot.I have since tried many brands, types of custom insoles - I tried other Superfeet, Soles,Scholl's and more - and I am going to say it again - for my needs, all these insoles do is make a good fitting pair of shoes not fit anymore!  Your mileage may vary!THanks for reading.

Seriously, this is good stuff - I have tried a few different varieties over the years, and this is simple to apply, is not too greasy, and penetrates nicely into the teeth of the zipper.  It also stays active for a long time, you don't have to keep reapplying - this will last for a good amount of time.Give this a try, I bought a few tubes and like it immensely.Thanks for reading.

Did you notice that the black visqueen - formerly known as Landscapers Plastic - is no longer available at most local home centers, like Home Depot, Lowe's, etc?  And even the painters plastic you can find is of lower mil rating, most of the time of the thinner variety.Good to know you can still get variety / choice on Amazon.  Though I wish this was a few $$$ cheaper, it is exactly what I wanted, and the thickness is tough to beat.  This is a durable, well made plastic.Thanks for reading.

Believe the reviews that state that one of the ear pieces will fail after limited use. My son told me yesterday that the right ear piece no longer works - after only about two weeks use.We are currently contacting Sentey for a warranty replacement - I will update this review to convey how that went.Shame on Sentey for producing such a flawed product.  And shame on Amazon for allowing Sentey to pull the product, and stop selling it. Amazon should back the buyer and hold Sentey accountable. If Amazon is going to provide this elaborate review system, then it has to work both ways and benefit the buyer too, as well as selling more product.What an absolute horrific product.... I hope Sentey makes it right for all these ripped off consumers.

I needed to share an old LaserJet 3300 Laser Printer / All In One - and purchased this due to price, footprint, perceived ease of use and of course the reviews seemed positive.  I also like that It came with two USB cables so I did not have to purchase any in addition.Bottom line - after over a month of use, this has done the job we had hoped - it allows both my sons separate computer to use the LaserJet as if it were attached solely to their machine. At the price and the fact it works - then comes with two cables - makes this an easy decision to buy.  I would recommend this switch based on these criteria....Thanks for reading.

I own multiples of this type of Nalgene container in the 8, 16, 32 and 64 ounce sizes.  These bottles are thick walled, heavy duty and impart absolutely zero taste to any water or beverage stored in them.  They also are easy to clean and dry quickly due to the wide mouth opening.  In addition, they are virtually leak proof with just a firm turn of the cap - I have never had anything leak out of these bottles after years of use over many different applications.  One of my bottles is about 15 years old and has seen near daily use, and other than a little yellowing of the plastic, it functions as new.I use them for anything and everything - for example, I use them for drinking water storage in my refrigerator. Where I live, I have to avoid tap water, so I have to buy / mix my drinking water (mine is a combo of mineral water, Arrowhead and RO). I also use them to store my coffee / espresso water, which is a different mix of water. Then, I use them for camping to hold juice, water and milk in my cooler.  I also use them as an ice block in the cooler itself - I fill them with water and freeze them, and combined with ice and a Yeti cooler makes a nice combination to hold ice for a long time.These bottles are worth every penny, as they are virtually indestructible and will provide years of leak proof service.  I would recommend them to anyone.Thanks for reading.

Here is how this product works - the company puts an expiration date on a sticker on the back - for example, lets say Jul 2021.  Well, when the product dies two to three years later (and four to five years before the expiration date on the sticker), the product is out of warranty and the company will not honor the Jul 2021 expiration date they calculated.  And when I say the product "dies" I mean it is no longer usable - you try to put fresh batteries in it and it just beeps at you incessantly and constantly.The issue is MOST ALL of these die long before the touted expiration date.  Two out of two of the ones I purchased did.  And from reading all the bad reviews here, and on the internet - this is how this product is designed.  This is planned obsolescence on steroids... this product is, in my humble opinion, designed to last a couple of years intentionally.Any time you see a positive to negative review ratio so two-sided, you have to ask yourself what the real deal is with the product.  I am here to share my experience - and that experience is stay away from this product, that  is, unless you like throwing $40 at something that will die in a couple of years.Thanks for reading.

How did I go so many years without this stuff in my shop, or in my car, or in my backpack? Every day I think of new ways to use this stuff.... for instance, today - I was filling a small spray bottle with bug repellent for my backpack, and I was concerned about the top coming unscrewed slightly causing a potential leak. Well, I pulled out my clear version of this same tape, and wrapped it around the top where it screws on, now I am confident it will hold.Yesterday, my weedeaters foam grip was cracking splitting - out comes the black Silicone tape to the rescue to provide a new grip for the handle. The day before, my tent pole plastic end cap was not staying on the pole, again, Silicone tape to the rescue.Then, when I was weedeating my lawn,  I noticed my trusty outdoor electrical cord took a hit with either the weedeater or hedger, and had a couple of chunks of the outer sheathing missing.  I used my Xtreme tape (in the Red color to match the cord ;-)) and it has been holding for weeks and about 4 uses, I don't see why it won't hold for a very long time.Next, both my backpacking and camping tent poles have vinyl or plastic ends on the poles - and after time these loosen up, want to come off and worse yet get lost!  Well, not only does Xtreme tape fuse the tent pole ends to the pole, it also reinforces them and makes them stronger and more durable...And then the big test - my garden hose had a pin-hole leak in it, and I applied this tape to it.  The key is to make sure you extend the tape on either side of the hole by a few inches (I did three inches on each side of the hole) - and then make sure you stretch the tape very well and evenly around the hose.  Also, make sure the hose is on a flat surface, and try to avoid flexing / bending the hose while taping, keep it as straight as possible.  Also, give it at least two windings (not just one).  It is working fine, if there are any issues I will update.You get it. This stuff is amazing. Once you wind it on itself it sticks like white on rice. Its resiliency is quite good - it is very tough and it will not come unwound unless you intentionally start to pull on the seam. Then, it will rip instead of lose its contact... it is that sticky to itself.The list goes on.... like I said, I keep finding more uses for it daily.I would say just get a roll, and keep it around. You will be amazed at the number of applications this stuff will satisfy.... an easy five star!!Thanks for reading.

Initially, I was impressed with these out of the box, however, after a week the first lighter I bought started noticeably sputtering.  This was not from abuse, the lighter never left my shop.  It was only used a few times to fuse some rope ends, test out a few backpacking stoves, etc...Since I bought two, I deployed the second one for duty... then, about a week later when I noticed it was running low on fuel, I attempted to fill it.  Well, to make a long story short, no matter what I tried, I could not get the lighter to accept fresh fuel... the fuel fill valve is defective.Good news is I contacted the seller and they took care of the situation, so kudos to the seller, whom I left five star rating for on Amazon.It looks as though there are many happy customers with these judging from the positive reviews here, so apparently my two for two of getting duds was an anomaly.... but it is what it is, and I call it as I see it!Thanks for reading.

These bottles have done the job for me, as stated in the title, I use these for backpacking for my Picaridin bug repellent, or my Eucalyptus bug repellent.  What is nice about these bottles is they are light weight, \the top screws on tightly / securely without leaking, and the spray mist is very fine and  atomized, without drips after dispensing.Note these are made of plastic, and can break if abused or hit with a blunt object, so care is required of course.  I also put Teflon tape around the neck before screwing the cap on just for insurance of keeping the cap tight and leakproof..  I keep these stored on the outside of my pack away from my valuables in case of any issues - also they are double bagged in Ziplocs.Would recommend to anyone looking for an economical and lightweight / compact solution to dispensing with a fine mist spray pattern... these are cheap enough that if they break, just use another.Thanks for reading.

UPDATE:  I had to dock the Mini two stars - the most recent one that I bought came in a plastic bag, with no tamper evident seals or anything on the bag. At first I thought it was the seller that was the culprit, and they repackaged in a bag - but NO - it was Sawyer!!  Sawyer is no selling these in a small ziploc bag with no factory seal or tamper evident seal!!!  To me, given the nature of this item, this is completely unacceptable and crosses the line.  If they are going to ship these in a bag, at least put a tamper seal or perferation on the bag so the user can see if the bag was opened!!  I returned the filter to the seller, and will look for one still produced in the original clamshell packaging.END UPDATEI had been using the larger Sawyer Squeeze filter for years, and recently purchased a couple of these "Mini" version for my most recent Backpacking trip.  I used this in my homemade gravity filter, and it performed well.  I also used it "on the fly" trail side to fill up a 32 oz water bottle, and it was a breeze to deploy and use.It should be noted that this is a Mini version of the Sawyer filters, and its design is intended to minimize weight - therefore, there is a trade off with this design, and the water flow through it will not be as fast as fatter / larger filters.  Stands to reason.Some things to consider when using this filter to maximize efficiency:-  If possible, pre-filter your water before putting through the mini. Putting dirty, gunky water with visible large chunks floating in it will clog the filter much faster, and result in painfully slow flow rates.  For me, this is easy - I carry an MSR Nano cloth and a small funnel in my pack, and I run the water through this to filter out the main gunk.  It works well.  You can substitute the Nano cloth with Cheesecloth folded over a few times if you want.-  If you are using this in a Gravity Filter set up, be sure and put as much distance between this and the dirty water reservoir as possible.  I use about 48 inches of hose between this filter and the dirty water bladder when it is hung  - the further that this filter can be placed / hung away from the water source, the faster the flow.  It's simple Physics - the greater the distance the greater the pressure of the water.  It becomes even more important to consider hose length given the small size of this filter.All in all, a good filter for what it is intended to do - low priced, light weight, easy to store / carry - it checks all the boxes!  It is light enough that our group carries a backup filter!Thanks for reading.

What can I say about these filters that has not already been said?  They are a well priced, well made, high quality filter that does the job intended.How do I use these?  These help me make coffee while backpacking - and why they are a great addition to my pack is that they are lightweight, make good coffee in a very simple process, and are durable and well made where they can be used repeatedly without the need for replaceable accessories, filters or parts.For those of you relying on "Cowboy Coffee" while on the trail - take a long hard look at these filters.  One  option, you can pour your Cowboy Coffee through this filter and take all the grinds / grounds out of your coffee, removing the cowboy and just leaving the coffee.  Or simpler yet, just pour your grounds into this filter, then put this directly into a cup of boiling / hot water, and let it steep just like you would French press or tea.  Just don't let it steep too long, or it will be quite strong!  Experiment to the taste you prefer....One thing to note - if you don't want your coffee grounds floating to the top of the filter when you dunk it in your water - then pre-infuse your grounds with a little water before dunking.  Pre-infusion just means the act of pre-soaking the grinds, and letting them sit for 30 seconds before use.  Google pre-infusion for more details.Another note - there is a smaller version of this filter which is even better for you ultralighters out there that still want coffee on the trail!Thanks for reading.

If you already have some of the components needed to make a gravity filter, and don't want to spend $120 on the Platypus Gravity Works retail / complete version, than this hose kit may be one of the items for you!I already had a "Dirty" 2L reservoir (which you can get for under $20 new if you shop), plus I already owned a couple of 2L Platypus bottles ($9.99 for these), and I already owned two Platypus Hoser bladders in the 2L and 3L sizes.  Note - I use the 2L and 3L containers for my "Clean" water.  This hose kit allowed me to complete the same quality and function Gravity filter that Platypus sells for over $100.So, what is the bonus I refer to in the title?  The picture, at least at the time I bought mine, does not show that you get the connector ends to hook up to a Platypus Big Zip bladder, AND the connector end to hook up to a Platypus Hoser and Platypus 2L bottle!!  The picture shows the connector that you would hook to the "Dirty" 2 or 4L reservoir - but does NOT show the connectors on the clean end - namely the two I mentioned that will connect to either the Big Zip, Hoser, Platypus bottes, Platypus Water Tank, etc.This is a nice kit and comes with a lot of parts for the money!  I would recommend it to anyone who is patching together a DIY Gravity Filter system.Thanks for reading.

When I saw these Eneloop Pro AAA batteries offered by a Japan based seller, I initially balked being concerned about shipping time and if there were issues with authenticity, or if they were different specs than the US version.Bottom line - nothing to worry about - if you are looking to buy Eneloop Pro AAA - if these are less $$$, and you don't mind waiting an extra week - then buy them.  Note that the seller I purchased mine from was "Buy in Japan" and the price was $26.There is one BONUS to these Japan based ones - they come in a really nice battery storage container - where the US offered Eneloop Pro's DON'T come with this storage case - the US ones come with a disposable plastic outer shell.  This nice case the Japan version comes with is worth a couple of dollars IMHO, making these and EVEN BETTER DEAL!!!I buy these over the standard Eneloops due to the additional 100 Amp Hour rating - and extra power / duration this provides.Thanks for reading.

When I saw these Eneloop Pro AA batteries offered by a Japan based seller, I initially balked being concerned about shipping time and if there were issues with authenticity, or if they were different specs than the US version.Bottom line - nothing to worry about - if you are looking to buy Eneloop Pro AA - if these are less $$$, and you don't mind waiting an extra week - then buy them.  Note that the seller I purchased mine from was "Buy in Japan" and the price was $25.There is one BONUS to these Japan based ones - the retail packaging it comes in doubles as a nice battery storage container. The packaging has a slide-off, thick plastic backing - and then after sliding off, there is another plastic sheet that folds back, exposing the batteries!  By contrast, the US offered Eneloops I have purchased literally come with a thin, throwaway outer shell retail package. I am not sure if this packaging is exclusive to the Japan version of the Eneloop, but I have purchased four Eneloop Pro orders from Japan based sellers, and the packaging has been identical. IMHO, the fact I got these Eneloop Pro's from Japan cheaper than I could from the US, the packaging that suffices as a storage container make these an EVEN BETTER DEAL!!!NOTE:  Not all would agree that the retail packaging would double as a battery case - I have to use a rubber band to assure it is securely closed - so don't buy these expecting to get a separate or formal case. But I am saying for my needs, it is sufficient.I buy these over the standard Eneloops due to the additional 400 Amp Hour rating - and extra power / duration this provides.Thanks for reading.

You are probably wondering "What is the difference between these Katadyn adapters being offered at $7.95, and say, the Platypus adapters being offered at $16?"  The answer - "NOTHING!!!"  That's right.  Same with the ones offered by Sawyer for $9.... they are all basically the same part(s).In fact, I use this Katadyn set interchangeably with my Platypus Big Zip and Sawyer Filter and connector products, without any issues.  I use them in my home made gravity filter system.  Note a previous reviewer alluded to these not working with Camebak bladders - I am not sure which Camelbak bladders they were referring to, because they were not specific - but I also own a Camelbak Antidote, and these fit just fine.  The only difference was the Camelbak was blue and these were white.  (and yes, I own a lot of hydration bladders - that is what four hikers in the family will do).To make this review short and sweet, shop these adapters by best price before name, and have full confidence that they are most likely interchangeable to the other ones that look strikingly similar.... I know, I own these and they fit fine in Platypus, Sawyer, etc...Thanks for reading!

What follows is a long-winded review, read this around bedtime if you are having trouble falling asleep! ;-) For those seeking the Reader's Digest version - overall, I think the Freiling French Press, though expensive, is the best French Press money can buy. I have tried offerings from 4-5 other French Press makers, including Espro and Bodum, and the Freiling IMHO has the highest quality build, has the best heat retention capability during the brew cycle, and will be the most durable long term due to its 100% 18/10 stainless construction - no plastic parts here!!. It is one of the very few 100% stainless French Presses you can find - plus it also a very attractive vessel to boot! I actually leave it out on my counter due to its good looks!! There are many good reasons why the Freiling French Press are the best sellers, and why reviews here on Amazon are so plentiful and positive. Amongst those reasons are quality, reliability, consistency and durability.Do realize however, that just because you spend the money and buy a Freiling will NOT guarantee you will automatically start making great coffee - as with any French Press the method is more important than the tool! You must pay attention to ALL of the variables involved in correct coffee extraction procedures - if you want the best coffee possible with a French Press, it is all about the process - assuring correct brew temperature, you use freshly ground beans, you are using an adequate grinder that grinds to consistent texture, and more!! Below I offer some tips to assuring a great cup of coffee with the Freiling, those may help in your pursuit of the perfect cup!!Just as important - do realize that the Freiling is a BREWING vessel ;-) and not a STORAGE carafe. You will see in the reviews that some complain the Freiling does not keep their coffee "hot" for hours - the coffee should only stay in the Freiling for around four minutes to brew, you will need a nice storage carafe to keep it hot thereafter!! Those that keep the coffee in the press with the grounds after the four minute mark are destroying the taste. Moreover, even if you transfer the coffee out, and remove the grounds and then use the Freiling as your storage vessel - you would be much better served purchasing a separate carafe to store the coffee when done. The Freiling is NOT an ideal storage carafe. (For example - I use a Zojirushi glass lined carafe for my needs).***End of Reader's Digest version - now on to the details!!Here is what I like about the Freiling Press:- Double Wall carafe construction - this is both ideal and necessary for the ever-so critical heat retention during your preheating and steeping phases. The method I employ can hold brew temps between 195 and 204 throughout the entire steeping / brewing phase, and I could never accomplish that with other presses made of glass, plastic, etc. Some have claimed that the Freiling is vacuum sealed in addition, but it is not - it is double walled and that is it. *** Note - I typically keep my brew temps around 200-202 degrees - please Google "SCAA recommended coffee brewing temperatures" for some background on correct temps to brew / extract coffee**- 100% 18/10 stainless - beautifully finished, but it is more than just good looks - the thick stainless assures the press will last for a long time and it will aid in heat retention already mentioned. It is durable and virtually indestructible if used with any modicum of care and not dropped daily on the tile! My 33oz Freiling is 3 years old, and it operates like the day I bought it. Plus, it still looks good also - other than a couple of minor scratches to the polished stainless exterior.- Top / Plunger assembly comes apart for thorough cleaning. You get a sense of the attention to detail and the cost it takes to make a Freiling press when you disassemble the constituent parts that make up the top / plunger. It wreaks of quality through and through... the fact it can be disassembled, and remains 100% stainless is no small feat, and a testament to the quality - and why it costs so much. Consider what it takes to be able to deliver this assembly - and why competing press makers don't!- Double walled top / lid - I already mentioned the double walled carafe - but the fact the lid is ALSO double walled construction is worth calling out- again, the competitors don't even approach this and even make their tops / lids out of PLASTIC says it all.- They are darned nice to look at! Let's face it - they are an attractive vessel.Here is what I don't like about the Freiling:- Price - this one is more of a whine ;-) and not anything wrong with the product, but hey, I can still not like it! Bottom line is I would still buy it again.. To make it less painful, I got this 44oz version for $98 here on Amazon - it was in my cart for over a year in the $125 range, and when I saw the price drop temporarily I jumped on it!- The top on my 33oz version had a weld seam failure around the hole where the plunger is inserted - causing the top to fill with water that I could not get back out. HOWEVER, Freiling sent me a new top when I asked with no hassle... it was a "one-off" problem and don't expect it to happen on my other Freilings.- I can't think of anything of substance I DON'T like about the Freiling - if you learn how to use it, perfect your method then this is the top of the heap when it comes to French Press. It is the best tool for the Press job IMHO.In addition to this 44oz Freiling Stainless Press, I have owned the 33 oz Freiling Stainless Press for a few years and have used it almost daily to make my morning coffee (except for the once a week I use my Technivorm drip brewer). Therefore, I do have experience with Freiling's presses, and understand how to best utilize them to squeeze out the optimal cup of coffee. So, why did I buy the 44oz Freiling when I already own the 33oz? For one, that extra cup on some days makes a difference ;-) and second I think the Freilings are cool, have grown attached to them and see absolutely nothing wrong with owning two different sizes!! Lol. So there it is...Finally, some pointers / things to think about as you pursue the "perfect" cup of coffee:- Make sure and pre-heat your Press and storage carafe in advance - don't put your coffee / boiling water into a cold French Press; and don't put your finished product in a cold storage carafe!!! (google it, this affects the taste). At a minimum, use hot tap water to pre-heat, which usually gets to 130-140 degrees. Personally, I use boiling water to pre-heat - you can boil it on the stove, or perhaps use something like a Zojirushi hot water kettle / boiler that is ready in advance when you wake!- Use fresh beans, and grind the beans right before use. Coffee beans are best within two weeks of roasting, and most store bought beans can be MANY weeks old by the time you buy them. If you can find a local source for your beans that are fresh, do it. You will notice a marked improvement in your finished product.- Buy a decent quality grinder. The $20 blade grinders are just not good enough for French Press - it needs a consistent, coarse grind. At a minimum, I recommend a Capresso Infinity for around $70, then use the "Coarse" settings, dialing it in to where you eliminate 95% of the sludge in your cup. I use an Orphan Espresso LIDO hand grinder ($150), and alternate that with a Capresso Infinity. You can also get a Baratza Virtuoso if you want to spend more! The grind is CRITICAL - it needs to be the correct coarseness - but more importantly needs to be CONSISTENT. Consistency is the main challenge for most cheap grinders on the market.- Assure your steeping / brewing temperatures are in the 195-204 degree range. This is not my own recommendation, this is the "proven" range for the best coffee extraction. Invest in something like a Thermapen, or a cheaper temperature probe, that allows you to test the water temperature while steeping. Another critical step to success. For my brewing, I stay in the 200-202 range typically during the four minute brew cycle. *** Note - please Google "SCAA recommended coffee brewing temperatures" for some background on correct temps to brew / extract coffee**- Depress the plunger SLOWLY when it is time, doing it too fast will cause sediment. Also, if the plunger seems to get "stuck", lift it ever so slightly, then depress again!- Fill the water level BELOW the spout depression / line in the carafe when filling for brewing / steeping. This will help guarantee less grounds in your finished product.To summarize - now that you have spent the $$ on a top of the line French Press, consider getting a good grinder that can consistently grind on a coarse setting without a lot of "fines" in the grind; considerr purchasing a good temperature probe (like a Thermapen to check your temperatures of different components throughout the process to find what needs tweaking; consider getting fresh coffee beans. This will give you an even better cup in the end... also, search the web for you tube videos, etc on different processes, find out what works best for you. Once you experience a "perfectly" executed cup of press coffee, you will be hooked!! ;-)Thanks for reading, and best of luck in your choice!

I bought this knife (actually bought two) for my sons' to side carry on our camping / backpacking trips.  I got tired of them always lacking a cutting implement when needed, and tried to find something idiot-proof (and cheap) that was sharp, and was easy to re-sharpen when required.  (btw, I didn't just call my boys idiots, did I??  :-))  Actually, this knife is *better* than something easy to re-sharpen - if the blade gets a bad knick or gets dull, just swap it out for a new blade!  Plus, believe it or not, these blades are VERY sharp, and hold their edge fairly well!I own a number of high end knives (Spydercos, Kabars, Multitools), and I am not going to claim this knife is made to the same quality and standard.  However, when I saw this knife, handled it, cut with it, felt the weight / balance - I was impressed for all this knife gives you in a $30 package.  There is a reason hunters carry this knife for skinning game - it is a very sharp, well built knife with replaceable blades so you don't have to be overly careful.In summary - I am pleasantly surprised at what this knife is for the price, and would readily recommend to anyone as long as your expectations match what you are getting.  This is NOT an heirloom quality knife, however, it is a very serviceable knife that is sharp and immediately resharpens itself when need with the replaceable blades. Oh, did I mention that the replacement blades are very cheap?  It already comes with six blades, but if that is not enough and you detest sharpening, just buy more, they are priced as throw away commodities.Thanks for reading.

I purchased this reel as a ultra light weight option for backpacking - so one of my main objectives was to minimize weight, while maintaining quality at a sub $50 price point.  After doing a little research, I found there are some reels that are lighter - but not by much.  And some of those were MUCH more expensive.  The Pflueger President is known for decent quality at a good price, and this one is no exception!This specs on this one says it weighs 5.9oz, it weighed in at 6.1 oz - so close enough!  I put 4 lb line on it, that should give me enough to catch decent size trout.  I am going to pair this with a St Croix Triumph, UL 5 ft rod that breaks down into four pieces.  This makes a pretty nice combo!Highly recommend to anyone looking for a good quality reel at a good price - of course there are better reels out there, but the Pflueger President has a good reputation of balancing quality and price.

Believe the reviews and the hype about the Para MiIitary 2 --- the size, weight, feel and blade quality of this knife have made it an EDC classic!  I had considered purchasing this knife for a few years before finally taking the plunge - now,  I have been EDC'ing this knife since the day it arrived, and it is one fine knife that holds a keen edge, and holds it very well.  I am really beginning to appreciate the S30V steel on the PM 2.  S30V it is a very high quality knife steel!I own three other Spyderco's - the Police Stainless, a Delica FRN and a Lil' Matriarch - and all have a lot of use between home, work, camping, hiking, backpacking, etc.  But, the next backpacking trip will have this knife at my side, I enjoy the size and action of this knife a lot.  It is very light for its size at 3.8 oz, and it has a very good feeling in the hand with the G10 handle.  The balance is very good and most importantly it cuts like a dream.  The locking mechanism has a good "snap" to it when opening, and it has just the right amount of stiffness on the action where it opens very smoothly.Owning the Delica with a 3" blade and the Police with the 4" blade makes me realize how perfect the 3.5" blade of the PM 2 is for my hand size.  The Delica always felt a little small and I carried mainly for its light weight.... likewise, the Police always felt a tad big, and heavy due to the all stainless construction.  Then again, the Police was never an EDC for these reasons, I typically keep that for around the house duties.I am not a big fan of the blade release / locking mechanism on the PM 2, but that is a minor concern and does not even come close to outweighing all the positives about this knife.I liked this knife so much that I also ordered the Camo with the black blade - it is backordered and may take a few months to get it - but it will be worth the wait.  I look forward to passing these knives on to my sons' some day....I highly recommend this knife..... Thanks for reading.EDIT:  For those concerned about the number of ParaMilitary 2 fakes floating around out there, I thought I would add a few sentences...First, the knife I purchased was sold / shipped by Amazon directly, and arrived with the box taped on both ends.  This gave me initial cause for concern, as the Spyderco factory does NOT tape the box (I called Spyderco and they verified that).  I still have not found who taped the box, whether it is Amazon, or perhaps a 3rd party that might be supplying Amazon (note again, I called Spyderco directly, and they stated definitively they do NOT tape the boxes).  Also, even though my first box was taped shut, the knife had definitely been used and handled previously - perhaps a return?  I called Amazon, expressed my concern, and they sent a replacement out - which was brand new, never used.  However, the box on the replacement was also taped... so my guess is Amazon is taping the boxes shut.  The tape job is professional, uses rounded corners and is well done, but just a heads up.Next - as far as real vs fake - I spent a lot of time checking the knife I received from Amazon (both of them) and I am 100% confident that these are authentic.  I checked all the known issues with the fakes, and none of them exist here.... this is an authentic Spyderco, so at the time of writing this, the current stock sold by Amazon looks good.  Just don't be alarmed if your box arrives taped on both ends... both of the PM2's I purchased Fulfilled by Amazon were taped on both ends.

If you are looking for a headlamp that has high lumens, is ultra-bright and can light up the night, look elsewhere - this e+LITE is NOT a power house.  However, if you are looking for a headlamp that is ultra-LIGHT, can provide task lighting for your immediate vicinity, and make sure you can navigate in dark environments, than this is worth a look.I bought this headlamp solely for backpacking, and the purpose was to save weight.  I own many headlamps currently - like a Spot 90 and 130, multiple Petzl TakTikka and Tikka-whatevers, and more... and own many high lumen, light weight flashlights - and they all have specific purposes.  But when I am looking for something that bridges the gap between lightweight and brightness, I put this in my pack.  My other headlamps are 3+ ounces, or 200% heavier than this one... sure they are brighter, but to me, the trade off from brightness to usability has a different requirement when I have to carry all my equipment on my back.  Plus, when I backpack, I typically carry TWO lights so I have a backup - and the backup light is a handheld light (usually LED and lightweight) that provides more lumens when required.I use this primarily for around-camp tasks at night where I want hands free operation, and inside my tent at night for the same reason.  When in the backcountry, it is amazing how much more important hands-free operation becomes, and how much more frequently the requirement arises.  This light is rated at a max of 29 lumens - and that is PLENTY of light for tasks at night.  In fact, I prefer to save my night vision as much as possible, so I actually use the lower lumen settings more on this lamp - and that doubles in benefit as it saves battery!Another nice feature of this headlamp is the run time duration on the same battery.  Due to its lower output / lumen requirement, it runs for a long time on one battery.  Plus, you can literally leave the same battery in the device for years (according to the specs) and it will not drain the battery if the device is not used.  Not all devices can do that, there is always some sort of drain that kills the battery.  Also, even if you have to carry extra batteries, this utilizes the button type 2032 battery, so replacements weight next to nothing and carrying extras is not a big deal.  (as opposed to AA and AAA batteries which by comparison are heavy)Other advantages of this device for backpackers - this device is highly water resistant, and claims to be waterproof to 1m.  It also has a red light feature to further preserve night vision (nice feature for astronomy, which I also do).  Finally, the headband on this is intentionally low profile and light - it is really just a nylon string - but it is comfortable, does not exert too much pressure, and you can wear it for long periods and not know you have it on.  You have to realize the headband is where many devices get most of their weight from, so a lot of the weight savings comes from minimizing that.Overall, I would recommend this light if it meets your requirements of something that is lightweight, offers sufficient task lighting, is water resistant and durable and has a good battery life.  I liked it so much, I bought two more for my sons, who also backpack with me!!Thanks for reading.

I already own two utility carts - both two shelf models - and I was hoping this three shelf model was going to be a welcome addition to my workshop.  Wow, was I wrong.  After briefly attempting to assemble this Luxor cart, and encountering what I thought was a poorly manufactured cart due to poor part quality and fit tolerances, I then went back and read some of the reviews to see if anyone else had the issues I did. I found one reviewer touched on the lack of sturdiness of the shelves and the build quality - but nobody touched on the fact that the leg posts do not fit into the shelf posts!!!  Huh?  Did they change the design of the parts recently?  DId I get a lemon?  How could I be one of the very few to encounter this?First, a little about the two carts I already own - one is a WEN model, two shelf cart and one is a Husky cart, which is also a two shelf model.  These both were purchased from Home Depot - the WEN for $69 on sale (normally $99) and the Husky for $89.  The WEN cart looks exactly like the Harbor Freight $99 cart - and after further inspection I found out it is... although it is not a bad cart - I like it better than the HD Husky cart.  The main thing I do not like about the two Home Depot carts - only two swivel casters and NO locking casters - which is a pain in the rear on my sloped patio as I constantly battle the loaded cart toodling down the slope....So you can see from the two carts I already own that my expectations were not through the roof - the two carts I own are sub-$100 carts, and I look for something that is built sturdy that does not carry a high price tag.  It is not like I was comparing this cart to $500 carts that are made of stainless steel - I weighing my inputs against two HD carts that I got for $69 and $89 respectively, and carts made of plastic.  Keep that in mind when reading here - this is NOT my first cart, and my expectations were NOT too high.  Also, this review is only my opinion, others may beg to differ, and I respect that.Now, back to this Luxor cart.  Upon opening the box, the first thing that struck me was the "thinness" of the shelves.  Compared to the two other less expensive carts I own, the shelves are a lot thinner, and flexed with the slightest side pressure.  OK... I initially did not fret.  I was still looking forward to the fact I had four swivel casters, two that locked.  Well, I never got that far.  When I turned the first shelf over to install the posts, I was horrified first at the thin leg post material, and the cheapness of the plastic used.  They are square / channel designed legs, but made of VERY thin plastic, and very brittle plastic in addition - in my opinion.  But that was not the worst part - what was the real head scratcher was THEY DID NOT FIT INTO THE SHELF posts. I played with three or four of the legs posts on three or four different shelf posts, to no avail.  To make the leg posts fit, I would have had to file down the shelf post part... or force them on with a mallet, which would damage the receiving part of the shelf, and gouge out the plastic.  I refused to do that 16 times for the 8 shelf posts!!!!  They should fit, and if there was a concern about them being too loose, they should have designed them with a screw, or nut and bolt system!! If I attempted to force the legs on, it would peel back pieces of the shelf post, and I did not want to go any further.Note that this cart is designed with ZERO screws, bolts, nuts, etc.  NONE.  On one hand some might like that, but with this cart and the way it turned out, even if I did want to keep this cart, that was a minus.  Given the cheapness of the plastic used on the leg posts, there could be nothing but problems down the road.  The thinness of the leg posts, and the cheapness of the plastic simply does not add up to making a press fit design.  This cart is simply NOT made to last.At this point, I have described enough to paint the picture of my thoughts on this cart.  I never went past Step 3 on assembly.  I will stick with carts that are designed with thicker / beefier / sturdier parts, and ones that employ screw, nut and bolt hardware to hold it together.  I cannot believe this cart was more expensive than the two I already own...As a side note, when I went back to HomeDepot.com, I noticed a three shelf cart under the label "H Wilson" that was the EXACT same cart as this one - the picture was the exact stock picture, with the same specs.  HomeDepot wanted $129 for this same cart... so obviously this cart is made in one factory, then marketed by more than one brand / company with different labels.  Says a lot to me.  I know that most carts are mass produced these days, but I will stick with the ones that are better built for my needs.The pictures, description and reviews fooled me on this cart - what I thought I was getting and what I got did not match in quality in the end.  I am shocked at all the positive reviews for this cart... but again everyone's needs are different, YMMV, and I respect your assessment of this cart could be different.  Please return that sentiment....Thanks for reading.EDIT:  I did not mention this in my review above, but I did return this cart, and labeled it as "defective" since I could not get the leg posts to mate with the shelf standards without damaging the part or doing some major filing / modification.EDIT 2:::  After reading other reviews - some that say how easy this cart assembled - I have to assume that the company changed the design of the cart, as the one I received did not go together easy at all - not even close.  I am a woodworker, an engineer and work with my hands all the time.  What follows is not a review written by someone who rarely assembles things, quite the contrary.  But I had to write the review for the product I received, and call it honestly.  I know some may not like that, but it is what it is...... if the company has since addressed this design / assemble issue, then that is a good thing.  And if my review had anything thing to do with that, then that is also a good thing.  But if the reviews written before mine that state how easy this cart assembles are true, then the only conclusion I can come up with is a design change somewhere along the way.END EDIT:::

I only recently discovered the Turtle Fur Backcountry Bandana - I saw one at a local Sportsman Warehouse (the discontinued Ultra Lightweight "Gone Fishin" model) and liked the size, look and feel - so I bought it!  I then saw the Light Weight "Digi" pattern / model here on Amazon for a reduced price, so I bought it also.The "Lightweight" model reviewed here is made up of 92% Poly and 8% Spandex. The  "Ultra Light" model I also own is 83% Poly and 17% Lycra. You are probably thinking that since one is called "Light" and the other is called "Ultra Light" that there would be a marked difference in weight - quite the contrary actually - the Light version weighs 58.5 grams and the Ultra Light version weighed in at 58 grams!! I got a good chuckle when I saw that the difference in weight is only a half of a gram.Regardless of the weight, I like both of these bandanas a lot. Among other uses - I use these as a neck / side of the face cover under my Tilley and other hats - I drape them over my head and wear them under my hat. I was using cotton bandanas for this same purpose, but these are far better for four main reasons: - these are larger than the cotton bandanas - most of my cotton bandanas are 19 x19 inches, and these are 20.5 x 20.5 inches. This extra inch and a half makes a big difference in covering the side / back of my neck. - these wick water away and dry much faster than my cotton bandanas - they cotton stays too wet and my hat stays wet and stains as a result. With these, my hat is dry in most cases due to the wicking. Sometimes on hotter days I like the wetter cotton, so I do still use them on occasion. - these are much softer and more comfortable on my head / skin than the rougher cotton. The top of my head is a little thin on hair these days :-) and the Turtle furs feel nice on the dome. - these are much more UV protective than my cotton bandanas.I also use these as a neck gaiter when needed, and as something to carry for general use for wiping sweat off the brow, etc. I still own my cotton bandanas also, but they now don't see as much use as they used to.These have a nice, soft feel.... if you are looking for an alternative to your current bandana, neck gaiter, etc, give these a look. Thanks for reading!
