Among other uses - I use these as a neck / side of the face cover under my Tilley and other hats - I drape them over my head and wear them under my hat.  I was using cotton bandanas for this same purpose, but these are far better for four main reasons: -  these are larger than the cotton bandanas - most of my cotton bandanas are 19 x19 inches, and these are 20.5 x 20.5 inches.  This extra inch and a half makes a big difference in covering the side / back of my neck. -  these wick water away and dry much faster than my cotton bandanas - they cotton stays too wet and my hat stays wet and stains as a result.  With these, my hat is dry in most cases due to the wicking.  Sometimes on hotter days I like the wetter cotton, so I do still use them on occasion. -  these are much softer and more comfortable on my head / skin than the rougher cotton.  The top of my head is a little thin on hair these days :-) and the Turtle furs feel nice on the dome. -  these are much more UV protective than my cotton bandanas.I also use these as a neck gaiter when needed, and as something to carry for general use for wiping sweat off the brow, etc.  I still own my cotton bandanas also, but they now don't see as much use as they used to.These have a nice, soft feel.... if you are looking for an alternative to your current bandana, neck gaiter, etc, give these a look.  Thanks for reading!

In the past I have used Harper Palymyra Deck Scrubs in a similar size - but when I had trouble locating a Harper this time for the right price, I decided to give this one a try.  I was able to get this Weiler for just over $5 here on Amazon, where the Harper of similar size I could not find under $10.The quality of this brush is very good - not quite on par with the Harper version, but for the money it is good enough and I would have no trouble recommending it.  The bristles are well mounted, and don't fall out readily like so many other cheaply made palmyras;  plus, the wood block is well made and sturdy, and should last as long as the brush does at least.This brush has two connectors - one threaded (standard size, all my handles fit) and a tapered one also - which also fits the handles I own so I would say the size is fairly standard.I used this on my cool deck and rough concrete and they worked very well - the bristles were the right stiffness and held up well when scrubbing.  Many times, cheaper palmyra bristles are weak and will bend / flex too much when scrubbing, resulting in the bristles not penetrating well into the grooves and rougher surfaces.  The Weiler bristles are a good stiffness.Again, it is not quite the same level / quality of the Harper equivalent, but for half the price I am satisfied.  Thanks for reading!

This is my second pair of Danner Instigators, with my last pair purchased back in 2007.  What I like most about these is they are pretty much the same boot eight years later - there are not many changes to the design, the last, and the build quality after all these years.  Many shoes suffer from the "declining quality" syndrome, where they get good reviews, then are summarily cheapened in later revisions.  Not these, and many other Danners, the build remains consistent over the years.Now, these boots are not made in the US like some other Danner lines, and they are not their top of the line shoe.  I own MANY shoes, and I purchase this particular one for a work shoe, and like it the "price to comfort to value" ratio.  I got this pair for $114 after Amazon price fluctuations, and for that price it hits the sweet spot for me.  I do NOT use these for hiking - again, I use them as a work shoe around the house (in the woodshop, painting, yard work, washing the car etc, etc).  I have other high quality outdoor / hiking shoes for th the outdoor endeavors, and don't look to the Danners for that.As far as the fit - I typically wear a 12.5 to 13 wide in other shoes, and the Danner 12W fits.  If Danner made a 12.5 Wide, I would get that, but the next size up is a 13 and that is too big for me. What I like about the Danner for someone with wide feet - the sides of the shoe below the toe box and into the forefoot is soft leather, and will form to your feet.  This allows my wide feet to push the side of the shoe out to where it needs to be, and there are not protrusions or plastic inserts in the Danner to push back or fight that side formation.As far as waterproof performance - like all leather / Goretex shoes it takes maintenance to keep your leather soft, supple and conditioned - and more importantly to keep top waterproof performance.  For this shoe - when it is new, I immediately condition the leather with Nikwax Leather conditioner, then wear the shoe wet to help with initial break in and leather formation to my foot.  Then, I periodically apply Nikwax Waterproofing Wax for Leather (and some left over Nikwax Aqueous) when I notice the water not beading up and penetrating the leather too quickly.  Then, every four to six months, another Conditioner step to keep the leather rich and soft.For my foot, this shoe is a good trade off for price, quality, comfort for an around the house work shoe.  I would recommend it to anyone looking for a good work shoe, and seeing how I got eight years of periodic use out of the last pair, that is good enough for me.  Note that when I do wear them, it is for long periods and for heavy duty work.  For instance, I can put 4 days straight in the woodshop for 10-12 hours a day, be on an outdoor painting project, driveway project for days on end, etc.  So, these shoes by no means have been treated lightly, and the 8 years of use is a good indicator of build quality.Thanks for reading!

For many years, when I needed a handle for one of my files, I would shape one out of scrap wood and be good to go...... however, now with the ability to get a quality handle, complete with a ferrule, for only $2 - I think my days of spending an hour or so of my time to make a handle are over.These are not perfect, but for the price they MORE than do the job. You could make your own, but for $2 and the time savings of doing something more fun than making a handle, the why would you???Highly recommended as long as they stay in this price range.

For many years, when I needed a handle for one of my files, I would shape one out of scrap wood and be good to go...... however, now with the ability to get a quality handle, complete with a ferrule, for only $2 - I think my days of spending an hour or so of my time to make a handle are over.These are not perfect, but for the price they MORE than do the job.  You could make your own, but for $2 and the time savings of doing something more fun than making a handle, then why would you???Highly recommended as long as they stay in this price range.

When I saw Osprey's new Rev 18 and 24 packs, I was intrigued.  I was initially impressed how the pack wore easily in the store - and thought it was worth a closer look.  I liked what Osprey was trying to target with this pack, and it is about time they recognized the gap in their current lineup!!  Another big plus was how feature rich the Rev 18 and 24 packs are - here is a summary of the features and my opinion on how they stack up:- Large hip / waist belt pockets - ALWAYS a nice feature in a day pack - and these are done right!  First, there are TWO and not just one, and second they are LARGE enough to put a camera, your keys, snack bars and still have room for a compass!!  Very nice.  They are also VERY easy to access and zip / unzip which is a plus.- Easy access / zippered and separate water hydration compartment - amazingly, the hydration compartment is done right.  I say "amazingly" because so many packs are not well thought out in the hydration area.  The Rev 18 is an easy access, zippered compartment with a tailored Osprey bladder that is wide and flat - not a big bulbous mass like some other bladders.  The compartment can be accessed without emptying the pack, and most of all can be filled WITHOUT removing the bladder from the pack!!!  That is a VERY nice feature.- Baffled hydration bladder - the Osprey bladder, as mentioned, is wide and flatter in design than some other bladders - and most importantly incorporates a baffled design so the water "sloshing" around is minimized.  I noticed this right away and appreciate the attempt.  I also like the way the bladder hangs in the hydration compartment - very sturdy and stable way to mount the bladder.  Most packs just give a loop / hook, this pack gives a structural cross - beam to hold the bladder at its strongest point.- Easy access, large water bottle pockets - I am VERY impressed by the accessibility of these pockets.  These pockets are angled toward the back so you can easily reach around and get your water, binos, or whatever you want to store in them.  Very well thought out design, and I really appreciate the easy access.- TWO pockets on the shoulder straps - and one of the pockets is big enough for your cell phone or GPS!!! Very nice touch.  Plus, this pocket is waterproof , which is also a big plus!! The other pocket is the standard smaller sized pocket, and you can put your iPod, or whatever else you want in there.  The second pocket is NOT waterproof.- Separate, easy access smaller gear compartment - the stuff pocket is well placed and easy to get to - I wish it were just a tad bigger and had a zippered mesh pocket in it, but it is adequate.- Large, easy-in, easy-out main gear compartment - that says it all, the main gear compartment is no frills, just a large space to put your stuff.  No mesh zipper pockets inside, just a large space that you can organize the way you want it.  I don't mind this, as if I need to segregate things, I just use my own mesh bag or Ziploc or whatever works.- External bungee cord storage on the front for jackets, wet gear, etc.  This is always a plus - I like the exposed bungee system more than a pocket style external pocket for wet gear.- There are more nice touches also - like the magnetic water hose mount on your sternum strap, and the fact you can position it close to your pie hole.  Also, there are two sternum straps, not just one, and I like the fact I can use the bottom one to steady my binos so they are not bouncing around.With all the features mentioned, what do I like BEST about the pack??? THE FIT!!!!  I have used this pack on four hikes now - anywhere from 5 to 10 mile hikes - and this pack just melts into your frame, and you don't even know you have it on.  It literally fits like a vest.  I am 6'3" tall with around a 20" torso, and the pack fits comfortably in all the right places.  It does wear a tad warm as it is a close to the back fit - but that is by design and one  of the trades offs of a pack that fits close to your frame.I like this pack so much, I am considering getting another for my sons' - they have picked up on my satisfaction with this pack, and they really like the cell phone and iPod pocket potential, plus the easy access hip and water bottle pockets.In summary - this pack nails the triad of convenience, comfort, and feature richness- and not just for the day hiker, but also for a scrambler - it hugs your frame and is perfect for either activity.  Would I recommend for a marathoner or trail runner?  Marginally, as at 18L it is a little larger and maybe not ideal... depends on your needs.  There is also a Rev 12 and a Rev 6 that might be better for runners.I would unequivocally recommend this pack to anyone - and normally would quality the "if it fit" moniker - but with this pack, due to its flexible / vest design, also long as the torso is long enough, it will fit more people than not.  It is not like a frame pack where there is a limiting factor to fit.Thanks for reading.Note - I own a LOT of day packs of different sizes and make, and each have their own place in my families hiking regimen.  My wife and two sons also hike, so that contributes to the justification to try / own many different packs.  Currently, some of the daypacks I use are - Talon 5.5, 11 and 22, and also own Talon 4 and Talon 8 hip packs that see use.  (we like the Talon series :-)) We also have a couple of Go-Lite packs for fast, light hikes and scrambling, and a couple of Camel back "bladder only" type packs for biking and short hikes.  For long day hikes we also use Deuter 30 or 32, Osprey Stratos 24, among other packs.

Before discussing the quality build / construction of the Pamir, let me say it - these boots just look sexy!  Every time I wear these boots, I get questions like "... what kind of boots are those?"  and "...where did you get them?"  Then it usually goes something like "those are nice looking boots!" Most people have not had exposure to the Pamirs, and most will never buy them due to their size / weight and the fact they don't have GoreTex.  Well, I gotta say, it's their loss.  Most hiking boot buyers have been brainwashed to think GoreTex HAS to be part of the boot, or it is not waterproof.  The first mistake with that thinking is that GoreTex is waterPROOF - it is merely water resistant. What most don't know is that a high quality, thick leather boot can also be highly water resistant if you maintain it.  (what do you think folks did many years ago before GoreTex?)Next, most buyers of packing / hiking boots are being inundated with the notion that backpacking boots need to be "light" - really?  The marketing / sales push for lightweight, high margin and "temporary" shoes has put a lot of pressure on the tried and tested hiking / packing boot, and has led many to believe that they can carry 40 lbs with lightweight slippers on... until they try it and limp into camp with sore feet.  Let's be sensible and separate marketing and sales from carrying 40-50 lbs for 10 miles over rock terrain before buying those trail runners for backpacking.I have owned a pair of Pamirs for going on three years now, and currently shopping for my second pair.  These are simply well built, high quality boots that I don't mind using for even day hiking.  I just enjoy wearing them!  OK, they are definitely overkill for most of my day hikes - but sometimes I take hikes through mud, rocks, bushes and that is where these shine.  I just enjoy wearing these boots!The leather interiors are just simply exquisite - it is top quality leather and really holds up well.  La Sportiva recommends maintaining the interiors with Lexol leather conditioner - and it works well.  I use both the Lexol Cleaner and Conditioner to maintain the interiors, and do this every few months, or when I notice the leather starting to look dirty or getting to dry.The exteriors are just plain built like tanks!  The rand is very tough, and has never come unglued from the leather.  The Vibram soles can take a beating and have held up after hundreds of miles over every type of terrain.  The Perwanger leather exterior is VERY thick, and very durable.  And with proper treatment, can hold back water VERY well.  Again, the boots are not waterproof, but then again, no shoes really are unless they are made of rubber!  I own GoreTex boots also - namely the Zamberlan Vioz Plus, Salomon Quest.  I also own a Kayland Contact with Event lining - and two other leather lined boots - Lowa Renegade and Trekker.  Comparing the water resistance to the GoreTex and Event lined shoes, the Pamirs perform on par with these.  Plus, the GoreTex seems to dry slower once they get wet.  (The Lowa leather lined shoes do not perform well in water).  The biggest advantage is I find leather interiors breathe better than GoreTex boots, especially in the warmer climates...Note that La Sportiva recommends Nikwax Waterproofing for Leather (formerly Aqueous Wax) for maintaining the Perwanger leather exteriors.  I found it works well if used correctly.  I still have some Nikwax Aqueous Wax left over before they changed the name to Nikwax Waterproofing, and I find it works very well.  Realize the Nikwax Waterproofing for Leather used to be called Nikwax Aqueous - Nikwax claims it was just a name change, and the formula is the same, but I am skeptical and still like the older Aqueous better.  I also use the Nikwax Leather Conditioner once a year when the leather starts to dry out.Bottom line - if you like heavy backpacking / mountaineering boots, don't require Gore Tex, and the Pamirs fit you foot type - I would recommend giving them a try.  They are top quality, hand made Italian boots that look sexy too!!Thanks for reading.

Salomon changed the design / cut of the Quest 2 in some key areas that resulted in the shoe not being as ideal for my feet as the Quest 1's were... these changes probably won't affect many with "normal" feet, but if curious please read on.Please understand that I absolutely LOVE the Salomon Quest line (and other shoes by Salomon), so my observations about liking the older version more than the newer version does NOT mean the Quest 2 is a bad choice - quite the contrary, it is still a wonderful shoe as the other reviews will clearly attest also.  It is just not the same for MY particular foot anymore, nothing like the first Salomon Quests released in 2010 (which were ideal for my foot).Additionally, for those that were not aware - Salomon is now offering a "Forces" line for some of their shoes - which include the Quest as an option.  This "Forces" offerings are a tactical / military version of certain "chosen" Salomon shoes - and interestingly the Forces Quest is based on the Quest 1 (the older model) and not the Quest 2.  This may change at a later date, but as of this review the Forces Quests are based on the Quest 1.  These shoes are all Black or Navajo in color - AND come in a Non-GoreTex version as well as the GoreTex.  Check out TacticalGear.com or USElite.com - very cool shoes, and a great choice for those like me that still like the Quest 1 better.Now onto more details .....  First - I have owned Salomon Quest's since they came out with "Version 1" a few years back and bought my first pair in 2010.  I have since owned two pairs, and when I went to purchase another pair a few weeks back, I was surprised to discover there was now a Version 2 out.  I had not paid close attention to the Salomon new releases and only found out about the newer version recently.Second - my son wears Salomon Quests also, and my other son is on his 3rd pair of Salomon Comets (the Quests little brother).  And to pile on even further, one of my boys wear Salomon XA shoes as his every day shoe to school.... and my wife has a pair of Salomon trail runners!  So let's just say our family has logged a fair amount of miles on Salomon Quests and Comets,  plus their other offerings.The biggest reason I opted for the Version 1 Quest is they were renowned to fit people with "hard to fit" feet like mine very well - wide in the toebox, low volume in the forefoot, and a thin low volume heel. (think duck foot but not yellow!).  The Version 1 was cut tight across the forefoot, had a tight heel cup and the side and toebox taper / flare was perfect for a wide foot.  Most of all, the area over the forefoot and toebox was not overly elevated and cut tight, meaning those with thin feet did not have a bunch of extra / unneeded room.Version 2 is a fine shoe...no doubt.  But they are definitely cut differently, and some of the features in Version 1 have changed in Version 2 that changed the game for me, and have resulted in me opting out of the new Quest 2.  Most won't really care or notice these changes, but those who targeted Version 1 due to hard to fit feet might be disappointed.  The biggest change has to do with the volume increase over the forefoot and over the toebox.  The Version 2 is cut higher and simply has increased the volume in those areas significantly.  If you put the two Versions side by side, it is easy to see this.  The Quest 2 is just "taller" than the Quest 1.  Next, the cut of the area on the outside edge just below the toe box has a more narrow / aggressive slope, meaning those with wider feet may find the Quest 2 tighter and uncomfortable on the outside edge below the baby toe.In actuality, these changes probably mean they will fit MORE people and result in more people with normal feet (unlike me) to fit into the shoes - so from a business perspective, it was probably a smart move by Salomon.  But for me, I have already begun my search for the older version, and plan on buying an extra pair or two of the Quest 1 to put away since the fit me so well.  Again, the Quest 2 is a fine shoe, and carried forward the great quality and reputation from the Quest 1 - but the changes were enough to make me look elsewhere.Hope this helps one or two folks who may have purchased the Quest 1 for the same reason I did! -)  I would still recommend Salomon Quests to anyone that they fit correctly.In closing, just wanted to add I mostly use the Salomon Quests for day hiking, or in situations where I am not carrying more than 25 lbs in my pack - my legs / feet are older and I prefer a heavier / sturdier shoes for the heavier loads, but for younger legs the Quests could be fine for heavier loads.  I know of some that use the Quests for heavier loads.  I also have no issues using the Quests on rocky / rugged trails, they perform well on smooth and rough trails.  The only thing they don't get a passing grade on is cactus spines - I have had one or two find its way in due to the softer sides.Oh, one more thing - there is a good news / bad news ending here - my son, who does not suffer from the duck foot problem I do - actually likes the fit of the Quest 2 MORE than the Quest 1, and wants to buy a pair!!  So even in our family there is a split decision on the Quest 2.  But as I already said.... it is still a fine shoe.Thanks for reading!UPDATE 4/10/2015:  I purchased a pair of Salomon Quest 4d Forces GTX from USElite (Navajo in color) - which are modeled after the Quest 1's.  For me, it is a keeper, it checks all the boxes, and seems to fit like the earlier, 2011 version of the Quest 1.  (the later versions of the Quest 1 were cut more like the Quest 2 than the earlier Quest 1).  I wanted black, but for some reason the GTX version in black goes 12 to 13 with NO 12.5 offered (that may change) so I got the Navajo - and you know what, the color has grown on me... I like it!I also tried the Non-GTX version of the Quest Forces, but for my foot, tastes, there was something about the non-GTX version that just felt off... I returned them.  Still a great choice for those seeking a non GTX version.  Note also that opposite of the GTX version - the Non GTX DOES come in 12.5 in black, but NOT in Navajo.Additionally, I found a pair of Quest 12.5's online in the Audobahn / Black / Flea - got them for $160 and they are on the shelf for my son for later this year when he wears out his current pair.  With these, I am going to make the last stand on Quest 1's and see where it goes from here.... still hoping Salomon returns to the cut design of the Quest 1 from early 2011 / 2012 timeframe (with the beefier tongue, leather, slimmer cut, etc)... but doubt that will ever happen and sure those are history.

Salomon made a winner with this boot - it is one of the few boots that is durable enough for light backpacking, yet light enough to use for day hiking also - plus it has a Gore Tex lining to make them high water resistant.  And oh, did I mention they are also a very comfortable boot?  (assuming they fit your foot type).How are these boots cut, and how do they fit?  First off, my foot type -  have a thin foot in girth, wider in the toe box with the widest point under my baby toe.  Plus, my forefoot is narrow and I have a thin / low volume heel.  For my foot type, shoes are hard to find, especially hiking boots.  For me, if the shoe fits in the toe box, it might be too wide in the forefoot, or my heel slips because it is so thin.These boots are cut perfectly for my foot type, and they lock on tightly to my heel.  They are probably the best fitting hiking boot I have ever owned.  If your foot is wide in the forefoot, or thick in or over the arch, or you have a high volume heel - this boot make not be the best for you.  These narrow considerably in the forefoot, and if your forefoot is wide, these will be uncomfortable IMHO.Moreover - if you like to put custom footbeds, orthopedic inserts, etc into your boots - forget it with these boots... you have to see them to understand why, but these were simply not made to accommodate even the thinner custom footbeds or inserts.  If the footbed is very thin and cut just right, maybe - but again footbeds are not ideal in these boots.I like these so much I wear them for yard work at home also, in addition to hiking.  I would buy these again in a heartbeat - five stars for this buyer!!Thanks for reading!

I have purchased Mediabridge HDMI cables numerous times, in addition to their Toslink Digital Audio cables.  Every time I have purchased them, I have been satisfied with the packaging, delivery and overall quality of the cable.I use Mediabridge for a 65" Panasonic VT60 among three other TV's in the house - and in all cases, they are all you need for optimal picture quality.You could pay more, but why?  Remember years ago when all the TV retailers would charge $100 for cables like these, and try to convince you that you needed to spend that much to get the quality??Well, those days are over... if you want the best bang for the buck going - buy these.  End of story.Thanks for reading!

Before purchasing this mouse, I was using the Logitech V380 Bluetooth / Wireless mouse for about three years.  The V380 started acting funny, so it was time to look for a new one!  Well, when I searched on "Bluetooth" mice, it appears the choices have narrowed over the last few years, and the USB mice have become the better quality / lower cost option.After looking around, it was clear the Logitch M325's rated well, and that they were a top seller.  Based on this fact alone, I thought I would give one a try.  The only thing left was - what color??? ;-)  I usually don't fret too much about such things, but then I saw this "Circuit Board" design in a bluish color - and WINNER!!  That was what I chose.Bottom line - after a couple of months of use, I am extremely pleased with this mouse.  The USB plug is low profile and does not get in the way on my three year old Sony Vaio laptop, and the mouse itself can be used on most any surface with great tracking!  One thing I liked about my Bluetooth mouse was that it worked on most any surface - same with this one!!The M325 tracks well, is portable for laptop use, and it fits nicely / ergonomically in the hand.  I have had some minor challenges with getting the right double click rhythm down at times, and once in a while it does not highlight a single word in some apps with a double click - but other than that a great little mouse!Would recommend this to anyone looking for a good portable, versatile mouse!Thanks for reading!

The Spot 90 is also a darn good headlamp, and I have owned one for over a year.  I also recently purchased the "new" Black Diamond  Spot 130 headlamp, and I am writing a review about both the Spot 90 and 130. If you were thinking of getting this headlamp, give the newer model Spot 130 a look too - I paid the same $30 for each... your call!  You get 40 more lumens and a couple new features, read on! Either way, the Spot 90 is still a darned bright, well made headlamp!!I have owned a number of headlamps over the years, and for $30, Black Diamonds have become my "go-to" choice because of the price to value ratio - not many headlamps possess the same quality for such a great price!  These do "retail" for $40, but Amazon has them for $30 and now that the Spot 130 is out, getting the Spot 90 for $30 is easier.Here is what I like about the Spot 90:-- The quality - these lamps are well built, and built every bit as good as a Petzl. My Spot 90 is over a year old, has seen heavy use and looks like new.-- The large on / off button - although still not perfect with gloves on, it is easy to operate and does not require too much pressure and fumbling around! The Petzls I own have a smaller button, and sometimes it takes just the right pressure to turn it on, and can be a little harder to locate instantly.-- The fact it has a red / night light mode - I like to do astronomy, and this is invaluable to maintain night vision!-- The head band - good adjustability, comfortable.I am still trying to find out what I don't like about the Spot's - for the price, it is hard to find anything wrong with this headlamp. I guess maybe three levels of brightness instead of just two - high and low.I use my Spot 90 (and now will use the 130) for MANY uses, including:-- first, for night bike riding. We have a handle bar mounted Cygolite for the main light source, and the Spots for the head lamp. When you are riding, and turn your head to the side of the trail to look, you want to be able to see what you are looking at. Handle bar lamps always point straight ahead...-- Camping - of course... when there are no city lights, a bright headlamp is a must!-- Daily chores around the house - my 50 yr old eyes constantly need a back up when doing virtually every chore - just yesterday I had it on my dome as I updated the plumbing valves on all my sinks. I always have one close by, for even the simple chores of more light to read fine print, etc. An invaluable tool, and have made my flashlights obsolete!Comparing tee Spot 90 to the Petzl line of headlamps from a cost perspective - consider the Petzl XP 2 retails for $59.99 and gives you about 80 lumens of light. And to surpass the output of the Spot 90 in the Petzl lineup, you are going to shell out $89.99. Petzls are FINE lights, I own 4 of them of different types, but with the price / per lumen and the quality level of the Black Diamond Spots, my last four headlamp purchases have been the Black Diamonds.So what are the differences between the Spot 90 and the Spot 130?-- How about an additional 40 lumens of light!! And you can really tell the difference between the two.-- When you power on the Spot 130 it defaults to the high intensity beam. To get to the low power beam, you have to push the button twice rapidly. When the Spot 90 is powered up you randomly get low or high power, depending on which mode it was on the last time you were using it. If the 90 does not power up in the mode you want, you have to press once for off, then once more to turn it back on for the correct mode. I like the new 130 defaulting to high intensity beam - most of the time it is the mode I want. On the Spot 90, it is annoying to potentially have to press it three times to get it there - obviously someone at Black Diamond agrees!-- The hinge system on the new Spot 130 seems to be beefed up and more substantial - on the Spot 90 it just seemed to loose.From a technical spec perspective, the Spot 90 and Spot 130 are very similar:-- Both weigh 3.2 grams;-- Both have a rated burn time of 50 hours on TriplePower LED, 200 hours on SinglePower LED;-- Both have a rated distance of 75m on TriplePower LED, 15m on SinglePower LED;-- Both run on 3 AAA batteries, both have a 2 LED red light mode-- One has 130 lumens, the other 90 lumens max outputThanks for reading!!

OK... it's a funnel, and as a funnel, it does the job - not much to write about there.  I was not "floored" by the fit / finish of the funnel, it does say in the Description "made of high density polyethylene" which should mean it is food-grade.  I own a number of polyethylene items, and this I am not 100% convinced it is of the same quality.The finish on this funnel has a bunch of swirl marks / scratches, and it is not finished to a smooth appearance.  Plus, I am not entirely sure where it is made, it has an American flag on the label, but does not actually say "Made in USA".  In fact, it does not indicate country of manufacture on the label.Not a bad funnel, but not enough quality that I would give it five stars!Thanks for reading.

What follows is a long-winded review, read this around bedtime if you are having trouble falling asleep! ;-) For those seeking the Reader's Digest version - overall, I think the Freiling French Press, though expensive, is the best French Press money can buy. I have tried offerings from 4-5 other French Press makers, including Espro and Bodum, and the Freiling IMHO has the highest quality build, has the best heat retention capability during the brew cycle, and will be the most durable long term due to its 100% 18/10 stainless construction - no plastic parts here!!. It is one of the very few 100% stainless French Presses you can find - plus it also a very attractive vessel to boot! I actually leave it out on my counter due to its good looks!! There are many good reasons why the Freiling French Press are the best sellers, and why reviews here on Amazon are so plentiful and positive. Amongst those reasons are quality, reliability, consistency and durability.Do realize however, that just because you spend the money and buy a Freiling will NOT guarantee you will automatically start making great coffee - as with any French Press the method is more important than the tool! You must pay attention to ALL of the variables involved in correct coffee extraction procedures - if you want the best coffee possible with a French Press, it is all about the process - assuring correct brew temperature, you use freshly ground beans, you are using an adequate grinder that grinds to consistent texture, and more!! Below I offer some tips to assuring a great cup of coffee with the Freiling, those may help in your pursuit of the perfect cup!!Just as important - do realize that the Freiling is a BREWING vessel ;-) and not a STORAGE carafe. You will see in the reviews that some complain the Freiling does not keep their coffee "hot" for hours - the coffee should only stay in the Freiling for around four minutes to brew, you will need a nice storage carafe to keep it hot thereafter!! Those that keep the coffee in the press with the grounds after the four minute mark are destroying the taste. Moreover, even if you transfer the coffee out, and remove the grounds and then use the Freiling as your storage vessel - you would be much better served purchasing a separate carafe to store the coffee when done. The Freiling is NOT an ideal storage carafe. (For example - I use a Zojirushi glass lined carafe for my needs).***End of Reader's Digest version - now on to the details!!Here is what I like about the Freiling Press:- Double Wall carafe construction - this is both ideal and necessary for the ever-so critical heat retention during your preheating and steeping phases.  The method I employ can hold brew temps between 195 and 204 throughout the entire steeping / brewing phase, and I could never accomplish that with other presses made of glass, plastic, etc. Some have claimed that the Freiling is vacuum sealed in addition, but it is not - it is double walled and that is it.  *** Note - I typically keep my brew temps around 200-202 degrees - please Google "SCAA recommended coffee brewing temperatures" for some background on correct temps to brew / extract coffee**- 100% 18/10 stainless - beautifully finished, but it is more than just good looks - the thick stainless assures the press will last for a long time and it will aid in heat retention already mentioned. It is durable and virtually indestructible if used with any modicum of care and not dropped daily on the tile! My 33oz Freiling is 3 years old, and it operates like the day I bought it. Plus, it still looks good also - other than a couple of minor scratches to the polished stainless exterior.- Top / Plunger assembly comes apart for thorough cleaning. You get a sense of the attention to detail and the cost it takes to make a Freiling press when you disassemble the constituent parts that make up the top / plunger. It wreaks of quality through and through... the fact it can be disassembled, and remains 100% stainless is no small feat, and a testament to the quality - and why it costs so much. Consider what it takes to be able to deliver this assembly - and why competing press makers don't!- Double walled top / lid - I already mentioned the double walled carafe - but the fact the lid is ALSO double walled construction is worth calling out- again, the competitors don't even approach this and even make their tops / lids out of PLASTIC says it all.- They are darned nice to look at! Let's face it - they are an attractive vessel.Here is what I don't like about the Freiling:- Price - this one is more of a whine ;-) and not anything wrong with the product, but hey, I can still not like it! Bottom line is I would still buy it again.. To make it less painful, I got this 44oz version for $98 here on Amazon - it was in my cart for over a year in the $125 range, and when I saw the price drop temporarily I jumped on it!- The top on my 33oz version had a weld seam failure around the hole where the plunger is inserted - causing the top to fill with water that I could not get back out. HOWEVER, Freiling sent me a new top when I asked with no hassle... it was a "one-off" problem and don't expect it to happen on my other Freilings.- I can't think of anything of substance I DON'T like about the Freiling - if you learn how to use it, perfect your method then this is the top of the heap when it comes to French Press. It is the best tool for the Press job IMHO.I have owned the 33 oz Freiling Stainless Press for a few years and have used it almost daily to make my morning coffee (except for the once a week I use my Technivorm drip brewer). Therefore, I do have experience with Freiling's presses, and understand how to best utilize them to squeeze out the optimal cup of coffee.Some pointers / things to think about as you pursue the "perfect" cup of coffee:- Make sure and pre-heat your Press and storage carafe in advance - don't put your coffee / boiling water into a cold French Press; and don't put your finished product in a cold storage carafe!!! (google it, this affects the taste). At a minimum, use hot tap water to pre-heat, which usually gets to 130-140 degrees. Personally, I use boiling water to pre-heat - you can boil it on the stove, or perhaps use something like a Zojirushi hot water kettle / boiler that is ready in advance when you wake!- Use fresh beans, and grind the beans right before use. Coffee beans are best within two weeks of roasting, and most store bought beans can be MANY weeks old by the time you buy them. If you can find a local source for your beans that are fresh, do it. You will notice a marked improvement in your finished product.- Buy a decent quality grinder. The $20 blade grinders are just not good enough for French Press - it needs a consistent, coarse grind. At a minimum, I recommend a Capresso Infinity for around $70, then use the "Coarse" settings, dialing it in to where you eliminate 95% of the sludge in your cup. I use an Orphan Espresso LIDO hand grinder ($150), and alternate that with a Capresso Infinity. You can also get a Baratza Virtuoso if you want to spend more! The grind is CRITICAL - it needs to be the correct coarseness - but more importantly needs to be CONSISTENT. Consistency is the main challenge for most cheap grinders on the market.- Assure your steeping / brewing temperatures are in the 195-204 degree range. This is not my own recommendation, this is the "proven" range for the best coffee extraction. Invest in something like a Thermapen, or a cheaper temperature probe, that allows you to test the water temperature while steeping. Another critical step to success. For my brewing, I stay in the 200-202 range typically during the four minute brew cycle.  *** Note - please Google "SCAA recommended coffee brewing temperatures" for some background on correct temps to brew / extract coffee**- Depress the plunger SLOWLY when it is time, doing it too fast will cause sediment. Also, if the plunger seems to get "stuck", lift it ever so slightly, then depress again!- Fill the water level BELOW the spout depression / line in the carafe when filling for brewing / steeping. This will help guarantee less grounds in your finished product.To summarize - now that you have spent the $$ on a top of the line French Press, consider getting a good grinder that can consistently grind on a coarse setting without a lot of "fines" in the grind; considerr purchasing a good temperature probe (like a Thermapen to check your temperatures of different components throughout the process to find what needs tweaking; consider getting fresh coffee beans. This will give you an even better cup in the end... also, search the web for you tube videos, etc on different processes, find out what works best for you. Once you experience a "perfectly" executed cup of press coffee, you will be hooked!! ;-)Thanks for reading, and best of luck in your choice!

Once you experience a "perfectly" executed cup of press coffee, you will be hooked!! ;-)Thanks for reading, and best of luck in your choice!

These meters are good for what they are, and for the cost.  For a $20 meter, and then paired with the Calibration Solution (342 NaCl), these can be a fairly accurate, reliable meter.However, if you are looking for repeatable precision, where you get the same reading on a consistent basis, plan on spending more on a better meter.  You will find that these TDS-4's will have a little variance, and often times more than the + / - 2% claimed.  You can easily get different readings in the same solution if you try also.This DOES NOT mean this is a poor meter - for the cost, this does a bang up job.  Some things to help you get good readings:-- Turn off the meter, then turn it back on before each reading.  It IS a little more hassle, but it will help with accuracy.  The instructions say the same thing, and there is a reason for that.-- When changing solutions / water sources to be measured (like when going from tap water to RO, etc), turn the meter off, and gently shake the meter to get the water trapped in the tip out.-- Sometimes when you submerse the meter, there will be an air buble trapped in the tip.  Gently swish the tip around to release the bubble or you will get skewed readings!-- If you drop the meter, you will probably need to recalibrate it!For the price, I would recommend this meter!  Just don't expect $100 build quality and precision, that is not what this meter is!!Thanks for reading!

Apparently this movie resonates with some people. Maybe the only way to find out is to watch it. But for me, it was a disappointment. The dvd jacket makes it look like two people having a fun time but there was a lot of ugliness (in behavior and character) and many, many unrealistic scenarios, including the main premise, that these two very different lead characters fall in deep love in the course of a few hours.For those that care, yes the two leads are married to other people. No, they don't "do" much of anything aside from what would be called emotional cheating.Here are the sort of things that drove me crazy (not in a good way):The Mom behaves very rudely to another tour group, interrupting their tour and dredging up her own family dysfunction in a rant. One person in the tour group responds with some minor sarcastic remark like "Thanks for sharing!" Then the dad, the uptight conventional heart surgeon, makes him (the recipient of the abuse) apologize instead of the other way around!The dad has a fear of heights which the mom miraculously cures in a few minutes atop the bell tower.The two parents steal bicycles for an extended joy ride around campus and this is supposed to be funny?Both parents completely ditch their children on an important college tour that was supposed to be a bonding experience. They don't even meet their kids for lunch and they lie to their kids in order to prolong their escapades with each other. Besides being an awful life choice, it's unbelievable, particularly on the part of the dad.I didn't exactly find it boring and I did watch it through (maybe because I was sick and didn't have anything better to do) but it was not an enjoyable experience.

"Grip you with its emotional power?" "Mesmerize you with its magic?" I don't think so.SLIGHT SPOILER BELOW BUT YOU WOULD KNOW THAT PART WAS COMING RIGHT FROM THE GET-GOIt started out kind of interesting, then as the lead character got more and more into the hundred names, it wandered all over the place with a lot of cardboard characters. There were so many incidental characters that from time to time when a name would pop up I either didn't remember ever seeing that name before, or I couldn't remember who they were.After about the middle, when Kitty finally "gets it" but the reader still doesn't, I just kept reading to see what the connection was, which in the end was very anticlimactic.Lots of unbelievable parts, no motivation given for how so many characters suddenly blossomed or became completely different. Lots of high-school-like "love" interest--oh, does he love me or not? oh was that a friendly hug or does it mean something more? oh what did that look mean?--and in the end pretty much everybody pairs off predictably.In my life nothing works like that. A bunch of random people, most with issues, would not have a jolly good time together as well as find true love. Everything tied up too neatly. The author tried to leave a few strings hanging but it didn't offset all the happily ever afters.I was irritated by this sort of writing:"Ashford Private College was situated on Parnell Square beside the Irish Writers' Centre, which faced the Garden of Remembrance and other such important venues as the Gate Theatre and Rotunda Maternity Hospital."Was she getting paid by the word? None of those names mean anything to me, they don't create a picture in my mind, and it's all completely irrelevant to the story. Maybe Irish readers get something out of it, I don't know.If you're stuck somewhere and this is the only book available, or the choice is Stephen King or this book, and you hate scary books, then by all means read this book. Otherwise find something else. I have not read anything else by this author and now I probably won't.

I have been using Almay Sensitive Skin Fragrance Free Clear Gel. They recently changed the container so I've been checking out alternatives. I am totally fine with the Almay product itself.This Dry Idea flunked badly. I definitely could see a white sheen where I applied it. About 20 minutes after applying, I put on a black tank top, then changed my mind and took it off. There were white marks all over the tank top.This deodorant had a very noticeable chemical smell when first applied. Sometimes my morning routine gets interrupted and with the Almay, it's really hard to figure out whether I've put deodorant on or not (I'm not a morning person so I'm on automatic). Would never have that problem with Dry Idea, if the whiteness isn't obvious enough, the smell is obvious for at least a half hour.The container is not much different than the Almay although I found it harder to dispense just the amount I wanted. The old Almay had a few slits instead of the dots and I found that easier to control plus it didn't ooze out as much if I threw it in a gym bag and it ended up on its side. But the new Almay has all the little holes just like everybody else.

My daughter mentioned she was going to see this film (in another state) and I thought it would be fun if I watched it too. I was shocked to find it at my local "machine that dispenses movies."I almost quit watching in the middle and probably would have except I didn't want to have to admit that to my daughter. But in the end I was glad I watched the whole movie.I wouldn't recommend it if you're mostly looking for laughs. It's more of a thinking person's movie with a few comic moments.

I enjoyed the first part of the book and was looking forward to perhaps some profound insight....well....I personally identified with many themes in the first part--feeling stuck and adrift in a location not of one's choosing, a custody battle with the social worker distinctly in the ex's camp, a surprise home visit, a stacked deck of a parent-teacher meeting. Wow, I've been there and she nailed it.Then somewhere in the middle of the book, I felt like I had been duped into reading a romance novel of the very kind that the heroine is being pressured to write. Granted, none of it is very explicit, but there was scene after scene of virile manhood, lusting women. Suddenly everybody is sexy, attractive, and compatible. Along with the harebrained and completely unbelievable idea of the whorehouse for women.I continued reading to see how it all turned out, a little too neatly for my taste, and based on subterfuge and blackmail rather than insight or personal growth. So, more like beach reading than anything else.

I was expecting a cat and mouse story of a painting hidden away, changing hands multiple times, hidden from or stolen by the Nazis until finally rediscovered in some obscure location. This book is nothing like that. The painting was pretty much in plain sight the whole time and the story of its repatriation is a complicated one of love, high society, women's rights, Nazism and collaboration, and institutional and national denial of that Nazism and collaboration.I wasn't looking for another book on the Holocaust but that's what I got, from a new and fascinating perspective. It was positively frightening and astounding to learn that even 60 years after the fall of Hitler, Austria and Austrians were still whitewashing their involvement, refusing to give back treasures that any average lay person would agree had been stolen, allowing documented Nazi experimental "physicians" not just to live in peace but even to teach medical students! And to learn that the U.S. knowingly hired Nazi scientists for our rocket projects!This book covers a lot of territory, really giving you a feel for the age, providing very personal experiences, while not dwelling too long on the horrors, all the while entwining the details of the portrait. I wish I had realized sooner that everything has been documented page by page in Notes at the end of the book, although there aren't actual footnotes.Sometimes the author's writing is obtuse and you're left trying to figure out the meaning of a sentence. Definitely it is hard to keep track of all the characters but I feel I got the gist of it even if maybe I have missed some details.I have a print of Klimt's beech forest on my wall, just because I like it. I never knew anything more about him and never particularly cared for his gold paintings, but now they appeal to me in a different way. Just seeing Adele's portrait brings to mind that whole era as well as the undying love her husband had for her. Whether or not she had an affair with Klimt, and what to think of his treatment of women, there's a whole other thought-provoking avenue to explore.

I just wanted light comedy diversion while home sick. While I like both of the stars, I don't think this is a movie they brag about.Very hokey, full of stereotypes, not particularly funny. The twins' accents miraculously morph so no one ever suspects anything based on how they talk. In fact towards the end of the movie they all talked the same and I could not keep track of who was supposed to be who.The only well done part is when the four twins are finally in the same place at the same time.Being very sick, I watched the whole movie anyway, but I would never recommend it or rewatch it. Maybe if you're a big fan of the Beverly Hillbillies.....

I have a pumice stone I've had for years and it's down to almost nothing. I have never been able to find another similar quality natural pumice stone till now, although after purchasing this one I noticed natural stones in the health food store.I am very happy with this. It is most definitely natural, no perfume or smell. I use mine dry even though everybody says to use it wet. It does not get icky or moldy and can be washed and dried as needed.I was not prepared for how gigantic this thing is. It is the size of my closed fist. I could not possibly close my fist around it. So it's a little awkward to use, I'd really rather smaller, but I'm happy to have it just the same.

I already have a SWE Autochron Wireless Wall Switch Timer (sorry, the Insert Product Link is not working). I wanted another timer for a different room and thought I would try this one. This timer would turn my switch on but not off. I tried several times. I also tried the Autochron on that switch and it would not turn the switch off either, so it's something to do with that particular switch which is pretty old. So I returned this unit and will have to devise Plan B.Also, FYI, I had to buy a standard face plate for my switch which had a wooden plate that left the switch too far recessed. Not a big deal, just another step.Some comparisons of this unit vs. the Autochron:-- Woods is smaller and narrower.-- Woods is easier to program.-- Autochron is easier to install and remove, a distinct advantage if you want it out of your way inbetween vacations.-- Autochron allows you to open the battery compartment and manually turn the switch on or off, in addition to pushing a button like on the Woods.Because I do not leave my timer in place all the time, I much prefer the Autochron unit. One screw to install. The Woods requires fumbling with two tiny recessed screws in addition to two screws through the face plate. However I have to admit that the Woods is more stable in place because it uses both face plate screws, but under normal use the Autochron performs just fine.

UPDATE:Router worked fine first day. Next day I noticed slowness and speed test result was 1.5 mbps! (60 mbps yesterday)When I unhooked the router and just ran the pc through the modem only, I got my 60 mbps back. Hooked up the TP-Link again, 1.5 mbps. Reinstalled my old Linksys WRT54G2 v1 router, I had 60 mbps again. That's all the troubleshooting I'm doing. I am returning the TP-Link to amazon while I still can. I will probably look locally for a more up to date router (the Linksys suffers from WPS vulnerability).My original review was 4 stars:"Some trouble getting set up, a few minor complaints, but a good deal for $20"Unlike most others, it seems, I had to do some troubleshooting getting this router set up. It comes with a flier with special instructions for error messages relating to cable internet so I am not the only one with this problem. First I just tried inserting the cd and following the directions but it failed.In case of failure it gives you an option to go back and try a cloning process which also failed. Then I tried starting at the beginning again and doing the Easy Setup with cloning, no go. I followed the troubleshooting for cable instructions (several pages of fine print but not as bad as it looked), again no go until the very last step (to be followed if all else has failed) of rebooting both modem and router, then finally Bingo.Perhaps rebooting would have taken care of it earlier in the process. My modem takes a long time to get up to speed and I had already unplugged it before attempting to install this router so I was hoping to avoid doing it again.I was also hoping to see full speed on my Nexus 7. I am getting 60 mb on my wired pc. With this router I am getting 26 on the Nexus vs. 18 previously, so an improvement, but not what I was hoping for. I am measuring the speed when the nexus is practically right next to the router.The Quality of Service, aka Bandwidth Control setting, is not at all intuitive. Other reviewers rave about it but I don't have a clue even though I am looking at the manual. I'm fairly savvy about computers but this process calls for entering "IP range," "port range," and egress and ingress measurements in Kbps. I'm not sure how bandwidth is allocated if I do not set up any controls. Not a big issue for me but one I had hoped to experiment with.The sideways power block required me to get an extension cord to plug this thing in. Oh, and the port colors are exactly opposite of my old router (blue/yellow) and are labeled as and referred to as "WAN" and "LAN" rather than ethernet and internet. Not too hard to just follow the illustration but my cables are blue and yellow so it's a little mind-boggling to set them up opposite. This router comes with one fairly short cat 5 cable in neutral beige.My product was brand new in a plastic-sealed box. Can't tell about longevity or customer service at this point. I cannot find anything indicating a warranty anywhere on the box, on the paperwork that came with it, or online, but at this price point it doesn't matter much. Most companies require you to send in the defective product at your own expense which nearly negates any benefit.There is a toll-free 24/7 customer service number. In case you need it when you're offline, it's 1-866-225-8139, but I did not try it myself.

My daughter came back from a trimester in Mexico with some of these. She loves it and was all excited to get me to try it on raw vegetables. I like it just fine, not totally crazy about it like she is, but I think it's a good addition to my spice cabinet. I'm looking forward to trying it on popcorn.The little bottles are adorable and I thought they would be cute little additions to the care packages I send to my grown kids, as well as there being enough bottles to keep some for our use here at home.I bought from Colby. It came very promptly even though we're getting into the Christmas rush. It was well packaged and the box is all sealed and has an expiration date 10 months out.

Perfect for my teenage daughter who lives in her boots all winter. She likes the ease of a slip-on boot and that's really hard to find sometimes! The laces on these are just elastic and don't really do much.Most of her footwear is size 10 and that's what I ordered in this boot. It is snug but comfortable, with just a thin sock, which is what she likes to wear. She thinks the "fur" will gradually squish down, making them not so snug after a while.The bottom rubber section makes for dry feet in slushy conditions. They have good tread and a good brand behind them.This is not an Arctic boot. While it's quite warm, if you work outside or stand around for hours in Arctic conditions, you probably need a more serious boot.Made in the USA.UPDATE: Ultimately these gave my daughter blisters although still wearable.

Very well made and a great idea, very ingenious. However, I know it doesn't say this, but I thought the small size would be a lighter weight rope, but it's not. The first thing I noticed when I pulled it out of the package was how heavy it is, and the rope is quite thick and hefty. My dog is just under 15 pounds. I read more than one review from a chihuahua owner which led me to believe this was sized for smaller breeds, not just in length, but not so. I realize this is my own misunderstanding, just giving you a heads up. I can't even imagine a chihuahua wearing this thing, but apparently some do.I gave it a whirl anyway. For me, it's actually trickier to get on than the step-in harness we have been using. My dog kept trying to bite it as I tried to put it on her, which does not usually happen with our regular harness and leash. I imagine that would get better.Tried actually walking her with it and she still pulled. If anything, at one point she smelled something interesting and braced her legs against the ground harder than ever. So, no improvement on that front.It's marketed as escape-proof but the instructions do have a disclaimer, sorry I don't remember what it said exactly, something about not allowing slack somewhere. I sometimes pick my dog up to avoid an unpleasant doggie encounter and she has managed to slip out of her regular harness while being held (and squirming). I was afraid something similar might be possible with the Harness Lead.I can see where this can be a great option for dog shelters or multiple pet owners because it's easily adjustable to fit different sizes of dogs.

I have continued to wear an old ragged parka because I have not been able to find a replacement at a reasonable price till now. This jacket packs a lot into one reasonably priced package:  * Pit zips  * Besides handwarmer pockets, another exterior zipped pocket for quick access to money or key  * Storm flap over main zipper (I wish the pocket zippers were covered but they are not)  * Snow skirt and a zipper to attach pants  * Great insulation including sleevesI will address some issues I read about in reviews here and on other sites:Yes it runs small. I normally buy size medium jackets and they allow me lots of room for layering. Not this one, but it is so warm I won't need layers. I am  5' 2" and weigh 118, hourglass figure, and this jacket is snug and is about mid-palm length. From the back neck seam to the hem in size M is 26 inches. The jacket itself has a distinct hourglass shape.Yes all those snaps on the front flap are a nuisance, but to slip in and out of it quickly, you can get by with just snapping the bottom two snaps and the rest of the flaps stay in place well enough.It's definitely very warm and not appropriate for warmer weather skiing. I was looking for warmth and I'm using this for streetwear. When it's bitter cold I just want to be able to put on something really warm and not mess with umpteen layers. I generally leave the pit zips open.The hood can be cinched on either side of your chin as well as at the center back of your head.The sleeves do not have inner cuffs, which I was worried about, but I can snap them on the smallest setting without having to undo them to get it on and off, and I think it will be just fine.It is heavier weight-wise than my last parka but doesn't feel heavy on me. The fabric does not feel too stiff. I can't test out the waterproof/breathability just now, but the specs are good and it has a good company standing behind it.It has just a one-way zipper, which I prefer, but if you definitely want a zipper that can open from either the top or the bottom, this jacket is not the one for you.I am so happy to get a new jacket with a unique design at a price I can afford!UPDATE NOV 2015: I have had more than one perfect stranger compliment me on this jacket and I am totally happy with its looks and performance..

UPDATE:My daughter did in fact come home with an active lice infestation. I spent about half an hour going over her head and found 6 lice and 3 nits. To check for lice I used the pointy end of a rat tail comb and systematically checked her scalp in sections of about an inch or two. I figured the more lice and nits I removed ahead of the treatment, the less chance of one managing to escape the gel.This gel was just fine to use and not as slippery and drippy as I remember the lotion being, plus much shorter time frame overall. After 20 minutes, I used handfuls of cheap shampoo and worked it into her hair before trying to wet it. I probably used a good cup of shampoo, and then I did a second lathering (the first go-round of shampoo hardly even lathered after wetting). It came out fine and left her hair feeling very soft! Then I scrubbed the tub well to remove the slippery residue.I had checked at the Hedrin website before deciding how much to buy, and I wish I had bought more. This 100 ml bottle barely covered my daughter's long thick wavy hair. I made sure to get her scalp area very well but I was just barely able to work it down to the ends. Hopefully no lice scurried down there to escape if any had missed my pre-treatment examination.This is what the Hedrin website says:"How much will I need?A little Hedrin goes a long way. The amount needed depends entirely upon the length of hair to be treated. A 50ml bottle should be sufficient for a two-dose treatment of short hair. Longer hair or multiple treatments will require a larger bottle."My recommendation is, if the person's hair is thick and down to the middle of their back, you'll need more than 100 ml for a single treatment of the gel. Possibly the lotion, being runnier, requires less, but the runniness is what makes the lotion potentially less effective (and you have to leave it on for hours).WHAT FOLLOWS IS MY ORIGINAL REVIEW:Disclaimer: I have not yet used this exact product (read on, I'll explain) because my daughter is currently out of the country where she picked up head lice and was treated with who knows what. She wanted me to be ready to check her head and re-treat when she gets back home. I was so delighted to find that I can now order Hedrin through amazon!To explain, when my daughter was younger she got head lice twice and we had fabulous success with Hedrin Lotion (a friend just happened to be traveling in England at that moment and brought it back for us, after I discovered it through my internet research).Since then, Hedrin has been perfecting their product and they now offer Hedrin in a gel form (this product) which had excellent results in clinical trials. Evidently the gel is easier to apply and sticks to the hair and lice better, resulting in a better kill rate in a shorter time. Other than one being gel and the other lotion, they have the same active ingredient and strength.The product title on amazon says 15 minutes and the description says 1 hour. 15 minutes is the latest recommendation, based on actual studies, and that's what's on the box.The bottle I received is from a recently manufactured lot with an expiration date almost 2 years out. I ordered this on a Sunday and found it in my mailbox on a Monday just 8 days later, COMING FROM ENGLAND, even though the expected arrival date was 4 to 6 weeks after my order date. Yay!!In previous dealings with lice, we have used Nix (which is very toxic, stinky, and doesn't kill eggs so has to be done at least twice plus studies are finding very low efficacy because of resistant strains of lice), Cetaphil lotion (google it; I found the smell so nauseating and it so hard to get out of one's hair that I was ready to go back to Nix), and Hedrin lotion (hands down winner).I don't know why the US doesn't come out of the dark ages and license some of the newer treatments that are not toxic. You can buy them in Canada and overseas. And they are not some quack treatment--Canada's health service will pay for them for instance.I have now discovered that here in the US we can buy LiceMD Pesticide Free which is also a dimethicone product. It's licensed as a cosmetic (although it's in the head lice section of the store) which I guess means it doesn't have to go through the more exhaustive FDA approval process for drugs.LiceMD promotes itself just as an aid to nit-combing, but if we need a second lice treatment after the Hedrin, I am going to try LiceMD and see if it seems the same. I have not been able to find what percentage dimethicone it has, to compare it to Hedrin which is 4%. I can buy LiceMD locally as needed which of course is more convenient than sending off to UK. But hey, I was impressed with the delivery, and the gel may be just the ticket.You can search online and find various studies and clinical trials comparing different treatments, their results, and their safety. No product offers 100% because of possible human errors in application--miss one tiny section of hair and there might be an egg left to hatch out--so careful application is very important.This product is very slippery and hard to wash out of hair, but otherwise it is way less objectionable than other treatments. As far as the slippery-ness, just one drop on the floor could cause someone to slip, and you will have to scrub your tub/shower well afterwards to avoid falls. When we used Hedrin before, we had a utility sink for washing it out which was a great option.

I always set lamp timers when I'm going to be out of town, but realistically, it's the ceiling lights that are frequently on when I'm actually at home. Up till now I've been rigging up a floor lamp, minus shade, with very bright bulb, on a lamp timer, to try to mimic my typically brightly lit kitchen.This gadget makes it happen! I am testing it out now and so far so good.I'm not sure if I'm going to leave it installed since my next trip is 5 months away, but it's simple to install and uninstall, held in place just by the lower screw of the faceplate (they provide a longer screw to accommodate the thickness of the device). While the timer allows for manual override, this is a switch I often turn on and off and I think I'll want the ultimate convenience of just quickly flipping the switch as I walk by.The programming is a little tricky until you get the hang of it. I wrote out some notes for myself. Sometimes you hit Enter when you think you would, sometimes you don't, but once you play with it a little you will see that it's actually pretty easy. You can go in and change just one part of a program if you want (i.e., change only the OFF time).I think the weirdest thing, and most counter-intuitive, is that as you start to set a program, say for the group of days M-F, and you have set the ON time, when you go to set the OFF time you have to reenter the M-F again or it will program the OFF time for some other default day. It's no big deal to hit "DAY" a few times to get to M-F again, it's just not what you'd expect. The first time I tried programming, I ended up with the timer set to come on at 6 for MTWTh but off at 8 just on Tues.I highly recommend you program it before installing it, just for comfort and ease of accessibility--not the timer's fault--it's just much easier to be sitting at the table in good light compared to bending over in front of a light switch--especially the first few tries when you're probably going to mess up and have to redo it.

While this movie has its funny moments, "sweet" and "heartwarming" are more descriptive of the movie overall. I enjoyed it, but my expectations were in line with what I got.It's kind of like reading a human interest story in the newspaper. I like that once in a while. If you're really looking for laughs, look elsewhere.

If your idea of a fun movie is sitting in on someone's marriage counseling, by all means watch this movie. However, that's not my idea of a good time and frankly it wasn't even interesting. I borrowed this movie from the library and the blurbs on the case used words like "funny" and "comedy," but they lied.I thought with Steve Carell being some big therapist the couple had to fly out of state to see, there was going to be some humor there but his part was totally straight and very conventional. I have no idea why anybody would spend big bucks for such therapy, a brand new college grad could have provided the same quality of therapy. Even with us (the audience) sitting in on the therapy sessions, we never really learn why the main characters have ended up the way they did. And a LOT of the movie consists of therapy sessions.Yes there were a few chuckles here and there and a heartwarming ending, but I really only kept watching because with such good actors I felt sure it must get better (wrong).If you don't agree with my review, please just enjoy this movie, write your own glowing review, and don't slam me. I'm entitled to my opinion and maybe someone else will benefit from my review. Sorry to be on the defensive but movie reviews seem to be a world unto themselves. I'm just trying to be helpful. People will read a variety of reviews to try to get a feel for a movie and I'm just giving my take.

When you just want an enjoyable movie for entertainment or relaxation, this is a good one. Mostly a comedy with a few touching scenes and episodes, nothing too heavy, well done, with a number of my favorite actors. Overall it will leave you with some chuckles and a good feeling.

The authors, principals in Skyline Group International, Inc., a Silicon Valley-based human capital solutions company, contend that too many people waste their time working on their weaknesses. A better strategy is to focus on the neglected skills in the middle.One quoted study backs this point up:The Sales Executive Council also looked at the middle performers (the middle 60 percent) that produced $271 million. Getting 5 percent more out of them would yield another $13.5 million--almost double what you would get out of the high performers! Although the top salespeople achieved much higher sales individually, it didn't make sense to squeeze another 5 percent out of them versus 5 percent out of each of the middle performers.What I liked best about this shirt, but oh-so-valuable book was the accompanying free online Hidden Strengths Assessment.In addition, I liked the five-step Hidden Strengths Development Plan:1. Find your motivation.2. Identify your goals.3. Choose your Hidden Strengths to develop.4. Turn your Hidden Strengths into Learned Strengths.5. Evaluate your progress.

The author, a columnist I enjoy reading in THE NEW YORK TIMES, shows that there is life for those who don't make it into Ivy League schools. In fact, students are often better off for not having been admitted--and become even more successful as a result.The real key, as Bruni repeatedly points out, is what the student does in and out of the classroom.If you have a child not yet in college, please read this book. It will get you thinking about is really needed to prepare for college admissions and whether it is essential to spend thousands of dollars on such things as prep courses, pre-college internships and specialized counselors. Also, it will get you to rethink the entire system of college ratings.

The author, a favorite of mine because of such other thrillers as PARANOIA, POWER PLAY and VANISHED, has another winner here.This one involves a single father who finds himself in need of money. So he takes a loan from the father of his daughter's new best friend and then immediately finds himself in trouble with the Drug Enforcement Agency.I was drawn into this book from the very first paragraphs:Sometimes the smallest decisions can change your life forever.Abe Lincoln's bodyguard decides to stay for another drink at the bar at Ford's Theatre during intermission.The archduke's driver makes a wrong turn in Sarajevo because he refuses to ask for directions. (Men, right?)You finally listen to your know-it-all brother-in-law and invest everything you have with a guy named Bernie Madoff. Steady returns, dude. A no-brainer.The tyranny of small decisions, someone once called it. The gate of history turns on small hinges.Danny Goddman's nightmare began with a quick handshake and a friendly smile.The various twists and turns kept my interest throughout. There's a great ending, too.Lastly, Finder's attention to detail especially impressed me. As I was reading the book, I kept wondering how he knew so much about so many topics. And then I read the Acknowledgments, which detailed all his research into such topics as the details of the Drug Enforcement Agency, computer forensics, explosives and Aspen.

This book is a companion to The History Channel's series of one-hour documentaries on the same subject. I'm now sorry that I never watched that, if only because this was so informative.The author, a professor of the University of Oklahoma, makes history come alive.He doesn't write about such famous events as July 4, 1776, or the day Neil Armstrong set foot on the moon. Rather, he concentrates on some less well-known but historically sihnificant events that changed America.In doing so, I learned about the significance of January 25, 1787. That was when the men of Shays' rebellion attacked a federal arsenal and started this nation on the path to a strong central government. I also found out about January 24, 1848, which was the beginning of the Gold Rush in this country.My only regret is that I never had Gillon as my teacher when I was in school. He presents his material in a most engaging manner.

The author, a licensed clinical psychologist, scientific researcher and interdisciplinary narrative construction worker, takes a new approach to the subject. He doesn't give you any meal plans, nor does he tell you what food to avoid.Instead, he presents a process to help you decide on what foods to eat, and then he has you plan ahead one day. So all you need to do is have the willpower to stick with the decisions you have already made.It sounds simple because it is.In particular, I thought what he had to say about treats made a lot of sense:The process of plotting out one's upcoming indulgences in treats; i.e., the process of making sure one always has something to look forward to, makes it so much easier to set reasonable limits on the self.

This is the 19th book in the Harry Bosch series about an LAPD detective. I've read a few of them and am always amazed that they hold my interest.They also manage to feel different in their plots. In this one, Bosch teams up with Lucia Soto, a newcomer in the department, to solve a murder that has gone unsolved for some ten years. During their investigation, they're led to another unsolved case--this one involving the deaths of several children in a fire that occurred twenty years ago.I especially liked THE BURNING ROOM because it enabled me to learn more about Bosch, the man, with regard to both his daughter and a reporter that he begins dating.There's a great ending, too.And kudos to Welliver for his narration. I was grateful for the fact that he didn't try to make his voice sound female when a female character was saying something; rather, he just kept his normal voice for those passages and that was just fine.

The author, previously head of business development for a large regional bank, decided to leave his job so he could set off on a six-year journey to see the earth's remaining wilderness. He visited New Guinea, Uganda and Togo, among other locales, and wound up hunting with the Pygmies, feasting with former cannibals and attending a Madagascar highland death ritual.Along the way, he also lost his wife to divorce, fell sick several times, got robbed and found romance.He even managed to find humor in such things as contemplating a personal ad that a Huli male might post when seeking a mate:Great Huli warrior with many pigs, hard strong hands, has been growing out beard for many moons, seeks ideal partner. Must be Huli, have dark, short, dirty fingernails, and at least a 2-finger gap between front hairline and back hair. Pig raising and gardening skills a plus! Also has to be a good provider and self-sufficient.This was a very readable book that will give you a fascinating perspective on places that you will probably never visit.My only disappointment had to do with the fact that there were no pictures in the book.

This is an engrossing first book by an author who spent 25 years in the nursing home business.He tells the story of what it was like to grow up as part of the only Jewish family in a small Southern town that's not far from where I now live. In addition, he explains the title; i.e., why you can't coach height.I very much liked this book because it reminded me of my childhood days when I would hang around with friends and plays such games as the one Kaplan did:We actually invented a football game that we could play on our knees using the one of the small, six inch toy footballs. The "field" was the distance from the front door down the hall past the dining room to the entrance to the kitchen. I can't believe we had more than two to a side, maybe three. It could get rough and end up with carpet burns on knees and elbows. There were day long Monopolly games, card dames, all kinds of ways to entertain ourselves without parents, without television, without computers.
