To put it another way, it wasn't just that he wanted to be less shy, and that he wanted to be able to talk to women. Rather, he had been operating under the absolutist conviction that he needed their approval. Later, he would coin a name for this habit of mind: "musturbation." We elevate those things we want, those things we would prefer to have, into things we believe we must have; we feel we must perform well in certain circumstances, or that other people must treat us well. Because we think these things must occur, it follows that it would be an absolute catastrophe if they did not. No wonder we get anxious: we've decided that if we failed to meet our goal it wouldn't merely be bad, but completely bad-absolutely terrible.And Burkeman shared this neat way of behaving at funerals:* Francisco parked the van, and we walked into the cemetery. It took a moment for my eyes to adjust to what I was seeing. Many of the gravestones were only rough concrete slabs, or stubby pieces of wood, but almost none were unattached. Next to each, sitting in folding chairs, or cross-legged on the ground, were groups of two, three, or four people, sometimes more, holding murmured conversations and drinking tequila from paper cups. In one corner, a mariachi band in full costume strolled from grave to grave, serenading every headstone in turn. I stopped a woman who was carrying armfuls of rugs and chairs towards a nearby headstone, and asked what she was doing. "Oh, it's my mother," she said brightly, gesturing at the grave. "We come every year."I don't think that THE ANTIDOTE has made me a negative thinker. However, it has made me open to the possibility that there are many different ways to look at happiness.

Heard HOW SUCCESSFUL PEOPLE LEAD: TAKING YOUR INFLUENCE TO THE NEXT LEVEL (Hachette Audio), written by John C. Maxwell and read by Chris Sorenson.Though this is a short book, it is packed with powerful ideas taken from the author's most requested speaking topic that he has presented to FORTUNE 100 companies and leaders around the world.To cite just a few of them:* Titles are not enough. They are ultimately empty.* People not positions are a leader's most valuable asset. It takes no time to let others know that you value them.* If somebody on your team can do a task as well or better than you can, give him or her responsibility for it.* Helping others grow and develop brings great joy to any leader.* Helping others develop their potential enables leaders to become world class.* If you've become successful, it's only because a lot of people have helped you along the way.I've enjoyed several other books by Maxwell with respect to leadership. This is up there as being one of his best.

BLIND CURVES: ONE WOMAN'S UNUSUAL JOURNEY TO REINVENT HERSELF AND ANSWER: WHAT NOW? (Opus Intl.) by Linda Crill is an engaging book about a former corporate executive who lost her husband to cancer. To shake things up, she learns to ride a motorcycle in just four weeks and then heads out on a 2,500-mile trip down America's Pacific Coast Highway.It felt like I was part of the author's learning curve every stop of the way . . . what she went through also got me thinking about my life; for example when she observed:* In most of life, I take living for granted and assume I have plenty of time to accomplish anything I want to do. Since time seems so bountiful, it's easy to waste it doing nothing. How often have I spent a whole evening in front of boring television, eating unsatisfying junk food, feeling sluggish and dull? In moments like these, life is cheap and its exquisite value unappreciated. But at times when I am pushing life to its limits, there is recognition of the volatility of life. In these moments life is priceless. The present moment, all moments, become sacred. Full attention is paid to each second-to each detail. Nothing is missed or unexamined.In addition, I'm now rethinking my future vacations because of the following tidbit:* Arthur Frommer said in his travel books that the purpose of a vacation is to provide contrast. To me the best vacations were the ones that offered a change in weather, location, activity, food and routine. This vacation had certainly succeeded in doing that. I had chosen a radical departure from my solitary life. For the past nine days, I had spent few moments alone.And I was especially touched by how Crill described the love story that was her marriage:* Two hours later my name was called over the loudspeaker, and I was escorted to Bill's bed in post-op. He was still groggy from sedation, but it was reassuring to see him. I instantly relaxed, leaned over his bed's side guard, touched his arm, kissed him and told him I loved him.Bill smiled up at me.After a brief conversation he asked, "So what did they find? Is it a virus like we thought?"Shocked that no one had told him the results of his surgery, I tried to disguise my inner panic. It was up to me to deliver the diagnosis no one ever wants to receive or report. I knew Bill would not want me to tiptoe around the truth so I told him as gently as I could."The doctor said it's cancer, probably mesothelioma." I awaited his response, unable to predict his reaction.He pondered for a moment, then smiled up at me and smiled up at me and said, "but I haven't had my fifteen minutes yet.""What?" I said."I haven't had my fifteen minutes yet.""What?" I asked again, still not comprehending Bill's answer."Everyone's supposed to have their fifteen minutes of fame before they die. I haven't had mine yet. "Even if you're not a motorcycle enthusiast, you'll like BLIND CURVES. The accompanying illustrations by Kevin Miller will add to your enjoyment of the book.

Heard THE ASTRONAUT WIVES CLUB: A TRUE STORY (Hachette Audio), written by Lily Koppel and read by Orlagh Cassidy.It's a fascinating look at the women who stood behind America's Mercury Seven astronauts in both triumph and tragedy. They all started as military spouses and morphed into American royalty, appearing on the cover of LIFE magazine and becoming fashion icons.Some had picture-perfect marriages; others had to deal with divorce. Yet they all stayed friends for over half a century. This book provides an engaging behind-the-scenes look at women you may only have known by name.

THANK YOU FOR LISTENING: GAIN INFLUENCE & IMPROVE RELATIONSHIPS, BETTER LISTENING IN 8 STEPS (CreateSpace Independent Publishing Platform) by Marc Wong contains practical advice that will enable you to be a good audience and contribute to a conversation, as well as show you how to provide support and encouragement.The author brings in examples from such diverse fields as movies, poker and women's shows, and these help to bring home such points as the following:  * When a physician listens respectfully, and ask questions and picks up on clues, patients tend to be more involved in their care, more open about what's wrong, and better informed and more satisfied with their visit. Satisfied patients also have fewer hospitalizations, doctor visits and lab tests.* Philosophical questions aside, if you tell a joke and nobody laughs, then you know how it feels not be heard. Of course, your joke or perhaps your delivery might not have been perfect. Nevertheless, your sentiment was not acknowledged or shared. If you think you have a great sense of humor, but your spouse never laughs at your jokes, then you know how frustrating it is to never to be heard. You feel unappreciated. The other person doesn't "get" you. You don't feel validated.Wong also provides several insightful exercises, including this one:* Try to pick an unusual topic. See if you can come up with some good questions about this topic. For starters, choose situations in which you stand to gain by developing rapport. For example, if you're on a first date or with a new client and she mentions kites or bonsai, what questions would you ask to get her to elaborate on the subject?As a listener, we should also be aware that people exaggerate. Sometimes we exaggerate for comedic effect.  All the "Your mother is fat..." jokes are based on exaggeration. We also exaggerate to highlight our frustration. "I'm going to quit this stupid job and go join a circus!" "I'm going to hit the next person who says 'paradigm' or 'think outside the box'!" We're not necessarily going to join the circus or hit anyone. We just feel so frustrated that we want to do those things. If we're allowed to talk freely about the reasons for our frustrations, we'll most likely calm down and forget about the exaggerated threats.We learn many things in school, but rarely is listening taught. THANK YOU FOR LISTENING may well help you fill that gap in your education.

Heard THREE NIGHTS IN AUGUST: STRATEGY, HEARTBREAK, AND JOY; INSIDE THE MIND OF A MANGER (HighBridge Company), written by Buzz Bissinger and read by Jeffrey Nordling.Bissinger, author of the classic FRIDAY NIGHT LIGHTS, was hired by St. Louis Cardinals manager Tony LaRussa to write this study of a three-game series between his team and the Chicago Cubs in August, 2003.Ordinarily, you might think that such a narrow focus would be overkill . . . but the author manages to keep your interest on every page by incorporating background stories on such players as Darryl Kile, the star player who died in the middle of a season; Rick Ankiel, the pitcher who lost the ability to throw strikes; and the incomparable  Albert Pujols.If you're a baseball fan, you're going to love THREE NIGHTS IN AUGUST.

If this toaster didn't have a window I probably wouldn't buy it, but I definitely wouldn't bother replacing it.  It's a good toaster, fancy red color, cool touch exterior, and window notwithstanding.  Ah, but it has a window!I've always wished I had a toaster with a window, and while my dreams or world peace and more leg room on airplanes have generally been ignored, we now have this.  To be honest it's a little anticlimactic, and the toast toasts so fast, it's not like it makes that much of a difference, but it's there.  The ceramic tubes do a good job of not only toasting bread but doing so in a relatively even manner, and the plastic exterior stays cool under most home toasting scenarios (use it 3-4 times in a row and watch out).It's been a while since I've used a toaster (somehow I got on the toaster over path), and I forgot how much better these dedicated units toast.  You give up some flexibility in regards to bread size, but it accepts most bread stuffs.You can't go wrong with this model, but it's not quite toasting nirvana if you want to try something else.

I have a Stuhrling Original watch for a few years now (yeah those cheap automatics can last while--albeit with quirks), and after getting the crocodile strap I added to it wet one too many times, it started getting a little gamey.  The watch itself is fine (close enough), so I decided to breath new life into it!My order arrived within a couple days in a rather large box (large compared to a flat padded envelope I expected), and it looks more or less as indicated here, although if your eyes see royal blue in the picture--it's not.  It's navy as indicated in the title (kinda wished for royal, but it looks good).  No instructions or pins were included, so keep your old ones handy (or order more).  The hardest part was removing my old strap. Once that was out, you put the pins in sans strap and thread it through (there are tons of guides out there).  The strap barely slide through the gap between the pin and case, but it works and I don't feel there's undue pressure being applied.  The whole process tool less than five minutes with 3-4 of that being spent removing the old strap.The length is good (I have a largish wrist), and it has ample holes for smaller wrists and a means to deal with extra slack.  There are no frays or other defects, and the stitching seems good.  I don't anticipate any issues, but if there are any, I'll update this review.  Frankly I expect the band to outlive my watch.

This is a lot to pay for a rock tumbler, but ...This is by far the best model I found complete with all of the bells and whistles, and is quiet (and gets quieter as the stones smooth out) to boot.  You can set the number of days, it can handle a ton of rocks (well 2lbs), offers speed control, and protection against thermal overload (in case you put too much in there).  I've had no leaks and while some of the stones are blah, many look amazing!Do note this really takes patience, as the steps take days, but your simulating what may be decades of natural effects, so it's not that bad.  The real benefit comes with interacting with your kids (or whomever you partake in this with), experiencing the science, and the thrill of the reveal.  As noted in the Q&A section, you can use any rocks (up to a certain size) and grit.  Thus you can use rocks you find in your travels!Back to the price, if you compare it to other tumblers and even vaguely similar devices (for different purposes) such as marinading machines (yeah, there's such a thing), water tight tumbling devices that can hold pounds of stuff generally cost this much or more.

I enjoy Steam in home streaming via my ultrabook (my gaming desktop does all the work), and this makes for a quick, precise, and familiar controller.  While the cord would normally be a hassle, here it's easier than attaching a dongle to my laptop, and it's ready to go in seconds.  No driver or anything to worry about.  For most users, I recommend the adapter to use the wireless controllers (which have flooded the market), but that's more for the freedom of no wires,  Otherwise, this is perfect.

This worked beautifully in replacing cracked glass on a 13" Macbook Pro (~2010).  My only advice is to remember that the rubber gasket around the existing glass will become easily damaged by metal tools especially with heat.The glass panel arrived securely packed and free of any blemishes.  The back (seen in the pics) peels off easily and the attached tape secures it to the frame.  Be sure to have the frame ready (I heated it a little prior to mounting the glass to help adhesion) and free of the old tape, glass, or other debris.  You'll be rewarded.Just about anyone can replace the glass, but don't be surprised if it's a little intimidating.  With patience, the right tools, and care with the heat gun, it's not that hard.

This is a versatile tool kit, and it worked great at opening up a Macbook Pro (cracked glass).  It would work well for most phones and other devices.  The tweezers always come in handy, as does the roll up case.  My only complaint is that the thinnest pry bar has a plastic cover that melts.  As the metal pry bar of this nature is often used to pry glued on screens off using heat, it would have been nice to have it wrapped in something more like a silicone.

It fits true to size (kinda important due to tungsten's nearly indestructible nature), and it looks better in person.  Doesn't look fancy, but it doesn't look cheap or gimmicky.  The ring has proven to be very durable and comfortable.  I may upgrade at some point, but this will always make a good ring when working on a car, snorkeling (how I lost my last ring), and anywhere softer metals fail.

I ordered this to upgrade an old Compaq (HP) laptop with an AMD CPU.  It replaced a problematic OEM DIMM and immediately the problems went away.  Didn't do much besides swap the modules (and ran some memory diagnostics) and it's worked perfectly.

Other than the iPad Pro, iPads aren't exactly meant for keyboards, and the Mini is probably the worst case scenario.  It's not that people don't need keyboards or can't use them (otherwise this wouldn't be needed), but the deck is stack against device makers like Zagg.Despite that, I see this as a success.  It pairs easily and quickly and is quick to resynch.  It's not quite as natural as a dedicated keyboard ALA Asus Transformer or Microsoft Surface, but you don't miss out on much.  iOS begrudgingly accepts Bluetooth keyboards, and you get everything else you love about iPads along with a keyboard.  The Mini creates another challenge due to its size.  Zagg has done the best they can with a tight layout, and it;s not too hard to get used to, though it'll never be as natural or as fast for me as a full keyboard.  It really shines when used by kids, who are just as likely to use an iPad as a PC, and the size of the keyboard (and iPad Mini) suits them.Other things to consider: the case secures to the iPad nicely and the included kickstand is quite nice.  It almost makes for a modern netbook like experience, though iOS is snappier than any netbook I've used.  While I imagine you could pair this with just about any Bluetooth device (without the whole case experience), I've yet to try that.In general I'd recommend an iPad Air if typing on an iPad is expected to be a primary use, but if you want a keyboard for an iPad Mini, I'd strongly consider this one.

I've acquired quite a few devices, and they all have Bluetooth.  Most however lack a keyboard, so this is quite convenient.First off it pairs easily with everything (Kindle Fire HDX 8.9, Windows 8.1 HTPC, and Samsung Note 5), and it's easy to switch between all of the devices while remaining paired.  With those two features, I'd deal with a bad keyboard and other hassles.  It doesn't have a bad keyboard--actually it's better than I expected.  I wouldn't say it's great, but the key spacing and travel make using it natural.  When using with a Windows PC (or Mac) note that this is just a keyboard and you'll probably need a mouse, but for my HTPC, all I need is a keyboard (to do occasional searches where using the remote is a pain).  I haven't reached the end of the range, and given the uses this is designed for, range won't be an issue.  Speaking of those uses, the ability to prop up a phone or tablet makes this much more useful, and while the keyboard is larger than most tablets, it's not likely to be too big for class or travel.  It's not the most robust device, but I didn't feel the need to be overly concerned about wear and tear.

I wanted to doubt the speed of my AV600 kit.  It doesn't.  It's hard to say what the issue is, and I get that turning electrical wiring into ethernet is magic in itself.  I did get 25-40% bump in speed, and if I were buying one, I'd get the Power Line 1200 with the pass through. This works, but you'll need a separate power strip, and it will need a particular kind of plug (most will do, but some angled ones will cause issues).  As with all of the TP-LINK gear, it's easy to setup, as well as secure (optional but recommended).  The connection is stable, and all in all I'm rather satisfied, but I'm left wanting a bit more of a bump in speed.Another thing to consider is whether or not one device is all that needs ether.  This (and all of the other Power Line gear) works well enough as a bridge, but you may still need a switch or an access point to serve more devices.  Of course you can add a switch or access point, but when you combine that with the possibility of needing a power strip (which may need room to plug the access point and or switch into), all of a sudden you got a lot going on.  None of this is a negative as much as an item to consider.  They make ones with a switch, but those are slower; likewise there are Power Line equipped access points, but they are older.Anyway, this works, and it works well.  It could be faster, but it handles high bit rate 1080p fine, and I'd get the 1200--just the version with the pass through.

It's kinda ironic that this is pictured on a MacBook Pro, a product from a company know to put aesthetic design at a premium even over usability and definitely over cost.  It's ironic because the GeekOut V2 looks like a homemade creation of a mad scientist that you bought at the flea market!  Perhaps a middle ground would have been best.Looks aside, it sounds great and like any other USB amp/DAC, it's plug and play.  The only real setting is the hi/low current setting to drive large cans that have higher resistance and avoid blowing out earbuds.  Everything sounds amazing whether I'm using my Ultimate Ears TripleFi in ear monitors or my Audio Technica Sonic Pro over the ear headphones.  Top quality FLAC sources have a richer feel than 128kps MP3s, but the added clarity and warmth still enhances the MP3s.  In short I wouldn't buy this purely to make Pandora sound better, but it kinda does.  The audio quality on FLAC sources makes this worthwhile.The biggest knock is the homemade 3d printed shell.  It's bad.  It works: nothing overheats and the plugs fit where they should, but I've seen better made Kinder Eggs!Highly recommended audio

This is a nice fleece on many levels.  It's relatively soft, and I can only imagine it will get softer, it's just about the right weight, and the little one likes it!  It is very loud, and it almost seems more at home hunting than on the playground!

I got this as a perk for completing a bunch of training from Intel (one of the few nice things about computer retail), and until that moment, I didn't even know Intel made liquid coolers.They don't really make these, as it's a licensed Asetek clone, that Asetek (or whoever they have build their systems) makes.  That's not a bad thing.  What you get is a complete setup for Intel CPUs LGA115x, LGA1366, LGA2011, which is pretty much anything folks buy these days.  One of the benefits of being an Asetek clone is all of the compatible mounts (not included but available), so yeah you could even put this on an AMD CPU or a video card.  Installation was easy, though the hose isn't too long.  The included fan is a nice 4 pin one, though there are better ones out there (you can replace it, but if that's your thinking, you may want to get the Corsair or another AIO water cooler).  My temps lowered and the system remained quiet, though it was quiet and cool to begin with.This is a good setup, but it's not the best.  When you combine the price, the simplicity of installation, and results, it's a 5 star solution however.  Recommended to newcomers to water cooling.

I loved my Gigabyte Windforce 980, but I not only wanted to gain the sizable bump from the 980 to 980 Ti, but also to move away from air cooling to a simple AIO water cooled setup.  FWIW, most uses will be happy with a reference 980 Ti, but I like the cooling setup here.As I've moved to smaller and smaller cases (I've owned towers bigger than my Saint Bernard), it's getting harder to keep the contents cool, especially when those are at the extreme end of things.  I used a all in one cooler (Corsair 105) on my i7 4790k to great effect, but my video card would make a bit more noise (the 980 and 980 Ti generally are very power efficient and have limited thermal demands by high end video card standards), so I wanted to nip that in the bud.The 980 Ti is amazing.  It swallows up 1080p at any setting and 1440p isn't too much trouble.  4k is certainly possible, but some games will need some reduced settings (mind you at 4k just about anything looks amazing), and there's always SLI!  Just about any 980 Ti card will give you this.  Some will have a higher base of boosted clock, but the differences are minor.  If the above is all you want, get the cheapest 980 Ti from a reputable seller.  As noted earlier, I had a small case and wanted to run cool and quiet.  I've noticed that you can be fast, cool, quiet, or affordable--hell you can even pick two or even three.  You can't do all four!  This comes close (by 980 Ti and water cooling standards).  You do trade off some of the ultimate performance, as the memory and VRMs are air cooled, but the air cooling is great, and all of the heat from the GPU die is taken away.  The included fan is ok, and rarely adds much noise.  The GPU die is much cooler, and while I haven't done much overclocking (it already comes with a higher clock than most 980 Tis), I've seen some push past 1.5ghz (vs 1ghz base clock for reference 980 Ti, but all seem clocked a bit faster from the factory).  Anyway if you're looking to get some added speed for your investment, it's there.The market for AIO liquid (or in this case liquid + air though EVGA does sell a liquid only solution for a custom loop) cooled video cards is limited, especially for Nvida.  There are a ton of BYO solutions, but I didn't want to do that.  As a result there is a price premium, though now that's dropped to a small premium.  At $699 this is a great deal.  At $799 or so, maybe not.

Steam in home streaming is a killer feature many people don't know about.  I love being able to use my gaming system anywhere in my home, and there's rarely any issues with lag or image quality.  Traditionally you needed a system (could be Windows, Linux, or Mac) running steam to be the client (plus a Windows PC host with appropriate hardware for your games).  The client system could be old, slow, or both, as long as it had a strong network connection and ability to decode HD video streams.  This turned my ultrabook into a gaming setup on the couch while my wife and I watch a movie or TV.Anyway, this takes that idea and turns the software feature into a standalone hardware product.  It's not a bad idea, and it works great (I only tested via gigabit ethernet).  It does everything I expect from the software Steam in home streaming, and it doesn't require a PC.  It saves a little power too.  I'm kinda regretting getting this, as that's all it does.  I kinda wish I could do steam in home streaming on an Apple TV, Roku, or Kindle Fire TV (think you can sideload the hacked Nvidia clone, but I've had bad luck with that on Android), as there's really no other use for this.  It it could run Kodi or something, I'd understand.  For now, it's a $50 one trick pony.  Note there's no controller, so it turns to closer to $100, though you can use that elsewhere too.It's not bad, not do I recommend avoiding this.  Just know what it is.

This is a tough product to review, but suffice to say it's not a game pad in the traditional sense.  If that's what you want, use a Xbox 360 or Xbox One controller and the appropriate adapter for your PC.  They will give you that experience.So what do you get with the Steam Controller?  It can be a game pad, albeit with a bit of a learning curve, and if that's your only controller, you'll adapt soon enough.  Maybe 1-2 hours of gameplay, but even after that, you'll probably want to work on custom configurations.  It's not something you have to do, but to it'll help you get the most out of the Steam Controller.  Fortunately Steam makes the customizations (or borrowing someone else's layout presets) simple.  The real benefit comes from games that don't work well with traditional game pads, as the touchpad surfaces can make traditional KB mouse games playable, though there are some compromises.The build quality is solid, and everything you need is included (including batteries).  There's a dongle, but there's hardly any latency.  As I'll still be keeping my 360 controllers, I'll just have to have a dongle for keyboard/mouse, another for the 360 controllers, and this.  Ugh.So ... if you're looking for something different, go for it.  Otherwise, you can't beat all the deals on 360 controllers.

In an era where how headphones look seems to matter more than how they sound, it's great to restore the focus on audio fidelity.  After a brief break in period (honestly I couldn't wait to try these), I plugged these into my Geek Out v2 headphone amp and tried some of my favorite FLAC tracks.  I was immediately enthralled with the rich sound stage and the complete balance in the presentation.  The rich flat sound stage (better than any closed back headphones I've used) allows you to adjust things as you see fit with an equalizer, though out of the box these will lack the pop of a Beats or similarly bass boosted headphone. That's not to say these cannot produce bass or will leave you wanting.  Just tell them what to do (via input) and expect the best (and still get blown away).  On the flip side the treble is crisper than I can articulate.  I'm a bit hard of hearing from childhood ear infections, and I struggle with muddled sounds.  With these, I can hear details I cannot recall ever hearing.  Simply put, you'll have to pay 3-5x the price for anything better sound wise.The only real con is that comparable (in audio performance) headphones are generally built better than these, but as noted they cost a lot more.  You can also find headphones for this price with a better build, but they offer the sound of $25-30 headphones.  Anyway, it's I think Audio-Technica designed these with the best parts where it matters most, and these won't break anytime soon.  The detachable cable is a nice plus that will also add years of life to these.

While I understand the value of probiotics, I'm not that partial to kefir, yogurt, etc to get them naturally.  I've embraced various supplements, and generally have had good results.  When I looked at these I looked for the stated potency and looked for any adverse reactions.  The claimed potency (and variety of strains including Bifidobacterium Lactis) is top notch and my body has had zero issues with these.  I've tried it with and without food and have generally stuck to 1 pill twice a day.  As I started these after taking another supplement, I didn't notice a whole lot of difference (more than day to day changes my diet might cause), but that's ok.The cost is a bit high, but for the stated potency including Bifidobacterium Lactis (as opposed to acidophilis), you're looking at the high end of the market.

This is a nice though not remarkable knot hat.  There are others that exceed it in fit and finish as well as size (it's kinda big enough for my large head, but not exactly generous in size).  I'd look around for another option if I were you, but I'm not exactly disappointed.

It's an OEM battery and lasts every bit as long as the original.  The cost is the biggest challenge.  I kinda hate how Nikon has had 10 or so battery designs in the last decade, but there are a couple legitimate reasons for that (more than a couple questionable ones).

The long cord and four outlets spaced for transformers is quite the blessing.  I use it more or less as a power strip (it's hooked up to my UPS), so I cannot speak of any surges or other tests of strength.  The outlets are a bit tight at first, but no more than most strips and it's a good thing for safety and whatnot.  Otherwise there's not much to say.  I like it and when I need another strip with a cord this long, I know where to go.

These are nice fashion sneakers. They work well when I'm sitting at work, but I'd hate to do much more in them, as they don't flex well, have much arch support, or any cushioning.  If you're young, lightweight, or enjoy foot pain, feel free to walk 20,000 steps in these.  Otherwise, they're good sedentary shoes (maybe 4000-8000 steps).They look great however!

This looks far nicer in person.  It really warms up a room, especially a smaller one where the light can really shine.  It's not Tiffany, but it definitely looks classy for a college logo nightlight.  It's saved me from stubbing my toes or tripping on my dog at night.

As a Saint Bernard papa, I appreciate how these are nice thick and sturdy.  They are more elastic than most bags, and a tad bigger (boy does my boy need that extra space).  My biggest issue is that I've had bags that are hard to open, but that's a 1% of the time issue.  The perforations work great and I've had zero rips or other failures once there's a payload inside!  Sometimes my boy poops on twigs, which can cause issues with other bags. None here.  The size makes tying bags shut easy too.

I love the notion of a cross body sling, and Black Rapid is among the best.  I still don't like their (and most other similar models) clasp, as it's bulky.  I also don't like losing my tripod socket or more importantly losing the flat bottom of my camera.  There are other ways to clasp on, but out of the box it's an imperfect approach to a great idea.  The 2nd gen Luma Loop really knocked it out of the park, but Black Rapid sued them out of existence.  I merely added some mil-spec style QD swivels to this to recreate the Luma Loop and called it a day.The strap itself is well made though a bit thin (they sell thicker models), and it's more ambidextrous than the thicker padded models.  It adjusts well for length, and I have no doubts about it remaining secured to the camera.  The clasps and other metal hardware are definitely a notch above the knock offs I've bought.

I have three "wireless" printers, but all are near my server and much more reliable over USB and old school sharing.  That's fine by me, but adding a switch like this helps with wiring.  While the printers are USB 2.0, I occasionally plug one or two USB 3.0 hard drives in, so I went with this 10 port USB 3.0 hub.  It's powered, so I can and do plug any type of external hard drive in.  Setup is as easy as you'd imagine, simply plug and play.  Speed (for the hard drives) matches being plugged straight into the motherboard, so no issues here.  The only real "issue" is the oddly large power pack, but that's more of a curiosity than a problem, and it's not a power strip hogging wall wart.  I used my own longish Amazon Basics USB 3.0 cord, but the one that's included seems nice enough.

While this may not be for every cat (it's rather tall and narrow), ours love it (and a three other cat trees, so they're not finicky)!  The tall design that takes limited floor space is a bit unique, and it's a great solution for our finished basement with just one window way up top.  I paired this next to a more traditional (broader base and less versatility) to create whole cat complex.  They love this as much as the other, if not more.  There's a ton of scratching space, a few little cubbies, and ample shelves at different heights.  As my older cat likes to have some distance between him and his much younger (and playful) sister, this works great!  My cats never tried the tube (or any other tube on a cat tree).The build quality is very good, and I got it built in about 30 minutes (I've built a dozen or so of these over the years).  The instructions could be clearer, so I can see first time builders having some issues.  Once assembled, I have no doubts about its long term viability.  I do recommend securing the top as well to avoid and topples from aggressive play, and as such, it may not be best for all rooms (it does fit a range of heights).

If you've gotten this far, go ahead and buy these.  You will not be disappointed.  These lightweight crystal ornaments absolutely come to life on a tree.  The way they interact with light is frankly angelic, and the subtle colors allow the light to shine through in a way that a heavier application of color wouldn't allow.  Bravo!

If you like the picture, you'll love this ornament.  It looks far nicer in person, and it's a very classy ornament to keep and even better to give.  The included hanging tassel is also nicer than I expected, and it makes for a rather nice presentation on the tree or as a gift.

Generally I tend to use a wired connection whenever possible with desktops, but sometimes that's not possible.  My motherboard has wireless N built in, so I decided to upgrade to AC.Installation was simple, and the included half height back plate is a blessing for some older compact cases.  Another perk is the external antenna.  It's great!  It not only is detached from the card so I can place it anywhere (within a meter), it also has a robust (magnetic) base and it's own antennae.  I've used a few of these, and this is among the best antenna setups.  I downloaded the latest driver (6/23/15), and it installed nicely.  Since I have a wireless AC router, I was able to access at top speeds on 5ghz as well as Wireless N on 2.4ghz (this is the best one can ask for).  I didn't do any formal speed tests, but it was plenty fast for 1080p mkv files.I couldn't ask for more in a wireless card.  Some things to consider: if you have a free PCI Express slot, you can use this or a USB solution.  Do note that many USB solutions struggle with the power provided by a USB port (especially one on the front of the case) and need a powered USB hub for maximum performance (the internal amplifiers need more power).  Also, there's a huge difference on performance with the antenna placed where you want it (up top out from behind the PC or desk) vs stuck behind your PC.  This will get you the performance you want.

This is an adorable set that looks better in person than in photos (lots of fine details), and it's rather durable to boot.  It's a great foundation to start on, but you'll probably be buying accessories.  They're reasonably priced, and it gives you opportunities to keep things interesting.  The box even has room for the extra horses you'll be buying (one included).The jumps are nice, and there are a host of little nuances (break away jumps!), which show it's been well thought out by someone who's at least seen an equestrian event.You'll be quite happy with this!

For bagged tea, this is mighty fine.  It's a great mid afternoon tea, though it works in the AM as well.  One bag does the work of two for me (ymmv).  The favor is rather balanced, and it works equally well with sugar, splenda, and honey.  I haven't tried it iced (I have cases of Luzianne, so I'm set there), but I imagine it would work great there.  Not at all bitter.

I like this bag because it's a sling that fits a SLR with a vertical grip (I've used a D7100 and D750 in said configuration) and a pro midrange zoom mounted on it.  I can squeeze my Fuji X-E2 (with 56mm f/1.2) and Fuji X100s.  That's damn impressive.  I could swap either for a flash.  Its relatively comfy, and well built enough.There's a lot to like, but there's a couple things driving me crazy.  The dividers are poor.  Slick, semi rigid (more rigid that I like), minimal padding, and minimal configuration.  The outside and overall design is well though out, but my camera barely fits, not because the lens is too long (well that's the case with my 70-200/2.8), rather because of the padding.  You can't adjust any for depth.  The mini dividers only attach at one point near the opening.  Speaking of the opening, another issue I have is the upper compartment.  It's great, but the opening is a bit difficult.  Granted putting a mirrorless camera/lens up there is a bonus (you can do the same with Case Logic's smaller slings too!), but the opening lags behind the compartment.  Fix the lining of the lower compartment and this definitely is a 5 star case, and with the price around $40, it's the best out there in that range (by a large margin).Otherwise, as noted the overall design is nice, and the buckles and adjustments are well thought out.  It fits/feels ok on my back (I'm 6'7" and hefty so nothing really is designed for me), and there are handles.  The quality of materials isn't so much lacking, rather it's unremarkable.  Some brands have a much more premium feel.  For the price, I'm ok, but I'd love an upgraded interior.If you've got a battery grip on your camera, there's very little to choose from in the size range, and nothing for $40-45.  Hard to pass up.

To be honest, I wouldn't have ordered this if it weren't a complementary Vine item, but I'm glad I did.  I never even heard of such a ball, let along did I think it would work--it works!A friend of mine is a basketball coach, so I dropped by with this ball.  After getting curious looks of disbelief and questions as to if I missed the deadline on April fools, we started trying it out.  The players really responded to it.  It felt like a normal ball (a good one at that), but they could immediately track their stats.  That's the real genius here.  Most of us can seen when the ball goes in the net or not, but keeping track of shots made/missed in practice can be tedious.  Plus you can hook some speakers (preferably bluetooth) up and have this make solo practice a game and keep tabs.  It really works!Wow, this sounds amazing!  It sure does, but there are some limitations.  For now iPhone (or iOS) only (works on iOS 9 btw).  Android is coming.  It also isn't for tracking layups or dunks, rather it's designed for 7+ foot shots.  It's also not perfect.  I was hoping for 95%+ accuracy, but 85-90% accuracy (requires a net to work at all btw).  That's still amazing, but there's room for improvement.  Also it's more useful in solo practice, as there are plenty of other ways to make group practice interesting.  That's not to say it's not useful there, but $200 can probably be better used in that context.As a solo practice tool, this is awesome.  Like a fitbit or other modern doodad, this aids in accountability and adds a game like aspect to a mundane activity.  Sure great players have always driven themselves to taking thousands of shots a day, but not everyone has that focus.  This can definitely help, and while the accuracy is still a work in progress, over thousands of shots, it will show trends (and hopefully improvement).  Plus it talks to social media, so if by chance you and a buddy have one, you can share stats and trash talk on Facebook.  Isn't life grand!  On a more serious note, it can show coach, dad (or mom), that you're using it and getting your reps in, to help justify that expensive summer basketball camp.So is this a gadget for early adapters and hard core basketball players?  Mostly.  We all have different budgets, and for some $200 isn't much, but for many it is, and yeah, it's a niche.  It'll do more to help your game than a pair of fancy shoes or expensive athletic wear, and for the gym rats who put in hours a day working on shooting, this is a great (and novel) addition to the arsenal.  For everyone else, maybe wait a bit.5 stars if you're in the niche

I've owned several Panasonic shavers (Arc 3, Arc 4, older designs ...) over the years because I tend to like them, usually quite a bit.  With that in mine I had high hopes.To cut to the chase, this was a bit of a letdown.  It's still a rather good shaver, just not the best Panasonic by a good measure.The design is similar to what I've seen the past few years, and that's perfectly fine.  The weight was oddly light, and while a lighter weight shave can lead to less fatigue, here it just feels cheap.  The quality of the plastics don't help, and in the end the lighter weight made it harder to control.  Worst of all, the high degree of vibration present would be mitigated with added heft, and in it's absence it's a bit hard to use for longer periods of time.  I'm unsure how someone new to Panasonic would view the weight, as I'm largely biased towards a certain feel this lacks.The shave itself is good, though not great.  It can take a little time to break in, though I'm past that point and I'd say this is a slight step behind my previous shavers, though the lack of heft may mean I'm not quite using it right.  It's still a rather good shaver, but if you're already using a great one, you may be taking a step back.  One area where this continues Panasonic's prowess is the ability to use this wet or dry.  It may be unusual for you to use an electric in the shower or with soap, but it's a great experience (and entirely optional).  I've generally had better results wet, and this is no different.Charging is relatively quick, though the cleaning base is rather bulky and somewhat ungainly (fortunately it's optional).  Panasonic never quite got these right, and I think they're more of a way to get a revenue stream from consumables than altogether necessary.  Once charged you get an hour or so (many variables) of use, but you can't really tell how long.  The best of the best give you a precise measure, and here's you're guessing a bit with the limited LEDs.  The battery is a lithium one, which explains the lightweight and should provide years of carefree performance.I didn't really do much with the trimmer (I have a rather nice dedicated trimmer), though it seemed a bit flimsy (for what it's worth, I've had mediocre results from similar trimmers on Panasonic shavers).Overall this is a 4 star shaver, mostly because of what this (and all Panasonic shavers) gets right, especially the wet dry shave.  The price is good if you're looking for a cleaner (typically models in this price range lack that).  There are better Panasonics out there (look for deals on older Arc 4 models), but this is still better than most.  If you've used Panasonic before and prefer Norelco or Braun, this won't change your mind.

As digital has largely replaced film and applications like Photoshop and Lightroom have replaced literal photoshops and lightrooms the concept of a filter went from a piece of glass (or plastic) in front of a lens to a software function with sliders and other configuration options.  Sure you can still buy various colored filters, but for the most part, you can replace many filters in software.  Polarizing filters are one of a couple or so that you simply cannot replicate effectively after the shot.Much like polarized sunglasses or coatings on screens, windows, etc... polarizing filters reduce light transmission (not the intent of a polaring filter, but it's the most obvious effect) and more importantly reduce glare.  Simply put some light (that's polarized a certain way) passes through while the rest does not.  This means that water, glass, and other reflective surfaces no longer create distracting glare, and sometimes you can see through what you otherwise couldn't (which is why driving sunglasses are often polarized, especially with today's rather angled windshields). You can't really remove glare in post production, so a polarizing is essential for these situations.  There's even more benefit however, as these filters can do wonders with the sky.  Similar concept to what it does with water or glass, but the deep blues created by the effect are magical.  Do note that wide angle lenses can capture light from such an array of directions that some see this effect more than others, so YMMV with polarized skies on wide angle lenses.Onto this polarizer.  Simply put, it's about as good as it gets.  There are a couple niche vendors (Singh-Ray) that arguably offer comparable glass, but B+W makes some of the most solidly built filters (a bit more important with one that needs rotating like these) with a bronze body, slim (almost unbelievably so when you consider these take a cap) frames, and top notch German glass and filter coatings.  The ones used in this particular coating minimize the darkening (to allow for more control over ISO/shutter/aperture) and don't add a color cast.  Speaking of coatings, they minimize internal glare and make these easy to clean/keep clean.The biggest challenge is price and the fact that these are probably not going to be used all the time.  On a trip (I'm no pro, just an amateur who takes way too many photos), I may use it a couple times (more if I'm outdoors with beautiful clear skies).  It turns good shots into amazing ones, but given the cost of this, users on a budget may want to spend elsewhere first.  I do recommend getting a great polarizer, such as this, rather than skimping now and paying again later.

I originally ordered this as a gag gift--something for some holiday gift exchange, but my wife mentioned all the DIY recipes on Pinterest, so it piqued my curiosity.  I suppose the DIY recipes make sense, since this is all natural.  I didn't bother with them, but I did find this oddly effective.  It's a bit of extra work, and frankly I'm not that concerned with how my poo smells.  A few (three seems to work, but YMMV) sprays leave a lasting scent that seems like a nice bath, maybe eucalyptus.  No wonder koala's don't smell that bad!  The smell doesn't go away leaving you with the stinky reality of what you're covering up, rather it stays.  It really lingers--not that it's a bad thing.I can't see any reason why this isn't the best product out there that does what it does, so 5 stars.  Cost is the only real negative, but that's a matter of priorities.  Just know that you'll be spending $15 for 150 or so uses.  Is a dime worth avoiding embarrassment?

I tend to let my beard grow because I'm a bit too lazy to shave.  I have a ton of great shaving gear (silvertip brush, various soaps, German razor, etc...), but it's not so easy to do when I'm tired and grouchy.  If I let my beard get all loko, then the wife gets a bit grouchy (as she should).  I had other trimmers, and honestly they get the job done, but this--this is sweet.First off it has power.  Both to easily chew through some pretty thatchy beard and to do so a few times without recharging (I've had others that seem dead after 1 1/2 trims (albeit heavy trims due to the neglect mentioned above).  This makes short work of trimming and is a joy to use.  It's quick, and with the gazillion settings, can do whatever I need and then some.  The balance makes it easy to pull of the "and then some" with flair and panache, and that along with the ergonomic grip keeps you from getting tired.This isn't the best at fine details, though it's not so bad either.  The combs do a great job of handling different levels of fullness, and honestly if you can't get your beard the way you want it, keep trying, as this tool can do it.  Cleanup is a breeze (though most beard trimmers a simple compared to a traditional electric razor).Kudos to working corded as well.  It's a simple feature, but having used razors that can't work corded, it's a nice feature.

This is a decent extender, and all in all there aren't many great ones out there (it's the nature of the beast, as you'll always have some overlap/interference).  It does well in areas of opportunity (ease of setup, raw power), but it's not a panacea.  Ideally one can use powerline or MOCA to get to the far perimeter of a home and add an access point.  This also works as such an access point and it works better in that regard.Minus a star, as it doesn't do so well with interference in a congested scenario.  I kept dropping connections and reverting to weaker signals.

These are adorable (and tiny) swaddles.  It's so easy to get baby in and out of these, and the two way zipper gets a lot of use with changes and taking baby out to admire are the little fingers and toes!  The fabric is very soft and looks bette rin person than in pictures.  It cleans nicely and is refreshingly gender neutral.  As noted earlier, these are very small, and the 7-12lbs size range listed on the tag is spot on.  Depending on your newborn, the age that represents will very, though the next size up works for larger newborns as well.  I cannot really compare the results, as we started right away with our first child, but my mom seemed very impressed.  Baby does seem calm and relaxed, but we could just be lucky!So ... soft and gentle, easy to unzip (top or bottom) to slide baby in, and looks adorable.  Definitely recommend trying it, but only for the 7-12lb newborns (stage 2 "original swaddle" takes over from there).

These days many devices forgo wired ethernet connections for wireless, either to reduce cost, allow for smaller devices, or just to move us forward to the wireless future.  Who knows (I always bet on reduced cost).  Anyway, there's still a lot of value in a fast, consistent connection that forgoes the magic and misery that wireless can inflict.  My Dell XPS12 is a system without ethernet, but it does at least have a couple USB ports, so voila!Setups is well nothing.  Plug ethernet into device; plug device into laptop (you can even flip the order).  Everything else is automatic (only tried on a PC, but I've used similar devices on Linux machines--even Nintendo Wii) as much like a USB mouse, keyboard, or speakers, it's just a part of the overall USB spec.I didn't do any formal speed tests, but my laptop is copying 1gb+ files as fast as my desktop under similar circumstances, and more importantly Steam in home streaming works great!  That's my main use (allows me to use my beefy CPU, GPU, and loads of ram of my desktop gaming rig on my thin and light laptop anywhere in my home).I've got a couple of these now (they generally work the same, though this supports USB3), and I keep one upstairs and one downstairs to simply plug in (fyi, removing is simply a matter of unplugging--no need to "eject" or anything like that).5 stars for doing everything right, and the white color makes it much much easier to find in a ball of black wires and blue ethernet cords.

The opener works well, but the vibrant royal blue with clear logo shown in the picture is a bit disingenuous.  It's a dark almost navy with a dark and hard to read logo.  Not saying it's counterfeit, but it doesn't look like it should.

These aren't anything special and they were a bit of a pain to install on the lugs of my FujiFilm x100s (bought used with everything but split rings).  Once on they look nice and do their thing.  No real faults.

I'm generally not a fan of Otterboxes.  They do their thing, and supposedly they do it well.  It just makes every phone look like it's wrapped in a block of foam from an old pair of cheap flip flops.  I don't tend to revere the thinness or industrial design of phones as much as tech reviewers seem to (had no problem with plastic Samsung phones or thick phones with big batteries), but the Otterbox look wasn't for me.  I tried the Defender on the Note 5, and between the case being a little trimmer than others and the size of the phone, the scale wasn't that bad.  It just suffered from the other thing I hate with Otterboxes--the crappy screen protector that makes everything look bad and gets weird air gaps.  With some work you can remove it from the otherwise nice Defender ...Or you can buy this!  Yeah it also has a crap screen protector, but you can bypass that easily and use a ballistic glass one (my recommendation) or just pass on the protector.  The overall effect is a grippy and not too big (it's a Note 5, so it's still big) result.  It's easier to hold than the bare phone, and it seems to offer loads of protection.  I've yet to drop my phone, and I don't really do much that a bare phone couldn't, but the protection (or at least notion of protection) and grip is well worth it.  The ports and whatnot work--including the pen, and it works with my Nokia Qi chargers.  I didn't use the screen protector, but it looked as bad as other reviews stated it was.

OMG this is heavy--like super massive black hole heavy.  Like bronze statue of Jabba the Hut heavy.  Poor UPS dude :-(The weight is in the specs (105lbs!!!!), but somehow I didn't really care to look (I guess I figured that's someone else's problem--free shipping!), and it may be an issue.  The cartoon girl in the photo next to the box doesn't seem to be sweating it--even though the box weighs as much as she does!Anyway, it's heavy.  It's also well built, and more attractive in person than on the screen.  The dark pattern doesn't photo well, and some of the details such as the smooth drawers have to be experienced.  Assembly was pretty straight forward (I've assembled 100+ similar things over my life, so YMMV).  Given the weight, you'll probably want to get it in the right room (with help) before assembling.  The finished product doesn't have too much of a weird smell (it's supposedly non-toxic).Given the build, it could last forever, or just a couple moves (if not careful--though this heavy unit will probably break a few other things and or backs in the process).

I preordered my Note 5 as soon as it was announced, and got bought the first decent case that I saw--Spigen Neo Hybrid.  It's not the gold standard of cases, but it's what I started out with.  As noted, I bought it based on availability rather than any thorough comparison, so when I had the chance to try some other Note 5 cases (thanks Vine!), I did.This Verus case is nice, but I'll be putting the Spigen back on.  If I didn't have the Spigen, I'd be happy with this.  Looks are always subjective, though the Verus looks better in person.  Not amazing or anything, but the textures are nice.  The back has a nice texture, which is grippier than the phone itself (not saying much) and my Spigen case (not among its strengths), and the side has a somewhat grippy, vaguely metal looking trim piece (this is a 2 piece case).  If it were girppier or more "premium" this might be a 5 star case, but it's only kinda grippy (though grippy isn't always a positive when it means gripping dirt, lint, and pocket linings), and the buttons feel cheap.  The Spigen has metal buttons, and honestly, I never appreciated that so much until I went back to cases like this (the Verus).Those nits aside, the Verus fits well, all the ports are where they should be, offers screen protection (when laid screen down), seems to offer decent (though not Otterbox) protection (haven't dropped), and it retains the general feel of slimness (for a 5.7" phone).  I wish this had a metal trim piece (I get that plastic with a metal look is better for radio signals) with metal buttons.  Otherwise, to be honest, this is another case.  It's not a bad one, and I wouldn't be itching to buy a new one, but since I already have one, I'm putting that on.5 stars for getting the basics right but lacking some premium feel.  Check out the Spigen Neo Hybrid for the same price.

The lessons discussed in this book as well as the overall focus can both reinforce what some already know and inspire grander visions for one and all.  It's more than "go big or go home", but I suppose you could sum it up that way.  We all have different outlooks and personalities, and for some, much of what's laid out here doesn't come natural, and I think this book tends to help best with those personalities.More than anything, it helps transition from thinking like an employee or individual contributor to an entrepreneur or owner.  It also offers a realistic assessment of your chances if you don't make the most of every opportunity, even if it means stepping outside your comfort zone.  Where this book falls short is in details or examples one can apply.  It's more of a focus on attitude than execution, though there are other books that better address the how.This book isn't for everyone, and it's not perfect, but I found it to be a good read and passed it on.  4 ... almost 5 stars (could be better written, more actionable, and less about the author--I get these books are based on experience, but I put the book down a few times because he was unctuous).

I got this for my 65" plasma, which I found out lacks a USB port (using the TV's USB port is great because it turns these off when TV is off), so I used these on the 47" LG LCD.  The length is perfect for the 47" TV, and the lighting effect is wonderful.  It's a coolish light (6500k sound right), but  it's effect will be influenced based on wall color.  Like any LED, they light immediately at full brightness, and the power draw is minimal.  Application was easy, as the strip has wonderful adhesive.  Be sure to clean the back of your TV first and allow to dry.  The tape is flexible and made an upside down U shape on my TV.Highly recommended

I wanted to doubt the speed of my AV600 kit.  It doesn't.  It's hard to say what the issue is, and I get that turning electrical wiring into ethernet is magic in itself.  I did get 25-40% bump in speed, and if I were buying one, I'd get this (the pass through is a huge plus too), but the upgrade experience was a bit lackluster.  As with all of the TP-LINK gear, it's easy to setup, as well as secure (optional but recommended).  The connection is stable, and all in all I'm rather satisfied, but I'm left wanting a bit more of a bump in speed.

**Update 10/1/15**The lack of a web interface (really Google?) or ability to see what's connected via the app is really annoying.  You can get some info when trying to set up a "static IP" (more of a reserved DHCP address, but a nice though not unique feature), but even then a lot of things are listed as "unknown device" (despite having NETBIOS names).  Most folks may not even notice, but for advanced users that omission, plus the inability to change DHCP settings (IP range, router IP, etc...) has made things rather difficult.  For a new network of more modest usage, it would be fine, but I have a lot of things set up for a 192.168.1.xx network, and this refuses to play that way.  Again most things will simply get whatever address the router provides and move on, but with a home domain and a ton of NAS units, I really started wishing I never saw this router.What you can do with the app (only way to configure):* Basic setup* Change SSID/wireless password (one total SSID for 2.4ghz/5ghz)* Measure network performance* Prioritize network performance by system* Configure DNS: use Google's servers (default), use what your ISP provides, or custom (only primary and secondary) DNS servers* Enable/disable DHCP (default enable)* Reserve IP address (referred to as Static IP in app)* Port forwarding* uPNPWhat you cannot do (as of 10/1)* View/change wireless channels* Enable/disable 2.4ghz or 5ghz radios* Force AC on 5ghz or N on 2.4ghz* Set router LAN IP (defaults to 192.168.86.1) note WAN IP is defined by modem* Set subnet* Set DHCP range (defaults to 192.168.86.2 +) or other DHCP options like lease time etc...* View connected devices (NETBIOS name, IP address, MAC etc...)* Name connected devices (for management)* No port based QOS (only one port)* No granular firewall (block MAC addresses, ports, IPs, URLs, etc...)* No MAC filterHonestly the 2Wire home gateway provided by Uverse had more options.  I get that the whole idea is to keep much of this behind the scenes, but if there's going to be "Extended Settings", they should be comprehensive.**Original review**I'd consider the grade to be "incomplete", but here's what we have for now:I've owned and reviewed ten or so routers over the years (both bought with my funds and via Amazon Vine), though I don't exactly consider myself an expert, more of someone who knows what they like and how to achieve it with traditional routers.  In many ways I think I'm not exactly the intended audience for this, but I suppose in others I am.  Anyway, it's been a journey with this little guy!While it's made by TP-LINK, I see it's ancestors as the HTC Dream (T-Mobile G1) and Google Glasses moreso than TP-LINK's earlier routers.  It's more refined than the Dream, complete with a slick design, nice packaging, and mostly complete UX.  It's a bit like Google Glasses, as I see this as being ahead of it's time, but unlike Google Glasses, I think the time will come for this router.  I'm just not sure it's today.  Looks aside, it's caught being too similar to a traditional router with some transformative features but not a huge leap forward, and certainly not enough for the price.  Software updates and price reductions may change this assessment, but at $200-400 (think some supply-demand price spikes going on), it's just not worth it in Sept 2015.The gazillion antennae just work.  That's a huge plus.  There's not much to setup (we'll get to that in a minute), and I've had very stable connections.  I have not however seen any appreciable increase in range (compared to Netgear r6300v2 running DD-WRT) and I've seen a marked decrease in 5ghz bandwidth.  Of course my gigabit network performance has dropped, as I can't plug anything in!  Really Google?  I get that wireless like Tang, flying cars, and nuclear power is the future, but when has a wired connection failed anyone? So now I need to put an eight port switch in the living room to branch to the unmanaged 24 port switch in the basement and another one upstairs.  Switches are cheap, and in theory bandwidth is unaffected.  Latency and timing is another matter, and Nvidia recommends a direct connection to router for GameStream (oh well--thanks Google), though Steam in home streaming is working great.  I really consider 4 ports to be stingy and 1 is almost spiteful.As for the setup ... it's unique.  I think it can be said to be better, but I'd rather use a browser.  For novices the app driven approach removes a lot of the confusion and intimidation at the expense of making what I want to do (generally rather advanced) harder to find.  I also worry what happens when there's no longer an app available.  Google has a slowly increasing graveyard of unsupported products.  Without a web gui, if I need an available app for whatever my device is 2-3 years from now to update this, will it be there?  Will it work on my old phone, will it work on my new one?  These questions aside, I think 95% of people will find this setup experience to be both refreshing and beneficial.The rest is TBD.  I don't own any Nest (or similar) devices.  For now it's a stylish cylinder that does a decent job as a router, but a year from now will it be the center of my connected home, or will it be an expensive and firm foam roller?  Speaking of expensive--it's really a $80-100 device inside.  The software side doesn't feel like it adds $100+  If it was an Amazon Echo or somehow did something appreciable besides be a router, I'd get it.  I just don't see that, and I see plenty of better performing TP-LINK devices for less than half the cost.  I think Google is short sighted in their pricing and had a chance to really get a foothold in connected homes, but it will be much tougher at $200+ (especially when bundled with a lower tier brand).A generous 3 stars based on appreciating the fresh approach and potential, but losing one for being stingy with ethernet ports and another for price.  Who knows, maybe it will be transformed in a firmware update, but for now, it's just not worth the price.

I've never encountered such a robust label. I can't say I'll be labeling chemicals or submerging these in water for weeks, but it's good to know I can. Like any other Avery product, there are ample templates that make using these a breeze. My cheap Brother laser printer works well with these. They're sticking on the various items I applied them to. Very satisfied.

I've never encountered such a robust label. I can't say I'll be labeling chemicals or submerging these in water for weeks, but it's good to know I can. Like any other Avery product, there are ample templates that make using these a breeze. My cheap Brother laser printer works well with these. They're sticking on the various items I applied them to. Very satisfied.

As with many books on entrepreneurs/leadership/business, many of the items presented here can be seen as novel the first time you read it and thus the value you receive from this book will vary based on what you may have already read.  With that it mind, I reserve the best rating for books that expand upon the existing pool of wisdom and present the information in a new or at least more effective way.  This book scores a little in both areas, especially the author's sincere humble story like writing.As a book largely targeted towards millennials (anyone can benefit from this book) and with a skew towards modern tech driven startups (though again it can benefit anyone), the focus on being genuine, entertaining, and innovative is a success.  The writing style makes this more of a story than text or reference book, and the author's first hand experiences, combined with the author's humility and insights elevate this book above the rest.You can be successful without reading this, and many successful entrepreneurs didn't follow the path the author lays out, but it's hard to imagine a better approach to succeeding today.  It's not easy, and there's no road map.  That's the point, you will need to blaze your own trail, but this book helps you understand what that's like.

always liked the critters, but the cases seemed so bulky.  Whenever I used a tiny old iPhone with one of these it really seemed rediculous, but I decided to give this a try.The size of the Note makes the added Otterbox girth less rediculous, and if you've only owned older notes, the combined thinness of the Note 5 and added bulk of the Otterbox still leaves you with a manageable phone.  The added grippiness of the Otterbox is way ahead of the base phone or my Spigen Neo Hybrid.  The grippieness and innate Otterbox protection make this a good fit for the working phone reputation of the Notes.  The difficulty in getting the S Pen in/out and the lackluster screen protector don't.  Cases with integrated screen protectors just don't do it for me.  The airgap and lack of quality vs (the amazing screen) just annoy me.  It's the usual Otterbox screen protector (glare, reduced sensitivity, etc...), so if you've used an Otterbox before and didn't mind the screen protector, you'll be happy.  I'll probably remove the screen protector (there's a helpful YouTube video from "HD Geek Review" which shows you how).  I've had good luck with glass screen protectors, so I'll probably just do that.

This is a fun kit, and a great activity for child and parent alike.  It won't teach aerodynamics or provide uber realistic models (hint the space shuttle didn't have a propeller) of real planes, though the silhouettes and shapes do connect with familiar aircraft of various generations.  The planes really do fly, and you'll be up and running in no time with no frustration along the way.  That being said, you probably want to save the earliest model (the Wright Flyer) for last, as it's the most complex model.  As noted earlier this isn't exactly authentic, but the fun is real, and it can open the door for future more complex endeavors, and it can make enjoying a documentary, book, or wikipedia article on one of these great planes that much more hands on.  For now, this is all we need--that and astronaut ice cream to enjoy while flying the space shuttle!

While these aren't one size fits all, the xxl size kinda makes that the case.  I can fit in xl, but these give a bit more room, and they let me keep my wedding ring on.  They're not exactly heavy duty, but they've yet to tear doing detailing, cleaning, painting/finishing.  Your hands may sweat in these, but I find these to create less of that wet cold sweat sensation of other types of gloves.  I keep these all over my house, my car, etc... They just come in handy.  I'm sure there may be a time where old school Playtex cleaning gloves are a better choice (I've yet to encounter that) and likewise these work great for anything less than Mechnix Wear moments.

I've used three of these for adding multiple powered USB 3.0 hard drives (mostly Seagates), and they work great on Chromeboxes (two) and my Windows Storage Server (made by Seagate).  No issues whatsoever.  On occasion I'll use this for an unpowered (ie USB powered) hard drive, and those moments are also without issue.

Back in the day a 2.1 amp charge was a fast charger, then Qualcomm and their partners introduced various quick charge solutions, and now they're on their 2nd gen version (3rd gen just announced as a technology), and this works with my Note 3 (first gen) and my wife's Droid Turbo and my Note 5 (both 2nd gen).  The speeds are what we're used to and the phones reports Quick Charging as being active.  Only one of the two ports is a QC port, but the other is 2.1a.  If we somehow needed to charge both quickly, once you get to 80% charge the other port is pretty much just as fast, so charge until 80% and switch as needed, but with one phone, you might as well always use the QC port.The size is compact but not micro.  The included cable fits just about any case, and of course you can use any cable you want to.  Heck, this can charge an iPhone or any other USB based device (just as a 2.1a charger).  Having this option at this price more or less makes this a universal recommendation (even without a QC phone, it's a great charger).  No overheating or other issues.  Highly recommended.

Putting on a screen protector has gotten easier, but if you're looking for perfection, it still can be a chore.  This product (and most glass screen protectors) makes it easy to install.  You'll definitely get it on, mostly centered and have full functionality without much effort.  Having it perfectly centered with even clearances all around, can be a bit more of a challenge, but I haven't seen a solution for that.  Bubbles are a non-issue, and the clarity is superb.  The glass seems durable, even when I treat it as disposable, I have yet to scratch or scuff it.  I recommend these (also enjoy tech armor ones, but they cost more) to anyone with a phone.  They're so much easier than the film based ones and they're nice and hard.Note that the manufacturer provided me with a discount (it almost was free) in exchange for a review.  The content of the review is my own.

This is a basic product for a basic need.  The beauty is in the execution: nice materials, nice feel, does't slip or lose it's position without direct input, and it's $12!  I use this more my old Note 3, but it works with my wife's Kindle Fire 8.9" tablet as well.  I imagine it could serve a million other uses, and it won't become scrap once either of those devices do the same.  Is it perfect?  I suppose not, but I'm not left wanting.Note: the manufacturer invited me to review this at their cost (ie free to me) in exchange for a review.  The content of this review is my own.

I'm not much of a bulky Otterbox kind of guy (often I use phones naked), so this really suits me and is among the best minimalist cases.  All for <$10!  It holds even its own vs the priciest models while saving 10-20 vs those.What you get is a relatively compact case that preserves the overall iPhone size and shape while adding a modest amount of protection and a bit easier to grip profile.  The fit is top notch, and it has a first party grade feel.  I wouldn't say "premium", but it's definitely tailored and well thought out.  All of the holes match up perfectly and it's got a well executed less is more vibe.While I haven't dropped this, supposedly it's reinforced with magic corners that help in the worst case (and common) corner impacts.  I hope I don't find out if it works, but if it does or doesn't work, I'll update this review.Note: the manufacturer provided me this case for free in exchange for a review; the content of the review is my own.

This is a somewhat novel somewhat good and altogether naughty game.  It'll get played once, then most will put it in the closet for a while, maybe get played twice, then end up in some church garage sale for a real surprise!That's the quick and dirty summary.  The game play is beyond basic, but that's not necessarily a negative.  It's a very personal game, so it's best played with close friends or complete strangers (who you'll never meet again!).  If you often find yourself saying of thinking TMI, well ... this may not be for you.

I've used Frontline (and after that Frontline Plus) since ... forever, and other than the cost, it's a great product.  Now that the active ingredient is available elsewhere, you have options!  I've used this product off and on the past two years, well not me, my dogs.  It seems to work as well as Frontline (living in a condo, there's not a lot of time spent outside), even after stays in the kennel or doggy daycare (one would assume high risk areas for taking on fleas).  I've used the larger size for my Saint Bernard and this for our Golden, so it works on a ton of fur!Why not 5 stars?  It doesn't spread quite as fast or as even as Frontline.  There's an oily spot visible for a 3-4 days where Frontline looks fine after a day or so.  I'm no expert, but it would seem to not spread as fast, but hey for the money, it's not a bad tradeoff (just make sure to put it on a couple days sooner!).On the positive side, it's much much easier to get out of the packaging.  Frontline has the worst packaging that all but require scissors for the outer foil, which this doesn't use.

I don't do any medical exams, but I like these gloves.  Great for working on the car (detailing and such--not what I'd use Mechanix Wear for), painting, doing my wife's hair (yeah renaissance man) and cleaning around the house.  They're just the right weight with just the right give.  They're not perfect, but they're better than latex, or some of the alternatives.

I didn't realize toddlers played fetch! I saw them do that on the movie Knocked Up, but thought it wasn't a real thing.  Who knew!  It really does help capture some of that energy and work on some motor skills, but it's mostly a fun activity, and as a bonus the cats find it amusing.  It's not perfect however.  "Some assembly required" and "Batteries not included"--oh and they're D batteries.  The balls could fly a bit higher/further, and it's not a huge draw for kids.  It's fun, but they seemed to tire quicker than the cats (lets hope it's because they require more intellectual stimulation and not that they are more lazy than the cats).  I debated giving this 3 stars, but it does enough right to earn 4.  It's just not the first toy I'd recommend.

While one can use a variety of blankets to swaddle a baby, these make it much easier and more effective with the velcro.  They don't get too tight and allow for easy changing.  The patterns are cute (look better in person), and make for a happy baby.  What more can I say, these get the job done.

This game is amazing.  It's simple, fun, and connects at a fundamental level, bypassing political correctness.  Me and my friends already do bad impressions, so it came naturally.  It's more of a fun game than a competitive one, but so are the other ones we tend to play.  I think your experience will vary greatly based on who you're playing with, but for me, that makes it fun!

An AeroPress isn't for everyone.  But if you like great coffee and espresso and don't mind (or even appreciate) a hands on (quite literally) approach, this is the way to go.  It's the go to way to make espresso on the go or without a big fancy machine, and hell, even if you have one, it's not a bad approach.  There are a ton of AeroPress SKUs here on Amazon (various bundles and kits), though they all seem to be the same AeroPress (no knockoffs), so you really can't go wrong with any of them.I use coffee ground at home in a burr grinder to espresso level fineness, but to be honest, this will work with various grinds, including store bought drip coffee (different, thought not bad, results).  Store bought espresso grinds would also work (either pre ground bags/cans or using whole beans and a store grinder).  The cleanup is easy, especially with fine grinds, as it comes out more or less as a puck.  The coffee isn't exactly the same as an espresso machine, but it's close and it's great.The build is very robust, and the simplicity will only keep this around for a very long time.

These greatly increased the speed of my D7100 (especially when I have one set for NEF and the other JPG).  The buffer clears a shot in about .5 seconds (14bit loss less compression NEF and fine JPG).  I really like these, and I ordered the slightly faster newer ones for my d750.  No issues in camera or reader (these really speed up adding files to lightroom as well).

I bought this mower at Home Depot because after reading the reviews I was worried it would be too much work and I'd need to return it. I am a small female, and I am not strong. My yard is about 1/3 acre with a pretty significant 45 degree hill in the back. I have used the mower to do the entire lawn twice now and I am very impressed. I didn't bother with the bag and just let the clippings go onto the lawn as mulch. The first time was a lot of work because the grass was longer, but the second time it was much easier.
