Each go was about 1.5-1.75 hours. I put the mower on the third shortest setting (there are about 10 or 12 length settings). I won't lie, the hill is kind of a pain to do with this mower, and yes, sticks get stuck in the mower and I have to occasionally stop and pull them out. But, this is not a reason to give up on using a reel mower. There is no gas to use, there are no fumes. It's a little loud (I feel a little silly for thinking it would be almost silent), but it's definitely quieter than a gas-powered mower. If I can do it, you can do it too, and bonus you don't need to go to the gym that day!

I have blonde hair and these neon colors work well for me. They are soft and stretchy, and add a little extra class to a pony tail. I don't feel the need to hide the tie with my hair when I use one of these. They are a little expensive but as long as you keep track of them they will last forever.

I had a little trouble getting this to stay in place because it is so powdery. Each time I used it I ended up with very sparkly cheeks. The colors are nice though and it was fairly long lasting. I have green eyes and there are many shades that I thought worked very well for me.

I don't understand the hype about this product. To me it seems like regular lotion that is just thinned out a little bit, which doesn't justify the extra cost over face cream. It leaves a white hue underneath my eyes which looks very strange if I don't blend it just perfectly. I went through a sample tube but I would not buy it myself.

I am another birchbox sample receiver. I very rarely purchase the full size of anything because I don't like to spend too much money on these types of products, but this is one I would make an exception for. I have very sensitive skin and roseacea, so not a lot of products work on my skin. I found that this one was gentle enough for me and cleared up a lot of my clogged pores. Another method that I occasionally use is to mix ground nutmeg with a tiny bit of whole milk / cream and use that to exfoliate once or twice a week. It's cheaper but of course takes a little extra preparation.

I received this as a gift. The quality of this notebook seems to be very high but I do wish that the leather was softer. The cover is very stiff and I doubt it will ever lay flat like in the picture. This makes it difficult to write in as you always need one hand to hold it open. The paper is smooth and slightly shiny, so it is easy to write on but can cause ink to smear a little bit if not careful.

I don't normally use shaving cream but after receiving a sample of this I may just have to change my ways. It makes me skin feel amazing and so much more moisturized. The wonderful smell is a bonus. It is on the expensive side but my small sample lasted me a couple of weeks, so the full size bottle should last a few months.

I have sensitive skin and for some reason this product was very irritating to me. About twenty minutes after using it my eyebrows get very itchy and the skin around them started to break out. I only used it for about a week before I gave up, it's not worth being uncomfortable all day.

My favorite part about this product is that when I use it, I don't need to add any face powder to make sure my skin doesn't look shiny. One less product to apply in the morning is definitely a plus. It's tinted but I still need to use a foundation if I want to cover anything up.

When I can apply it correctly it looks great. I think the idea is to go for a subtle hint of color so I can see why some reviewers said it didn't do much for them. The problem I have sometimes is that if I don't apply it just right, I just look like I've been drinking red kool-aid. It also feels a little sticky so I'd recommend putting something on top like chapstick. For me it doesn't last past a meal, but that's not too bad if you only need two applications to get through a work day.

This game is a lot of fun for anyone who enjoys solving mystery puzzles. My husband and I purchased two copies of the game and sent the second copy to our friends who live out of state. We've played through 5/10 cases so far in our four person group (we use Skype or Google to talk for free). The game is a lot of fun but we all found it pretty difficult, especially as you get into the later cases. There is a newspaper provided for each case but they are chronological, so a case can reference any past newspaper as well as the current. We've been unable to get all the answers to the final questions in all but one of the cases (the first one) but it's still a blast and a great way to connect with our friends. You can spend an hour going through a case or you could spend three, it all depends on what your style of play is.

I am not a makeup person, I need products that are extremely easy to apply and are difficult to screw up. This eyeliner fits the bill for me - it allows you to put on a very thin, even line that looks great even without eye shadow. It goes on shiny but then dries matte, and it creates a very sharp edge that really cannot be smudged out, so only buy this if you like that look. Sometimes in the inside corner of my eyes it will crack and the line will have gaps that I need to go fill in again. When you wash it off it comes off in strips (I guess that is the waterproof part) and I normally only get about 50% off at night and have to finish the job in the morning.

I like this cream even better than the day version of it. I will sometimes use this during the day if I am using a separate product that has SPF in it. This version is less greasy and feels better to wear. It has a wonderful light scent and makes my skin feel very smooth. One container lasts me about three to four months with daily use - it is pretty easy to apply so you don't need to use a lot to cover your face.

This is a great product if you want a moisturizer to use in the morning underneath other makeup. I love that it has SPF and it is unscented. I wish that it came in one of the pump bottles so I didn't have to put my fingers into the container each time to use it. Sometimes instead I get a little bit out with a q-tip. It also works very well for removing makeup - a tiny bit on a q-tip underneath my eyes makes removing smudged eyeliner / shadow / mascara a breeze. The reason for four starts instead of five is that I have skin that can be somehow oily and dry at the same time, and sometimes this moisturizer feels a little too greasy / heavy to me. It also makes my skin very shiny so I need to add powder over my foundation to get a more matte finish.

I'm a big fan of the entire Boots product line. I like to use the beauty serum in combination with moisturizer after washing my face in the morning. One bottle lasts a long time (around three months for me with daily use). There is no scent and it goes on smooth without feeling greasy. I don't know that it really improves the youthfulness of my skin but it feels great to apply and wear, plus I think it helps my makeup to last a little bit longer.

I received this book as a gift as my husband and I are just beginning the home buying process. Overall this was a great book for a first-time buyer who has very little background on how to go about what is probably the biggest purchase of your life. I marked several areas in the book that I thought were important, such as how to find a motivated seller, avoiding loans with pre-payment penalties, examples of lender fees you might not be aware of, traits of good lenders, pros and cons of new vs old homes, and the best way to tour a house.I was irked by some of the occasional nonchalantly sarcastic language, especially the part where the authors described graduate degrees as pointless and silly (although maybe this was a bit of self deprecation since one of the authors has an MBA). I also didn't like suggestion in Chapter 10 that you should go for an adjustable rate mortgage if you can't afford the higher monthly payment on a fixed rate mortgage but you still want to buy a more expensive house (to be fair in the actual mortgage section chapter 7 they cautioned against this).One important point in this book that is missing is a description of the opportunity cost of money. This was absent from the loan section where the amount of interest paid between 15 and 30 year loans was compared. This seems like an important topic that home buyers should know about before choosing a mortgage. Just because you paid less interest doesn't mean you saved money.With this review I was also hoping to dispel the very pervasive myth that deducting mortgage interest saves considerable money on your taxes. For the vast majority of home owners this will not be the case, and I was disappointed by the way this was never mentioned in the book. To deduct mortgage interest, property taxes, etc, you have to itemize your deductions. This means that you give up the standard deduction, which is currently $12,600 for a couple filing jointly. Your only savings comes from itemized deductions over this amount. On a $350,000 home with 20% down payment, you are looking at around $15,000 in interest + property taxes if you started paying January 1st. Without any other deductions this saves you about $700 on your taxes if you are in one of the highest brackets. This amount goes down every single year as you pay less interest. Not the huge savings that your realtor and lender might suggest to you.

Glasslock containers are my number one "go to" for food storage, especially for containers for taking to work that I am planning to microwave. I've had two of the round ones for about three years that my husband and I have used almost daily. They survived many many trips banging around in my work bag. The lids on my two original ones are starting to give out (sometimes hard to close, and the plastic at the creases seems to be weakening, although they are still usable), so I decided to get this new set.In the first box I received, the lid on the largest rectangular container was cracked. I let Amazon customer service know about this and they immediately shipped a new set. I checked over all the new ones very carefully and there were no issues. My only complaint is that it can be hard to open the lids, and sometimes the little rubber seal comes out because of this. I had never had this issue before with the old ones.I didn't experience the chipping issue that others have mentioned with my old set of containers, and these seem to be identical in form although the markings are a little different. I will definitely update this review if I do have any chipping.

I recently upgraded to this toothbrush from the Oral-B Vitality. The battery on my old one lasted about seven years before it wouldn't fully charge up anymore, so I have high hopes for this one. The first time I used it, it repeatedly complained (the red light flashed) because I was brushing too hard. It lights up your entire mouth so it is hard to miss no matter which way you are holding the brush. Since then I've learned where I am pushing too hard and can adjust the pressure so I don't get the light flashing as much.In general my teeth feel significantly cleaner with this new brush, especially in the back where it is hard to clean all the way, and also the inside of my front bottom teeth where it's hard to sweep back and forth. I think the majority of this is due to the more powerful motor (and fresh battery) on this brush since the head is basically the same.My favorite feature is the 30 second timer that tells you when you move to the next quadrant of your mouth. My old Vitality had a two minute timer, which I often didn't make it all the way through, but with the 30 second timer it basically guilts you into doing the recommended amount of time.I also appreciate the little house for the toothbrush heads that you snap the charger into. After each use you can remove the head and put it away to keep it clean. I hope this prevents the yucky toothpaste buildup on the handle (if you've used these electric brushes you know what I mean...) It also allows multiple people to use the same toothbrush base since the house holds 4 different brush heads. If you are using this brush by yourself, I could see this feature being less great for you since it takes up a lot more counter space than the older models that don't have it.My only complaint about this toothbrush is that there is only one on/off button which cycles through the different modes. To turn it off you have to hit the button three times (if you are using the first mode). This is pretty minor, not worth taking off a star.

I just finished my first bottle of this shampoo. I love the earthy, spa-like smell. It makes me feel like I am taking a shower in the rain forest. I occasionally have issues with my scalp being very dry and flaky. Since starting the bottle my skin feels a lot better and there is no flaking. It's nice to be able to achieve this effect without using any harsh chemicals on my hair.

I bought this product along with the nighttime version because I have rosacea and I was hoping this would help with the redness. This doesn't seem to do anything to reduce the redness on my skin but it definitely helps to cover it up. If I am just going somewhere casual I can put a little bit of this on my nose and cheeks where they are red and I am good to go without any other makeup. It also works well under foundation if you want more coverage. The SPF is nice, but unless your face is red everywhere, you are going to need a separate SPF product. You definitely don't want to put this lotion anywhere where your skin is not red, otherwise it will be difficult to avoid making it look green.

This is by far my favorite nighttime lotion that I have ever used, and the low price makes it even more awesome. It is light, unscented, easy to apply, makes my skin feel great, and lasts a very long time. However, I just couldn't give it five stars because even though I love the way it makes my skin feel, I haven't seen any reduction in the redness on my face after several months of using it. I bought both the night and the day "redness relief" cream because I have rosacea which makes my cheeks and nose very red, especially in the winter. I will keep using it unless I find a product that actually dose reduce redness for me, since I love pretty much everything else about it. Based on the reviews here it looks like this does work for some people, so I would highly recommend giving it a shot. Even if it doesn't reduce redness for you it is still a great moisturizer.

I sincerely enjoyed reading this book which I was able to get from my local library after being on the waitlist for several weeks. I have a math and science background (although I haven't spent much time on stats) and now work in the medical field. I think that almost anyone from any background could appreciate the ideas in this book. There are so many interesting stories and anecdotes that I found I learned so much more than I anticipated. It would be wonderful if more people read this book so that we all could have a better understanding of how statistics and predictions really work.

This review is for the WeMo Insight switch. I love this little device. It was very easy to set up - all you need to do is plug it into the wall, download the app to your phone, and go through the simple instructions to get the firmware installed. It takes about five minutes. For me the most interesting part is the information on energy usage in the app. I normally have it plugged into a lamp in my living room. The app tells me that on average the lamp has been on 25 mins a day, it's an average of 16W when it is on, and is costing me about 2 cents per month in electricity. I can turn the light on and off from anywhere as long as the WiFi in my house is on. Sometimes I flip it on and off when I know my husband is home just to say hi.A nice feature is being able to set it to "away mode", which allows you to set up rules for turning on and off while you are gone. You can also set regular rules for this as well, and even have it turn on and off with the sunset / sunrise.The plug itself is pretty large, although it still allows me to access the port below it as long as the plug is regular sized. You could not put two of these into the same outlet.It's a little strange that the reviews here are for four different Belkin products, although they are similar. It would be great to be able to separate them out because after using this one I'd like to know on average what customers have thought of the other options.

This book is divided into three parts: addressing company operations and organization, team-building and leadership, and career management. I thought the advice about dealing with crises was particularly useful and something I hadn't read too much about before. The real life examples were also useful. However, some of it felt kind of embarrassingly cheesy (Area of Destiny?). I agreed with most of the book but it seemed mostly common sense and I didn't see a lot of new ideas. If you haven't read any books about career development before, this would probably be a good book to pick up.

This is a really pretty color and very long lasting, however, it can be difficult to apply without getting it all over your face. The brush screws onto the base with a spring mechanism so it's not possible to control how much powder gets on the brush. The brush is also quite large so it can be difficult to get in the corners of your eyelid. I use a primer to help keep it in place but I still can end up with smears of sparkle below my eyes. What I usually do is put a layer of moisturizer below my eyes before putting on this shadow. The moisturizer catches anything that falls and you can just wipe it off when you are done. Note, the shadow looks lavender in the container but it goes on silver.

This makeup doesn't work that well for me but I still gave it four stars because I think it is mainly my skin type. I have drier skin which can look very flaky when I apply this. If I really go to town on moisturizer, then this powder makes my skin look fantastic by absorbing any extra oil and providing a smooth, even finish. However, I'm not a huge fan of putting on that much moisturizer. I think if you have naturally more oily skin then this product would work wonders for you if you prefer a matte finish.

I have been using this foundation almost every day for several months. It's one of my favorite foundations.Pros:  Easy to apply and blend  Bottle is well designed so you can get small or large amounts out  Easy to choose your level of coverage, and still looks natural if you put more in certain areas and less (or none) in other areas  Nice finish that isn't too shiny but also not dry (as long as you pick the right moisturizer - see below)  One bottle lasts forever - I've barely made a dent in two months!Cons:  It's a little bit expensive for foundation, but as I mentioned above it lasts a while  If your skin is dry, it can exacerbate the problem. In the winter I have to be very careful what moisturizer I pair this with. If you aren't getting good results, try a moisturizer that is creamier to see if that helps  No SPF

I truly love this top coat. My nails dry so fast, are super shiny, and I never get that bubbling effect that I've seen with other polishes and top coats. It's basically fool proof. You have to try it to believe it.

This sunscreen is easy to apply and I find with the spray it is easier to make sure that you don't miss a spot. The bottle doesn't last as long as you think it might since a lot of what is in there is just compressed gas. I did feel pretty greasy after applying this though, and I noticed that with this spray bottle, the top gets really messy unless you wipe it off each time you use it. There is no cap, just a twist to lock it so it won't spray. I don't know if I would trust this not to leak in my luggage.

I like the fact that this sunscreen has a high SPF and still doesn't feel greasy going on. It is easy to apply and doesn't leave me feeling uncomfortable like some sunscreens do because of the stickiness. However, an odd problem I have had with this particular brand of sunscreen is that it takes the outer layer of nail polish off my fingers. If I apply it while wearing a shiny polish and I am not careful, the polish will be completely matte and tacky by the time I am done. I have to apply it with the palm of my hand and be careful not to get it on my nails. I'm not sure what ingredient is causing this to happen.

These bags are truly awesome. I highly recommend them for moving, especially if you are doing the move yourself and you have a limited amount of space. However, I they aren't ideal for using more than one time. Sometimes they work, but other times you come back to find your closet taken over by a giant comforter that suddenly became eight times the size because the bag gave out. I thought if I was just careful with the bags they wouldn't get holes in them, but they are somewhat fragile and this is difficult to do. They hold up well to even pressure, but the plastic is thin and very crinkly, and any sharp object or even just folding them too tightly can cause a break. I've never had one give out on the first use, but the second go around only has a success rate of about 50% for me.

Obviously, Doritos are delicious and if you are buying them I'm sure you already know what they taste like. I wanted to make a comment on the note in the description that says "No gluten ingredients**". I couldn't find what the ** means, but this is Frito Lay's terminology that they use when the product is manufactured on the same lines as products that do contain gluten. You can read about it here: http://www.fritolay.com/nutrition/special-dietary-needs/us-gluten-free-products-and-products-not-containing-gluten-ingredients.htmIf you are a celiac or gluten intolerant, this may not be for you. I would have put 5 starts if this was more clear in the description.

We place adult coloring books in the waiting room of the hospital area in which I work. We've just added this one to our library and I'm a huge fan of the designs. Patients and their families can color in the books while waiting and easily rip out the pages if they want to take their artwork home with them, or they can leave it for other people to admire or add to. We've occasionally get people mentioning how much they enjoyed using the books but what really speaks for itself is how quickly they get completely used up!

This is VERY important - there are two versions of this product, one for normal to oily skin and one for dry skin. This version is the one for normal to oily skin. The other one is the "Toning Agent" which is for dry skin, but the bottle looks nearly identical. I bought this in an Aveda store because it was recommended to me to help with dry skin in the winter. It made my dry skin significantly worse. I didn't realize until the next time I came into the store that this one was only for normal to oily skin.I'm giving this 4 stars because it smells great and feels very refreshing. Now that it is not winter anymore I can use it and I don't have a problem with the dryness. The description on the Amazon website is not very good (it actually says it is for your hair) and doesn't mention the skin type this appropriate for.

I really enjoy using this mask. It feels so good on your skin, especially on a hot day. I also got the idea from another reviewer to add a little bit to my moisturizer. This product is definitely a winner!

I really enjoy using this mask. It feels so good on your skin, especially on a hot day. I also got the idea from another reviewer to add a little bit to my moisturizer. This product is definitely a winner!

I really enjoy using this mask. It feels so good on your skin, especially on a hot day. I also got the idea from another reviewer to add a little bit to my moisturizer. This product is definitely a winner!

I really enjoy using this mask. It feels so good on your skin, especially on a hot day. I also got the idea from another reviewer to add a little bit to my moisturizer. This product is definitely a winner!

I can't get over the smell of this product. Yes, it is smooth and creamy and is probably great for my sensitive skin, but I almost never use it because it smells so bad. I think I've gone through about a tenth of the bottle in fix months.

I recommend to purchase this product from an Aveda store the first time in case you want to return it. You can use up to half a bottle to see if you like it. The people working in my Aveda store raved about this product and were very surprised when I returned it because it wasn't making a difference for me. I have long, fine, wavy hair and haven't had good results with any of the Smooth Infusion line. I used this every day for about a month before I gave up.

I have long, fine, relatively thick, wavy hair. I used an entire bottle of this conditioner in combination with the Smooth Infusion shampoo. Aveda claims that this product does the following:1. Daily conditioning that smooths and softens hair up to 60%: I have noticed a definite difference in this category. My hair feels soft and silky and very clean after using.2. Exclusive plant infusion that creates a smooth new surface on hair: Same as #13. Significantly reduces unwanted wave, helps prevent flyaways: I have not noticed any difference in this category, even after also using the Smooth Infusion Glossing Straightener at the same time.4. Protects against surface damage from heat styling: Maybe, but hard to tell. My hair stylist still said I had a lot of split ends. I'm not convinced that a shampoo can protect against heat.All in all a pretty good conditioner but I chose 3 stars because for me it doesn't do the main things it advertises, which are to smooth your hair, get rid of flyaways, and make it straighter. For me it isn't worth the extra price.

I have long, fine, relatively thick, wavy hair. I used an entire bottle of this shampoo in combination with the Smooth Infusion conditioner. Aveda claims that this product does the following:1. Moisturizes and reduces frizz: I have noticed a definite difference in this category. My hair feels soft and silky and very clean after using.2. Exclusive plant infusion of organic aloe, maize and guar bean creates a smooth new surface on hair: Same as #13. Significantly reduces unwanted wave, helps prevent flyaways: I have not noticed any difference in this category, even after also using the Smooth Infusion Glossing Straightener at the same time.4. Protects against surface damage from heat styling: Maybe, but hard to tell. My hair stylist still said I had a lot of split ends. I'm not convinced that a shampoo can protect against heat.5. Softens hair with a luxurious lather: Same as #1.All in all a pretty good shampoo but I chose 3 stars because for me it doesn't do the main things it advertises, which are to smooth your hair, get rid of flyaways, and make it straighter. For me it isn't worth the extra price.

I went through half a bottle of this before returning it (Aveda has a great return policy). I kept thinking eventually I would see a difference because everyone just raves about this product, but I never noticed any change in my hair. They actually warned me when I bought it that it could make my hair too straight, but after half a bottle I didn't experience anything like that. I have fine, wavy hair that gets frizzy in humidity, so maybe this product just doesn't work for my hair type. It does have heat protectant in it though, so I liked that part. It may be worth a try for you if you buy from Aveda since you can return it if you don't like it.

I've been using this face wash for about five years. I use the morning burst version both in the morning and at night - don't worry, it won't keep you awake at night. One of the best things about this face wash is that a single bottle of it lasts an incredibly long time, maybe 6-8 months, because you only need a tiny bit each time you use it. I don't notice the beads when I am using it, but the scent is very nice.

This is the one makeup product that I use every day. The first few times I bought it, I used the original (non-matte) version. I switched to the matte to help get rid of the shininess left behind with the original. Choosing between the two depends on your skin type and on the moisturizer you are going to put on underneath. If you like to use a thicker / creamier moisturizer, or if your skin is oily to begin with, you might like the matte better (that's my case). But I've also found that in the winter, the matte version can make my skin look dry no matter what I put underneath it.Overall this is a fantastic foundation that is easy and fast, perfect if you are rushed in the morning.

I bought these flip flops to change into for my wedding reception. They definitely fit the bill for the wedding, but it was a little hard to get around in them. The bottom of the flip flops are very smooth, and so it was easy to slip on wood or tile surfaces. The dance floor was almost impossible, but carpet was no problem. If there was more grip I would have given five stars.The padding on the flip flop is very comfortable, and I love that it is a little bit angled to give you some added height. The strap is not all that comfortable, so I don't think I would wear them all day.The rhinestones have held up for me, still have them all after a year and a half.

If you like the Assassin's Creed series, you can't go wrong with this purchase. Hundreds of hours of playing time for an incredible price! The original price for this 2.5 years ago was almost double what it is now.

I received this flat iron as a Christmas gift a year and a half ago. It's the fourth flat iron I have used and it is definitely my favorite. I specifically asked for this one because of the auto-shutoff feature, which prevents me from worrying all day at work that I left it on when I left the house. If it ever breaks, I will by the exact same one again.Pros:  1. Auto shut-off  2. Never snags my hair - doesn't require separating out individual sections  3. Plates are floating so it presses evenly on your hair  4. The plate coating still looks perfect after using it almost daily for a 1.5 years. I've had trouble with this with some other models.  5. Heats up very fast, about 30 seconds to get to 400FCons:  1. As fast as it heats up, it also cools off as you use it. The first few swipes work far better than the last few.  2. The swivel feature on the cord. It hasn't quit on me yet, but I can tell this is the first thing that is going to go. The unit won't always turn on unless I get the swivel in a specific position first. But, 1.5 years is still pretty good.A tip to deal with the unit cooling off: Once the flat iron reaches its desired heat setting, it changes the current to maintain that setting but doesn't take into account the fact that using it causes it to cool off. This can cause it to cool far below the set temperature. What you want is for it to be continuously heating as you use it. Set the temperature to one level below what you really want. Once it reaches this level, push the up button one more time and begin using it. It will likely never reach the next level because it will cool as you use it, and so it will continuously heat the whole time you use it. This will keep it much closer to your desire temperature.

I had really high hopes for this highlighter given the excellent reviews, however, it doesn't seem to work on my skin type. Parts of my skin are dry and parts are oily, and my face is very pale (I'm always the lightest shade available for foundation). Instead of making my skin look luminous, instead it just looks both greasy and sparkly, like I decided to put sparkly eye shadow all over my face. I've tried different combinations of makeup underneath it but I can't seem to find a combination that works for me.

I have borrowed this mascara from a friend several times before going out for the night. I am completely inept at putting fake lashes on, but I have no problem doing this. I think it actually looks better than fake lashes. You get a carrying case and two separate tubes. The first one they call the "transplanting gel" and the second one is the fiber lashes (box says they are made out of green tea leaves). You have to put your own mascara on first. You then do the gel, the lashes, then the gel again. The lashes tube looks like it is filled with little fuzzies. I agree with the other reviewer about the flakes. The second time I used this kit I put more gel on for the last application and then waited for several minutes trying not to blink. This helped a lot with the amount of flakes but didn't completely fix the problem.Pros:1. Easy to apply2. Lashes are significantly fuller and longer than with basic mascaraCons:1. Takes much longer to apply than regular mascara. About 10 mins total for me but I am a little slow.2. Not sure how to stop the mascara from flaking completelyThere are some nice videos on youtube that show how this mascara is applied and how it looks.

I have also used the base model Dyson V6 and the Hoover Linx. Dyson has now renamed all of their stick vacuums with "v6", so these are the original vacuums with new names. The major difference between the base model and this one is the extra attachments. It also has a special roller for hardwood floors and a higher end filter (which falls out a lot - sheesh). Other than the extra accessories, all the parts are the same high quality as the less expensive model. On the regular (non-turbo) setting the battery lasted 20 minutes and I could clean my wood floors but it didn't seem to do anything for the carpet. On turbo I get about 5 minutes but it doesn't give you any warning when you are about to run out, it just sort of dies.Another option if you don't want to spend so much on a vacuum is the Hoover: [...]. I have two cats and the Hoover handles pet hair much better, although the suction on carpet is slightly worse than the Dyson on turbo setting. With the Dyson, any time I save by not hauling out my upright is lost in time spent picking cat hair out of the roller, especially the hardwood piece.

This is a fabulous book that gently leads you to achieve your own health and wellness goals. Not overly scientific, easy to read and understand, and simple to follow the advice. I appreciated how well-rounded to book was, not simply focusing on diet and exercise, but on the bigger picture of well-being.I have read a lot of health and fitness books. Many of them cite numerous peer-reviewed articles in high profile journals supporting their story, but I find myself disappointed when I take a brief look online and see that what was printed in the book left out important details and facts that did not support the author's hypothesis. However, it's hard to argue with Buettner's work, based on studying the commonalities between communities with the highest concentration of 100 year olds who have grown old without suffering from the diseases that commonly plague our modern society (heart disease, obesity, cancer, diabetes). He immediately and wholeheartedly acknowledges that health and longevity is not simply about what you eat, but about a whole host of points which he terms the Power Nine.I am very happy to help support the Blue Zones Project which is actively helping communities around the country live healthier and happier lives. I bought several copies of this book for my friends and family and I hope it continues to grow in popularity.

I received this book as a gift from a friend who knows I love cats and I am really enjoying it so far. The paper feels high quality and it's easy to color on without any bleed-through to the  other side. I like to sit down with this after a long day at work and use it as a sort of meditation. It definitely calms me down. I don't worry too much about the colors or the end result. Coloring books for adults...what an awesome idea!

I bought this to use before my wedding. The pros:1. They work well, a noticeable difference2. You only have to do it 7 times3. They stay on really well (compared to previous versions) even if you are talking to someone4. The taste is much better than previous versionsA few cons:1. Holy geez did my teeth hurt by day 5. I don't consider myself someone with sensitive teeth, but I would get these random incredibly painful jolts in my mouth that were pretty unpleasant. It wasn't just in the few hours after using them, it was any time. This went away within a few days of finishing the last one.2. Two hours is a long time, but any stronger and I think it would be too difficult to tolerate3. For the cost, I didn't think the effect lasted that long. It's hard to tell because the whiteness fades gradually and depends on what you eat. For me I'd say it lasted a few months.Overall it did exactly what it was supposed to do. Considering the price and the pain factor, I'd only do this for very special occasions.

This was exactly the same paper that my professional moving company used. No issues with anything breaking, even especially fragile items. You have to make sure to also squish it up into balls rather than only wrap it flat around objects. Crushed up this packing paper absorbs a lot more force than you might think. It's definitely the way to go whether you are moving or just storing things.

We ordered this ring based on sizing at a jewelry store and it was about 0.5 size larger than expected. It has the Benchmark stamp on the inside even though I don't think they are allowed to say that in the description. We felt like we got a great deal compared to prices we saw in the store. Still married after 1.5 years so it did its job!

Why are these so cheap when they are so awesome? I have six of these frames in my house and they all look great. Yes the quality isn't the same as you would get for a significantly more expensive frame, but unless you put your nose right up against it you won't be able to tell. A few of mine have gotten dinged during moves but a quick application of a sharpie marker easily fixed the marks. One thing that is a little confusing is that it says 11 x 14 frame and then shows a floating document in the picture. 11 x 14 is the actual size of the frame, not the size of the floating document. This is explained in the description but I could see someone misunderstanding.

This is a great little device. I use mine almost every day. I wanted to confirm that customer service will still send you a new one if yours is lost. My mom lost hers last week, heard back from customer service in one day, and had a new fitbit five days later. Truly amazing service!

I love this mix! I buy the three pack once every three months or so. I use it both to make bread but I also use it as a flour substitute in several recipes. There are also lots of recipes on the Pamela's website that you can try as well. It's one of the few mixes I have tried that doesn't have a grainy texture to it. The results also seem fairly robust to how it is prepared, whether by hand, with a mixer, different types of pans, etc. I like to use a non-stick loaf pan otherwise you can lose parts of it when you are getting it out. The trickiest part is getting the inside done without burning the top. If you have this issue I would suggest lowering the temperature by a small amount and increasing the time until the top gets golden brown. I have noticed that the price sometimes changes up and down by 15-20%. It's worth keeping an eye on if you buy regularly.

Another exciting adventure with Nicholaas and his friend Pieter. This one finds Nicholaas and his family living in Arizona. Pieter has come to live with them for a short time. Both of the teenagers share a passion for baseball. The story alternates between the past and present with lots of interesting life lessons and adventures.At the outset Nicholaas and Pieter are playing a tension filled game of  baseball when they get an unexpected surprise; a vision of a blood moon with the image of Cochise imprinted on it. The boys will find themselves transported back in time. They will learn much about the honor and courage of this Native American warrior, as well as Rick Monday, a different kind of baseball hero who defended the American flag from dishonor.On a family visit to a ghost town, Nicholaas again steps back in time in the midst of a battle between Cochise and the white soldiers. A turquoise charm in his pocket allows him to be transported back to the present.The author nicely summarizes the end results of Nicholaas and his adventures in the present and future. Readers learn about honor, courage and bravery. Their lesson is not to fear losing their way, but to have faith in one's own determination and capabilities. Love the bright colorful illustrations. Recommended for readers ten and up who enjoy history, fantasy, travel, and adventure.

This book contains exactly what the title says, two completely different dog stories. In both of them, man's best friend succeeds in making an important point. Ultimately that lesson will lead the young boy protagonist to learn something about himself as well as the dog character in the story.Plot of the first story features a boy named Alex and his Jack Russell Terrier pup, Bud. Like many children, Alex is finding walking his dog a task not high on his priority list. When he tries to combine the task with playing with his friends in the park, Bud gets into trouble. Alex unfairly blames Bud. But a visitor at school next day, teaches Alex to change his ways.In the second story, Peter is a shy boy who has few friends. When his parents inform him that they will be traveling to Italy, his fears are intensified. Ms. Muffin, his teacher, tries to encourage him. What happens to Peter when he gets to Italy, and how will his new friend influence his life when he gets back home?The book is targeted for ages five through twelve. In my opinion, it is most effective as an early independent reader. There are some illustrations, but they are rather small and stylized. Together with the length of the sentences, children in the five to seven age might find it hard to follow. Teachers might use the book in read aloud sessions for class discussion.

A set of stories which contain lots of sight words and simple sentences for children who are just embarking on the path to reading. Themes center around things that appeal most to young children. In this collection, the young reader will explore black and white text along with large, simple illustrations that focus on topics like body parts, pets, weather and familiar animals. Simple rhyming word groups like dog on a log and fox on a box encourage a young child because they are fun to read aloud.I recently purchased a beginning reader set for my six year old granddaughter who has begun to read. This set will make a wonderful addition to her collection. Recommended for preschool and kindergarten teachers, librarians, and parents who want to build and reinforce early reading skills. While I read the set in kindle form, I hope to see it in paperback soon.

Rhyming book with four lines of text on a page featuring a rather sweet monster named Clarence. This monster lives in a tree and his mission is not to frighten people, but an intelligent, intuitive creature who enjoys having adventures and meeting new people. He has an upbeat personality and is always willing to use his imagination.Preschoolers will delight in the large illustrations and easy text. Nice bedtime story or read aloud for young children who love the monster concept but don't want to be scared.

Third book in a series featuring a dragon named Spark and his owner Jed. Spark has recently returned from a secret mission; he lives in Jed's garage. He is suddenly startled with an eerie feeling that there is something he needs to tell Jed, but when he talks to Jed, Spark cannot remember. The rest of the story revolves around the upcoming Halloween holiday. Spark has never experienced this; Jed conspires with his friend, Nick, to come up with a scheme to scare Spark. The three make quite a sight in their Halloween costumes. While trick or treating, they meet someone Spark never suspected possible as well as a troll who poses a real threat. This story ends as a cliffhanger. Fans will need to wait until the next book in the series to see what happens.Arrangement of text and digital illustrations is unusual and interesting. The beginning of each chapter looks like a comic book. Then the author relates the rest of the story in longer sentences, as if a chapter book. This format will appeal to reluctant readers who do not want to read the sentences in entirety. Targeted for ages six to high school, the book probably is best suited for middle grade students.

Another book in the series featuring Zigi, the alien, and his adventures from the planet Nepi to Earth. In this adventure, Zigi decides to visit Earth because he has a cold and sore throat. Chocolate is the cure for his ailment; he cannot find it on his planet. So Zigi sneaks into places where chocolate can be found like coffee shops, bakeries, a cooking class, and a birthday party. Wait until you see where he finds chocolate on his last stop.As with the other Zigi book, parents should explain that taking things without an owner's permission is wrong, even if one leaves moon rocks in payment. The formatting and layout of this kindle book is much improved. Young sci fi fans, especially in the six to nine year range, will enjoy the ride.

Interesting early chapter book features protagonist ten year old Charlie. The author calls it an interactive bedtime story adventure. This book touches on many of the issues facing todayâ€™s children like bullying, moving, and living in a divorced family. Charlie has carrot red hair; children love to pick on him. To make matters worse, his mom tells him that she has been offered a better job in London. He will have to leave his friends and home in Suffolk and move to the city.On the first day in his new school, the â€œpopular kidsâ€ make fun of Charlieâ€™s physical appearance and athletic abilities. His Aunt Kate suggests that things will be better after he makes a friend. Charlie is puzzled when she takes him to the circus. What does Charlie discover? How can this possibly be a solution to his problem?This book contains seven short chapters whose length is perfect for children who are learning to read content independently. I would recommend it particularly for seven to ten year old readers. The simple black and white drawings enhance interest. Free downloads, video clips, and competitions included in the book will sustain interest and extend reading

This is Book One of the Alexandra Fry detective series. Angella is a pretty ordinary twelve year old, who is nervous about starting the first day of seventh grade in a new middle school. She shares time with both of her divorced parents. At the beginning of the tale, readers are introduced to Alexandraâ€™s unique talent. She is able to see the ghosts of famous historical persons, who ask her help in solving mysteries. Alexandra has assisted Magellan in finding his lost compass and Abraham Lincoln in finding his stolen top hat. As if the first day in a new school isnâ€™t difficult enough, Alexandra is contacted by Queen Elizabeth I of England, who insists that if the family locket is not located, a curse will be visited upon the current community. Her classmates and teachers think that she is talking to herself.Fortunately for Elizabeth, her dad works in the City Museum. Her ability to gain easy access has helped her solve many cases in the past. In this mystery, she will be able to enlist the aid of a new friend, Penelope, and an eighth grader named Jack who at first appears to be more of a suspect than a friend. Alexandra must face the same issues most preteens face: bullying, fitting in with the crowd, negotiating their way with adults and asserting their independence. The author narrates a plot that has lots of twists and turns and combines elements of paranormal, history, mystery and adventure. Characters are believable and use authentic dialogue. The text is easy enough for preteens, but also is sophisticated enough for a young adult or adult reader. I was totally drawn into the mystery and felt empathy for the young characters.Readers age eight and older who enjoy history, mystery, detective, paranormal and coming of age books will all find something here to their liking. Look forward to the rest of the series.

Magelica's RescueThe Second Book is the series written by Louise Courey NadeauIn her second adventure, Magelica has a dream shortly after being tucked into bed by her guardian, Gri. Magelica dreams that Prince Will is in trouble; she sees him washed ashore on The Island of Darkness. Together with her pet dragon, Tris, she embarks in her magical bathtub on a voyage back to the island where she met Queen Raya and discovered her power to make effective changes once she believed in herself. Magelica does indeed find that the prince is stranded. The people of the kingdom learn how to stay positive and use the power of laughter to achieve their goals. Magelica teaches the prince a song of inspiration. By the time Prince Will is returned home and Magelica is tucked back into her bed, they discover a very special connection that not only will help them to protect each other, but one that might help Magelica discover her true origin and birth family. Future books hold the  promise of many new adventures and the seeds of inspiration for Magelica's  readers to achieve great things.

I had a bit of difficulty deciding on a rating for this book. The plot is quite imaginative; I really do like that. An alien named Zigi who lives on the planet Nepi, frequently visits Earth because he has a fascination with stinky socks. The inhabitants of Nepi do not wear socks or shoes. So Zigi, goes to apartment buildings, beaches, the mall, and a kindergarten playground, among other places to seek his treasures.Zigi does not steal; he removes one sock and leaves moon rocks from his planet in exchange. But Zigi does not ask permission, and he does not explain how his victims fare the rest of the day with only one sock. Zigi also sees sunburn as magic because his skin goes back to normal once he is out of the sun. Parents and teachers will need to explain to young children, that it is wrong to take things without asking and that staying in the sun for long periods of time can be harmful for human children.On the other hand, the illustrations are easy for young children to follow and they will love the off beat humor. There are a few formatting issues: text and picture are not on the same page, and the size of the text changes on a few of the pages. Recommend the book for parents of preschoolers and young children who are careless about taking care of their belongings, and children who are intrigued with the concept of aliens from outer space.

This author has a passion for explaining how to do things, and she displays a definite talent in this area. Adults who have always wanted to learn how to draw or those interested in helping children learn will find value in this book. The step by step approach laid out in the Table of Contents sets the tone for this book of approximately fifty pages.Williams tells her readers that drawing begins with a dot, then connecting the dots and proceeding to lines. She encourages us to surprise ourselves by allowing ourselves to scribble. Later we can train our eyes to see shapes in the objects around us. I found the section on artist tools helpful. Williams explains the need for an artistic pencil, erasers, sharpeners and the importance of using drawing paper with the proper weight. She cautions the budding artist not to draw from memory, train your eyes and always keep a drawing pad near you. The section on mistakes to avoid includes not throwing away your drawings and not to be afraid of darker values or outlines. As you become more proficient you can learn more about three dimensional forms as well as light and shadows. Drawing can be a fun activity; you do not need to possess great talent. It is a wonderful way to connect to the world and release your frustrations.I highly recommend this book to anyone who has an interest in learning to draw or to understand the basic elements of drawing Children ages ten and up should be able to handle the text independently or the book can be used as a joint adult and child teaching tool.

The author targets this book for children ages three to seven. Simple plot centers on three bunny brothers and how they spend a Saturday morning. Their mom tells them she will be visiting granny; they will be staying home with dad. Then she gives them a list of suggestions as to how to spend the day, asking only that they clean their room before she returns. She elicits a promise to comply, and leaves a special dessert for them. Of course the three bunnies procrastinate in cleaning, thinking they have plenty of time left. When Jimmy goes to the room and cannot find his basketball, he cannot find it. What do the boys decide to do? Will they get their room cleaned up in time?Although the lesson of responsibility is a good one, the plot is fairly predictable. The text font and size of illustrations are rather small for younger children. I could not enlarge it on my kindle HD fire. Recommended as a bedtime story or read aloud, particularly for parents of children who don't enjoy cleaning up.

Cute story about a Jack-o-lantern named Bob. This pumpkin was carved by a nine year old girl while she was bobbling for apples at a Halloween party. Bob hates his name; he doesn't sound very scary. Isn't that what Jack-o-lanterns are supposed to do on Halloween? Together with his friend, a cat named Bubbles, he scours the neighborhood trying to square other creatures like a spider, mouse and a dog. Finally, Bob meets an owl who tells him to use the one thing that makes him special to scare children. Puzzled by this, Bubbles and Bob try to figure out what that is. Will they succeed before Halloween arrives and they run out of time?This book is a good fit for preschoolers, even though the sentences are a bit long and the adult reader might need to paraphrase. The digital illustrations are colorful and cute. The book is in need of some editing, which probably won't bother most readers. Teachers and parents might choose this one as a change of pace in Halloween stories.

Princess Nancie is so excited. She just can't wait for the ball to begin at seven tonight. She tries to avoid thinking about the long wait time and tries to find activities to amuse her and pass the time. Then catastrophe strikes when she knocks down the suits of armor lined up along the castle wall. Nancy is a princess; she does not need to pick up after herself, but she feels guilty. How does Nancie handle her problem? Will we get to see her dancing at the ball?The book is targeted for children under the age of six. It will teach young children an important lesson about responsibility. This book of approximately twenty pages is written in rhyme. There are a few spots where the rhythm is a bit off. The story does seem to end a bit abruptly, leaving the reader wanting to know more. Recommended for preschoolers.

Bubbles is a cute frog with a serious problem. It seems that no matter what he eats, he makes bubbles in the pond. Bloop! Bloop! His stinky farts don't make him popular with the other frogs in the pond. Eventually, they ask him to leave. Then one day some boys arrive at the pond site determined to catch frogs. Bubbles dreams about their plight. Should he try to save them?The book is targeted for three to seven year olds; story line will probably appeal to the upper end of that range. The illustrations are simple and the plot is predictable.. Children who like humorous, quirky books will probably like it. Not the type of book to read and reread. Some parents or teachers might want to use it to approach a sensitive topic.

Four stories centering on familiar themes and characters with surprise endings. Each story features one protagonist speaking to the reader in first person. The first story showcases a frog who was once a king now trying to woo his sweetheart. In the second book, a little chickadee discovers there is a certain someone that he cannot get off his mind. How can he tell her that he loves her? The third book features a rather self-centered Easter bunny who is attempting to train the â€œnew guy.â€ He gives a lot of history about the Easter bunny and what it takes to fill the job. Finally in the fourth book, a robot from the planet Infinim, which is a replica of earth, is interviewing candidates who want to be robots for his planet. Readers will be surprised at the current candidate who is interviewing for the position. Who is he and will he make the cut?The photos and illustrations are delightful. While the stories feature somewhat familiar characters, the clever surprise endings will delight both the child and adult reader. Each story is about the average length of a picture book. These tales are targeted for the three to six age audience, but older children will appreciate the subtleties and clever twists. The collection is a nice set of bedtime stories or family read aloud. Highly recommended.

Clever, humorous and well-written detective mystery targeted for late elementary and middle school readers. I must admit the plot kept me guessing and entertained. Chapters are short and easy to read. Pencil sketches are an added bonus. I particularly enjoyed the way that the authors found a way to integrate those dreaded hard to solve math word problems right into the story line. As a bonus, the reader is presented with a few more problems to solve at the conclusion of the mystery. They can check their answers on the authorsâ€™ website.Felix, Gertie, Stanley and Charlotte are a bright group of sixth graders who become interested in forming a detective agency. Using Felixâ€™s tree house as a base of operations, Felix attempts to find out who is stealing his food from the kitchen by using his binoculars. When Charlotte brings a police scanner up to the house, they hear about an armed robbery at the local jewelry store. The budding detectives rush to the scene. They discover the owner Mr. Franklin has been hit on the head and his most valuable possession, the Claymore diamond, has been stolen. Police apprehend a suspect quickly, and the case appears closed. Our four young detectives believe otherwise; they refuse to quit until what had appeared obvious is revealed as erroneous.Lots of twists and turns in the plot. The characters are believable and authentic middle grade students. Readers will find themselves enjoying the math challenges that come along with the case. Great way to get students involved with math while reading. Look forward to reading new books in the series as they are released.

Jack is a cute Russell puppy who lives with his human parents in Aberdeen, Scotland. This book is a collection of three very short stories, suitable for children in the five to eight age group. Jack thinks and acts like a human; his parents talk and act as if Jack is human. In these three adventures, Jack succeeds in foiling a robbery, solves a detective mystery, and resolves his loneliness problem by finding a new friend in a most unlikely way.The kindle book has a few editing and formatting issues. Photos are cute; they will appeal to young readers. Recommended for dog lovers and children who are learning to read early chapter books. Teachers could adapt the text to be used in read aloud classroom sessions.

Charming counting book for toddlers and preschoolers. Simple sketches and soft watercolors make the illustrations appealing and a pleasant change from computer generated illustrations. The animals of Hazelwood Forest plan a birthday celebration for Pepper, the squirrel. Numbers are presented in ordinal and word formats together with pictures of the objects that they name. A free downloadable coloring book is offered with the book.Recommended for parents and teachers of toddlers and preschoolers to learn from and enjoy.

Webster's mom wants him to go to bed. Like many children growing up today, he has trouble separating himself from electronic devices like computers, phones, and TV sets. But Webster is shocked when he learns that his electronic friends need down time as well. They discover a way to find the balance humans and machines both need.The electronic devices are personified in this story. Webster and his mom are portrayed in simple geometric shapes. Parents of young children who are on technology overload may find this book useful. The simple illustrations will appeal to children in the primary grades. Readers should note that the rhymes in the book need some smoothing out and the book could use some editing.

The author is not trying to reinvent the wheel, but to collate and abridge a nice assortment of stories from around the world in five to seven minute segments. Just the right size for a busy mom or dad for a bedtime story read. They are suitable for school age children ages six through twelve and are not meant for toddlers or preschoolers. While all of them have familiar themes to many cultures; â€˜The Emperorâ€™s New Clothesâ€ will probably be recognized by all readers.I think my favorite of these ten is the one titled, â€œThe Story Without an End.â€ It tells the legend of a king who lived in a time before there were printed storybooks. This king had an insatiable appetite for stories. After a while, his subjects ran out of stories to tell. The king promised that whoever would tell a story that did not end could marry the princess. Unfortunately, if the story ended, that storyteller would be thrown in jail.One day a poor farmer showed up with the promise of a story without end. But first the king had to promise to listen to the end. After receiving that promise from the king, the farmer began his tale, which was so cleverly crafted that it went on for months. When the king could take it no longer, he begged the farmer to stop telling his story. So the farmer married the princess and eventually ruled the kingdom.Each story is accompanied by a black and white pencil drawing to complement the tale. This is a nice touch and provides encouragement of more discussion on the topic of each story. Creative and novel way for parent and child or teacher and child to share a short read aloud. Look forward to reading Book 2 in the collection.

I think the most valuable parts of this book are presented in the introduction and conclusion. Time is our most precious commodity; in order to be successful we need to make good use of it. All of us are guilty of procrastination. When we waste time and fail to achieve our goals, we become frustrated. That can lead to a vicious cycle and failure to meet our goals.The author encourages the reader to practice self-discipline and stop worrying about things we cannot control. She teaches us how to make effective lists that will encourage productivity. Develop a winning attitude and prioritize the tasks you need to achieve within the time you have.Most of us recognize that we need improve our organizational skills. While there is little  new content here, the author presents a cogent plan to use as a springboard.

Cute story introducing toddlers and preschoolers to the activities of bees in the garden. The bright colorful illustrations are adorable. Young children will enjoy looking at them over and over. The text is done in rhyme with large print which also enhances appeal to the young reader. While there are only four or five lines of text on a page, there are a few challenging vocabulary words like lair and mischief. In the kindle version, text and illustrations were displayed on separate pages, which might be distracting for some readers. For these reasons, I gave the book four instead of five stars. Toddlers and preschoolers will enjoy the book.

This book is not a biography or carefully researched book about military history. Rather it is a book with a very specific point of view on how to set out to achieve your goals. In fact, the first quarter of the book deals with the theory that the simplest way to defeat obstacles that stand in your way and to systematically accomplish the goals you set for yourself is to be as determined in your drive as Alexander the Great. Patrickâ€™s theory states that if you do this, you will show your bravery and tenacity to your opponents, who will then lose the will to keep fighting you.The middle section of this book retells the events of Alexanderâ€™s campaigns. Patrick consistently presents Alexander in a favorable light, largely discounting other reasons for success or failure. Finally the last third of the book explains what the author calls The Power of Purpose. All of us should learn from Alexanderâ€™s journey to greatness that to be successful the reader needs to do the following: strengthen her will by having a clear purpose, put that purpose into motion, and then follow through to reach the goal by never relenting or giving up on it.This is an interesting theory, if you are looking for inspiration and motivation. On the other hand, if you are expecting to find a book based on meticulous historical research or an accurate portrait of Alexanderâ€™s life, this one will not fill your expectations. At approximately fifty pages, it is a short motivational read for young adults and adult readers.

Second book in The Fantasy Farm series which is set on a small farm in the French countryside. Toby, the Border Collie, joins his owners Sam and Susan in a tale focusing on the free range chicken inhabitants of the farm. Bubbles has lost one of her chicks named Pippin; Toby takes the lead in investigating his suspicions of a fox on the loose. Michael and Susan hatch a clever plan to scatter human hair around to discourage the foxes to retreat. But Mr. Fox is not fooled. What can Toby do to protect the chickens on the farm? The answer will surprise you.This book is shorter than the first with fewer chapters, larger print and colorful pictures. While the series is targeted for ages five through fourteen, this book is most appropriate as an early reader, probably suited best for ages six through ten. Readers will learn a lot about animals and farm life.

Lily the goat loves to sing. One day she and her goat friends take a walk through the forest. They encounter many groups of animals who also enjoy singing, but their request to join them in song is rejected. One would think that after being rejected by the birds, cats, and frogs, Lily and her friends would give up. They continue their journey until they find a very unusual choir. Will they find a choir willing to accept them?This book is targeted for preschoolers and children in the primary grades. Illustrations are bright, expressive and colorful. There are a few places where the rhyme and grammar are a bit off, but the story is sweet and written with a valuable lesson.

Dicks has done his research on a controversial topic; he presents it in a straightforward and objective fashion. This book is not a sci-fi tale of invasion of the earth by little green men. In this book of approximately eighty pages, the author covers a lot of territory.To summarize briefly, readers will learn about the exact location and historical background of Area 51. They will learn about the earliest projects dating back to the 1940â€™s and 1950â€™s like the A-12 Spy Plane and the Lockheed U-2, plus other projects that have been rumored tested there. The author explores the conspiracy theories, and the rumored alien crash at Roswell, NM. He discusses mysterious cleanup activities around the base. I found the discussion about ancient texts around the world and DNA analysis interesting. Dicks discusses the testimony of those who claimed to have seen aliens including astronauts and pilots from the US and Russia. Perhaps the most controversial part of the book is the work of Dr. Dan Burisch and the Lotus Project which discuss aliens as human intelligences from the future.Whether you believe in aliens or not, this book is a well-written analysis on the subject of Area 51. Appropriate for readers ages twelve and older, I am sure that budding middle grade scientists and sci-fi fans interested in the subject will be able to handle the text.

The author has her pulse on the middle school audience. Gabby Gibson, the protagonist, is the perfect heroine. Gabbyâ€™s dad has passed away, but she follows in his footsteps as detective par excellence.She is a seventh grader at Preston Middle School who experiences many of the problems that her young readers face. There is gossip among the girls, bullying, the nerds, those perceived to be the haves and the have-nots. The dialogue is funny and authentic. Readers will laugh and cry with the characters and their foibles. Student and adult characters share equally the laughter and the criticism.Plot centers around the mystery of how the Panda mascot of Preston Middle School got his head cut off at an important soccer game, and how the money for the annual seventh grade dance went missing. When the dance is canceled by principal, Mr. Sauerbutts, Gabby kicks her detective skills into high gear. There are enough twists and turns to keep the plot interesting. Our detective thinks she has the answer, but discovers she was wrong. Will Gabby solve the mystery and save the dance? Does the Panda mascot find his head?At just under two hundred pages, the book is a nice fit for readers ages nine and up. Just a suggestion, a few simple drawings might have made some of those hilarious scenes even more effective.

The subtitle in this book sums it up: motivate yourself when no one else can. It is easy to sit back, find excuses and do nothing. That just leads to further frustration. There is not a lot of new material in this book, but the author does an excellent job of summarizing what needs to be done and effective ways to implement your goals.Collins begins by explaining procrastination, why we do it, and the damage it can cause. Next the reader is encouraged to take charge, believe in himself and take the steps to pull out of his lethargy. These include prioritizing, focusing on task, planning, breaking tasks into time blocks, and setting deadlines. Finally, the reader is encouraged to implement self-discipline, establish routines, and reward himself when successful.This is a great little book to keep handy whenever you feel yourself slipping into the doldrums or finding your desk a helpless mire of unfinished tasks. Highly recommended for tweens, teens, and adults.

I have mixed emotions about this story. Narrated in first person by a little girl, the story is divided into two parts. In the first half, our little narrator presents rhymes of four lines per page with some of the reasons her grandpa might be cranky.  While the illustrations are adorable and funny, some parents may feel they are too graphic especially for very young children. For example,  losing his teeth in the toilet bowl and falling asleep because it is too difficult to cut his long toenails. The second part of this story relates how the little girl has so many reasons to appreciate her grandpa like how he supports her emotionally, spends time with her, and has unlimited patience. Her conclusion is that he is not grumpy, but just getting old.The book is targeted for readers ages two through eight. Toddlers and preschoolers won't understand the underlying message. While children might find the situations and illustrations funny, some of the topics chosen are a bit weird. Parents and teachers definitely need to preview the whole book before reading.

Little Leigh was a lonely girl who had no friends to talk or play with at school. While walking to school alone one day, Leigh finds a mirror, and looking at her reflection, Leigh decides that she is a nice girl. The mirror answers her back affirmatively. Leigh continues to ask the mirror questions about her positive attributes. She discovers a new self-confidence and begins to act accordingly. In no time at all, her classmates notice the good in her, and begin to befriend her. Then one day Leigh drops the mirror. Will she be able to maintain her friendships and newly found self-confidence?This is a perfect book to read to a shy child who is beginning a new school year. It is a perfect choice for a read aloud or bedtime story. Appropriate for preschoolers and primary school age children.

Quite a mouthful for a title! Most any parent would say they want all these things for a child, yet delivering them is by no means an easy task. The author of this book is not revealing new information, but organizing and structuring it in an easy to read, practical guide.The book is divided into fourteen chapters starting with the big picture and working toward specific steps for implementation. At the outset parents must believe in their children, ensuring that they donâ€™t feel inadequate, celebrating their successes and avoiding nagging. Parents need to understand why school is important by building up a childâ€™s dreams, discussing the future and helping them to discover their own passions and talents. Then parents can follow through by setting realistic but high expectations and helping children move toward them.In the later sections of the book, the author explains the importance for the child to listen to the teacher and how parents can encourage that. Ambe insists that achievement is tied to a love of reading, which spills over into all subjects of the curriculum. She explains the importance of completing homework, maintaining a good structure at home by establishing routines, doing extra credit work and practicing for tests. I found the section on math interesting. Ambe stresses the importance of mastering math skills in the early elementary grades and urges parents to visit the school to ensure those supports are in place. Other important areas for parents are teaching character and integrity through personal example, demanding accountability, and communicating empathy. Parents will help a child find balance and provide discipline by seeking the right extracurricular activities to instill motivation and leadership qualities. Above all, the parents themselves must put their best foot forward as mentally and physically stable role models who pursue their own passions and goals.At the end of each of the fifteen short chapters, parents are give a short exercise by answering pertinent questions about their own child to help reinforce the content of that section. These can serve as a kind of notebook or reference guide. This book of approximately one hundred pages belongs on every parent and guidance counselorâ€™s bookshelf. I found the common sense and practical guide valuable and easy to follow. Wish I had this when my children were still in school.

I think this may be my favorite book in The Oliver and Jumpy series. In the first story young readers are taken on a wild adventure with Loci, the locomotive turned roller coaster. Passengers get more than they bargained for as they are taken under the sea, through a land of giants, and a cavern filled with fire-breathing dragons. The second story involves Oliver's plight with uncontrollable hiccups. When he remembers the legend of a deep flower hidden in the jungle that provides food for the hiccup bird, he is forced to become a mountain climber. Can Oliver successfully disguise himself as a hiccup chick, find a cure, and return home safely? The third adventure finds Uncle Oliver having breakfast with Joey, his young kangaroo friend. They decide to go fishing in a rowboat on the nearby lake. What happens when Joey gets impatient?Cenizal does a wonderful job illustrating the cast of characters which include sharks, mermaids, dragons and giants. Their facial expressions are priceless. Preschoolers will love them. If you haven't read any of the stories in this series, I recommend that you start with this one. You can read all three stories in one sitting or break them up into individual bedtime stories. Highly recommended!

I was not disappointed with this poetry collection. Children will delight in the variety of subjects and clever rhyme. Some of these poems address ordinary objects like lunch and rocks. Others address fears like being sick and cowering in a thunderstorm. One of the funniest poems is the very first, â€œConfusion.â€ It addresses the many complexities and anomalies of the English language.I gave up the fight and called it a night It really didnâ€™t matter if write wasnâ€™t right All those words are still in my head Iâ€™ve got an idea! Iâ€™ll learn German instead!A few of the poems deal with growing up issues like personal appearance, wanting straight hair instead of curly or â€œThe Joy of Boys.â€ Some poems illustrate our deepest feelings like the loss of a loved one in â€œThe Legacy, â€ or exploring magical memories left to us by a loved one in â€œGrandmaâ€™s Magical Pot.â€ Children who have never even tried to write down their thoughts in a poem might be encouraged to do so following the simple format of the poem titled simply, â€œI Like.â€I donâ€™t ordinarily read the poetry genre but have to admit I really enjoyed reading these poems. Adults will have just as much reading them as a child being introduced to them for the first time. Recommended for children ages eight and up and for readers of any age who enjoy reflecting on the simple things in life.

Tale about a young boy who wants to grow big and strong so that he can see the world and go on a great adventure. His grandfather learns of his wish and sends him a giant wedge of cheese  from his farm. Soon the entire village appears seeking a piece of the cheese. The little boy has no problem sharing with everyone. Word of his generosity spreads to the prime minister and celebrities worldwide. While travelling home, the boy remembers that his Uncle Troy asked him for a piece so he travels to the desert. He continues his journey encountering many obstacles but always remaining generous. Will the boy ever get to enjoy his cheese?Illustrations are colorful and delightful. Text is simple and appropriate. Love this book for primary school children.

This is the author's first book featuring a nonfiction topic, the metamorphosis from caterpillar to butterfly. Story features a boy named Dave who has a pet caterpillar, Wiggles. Dave and his father take us through the stages; eventually Dave realizes that it is time for his pet to go free.I like the idea of comparing the caterpillar's life cycle to the maturation process of a child. Dave's father has a powerful message for his child. This book is targeted for children ages 4-16; the illustrations are large simple and cartoon-like. However, the text includes many sentences approaching twenty words in length, and vocabulary words like lurked, transformed, abundance and succulent are too sophisticated for very young children. While they may be able to follow the pictures, an adult will need to explain the text. For these reasons, I would recommend the book especially for children who have mastered beginning reading skills; most third and fourth graders would be comfortable with it.

Princesses, dragons, lizards, time travel, castles and fantasy. What more could a middle grade reader want? This book is targeted for children in grades three to six.Suzie is sitting in seat 32A feeling bored.
